HEADLINE: After Sheff: An Rx for Schools

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
MEMBERS of a New Haven educational panel say resolution of issues raised by the Sheff v. O'Neill decision lies in promoting diversity and enhancing educational quality, and that neither can be accomplished without pursuing structural reform.
The panel, which was appointed by Mayor John DeStefano Jr., released a report last week that members said they hoped would contribute to improving education and reducing racial isolation in schools around the state. And, they emphasized, many of their proposals could be initiated without waiting for action by the General Assembly. 
 The Sheff v. O'Neill ruling from the State Supreme Court last summer also prompted Gov. John G. Rowland to appointed a state educational improvement panel (known as the Sheff panel) to make recommendations on how to remedy the inequalities among urban and suburban public schools. (The Governor's panel must submit its recommendations to the General Assembly by Jan. 22).
In looking at the underlying reasons for segregation, the New Haven group "took a more global approach" than the Sheff panel, said the group's chairman, the New Haven Superintendent of Schools, Reginald Mayo.
The president of the Greater New Haven N.A.A.C.P., Roger Vann, was chairman of the committee on structural reform, which called for affordable housing, for more jobs and economic development, and for property tax reform and other changes in the way public education is financed. Mayor DeStefano, one of the state's most outspoken advocates of property tax reform, noted that a recent survey of state residents indicates a preference for a cut in the property tax over a cut in the income tax or gasoline tax.
"Severe disparities in property tax rates are driving people of means out of urban areas and exacerbating racial and economic segregation," says the report. It calls for a "property tax circuit breaker" that would allow people to deduct "excessive" property tax payments from their income taxes. (The report did not define excessive.)
The structural reform committee's report also calls for increasing state payments to municipalities in lieu of taxes for tax-exempt property or for revising the mandated exemption laws. And the committee calls for leveling the playing field in terms of per-pupil expenditures, which now vary by hundreds of dollars between the poorest and richest districts.
"There are many ways the state can help us achieve equity," said Mr. Vann. While the panel did not endorse any specific plan, he said one idea that was discussed was repealing the "hold harmless" provision in the current funding law that allows the 20 wealthiest school districts in the state to receive money for education, even though they do not meet the funding formula.
If that money -- $40 million -- were transferred to the 20 poorest districts, he said, it could be used for "targeted purposes such as improving the staff-pupil ratio, enhancing technology or expanding staff development." Mr. Vann added that though the issue has been discussed by the General Assembly several times in recent years, no action has been taken. Now, he said, "the Sheff decision might give it some impetus."
The 31 people appointed to the New Haven advisory group included teachers, administrators, members of boards of education, superintendents of schools, education-related organizations, community leaders, business people, New Haven aldermen and women, city administrators, parents and students. Most are from New Haven, but a third are from surrounding towns.
When Lynne Lieb, a member of the Amity Regional 5 (Woodbridge, Bethany and Orange) school board heard the panel was forming, she promptly invited herself onto it.
"We in the suburbs have tremendous advantages that we reap by living close to New Haven," she said, "and I think it should be more of a mutual relationship than it is. I have been very impressed with New Haven's magnet schools. I know people are concerned about local control, but if we think about local control in a larger sense, I think we can enrich each other's lives. I believe you can't have quality education without integrated education."
The president of the New Haven Federation of Teachers, Frank Carrano, was chairman of the committee on promoting diversity. Among its recommendations, he said, "the most important is that all school districts should provide space for students from other communities, but it should be a two-way effort, not just city kids going to the suburbs." (Last week, the Sheff panel came out with a similar proposal for open enrollment, but it assumed the movement would be virtually all from the cities into the suburbs, thus creating a potential for overcrowded suburban districts.)
The superintendent of the Woodbridge schools and an advisory group member, Peter Madonia, endorsed the concept of open enrollment. "It deserves to be tested," he said. Mr. Madonia also said that to achieve school choice "there must be both a long-term state commitment of dollars and protection against disenfranchising students in both urban and suburban communities." At issue, he added, is not just school space but also conditions like class size.
The open enrollment issue caused another suburban school superintendent, Bruce Storm of Branford, to leave the advisory group. Mr. Storm said that he supported everything in the report, but that some of it would be hard to sell to his community. . He said he recalled "some pretty awful things being said" in the suburbs during earlier attempts to bring about voluntary regional desegregation and forecast "some serious political backlash" but said he assumed that "a lot of these things" are going to be mandated by the legislature, and that he was "just going to do them."
Mr. Carrano's committee also recommended pre-school programs statewide, regional magnet schools and schools connected with large places of employment, so parents could take their children to a school near where they work. Since workplaces are more diverse than schools, this would enhance educational diversity. The committee also recommended exploring the establishment of two-way bilingual programs, so that being fluent in a language besides English becomes an asset.
The committee on enhancing educational quality, headed by Dr. Rod Lane of Southern Connecticut State University, recommended establishing statewide standards in curriculum, technology, professional development, parental involvement and diversity. Improving teacher education, limiting class size to 20, providing paid in-service training and improved public relations were also recommended. "I learned how many successful programs exist in the New Haven schools," said Dr. Lane, "but they don't get publicity."
The report specifically disavows publicly financed vouchers for private schools, saying "it would distract from the real business of diversifying and improving our public schools and communities."
Mayor DeStefano insists that the panel he convened should be seen as complementary to, not in competition with, the statewide Sheff panel. The report, which includes no specific price tag but whose recommendations would cost millions of dollars to implement, is being forwarded to the Governor and to the General Assembly for consideration. The Mayor pointed out that with all the talk of a tax cut -- whether property tax, income tax or gas tax -- money could be made available to improve education.
Advisory group member Patricia McCann-Vissepo, chairwoman of New Haven's board of education, said, "I don't think the legislature on its own is overwhelmingly motivated to do anything about this issue, so there has to be pressure from as many sides as possible. A lot of people on the panel feel, 'Why should we wait for the legislature?' Things like more urban/suburban interchanges, more regional schools, a workplace magnet school, could be implemented without legislative action."

HEADLINE: Anchor Wars Around the State's TV Stations

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
FOR years, television watchers in Connecticut have been switching around the dial, following their favorite news anchors who have made their own switching around, from station to station, almost a way of life.
The dean of the wandering anchors is Pat Sheehan who over the past three decades has worked at public television in Hartford; at WTNH, Channel 8 (ABC) in New Haven; at WFSB, Channel 3 (CBS) in Hartford, and is now doing the nightly news at WTIC, Channel 61 (Fox) in Hartford. 
 Others are close behind in their perambulations.
Al Terzi, who was once Mr. Sheehan's second banana on Channel 3, left there to work in Florida but returned to Connecticut to Channel 8 and is now back at Channel 3. Janet Peckinpaugh went from Channel 8 to Channel 3 and is now at WVIT, Channel 30 (NBC) in New Britain. Gerry Brooks, who once worked in Hartford radio, went from Channel 3 to Channel 30.
Some of the comings and goings have been accompanied by little incidents that pointed up the intensity of the television news business.
For example, after Mr. Brooks, known as the cutup of the anchors, decided to vacate Channel 3 for Channel 30, a big flap ensued when he appeared in an advertisement on Channel 30 for the United Negro College Fund before his contract time at Channel 3 had run out, upsetting officials at 3. And mysteriously, his popular feature, "The Brooks File," did not travel intact with him to Channel 30. Along the way it became "The Brooks Report."
The length of tenure at each station has depended not only on negotiated contracts but also on the whims of management and marketing surveys on who out there is watching what station, and when. So the anchors tend to arrive, eventually depart, and sometimes return.
Basically, the watching public accepted the appearances and reappearances of the anchors as part of the strange and wonderful world of television. Besides, in a state as small as Connecticut and with cable in most homes, people could follow their favorite anchors by just hitting the remote control.
And through all its changes of anchors, the one constant in Connecticut television was that all the anchors seemed to like each other, smiled a lot, exchanged little pleasantries, or bromides, between news items in a formula that has become familiar from Connecticut to California. The image was of one big happy family, regardless of where the television news siblings were working at any one time. And then last month, that whole image crashed.
Janet Peckinpaugh filed a suit in Federal District Court in Hartford against Channel 3.
Ms. Peckinpaugh has become one of the best-known women in the state through her work as a prime-time news anchor for 10 years, first at Channel 8 and then at Channel 3. She left the latter in 1994 and for the past year has been working part-time at Channel 30, in the lower-paying early morning time slot.
In her suit, she says that her fortunes fell at Channel 3 when the station decided to hire Al Terzi away from Channel 8. It seems Mr. Terzi did not want to work with her. The reason, she maintains, is that in 1987 when she and Mr. Terzi were working as lead anchors at Channel 8, Mr. Terzi attempted to attack her sexually in a New Haven hotel where both were participating in a charity telethon. She says that she told a lot of people about it, including station personnel. Shortly after, she left the station and went to Channel 3.
Now, according to her suit, she wants her old anchor job back at Channel 3 and damages.
Mr. Terzi has denied Ms. Peckinpaugh's allegation and Channel 3 management has issued a statement that anchor changes at the station are based on economic factors and audience research.
The filing of the suit turned out to be a major news story in the state and radio talk shows took up the topic, with plenty of people waiting on the phone lines to voice support for one party or another.
To many observers, this kind of response might be considered a bit bizarre since most of the callers had never actually met either Ms. Peckinpaugh or Mr. Terzi. But to people who follow the television business the outpouring of sentiment was no surprise.
"Television is a very visual medium," said Maureen Croteau, head of the journalism department at the University of Connecticut. "It's much more personalized than print. You can read a newspaper column for years but know little or nothing about the columnist. But in television there's a myth of contact. You feel you do know these people."
Ms. Croteau isn't very happy with what she calls "the cult of the cute" in television in which news anchors engage in little witticisms with each other, with the weather forecaster and with the sports reporter as part of the presentation of the news. She thinks it demeans listeners, if not the anchors themselves. "It's gotten out of hand. They underestimate the viewers and it's not necessarily something everyone likes.
In general, she added, television news is a tough industry, "with everyone having to be young and beautiful." "People don't stay in for the long term. Look at TV news and how many people are nearing retirement age." It was not a question.
She does not know, she said, why anchors seem to remain so long in Connecticut, at one station or another, except that Connecticut is considered a good place to work, and they get good money for an area that is not considered one of the major markets in the country.
Al Primo, the head of Primo News Service in Greenwich, agrees. "An anchor team is critical to the success of a station and you don't have to be in a major city to make big money today," he said. "Even though Connecticut is considered the 24th or 25th market in the country, anchors can make $250,000 to $400,000 a year now. I'm sure Al Terzi makes $350,000 a year."
Mr. Primo's company advises television stations on how to present the news. In fact, he said, he was the inventor of what is known as the Eyewitness News Program in which news anchors interact with one another in "a credible, interpersonal relationship." That was three decades ago, he said, at Channel 7 in New York when he added a second anchor to the newscast and Channel 7 quickly rose from third to first in the ratings. Eyewitness News is the same system that Ms. Croteau thinks has gotten out of hand.
Mr. Primo agrees that television anchors are some of the best-known people in today's culture. "These are the people you bring into your home by turning on a television set," he said. "They become icons in your life. They have celebrity status. When I go to lunch or dinner with them they're beseeched for autographs. They're the movie stars of today."
He is not happy about the latest development involving two of the celebrities. "My position is that such a serious matter should be tried in court, not on tabloid news shows or in newspaper columns," he said.
At the television stations, calls are not being returned by the celebrities, lest they be quoted on the Peckinpaugh suit.
One anchor, who said he very much wished to remain anonymous, summed it up: "What a mess. I'm glad I'm out of that."
The one person who does return calls is Janet Peckinpaugh.
She won't talk about the suit on advice of her lawyer, but about other things, sure.
Why has she remained in Connecticut, even though the last two years can't have been much fun?
"I made a conscious decision to stay here," she said. "I've loved Connecticut ever since I first came here. I grew up in the Midwest and I worked in radio in Washington and in television in Richmond, Va., for six years. But I never felt I belonged and I always had one bag packed." She laughed. "Now I can't move," she said. She has a lawsuit going.

HEADLINE: Controlling Pollution, But at What Price?

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
LOOK across the Hudson River from either shore and what do you see on many days? An orange-brown haze lurking over the landscape, which environmentalists claim is payment for the sins of the past and some business and government leaders call progress.
While environmentalists wag fingers at incinerators, increased vehicular traffic and smokestacks in the Midwest, many businesses counter that pollution is sometimes simply the unavoidable byproduct of economic growth. 
 Since the Federal Government announced on Nov. 27 its latest assault on smog and soot -- technically referred to as ground-level ozone and particulates -- the national and local debate over air quality has greatly intensified.
In places like Westchester, which are already classified by the Environmental Protection Agency as Severe II Non-Attainment Zones for ozone, such a debate often centers around matters of life and death.
Citing pressing public health concerns, Carol Browner, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has proposed tougher regulations, which could force localities and businesses to find costly new ways to control smog and average Americans to make significant changes in the way they live.
Nationally, lobbying groups representing industry and some governors and mayors described Ms. Browner's proposals as Draconian and predicted costly changes for businesses, mandatory car pooling and restrictions on pleasure boats, lawn mowers and even outdoor barbecues. Gasoline prices could also increase.
Locally, reaction to the administrator's recommendations was diverse. While some business leaders dug in their heels and prepared to fight, Westchester government officials, though wary, said they would cooperate, despite the anticipated added costs.
Meanwhile, environmental groups applauded Ms. Browner's latest move but called for even stricter measures. And medical experts nodded their heads in agreement with the newest body of statistics linking airborne pollution with the growing death rate from respiratory diseases.
The proposed rules would tighten pollution limits, which many cities are already failing to meet, and for the first time the rules would apply to tiny particulates in the air.
The agency's statistics show that controlling smog and soot would prevent an estimated 40,000 premature deaths each year and reduce serious respiratory problems in children by about 250,000 cases annually.
The Clean Air Act of 1970, strengthened by President Jimmy Carter in 1977 and President George Bush in 1990, resulted in cleaner cars, fuel and power plants. And while the country's air quality has improved 30 percent since 1970, results of research linking ozone and particulates to increased respiratory ailments had not been forthcoming, despite promises by the Government.
The data was finally released and new standards proposed in the wake of a Federal court order stemming from a 1993 lawsuit against the Government by the American Lung Association.
Some 185 ozone-related studies on humans have shown harmful effects from ozone at current standards, including more than 1.5 million incidences a year of significant respiratory problems, like loss of lung capacity and exacerbation of both childhood and adult asthma.
In 1990, the Environmental Protection Agency mandated that businesses with 100 or more employees reduce commuter traffic by paying workers to take mass transportation or buying vans to transport them, among other things.
But after an extensive lobbying effort -- led by the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce -- the United States Congress and New York State agreed that employee commuter programs should be voluntary.
"Onerous" was the word Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive officer of the county chamber, used to describe the 1990 regulations. This time around, he said, "We're still vigilant, but open minded."
The Government has acknowledged that carrying out the new rules could cost local governments and businesses up to $8.5 billion a year.
At Ziereck Manufacturing, a small company in Mount Kisco, which joined the lobbying movement two years ago, Gretchen Ziereck, secretary of the corporation, said, "We fought the regulations before, and if necessary, we'll fight them again."
Another concern, Refined Sugars in Yonkers, however, voluntarily complied with the program. It did so with great difficulty, Joseph L. D'Angelo, the office manager, said. Many workers at the company rotate shifts, and forming car pools was not easy, he said.
Ms. Ziereck, Mr. D'Angelo and other business owners continue to believe that they are being unfairly singled out and that the Federal Government should go after other sources of pollution, including airborne pollution originating in the Midwest.
"Why doesn't the Government look at smokestacks or diesel trucks and buses?" Ms. Ziereck said. "Why don't they get older cars off the road? How about more effective vehicle inspections? Just stop unfairly picking on small companies like us."
At the county's Department of Transportation, Commissioner Joseph J. Petrocelli predicted that the steps Westchester had already taken to reduce pollution from vehicular traffic would stand it in good stead in the next round of environmental upgrades.
The county provides shuttle service to and from the White Plains train station and industrial parks along Interstate 287. It has also been commended by Metropool, Inc., a nonprofit ride-sharing agency in Stamford, for developing a commuter-options plan.
In addition, Mr. Petrocelli observed, Westchester has 43 commuter railroad stations served by three rail lines and the second-largest public bus system in the state.
"Economic development and clean air really can go hand in hand," the Commissioner said, "particularly when you have a good transportation network already in place."
The Regional Plan Association in Manhattan, a nonprofit planning agency, has prescribed a $21 billion, 25-year transit plan, which would connect the Long Island Railroad, Metro-North, New Jersey Transit and New York City's subway system to encourage more reliance on mass transit.
Jeffrey Zupan, a senior fellow for transportation at the association, said that mass transit, electric vehicles and "a series of measures like more flex time at work and more telecommuting" could significantly reduce air-borne pollution generated by heavy commuter traffic.
In another branch of county government, Westchester's Director of Environmental Planning, Gina D'Agrosa, said she, too, was ready to comply with the regulations. The Planning Department's focus would be on particulate matter generated by three public incinerators at sewage treatment plants in Ossining, Port Chester and New Rochelle. If the county did not comply, it would risk losing Federal funds, she said.
The Environmental Protection Agency's latest recommendations would require communities to cut ozone levels by one-third to 0.08 parts per million cubic feet of air from 0.12 parts per million and would regulate tiny particles of dust down to 2.5 microns in diameter.
Westchester is in compliance with current standards for particles, but Manhattan is not, said Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the Environmental Protection Agency. It is not known, however, whether the county meets the proposed new standards.
Maureen M. Morgan, former president of the Federated Conservationists of Westchester, an umbrella group, said she was pleased that the Government had finally taken the next step, especially since it missed a 1992 deadline to upgrade air-quality standards.
"Everyone keeps thinking they can avoid the really tough choices, but we can't anymore," she said. "We all have to figure out a better way."
But Marian H. Rose, chairwoman of the Lower Hudson Group of the Sierra Club and its New England Regional Conservation Committee, said: "Business is complaining that the new regulations are too strict. I think they don't go far enough. They should be even tougher."
Meanwhile, Westchester's Acting Health Commissioner, Dr. Howard N. Adel, and the Chief of Pediatric Pulmonology at New York Medical College and the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, Dr. Allen J. Dozor, said they were grateful that at least some of the health hazards from pollution would be mitigated.
Dr. Dozor said that pollution-induced asthma is the No. 1 reason for childhood emergency-room visits and hospitalizations.
"When the air quality is lousy, my phone rings off the hook," he said. "Kids are coughing, wheezing, short of breath. There's a long list of problems."
Health experts say that the smallest particles of polluted material cause the most trouble because they can lodge deep within the lungs, and children are considered particularly susceptible.
The incidence of pediatric asthma -- Dr. Dozor sees about 5,000 cases a year -- is greatest in Yonkers, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle, the Westchester cities closest to Manhattan.
Although the county does not collect data for the incidence of asthma in the population at large, Dr. Adel at the County Health Department said, "Westchester undoubtedly suffers its share of the consequences of pollution."
The Environmental Protection Agency is seeking comments from the public before a Feb. 18 deadline. The person to contact in New York is Mary Helen Cervantes-Gross at (212) 637-4440.
The new standards are scheduled to be issued in their final form in June. Key Republican members of Congress, however, have indicated they intend to veto the new air standards under a 1996 law that gives them authority to review major Federal regulations.

HEADLINE: Can Poetry Provide An Economic Lift?

BYLINE: By LEONARD FELSON 

 BODY:
THE Windham area of eastern Connecticut, once a thriving textile center, has struggled for decades ever since the mills closed and moved South. Now it is in the midst of a revival, but it's not an industrial one. It's poetic, literally, although organizers hope it also will provide an economic boost to the region.
The Windham Area Poetry Project, a six-month effort that culminates in April, may be unlike the average poetry festival, for this one is attempting to reach residents, institutions and businesses that normally don't make poetry part of their lives. 
 There are 10 contests so far planned (with 15 more to be announced in the months ahead), with prizes lined up. Espirit Travel, for example, a local travel agency, will give a $50 certificate to the person who writes the best poem on travel; the Willimantic Food Co-op is giving a $25 gift certificate to best poem on food.
There will be poetry on public transit lines, a poetry slam at the Windham Boxing Club and Youth Development Organization, and an anthology of ordinary citizens' poetry to be published under the title "The Heroes of Daily Life."
"We hope this project contributes toward bringing the community together and getting people to cross boundaries that a lot of times they don't," said Alexander Taylor, a director of Curbstone Press, a Willimantic nonprofit publishing company that is one of the project sponsors.
Organizers are hoping that as the festival draws people to the area, they will shop in local stores and dine at area restaurants, and that the festival will become an annual event not only growing each year but also becoming something of a drawing card for tourists.
At its core, though, the poetry project is no more ambitious than to open the doors for people who normally don't read or appreciate poems. "Our objective is to let people know the enjoyment of poetry does not require a critical approach. It relates to all aspects of life," said Judith Doyle, the other director of Curbstone Press. "Poetry," she said, quoting the poet Roque Dalton, "like bread, is for everyone."
"You don't have to have a Ph.D to appreciate poetry. People say they don't understand poetry, that they aren't able to listen to poetry the way they listen to music," she said. To address that issue, the poetry project will reach out to settings beyond the academic. In Windham public schools, another sponsor of the project, the high school library is developing a poetry center, collecting contemporary poetry, including many books in Spanish, being donated from different presses around the country. More than 130 books have been received.
The high school sponsored a poetry workshop for all teachers in the fall, just as the festival was getting underway.
In the larger community, posters donated by the Streetfare Journal in San Francisco are glued to buses with this poem by the San Francisco poet George Evans:
That night we drank warm whisky,
In our parked car beyond woods now lost to the suburbs,
I fell in love with you.
Posters of illustrated poems also are hanging at the Willimantic Food Co-op and the Main Street Cafe, and other businesses are being encouraged to integrate poetry into the workaday world.
Most of the poetry events will be bilingual, free and open to the public. Poets who will be participating include Jack Agueros and the state's poet laureate, Leo Connellan, as well as Martin Espada, Gray Jacobik, Marilyn Nelson, Cheryl Savageau and Tino Villanueva.
Besides the travel and food contests, others will come from the University of Connecticut Book Co-op in Storrs for the best poem on reading, Paradise Cafe for one on diversity, the Mansfield chapter of the World Federalists for one on the idea of One World, the Storrs Friends Meeting for one on nonviolent reconciliation and Curbstone Press for one on work.
Elderly people will be eligible for a poetry contest. There also will be a contest for the best Spanish poem, the best poem on the subject of play and pets and one for the best religious poem.
The festival will culminate with "Poetry in the Park" in Jillson Square in Willimantic on the last weekend in April. Aside from poets, there will be storytellers and face painters to entertain children, and a book and arts fair.
Major funding for the poetry project came from the Connecticut Commission on the Arts as well as several other local foundations and businesses.
Mr. Taylor, who also teaches poetry at Eastern, said the festival should not be viewed as a frill. "Writing poetry in its proper context builds self-confidence in people and develops their problem-solving faculties," he said. "This is why M.I.T. encourages the study of arts for engineers."

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: John Feingold;
A Protector of Land Lists Ways to Save It

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
JOHN FEINGOLD, executive director of the Westchester Land Trust, says his interest in protecting the environment had its roots in his childhood when he saw firsthand the pollution of Long Island Sound and the disappearance of creeks and marshlands.
Today, Mr. Feingold, a resident of Pound Ridge, like many in the environmental field, believes things are better than what they were back then, but he also feels that more must be done. 
 The Westchester Land Trust is a nonprofit, countywide organization formed in 1988 and based in Bedford Hills. Its core mission is to preserve land. It does this, Mr. Feingold said, the quiet way -- not by confrontation but by persuasion and education. It has about 2,000 members. The number to call for information about the Land Trust's activities is 241-6346.
Mr. Feingold has more than 20 years' experience in the field of land protection and conservation. Before coming to the Land Trust in August 1995, he served as the New York director of the Regional Plan Association, overseeing environmental and land use initiatives in the state and New York City.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him:
Q. Do you think it is better for the environmental movement if its activists are idealistic or should they be pragmatic and understand the economic issues as well? Which way will yield better results?
A. You've got to go in as an idealist with your eyes opened. It's very important for us as citizens to envision the kind of future that we want to have -- and then be pragmatic about getting that.
Q. Over the years some in the environmental movement have been criticized for not understanding the economic issues that environmental protection cause.
A. There is a quiet side to the environmental movement. I would say the Westchester Land Trust is right there, working with the establishment and citizens of the communities to envision what the future might be. I think it's important to say that the Westchester Land Trust is not a confrontational advocacy organization. We find that we are most effective when we are working with public officials and the private landowners and other organizations to identify the places that really need to be preserved and to work with a laser-like focus to preserve those specific places.
In some cases that means that we work with developers to insure that development is better than perhaps originally proposed. We do, however, feel it is very important -- this is our major goal -- to be in front of the curve, to be identifying and working with major landowners before the development proposals come forth for them. Our feeling is that once the blueprint arrives at the planning board it's in many cases too late. There are a plethora of other organizations that pick up the mantle at that point and become litigious and the like.
Q. Educating people, then, is the way to change attitudes?
A. Yes. The trust has really had two major thrusts to its environmental-education programs: we have a series of lectures and conferences that are focused on adults, where we try to train adults about land conservation and some of the tools and techniques to achieve the preservation. And we have a school-based education program for kids. In conjunction with Purchase College, we have an accredited teacher-training program and we put on a dozen teacher-training workshops. This year we're working with about three dozen schools here in Westchester on the programs.
Q. Generally, are things better today for the environment than, say, a decade or two ago?
A. What I think we've seen over the last 25 or 30 years have been pretty dramatic improvements in environmental quality, in this country at least. Internationally, I think we have some creeping concerns about growth and development in third-world countries that need to be addressed.
In America, we've made terrific strides, but we've only addressed 20 to 25 percent of the environmental issues. And the remaining ones are going to be the difficult ones. Those have to do with issues of nonpoint-source water pollution. We have to address the issues of chemicals and fertilizers that run off into the waters.
Q. You were formerly with the Regional Plan Association, and regional planning is still controversial -- hard to achieve. Communities do not consult other communities about development. How do we overcome that?
A. As it has been stated, we need to think globally and act locally. Municipalities need to work together to achieve those shared goals and objectives.
As an example of the work that the Westchester Land Trust is doing on that basis, over the last several years we have focused on regional systems that cross municipal and state lines. Currently, we are working to preserve the water quality of the Titicus River and the Mianus watershed. To do so, we have helped forge compacts that cross state lines into Connecticut and involve towns and cities.
Q. What are the environmental issues for Westchester this year?
A. What we saw in '96 were at least two major actions: one was the agreement on the development of New York City watershed property and secondly the passage of the state's Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act. These were both things we worked very hard on during 1996. During 1997, we very much look forward to watershed-protection activities on the part of Westchester and New York City and new infrastructure investments, water-pollution controls and the protection of local drinking-water supplies through the bond act. We think these will be two major areas of activity that will just be hitting the ground during 1997, but they will have a real impact in Westchester.
Q. I understand that you work to protect -- or reclaim -- open space in some urban areas. What do you do?
A. The Westchester Land Trust is, in fact, one of the few environmental land conservation organizations in America that actually works in the inner cities, to create quality of life where it's lacking. For example, in southwest Yonkers, we're working in partnership with the Yonkers public schools to reclaim a derelict lot immediately adjacent to P.S. 18 as a neighborhood park and an outdoor environmental-education classroom. We have another program in Peekskill. These kinds of parcels are less than an acre in size, but from them we're able to create new urban environmental opportunities.
Q. You also deal with bigger parcels, don't you?
A. One of our major thrust areas in 1997 will be to focus on the pristine stream systems and the remaining big farms and the Hudson River habitat areas. Even where we have a relatively pristine stream there is development that is encroaching on it. This is the water that we drink and we rely on. We're focusing on trying to preserve this.
Q. How do you do that?
A. We work with individual landowners who have made donations of land or what we call "conservation easements" to the Land Trust.
Q. What is that?
A. It's essentially a perpetual agreement between a landowner and the Westchester Land Trust, with legal standing. It allows the land to remain in private ownership. However, the conservation values of the land are preserved. Generally, conservation easements prohibit any further development or subdivision of the land.
Q. Does the county have many such agreements?
A. We have 23 conservation easements throughout Westchester, ranging from Yonkers to Lewisboro. We are in the process now of negotiating or finalizing terms of conservation easements or the outright donation of land involving more than 1,800 acres throughout Westchester in places like Purchase and Ossining, Pound Ridge and elsewhere.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Office Space Market Coming to Life in Lake Success

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
THE turnaround of the office market in Lake Success, where the vacancy rate is now 12.4 percent, very much reflects the vitality of the broader Long Island commercial market. The Island's 13.4 overall vacancy rate is the lowest since the 12.7 percent rate in 1988.
Large blocks of space are hard to find in Lake Success, institutional investments are flowing in, renovations are a driving force and major new construction -- in the form of a pre-leased, build-to-suit project -- is possibly in the offing. 
 Building upgrades are still the leading source of new office development, illustrated by capital improvements costing $13 million that are under way at 1981 and at 1983 Marcus Avenue.
The two buildings, which total 660,000 square feet, were acquired earlier this year by Matterhorn One, a real estate investment fund managed by Canyon Partners of Beverly Hills, Calif.
Matterhorn purchased the mortgages as part of a package of assets from GE Capital Corporation of Stamford, Conn., and then foreclosed on the loans, which were in default, taking title in February.
"Value and the growth of the economy on Long Island is very positive, and the demographics are exceptional," said K. Robert Turner, managing partner of Canyon. The money-management firm's real estate funds are active investors on Long Island, he said.
Matterhorn, which is calling the two-building complex Gateway at Lake Success, has begun an improvement program that includes renovating the lobby and exterior areas, upgrading the cooling and heating systems, improving landscaping and signage, and upgrading parking.
As a result, new leases and lease renewals have been signed on 220,000 square feet of space in the two buildings, said Herb S. Agin, president of Sutton & Edwards, a commercial brokerage in Lake Success, which is handling the leasing for Matterhorn. Vacancies in both buildings have dropped from almost 20 percent to less than 10 percent, he said.
Last month, for example, the Greenpoint Financial Corporation of Manhattan began moving its consumer banking and mortgage operations into 105,000 square feet at 1981 Marcus Avenue, after leaving space it occupied in Flushing, Queens. There will be 600 employees at the Lake Success site.
The build-to-suit project proposed in Lake Success is for a 6.5-acre vacant site on Marcus Avenue, which was also acquired through a foreclosure, in this case by Mutual of New York, a Manhattan insurance company.
"Long Island has slowly improved over the last few years to the point that the next large tenant coming along will probably require someone to build a building," said Lawrence R. Botel, a vice president with ARES Realty Capital in Stamford. ARES is a subsidiary of Mutual of New York and its real estate portfolio manager.
AT least half the proposed 250,000-square-foot building would have to be pre-leased before construction could start, Mr. Botel said. To be called the Centre at Lake Success, the building already has a preliminary design by Peter K. Toh, a partner at the Spector Group of North Hills. It would have three floors of offices with setbacks for terraces, a day-care center, a cafeteria, and underground parking for 800 cars.
The two Matterhorn buildings, as well as the vacant lot owned by Mutual of New York, are in what was once called the Triad Office Park. The once thriving office center fell on hard times during the recent recession, illustrating how quickly fortunes can fall during a market downturn.
But Triad's problems were typical of problems encountered by many developers, said Mr. Agin of Sutton & Edwards.
Although the desirable Lake Success location helped keep vacancies fairly low during the recession, when leases came up for renewal tenants who had been paying annual rents of $25 a foot and up were signing renewals for $20 a foot, which was not enough to pay the owners' debt service, he said.
The goal of the original development group, which was composed of different partnerships with Irving Feldman of Lake Success as the general partner, was to build six buildings totaling 1.7 million square feet on 48 acres between Marcus Avenue and Union Turnpike, he said. The first building was completed in 1979.
Four more followed, with the 310,000-square-foot 1985 Marcus Avenue purchased in 1982 by the Chase Manhattan Bank Corporation, which occupies it.
In addition to the two buildings now owned by Matterhorn, another structure in the complex was also lost through foreclosure: the 220,000-square-foot 2001 Marcus Avenue, which was taken over by its lender, the Equitable Life Assurance Society in Manhattan, in 1995. It is still owned by the insurance company and is leased out to multiple tenants. The remaining building, the 350,000-square-foot 1979 Marcus Avenue, is still owned by a Feldman partnership, but an outstanding mortgage of more than $50 million, on which there also is a default, was discounted and sold by the lender, Bankers Trust Company of Manhattan, to a group of investors that includes Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, a real estate investment trust.
The investors expect to take title to the building in 1998 following foreclosure proceedings. Reckson, which purchased about a 70 percent share of the outstanding nonperforming loan, is taking an active role in the building's management.
According to Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island, based in Melville, the overall vacancy rate in Nassau at the end of the fourth quarter was 13.5 percent, a drop from 15.8 percent a year earlier. In Suffolk over the same period, vacancies dropped from 16.3 percent to 13.1 percent.
The Melville-Route 110 area, where vacancies were 17.6 percent a year ago and are now 10.5 percent, has become "incredibly hot," said Kevin P. Welsh, senior vice president of CB Commercial/Hampshire of Hackensack, N.J. The brokerage, which has two Long Island offices, is handling leasing at the 177,900-square-foot 538 Broadhollow Road in Melville, which is owned by a subsidiary of the New York Life Insurance Company.
The building, once occupied by the Grumman Corporation, which moved out in 1991, is undergoing $750,000 in capital improvements. CNA Insurance moved into 20,000 square feet in May, and Hewlett-Packard moved into 21,000 square feet last month, Mr. Welsh said. And negotiations with a California-based insurance company, which wants 50,000 square feet, are now being finalized, he added.
"The market has been turning around for a year and a half, but activity now is accelerating," said Theodore P. Sasso, senior managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company of Long Island in Syosset, a newly opened branch of the Manhattan brokerage.
"We're generating jobs again and we are getting them in diverse businesses with the high-tech industry continuing to grow," he said.
"We have become a market leader in software, the biotech industry is growing, and we are doing very well with financial services, of which Greenpoint, which Edward S. Gordon represented, is an example," he added.
Long Island has now regained two-thirds of the jobs that were lost during the 1989 to 1992 recession, said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a business group, and also a consultant to the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
BARRING a major selloff in the financial markets, she said, 1997 should see further growth, with the creation of between 10,000 and 15,000 new jobs.
But the improving economy has not yet translated into new speculative construction, in which buildings are built without lease commitments.
"You won't see a speculative building going up for a long time," said William T. Yorio, a managing director at Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island. "What you will see is a building started based on a majority of commitment to space."
For any kind of speculative construction to take place, rents would have to increase significantly from their current levels, said Paul F. Amoruso, president of Oxford & Simpson, commercial brokers in Jericho. "We've had absorption without a lot of rent increase," he said.
A developer would need a rental of $30 a square foot to justify the cost of new construction on a speculative basis, Mr. Amoruso noted, adding that rents in Nassau are still $22 to $24 a square foot and in Suffolk they are $20 to $22 a foot.
Scott Rechler, chief operating officer at Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, which owns a 35-acre parcel in Melville on which it could build 500,000 square feet, said he does not foresee the start of speculative construction for another two to four years. Before it starts, he said, rents would have to increase 25 percent over what they are today.
But that will happen, he added. "Good quality office space is drying up," he said, "and if tenants want to find locations they want to be in they will have to start paying more."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Wall Street's Boom Echoed in Fairfield Housing

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
A SURGE in speculative building of multimillion-dollar homes in Fairfield County is being attributed by realtors, architects and builders to good times in lower Manhattan. The Wall Street boom has led home builders for the first time since the roaring 1980's to put up houses of at least 7,500 square feet with four-car garages and swimming pools in advance of finding buyers.
The number of homes under construction countywide in the $2-million to $6-million range has been growing for the last year. Each of the Gold Coast towns of Greenwich, Darien, New Canaan, Westport, Wilton and Weston report from 2 to 12 such luxury homes currently near completion or finished, on the market or sold, with more on the drawing boards. Buyers are widely identified as Wall Streeters bearing the fruits of a bull market. 
 Michael Hobbs, a New Canaan builder of $5-million and $6-million homes, said that "10,000 square feet is not a large house anymore, and you don't see some grizzled old guy coming in who spent all his life working to afford it -- you see a young guy who made it big on Wall Street and wants to enjoy it."
Mark Finlay, a Fairfield architect whose 10,000-square-foot houses in New Canaan, Greenwich and Darien sell for $3 million and up, said: "Our clients are youngish Wall Streeters and a percentage of celebrities. There is lots of money for wine cellars, guest quarters and billiard rooms. We are lined up six months in advance.
"People are building classic homes, not what they built in the 80's. They have all the bells and whistles, but the materials are the real thing and the architecture is timeless."
The Mayfair Construction Group in Greenwich is completing an 8,000-square-foot house in American Shingle style -- a homey, middle-class look from early in this century that in today's luxurious reincarnation is the rage. The house, on 4.6 acres with a pool off Round Hill Road in Greenwich's legendary back country, is for sale at $5.9 million. "It's a real family house," said Timothy Ryan, Mayfair's owner, "with a turn-of-the-century feeling."
In an era when a full-time domestic staff exists only in reruns of "Upstairs, Downstairs," the kitchen has again become the heart of the house, as it was in poor families for centuries, but with two dishwashers, commercial-grade stoves, refrigerators with sub-zero freezing capacity, polished granite counters and elegant woodwork.
Richard Girouard, a custom-home builder in upstate Farmington and Avon, began building in New Canaan last year. "When my banker at the American Bank in Waterbury suggested I look into this market, I could see that it was heating up because of expansion in Stamford," he said. As with most builders of expensive homes, his is a small, compact operation.
AFTER 22 years in the business, he has learned how to put up a house in less time than the one-year average that he saw in Fairfield County "and with better quality," he said. "I have the same work force for all my houses," Mr. Girouard said. "I keep the crews busy going from house to house so that there is no lag time."
Last year, he bought eight lots of a former New Canaan estate called Stoneleigh from an investor who had bought it from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The first three homes of 7,500 square feet, priced at $2.5 million on two-acre lots, were begun on speculation and sold while under construction.
Dr. Gary Cook, chief executive of Witco, a chemical corporation in Greenwich, and his wife, Brenda, bought one that is nearing completion. James Hall, an investment specialist with Swiss Bank, which is building a $145 million headquarters in Stamford, and his wife, Jennifer, bought the second house, and the third is in contract.
In addition to the Stoneleigh project, Mr. Girouard is building other houses on speculation in New Canaan. Some are as large as 6,500 square feet and priced from $1.2 million to $1.4 million on two- and four-acre lots. "One at Twin Ponds and one on Ponus Ridge were sold in the framing stage," he said. Two more have been started on Old Studio Road.
New Canaan is described by realtors and builders as the current hot spot for construction, an assessment borne out by its public school system. Additions under way at all three elementary schools will increase their capacity from 1,387 pupils to more than 1,800, and expansion plans for the middle school will go out to bid in May.
Stoneleigh appears to be the only high-priced subdivision of its size in the area. Most new construction consists of one or two houses on 8- and 10-acre parcels. It also falls into the half of new construction on vacant land, which can cost $750,000 to more than $1 million for a two-acre lot.
The other half involves demolishing older homes to make way for immense new ones. The practice has municipal officials considering new regulations limiting the square footage of buildings relative to the size of the lot. The longing for a grand country house -- English, Norman or Colonial -- can take its toll on the neighborhood.
In Darien, 17,000 square feet of a two-acre lot can be legally covered by a house, tennis court, pool, garage and other structures. "There is talk about adjusting it downward this year," said Ray Nurmi, the town planner.
"Scraping -- that's what they call tearing down and building new in England," said Dan Foley, New Canaan's planning director. "Most of the complaints we get are that houses people build to replace older ones are too big. The value is in the land, and so far what they are doing is legal."
Towns are also looking to protect what land is left. Plans are afoot in Greenwich, a town of 48 square miles, to set up a fund for the municipal acquisition of open space, including some of the scant 2,138 acres of vacant residential land available for development, according to Tom Baptist, the town's conservation director.
WHILE a segment of home buyers will probably always acquire their mansions the old-fashioned way -- by remodeling existing buildings, "busy young people don't want the hassle of redoing an older house," said Ruth LeBlanc-Jones, district manager of Coldwell Banker's new homes division based in New Canaan, whose office is handling sales at Stoneleigh.
"Once they see what it will cost in money, time and aggravation to rip out the plumbing, electrical and heating systems, make repairs and renovations, and still not get exactly what they want, they are better off investing in a new house," she said.
This resurgence of home building raises the specter of the 80's, when buyers fought bidding wars, running up prices to dizzying heights, only to find in the subsequent recession that their mortgages exceeded the resale value of their homes. High-fliers who bought multimillion-dollar homes for cash lost heavily on resales as well.
"I don't perceive this to be a market of the 80's," said Linda Hodge, a vice president at Preferred Properties in Greenwich, a real-estate company. "People then were buying high with the idea of selling higher a couple of years down the road."
Paul Hopper, a Greenwich architect, agreed. "In the 80's, a lot of homes were poorly constructed, overvalued and quickly outdated," he said. "Buyers today are demanding something that will hold its value."

American Shingle style, 8,000-square-foot house now nearing completion in the back country of Greenwich is for sale at $5.9 million. It is on 4.6 acres with a pool. HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
For 1996, Office-Building Sales Top $1 Billion

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH more capital available and its office market on an upswing, 1996 was a banner year for investor purchases of buildings in northern New Jersey, with more than $1 billion in sales. In the process the field of buyers grew, including several from out of state.
"Investors have seized upon office buildings because they are perceived as having the greatest potential return," said Andrew J. Merin, executive director of the financial services department at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage. While sales prices increased, they are still below replacement costs, he added. 
 Last year his concern reported that 28 buildings of 95,000 square feet or more, totaling 9.2 million square feet, were sold and 2.4 million more square feet in 8 buildings were under contract in the 11-county northern New Jersey market. That compares to 35 sales totaling 9.3 million square feet, purchased for $844 million in 1994 and 1995.
"Adding value is the name of the game today," said Geoffrey Schubert, senior vice president at the New Jersey offices of Koll, a national real estate firm. He said investors are buying on the theory that rents can be raised as the market continues to improve.
Local development companies continued to buy, often in partnership with large institutions. Among them were SJP Properties of Parsippany and Gale & Wentworth of Florham Park. But the dominant players were real estate investment trusts, led by Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford and joined by Reckson Associates Realty Corporation in Melville L.I.
Other out-of-state buyers included the Townsend Company of Towson, Md.; TA Associates Realty of Boston; K/B Realty Advisors with offices in Newport Beach, Calif., and Boston; and the Berwind Property Group of Philadelphia.
Prices rose to an average of $100 a square foot, up from $90 in 1995 and 1994, with Class A, mostly occupied buildings going for $150, according to Cushman & Wakefield. The rise did not scare off investors because rents also rose and the cost of buying a building was still 10 to 15 percent less than the cost of constructing one.
Many buildings trading hands are substantially leased and well located in tightening secondary markets. But the activity is spilling over to vacant or nearly vacant buildings and/or those in secondary locations in rebounding markets.
The strengthening office market is also stoking sales. Vacancy rates at year's end dipped 3 percentage points to 16.4 percent and average asking rents rose to $23.41 a square foot from $22.53, reported Cushman & Wakefield.
The lack of office-building construction also helped, as did the state's improving economy and job picture. New Jersey has regained 204,000 of the 262,000 jobs lost in the recession, according to state figures.
MOREOVER, capital for purchases is flowing in, mainly from institutional sources, including pension funds and real estate investment trusts. And the northern New Jersey market's size -- with 140 million square feet of space it is the sixth largest in the nation -- turned investors' eyes to New Jersey "as the current land of opportunity," said Mr. Schubert.
Cali Realty, for instance, purchased 15 buildings with a total of 3.3 million square feet of space at a total cost of $450 million. Its largest acquisition, and the biggest in the state, was the 1.9-million-square-foot Harborside Financial Center on the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City. Cali bought it for $282 million from US Pension Trust, a division of US West, a telecommunications company in Englewood, Colo.
Of the competition from other investors, Thomas A. Rizk, president and chief financial officer at Cali said: "While the investment community is recognizing New Jersey as a good market, we started buying two years ago, giving us a huge headstart." He said his concern would "acquire its fair share" of the $1 billion in purchases it is considering. But if prices get too high and the return is too slim, "we will not buy," he said, adding that "nothing is in the pipeline to change our rate of acquisition."
He said he was continuing to look for well-leased buildings with rents that were at or below the market and that could be raised. The company may expand into Philadelphia and New York State, he added.
Another big buyer was K/B Realty, which bought 1.6 million square feet of space. That includes the 600,000-square-foot Metropolitan Corporate Plaza in Woodbridge, purchased from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for $41.5 million.
"We're buying opportunistic properties, those that are 60 to 70 percent vacant and have upside potential," said Robert A. Provost, director of real estate acquisitions for the company, which invests on behalf of large pension funds.
"New Jersey is getting crowded," said Mr. Provost. But that will not "preclude us from looking in the state," as long as there continues to be upward pressure on rents, demand from tenants for space and little new construction, he added.
Among the local companies with a hearty appetite for space was Gale and Wentworth, which acquired 1.5 million square feet in 11 properties. The largest was its $25 million purchase of the 560,000-square-foot, mostly empty former I.B.M. complex in Franklin Lakes.
The firm focuses on such properties where value can be added. It buys with its own equity and that of institutions such as Morgan Stanley.
"There is a lot of capital chasing a few good deals," said Finn Wentworth, a principal, Still, he said his firm is reviewing sales, totaling 1 million square feet.
Meanwhile, Reckson entered the market with the $56 million purchase of 500,000 square feet of space in a four-building complex in West Orange and an office building in Montvale. Scott Rechler, its chief operating officer, said his company did so "after monitoring the market for a year and deciding there were enough opportunities available."
AS it has done in Westchester County, N.Y., and Stamford, Conn., Reckson bought the properties from entities associated with a local developer, Robert Heller, and set up a New Jersey division "giving us a local market presence" said Mr. Rechler.
"Our goal is to create value in real estate over the long term," he added. What makes northern New Jersey distinct, he said, is its size and leasing activity. He said his company expected to close on several more buildings, totaling up to 1 million square feet, in the first quarter of 1997.
Some investors, like the Townsend Company, feel the playing field is getting too crowded. The company, as it has done elsewhere, bought a mostly vacant, 660,000-square-foot, three-building complex in Franklin Township from Mutual Benefit Life Assurance Company at "below replacement cost," said Daniel C. Cramer, vice president at Townsend. He said his company then leased out all but 130,000 square feet at $17.50 to $20 a square foot, adding that rents had been "in the $16 range." Brokers say the price was $27 million, a figure Mr. Cramer would not confirm.
The company also bought a 738,000-square-foot office building in downtown Newark, where he also hopes to increase the rents.
"We caught the market just as it was rising," he said. "We had one good year but with the increasing competition and sale prices it's questionable whether we will get a second."
Analysts say the pace of buying will slow when the prices exceed replacement cost -- about $150 to $180 a square foot -- or rents rise high enough, about $25 to $30 a square foot, to spark new construction. Another factor that could slow buying is if the state's economy sputters and tenants put leasing decisions on hold.
But, they add, since none of those factors are on the near-term horizon purchases are to expected to continue for another 12 months. Still, the volume will decrease due to a lack of high quality buildings being marketed, said David Bernhaut, director of the Cushman & Wakefield Financial Services Department in the East Rutherford office.
"We see a step up in buildings that have been stabilized and will be made available for sale by owners, who are looking to take advantage of the strength of the capital market," he added.
That will draw more investor interest, likely producing "increasing prices and decreasing returns, only this time for Class B buildings," said Mr. Bernhaut.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk
