HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
An Old Word Is Back: Prosperity

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
ASK real-estate professionals what's on the horizon and their answers would have been unimaginable not so long ago: Speculative building of unsubsidized office towers in Manhattan for the first time since the 1980's. Conversion of older office buildings to hotels. Redevelopment of the retail spaces at Rockefeller Center. Finally, a decision on what to do with the New York Coliseum property at Columbus Circle.
These are events many real estate executives expect to happen this year, following what they say was the prosperity that finally returned to the market in full measure in 1996. 
 It was a year that saw vacancy rates in the most desirable midtown office buildings fall into the single digits for the first time since late 1994, and the Durst Organization all but complete leasing of its new building at the corner of Broadway and 42d Street before demolition of the old structures on the site was finished. The price of existing properties rose as well, with prime buildings selling at over $200 a square foot, which is double the level of just a few years ago.
In the retail area, Mickey Mouse and the Disney Company opened on the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street, making it clear that the long-awaited redevelopment of the Times Square area was really going to happen. Warner Brothers expanded and Niketown joined it, along with Tiffany and Chanel, on 57th Street, providing destinations for local shoppers and the tourists who continued to crowd the city's streets right through the end of the year.
"Popular culture is what's driving the city today, not the financial institutions of the past," said James A. Austrian, president of Austrian Shapiro & Partners, a real estate consulting company in New York. "Not many people are visiting Wall Street these days, but they are visiting Times Square and shopping at Disney and Warner and packing into theme restaurants. It's all related to entertainment."
Hotels were jammed almost to capacity, with room rates up sharply. Retailers benefited as well, with luxury companies establishing themselves uptown, while some big-box stores, notably Kmart, on 34th Street and at Astor Place, opening despite a political row between the Mayor and the City Council over whether they should be permitted in other areas of the city.
Office leasing, one of the primary engines that drive the New York economy, was brisk in the prime areas of midtown, although some brokers cautioned that much of the activity was from tenants seeking to upgrade their space or location, rather than economic growth or an influx of companies.
"There has been a lot of lateral movement in the midtown Manhattan market," said James S. Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners. He said that large numbers of tenants in less desirable Class B buildings had moved to Class A properties.
The result was to diminish the supply of Class A space available, increasing the pressure to commence new construction.
The availability of Class A space in midtown declined to 8.85 percent last month, compared with 10.4 percent in December 1995, according to RE/Locate, a real-estate information concern.
"There was a real energy in the market in 1996," said Mary Ann Tighe, a broker with the Edward S. Gordon Company. "There was a sense among customers that opportunities would disappear if they did not act quickly. In fact we saw something we had not seen in a long time: tenants competing for space."
Rents did not increase markedly -- rising to an average of $40.05 a square foot for Class A buildings in midtown in December, compared with $39.70 in the previous year, according to Re/Locate. However, brokers reported that landlords were offering less in free rent periods and other concessions. One estimated that the free rent period in midtown was down to about 6 months compared with 9 to 15 months in 1995.
Some market participants said the prosperity was not spread evenly, that the urge to upgrade had left owners of Class B buildings with increased amounts of vacated space. "It is a bifurcated market," said Ruth Colp-Haber, a partner in Wharton Property Advisors, a tenants' broker. "The best spaces in a market go first, but the B buildings in midtown are not participating in the boom."
Another cautionary note was sounded by Anthony E. Malkin, the president of W & M Properties, a company that owns and manages real estate. He noted that the Manhattan economy had generated just 25,000 net new jobs during the previous year and said that, in his view, much of the city's office -- as well as residential -- recovery had been driven by Wall Street, and especially such high-fee-generating activities as initial public offerings. "The I.P.O. market set a record in 1995, and 1996 blew that away," he said. "I have the sense that we are at the top of a very high pinnacle and if Wall Street hiccups the rest of us will get a bad case of indigestion."
Nevertheless, demand is strong enough so that combined Class A and B vacancy rates should be in single digits by the end of this year, said Darcy Stacom, an executive director at Cushman & Wakefield.
"That means we are getting close to new construction," she said. "The need is obvious; there are tenants available and financing is available."
In the meantime, upgrades of older buildings are the hot product on the market, said Jerry L. Cohen, vice chairman of Cushman & Wakefield. He said the rapid leasing of the former Metropolitan Life building at 11 Madison Avenue at 24th Street, where the telecommunications, elevators, electrical power and air-conditioning systems were completely retrofitted, is an example of how well this approach works.
"As brokers, it has been as if were have been selling used cars," he said. "Now we are in a new-car showroom."
 
Building Sales
 
Prices Rise to Levels Of the Mid-1980's
Another indicator of the strength of the market is the rapidly rising price of existing buildings, market participants say. "Last year brought us back to the levels of the mid-1980's," said Peter Hauspurg, chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a brokerage company specializing in sales. "I'm amazed at how quickly the office market has come back."
From a high of about $290 a square foot, the average value of Class A Manhattan office buildings fell to about $100 in 1993, he said. "Now it is back to about $200 a foot on average."
He said the ready availability of financing, particularly from Wall Street, was supporting the rise in prices. In addition, he said there were numerous transactions in which cheap debt was substituted for expensive equity, which had the effect of increasing the prices of the buildings involved. He said capital was currently available at 8 percent interest to replace funds with a 20 percent return.
Ms. Stacom said the availability of capital made possible deals that might not have been completed a few years ago. "I haven't added it all up yet," she said, "but I would not be surprised to find, if you include Rockefeller Center, that total sales in 1996 went over $4.5 billion, which is more than any time in the 1980's."
Ms. Stacom said she expected sales prices to keep rising until a new supply of prime space was announced. "In 1997 you are likely to see $300 a foot for trophy properties in midtown," she said.
There is one new building going up in midtown, of course, the 48-story, 1.6 million-square-foot tower being built by the Durst Organization. The project started last spring with Conde Nast, the publishing company, as the anchor tenant committed to lease 585,000 square feet of space.
In October, Douglas Durst, the president of the real-estate company, announced that the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom had agreed to leave its present location at Third Avenue and 56th Street and lease 660,000 square feet of space, virtually filling the office part of the structure.
Because of the building's location in the redeveloping Times Square area, it benefited from $10.7 million in city aid, and most real estate professionals said the project's economics would not have made sense without the assistance.
But with the continued strengthening of the market those economics are changing, market players say. "This is the year you will see the start of a nonsubsidized, speculative office building," Mr. Hauspurg said.
 
Retail
 
That's Entertainment: A Very Good Year
With the opening of the second Disney store in Manhattan, at the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue -- the first is at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street -- and a larger Warner Bros. Studio Store and a new Niketown on 57th Street, entertainment retail became firmly established in Manhattan.
"Good things happened in retail last year and Niketown and Warner Brothers helped add to the excitement," said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of Lansco Corporation. "But you also had Armani and Versace uptown and J. Crew in SoHo. The whole retail sector had a lot of energy and many of the stores have done quite well."
One pleasant surprise was the Borders Books and Music store in the World Trade Center, said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director of Edward S. Gordon Company. "The was the first store of that size in that part of Manhattan and it was assumed it would be a 9-to-5, five-day-a-week operation," he said. "But it's doing well at night and on weekends and that has got other retailers looking in the area."
He said rents for retail spaces were up 12 to 15 percent last year over 1995 levels.
"Last year was the best for retail leasing since 1980," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services, a New York brokerage specializing in retail leasing. "It helps that neighborhoods, like 14th Street and 34th Street, that were distressed are coming back with the help of their business improvement districts."
The biggest comeback of all is Times Square because it is the face the city projects to the world. "The transformation of Times Square is the most important urban renewal project since Lincoln Center in the 1960's," Mr. Fox said.
All retail specialists said the influx of tourists, encouraged in part by the city's improving image, has been a boon for storekeepers by increasing sales. "Try to exchange a package at Saks and you find that nobody's speaking English," Mr. Victor said. "Tourism used to be a seasonal thing, but now it's 12 months a year and that is wonderful for retailers."
"New York is has become the international city of the world now that it is perceived as safe and clean," said Mr. Cohen, of Cushman & Wakefield. "You have all the international companies that are located here, you have the United Nations and I've never seen as many tourists on the streets as there are now."
One question facing the retail sector this year is what will happen to the large stores offering a wide range of goods, often at lower prices than those in smaller shops already established in neighborhoods. A city administration proposal to alter zoning rules to allow them in old manufacturing locations was rejected by the City Council after extended debate.
"There will be an opportunity for large retailers to locate in New York," said Mr. Seligman of Edward S. Gordon. "That decision just made it more difficult, because it conveyed the impression that somehow New York has voted to keep big stores out."
Another question is what will happen at Rockefeller Center, which came under the management of Tishman Speyer Properties in a complex financial transaction last year. Brokers said the new management considers the retail operations of the center, which receives millions of visitors a year, in addition to its tenants, to be underutilized.
"They are looking at a lot of different concepts, including the creation of bigger spaces," Mr. Victor said. "They could combine the ground floor, the concourse and maybe even the second floor to make those big spaces."
A decision is similarly expected on how to redevelop the site of the Coliseum at Columbus Circle. State officials have said they expect to decide by spring which of nine competing proposals they will accept. The proposals, each backed by a development group, include a mix of residential, commercial and retail applications.
In addition, a decision may be announced on what will happen at the site of the former Alexander's department store, which occupies most of the block between 58th and 59th Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues. The property is controlled by Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook, N.J. Brokers said the company was trying to decide whether to develop the property as retail again or to convert the site to residential usage.
 
Hotels
 
Occupancy Rises, And So Do Prices
The surge in tourism that has helped retailers has produce nothing short of a boom for hotel owners and operators. Indeed, complaints are heard about how difficult it is to get a hotel room in the city or the suburbs.
The occupancy rate for hotels in the city last year was 81.5 percent, up from 79.5 percent in 1995, said John A, Fox, a director of PKF Consulting, which specializes in hotels.
"That is the highest level of occupancy since we started keeping records in the 1960's," Mr. Fox said. Since there are certain periods of slack demand that are almost structural, he said it is not likely that occupancy rates would go much higher.
What can go higher is room rates, which increased to an average of $170.50 a night, about a 10 percent increase over the 1995 average of $155.50, according to Mr. Fox.
The higher occupancy rates and room charges, plus the fact that very little new construction is under way, are pushing up the value of existing hotels, according to Stephen Rushmore, the president of HVS International, which appraises values.
"Values went up 42 percent in 1996," he said, "compared to an increase of 31 percent in 1995 and declines of 23 percent in 1991 and 15 percent in 1992."
He said that domestic and foreign investors who would not touch a hotel property in New York in the late 80's and early 90's are looking for properties to acquire. "Most of the talk today is about conversions, which can be done more quickly than new construction," he said.
One example of this effort is the old Macmillan building at 52d Street and Third Avenue, where the upper tower is to be converted into a Marriott Courtyard hotel starting this spring.
Some new hotels are expected as well, including one to be built by Tishman Realty & Construction Company as part of its E Walk project along Eighth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets.
 
The Suburbs
 
Despite Downsizing, Demand Grows
The demand for office and retail space extended to the suburbs ringing New York, although the effects of corporate downsizing continued to be felt in places like Westchester County.
"As a general rule, the buildings in the suburbs that are successful are the ones catering to small business, not big corporate clients," said Richard Podos, a vice president of Equis Corporation, a brokerage concern specializing in representing tenants. "And the reason is that there are fewer big businesses and a lot more small ones."
He said Class A property in northern New Jersey was growing scarce, although less desirable office space remained available. Nevertheless, he said, builders are cautious when contemplating new construction. "Speculative developers now build a building about halfway and then go out and market it like crazy before finishing," he said.
The flight to quality continued in the Westchester and Fairfield County markets, said Kim Mowers, a senior vice president and district manager with Grubb & Ellis. "Vacancies are in the single digits in Stamford and Greenwich because a lot of the people who were downsized and spun off started their own businesses," he said. "But the Class B market will continue to be frustrated because many of those buildings are functionally obsolete."
He said a good indication of the improvement in the market was the decision of the owners of 287 Corporate Plaza in White Plains., a building whose construction was halted as a steel skeleton in 1990, to proceed with the project.
 
Downtown
 
An Unclear Future, But Hope for Success
The future of New York City's other central business district remained unclear, although the success of the Borders Books store and projects to convert old office buildings to residences held out hope that the Giuliani administration's plan to transform the formerly commercial area into a neighborhood may succeed.
"The conversions are happening," said Michael G. Geoghegan, a consulting director of the Gordon company. "25 Broad, 45 Wall and 127 John Streets are being converted and by the end of 1997 there will be 1,500 to 2,000 rental units available." He said that while some of the older buildings in the area were unsuitable for use by the financial companies that are still the area's major employer, lower rents were an attraction to other companies. "Rentals are $8 to $10 a foot lower than midtown and with a spread of that size you start to see migration."
"I think we are going to see a 24-hour-a-day, 7-day-a-week market in downtown," said Mr. Cohen. "It's like the Upper East Side. People want to live near where they work. So if the residential is successful, it is going to help the office market."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 949 words

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Will the Diesel-Bus Fleet Survive Trenton's Eco-Politics?

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
The belching diesel bus, long a hallmark of New Jersey's public transportation system, will be fighting for survival this year in in the State Legislature.
Two bills introduced last year by three Democrats -- Anthony Impreveduto and Joseph V. Doria Jr., the minority leader, in the Assembly and Nicholas J. Sacco in the Senate -- would force New Jersey Transit to buy vehicles that run only on alternative fuels: compressed natural gas, electricity or ethanol, for example. They would also require the agency to use bio-diesel, which comes from soybeans, in all buses purchased in the current and two successive fiscal years. 
 While political experts doubted the bills would survive in their current form, they said the coming gubernatorial election year, along with the possibility of more stringent Federal clean-air guidelines, have made it likely that some environmentally friendly compromise will be produced.
So far the bills have gained the support of 20 assemblymen and senators, including Richard H. Bagger, conference leader for the Republican controlled Assembly. While sponsors would need stronger Republican support for passage, the support that Governor Whitman has given, in principle, for some move toward alternative-fuel vehicles is likely to help sway her party should she not chose to offer her own plan.
"It is an election year and the environment is an apple pie issue," said David P. Rebovic, a political science professor at Rider University. "The incentive on both sides of the aisle will be to latch on to this and push things forward."
Mrs. Whitman's interest in the issue became apparent on Wednesday, when Harriet Derman, the Governor's chief of staff, and Eileen McGinnis, her chief of policy and planning, began the first of what is expected to be several high-level meetings with environmental groups. Representatives from the State Department of Environmental Protection, which supports phasing out of the authority's more than 2,000 diesel busses, also attended.
According to administration officials, the Governor is looking at several options that would force New Jersey Transit to the table, among them placing language in the state budget to earmark money to build compressed natural gas fueling stations and to buy the buses that use the fuel.
Transit authorities in other large cities, as well as the Postal Service and many local delivery companies, have embraced alternative fuels like compressed natural gas, which is relatively pollution-free and cheap at the pump. Alternative-fuel vehicles now make up one of the fastest growing sectors of the public transit market, according to the American Public Transit Association. But New Jersey Transit has so far been reluctant to follow the lead, complaining that the five buses it purchased in 1991 have so far not peformed as well as those in the diesel fleet and that refurbishing a bus depot to handle a large number of compressed natural gas vehicles would cost millions of dollars.
They also say that new formulations of diesel have drastically reduced pollutants, though diesel exhaust remains a chief source of the soot and other emissions that foul the air and contribute to a variety of ailments from asthma to emphysema.
"We have had our share of problems with compressed natural gas," said Jeff Maclin, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit. "And frankly I think we have exercised prudence in testing only a small number of these buses. To do otherwise would have raised questions as to whether this was a prudent use of tax dollars."
But mechanical engineers and fuel experts say most mechanical problems caused by compressed natural gas, such as its often uneven fuel content, have largely been overcome by new engineering technology. Other transit agencies agree.
Christopher Lynn, comissioner of the New York City's Department of Transportation, said the city's 55 compressed natural gas buses have far fewer problems than those of its aging diesel fleet. The buses are more economical to operate, he said, and performance -- the amount of time buses are on the road between shop visits -- has helped increase bus service by 30 percent.
"I just wish I could replace all 1,100 of our diesel buses," he said, noting that 174 more compressed natural gas buses have already been ordered by the city.
With a not-so-veiled reference to New Jersey, he added: "We're all part of the same ozone belt here and have the same pollution problems. But we can also have the same benefits because what we are doing in New York City can be be done anywhere."
If New York State's battle over alternative fuels is any indication, New Jersey may soon join the pack. Unlike New York City transit agencies, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority fought for years against committing to buses running on anything but diesel. But this changed after a bill, much like those now working their way through the New Jersey legislature, was introduced by Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Westchester County.
Although the bill has never passed, it attracted the attention of Governor George E. Pataki and other powerful politicians, whose patient prodding resulted in a compromise with the New York City Transit Authority last September. Under its guidelines, the authority would replace 500 of its diesel buses with ones that uses natural gas or electricity over a three-year period.
"That's the purpose of bills like this," said Assemblyman Brodsky, speaking of the similarities between his bill and those in New Jersey. "They have a mule and two-by-four quality to them, because they bang people over the head, wake them up to the problem and push the issue to the front."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Jersey lags in nondiesel technology; in Manhattan, an electric bus has a trial run. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Trucks Roll Along Town Streets, Trailing Protests

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: EAST AMWELL

 BODY:
Ilona English seems a prototypical resident of this sleepy, picturesque township not far from the cultural riches of Princeton. She is a Wharton graduate, a baby boomer who used to be a financial analyst but now breeds horses, the type of person usually too busy to delve into civic matters.
But there is one local issue about which she has become so passionate that she is willing to go to jail: the increase in the number of trucks rambling past her 250-year-old clapboard house on Route 518. 
 "I never protested in the 1960's, and I've never been arrested," said Ms. English, who is active in an antitruck group called Country Roads Coalition. "But I would gladly do it in this case. If we don't stop this, the whole state will look like the Turnpike and Bayonne."
Ms. English's aggressiveness is emblematic of a surge of civic activism in a well-to-do area that has not been a traditional hotbed of protest. But in the last year or so, half a dozen groups have sprouted in places like the Amwells, the Windsors, the Hopewells and the Princetons, alarmed by a host of transportation issues.
The Truckstop Coalition has distributed more than 500 "No Heavy Trucks" signs to homeowners on properties fronting Routes 31, 206 and 518 (including that of Ms. English). The Princeton Residents Traffic Safety Committee is also concerned about trucks. The Alliance of Bypass Committees objects to a road project called the Hightstown Bypass. The Sensible Transportation Options Partnership (STOP) opposes a project called the Millstone Bypass. The West Windsor Citizens Against the Turnpike Extension objects to both bypass projects.
These groups represent a collective counterweight to the trucking lobby and the State Department of Transportation. The groups are related, in that they are born of two recent changes that have bedeviled residents: the opening of Interstate 287 and the explosion of development in central New Jersey.
Only a few years ago, this area looked different. It was the kind of place where Ms. English could actually ride a horse and buggy into town to run errands.
Then came the completion of I-287 in November 1993. This created toll-free alternatives to the New Jersey Turnpike on local roads like Routes 31 and 206, saving north- and southbound Interstate truckers as much as $61 a round trip. Within 18 months, truck traffic on Route 31 more than tripled, going from 900 trucks a weekday to more than 3,000 a day in March 1995.
Meanwhile, central New Jersey was booming, as more corporations moved to Route 1 and more housing developments popped up on former farmland. No longer did retailers want (or have space) to stockpile goods in warehouses. Instead, they were demanding more just-in-time deliveries, just-in-time manufacturing. One result was an increase in the need for trucks, said Dianne Brake, president of the Middlesex Somerset Mercer Regional Council, a nonprofit planning group.
As a result, transportation officials have floated several plans, some decades old, said John Dourgarian, a public information officer with the State Department of Transportation. Here are three:
* The State Department of Transportation has broken ground on the Hightstown Bypass, which would reroute traffic around Hightstown and into East Windsor on a four-lane highway running from Route 571 just east of Route 535 to Route 33 near Exit 8 of the New Jersey Turnpike. Cost: $56.8 million. Opening: 1999.
* The State Department of Transportation has started environmental work on the Millstone Bypass, a two-lane 2.3-mile road that would channel traffic off Route 571 to ease the bottleneck at Route 1. Plans call for building an overpass near Harrison Street and sealing off parts of Washington Road. Cost: $40 million. Opening: 1998.
* The State Turnpike Authority plans to build Route 92, a four-lane 6.6-mile toll road connecting Route 1 just north of Princeton with the New Jersey Turnpike. Cost: $255 million. Opening: 2001.
But these projects have irked residents. Sandy Solomon, a member of the Princeton Residents Traffic Safety Committee, says building more roads will only entice more traffic. She says resources would be better spent trying to get trucks back on the Interstate highways, and trying to develop more pedestrian and mass transit alternatives.
"The D.O.T. is really the D.O.R.: Department of Roads," said Alan Goodheart, a landscape architect active in Sensible Transportation Options Partnership, which is primarily concerned with the impact of the Millstone Bypass on historic, elm-lined Washington Road. Its subcommittee, Good Options (GO), has proposed an alternative of building a Route 1 underpass below Washington Road.
These concerns have not fallen on deaf ears. In some areas, the Department of Transportation lowered speed limits. In Princeton, the Borough Council plans to introduce an ordinance that would limit the weight of trucks passing through town, said Mayor Marvin Reed.
In West Windsor, the planning board filed a lawsuit in October against the Department of Transportation, seeking to get more information about the Hightstown Bypass and demanding a new route, said Alan Di Sciullo, chairman of the planning board. In Trenton, Assemblyman Leonard Lance, a Republican, has introduced legislation that would restrict truck traffic on local highways.
The trucking lobby has not been impressed. "We haven't gotten off the floor laughing," said Sam Cunninghame, executive director of the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, about Mr. Lance's bill.
"It's that not-in-my-backyard syndrome," Mr. Cunninghame said. "It's like vigilante. And people haven't thought it through: the better the economy is, the better the trucking business is going to be."
The Department of Transportation, already stung by criticism from many residents, has been treading carefully. "We do believe that these projects will be a clear benefit to the region," Mr. Dourgarian said. "With the issue of truck traffic, it's an issue that won't be solved overnight, but we are committed to seeing it resolved."
But how long that will take is something residents are becoming anxious about.
"There are a lot of people who are newly concerned, who are willing to do whatever it takes," Mr. Goodheart said. "It'll come to protests. It'll come to people lying down in front of bulldozers."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
A Delegation for Gingrich, But Not All the Time

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
In his first two years as Speaker, Newt Gingrich could not always count on New Jersey's Republican delegation to toe the party line.
They did not abandon the leadership on every vote, of course. They supported Mr. Gingrich on most fiscal issues, but they broke with the leadership more than any other delegation except Connecticut. 
 It was mostly on issues: the environment, gun control, Medicare and Medicaid, which are important for political survival in their districts and in a state dominated by voters who are fiscal conservatives but moderate on social issues.
Yet as Mr. Gingrich faced his difficult re-election as Speaker last week, New Jersey's Republican delegation did not balk. They did not join the handful of Republicans who defected because of Mr. Gingrich's ethics problems. All seven New Jersey Republicans voted to keep Mr. Gingrich in control of the House.
In the two weeks leading up to the vote, Representative Marge S. Roukema of Bergen County, the dean of the delegation, had expressed some reservations about supporting Mr. Gingrich before the ethics proceedings were completed.
Of all the Republican members of the delegation, Ms. Roukema is perhaps the most outspoken and best known for urging the leadership to take a more moderate stance on social issues from welfare to family leave.
Ms. Roukema said that she would have liked to see her party elect a temporary Speaker while House members awaited the final recommendations of the Ethics Committee and the report of James M. Cole, the committee's special counsel. But since that was not an option, she said she chose to give Mr. Gingrich the benefit of the doubt.
"I wrestled with this," she said. "I did not want to prejudge him. I did feel that I owed him that, as I would have owed it to anybody to reserve judgment until all of the information is out."
Based on the information that was available about Mr. Gingrich's ethics problems, Representative H. James Saxton of Burlington County said that he had no trouble supporting Mr. Gingrich last week. He credits Mr. Gingrich with moving not only Congress, but also the White House, toward the goal of reducing the size of government and lowering taxes, and he thinks he is the best leader to continue the job.
"The Speaker was accused of and admitted to what seems to me to be a minor infraction of House rules," Mr. Saxton said. "And so he should be held accountable for that infraction. However, in my view, and I think, in the view of other Republican members in New Jersey, that infraction and the penalty for it does not foreclose him the opportunity to be Speaker."
But Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat from Camden County, criticized Republicans for electing Mr. Gingrich. "He should not be Speaker," Mr. Andrews said. "To elevate someone who is third in line to the Presidency, someone who very clearly has lost the trust of the American people, is the wrong thing to do. "
Representative Mike Pappas, the newly elected Republican from Somerset County who filled Representative Richard A. Zimmer's seat, said he did not have any trouble giving his vote to Mr. Gingrich. "I supported him and I support him because the agenda he has been promoting is the same agenda that I have been promoting. That is tax relief, regulatory relief and more growth in our economy that would benefit business owners and working men and working women. I understand the concerns that have been raised about things. But I look upon the alternative. The alternative is Dick Gephardt. There is no question in my mind that Newt Gingrich's agenda is in sync with the American people."
In a speech after his re-election as Speaker, Mr. Gingrich struck a decidedly more conciliatory tone than he chose two years ago. In this 105th Congress, it appears that New Jersey Republicans may not have to battle over as many issues that are as important to the state, such as environmental protection, as they did in the last two years. "I believe that we have convinced those who wanted to strip away layers of environmental protection that we have an opportunity in the next two years to have environmental policies that are more balanced," Mr. Paxton said.
But most of New Jersey's Republicans vow that they will continue to be independent in those areas that are important to their districts and the state.
The public hearings will soon begin for Mr. Gingrich, who admitted last month that that he had provided the committee with "inaccurate, incomplete and unreliable statements" about a course that he taught at two small colleges in Georgia. The question is whether he improperly used tax-exempt programs for partisan purposes. Mr. Cole, the special counsel, will present his findings in detail later this month. Then the committee will make its recommendations for punishment.
That will be a far more interesting vote to watch.
"In my opinion, that will be the telling vote," Representative Roukema said. "That will be the determining vote. We will then determine the penalty, whether it is a simple reprimand, and only a slight breach, or whether it is a more serious matter."

HEADLINE: COPING;
Matter of Life or Death: Who Can You Trust?

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
RICHARD WEINER, the public relations executive who helped make the original Cabbage Patch Kids a phenomenon, says he believes unequivocally that terminally ill patients should be able to end their lives. His wife, Florence, who has written several books on practical health issues, is so ambivalent she considers this her "weak" issue. "When did euthanasia become doctor-assisted suicide?" she asks. And her sister, Simi Linton, a professor at Hunter College, went to Washington last week to demonstrate outside the Supreme Court against doctor-assisted suicide and to hand out leaflets for the group Not Dead Yet.
If three members of one close Upper West Side family can offer such a range of opinion in the abstract, one can only imagine the deathbed turmoil of kin in conflict. Money, morphine, guilt, control and convenience are common subplots in the drama surrounding a terminal patient. And the definition of terminal becomes more complex when doctors have to make a prognosis under the growing economic pressure of managed care. 
 Two months ago, a column about arranging for a cremation drew a surprisingly large response from older New Yorkers who wanted to be cremated decorously and at a moderate cost that they would prepay. They did not want to burden their survivors, but they also did not trust that their children wouldn't be "guilt-tripped" by other family members and funeral salespeople into more elaborate send-offs.
But for all their certainties about cremation, when I asked them about living wills and orders not to resuscitate, the discussion faltered. Giving someone else the right to pull the plug, they said, was not easy, especially since they distrusted doctors more than ever; decisions, they felt, might be made not for humane or even medical reasons, but for cost-efficient ones. These people didn't want to suffer, but they didn't want an accountant-assisted suicide.
It was at that time that Mr. Weiner happened to call, to promote the American Academy on Physician and Patient, a small, new organization dedicated to improving communications between doctor and patient, particularly by educating and sensitizing doctors. Mr. Weiner is on the board, and one active member is Dr. Timothy E. Quill, a principal in New York's case before the Supreme Court and a national standard-bearer for the legalization of doctor-assisted suicide.
Mr. Weiner is smart, charming and erudite (he is the author of Webster's New World Dictionary of Media and Communications) but I told him I thought there were enough clubs for doctors. Sure, doctors need to be more sympathetic and to spend more time taking patient histories, but in these days of the five-minute exam, it's the patient who needs to be taught how to be in charge. Mr. Weiner agreed with that and, lexicographer that he is, agreed that the word "patient" needed to be replaced with something less passive, closer to consumer or customer.
In 1981, using public relations language and techniques, he was able to help create an image of cuddly, needy love around a bunch of ugly dolls. Can you imagine what he could do for really needy creatures? Like sick people? Still, his position was clear: the doctor is in the best position to offer a dignified, painless end.
"Doctors have to be convinced they can do a better job by understanding their patients, by knowing the whole person," he said. "Such a doctor would then also be in a position to help end suffering."
Maybe, says Florence, his wife, author of "Recovering at Home With a Heart Condition."
"I want a consortium, checks and balances, reviews," she said. "It's hard for people at their most vulnerable to assert themselves, especially disabled people, who are most dependent on doctors and have the least reason to trust them."
Her sister, Simi Linton, who teaches psychology in Hunter's Division of Education, is an expert in disability studies and is disabled herself. Legal doctor-assisted suicide, she said, would be the "slippery slope" down which a lot of people in wheelchairs would be rolled to death.
"Physicians are generally clueless about people's lives," she said. "I know people who have 24-hour care and are respirator-dependent and lead vigorous lives, married, with jobs. When they get depressed for the same reason anyone gets depressed -- got fired, divorced -- doctors are quick to ascribe it to disability. They assume disability is a tragedy.
"We can't allow physicians to make quality-of life and life-potential decisions. These are power and control issues. I'm also disturbed at how the media treats it, as: here are these poor folks; let's help them end their lives."
The Weiners and Ms. Linton have agreed to disagree on this one, but the debate will rage on, in courts, in kitchens and in hospital rooms.
Mr. Weiner, even though it's been years since he's been down in the Cabbage Patch, winces at my metaphor for giving accountant-whipped doctors too much power: You let those ugly little dolls into your homes, eventually they will start eating your kids.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Mark Matcho)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33; Column 1; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1480 words

HEADLINE: Can Superman Be Superseded By a Capeless Wonder?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
LONG ago on a Kansas farm, Martha Kent made the first supersuit for her teen-age son, Clark, who had arrived as a baby in a space capsule. Her Superman would wear a skintight blue leotard, a flowing red cape and a big red "S" on his expansive chest.
So attired, he went on to defend truth, justice and the American way, becoming the planet's most super superhero. Superman claimed a corner of the American consciousness known to Johnny Appleseed, Daniel Boone and Dick Tracy. 
 But soon the very essence of the Man of Steel will change fundamentally. Starting in the May issue of "Superman," which hits the stands in March, the costume lovingly fashioned by Ma Kent will be discarded in favor of high-tech garb, and his powers will become something far different: The man who could leap tall buildings in a single bound and stop bullets with his body will transmit himself through phone lines; bullets will pass though him like a vapor.
Superman will no longer need a cape. The red "S" will be blue, and the yellow background memory. No more red underwear, even the skimpier trunks of recent years. Instead, energy flashes will shoot from his bulkier body like lightning, and his hair will sprout the spiky topography of a club kid's.
Since the new look was previewed in magazines about comic books and on television news programs and talk shows this month, reaction has been sharp. Admirers of the old guy are, to put it mildly, grumbling that the new Superman resembles a tube of toothpaste and worse.
Written and telephone complaints have rained down on Mike Carlin, executive editor of DC Universe, the Time Warner comic-book unit, which owns Superman, Batman and scores of other superheroes. "Everybody says, 'How dare you?' " said the man who calls himself the most hated human in America.
Nowhere is the criticism sharper than on Superman Web sites. One writer called the change "a cynical gimmick"; another, referring to a sinister superhero, said, "This would have worked well for the Eradicator, but not Superman."
Still others fret that one more icon closely linked to the cultural history of the 20th century is being cast aside.
"His meaning to my generation has been lost," moaned Jules Feiffer, the cartoonist, who is 67 and who in his extensive writings about the Man of Steel has dubbed him the "ultimate assimilationist fantasy" in a melting-pot nation. Mr. Feiffer suggested the new Superman looks like "a suffering transvestite," "somebody who just came off the Geraldo show" or "an electic-shock patient."
Tibor Kalman is an influential graphics designer who has made waves by criticizing the processes of corporate creativity, championing a utopian American mythology that even he acknowledges never quite existed. It is his view that the new Superman emerged from a focus group.
"We think we own these characters," he said. "But the reality is that their look and actions are going to be defined by market forces.
"This just isn't human, and Superman's best quality was that he was human. Why don't they redo Mount Rushmore and give the guys better haircuts?"
Could it have something to do with the economic downturn in the comic-book industry, whose annual sales in comic outlets, a DC spokeswoman said, fell to some $450 million last year from more than $1 billion in 1993? Has a treasured icon been transmogrified as a sales gimmick?
The answer, of course, is yes. Mr. Carlin noted that Superman and Batman have weathered the industry slump better than most titles, but declared, "If comic books were selling 10 times what they are now, we would do the same thing to try to sell 11 times more. Everything is geared to selling comic books."
In particular, Mr. Carlin longs to lure the young readers -- especially comic-book-buying adolescents, now engrossed in CD-ROM's and the Internet -- that he fears Superman has lost. He goes so far as to claim a higher purpose: destroying the time-honored look of Superman can serve to pass his values on to an audience attracted by his cool new look.
"This is a way to try to get people to focus on something that feels old-fashioned," he said. "We can now keep the role model in the forefront of the public's eye."
Mr. Carlin, who oversees the team of 18 who write and draw four monthly and one quarterly issue of the Superman comics ($2.50 each), has shocked the public before, only to return to the status quo and count his money. In 1992, he killed the Man of Steel, resulting in the awesome sale of six million copies -- only to resurrect him and again spur sales.
Two months ago, he finally wed Clark Kent and Lois Lane, but only after Clark told his betrothed his other identity.
"If you stand for truth and justice, you can't start your marriage with a lie," Mr. Carlin said solemnly.
Lois thus thought she was marrying a full-time superhero, one who might sometimes wear cape and leotards and other times the off-the-rack threads of a mild-mannered reporter for The Daily Planet. But the new Clark has no superpowers. He wills Superman into being. When he is done saving the world, he wills himself back to whatever Clark was wearing before. (The new "energy being" will no longer need to duck into phone booths.)
So what about supersex? "It's like sleeping with a regular guy now," Mr. Carlin said, without disclosing what it was like before. But he then added an element of mysterious danger. "Realistically speaking, this could become a deadly problem for Lois," he said.
This is because of the tangled plot that has brought Superman to his new blue-costumed world. Some months ago, Earth's sun, the source of Superman's powers, briefly went out. He has since been struggling to get them back, going through a succession of punishing treatments that would have killed a mere mortal.
His new energy form -- and the new clothes that contain it -- is the result of this chemotherapy-like regimen. And it will all take some getting used to: as he zaps from place to place like a bolt of lightning, he will at first experience problems landing, DC editors say.
But it is not just the story line that is disturbing superhero junkies, design gurus and other cultural arbiters. It is such a radical change of appearance in such an immense cultural icon. Why? Why now? What is supertradition worth?
Mr. Carlin answers patly. "We have all the rights, and we can do whatever we want," he said.
Indeed, comic heroes change with some regularity. In the 1980's, Wonder Woman lost her high heels. Over the last year, Spiderman and Dare Devil were overhauled, only to return to their earlier forms after protest. But Superman has undergone only subtle sartorial alterations in 60 years.
Superman loyalists had thought their staid hero was as unchangeable as a "Leave It to Beaver" rerun, but Mr. Feiffer said today's trend represents a sharp reverse of tradition: once, he said, movie heroes resembled their counterparts in comics, but now the reverse is true. "They've all become Stallone," he said.
Mo Chin, 19, a freshman at Vassar College, agreed. "They're making him like every other superhero, aren't they?" he said as he browsed Jim Henley's Universe, a comic-book store on West 33d Street.
The question, in part, is one of pure design. Styles change. Today's superheroes, like Livewire, the Eradicator and many of the X-Men, are super bulked-up and cyber.
Ellen Lupton, curator of contemporary design at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's design wing, has studied Japanese comic heroes. Superman's Japanese counterparts, she said, depict sexier, grittier heroes on black-and-white pages and are growing in popularity in the United States.
She thinks the new Superman is closer to this cooler image. "The cape is such a Count Dracula notion," she said. "Superman shouldn't need a magic carpet."
Another position is held by Dr. Alan Manevitz, a family psychiatrist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, who owns some 30,000 comic books. He is writing a book on how the news and entertainment media, including comic books, affect youth. He suggests the big red "S" has deep and important meanings, sending a message of continuity across the generations.
"Children like to know there is somebody special out there to help them," he said. "They need to understand that there is some purity."
Superman himself grew up immersed in the traditional values of Jonathan and Martha Kent, playing softball and sitting under a tree with a book on that mythical Kansas farm. And many of his fans hope fervently he will go right back to the familiar muscle man after the latest change jangles cash registers for a while.
"We all know that this is a cheap sales gimmick designed to last four to six months," scoffed Mitch Cutler, owner of St. Marks Comics, at 11 St. Marks Place.
"We never say never," Mr. Carlin responded. "We never say forever."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Expanding, but Keeping an Eye on Value

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
FROM his staid gray suit to his low-turnover fund portfolio, Legg Mason's William H. Miller 3d is hardly a follower of fashion. But in 1996, a year when investors turned from mutual funds focusing on hot-growth companies to funds emphasizing more solid performers, Mr. Miller found himself, his funds and his value investing method very much in fashion.
Mr. Miller is manager or co-manager of three Legg Mason stock funds whose combined $3.2 billion in assets represents more than half the total of the company's 17 stock and bond retail funds. All three soared to top rankings last year: The flagship Value Trust fund, with a return of 38.3 percent, ended 1996 in the top 2 percent of all mutual funds; just behind it were Total Return Trust, which he manages with Nancy T. Dennin, and Special Investment Trust. In the fourth quarter, Value Trust, up 14.75 percent, ranked No. 2 among more than 1,700 diversified stock funds. 
 Armed with these impressive results, plus excellent performance from funds like its American Leading Companies Trust, Legg Mason plans to expand this year by creating a series of funds that will aim at the growing 401(k) market. The funds, for institutional investors, are expected to be introduced within six months and will be built on the company's successful retail portfolios.
"It is our strong intention to have 8 to 12 new funds," said Edward A. Tabor 3d, Legg Mason's senior executive vice president. "The beauty is we have the fund managers. We can take a Bill Miller and let him continue to run the Value fund, but at the same time he can have a portfolio almost, if not exactly, like Value that is distributed to institutional clients for, say, 401(k) plans."
LEGG MASON, based in Baltimore, started its first fund, Value Trust, in 1982, and has developed several others. But the group accelerated its growth in the last two years by acquiring asset-management operations. In January 1995, it bought Batterymarch and soon started two funds under Batterymarch management, Legg Mason International Equity and Legg Mason Emerging Markets. Last January, it acquired Bartlett & Company of Cincinnati, which oversees $211 million in assets in two stock mutual funds under its own name.
Legg Mason gained an international distribution line in February with the purchase of Lehman Brothers Global Asset Management, which had $2.9 billion in assets divided among institutional accounts and offshore debt and equity funds. The funds are now reorganized as the LM Global Funds.
"We want to build resources internally, but if it will take us three to five years to develop a product, we'll buy the expertise," said Raymond A. Mason, the company's chairman and chief executive known universally as Chip. The firm now manages more than $40 billion in assets, with a goal of $100 billion by 2000.
As it grows, the fund family is contributing a larger portion of Legg Mason's overall revenue. Half comes from the brokerage arm, called Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc., but the asset management division, which includes the mutual funds, now generates 29 percent, up from 18 percent in 1990. The rest comes from commercial mortgage banking.
Mr. Mason said asset management "probably contributes over 40 percent of our profits, and probably the single biggest source of that group's profits is the mutual funds."
In the fiscal year ended in March the company took in $516 million, versus $389 million a year earlier, and earned $38 million, versus $16 million. In the first six months of fiscal 1997, earnings were $26 million, up 53 percent from the period a year earlier, and revenue was $296 million, up 23 percent.
Legg Mason was created through the merger of Legg & Company, a Baltimore firm that traced its roots to 1899, and Mason & Company, a Newport News, Va., firm founded by Mr. Mason in 1962. The company has always used value investing, and Mr. Miller has adhered to it, but with his own spin.
A former candidate for a doctorate in philosophy, Mr. Miller, 46, retains a scholarly bent that he applies to investing. He is on the board of the Santa Fe Institute, which is devoted to studying similarities within complex systems like economics, ecology and the body's immune system. Because these systems adapt to their environments, the Santa Fe theory holds that history does not always repeat itself. Using that idea, Mr. Miller and his six researchers try to look past traditional data on stocks.
"We say changes are context-dependent," Mr. Miller said. "This summer, when the market fell out of bed, it was because everyone believed the Fed would tighten based on a specific employment report. The Fed doesn't tighten because of one report. The environment was conducive for the Fed to tighten, but not all of the data indicated that it would." Mr. Miller stood pat on his funds and the Fed did not move.
Mr. Miller looks at price-to-earnings ratios, price-to-book value and cash-flow ratios, but only as a starting point. He says a forward-looking approach is to be more attentive to free cash flow than to earnings. "We bought a big position in I.B.M. two years ago when it was in the $50's," he said. "Before that, it had been a cash user. In 1994 it went cash positive, focusing on profitability, not sales growth." The stock is currently trading at $163. "We don't forecast the market or prices," he said. "We try to understand where things are going."
That approach has led Mr. Miller to a longstanding bet in the financial sector. In September, the latest portfolio reporting period, Value Trust had 47 percent of assets in financials; Total Return, about 40 percent.
"If you say what makes a company do well in this market, you would look for earnings growth faster than the market, return on capital that is higher than the market, dividends equal to or higher than the market, dividend growth that is faster than the market, a company that generates excess cash and management that uses excess cash to increase shareholder value," he said. "That's a description of the bank group."
Mr. Miller started buying bank stocks in the early 80's, when the Mexican debt crisis cut many prices; he suffered through the down times of the early 90's, adjusting his portfolio to hold banks he saw as positioned for recovery and growth.
"With hindsight, we can see it was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," said Russel Kinnel, equity fund editor for Morningstar Mutual Funds.
PART of Mr. Miller's success can be attributed to a long investment horizon. Turnover in Value Trust is so low, said Christine Benz, associate analyst for equities at Morningstar Mutual Funds, that "it's positively glacial."
Mr. Miller said his average holding period was about five years, so turnover is about 20 percent a year.
Although his reading list includes books like "Adaptive Individuals in Evolving Populations," Mr. Miller is plain-spoken and likes to make stock-picking sound simple.
"We like to buy hysteria and sell euphoria," he said. "One of the reasons the fund has done well this year is there was hysteria in tech stocks." He cites a day last February when Compaq announced some distribution problems that sent computer stocks into a spin. He bought a million shares of Dell Computer at about $14; it is now at $60.
Of course, not every stock pick or yearly performance has fared as well. In four out of five years in the late 80's, Value underperformed the broad market. "In a recession, banks tend to go down more than other stocks and our heavy financial weighting hurt us," Mr. Miller said.
So how does he envision Value performing this year?
"If I were an investor looking to put my money in a fund today," Mr. Miller said, "I don't know that I would go with Value."
Instead, he prefers his Special Investment Trust for its emphasis on the mid-cap market. "Going forward, I would be surprised if Value outperforms Special," he said. "The relative performance of small or mid-sized companies will match or exceed large companies. This stuff tends to work in cycles."

HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
Despite a Lack of Bells or Whistles, A Can Maker May Be a Good Buy

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
SILGAN HOLDINGS is hardly typical of the ventures taking a bow in the new-issues market. The company has nothing to do with the Internet or with some innovative medical device. No one thinks its business is about to take off. And while it is not exactly a Rust Belt manufacturer, the company comes close in terms of excitement: it is the country's largest maker of metal food containers, like soup and coffee cans.
But investors may find Silgan alluring nonetheless, particularly given some of its other distinctive qualities. For example, unlike many new issues, it has a reasonable offering price. And even people who shun new issues because they fear an economic downturn might want to own these shares, which seem recession-resistant. 
 Founded in 1987 by two former executives of Continental Can, Silgan has spent the last decade buying up consumer packaging businesses from companies like Del Monte and Nestle, and signing contracts to provide containers for their vegetables or cocoa. The strategy of the company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., is to shut down the least efficient operations and consolidate the rest, to become the low-cost producer.
"It follows the basic trend we have seen of outsourcing," said Ryan Jacob, the director of research for the IPO Value Monitor, a research service for new issues.
So far, Silgan has succeeded. "They have a very good track record of making acquisitions and folding them into the company," Mr. Jacob said. The company's share of the domestic market for metal food containers has increased from about 10 percent in 1987 to 36 percent in 1995, and sales reached $1.08 billion for the nine months ended last September.
But to finance all these acquisitions, Silgan has taken on substantial debt. As of Sept. 30, its balance sheet was weighed down with roughly $700 million in long-term debt, more than twice its proposed market value of roughly $300 million. Indeed, virtually all the roughtly $65 million that Silgan expects to raise from the new offering -- it will offer 3.5 million shares at $17 to $20 a share, within the next month or so -- is earmarked for paying off some of its high-cost loans. The company also has plans to refinance some of its debt.
Although those moves will save the company about $20 million in cash interest payments, Silgan will still be left with as much as $880 million in long- and short-term debt. That would generally raise eyebrows, but analysts are not concerned because of Silgan's good cash flow. "If you have very stable, consistent earnings, you can afford to take on debt," said Mark S. Basham, a new-issues analyst for Standard & Poor's.
While Silgan is not the only option for investors interested in the packaging business, its stock may be more attractively priced than that of competitors like the Crown Cork and Seal Company and the Ball Corporation, according to Mr. Basham. One reason is the lack of enthusiasm these days for new issues.
For example, the stock of Crown Cork and Seal closed at $52 on Friday, a price equal to 16 times the company's estimated earnings a share this year. But Silgan's stock, at an approximate offering price of $18.50, would be trading at just seven times its estimated 1997 earnings of $2.60 a share, adjusted for certain tax benefits.
True, Silgan deserves a lower multiple because of its high debt and because its stock is new to the market. But Mr. Basham, for one, thinks the stock should still trade at a higher multiple than its estimated one; he judges the proper multiple to be between 9 and 10, which would translate into a stock price of $23.40 to $26.
But in another contrast to many new issues, the stock may need to be held for more than a day or two to realize most of such a gain. To justify a higher price with higher profits, Silgan will need to continue to pare down debt and make smart acquisitions. Those efforts will take time, Mr. Basham warned.
The company also plans to expand its plastics business, making items like containers for high-priced bottled water. And it hopes to increase its share of the market for specialty products like metal fasteners for glass jars.
Investors -- especially those who get great comfort from the predictability of a company's business -- may find the wait worthwhile. While Silgan's business depends somewhat on the weather (the smaller the lima bean harvest, for example, the fewer the cans required), the company is less vulnerable to a downturn in the economy or in the stock market.
Nevertheless, Silgan "is certainly not going to be a big winner," Mr. Basham said. But sometimes a nice gain from a colorless stock is all you need to end up ahead.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Price of Success: An Unbalanced Portfolio

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
PICKING stocks may not replace fixing teeth as his profession, but Bruce Bieber, a dentist in Bayside, Queens, is no passive investor.
"Sometimes I get caught up in the frenzy of the market," Dr. Bieber said. "I'll study a company, especially some of the smaller Nasdaq companies, and if I think it's a good one, I'll go for it." 
 As with many other investors last year, Dr. Bieber's enthusiasm was well repaid. With the Standard & Poor's 500 earning a total return of 22.96 percent in 1996, his stocks and equity mutual funds grew substantially, giving his overall portfolio an estimated gain of 16 percent.
But as investors perform the January rite of reviewing their portfolios for the new year, the market's 1996 gains and the resulting enthusiasm for stocks put a particular spin on the job. As Lewis J. Altfest, Dr. Bieber's financial planner, described it, "Because Dr. Bieber's stock portion did so well last year, it's out of whack with the rest of his portfolio. Though he may not like it, it's time to rebalance and put more in bonds and cash."
In other words, because stocks have risen so much, they occupy a larger percentage of Dr. Bieber's holdings, and other investors' holdings, than they did before 1996.
This process of allocating assets among the basic classes of investment -- and regularly reviewing the allocation -- is crucial to a portfolio's success, accounting for more than 90 percent of the differences in investors' returns, planners say. Put another way, although investors may spend much time choosing between two different stocks, it is the broader decision of how much to apportion to stocks, bonds and cash that most powerfully affects returns.
Experts caution, however, that no one asset allocation is proper for everyone. "The asset-allocation plan for each individual will most likely differ according to age, income, financial goals, risk tolerance and other factors," said Joel Isaacson, a New York financial planner. And even for the same person, planners will differ on the allocation they consider appropriate.
"It's more an art than a science," Mr. Isaacson said.
Most experts agree, however, on certain generalizations. A single, 25-year-old investor with a long-term horizon would invest most of his money in equities, with the balance in bonds and cash. A couple in their 30's with young children would also have much of their long-term money in stocks, though probably less than the 25-year-old. And an older person about to retire might devote even less of his portfolio to equities.
But whatever the preferred percentages, the 1996 bull market has made many investors stock-heavy relative to their desired allocation. Dr. Bieber, for example, is 39. He and his wife, Aimee, and their two children, Evan, 11, and Dayna, 8, live in Plainview, L.I. In view of the family's income, college plans and other factors, Mr. Altfest's prescribed asset allocation plan calls for 78 percent stocks, 17 percent bonds and 5 percent cash. But after the success of stocks last year, the Bieber portfolio now looks like this: 83 percent equities, 14 percent bonds and 3 percent cash.
Last year's gains are not the only reason Mr. Altfest wants to lighten up on the stocks in Dr. Bieber's portfolio. Adding to the pressure is Mr. Altfest's overall view of stocks for 1997. "I think the U.S. stock market is at the high end," he said. "I want my clients who have a heavy equity exposure to be prepared for a possible correction."
Other experts agree.
"We think this year will be a moderately down year because we have had higher interest rates, declining earnings growth and very high price-earnings ratios," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers in New York. In early December, he shifted his recommended portfolio from 50 percent stocks, 35 percent bonds and 15 percent cash to 45 percent equities, 35 percent bonds and 20 percent cash.
As investors review their asset allocations, however, they must avoid several mistakes. For example, while the recent bull market may make many investors overly enamored of stocks, a common error in the past has been the reverse: too much in bonds and cash. At the end of 1995, 36 percent of all 401(k) assets were in money markets, bonds or other stable investments, according to Access Research in Windsor, Conn.
"Investors usually lean toward fixed income or cash because they fear short-term risk and volatility," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors. But given that stocks outperform other assets in the long run, these investors "are embracing the risk that they won't make their long-term goals on a real-dollar basis, after inflation."
Another common error: forgetting to include all relevant accounts in computing an allocation. Investors may include their 401(k) plan, for example, but forget that dusty I.R.A.
Moreover, many people may resist changing an asset allocation if it means reducing the portion of a portfolio that has done well recently. Many investors instead want to increase that segment, but given that rapidly appreciating assets are often what puts an allocation plan off kilter, "that's usually the wrong approach," Mr. Isaacson said.
Finally, "I recommend that investors never sell to rebalance a portfolio," Mr. Markese said. "You only balance with new money. If investors can avoid selling by using cash flow from distributions, income or inheritances to rebalance a portfolio, in the long run they'll come out ahead."
Generally, Mr. Altfest is planning to do just that with Dr. Bieber's portfolio, and the dentist heartily concurs. "That won't be quite as painful as getting out of some of these stocks that have performed well," he said.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
New Software to the Allocation Rescue

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
FOR mutual fund investors, reviewing portfolios at the start of a new year can be a big chore. But this year, there is a lot of software available to expedite the task.
For example, Advisor Software of Orinda, Calif., offers investors a program called Mutual Max, which draws on a data base of 5,200 funds to examine the holdings of each fund in an investor's portfolio. The software displays extensive information about each fund in tables and charts. It then tallies the results to show the asset allocation of the portfolio's funds. Subtotals of other assets, like directly held stocks and bonds or cash, can be entered, too, to give investors their overall asset allocation. 
 The software can also compare the actual allocation to the investor's target allocation. If the numbers vary, the investor can try different fund combinations until the goal is met.
"Many people are surprised by the results," said Greg Hutchings, the managing director of Advisor Software. For example, he said, his father and his brother had thought their portfolios were more aggressively invested in stocks than they actually were.
One reason for the discrepancy is that some funds hold an unexpectedly large portion of their assets in cash. Another is that funds do not always invest as their nominal categories would suggest -- a matter that Morningstar Inc., the fund research company in Chicago, is addressing with its recent regrouping of funds based on actual portfolio holdings rather than on prospectus descriptions.
But because mutual funds must disclose their holdings only twice a year, the information that Morningstar and Advisor rely on may be outdated. A deluxe version of the Advisor software program, Mutual Max With Style, helps get around that problem and enables investors to engage in a more refined allocation of assets.
Based on the portfolio analysis theory of Prof. William F. Sharpe of Stanford University, a Nobel Prize-winning economist who is not involved with the company, the deluxe software displays the effective style of a fund as determined by comparing its returns with those of selected market indexes. The comparison, made monthly by Advisor Software, sidesteps the need to know the fund's actual holdings.
In addition to examining funds they own, users of Mutual Max With Style can scan the universe of funds to look for those that best fit their needs -- or those they want to avoid. For example, an investor might use the Sharpe analysis to help find the most aggressive of aggressive-growth funds.
Advisor Software also offers Style Data, an Excel spreadsheet, on the Internet to help investors categorize the strategy and risk of mutual funds, set their asset allocation and diversify their holdings.
Mutual Max is not a program for people new to fund investing. Its help files explain how to use the program; they do not explain how to set an asset allocation or determine an acceptable level of risk.
"The program is for the individual investor who has significant investment in mutual funds and is active with a PC," Mr. Hutchings said. "You don't need to be a math major." Still, knowledge of math or portfolio analysis would help.
People who need more elementary mutual-fund software can turn to Morningstar's Ascent or the Value Line Fund Analyzer. Both products teach about allocation and risk, and enable investors to create reports, perform screens, draw charts of fund performance and track individual portfolios.
Mutual Max costs $39.95, and comes with a preloaded data base of funds. Mutual Max With Style costs $94.95, with a funds data base and a style data base. Four quarterly updates of the funds data base cost $79.95, while 12 monthly updates cost $179.95. Four quarterly updates of the style and fund data bases cost $284.95; 12 monthly updates cost $854.95.
Both Mutual Max programs are Windows-based. Information is available on the World Wide Web at http://www.advisorsw.com, or the software may be bought by calling 800 738-6369.
Visitors to the Web site may also look up the returns-based style analysis for individual mutual funds, at no charge. Style Data, the Excel spreadsheet, has the styles of 5,200 funds and is available for $94.95. It will be updated monthly and may be downloaded from the Web or ordered on diskette.
Morningstar's Ascent 2.0, with toll-free technical support, costs $45; with quarterly updates, it is $95, and with monthly updates, $195. It can be ordered by calling 800 735-0700. Value Line has a range of Fund Analyzer offerings -- from $29 for a two-month trial subscription to the No-Load Fund Analyzer, to $395 for a year's subscription to its enhanced CD-ROM program with full data base, monthly updates and access to Value Line's on-line bulletin board for weekly updates. Value Line can be reached at 800 284-7607.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will Bad Loans Kill Japanese Banks?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Can the banks of one of the world's great industrial powers be brought to their knees by bad loans? Will most of them go broke?
Such were the fears that drove American bank stocks into the ground in 1990 -- and in the process created one of the greatest buying opportunities in history for those willing to take a chance on finding survivors. Today, Citicorp shares fetch almost 10 times what they sold for at the 1990 low. 
 Now those fears, after festering for years, are coming to a head in Japan. An index of Japanese bank shares fell 15 percent during the final four days of last week, sending the Nikkei 225 index tumbling. That broader average lost 11 percent of its value, roughly equivalent to the Dow Jones industrial average falling 731 points in four days.
The Japanese bank stock index was not exactly airborne before the latest plunge. Since the end of 1989, it has lost 61 percent of its value. That's just about how far the Standard & Poor's index of money-center banks fell before it hit bottom in 1990. One difference is that that plunge lasted a bit over a year. This one has lasted seven years.
The bearish case on Japanese banks has not changed much during those seven years. They have never really cleaned up their balance sheets after the bubble economy burst. No one knows how many bad loans there are, in part because the commercial real estate market has not been allowed to fall to the point where willing buyers would appear. The Japanese Government has stalled, hoping things will work out.
So far, they haven't, and bears see blood. "I think we are much closer to a meltdown in Japanese financial assets now than we have ever been," says Jeff Uscher, the editor of Grant's Asia Observer.
The current question for the banks is one of capital. Japanese bank accounting is sufficiently opaque that it is not easy to know just how bad off they would be if they wrote off all their bad loans, but the general suspicion is that they would be very bad off indeed. And one source of profits to add to capital -- from selling stock the banks own in other companies -- gets less likely every day the stock market falls.
As in the United States in 1990, the banks' problems are having an impact on the economy. A bank worried about its capital levels is not a bank eager to lend money, and the Japanese economy continues to limp along.
Over the last couple of years, Japanese banks raised billions of dollars in capital with a clever type of security that now appears to be coming back to haunt them. They sold convertible preferred stock, largely to foreigners, on what looked like can't-lose terms. The conversion rate would be reset if the stock fell, but not if it rose. But now one bank stock, Daiwa, has fallen so far that even the reset won't help. And with others not that far from the reset levels, it appears that some holders are scrambling to hedge their positions by borrowing common stock and selling it short. And that tactic only drives down the shares further.
We checked in with Gary Rosenfeld, of Rose Hill Capital Management, who runs a hedge fund devoted to Japanese securities. The plunge, he says, has left Japanese bank stocks oversold and likely to bounce back. "But fundamentally, I'm not sure if there is any real attraction," he added.
Which is the problem with accounting that hides more than it reveals. When people get suspicious, they assume the worst. If Japanese banks are not that bad off, it is time for them to open up enough to prove it.
