The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: January 12, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3067 words

HEADLINE: This Lead Dog Still Barks, but Has a Bit Less Bite

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
LAST month, Robert L. Crandall, the famously combative chairman of American Airlines, sounded a note of conciliation.
In a long interview in which he discussed the airline industry's prospects, as well as his own, the 61-year-old Mr. Crandall talked like a man who had grown more tolerant of a world that has never quite snapped to attention as precisely or as profitably as he wanted. 
 "The passage of time," he said over breakfast during a trip to New York, "has probably made me a little more understanding that you can't always move as rapidly as you'd like."
A stinging defeat last week will put that understanding to the test.
It was supposed to have been a good week for Mr. Crandall, the capstone to a series of bold moves over the last year.
Riding a strong industry comeback from the huge losses of the early 90's, Mr. Crandall trumpeted a big marketing alliance with British Airways last summer, saw his Sabre travel information subsidiary go public in a popular stock offering in October and placed an order in November for more than $6 billion worth of Boeing jets, American's first sizable order since the 1980's.
But Mr. Crandall made the Boeing deal contingent on his winning approval by American's pilots of a four-year contract that union leaders tentatively agreed to last fall. Without the contract, which put a tight cap on wage increases through 2000, the new planes could not be flown profitably and the order would be off, Mr. Crandall said -- a development that would restrict American's future growth.
On Wednesday, the pilots did not blink: by a 2-to-1 margin, they rejected the pact.
With company earnings strong again -- American's parent, the Dallas-based AMR Corporation, is expected to report record profits of about $850 million for 1996 -- the pilots say they are in no mood for raises that lag behind inflation, echoing similar sentiments at United Airlines, where mechanics also rejected a wage offer last week. (Another group of United workers accepted the offer; the outcome of a vote by pilots there will not be known until Friday.) Nor did Mr. Crandall give his pilots much reason to work with him; time and again, he has criticized them harshly in public.
It is anyone's guess what happens next. American says it might wind up scaling back its order with Boeing. Many of the pilots, however, say they are convinced that Mr. Crandall will buy the full order no matter what they do. On Thursday, their union, the Allied Pilots Association, which has about 9,000 members at American, warned of a possible strike if Mr. Crandall did not sweeten the wage offer. To underscore their harder line, union representatives said they would replace the five-member panel that negotiated the rejected deal.
But two things do seem clear.
One is that Mr. Crandall will indeed not be moving ahead as rapidly as he would like, either with the pilots or with Boeing.
The other is that it is hardly the first time he has stubbed his toe in labor negotiations, where his hardball positions are often criticized as counterproductive. He has drawn similar criticism over the years for his lobbying efforts in Washington, where he has also been given to making threats when a policy decision did not go his way.
"Bob has outsmarted his competition, but he does have an unfortunate history of failing to build consensus in Washington and with his work force -- that's been his Achilles' heel," said Clark H. Onstad, a former chief counsel at the Federal Aviation Administration and now a senior executive at Atlas Air, a cargo carrier in Golden, Colo.
Mr. Crandall said late last week that he was disappointed by the pilots' vote. "It's very disheartening, he said. "We negotiated with these guys for more than two years. The agreement is by any objective measure the best contract in the industry."
A spokesman for American, Robert A. Britton, said, "Clearly our goal is to reach an agreement with the union, preferably sooner rather than later."
Boeing apparently is willing to wait, at least for a while, for the pilots and Mr. Crandall to patch things up, although it is not clear how long the company will be able to commit part of its production capacity to the large order without a go-ahead. Under the terms of the now-postponed deal, American agreed to buy planes exclusively from Boeing for the next two decades in return for quick delivery and discounted prices. In a statement on Thursday, Boeing expressed confidence that an agreement with the pilots would be reached in the "near term" and that the plane order would then go forward.
Investors seem willing to bide their time, as well. Shares in AMR were off marginally on the day after the vote, falling $1.50, to $86.625. The stock finished the week at $85.125, down $1.50.
AS Mr. Crandall begins his glide path toward retirement, last week's setback was a fitting addition to the twists and turns of his storied career, a mix of industry milestones and miscues.
Since Mr. Crandall took over as president in 1980 -- he became chairman and chief executive in 1985 -- American's innovations have ranged from frequent-flier mileage to computer reservation systems to sophisticated software for setting fares. "If you're not the lead dog," he is fond of saying, "the view never changes."
But there have been times when he has demanded the lead-dog position and the rest of the team has not followed.
In 1992, he tried to force on the entire industry his so-called value-pricing idea -- a drastic change in the way fares are structured that eliminated deep discounts to big corporate customers. He made no effort to build consensus in advance, and his competitors and customers balked. Within months, he declared the idea dead.
Mr. Crandall, said Mr. Onstad, the former F.A.A. counsel, has had "a large number of imitators, but very few followers."
It is a problem that even Mr. Crandall recognizes. "Nobody wants to hear about it," he says of his opposition to the widespread practice of code sharing, under which two airlines market flights jointly in the computer reservation system. Mr. Crandall says that the practice is deceptive to consumers, who can book a flight on one airline only to wind up on another, and that he has reluctantly joined the trend so American can remain competitive.
Some day, Mr. Crandall said, people will wonder why they did not listen to him.
Plenty of people were listening in the early 80's, when Mr. Crandall instituted a two-tier wage contract, expanded the airline's hub-and-spoke system and invested about $20 billion in new planes and other equipment. Those moves enabled him to expand more rapidly than his competitors. By the end of that decade, the industry was making money and Mr. Crandall was lauded in the media as one of the toughest but most effective bosses in the country. "American Takes On the World," read the headline on a cover article of Fortune magazine in September 1990.
But in the early 90's, a big decline in travel prompted by the Persian Gulf war, combined with overambitious expansion, plunged the cyclical airline industry into its deepest trough ever, causing it to lose billions upon billions of dollars.
American's stock, which reached a high of $107 a share in 1989, tumbled during this period and has yet to recover completely. For some time now, investors have held the company to a different standard from other airlines. While American is widely perceived as a well-run company that occasionally blunders -- sometimes badly -- most other major airlines are viewed these days as in need of a turnaround or as recent turnaround successes. That is why the stock prices of newly rejuvenated airline companies like Continental and UAL, the parent of United, have far outpaced American's in terms of percentage gains.
American is a more steady performer, said Kevin C. Murphy, an industry analyst at Morgan Stanley. "They didn't have much low-hanging fruit to pick."
AT the industry's nadir, in the early 1990's, Mr. Crandall saw labor costs as American's big problem. Those costs left the airline's competitive position so bleak, he said then, that the company might have to shrink sharply and perhaps even largely abandon the airline business for subsidiary operations. The pilots had their own ideas about fixing American, and they commissioned a study in 1993 to suggest ways to run things better.
Mr. Crandall's frustration and impatience boiled over. In a meeting that September with analysts in New York, Mr. Crandall said the pilots' plan would ruin the airline. That plan, never adopted, would have used more American planes for shuttle-type service.
"If the pilots were in charge, Columbus would still be in port," he had said. "They believe the assertion that the world is flat."
Such remarks served only to widen the gulf between the two sides, many industry experts said. And Mr. Crandall, whose analytical skills help him win many a debate, has not been able to convince the pilots of much recently.
"People who want to preserve unnatural work restrictions or unnatural inefficiencies are kidding themselves," he said at last month's breakfast meeting, his first wide-ranging interview in more than two years. "I get very impatient with them."
He added: "My inability to persuade them that their self-interest is oriented toward growth, even if growth has to occur in ways that they think are not optimal, is very frustrating. My frustrations are completely a reflection of my desire to see the airline do more and do better."
American's pilots earn more than most of their counterparts at United States carriers, according to Air Inc., a career consulting firm for pilots. While the American pilots start out low, earning less than $30,000 a year, they can get more than $200,000 a year by the time they retire, at age 60. Over a 30-year career that began in 1996, they would average $125,000 annually (in current dollars), not including other benefits or retirement plans, Air Inc. said. American's profit-sharing plan is also among the most generous in the industry.
MANY pilots said their vote last week was for higher pay and against the company's desire to introduce jets to the fleet of its American Eagle commuter subsidiary, fearing that the planes would be used to take over some of their routes, thereby threatening their jobs. (The pilots at American Eagle are represented by a different union.)
They said the vote was not meant as a rebuke of Mr. Crandall, who, in fact, sent his president, Donald J. Carty, to reach the tentative agreement last fall with the pilots' leadership.
But the pilots clearly have a very personal beef with Mr. Crandall, particularly over his compensation. In 1988, to get him to turn down a job offer from a competing airline, AMR's board granted Mr. Crandall an award of stock, to be distributed in eight annual installments. The stock was valued at $12 million at the time. The value of AMR's shares has increased by more than 150 percent since then.
Since that award was made, Mr. Crandall's regular annual compensation has typically been less than $1 million. Last year, when American's revenues were about $16 billion, he received $662,500 in salary, with no bonus.
Still, many pilots think he is overpaid. A cartoon in the May 1996 issue of their union's magazine, Flight Line, shows Mr. Crandall running an AMR staff meeting. He is pointing to a sign on the wall next to him. Titled "AMR Transition Plan," the sign has an arrow pointing from a dollar sign to a likeness of his face. "Get it from the pilots," the cartoon shows Mr. Crandall saying.
The cartoon is part of a package of articles on AMR executive compensation that includes a time line showing how Mr. Crandall's pay, with the big stock award factored in, was increasing as he was winning concessions from pilots. The cover of the magazine reads: "The Amazing AMR Corp. Magic Show! Featuring Increased Executive Salaries, Record Profits, Large Executive Bonuses. Plus . . . the Newest Trick . . . Watch in Awe as Pilot Pay Cuts Appear Before Your Very Eyes!!!"
"He's getting increases in compensation because of the money he's saving the company," said Glenn Schafer, a pilot who helped to coordinate a lobbying effort among his colleagues to vote against the tentative labor agreement. "Mr. Crandall is a brilliant man, but at a certain point in time it becomes unethical and immoral for corporations to use employees to push downward on wages and working conditions to increase their own compensation," he said.
IN last month's interview, Mr. Crandall said the pilots were way off base. "The idea that I'm going to get individually rich if the company does well just isn't right," he said. "That isn't the way compensation plans are structured. It hasn't happened and it isn't going to happen."
Mr. Crandall received some backing recently when Graef Crystal, the widely quoted expert on executive compensation, wrote an article for the November issue of D, a magazine about Dallas, called "The Most Overpaid (and Underpaid) Chief Executives in Dallas." The section titled, "Why Robert Crandall Doesn't Make Enough Money" has its own cartoonish illustration, showing Mr. Crandall holding out a cup, as a beggar would, by the side of a road.
By Mr. Crystal's calculations, Mr. Crandall's total compensation package, including the stock award, was 69 percent less over the last three years than that of chief executives running companies of similar size with similar profitability.
"By my way of thinking, this is exemplary behavior," Mr. Crystal said in an interview. "He would certainly be a finalist in the Mother Teresa contest of C.E.O.'s in America."
Not that the American Airlines chairman is going soft. Mr. Crandall, a man of exaggerated features, a billboard smile and retro-slick hair, still maintains his Mick Jagger-thin body. He is still driven, even defiantly so -- he runs several miles a day on his treadmill (but refuses to give up his smoking habit). And he still practices the power breakfast, as he demonstrated during last month's interview, sending back his lone English muffin because it arrived buttered. When a new one arrived dry, as he had ordered it, he dug forcefully into a small jar of honey as if he were shucking a stubborn oyster.
"What keeps me motivated more than anything else is pride," he said. "Every day I get up with some idea of what we can do to make the company better." He wants American's earnings to be consistently better than those of its competitors, and he wants the airline to be considered the best in the world, something that he acknowledges he is not yet convinced of himself.
But he has, by all accounts, also throttled back the fire-breathing intensity. Those who know him say that his legendary bark is still there -- and it seems to grow loudest when talking about the pilots -- but some of the angry bite is gone.
In a speech in New York last month, Mr. Crandall -- the man who has likened the airline industry to legalized warfare -- stressed the need for all carriers to work together more effectively. "We must recognize that doing our best sometimes requires cooperation as well as competition," he said.
He is even changing his confrontational approach to Washington. Now, he is trying to build relationships, he said, rather than simply showing up to deliver a forceful message.
Mr. Crandall's wife, Jan, said in an interview that her husband also seemed less rushed these days. "Most nights, he does not want the dinner hour to end," she said. "He wants to sit and talk."
And when he talks, Mr. Crandall often has something interesting to say. He predicted, for example, that the rush by airlines to pair off in alliances will lead to even bigger groupings, providing new opportunities to save money. If, for example, the partner airlines collectively planned their new plane purchases so the cockpits were the same for each type of aircraft, the pilots of each airline could fly one another's planes. That way, the airlines could probably get more use each day out of their flying factories, which would help lower costs.
THIS idea of a simplified fleet was part of the logic behind the big Boeing order by American: one make of aircraft lowers training costs for pilots and mechanics, and also cuts inventory costs for spare parts.
Yes, Mr. Crandall conceded, such sharing of planes could create a logistical and operational nightmare. It also, of course, would be a problem for American's pilots. And how would he sort out the issue of liability in a crash caused by a pilot from one of the other partner airlines?
"Well, life is going to get more complicated," he said. "But life is already pretty complicated."
It can also be pretty frustrating, as he was reminded last week. But perhaps sooner than many people think, Mr. Crandall may put that frustration behind him.
"I have no immediate plan to retire, but I probably won't stay until I'm 65," he said. "There will be a graceful time to leave."
When he does, he will have plenty to do, he said. He wants to improve his sailing skills as well as his singing and piano playing. There is also more gardening to do with his wife And books to read -- particularly histories and biographies.
"Every day of my life after I stop working, I'm going to spend two or three hours reading," he said. "I can't imagine ever running out of things that I haven't gotten to yet."
After American, he said, he is unlikely to work in the airline business again. "My identification with American is so intense, to do anything in this industry would require being competitive with American," he said. "I would never want to do that."
Still, he said that if the phone rang with an attractive offer to run a business part time, he might consider it.
"The only difference between work and play is that work is what you have to do and play is what you choose to do," he said. "They are not necessarily different. Once you 'retire,' you ought to do exactly what you choose to do. I have always enjoyed the business world."
Well, perhaps not always, as when the pilots tripped up his plan to bring some shiny new planes into American's fleet.
"Business ought to be about new programs, new plans and new initiatives," he said. "And when it is, it's fun. When it isn't about those things, it's just kind of boring. You go to work and do what you have to do."

LENGTH: 805 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE LOPEZ WARS
Feel Better Now, G.M.?
Nobody, but nobody, pushes General Motors around: that seemed to be G.M.'s attitude in its four-year fistfight with Volkswagen. Yes, yes, a hotshot G.M. executive named Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua defected to VW, taking with him a few colleagues and, his accusers say, cartons of "trade secrets." But has anyone suggested that VW then started turning out bootleg Chevrolet Cavaliers? That VW drew any serious blood? Well, no. It seemed mainly a pride thing, and G.M. demanded satisfaction -- like an abject apology and, say, $3 billion or $4 billion to ease the pain. Last week, though, it settled for far less: $100 million, still huge by corporate-espionage standards. And did VW apologize? Well, sort of. It acknowledged the "possibility" of "illegal activities."
 
STOCK MARKETS
As the World Turns
The world's financial markets seem to be on a giant seesaw: the more stock prices rise in the United States, the more they fall in Japan. In many ways, the two countries' markets are unrelated. American stocks just keep soaring -- yes, yawn, more records last week -- because they've forgotten how to do anything else, while Japan is plagued by a stagnant economy and bank troubles. But here's one link: American investors have pulled money out of Japan, compounding both the good times here and the bad times there.
 
COCA-COLA
When in Doubt, Redesign
The soda can speaks of timelessness: Coca-Cola "Classic," it assures us. It's "Always." It's "Unique." And the stuff inside most definitely stays the same -- no way is Coke going to mess with that again. But for all the intimations of eternity, Coke just can't stop tinkering with the can. Add a ribbon -- a "dynamic ribbon," if you please -- or subtract a ribbon. Enlarge, or tilt, the photograph of the old bottle. (Why adorn a container with a photo of a container? Oh, you just don't understand.) And now Coke -- probably the world's most recognized brand -- has done it again, introducing yet another look. Does it really imagine that shoppers, poised in the supermarket aisle, muttering, "Coke or Pepsi? Coke or Pepsi? Hmmm. Which has the newest design?" Apparently so.
 
REAL ESTATE
Helmsley, Man and Image
"Helmsley," over the years, has become an odd sort of name, evoking such a jarring mix of images. Here's the overriding image: of truly serious New York real estate, of the empire built over many decades by Harry Helmsley. But then, yes, there's Leona -- first the mighty queen of the spotless hotel, the ultimate in demanding bosses, then the humbled queen, jailed for tax evasion. The rival images maintained a delicate coexistence even as Mr. Helmsley's health faded. (He was deemed unfit to face tax-evasion charges himself.) But with Mr. Helmsley's death last weekend, all the rules have changed. Though some lawsuits remain to be resolved -- and though Mr. Helmsley did leave some pocket change, $25,000, to his long-time secretary -- his widow is practically the sole heir to his $1.7 billion fortune. New York City, meet the undisputed queen.
 
INAUGURAL SHOPPER
Get Your Instant History!
You can feel it. All across the land, Americans aren't wondering when the floods will stop, when that new job will appear, when cancer will be cured. No, they are asking themselves, "What can I do to make the inauguration as lavish as possible?" Well, the Inaugural Committee heard them, took pity on their anguish and called up QVC. So just tune in that shopping channel, and you will have the rare, one-time, golden opportunity to buy, say, a bronze inaugural medallion for just $36. That's $4 off, of course; it would be un-American to buy something that isn't on sale. Then, just think: one day, tears in your eyes, you can tell your grandchildren that, yes, you were there -- that in January of '97, the very month of the second Clinton inaugural, you were sitting in front of your TV set.
 
PRESERVATION
This Land Is Her Land
The idea of owning 51,000 acres in the Adirondacks seems wildly out of kilter -- it belongs to another era. And the vast Whitney estate was, in fact, carved out in the robber-baron days. But it's still there, in the heart of a six-million-acre park, and preservationists have been longing to add it to public lands. It's "the missing puzzle piece," one environmental lobbyist said. Subdividing it would be "the greatest disaster for the Adirondacks I could imagine." But Marylou Whitney, the society-queen heir to the estate, wants to do exactly that. Last week she proposed slicing off 15,000 of those acres and creating what in her circle are no doubt considered low-rent lots: a mere 300 acres each. And, oh yes: you could also buy Little Tupper Lake. It's all a ploy, some critics say, to drive up the price for the obvious buyer: New York State.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
In the Market We Trust

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Common stocks, as such, are not superior to bonds as long-term investments, because primarily they are not investments at all. They are speculations.
-- "Investments and Speculations," by Lawrence Chamberlain and William W. Hay, published by Henry Holt in 1931. 
 The more data we analyze, the more confident we are that stocks are superior long-term investments. In the long run, the true risk resides with fixed-income investments, not with common stocks.
-- "Stocks for the Long Run," by Jeremy J. Siegel, published by Irwin in 1994.
THE American view of financial risks and opportunities has come a long way in six decades.
Four years after Lawrence Chamberlain, a respected investment banker, warned that stocks could not even be deemed an investment, the Social Security system was born as a way of providing an assured means of support for elderly Americans. Money would be raised by taxes on working Americans and, to the extent not needed to pay immediate benefits, invested in safe Government bonds.
In 1935, memories of the 1929 crash were fresh. No one suggested that the road to safety led through buying common stocks.
Now, three years after Jeremy J. Siegel, a finance professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, published his influential book, a commission has recommended to Congress that the Social Security system be partly financed by common stock investments. It split on important details, but on the central thesis it came down solidly with Mr. Siegel: Stocks are safe, for in the long run they always go up. Bonds, including government bonds, whose real value can be eroded by inflation, are the risky asset.
The change has come slowly, with some converting early and some not at all. The stock market gained adherents in the 1950's and 1960's, then lost them in the 1970's, when inflation scared many investors away from all securities, and briefly into such hard assets as gold and diamonds. But since 1982, the start of a bull market with few historical rivals, the academic work showing that stocks are the best long-term investment has gained widespread acceptance.
Accordingly, investors have been willing to pay more and more for stocks, feeling secure in the knowledge that they will do well in the long run, even if prices fall over shorter periods of time.
One way to measure the changing attitudes is to look at the relative level of dividends on stocks compared with interest rates on bonds. Investors have the choice of buying bonds, with a guaranteed interest rate and certainty (barring default) of getting their principal back when the bond matures, or of buying stocks, with a less certain yield from dividends and the possibility that the stock's price could rise or fall.
In the aftermath of the 1929 crash, it became accepted wisdom that the dividend on stocks should be higher than the yield on bonds. After all, investors deserved compensation for taking the risk of falling share prices. In the late 1940's, investors were quite willing to buy bonds that yielded little more than a third of the dividends they could obtain from a diversified portfolio of stocks.
 
 
 
25-Year Recovery
 But as the widely forecast post-World War II depression failed to occur, investors gradually became more and more willing to buy stocks, and stocks became more expensive relative to bonds. In 1954, the Dow Jones industrial average finally got back to its pre-crash high of 381.17. There was nervous commentary, but no crash.
Then, in 1958, there was much hand-wringing over the fact that the dividend yield on stocks was now actually lower than the bond yield. A scary article in Business Week was titled "An Evil Omen Returns." It warned that stock yields had been below bond yields back in 1929, and look what happened.
But it didn't happen again. It was not until the 1970's that stocks again performed badly over a long period. And after prices began to soar again in 1982, academics gradually produced what they viewed as proof that rising stock prices, in the long run, were inevitable. That gospel has been proclaimed in newspapers, personal finance magazines and on countless television shows.
Now the interest you can get on a high-quality corporate bond is about four times the dividend yield on the stocks in the Standard & Poor's industrial average, but most on Wall Street figure that is irrelevant. Companies can return money to shareholders by repurchasing shares, and in any case it is the prospect of rising prices, not dividend income, that draws in buyers. "It's a sea change in attitudes," says Paul Macrae Montgomery, a strategist at Legg Mason, the brokerage house.
"The Jeremy Siegel book hit at exactly the right moment," Peter L. Bernstein, a founding editor of The Journal of Portfolio Management, said last week. Now the expected return from stocks is seen as "a reliable projection," he said. "I think that is just extraordinary," he added.
Last week, in The Wall Street Journal, Jonathan Clements, a columnist, confronted the question of what a parent should do if he had all the savings for his daughter's college education invested in stocks, only to have her go to college in one of those rare periods when stock prices had fallen substantially. Mr. Clements's response: Pay the tuition with borrowed money "while you wait for stocks to bounce back."
Some people are appalled by such attitudes and worry that research "proving" that stocks are the best long-term investments may persuade investors to bid up share prices until they are dangerously overvalued, much as happened in the 1920's.
Mr. Siegel admits that is possible but says share prices would have to rise another 25 percent or so, to perhaps 8,000, for him to be really concerned. Still, he is not enthusiastic about the idea of putting Social Security money into stocks. "Suppose we come to a 10-year period when the return on stocks is not good," he said. "They happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In 1936, Social Security was young, and the nation freshly burned by the stock market.

HEADLINE: The World;
China Grows, Russia Shrinks, Albright Juggles

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
RWANDA, Peru, Serbia and even Cyprus have lately had their share of Washington's fitful attention. But the big game afoot this year for Madeleine K. Albright, soon to be confirmed as Secretary of State, is how to handle relations with two of the world's largest and most insecure nuclear powers: Russia and China.
How Ms. Albright manages Russian weakness and Chinese ambition will help define Bill Clinton's Presidency. With NATO expansion, the hand-over of Hong Kong, trade disputes and imminent summit meetings, Russia and China will loom large on her plate. 
 But as the United States tries to gauge (and guide) the futures of these two transitional powers, Washington is going to have to make clearer choices: Will Russia and China be made truly welcome in the new world of economic interdependence and security cooperation, or will they be effectively excluded? And if they don't want to join, or feel the cost of membership is too high, what are the consequences for American foreign policy?
 
 
 
'Let's Do Lunch'
 These themes ran through the courtly, genial hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week on Ms. Albright's nomination. She echoed, in her careful answers, the official American position that the expansion of NATO is not directed at Russia or meant as provocation to Moscow, with which NATO wants to negotiate a separate security understanding or charter.
As for China, she said, Washington seeks a balanced, "multifaceted" relationship that seeks to envelop Beijing in the larger community of nations, and commit it to a shared set of responsibilities.
But Washington's arguments have not yet proved convincing. In their different ways, Moscow and Beijing still suspect that the Americans are being insincere or disingenuous -- the international equivalent of a cheery, "Let's do lunch sometime!"
After 70 years of distorted and disastrous Communism, most Russians want to be part of the larger European civilization that the czars only belatedly tried to enter, and that Lenin's fanaticism denied them. But after the collapse of the Soviet Union and its expansionist ideology, it is NATO that is expanding. The clear message is that Russia is not really to be welcomed; in fact, it is to be mistrusted and feared.
"Washington won't be able to continue splitting hairs, saying that enlargement has nothing to do with Russia but that a NATO-Russia charter will give Moscow some influence on decision-making," said Leslie H. Gelb, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.
NATO's enlargement and its relations with Russia "is the single biggest security challenge of the next six months," a senior Administration official said. He and other senior American officials say that the Russians are undecided about whether to keep up their fierce opposition to expansion, in the hopes of derailing or delaying it, or to cut their best deal.
Before the Madrid summit in July, when NATO will announce its new members, the official said, "we need to have a package of understandings that makes concrete the rhetoric of cooperation with Russia." But, he said, "the Russians must first decide if they want to solve the problem, and start redefining it, so when expansion happens, which it will, it's not seen as a defeat." This may prove to be too much to ask of Russia, which is bound to feel ostracized, not embraced.
To the rising power of Beijing, conversely, the United States is trying to send an enticing message of welcome, of engagement instead of confrontation or containment. But the Chinese are not yet convinced.
Still Communist, and in the midst of an extended power struggle over the legacy of the silent, but living, Deng Xiaoping, Chinese leaders transmit strong messages about how they aren't really like Americans at all, and aren't at all sure they want to be. They cite cultural arguments about the Asian values of Confucianism and the collective versus Western values of individual rights and democracy, which is in essence a pretext to justify the party's unelected, Communist structure.
But the Chinese are also not convinced that joining the international club, at least as the United States frames it, is in their economic or military interest. This is not just a question of their arms sales to places like Pakistan and Iran, which Washington argues can violate international rules on nonproliferation. Nor is it just a matter of human rights and dissent, the heart of Beijing's worries about maintaining domestic controls in a time of wild economic and regional disparities.
Nor is it an issue of patriotic pride over the return of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, and annoyance that the West still tells Beijing how to handle Hong Kong's future -- which senior American officials say will be "an important benchmark" for relations. Nor is it even about Taiwan. China exercised a rare veto at the United Nations on Friday, blocking peacekeepers from going to Guatemala, because of its ties to Taiwan.
Beijing's internal debate about whether to join the World Trade Organization is for China the economic equivalent of the Russian debate on its future relations with NATO. After 50 years of relative autonomy and a refusal to let the outside world tell it how to run its economy, China is now getting $40 billion a year in outside investment through its "open door." But as Mr. Deng once famously said, the problem with open doors is that you can't stop some flies from getting in.
 
 
 
Membership Has Its Rewards
 President Jiang Zemin has made it clear that China wants to join the W.T.O., but as a "developing country" held to less stringent standards. The United States and its allies say China must open its markets enough to be able to join on "commercially acceptable terms."
Membership in the W.T.O., which is the organization that sets the rules and adjudicates disputes in world trade, has clear benefits for China in addition to symbolizing international acceptance. It would protect the Chinese, who have low production costs, from tariffs imposed by countries trying to protect their own, higher-priced products. But Beijing would also have to open its own protected markets. These issues go beyond the questions about textiles and compact disk copyrights that have already caused problems with Washington..
China would have to stop giving so much help to state-run and predominantly state-owned enterprises. And if another country dragged China to the W.T.O. and argued that tariffs or restrictive rules were protecting those companies from foreign competition, China would have to change or be penalized.
"The U.S. Government is willing to accept China as a major player in the world arena as long as it plays by the rules, whether in trade or human rights," said Stanley Roth, the former Asia director of the Clinton National Security Council and now at the U.S. Institute of Peace. "But does China want to be a normal country? One that plays by the rules and then helps to make them?"
"It's not clear to me they've faced this choice," Mr. Roth continued. "There's an intellectual lag between their economic progress and their ideology. But they won't be able to dodge these choices much longer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher introduced his designated replacement, Madeleine K. Albright, to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Harassment Case Against Clinton Now at Highest Level

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Monday in a case fraught with political peril and potential personal humiliation for President Clinton -- the sexual-harassment suit filed in 1994 by Paula Corbin Jones, a former state government employee in Arkansas.
It is a situation unprecedented in American legal history. No one has ever before filed a civil suit against a sitting President involving his private behavior. This one could force Mr. Clinton to answer questions about his sexual conduct, either in open court or in a written deposition, or it could give rise to a new form of legal protection for Presidents while in office. 
 The Court is to consider not the question of whether Mr. Clinton, then the Governor, asked Ms. Jones on May 8, 1991, as she says, to perform a sex act. It is to weigh a broader legal question: Can a sitting President, any sitting President, be tried while in office, or must the resolution of any civil suit related to private behavior await his term's end.
Ms. Jones's name may not even be uttered by the lawyers on Monday. The proceedings are sure to be formal and dust-dry. But of all Mr. Clinton's manifold legal troubles, none has a greater potential than the Jones case to complicate, even to discredit, his second term, which begins on Jan. 20.
Mr. Clinton's reputation as a womanizer is already an important element in the relatively poor showing he makes in the polls on "the character issue." Bob Dole's late surge in the 1996 campaign came when he switched his attacks on the President from economic policies to questions of personal probity.
But the Jones case has the potential to amplify whispers of scandal into shouts. In a media age, that would damage Mr. Clinton and the Presidency.
The whole issue is suffused with politics. On the advice of Cliff Jackson, a Little Rock political operative with a long history of hostility to the President, Ms. Jones first aired her charges in February 1994 at a Washington news conference sponsored by the Conservative Political Action Conference. One of her lawyers, Gilbert Davis, a former schoolteacher who will state Ms. Jones's case in court, plans to run for attorney general of Virginia, and indeed, he has already pledged to be "a fearless attorney who will fight anyone who does wrong, including the President of the United States."
Mr. Clinton's backers have worked feverishly to discredit Ms. Jones and her suit. James Carville, the President's former campaign consultant, told a reporter, "Drag a hundred dollars through a trailer park and there's no telling what you'll find."
Whatever the merits of Ms. Jones's case -- and an article in The American Lawyer and a cover story in Newsweek have argued that her charges deserve to be taken seriously -- the legal history of the case to date suggests that the Supreme Court could allow the case to go forward before 2001. Even if it does not allow the trial to take place while Mr. Clinton remains in the White House, it could allow pretrial examination now, with the trial postponed.
A Federal judge in Arkansas ruled in December 1994 that a trial, in which Ms. Jones seeks $700,000 in damages for what she says were violations of her civil rights, should be delayed until Mr. Clinton leaves office, but said pretrial testimony could begin sooner. Mr. Clinton appealed, and in January 1996, an appeals panel gave a ruling even more unfavorable to Mr. Clinton, saying the case could go to trial.
In a 1982 whistle-blowing case, Nixon v. Fitzgerald, the Supreme Court ruled that no sitting President could ever be sued for official acts but said nothing about private acts.
Mr. Clinton's lawyers have argued that permitting any phase of the litigation to take place before he leaves office would not only disrupt his conduct of the Presidency but would also open the gates for a flood of frivolous civil suits against himself and his successors. Attorney General Janet Reno said recently, "The Justice Department's position is not that there be immunity, but considering the tremendous burdens on the Presidency, the matter should be delayed until after the service as President."
Susan Estrich, a professor at the University of Southern California Law School who managed the 1988 Presidential campaign of Michael S. Dukakis, said in a debate in the on-line magazine Slate, "This is just one more political assault on the President, politically motivated and politically pursued."
Ms. Estrich said she doubted that Ms. Jones had a case under the civil rights statutes, because by her own account Ms. Jones rejected Mr. Clinton's overtures and he backed off. But putting that aside, she argued as follows on the question that will go before the Court this week:
"A rule that says that if you want to sue the President, do it before he gets elected or wait till his term is done, is one that encourages valid claims to be brought before the election, when they can be considered by the electorate, not afterward."
Stuart Taylor Jr., who wrote the American Lawyer piece, said in the debate that a "day in court" delayed from 1994 until 2001 was not satisfactory. He argued that "while the President's time is a precious national resource," it would not take much of it for him to confirm or deny Ms. Jones's charges under oath, in a deposition his lawyer could prepare for his signature.
Mr. Clinton has two main lawyers in this case -- Robert B. Bennett, a $475-an-hour Washington lawyer with a penchant for public relations, who has represented such clients as Clark M. Clifford, former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, former Representative Daniel Rostenkowski, and Walter Dellinger, the Solicitor General, a former Duke University law professor. Mr. Bennett represents Mr. Clinton, while Mr. Dellinger represents the Presidency.
Mr. Bennett came close to negotiating an out-of-court settlement with Ms. Jones in May 1994, just before she filed her suit. In it Mr. Clinton said he did not challenge Ms. Jones's claim that the two had met in "a hotel room." But the negotiations were torpedoed by leaks from the White House to the effect that Ms. Jones had no case.
On the other side are Mr. Davis and Joseph Cammarata, a pair of relatively inexperienced lawyers from the Virginia suburbs of Washington. They contend that Mr. Clinton seeks to be placed above the law.
"Do we have a nation of kings or a nation where there are truly public servants?" Mr. Cammarata asked. "Or do we have a nation where people are accountable for their own personal, private conduct, or where some, because of their positions of power, aren't accountable?"
Ms. Jones, now married with two children and living in California with her husband, Steve Jones, an airline-reservations clerk, does not plan to attend the Court session on Monday. She says she will give any damages ultimately awarded by the court to charity and has forsworn earlier plans to seek deals for book and movie rights.
Her suit contends that she was invited to the room of then-Governor Clinton at the Excelsior Hotel in Little Rock by Mr. Clinton's bodyguard, Daniel Ferguson. Her account was supported by Pamela Blackard, a co-worker of Ms. Jones in 1991, who told The New York Times in an interview in 1994 that she was at the hotel at the time.
In the interview, which has not previously been published, Ms. Blackard told Sara Rimer, a Times reporter, that Ms. Jones returned from the hotel room "in 10, 11, not even 15 minutes," and said: "He tried to come on to me. I'd push him away, say no. Pam, I'm so embarrassed. I should've known better."

HEADLINE: Landmark in Nantucket's Black History Restored

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NANTUCKET, Mass.

 BODY:
For the better part of this century, the one-room building at one of Nantucket's busier intersections had not looked like much. Its roof leaked. It badly needed reshingling. Its ceiling arched over nothing more historic than bicycles and vehicles that leaked oil.
But eight years ago, having learned that the building once had a central role in the life of the black community here, the Museum of Afro American History in Boston bought the structure for restoration. 
 That work is under way, and the building, once a meetinghouse, a church and a school for children barred from the public schools because of their race, is to be fully open to the public by next year.
Historians and people with ties to the island say what is now called the African Meeting House of Nantucket is more than another historic building in a place that is in its entirety a historic district. The building is a reminder that blacks are not insignificant in the history of this tiny predominantly white resort.
"It's one more tangible link to a past that has really been overlooked for so long on Nantucket," said Nat Philbrick, director of the Egan Institute of Maritime Studies here and a research fellow at the Nantucket Historical Association.
The meetinghouse was built in the 1820's in a flourishing black neighborhood of 274 residents, who constituted 4 percent of the population, compared with 151 blacks in 1990, who made up 2.5 percent of the population, according to the Census.
The construction date makes the house one of the oldest standing structures of its kind in the nation. At the time, Nantucket was a premier whaling port, and the blacks toiled in every aspect of the industry. Some prospered, and at least one whaling ship with a black captain and an all-black crew set sail from the island.
The meetinghouse was a hub for blacks. The daughter of a founder of the meetinghouse, for example, sued for admission to the public high school, and Nantucket, in 1846, became one of the first districts in the country to desegregate its schools.
The blacks were caught up in mainland conflicts over race, as well. Quaker traditions had long made Nantucket an abolitionist stronghold, and Frederick Douglass, the orator and former slave, gave his first public address before a mixed-race audience on the island.
Through such tidbits of history the African Meeting House has given people like Mary Fernandes a peek into unexplored and virtually unrecorded history. Her family, which originated in the Cape Verde Islands, has had ties to Nantucket for three generations. Her family continues to own a house on the island, and she vacations there.
"It's the only structure remaining on island that we believe was essential to the African-American community of the 18th and 19th centuries," Mrs. Fernandes said. "And preserving buildings is sort of like helping to preserve history."
The structure was last used as a meetinghouse at the turn of the century, when the economy shifted and the community that had built it gradually departed. As it fell into disrepair, its lone function was as a garage and a warehouse.
John James, the architect who is supervising the restoration, said when the first phase of the restoration was completed in May, the meetinghouse would look from the outside as it did in its heyday.
Restoring the interior, however, presents a tougher puzzle, as few original fixtures exist. A chandelier that once lighted the room is gone. But a pew door remains, as do the outlines of the pews along walls.
On Friday, a first public meeting was held to begin talking about the role of the meetinghouse. A fund-raising campaign has been started to cover the renovation costs and to provide money for operating expenses.
The executive director of the Museum of Afro American History, Sylvia Watts McKinney, said the only thing certain about the future of the building is that it will be open to the public as a place to learn, probably much as it was more than a century ago and much like a similar meetinghouse operated by the museum in Boston.
"We want to protect," Ms. McKinney said. "We want to restore and we want to tell the story. We want to open the eyes of the layperson who has never imagined that there were African-Americans who made contributions to the Nantucket economy. They built their community. Their community was self-sustaining, and they left something to us."

HEADLINE: Sharp Differences and Compromise Are Likely on Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
With the Presidential campaign over, the economy stable and considerable progress already recorded in reducing the Federal deficit, the Clinton Administration and the Republican leaders in Congress agree that the coming months offer the best, and maybe last, opportunity for reaching agreement on balancing the budget.
But after years of battles over how to do it, Democrats and Republicans still have deep differences on a variety of politically explosive issues that they will have to address to reach their goal of eliminating the deficit by 2002. 
 Those differences are again coming into focus as President Clinton prepares to send his budget proposals for the next five years to Capitol Hill early next month. The Administration's budget -- effectively its opening position in what will be months of political posturing and negotiations -- will call for more spending on Medicare, welfare, education and other social programs than the Republican plan that will be introduced in March.
The Republicans will also continue to call for deeper tax cuts than the Administration. With the White House's plan likely to assume more optimistic figures for tax receipts and spending requirements than the Republican leadership is comfortable with, Republicans have already signaled that they will question whether the Administration's plan is built too much on gimmicks and not enough on fiscal austerity.
"I hope that it will be a real budget proposal," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said last week of Mr. Clinton's coming plan. "I'm not convinced."
Early signs indicate that the two sides are working to accommodate each other. Administration officials said that their budget, the details of which have been tightly held so far, would go some way toward meeting one of Mr. Lott's specific concerns -- that the Administration not call for big spending increases in the first few years of its plan and then require deep spending cuts to be enacted by Congress and the next President after the turn of the century.
"People will find we will have a very smooth, sound path," said one senior Administration official. "It's not going to jig-jag around."
Mr. Clinton is planning to use his State of the Union Message on Feb. 4, to build support for his proposals, which will also fulfill campaign promises that included a $1,500-a-year tuition tax credit for the first two years of college. And Mr. Clinton's advisers are already arguing that the Administration's strong record on deficit reduction in the past four years means the Republicans will not be able to declare the new budget dead on arrival on Capitol Hill.
In the last four years, the deficit has fallen 63 percent, to $107 billion for the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30. That is far lower than the Administration, much less the Republicans, had forecast. The smaller deficit provides the Administration with an opportunity to argue that spending cuts will not have to be as deep as the Republicans have demanded over the past several years.
"It is clear that the budget will be a no-nonsense, clean budget moving towards balance in 2002," one Cabinet member said on Friday. "Our sustained and impressive record of economic growth along with increased discipline on the fiscal side gives you more flexibility, and also gives you more credibility."
The effort will be complicated by the need for Congress to reauthorize tens of billions of dollars in spending on subsidized housing and road-building, multiyear programs that must be accounted for in next year's budget. And both parties look warily at the possibility of saving money by changing the way the Government computes cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security and other benefits programs, a step that could go a long way toward solving the nation's fiscal problems but one that could generate a furious backlash from the elderly and other interest groups.
The first big battle of the season will not be over the President's specific plans, but over the Republican push to approve a constitutional amendment requiring that the Federal Government keep a balanced budget. The Administration is opposed to the amendment, arguing that it could exacerbate economic downturns by making it harder to use Government spending to stimulate a recovery. Lobbying by the White House helped defeat the amendment by one vote in the Senate last year. A two-thirds vote of both houses is needed to send an amendment to the states for ratification.
Proponents of the amendment believe they now have enough firm votes to approve it in both the House and the Senate when it comes to a vote, probably in the middle of next month. Republicans said a victory on the amendment would give them added political strength in budget negotiations with the White House.
As they pursue a balanced budget plan, the two sides will have to bridge differences on the following issues:
THE SIZE OF THE DEFICIT Because they use different assumptions about how fast the economy will grow and what future spending requirements and tax revenues will be, the Republicans see the deficit as being considerably bigger than the White House does.
The Republicans have relied for their numbers on the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, which has told Congressional staff members that its latest projections, to be released later this month, will forecast a deficit in 2002 of about $150 billion. The Administration's comparable number is about $50 billion lower. As a result, the Administration believes spending cuts will not need to be as deep as Republicans assert.
MEDICARE SPENDING Last year the White House proposed reducing planned expenditures on Medicare, the health insurance plan for the elderly, by $124 billion. The Republicans wanted a reduction of $158 billion. Neither plan is likely to change substantially in this year's proposals. While the differences are relatively small in the context of the overall budget, they represent one of the most incendiary of political flash points, and Republicans have not forgiven the Democrats for portraying them during the election as being heartless toward the elderly.
But some signs of compromise are emerging. The White House considered including in its budget an increase in Medicare premiums for wealthy retirees, a step that Republicans would have supported. White House officials decided not to include it, but sent signals to Capitol Hill that it might be willing to consider the increase as negotiations proceed.
TAX CUTS Mr. Lott said last week that he wants a package of tax cuts amounting to between $125 billion and $150 billion, and perhaps more, over the next five years. The Administration's tax cuts would amount to about $100 billion over the same period, an Administration official said, although some of the White House's tax-cutting proposals would be implemented only if the economy performed as well as its current plans assume.
The Republicans are also insisting that Mr. Clinton agree to a deep reduction in the capital gains tax. The Administration supports only a much narrower measure to exempt profits on the sale of most homes from the capital gains tax. But White House officials said they might be willing to discuss a broader capital gains tax cut if it were essential to getting an overall budget deal.
DISCRETIONARY SPENDING Mr. Clinton has already pledged to restore about $14 billion of the $55 billion in savings on welfare spending envisioned by the welfare overhaul legislation Mr. Clinton signed last summer. He has also made clear that he will seek increases or higher levels of financing than Republicans want for education, environmental protection and other social programs. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said he would fight for expansion of health coverage for uninsured children this year.
Some Republicans acknowledge privately that there is little political will for further deep cuts in domestic spending. But they said they would oppose any effort by President Clinton to increase spending for the next few years and push any deep cuts off into the future, for another Congress and perhaps another President to take responsibility for.
"We need no up and then down on discretionary spending," Mr. Lott said in a speech on Wednesday. "Do you think that if we allow discretionary spending to go up for the next two or three years before it starts back down, do you think it's actually going to be coming back down?"

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Despite Interleague Play, the Traditional Statistical Jumble Will Continue

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In 1990, Eddie Murray had the highest batting average in the major leagues of any player who had enough plate appearances to qualify for the league batting championships. But Murray did not win a batting championship.
In 1992, David Cone struck out the most batters in the major leagues, but he was never recognized as a strikeout champion. 
 Rick Sutcliffe won 20 games in 1984, but it took three years for him to be recognized officially as a 20-game winner.
The problem behind these developments and others through the years has been the strict way in which the National and American leagues keep statistics. Maintaining their separate-but-equal stance, the leagues have followed the commandment: Thou Shalt Not Commingle Statistics.
Thus, Murray did not win a batting title despite his .330 average with Los Angeles because Willie McGee batted .335 before St. Louis traded him to Oakland Aug. 29, and his 31-for-113 (.274) performance with the Athletics did not reduce his season average to .324 because it happened in the other league.
And Cone did not lead in strikeouts despite his total of 261 (Randy Johnson was next with 241) because his 47 with Toronto were not added to his 214 with the Mets, and John Smoltz struck out 215 for Atlanta in the National League.
And even though Sutcliffe won 20 games in 1984, his feat was initially ignored because he won 4 of those games with Cleveland and 16 with the Chicago Cubs. It wasn't until the 1987 National League Green Book that he was included in the list of 20-game winners. (The American League Red Book still doesn't recognize him or Hank Borowy, who won 21 games with the Yankees and the Cubs in 1945.)
"Baseball has a rich history of league records," Steve Hirdt of the Elias Sports Bureau said, neither defending nor criticizing the system. "In no other sport would there be a National League record for home runs. It's a recognized record."
But the separate-but-equal, or head-in-the-sand, approach to record keeping is about to suffer the first inroad. Beginning with the 1997 season, American and National League teams will play each other, and those games will not create yet another separate set of statistics.
"Our agreement calls for all statistics achieved in an interleague game to be treated as if they were achieved in an intraleague game," Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said. "Every American League hitter who gets a hit will have a hit for the American League statistics and a National League pitcher who wins a game will receive credit for a victory in the National League statistics."
If a player has a 40-game hitting streak in the National League, Phyllis Merhige, an A.L. vice president, noted, then fails to get a hit in an interleague game, his streak will be considered stopped. If he resumes hitting when his team returns to N.L. games and he hits in 17 consecutive games, he will not receive credit for breaking Joe DiMaggio's record.
N.L. hitters, on the other hand, will be recognized separately in N.L. averages, of all places, for the statistics they achieve as designated hitters in interleague games played in A.L. parks.
Once the traditional record keeping begins to break down, it could lead to more enlightened positions.
"We expect some further discussions before the season," Orza said. He mentioned the possibility of creating a merged leaders' list, such as who has the highest batting average over all or the most home runs or the most victories.
With the advent of interleague play, Hirdt said, it's possible that the sense of league records will eventually be lost. "Over time, if interleague play stays, National League and American League records could become an anachronism," the senior statistician said.
League records could certainly become tainted. If Gary Sheffield hits 57 home runs next season, that will be one more than Hack Wilson's N.L. record. But what if Sheffield hits three of those home runs in Florida's games with the Yankees, the Red Sox and the Orioles?
But the statistics have always been tainted. When Milwaukee traded Greg Vaughn to San Diego last season, he took 31 home runs with him, but when he hit a home run against St. Louis Aug. 5, he was listed as having 1 home run.
In the official averages for the 1996 season, the leagues don't recognize what players did in the other league.
Mark Whiten, for example, played for three teams last season -- Philadelphia, Atlanta and Seattle. The official N.L. averages show Whiten's total record in that league (.243 batting average, 10 home runs, 38 runs batted in), then has a separate listing that breaks down his statistics with the Phillies (.236, 7, 21) and the Braves (.256, 3, 17). The A.L. averages show Whiten's record with the Mariners (.300, 12, 33).
Nowhere, however, can Whiten's entire 1996 performance be found. Someone seeking that information would have to compute it for himself and determine that Mark Whiten -- as an entity and not separate beings in different leagues -- batted .262, hit 22 home runs and drove in 71 runs.

 
 
A New Bid on Antitrust
 On the first day of the 105th Congress last week, Representative John Conyers Jr., a Michigan Democrat, honored Curt Flood by designating his baseball antitrust bill H.R. 21, after the uniform number Flood wore as a player.
Saluting the "courageous" center fielder for his 1972 challenge to baseball's reserve system, Conyers said, "We all owe a debt of gratitude for his willingness to challenge the baseball oligarchy."
Unfortunately, as Conyers introduced his bill, Flood lay in U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles gravely suffering from throat cancer.
The bill, based on legislation approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee during the last Congress, would remove baseball's exemption from antitrust laws as it pertains to players' rights in labor relations. It would not affect the minor leagues or permit franchises to relocate at will.
Orrin Hatch, Utah Republican, is expected to introduce a similar bill in the Senate later this month.
The likelihood of Congress adopting legislation is much greater than ever because the owners, as part of the new collective bargaining agreement, will join the players in lobbying Congress to pass a law removing part of the exemption.

 
 
Tartabull in Limbo
 When Danny Tartabull was a free agent five years ago, no team was offering him more than $15 million. Then the Yankees swooped in and offered $25.5 million. Tartabull could use an angel like that this year.
A free agent again, Tartabull remains unemployed while most other productive free agents are already spending their signing bonuses. His situation, however, is not as bleak as it might appear, his agent said.
"We're talking to three or four different teams," said Rick Thurman, an associate of Dennis Gilbert. "There's a tremendous amount of interest. He's the last outfielder available who can put up some power numbers. We're moving down the line and in the next week or so it'll be very definitive where he's going."
Thurman would identify only one of the teams he said he was talking to, saying the Philadelphia Phillies were "very interested."
How to define "very interested?"
"There is some interest; I don't know how much," said Lee Thomas, the Phillies' general manager, who is looking for a cleanup hitter. "We haven't got into any details. Nothing's hot. It's going to take a while. I'm trying to do some other things. If he's still out there down the road, which he might not be, we might be interested."

 
 
Boggs Happy With Yanks
 Wade Boggs has quietly offered evidence to support his public position that he is not unhappy with the Yankees' decision to extend Charlie Hayes's contract so that Hayes would withdraw his trade demand.
Ed Lynch, the Chicago Cubs' general manager, recently called Bob Watson to inquire about Boggs's availability. Watson told Lynch that the veteran third baseman has a no-trade clause in his contract. "It was just an inquiry," Watson said. "That's where it is right now." But Watson called Boggs's agent, Alan Nero, to let him know about Lynch's call.
"We have no intention of collaborating with anyone on a trade," Nero said. "We have no intention of doing anything. Wade loves New York. The idea of getting traded doesn't appeal to him. He's very happy. He can't wait for spring training to start."
Watson emphasized that the Yankees have no interest in trading Boggs. "We've got a pretty good left-right situation at third," he said.
The Cubs are seeking a veteran third baseman because they want to make sure their good-looking prospect Kevin Orie is ready, and they don't want to put pressure on him. Terry Pendleton, Mike Blowers, Chris Sabo and Dave Hansen are more likely candidates for the job.

HEADLINE: Pataki Offers a Plan to Reduce Property Taxes Paid to Schools

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Calling on the state to assume a greater share of the cost of public education, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed today a five-year, $3.4 billion plan that would cut the property taxes paid by homeowners to their school districts while also increasing state assistance for local education, mostly to New York City.
In a sneak preview of the centerpiece to the 1997-98 budget he plans to release on Tuesday, Mr. Pataki said his school plan would gradually reduce homeowners' property taxes by a total of $1.7 billion by mid-2001, which he said would reduce the tax bill for an average homeowner by 27 percent a year. 
 The plan would also gradually increase state aid to public schools from the current level of $10.3 billion a year to just over $12 billion by 2002, an increase of $1.7 billion. He said New York City would receive a sizable portion of that additional aid, $680 million a year by 2002, which would redress the city's decades-old complaint that it educates 37 percent of the state's students but receives only 34 percent of state school aid.
Overall, Mr. Pataki said, his plan would shift more of the cost of public education onto the state's shoulders, relieving what he called the onerous burden of increasing school property taxes on middle-class homeowners. Renters and owners of cooperative apartments, commercial or industrial properties, would not benefit from the tax-cut program.
The Governor was clearly trying to balance regional politics in the plan, an essential strategy for budget negotiations with the Legislature, which is dominated by rivalries among rural, suburban and urban legislators. The plan's tax-cut portions heavily favor suburban areas where property taxes are highest. But the proposal also offers more school aid to urban areas, particulary New York City, which have consistently complained that they are shortchanged in educational spending.
"School taxes on average rose by twice the rate of inflation during the 1980's and early 1990's," Mr. Pataki said. "We have stopped this dangerous trend, which threatened our middle class and limited our ability to create jobs and opportunity."
Stealing a page from legislation that has been kicking around in both houses of the Legislature, Mr. Pataki also proposed setting a cap on local property tax increases. Under his plan, school boards could not increase property taxes by more than the inflation rate, or 4 percent, whichever was lower. School boards could raise taxes by more than that only if two-thirds of the voters in their districts supported them.
Mr. Pataki did not propose any new sources of revenue to finance the plan. Asked how he would pay for it at a time when the state is facing a projected $3 billion shortage in the $65 billion budget for the coming year, Mr. Pataki chuckled and said that continued economic growth combined with tight controls on state spending would provide all the money the state needed do his plan.
"There's no question we can do it, there's no question we are going to do it," he said. He added that he did not think the state would have to make drastic cuts in any programs or lay off any state workers to balance its budget, even with the new tax cuts.
Democrats greeted Mr. Pataki's plan cautiously, saying they supported the overall goal of reducing local property taxes but were concerned about how to pay for it without reducing state services, particularly if the economic recovery falters. "The Legislature remembers well the lesson we learned from the Wall Street experience of 1987, when the market collapsed and we were forced to cut state schools spending and delay tax cuts," said Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat. "For that reason, the Speaker is skeptical."
Republicans, who have advanced their own $2.1 billion proposal to reduce property and business taxes, were more effusive in their praise. "I applaud Governor Pataki for proposing a bold plan to reduce school property taxes and increase state aid to school districts," said the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County.
Municipal bond analysts and state fiscal monitors raised questions about how the state could afford a new round of deep tax cuts, which would come on the heels of a three-year, $3.9 billion income-tax cut, one that Mr. Pataki pushed through the Legislature in 1995, and a host of smaller business tax cuts enacted since then. Many of those tax cuts are phased in, so their real impact will not be felt for several years. "While we all hope the economy continues unabated growth, there is no assurance that that will happen," said Robert Kurtter, vice president for state studies with Moody's Investors Service, which rates New York State's bonds. "If there is a downturn in the next couple of years it will make paying for the enacted tax cuts very difficult."
School board officials and teachers unions greeted the plan warmly, though they said they wanted to see more details. "It's far more dramatic and far-reaching than I thought it would be," said Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association. "It takes major steps toward equity, mainly for New York City."
While they praised Mr. Pataki's plans to increase state aid to the city's schools, New York City officials also criticized the plan because it offered smaller benefits to city homeowners and nothing at all to its tenants and co-op owners.
"It fails to recognize the residential nature of New York City, where many people are renters or co-op owners," said Thomas McMahon, director of the City Council's finance division. Mr. McMahon said the city would receive only 9 percent of the $1.7 billion in property tax relief.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said: "I don't know if we are getting our fair share of that. I have to see the proposal."
Aides to Mr. Pataki said the plan provided less tax relief to New York City because the property tax burden there, as well as in the state's other major cities, is lower than in the suburbs or rural areas. They also noted that the Governor's plan would give more school aid to the city than to the suburbs.
The Governor's tax-cut plan would give homeowners a $30,000 tax exemption -- $50,000 for people age 65 or over -- that would be used to reduce the taxable value of their property. That exemption would be adjusted against a statewide median value of a home, which is $110,000. That would mean that homeowners in high property value regions like Westchester or Long Island would effectively receive more than a $30,000 exemption, while homeowners in lower value rural regions might receive somewhat less.
Under one scenario, the owner of a home worth $110,000 would use the exemption to reduce the tax burden to $80,000. The owner would pay school taxes on that $80,000, while the state would pay the district the equivalent of taxes on the remaining $30,000. That way, no district would lose any money from the program.
Because the plan would be phased in gradually, its impact would be relatively small in the coming fiscal year, which begins on April 1. Mr. Pataki said he would call for increasing school aid by $302 million in 1997-98 and for cutting property taxes by $110 million.
Under his plan, the Governor would also require local governments to reassess property values every four years, much more frequently than is now typically the case. He would have the state increase its payments to local governments in lieu of property taxes on state owned lands, which represent large chunks of many urban areas.
And he would establish a program worth $240 million by 2002 to encourage school districts to reduce their administrative costs and freeze their property taxes.
The Governor also said he will ask the Legislature to change the complex formula used to allocate state education aid. He said he wants the state to give more money to poor communities, New York City and suburban districts where residents have high property values but moderate to low incomes. Recognizing that the school aid formula is probably the single most contentious issue the Legislature deals with each year, Mr. Pataki said he would push for changes in the future, not in the coming year.
Following a tactic he used last year, Mr. Pataki will offer more glimpses into his budget proposal over the next two days, garnering, his aides hope, positive media coverage before he allows anyone to see the full parameters of his spending plan.
