HEADLINE: Pragmatism Is Supreme at Cabinet Session

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Four years ago when President Clinton wanted to brainstorm with his new Cabinet on public policy he called the officials to the Presidential retreat of Camp David, where professional "facilitators" also led them through an evening group exercise in sharing confidences about major life experiences.
But today when Mr. Clinton held another retreat for the incoming and departing Cabinets, New Age human relations exercises were out and pragmatism was in as the group focused on what Erskine B. Bowles, the chief of staff-designate, called the President's vision of governing "with more limited resources while operating within a balanced budget." 
 This time the Cabinet gathered -- under tight security -- in Blair House, the President's official guest house, which is just across the street from the White House but was considered a somewhat more relaxed setting. And the only one facilitating was Mr. Clinton."The President's pretty good at that himself," Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said recently.
Most of Mr. Clinton's new Cabinet nominees and White House aides have already served in the Administration, although the group now includes a prominent Republican, William S. Cohen, the former Senator from Maine who is the nominee for Defense Secretary.
Mr. Clinton's aides, who briefed reporters at the end of the day, described the day-long private meeting as a set of discussion sessions intended to provoke thought about the challenges facing the Administration, particularly in the crucial next few months, in which the President has an opportunity to set the tone for his second term. The President emphasized that he wanted his Cabinet "to reach out, especially to the Republican leadership" of the Congress, Mr. McCurry said.
The President's inaugural festivities begin next weekend and will be followed in February by his State of the Union Message and his budget proposal for the 1998 fiscal year.
The discussions gave Cabinet members a chance to hear about Administration priorities throughout Government, not just in their arena.
The morning began with sessions on national security and the "new economic architecture of the post-cold-war era," White House officials said. Signaling an Administration push to win bipartisan Congressional support for more money for foreign aid and international diplomacy, aides said that Madeleine K. Albright, the nominee to be Secretary of State, told the group that currently less that 1 percent of the Federal budget will be used to write "50 percent of the history and legacy of our times."
But the discussions also concentrated on the need to reach agreement with Congress on erasing the Federal deficit by 2002. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said Mr. Clinton impressed on his Administration that balancing the budget is "critical to the Administration's credibility."
The Cabinet officials and senior White House aides next moved on to a working lunch with the President and Vice President Al Gore. Hillary Rodham Clinton sat in on all of the day's discussions and Tipper Gore, the Vice President's wife, joined the group for lunch.
The afternoon schedule included sessions on budget priorities and ways to promote rising incomes, better education, preservation of the environment and technology. Richard W. Riley, the Education Secretary, said that Mr. Clinton considered a drive for higher standards in education "one of his top priorities for the next four years." All of those issues were raised by Mr. Clinton in the Presidential campaign, in which he embraced the Republican precept of balancing the budget in seven years even while providing some tax relief. Yet he also provided Democratic grace notes through an emphasis on issues like education and the environment.
With his second term set to begin when he takes the oath of office on Jan. 20, Mr. Clinton has recently held a series of White House events to highlight his campaign call for a $1,500 tuition tax credit to many families for the first two years of higher education and his pleas for corporations and churches to hire welfare recipients. But the first comprehensive look at his second-term program will not come until the budget is unveiled in February.
Today's Cabinet retreat was originally supposed to take place at Camp David and span the weekend, but the session was shortened so the President and staff members could watch the National Football League playoffs on Sunday.
Crandall Close Bowles, the wife of Mr. Clinton's new chief of staff, has an interest in two limited partnerships with investments in the Carolina Panthers. The team will play the Green Bay Packers for the National Football Conference championship.

HEADLINE: White House Plans to Aid Washington, Official Says

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Following President Clinton's pledge last month to help the struggling District of Columbia, his Administration is developing a plan for the Federal Government to assume responsibility for some of the governmental functions that have placed the District in a deep financial hole, a District official said today.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District's nonvoting representative in Congress, said the package would be part of the proposal the Administration will send to Congress next month. 
 Ms. Norton, who has taken part in discussions between the District government and the Office of Management and Budget, said in an interview that while "the pieces are still in play" and no final decisions have been made, the prospect was for "nothing less than a breakthrough" that could put the relationship between the Federal Government and the District on a new footing.
A major ingredient in the package, she said, would have the Federal Government assume all or part of the District's $5 billion in unfinanced liability for public employee pensions. Before Congress gave the District a limited form of home rule in the 1970's, workers for the District's public agencies were Federal employees, whose pensions were paid by the Treasury Department out of annual appropriations without any long-term financing arrangement. In transferring the employees, and the obligation for their pensions, to the District as part of the final arrangements for home rule in 1980, Congress required the District to assume what was then a $2 billion pension liability.
"The District's own political problems have obscured the largest case of unfairness that exists in this country," Ms. Norton said. The District, whose population and tax base has been shrinking, has responsibilities that are handled elsewhere by counties or states, including prisons and Medicaid. Federal assistance with these obligations is also part of the discussions, she said.
At a Dec. 13 news conference at which he pledged the Federal Government would make a "more serious effort" in helping the District, President Clinton referred to a source of the capital's economic problems when he called it "not quite a state, not quite a city, not quite dependent, not quite independent."

HEADLINE: Youth Gangs To Be Target, Clinton Vows

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that in a bid to "break the backs" of youth gangs, he would propose legislation early in his second term aimed at stopping gang members from intimidating crime witnesses.
"Too many people will not testify about gang crimes because they are afraid of violent reprisal," Mr. Clinton said in his weekly radio address. "We must not allow the voice of justice to be frightened into silence by the violent threats of gangs." 
 In the Republican radio address, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said Republicans would press for "permanent tax relief" for Americans in the new session of Congress. He gave no details.
Mr. Lott said Republicans would also act quickly on a constitutional amendment that would require Congress to pass a balanced Federal budget each year. The amendment passed the House two years ago but failed by one vote in the Senate.
Mr. Clinton opposes such an amendment but has said that if it is enacted, it should include safeguards to protect the budget from recessions, when economic slumps would result in less tax money than had been anticipated.
The President's radio address coincided with the release of a Justice Department report that said witness intimidation in cases related to gangs and drugs was hampering the investigation and prosecution of crime throughout the United States.
The report said gang members and associates of defendants often appeared in court to frighten witnesses into not testifying. It said a few jurisdictions, like California, permit the removal of courtrooms spectators who intimidate witnesses.
Mr. Clinton called the battle against youth violence and illegal drugs a priority of his second term and said he would offer legislation in the coming weeks to fight them. "I am determined to break the backs of criminal gangs that have ruined too many lives and stolen too many futures by bringing the full force of the law against them," he said.

HEADLINE: The Laptop Colonialists

BYLINE: By Michael Paterniti; Michael Paterniti has written for Details and Outside. This is his first article for the Magazine.

 BODY:
Out of the sweltering chaos of a saturday night in saigon, david Case bursts into the air-conditioned oasis of the Q Bar, where I'm sitting with a few American expatriates, all in their 20's and 30's, all engaged in some aspect of business in the city. Breathless, dripping sweat, Case falls into a chair, orders a Pilsner Urquell and starts airing out his soaked T-shirt.
"It's like this," he says. "You're on your motorbike, and you have to get to the Q Bar where you're supposed to meet your girlfriend." He checks his watch and gestures to his French-Vietnamese girlfriend, offering her a sheepish hello. 
 "There are a million total maniacs driving out there, the military police are busting people for bribes. Cyclos everywhere and lorries spewing exhaust and beggars with stump arms. Accidents left and right. And, oh yeah, prostitutes and scam artists. Everyone wants a piece of you. It's, like, Saigon: The Video Game."
"Sounds familiar," says a banker named Hung.
"Sounds like a million-dollar joint venture," says Mike, an entrepreneur, laughing. "Write it up as a proposal, and I'll get it to my investors."
This draws an impish grin from Case, who punches his Oliver Peoples glasses back up the bridge of his nose. For many young Americans living in the new Vietnam -- a place that according to The Vietnam Business Journal has sustained an 8.2 percent annual economic growth over the last five years -- the promise of profits in an emerging market laces even the most frivolous conversations. Although Vietnam has spent the last two decades in staggering poverty and without any real infrastructure, and although the country more closely resembles Myanmar than South Korea or Singapore, every day in Saigon teems with new business proposals, meetings and lunches over spreadsheets. Case's imaginary video game, just a whimsical breath of exasperation in a country with one phone for every 100 people, could end up on the first two million computers that will be sold here in the next decade. Recently, in fact, his proposal for a multimedia company attracted a $500,000 offer from an American investor, but Case scrapped the venture, uneasy with the risks over the short run.
You soon discover that everything in Saigon these days is about the short run. Three, five, 10 years tops. Sometimes the future looms no further than a Saturday night.
"So, gentlemen, where are we committing our crimes of pleasure tonight?" asks Mike. After a six-day workweek, the expats are ready to party. The familiar names of wartime Saigon -- the Caravelle Hotel, the Continental, the Rex -- are considered the boring relics of a closed chapter of history. Instead, the millennial foot soldiers of free enterprise travel a network of trendy world-beat clubs, restaurants and brand new bars.
"Saigon is the hippest, most electric place I've ever been," says Case, who has lived in Tokyo, Bangkok and Jakarta, and traveled widely in Southeast Asia. "A lot of people in the States say, 'Wow, don't the Vietnamese hate you?' Or, they tell me they spent the better part of their youth trying to stay out of Vietnam. But Vietnam is not a war anymore, it's a country."
In fact, half of the seven million people who live in Saigon today were born after the war. While our Vietnam iconography still consists of whirring helicopters, carpet bombings and jungle recon missions, Saigon now finds itself in an act of utter re-creation, a proliferating Cubist jumble of neon signs and half-sculpted buildings that rise from the delta as an augury of what the next century could bring. And although the Communist Government has renamed it Ho Chi Minh City and extended its borders to cover a 780-square-mile area from the South China Sea to near the Cambodian border, the city center, one of the most densely populated areas on earth, is still habitually called Saigon by the expats. Just five years ago, the main boulevards had no street lights.
"We were the first place with a working toilet," says David Jacobson, manager of the Q Bar, which opened in 1991. A low-lighted bastion of hipness with velvet curtains and Caravaggio reproductions on the walls, the bar has single-malt Scotches lined up across glass shelves and Tanqueray martinis for $5. It might be any funky, upscale rathskeller anywhere. Which is the point. The Q Bar offers its patrons a familiar Western refuge, and so the faces tend to repeat here each night, mostly fresh-looking white ones smelling of after-shave, crowding the black-lacquer bar.
As a group, these expats are perhaps like none other in history. Raised in an age of global capitalism, they've parachuted into what has long been regarded as enemy territory to try their luck against a wary Communist Government that, after the cessation of Soviet aid in 1991, encourages limited free enterprise. They E-mail home regularly. They do business in Laos and Cambodia. They have their Lonely Planet guidebooks earmarked for boondoggles in Phuket or Bali or Borneo. They gossip about who sleeps with whom, who is stranded in Phnom Penh waiting to get his or her visa renewed and who is bribing the Government to do business here.
The literati of the 20's settled in Paris, the Beats of the 50's escaped to Mexico City and the wanderers of the early 90's overran Prague -- while waves of backpacking expats have set down everywhere from Tangier to Katmandu. Now Saigon has been captured by young capitalists, in the process of creating a corporate bohemia. They are children of the mainstream, graduates of schools like Yale and Stanford, Middlebury and Duke, often from wealthy suburbs. Many have advanced degrees. Many boast that they are here to make their first $1 million.
What Saigon offers in the meantime is a constant party, the prospects of an exotic girlfriend, an easy home base from which to travel and a life among the elite in a country where the average weekly wage is about $12. For the most part, expats make anywhere from $20,000 to $150,000 a year. And if Saigon was once haunted by war, it is now haunted by the paranoia of life in a Communist country. At the Q Bar, the foreigners trade stories of late-night visits from the police or of mail that arrives already opened, of being the victims of daring daylight muggings and having their P. J. Harvey tapes or Details magazines confiscated by cultural customs. Often told with relish, the stories seem to highlight a feeling among the expats that they live in a taboo place, lending their lives notoriety and danger.
"People tried to make something of Prague a few years ago, but there finally was no edge to it," says Bradford Edwards, a California artist who spends half the year in Vietnam. "Saigon is the edge. We're on the frontier. It's a place where state-sponsored Communism and capitalism are colliding head on, and that creates this amazing tension. People come here to try to surf it or see if it will swallow them."
Though precise numbers are difficult to come by, over the last two years about 400 American companies have begun doing business in Vietnam, and about 1,500 Americans have moved to a country where there were virtually none, joining a community of returnees and French, Australian, Chinese and Japanese transplants that number up to 30,000. Their presence, along with that of the British and Australians, has spurred a cottage industry of English-language publications and a slew of support services. Alarmed by the Western influx but wanting economic growth, the Government will soon require work permits for all expatriates.
Several drinks later, we pull up anchor. After stops at the Camargue, El Globo and Cafe Latin, after oysters, tapas and creme brulee, we make the post-midnight pilgrimage to the French-run bar Apocalypse Now. Sandbags are piled in the corners to conjure foxholes, drips of blood-red paint cover the white globe lights and frescoed helicopters buzz from the ceiling.
The room is wall-to-wall bodies: a predominantly Western crowd of investment bankers, young professionals and backpackers mashed together. Around the pool table an elaborate seduction takes place as the regular Vietnamese call girls wait for their chance to play against an eager bevy of men. Meanwhile, on the dance floor, powered by thumping bass lines and flashing lights, more women in hot pants and halter tops dance to Sheryl Crow, LL Cool J and the Fugees, jockeying beneath a single bright strobe light.
At the bar, I talk to Rachel Loeb, a 23-year-old American who surveys the circus with a dispassionate eye. "If you're an expat woman, you're not here to find a man. There are occasionally flings, but everyone, everything is so transitory it's hard. And have you seen these women?" She gestures at the dance floor. "They're beautiful."
"Work and drink, money and sex," is how an American trader later sums up his life with proud weariness. Although the evening is getting late, people continue to trickle in from other bars and clubs, ready to push the party to dawn. Propped against the counter with a vodka in hand, in chinos and a pressed shirt, my new American friend inspects a Vietnamese woman as she walks by, hesitates briefly and, to the remixed strains of "Killing Me Softly," dives into the boisterous crowd after her.
Early on a muggy monday morning, i find myself on the back of Rachel Loeb's motorbike. Loeb works as a specialist for the Central Trading and Development Group, a Taiwanese company with a $600 million plan to build the infrastructure for a new city center called Saigon South. If there are any traffic rules here, they're improvised on a case-by-case basis; Loeb barrels down the street, wafting perfume, her shock of red hair startling the slower drivers. She caroms through traffic circles, gunning her motorbike past cyclos (bicycle-driven rickshaws) and bicyclists with inches to spare. "If I don't get out of this city for a while once every month," she yells over her shoulder, "I start wanting to plow into people."
Loeb is ambitious, uncensored and, like the city itself, growing up fast. If Americans of similar age once landed here knowing virtually nothing of Vietnam, many of the new expats have taken college courses, seen movies or read books about the war, arriving with at least a cloudy impression of the country. Still, with no firsthand memory or experience of the war, it is nearly irrelevant to them, simply part of the mystique.
"Why go back to that hellhole?" one father recently asked his 22-year-old son before he flew to Saigon. "Aren't we still trying to escape it?" If an older generation of Americans failed in Vietnam, then a younger one, in J. Crew garb and armed with high-tech paraphernalia, is returning to master it. "I would say the future of this country lies in the new expat yuppies with their cell phones and laptops," says one Q Bar regular grandiloquently. "We're the ones who can bring them jobs."
As a student at Northwestern University, Rachel Loeb wrote her history thesis on women's roles in Vietnamese culture and spent a semester in the country in 1993. When she graduated, she found herself at a crossroads: "I couldn't think of anything to do in the States," she says. "Or, it was more like no one was going to give me a chance to do what I wanted to do. Sure, I could be living the fat life somewhere, but I wanted to do this on my own. Most of my friends say, 'What's a nice Jewish girl from Kansas City doing in Vietnam?' "
After a few miles on her motorbike, we arrive at a co-worker's house and pile into a van. Besides Loeb and a female American colleague, Ty, who is 24, our fellow carpoolers are older Taiwanese and Chinese men. "My buddies," says Loeb, beaming. Ty, who like many expats asks to be identified only by her first name, works as a teacher for Central Trading's as-yet-unopened international English-language school. "Before I can teach in it, I practically have to build it," she says.
Ty is a Viet Kieu (pronounced Viet Q), one of the more than one million Vietnamese who left the country as refugees during or after the war. She fled Saigon with her family in 1979 and eventually settled in a Miami suburb. Her return, she says, has been filled with moments of exhilaration and paranoia. While the Government generally lets these refugees back into the country, they watch the Viet Kieu closely, suspicious that they might be subversives. "When we left 17 years ago it was because of the Communists, and then suddenly we were coming back to their country," she says. "I was trembling when I came through customs with my mom and sister."
Sipping from cans of Lipton iced tea, battling hangovers from "a little dinner party last night," both Loeb and Ty admit that it has been hard adjusting to Saigon -- "to all these worlds ramming together," as Loeb puts it.
"There's so much randomly happening here it can make you dizzy," says Ty. "Everything plays out on the street. You can't fight it and you can't impose your Western standards on it. You just have to be. The hardest thing for me has been acclimatizing to the poverty." She tells a story about seeing a dead child in the gutter, realizing that it could have easily been her 20 years ago. "I don't know if you ever become immune to it."
While Vietnam remains one of the poorest countries in the world, it is also in a real revolution, albeit a confusing one. In the post-apocalyptic, pre-McDonald's rush of metastasizing Saigon, capitalism in fact already thrives. There are 2,000 international companies settled in the country, thus far mostly manufacturers of goods for export. Factories have grown up like mushrooms; in one cluster south of the city, 51 have been built in the last three years, with 81 more planned. Since 1995, office space has quadrupled, as has the number of taxi companies in the city. Honda sold more than half a million motorbikes last year, and 127 licensed English schools have cropped up where once there were only five. Saigon drives the country economically, responsible for up to 30 percent of its gross domestic product, as well as nearly 30 percent of its revenues.
Still, Saigon has never quite reflected the mostly agrarian culture and Confucian ideals of Vietnam. Greatly influenced by the French and Americans during their respective wars here, plagued by traffic problems and street crimes like mugging and pickpocketing, the city has always been regarded by Vietnamese as a wild cousin on the high wire. To the primly disciplined and more cultured northerners in Hanoi -- most important the country's leaders based there -- Saigon is riddled with corruption and worthy of suspicion, a kind of psychedelic Sodom. It's a place that is so caught up in the now that it creates, at times, the unsavory illusion that there never was a past or a great war to liberate the country from the "colonial powers."
"It's hard to have close Vietnamese friends," says Loeb. "A lot of people just won't let you in. While they're incredibly friendly, they don't necessarily trust you." Loeb's biggest frustration is her isolation, her inability to forge lasting relationships, even with other expats. "Eight of 10 in any group are men," Loeb says. "I miss having close female friends. When Ty and I hang out, we talk girl stuff clothes, boys, sex."
The van crawls through traffic, stopping at an office building, where about half the men disembark. "See you, Zhong," says Loeb brightly, waving. "O.K., bye now Fred, sorry I was late this morning. I'll be a good girl tomorrow. . . ."
Both Loeb and Ty acknowledge that they are anomalies: women in an overwhelmingly male corporate environment, 20-somethings with the opportunities of 40-somethings. And the package isn't bad for a first job: Loeb says she earns $24,000 a year, plus a $4,000 bonus, a plane ticket back to the States and 36 days of paid vacation.
As we pass out of the city center into a newly created district just south of Saigon, the paved roads give way to dirt, children play soccer on a dusty field and a man sells watermelon from his pushcart. There's nothing but flat, marshy delta with a few bamboo huts. Pointing across the wasteland to a clump of mangrove trees, Loeb says, "That's Saigon's future stock market."
Surveying these 6,400 acres, it's hard to imagine that a city has already begun to rise out of the land, a controlled environment of 35-story skyscrapers, retail boutiques, luxury apartment buildings, a civic center, international exhibition hall and a river walk. Even now the rice paddies are being filled, huge concrete sewage pipes litter the horizon and steamrollers have begun work on a grid of roads. Poles with pieces of wood nailed to them stick out of the dirt announcing future thoroughfares with names like Broadway and Market Street. Central Trading claims that, when finished, all of its development projects in the area, including its new $142 million power plant, will increase the industrial output of southern Vietnam by a third while providing housing for more than half a million people.
Central Trading's effort is part of a larger Taiwanese campaign begun five years ago that includes $4.1 billion of financing for 273 projects to date, making it the leading investor in Vietnam. In the nearly three years since America has normalized relations with Vietnam, U.S. companies like Coca-Cola, Ford and General Electric have pledged $1.3 billion for a total of 63 projects, ranking it first among Western investors, though sixth overall. And yet, of the $23 billion pledged, less than one-third has actually been spent, in large part because of the country's tangled bureaucracy and archaic legal system.
Loeb's job, meanwhile, is to lease the metropolis, still invisible. "We're creating a city here," she says, "and I'm selling it to the fund managers and C.E.O.'s of the world. I don't know many 23-year-olds who can say that."
After touring the Central Trading complex -- a warehouselike office building with an outdoor basketball court and pool that sits on the edge of the swamp -- we look out over Saigon South from a sixth-floor deck. Standing in the blistering heat, the wind rustling her hair, Loeb perspires slightly in her lamb's-wool dress. As she takes stock of her empty kingdom-to-be, her eyes come to rest on a ramshackle bamboo hut that lies in the shadow of the complex. "The family that lives there doesn't want to move," she says. "They know they've got something worth money. But, I think we'll work it out."
It's 10:30 on a tuesday night, and again we're at the Q Bar. Hung is telling the story of an American friend who works in finance in Saigon. A group of four neatly dressed Americans sit with us at an outdoor table, drinking beer, watching the traffic whiz by. The streets are clotted with Vietnamese teen-agers and 20-year-olds flirting with one another at high speed, the women in traditional ao dais or designer jeans, a few lucky men reckless on their $2,000 Honda Dream motorbikes, the status symbols of choice these days.
"He's spending hundreds of dollars on this woman," says Hung over the noise, "and he hasn't even kissed her yet." According to Hung, his friend visits what's known as a bia om, or "hugging bar," where for the price of a drink one is entitled to the hugs and whispered sweet nothings of a personal hostess and, depending on the hostess, the promise of sex-for-pay later. As it has happened, Hung's friend has found himself in a predicament out of "Miss Saigon."
"He's fallen in love with this Vietnamese woman at the bar," says Hung, lowering his voice a note. "I mean, he's a 22-year-old kid in love for the first time, and he's like a confused puppy dog. He's not sure if she's a prostitute, and he doesn't know whether he should ask to go with her. So he keeps bringing her gifts."
During the war, drugs were plentiful and brothels blossomed on almost every downtown street, with 100,000 Vietnamese women working as prostitutes. Today opium is outlawed and the brothels are much less conspicuous, but Saigon remains a decadent place. Shimmering with the sultry heat of the delta, the city is shot through with a palpable sense of desire, the sheer aspirations of a culture striving for more than it now possesses. Surrounded by beautiful women in a karaoke bar or nightclub -- where cupidity meets cupidity to the schmaltz rock of a Singaporean band playing cover versions of songs by the 70's soft-rock group Bread -- the expats accept desire at face value, as if the women are truly interested in them rather than in the baubles of their material success. "It's easy to get a big head here," boasts one American in his 20's. "I don't just have one girlfriend. Let's say I have several."
Hung's friend, however, may have more in common with Alden Pyle, the protagonist of Graham Greene's 1955 novel, "The Quiet American." Pyle, employed by a dark organization known as the Economic Aid Mission, arrives in Saigon overflowing with an eagerness to lend a colonial hand and falls hopelessly in love with a prostitute. Seeing him for the first time at the Continental Hotel, the narrator, a cynical British newspaper reporter who happens to live with the object of Pyle's desire, describes Pyle's "unmistakably young and unused face flung at us like a dart. With his gangly legs and his crew cut and his wide campus gaze he seemed incapable of harm."
Minus the crew cut, this is how I see Hung's friend. In the confused sexual milieu of modern Saigon -- one that includes child prostitution fueled by foreign sex-tour operators -- the expats seem to tiptoe around the word "prostitute." Still, it's often understood that a "girlfriend," while perhaps not being paid directly for sex, expects certain perks. Some carousing expats supplement their steady relationships, too, with visits to brothels or karaoke bars. Many don't. But either way, it's not uncommon to see Western men out with Vietnamese women who, speaking only limited English or French, sit silently in the shadow of their boyfriends, nibbling on tiramisu.
"Most of them aren't career women," observes Hung, who himself dates a Viet Kieu woman, an Ivy League graduate in her 20's. "They won't threaten your manhood. They just want to be with you."
"Most of these guys probably couldn't get a date in the States," says Ty, who, like a lot of expat women, tends to date Europeans rather than Vietnamese men. "They come here and buy these big motorcycles -- we call them testosterone cycles -- and they think they're hot, but they're suckers. It's worth it for these women to put their bodies up for a dream of getting out."
While the American men have the luxury of treating their relationships with Vietnamese women casually, the women face a larger set of problems within their culture, which does not look kindly on miscegenation. "If a Vietnamese girl is with you, she's no longer neutral," says Edwards, the artist from California. I don't care if she has a wedding ring and your three Amerasian kids, she's still a whore to her people."
Case recalls a Vietnamese woman who fell in love with an expat banker and spent two years as his girlfriend, expecting to marry him. When the man went home, he broke up with her. Already disowned by her family, she wasn't accepted back into her neighborhood. "She definitely wasn't a prostitute, but I used to see her around, half-trying to pick up Western guys because she had nowhere to go," he says.
There are women in Saigon who own Honda Dreams, have their own apartments, cell phones and a few thousand dollars in cash each month, all compliments of rich boyfriends. "I think I'd be doing the same thing if I hadn't been lucky enough to get out when I was young," says Mei-Lee Dozier, a 25-year-old Viet Kieu. "There's a saying that Vietnamese men are gold and women are cloth. If a man is tarnished, he can polish it off. If a woman is stained, she's ruined."
Often Vietnamese men spit or swear at women who are on the streets with Westerners; to them, mixed couples threaten to unravel the social fabric that has sustained the country through four wars. The Vietnamese Government is also unsettled by these relationships, broadly looking to keep the cultures separate by occasionally cracking down on those nightclubs and bars where expats consort with Vietnamese women.
At the table, Mike -- a 30-ish self-proclaimed "lifer" in Vietnam -- confesses that he's dating a 19-year-old Vietnamese woman. "She picked me up," he says, smiling, then turns suddenly serious. "Eastern morals are different. Look, the Japanese and the Koreans and the Singaporeans are keeping these prostitutes in business. We're not the ones ruining some Confucian dream here." When asked if his girlfriend is a prostitute, he rolls his eyes. "Do I look like I need to go out with prostitutes?" he says. "My girlfriend has a 9 P. M. curfew. But that doesn't mean I haven't discovered what afternoons are for."
The symbiosis between money and sex eventually insinuates itself. Shopping in the antique district one afternoon, I stop at a small gift shop, looking for a wooden bowl. After some difficulty understanding me, the shopkeeper, an attractive woman of about 20 with stylishly cut short hair, asks me to return in a few minutes. When I do, fully expecting that she has found someone to help translate, she has combed her hair, put on lipstick and closed the shop. She leads me to a nearby restaurant, orders fried rice and spring rolls and, after an awkward silence, pulls out a battered notebook, from which she reads faltering bits of conversational English.
Not understanding, I ask to see her book. Scribbled in pencil is a list of questions: What make car do you have? Do you have a stereo? How big is your house? Do you like your television set? And finally: Will you be the one to show me good loving? When I repeat that I'm looking for a wooden bowl, she seems unsure, searching the scrawled lines of her book again. She tries again, enunciating slowly, leaning across the table, half-embarrassed.
"Will you be the one," she says, "to buy me a Honda Dream?"
A day in the life of david case is, by his own admission, "pretty schizoid." Depending on the shuttlecock volley of his mind, the amount of caffeine in his body or the deadline du jour, he is an entrepreneur who works with young girls from the countryside making and selling blankets (partly in an effort to keep them from prostitution), a freelance writer for Reuters covering Vietnam's volatile economic scene, a studio musician in the midst of cutting 10 jazz-influenced pop tracks for the first Western CD ever recorded in Vietnam and a proofreader for the English-language Government newspaper, The Vietnam News.
Case, 31, lives with his French Viet Kieu girlfriend, Elizabeth Nguyen, on the top floor of a colonial house, five airy rooms with tiled floors and ornate shuttered windows, for which they pay $650 a month (average in a city that now ranks as the third most expensive in Southeast Asia). Nguyen, a 26-year-old financial controller who grew up in Paris after her family fled Saigon in the 60's, works for a trading company. Case says he makes somewhere between $15,000 and $40,000, depending on how he spends his time. Their apartment is furnished with wrought-iron couches and chairs with overstuffed white pillows, huge iron-framed mirrors and wood bookcases, all of which Nguyen designed herself and had built by a local craftsman, paying a third of what she might have in the United States.
On the white walls are hung wooden bowls from Hanoi and several Vietnamese abstract paintings, as well as rudimentary pencil portraits that they painstakingly rendered of each other in their "quest to draw," as Case puts it.
On their combined income, they eat about half of their meals out -- enjoying dinners of duck and Beaujolais at one of many French restaurants or lunches at a nearby vegetarian restaurant where, even after vermicelli spring rolls, heaping plates of tofu, beans and rice, a salad and fruit shakes, the bill is still less than $5. The rest of their meals are prepared by a maid, a cheerful Vietnamese woman they pay $100 a month -- about three times the average -- to clean, cook, iron and shop. They also travel often in Europe and Asia. On most Sunday afternoons, after working a 60-hour week, they swim at one of the local hotel pools, where the patrons tend to be visiting Westerners and expats.
Case is articulate, self-reflective and sometimes given to worry. After four years in Southeast Asia, he is conversant in French and Thai but speaks only "taxicab" Vietnamese, as he puts it. It also happens he's a friend of mine from college. When he returns home for the occasional wedding or holiday, he is confronted by the life he has eschewed for the moment, the life of many of his friends: spouses, children, homes, office jobs, budding golf habits, sport utility vehicles.
"A lot of people are paralyzed in the States," he says. "They sit around watching television and accept their situation whether they're happy or not. I'm determined to go out and see if another way of living will make me happy."
Like many foreigners here, Case feels an addictive freedom to try on and discard various identities. For instance, he readily admits that he wouldn't have had the chance to record music in the U.S. or cobble together a decent living with his mixed ventures. This, he says, may have something to do with the fact that there's "no ceiling of middle-aged white guys over your head demanding a resume," as another expat puts it. Given a blank page instead, young Americans are allowed to write their own story.
And yet, while Case, like many Americans in Saigon, seems mostly content, living what he sees as some version of the quixotic expat dream, he still regards himself as a temporary passenger. "I love Saigon, but there are definite downsides," says Case. "My girlfriend had her laptop stolen on the street by some thieves on motorbikes. They dragged her 50 yards before she let go. And then there's this feeling that you're always being watched. A Government official called me and started randomly talking about my yoga. How did he know unless he watched through the windows? Why was he watching me at all?"

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 5; Page 33; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: A Wonderful Place for A Murder

SERIES: This is the first in a series about the link between a city and its fictional detectives.

BYLINE: By MARILYN STASIO; MARILYN STASIO writes the Crime column for The Times Book Review.

 BODY:
THE first time I visited Edinburgh, during a season that the natives laughably refer to as "spring," I nearly perished from the cold and the damp and the icy drizzle that weeps incessantly down the stone walls and cobbled streets of that wind-swept city on the Firth of Forth. Without stopping to unpack the useless clothing I had brought, off I ran to Victoria Street to buy a cashmere turtleneck with a matching tam that came down to my eyebrows and over my ears. Ah, better. My second stop was an antiquarian bookshop on Princes Street, where I spent $10 on an original 1924 edition (eureka!) of "The Fatal Countess and Other Studies" by William Roughead.
That's just the sort of book you want to be reading on a visit to Edinburgh, a proud, lofty city that takes perverse satisfaction in its violent history. Down these cobblestoned streets trundled the burdened cart of those infamous body snatchers Burke and Hare. Through that insalubrious alley lies Tweeddale Court, where Begbie, a hapless bank clerk, lost his life and his purse. At the foot of the Royal Mile that bisects Old Town, in the stately Palace of Holyroodhouse, is the wood-paneled dining room where poor, handsome Rizzio, the luckless companion of Mary, Queen of Scots, was dragged away from his supper to his death. And somewhere beyond the city's gray stone turrets and spires, legend tells of a castle where Macbeth and his cruel lady called the King to come and be killed. 
 Roughead, a distinguished Edinburgh lawyer with an obsessive interest in criminal lore, presented his case studies in "The Fatal Countess" in so seductive a narrative voice that no less a stylist than Henry James became an ardent fan of his "excellent art and animation."
"Bishops, bravoes and panders, poison-mongers and magicians" all played their parts in the infamous case of Lady Frances Howard, the "beautiful and evil" countess who was banished to obscurity in 1616 for the murder of Sir Thomas Overbury, a powerful court insider who was thwarting her ambitions to marry the King's Favorite. In his insinuating style, Roughead goes on to recount all the juicy details of a conspiracy that involved certain "parasitic, prodigal and rapacious" nobility in the "naughty court" of King James. Some said that the King himself was an accessory to the crime. "But as to this we have no certainty," cautions Roughead, who slyly adds, "and his Majesty, like lesser rogues, is entitled to the benefit of the doubt." Now, that's hot stuff.
 Roughead wasn't the only connoisseur of crime to discover in Edinburgh's forbidding architecture and bloody history the perfect setting for "a really good murder." Modern Scottish authors such as Ian Rankin and Quintin Jardine have also made the city their killing grounds and turned to its sinister past for literary inspiration.
 "This is a city," Mr. Rankin takes glum satisfaction in reminding us, "which flayed grave-robbers and made their skins into souvenirs, the capital of a country one of whose kings made a hobby of extracting teeth from his subjects. Nothing I could write about in such a context could ever be considered exaggeration."
 Mr. Rankin's novels take readers down the city's darkest, meanest streets. "Hide and Seek" slouches around the squalid haunts of derelicts and drug addicts. The teen-aged throwaways who hurl themselves off the Forth Road Bridge in "Let It Bleed" take a bleak route from youth shelter to jail to the morgue. And in "Mortal Causes," a torture chamber is discovered beneath Old Town streets, in a warren of stone buildings and passageways buried and forgotten in the 1600's when a plague swept the city.
 "I like to imagine that all my Edinburgh novels are modern reworkings of and critiques upon 'Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,' " says Mr. Rankin, who calls his mordant style "tartan noir." Taking the classic horror story of his countryman, Robert Louis Stevenson, as his literary model suits his theory that Edinburgh has two faces: the stern public face of Calvinist probity trying to avert its eyes from the wild thing grinning from the mirror. To Mr. Rankin, these dual moral personalities suggest that "in writing about Scotland's twisted present, I might be saying something about its past psychoses, too."
 Quintin Jardine isn't as dour a writer or as remorseless a moralist as Mr. Rankin, but his high-tension police procedurals featuring Assistant Chief Constable Bob Skinner will raise your pulse rate. You won't run into Mr. Jardine's rude and vulgar coppers among the Georgian terraces, crescents and squares in the New Town, but they are great companions on a pub crawl. Designated "Best City in Britain for Pubs" by the Good Pub Guide, Edinburgh has more than 700 of these hospitable spots, from elegant Victorian lounges to dark, cozy taverns with fireplaces, so there are lots of book nooks to crawl into.
 My favorite Jardine mystery is "Skinner's Rules," which finds a savage killer preying on strollers on the Royal Mile. Sports enthusiasts might prefer "Skinner's Round," in which members of an exclusive new golf club are being murdered right before an important tournament. Given that Scotland is acknowledged to be the ancestral home of golf, the arbiters of the sport at the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews are understandably put out.
 Spicing the police investigation is the rumor that the killings are the curse of a local witch burned at the stake in the 16th century -- a notion that no superstitious Scot would dismiss lightly. Even Skinner, who is a hard guy, gives the witch-burnings some thought. "The tourist people are happy to sell this country on the back of its golf, beaches and sailing," he notes, "but they keep quiet about the bloodshed and persecution for which it was famous before then."
 If it doesn't stop raining in Edinburgh, you might be ready for side trips. You'll want a couple of bodyguards -- uh, tour guides -- in Glasgow, Scotland's largest, grittiest city. William McIlvanney and Peter Turnbull write uncommonly unsentimental procedurals set on their rugged turf. Mr. Turnbull's cops have a streak of cynical humor ("The reputation for violence and aggression among the Scots is based wholly on the behavior of small men from Glasgow and Edinburgh") and Mr. McIlvanney's detective, Jack Laidlaw, has the voice of a poet and the eyes of a hangman. I leave you in their capable hands, and recommend you begin with Mr. McIlvanney's "Laidlaw" and Mr. Turnbull's "Long Day Monday."
 And should you be bound for the Scottish Highlands (the home of "gentle people," Mr. Turnbull assures us), dump the tough guys and stock up on M. C. Beaton's enchanting series of cottage mysteries set in Lochdubh. The crime rate in this fictional village is so low that Hamish Macbeth, a young constable who "seemed part of an older, cleaner world," spends most of his time salmon fishing. No wonder Ms. Beaton's books sell so well in Edinburgh.
Nonetheless, even if Clinton is wrong in this, he cannot be accused of inconsistency. It's one matter on which he hasn't flip-flopped. He campaigned with a promise to end "welfare as we know it." His D.N.C. and "inventing government" friends had long been advocates of moving people from welfare to work, and so had he. He knows the difficulties involved and granted waivers to 43 states to experiment with different approaches even while they were receiving all the guarantees of the old system. The policy wonk in Clinton loves to test and compare such plans. The states themselves were clamoring for control of their own welfare problems -- even though early experiments showed that it will cost far more money to get work for people than to keep them on the dole.
Welfare, as its opponents paint it, is simply a matter of laziness, unwillingness to work or a culture of dependency. Actually, it is the byproduct of multiple factors not working in synch -- of demography, family breakdown, technology, outmoded or absent training and world trade. Welfare recipients are mainly the dependents of people unequipped for the jobs available (if any), and they are falling even further behind in their preparedness for the kinds of jobs that will soon become available. Welfare was a comparatively cheap way of avoiding confrontation with such issues. Every year makes the problem more complex. Even if we can find work for the unemployed, and fit them to it, it is most often subsistence-level labor with few or no benefits. The states have taken on the task of providing training for jobs, then finding (or creating) the jobs; handling day care for the children left at home when single mothers go to work, and underwriting medical costs not provided to transient workers. If worker training does not succeed, all the old costs of the dole will continue, with the new failed outlays added. It is a daunting prospect for the states, and one they could try to solve by creating far greater problems: cutting off welfare at the end of the time limit even if no jobs have been achieved, bidding each other down to make "undesirables" leave their jurisdiction, leaving the problem to overstrained private charities -- all of which can lead to greater homelessness and crime, to resentment in the poor and repression by the better-off.
The reason Clinton delayed welfare reform in his first two years was precisely the cost, the fact that it is more expensive to end welfare, even under the best circumstances (which may not be present), than to continue it, endlessly deferring the problem. But the priority of deficit reduction made him continue the deferring for three years, and his signature on the Republican bill deferred it by devolving it -- to the states. He promised to "fix" the bill later. It will be the ultimate flip if he fails to make good on that promise -- and he may very well be unable to. In that case, his whole case for government flops.
The bill cannot be fixed just by restoring some of the Federal funds cut by it -- more money for food stamps and aid to legal immigrants are the ones most often mentioned. The bill is about jobs, and unless the Federal Government leads in the effort to achieve this, the bill's central but most difficult mandate, complaints about inequities in the states will mount -- just as complaints about unregulated H.M.O.'s have. Yet the thing that recommended the plan to some -- the ability to use states as laboratories for experiment -- will make it harder, perhaps impossible, for the Federal Government to prioritize the different states' problems and to respond appropriately to the specific failures in widely varying schemes.
Other government problems have run up against the time-consuming and costly problem of adjudicating different claims on their individual merits -- industrial safety cases and civil rights violations are prominent examples. To cut through the complexities of case-by-case investigation, probabilities based on numbers were used in these areas, an anti-bureaucratic measure attacked as using "quotas." But the problem of dozens of different statewide systems of welfare will be far more complex than the issue of safety in one plant or the hiring provisions in one institution. The new plan may be inefficient and still not create the necessary jobs! The probability is that the states will call for more intervention by Washington as their problems mount.
But when they "call the cops," will the cops come? In an ideal world, Clinton could use the states' difficulties to advance programs he is fond of and has promised. National service could be diverted into job training. Work projects to create new jobs could rebuild America's crumbling infrastructure of bridges and roads.
But fiscal restraints promise to be as strict in Clinton's second term as in his first -- not because they are needed as much, with the deficit more than halved, but because they worked so well for him. As Steven Rattner of Lazard Freres wrote last July on the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, the Clinton tax increase to cut the deficit gave him the steady economic progress that was the basis for his re-election. Even with the collapse of the radical Gingrich revolution, a moderate Dole anti-tax campaign could have defeated Clinton but for the rise of employment and our current low inflation, creating the lowest "misery index" (combined unemployment and inflation) since 1968. James Carville and his colleagues, who attacked Clinton's reliance on market advisers like Robert Rubin, were unwittingly fighting against their own earlier slogan: It was "the economy, stupid" that re-elected Clinton in 1996.
The reappointment of Rubin as Secretary of the Treasury indicates that Clinton is not going to bite the hand that fed him -- which severely contracts his ability to feed the poor left at the mercy of the states by the welfare bill. In the case of great suffering, will Clinton live up to his own basic belief in the need for a government solution? I think there is reason to hope for that. Though he is dithering and professorial when facing problems in the abstract or the future, he is a counterpuncher of nerve and concentration when set back, as he has proved over and over, and the personal commitment to solving pressing problems is there. The means may be lacking, but -- one hopes -- not the will.
 IT HAS BEEN SUGGESTED that Presidents in their second term look to their "place in history" by turning to foreign affairs. That may have been true in the cold war, though it is doubtful even there. Truman and Nixon made their historic foreign policy moves (the Marshall Plan and the China opening) in their first terms. Only Reagan turned to arms talks in the second term after neglecting diplomacy in his first four years.
Clinton has been no promise breaker in this area, since he kept his foreign policy promises vague and infrequent. He has been a foreign policy minimalist, doing as little as possible as late as possible in place after place -- in Haiti, in Bosnia, with China. There is much to be said for some degree of disengagement at this point -- which is not the same as isolationism. As Representative Barney Frank has argued, our troops in Europe serve little purpose but to boost economies there and drain ours here. After half a century of cold war, when the whole world's freedom seemed to be at stake in every trouble spot, the impulse to have America keep proving it is "a great power" (the hallowed phrase) by responding to any challenge is, at the very least, wasteful. For one thing, we shall never get our defense spending wrestled back under control if the Pentagon is able to use mission after mission to create new demands on a compliant Congress. Humanitarian aid should be clearly identified as such, and we should cooperate with multilateral peace-keeping instead of tearing down the basis for it at the United Nations. For these purposes the appointment of Madeleine Albright may be misguided -- for the very reasons given by those who praise her toughness. She seems to yearn back toward cold-war certitudes and swagger.
The thing that seems to interest Clinton most in foreign dealings is world trade, and a good thing, too. As the government's basic credibility had to be restored at home by deficit reduction, the basis for stable influence in the world will, of necessity, be economic influence rather than military power. The problem with Clinton's policy is not its aims but his desultory or inadequate explanation of its potential and perils. He fought through GATT and Nafta but did not defend them by recognizing the need for measures to counter their domestic impact, which diminishes or dislocates local industries. A vision of the benefits of trade has not been formulated for the American people. Perhaps Clinton should read "Worldly Goods," by Lisa Jardine, which explains how trade ties reached across ideological and ethnic ties in the Renaissance, creating some elements of a common culture at odds with divisive local causes. The historian William McNeill has pointed to this Renaissance parallel for our post-cold-war world.
Perhaps Clinton will have little leisure for reading, or even policy, if investigations continue to nag at and discredit him -- not least because of his evasive and feckless resistance to demands for information. It would be fitting, perhaps, but tragic if the man who believes so deeply in government is undone by the cops coming for him. But apart from the entirely unproved allegations of illegality, Republicans will gravely miscalculate if they think their path to power lies in the personal vilification of the President and his wife. That has been tried and failed.
Many people wonder why it has failed. Why, despite the public's recognition of grave character flaws, did it not reject Clinton in its ballots for 1992 or 1996? William Powers, in a long article in The New Republic, blames the national press for not building fires of ardent indignation. But, even if that were the task of the media, why should they have succeeded where Senator Alfonse D'Amato failed in his Congressional hearings and talk radio has failed despite its drumbeat of heated, even hysterical accusations?
Martin Walker, the British journalist, answers with an argument that Clinton is "the President we deserve" precisely because he typifies (when he does not anticipate) the hesitations, ambiguities and still undisclosed purpose of his own generation. It is hard for the rest of us to get indignant about his tries at marijuana when few of us can say our families have no members who have experimented with drugs. Newt Gingrich is a lame excoriator of Clinton's lack of military service.
Nor is it easy to dismiss Clinton as an unfaithful husband, as Senator Dole realized when he pointedly declined to exploit that charge (knowing that an account of his own adultery during his first marriage hung over him like the sword of Damocles, to be dropped if he dared bring up the subject). Changed mores, and changed attitudes toward candor about those mores, give the censorious little ground to stand on. This is not the fault of coverage by the political media. Things formally hushed up are now regularly brought to light in areas far away from electoral politics -- in churches, universities, the business and entertainment worlds.
When I was a college student, it was considered scandalous for a faculty member to divorce. Now everyone knows who is sleeping with whom. In fact, Clinton, with his obvious affection and support for Chelsea and his wife, is to be commended for the effort he has given to making a troubled marriage work. A recent cartoon playing on the popular movie "First Wives Club" had a circle of political first wives looking fierce -- the first Mrs. Dole, Mrs. Gingrich, Mrs. Limbaugh, Mrs. Gramm, Mrs. Armey. A long list could be compiled of our prominent wife-dumpers' dumpees -- the first Mrs. Kasich et al.
Clinton's attitude toward marriage is very like his attitude toward government. Both institutions are strained and under assault. Rather than give up on either, Clinton has tried, however imperfectly, to keep them both working. Perhaps that is as much as we can expect in a time of shifting moral winds and divided opinion about the basic values of our society. Does he believe in anything? There is more coherence than may at first appear, both in his private and his public life. Joe Klein's qualified private-public spectrum -- false in one, false in the other -- may even be read backward, as it were, and with similar qualification: True in one, true in the other.

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an essay on Jan. 12 about crime books set in Edinburgh referred incorrectly to a comment by Henry James about a work by William Roughead. A reader's letter received Jan. 23 points out that James died in 1916, before the appearance of Roughead's 1924 book, "The Fatal Countess and Other Studies." James expressed his admiration of Roughead in an exchange of letters between 1913 and 1915. (This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.)
Because of a production error, a picture on Jan. 19 showing Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton in 1982 was printed in mirror image. Hillary Clinton should appear at the left.

HEADLINE: The Cold War Winner?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Jan. 10 Advertising column reports on a new print advertising campaign with the theme that "winning is everything" by Ikon Office Solutions, an office equipment and technology company. It features a statue of Lenin being pulled from its pedestal with a caption reading "Second place, cold war." 
 I await the advertiser who will show a picture of Americans sleeping on the street, of New York City public school children attending class in a bathroom, of hospitals closing their doors, of the proliferating sweatshops in our cities, or of workers downsized onto the unemployment lines -- with a caption reading "First place, cold war."
 
STEPHEN R. SHALOM
Montclair, N.J., Jan. 10, 1997

HEADLINE: Paying Our Dues Won't Fix the U.N. Staff

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your lament in the Jan. 6 editorial "America's Obligation to the U.N." that "an early retirement program for a few hundred U.N. staff members considered less productive was stalled by a lack of funds" leaves the impression that if the United States would simply pay its dues, then funds would be available to implement this worthwhile initiative. 
 In fact, the early separation program exemplifies what is wrong with the United States-led approach to United Nations reform. Who took advantage of this "golden handshake"? For the most part not the "dead wood," but rather people who had grown disenchanted with the system and saw an opportunity to move on. Those international civil servants accustomed to long lunches and comfortable in the knowledge that harder-working colleagues will take up their slack have little incentive to leave.
Young, dedicated and hard-working staff members are also leaving in droves as a result of the United States-imposed financial crisis. It is now routine for valuable non-permanent staff to be offered contracts whose duration is one month. This is not the way to run a corner candy store, let alone the "World Organization." But whose fault is it? United Nations reform needs to be viewed in ways other than the "bottom line." Reducing staff and costs will not necessarily result in a strengthened and more efficient United Nations -- just a smaller and less expensive one.
 
ERIC BERMAN
Executive Director
United Nations Watch
Geneva, Jan. 10, 1997

HEADLINE: A Gold Rush From Software Reinvigorates Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Awash in new, high-paying technology jobs, Silicon Valley is in the midst of its most remarkable economic boom in two decades.
And thanks in part to the rise of the Internet and the scramble to exploit it commercially, the area's growth has been accompanied by a shift in new jobs from computer and semiconductor manufacturing to software development. 
 That change has led some economists to argue that the region south of San Francisco may finally find some stability, escaping the economic roller coaster that has led in the past to seemingly inevitable collapses after good times.
Silicon Valley, which has become the center for much of the innovation underlying the semiconductor, personal computer and now the Internet industries, added roughly 50,000 jobs in 1996, while average real wages grew 5.1 percent after accounting for inflation -- more than five times the national average.
This striking growth, fueled in part by a 73 percent spurt in venture-capital spending, is part of an exceptionally positive portrait painted by an annual review of the region's economy and its quality of life, to be issued on Monday.
"The good news is that in the last four years we have created 125,000 new jobs," said Becky Morgan, president of Joint Venture Silicon Valley, the business and community group that publishes the economic report.
By Joint Venture's parameters, the valley is centered between San Jose and Palo Alto in Santa Clara County. It runs northwest from Santa Clara County into San Mateo County and into southern Alameda County, on the eastern side of the bay, and includes part of Santa Cruz County to the south.
Particularly evident in 1996 was the imprint that the rise of the Internet has left on Silicon Valley. The area is headquarters for the leading companies in the computer-networking business. The 30 largest such companies more than doubled their employment from 1991 to 1996.
For example, Cisco Systems, the San Jose maker of computers that route data over the Internet, hired about 50 employees a week throughout 1996. The company has continued to expand and now has 800 to 1,000 job openings -- the same number as early in 1996.
Still, it is the growth of software companies like Netscape Communications and Oracle that suggests the region's new structure. Traditionally a manufacturing center, it is being transformed.
"The structure of the economy has changed," said Douglas Henton, president of Collaborative Economics, a Palo Alto consulting firm, which prepared the report. "There is much more software, which suggests that the dependence of the hardware industries on the capital-spending cycle may be broken."
Several economists, while remaining cautious, pointed out that because software was less sensitive than computers and chips to corporations' purchasing cycles, the current structural shift might leave the valley far more insulated from the nation's economic ups and downs than heretofore.
"There are indications that the good times will keep rolling for a while," said Stephen Roach, chief economist for Morgan Stanley & Company. But, he cautioned, "I worry about a potential financial bust on the Internet, or a culmination of a software product cycle."
The rise in the software business has brought sharply higher pay in the high-cost region. In 1996, the average wage totaled $43,510 (measured in 1995 dollars), compared with $28,040 nationally. Average annual earnings among software companies, the highest-ranked category, came to $78,400 in 1995. That compared with $74,300 in the semiconductor industry.
The only time the region had added more jobs was in 1978-79, when Santa Clara County alone gained 53,000 positions. That was the period when the modern semiconductor industry became a global force.
The current period of economic strength is all the more remarkable because only four years ago, before the emergence of the Internet, Silicon Valley faced what some described as a midlife crisis, losing factory jobs and venture capital.
Last year, almost all doubts about the area's future seemed to have dissipated, partly because of the explosive growth of "gazelle companies" -- businesses with more than $1 million in revenue and an annual compound growth rate of 20 percent for four straight years. In 1996, the number of these gazelle companies rose to 73; it had been near 40 for the four previous years.
This strong growth has also created a gold rush atmosphere for companies seeking the best talent.
"It's been a firestorm for us," said Stephen Combs, managing partner at Juntunen Combs Poirier, a San Francisco-based executive recruiting firm. "Companies are making what can only be called obscene offers for the best people."
As might be expected, the new growth has also renewed anxiety about its consequences. "1997 is going to be the year that growth concerns re-emerge as a pivotal issue," said Steve Levy, director of the Center for the Continuing Study of the California Economy, an economic research center in Palo Alto. "The rental rates have gone up, and the physical and social limits to growth will be debated anew."
Rental rates increased 23 percent from 1992 to 1996. Median income were up 14 percent in that period.
Since 1992, Silicon Valley has added 125,000 jobs, but only 26,000 new housing units.
To be sure, this has all happened there before, and those who have studied the matter predict that the region's growth will continue to be strong.
"I'm very cautious about saying there are any fundamental limits," said Anno Saxenian, professor of regional planning at the University of California at Berkeley. "If quality of life was all that mattered, everyone would be living in Portland right now."

HEADLINE: The Shift Toward Self-Reliance in the Welfare System

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
During the Depression, when so many people felt vulnerable to poverty, America developed a "one for all, all for one" economic system. New government safety nets like Social Security and welfare came into existence, and corporations took on new responsibilties for the well-being of their workers.
But now this communal system is giving way to a do-it-yourself approach that increasingly requires Americans to make their own way. The proposals last week to revamp Social Security, so that workers finance their own retirements rather than those of their elders, are the latest manifestation of this shift in the American ethic toward greater self-reliance, even for those who don't make ends meet. 
 Other signs are the proliferation of 401(K) savings plans as a replacement for guaranteed corporate pensions, the pressure on American workers to pay health insurance premiums once covered by companies, the rise of special schools and other alternatives to public school education, and the new hurdles to staying on welfare, with the message that the poor can and should lift themselves from poverty.
"We are growing up and we are getting out of the European mode, which is more the welfare state," said Dale Jorgensen, a Harvard economist who applauds the trend. "People are becoming more and more affluent and better educated, and as they do they move toward a more traditional American position of self-sufficiency."
For Mr. Jorgensen and other advocates, a set of propositions has emerged to justify the new system they welcome. The United States in the 1990's is prospering and outdistancing its industrial competitors, particularly Japan and Germany, with their more communal systems, they say. That is largely because so many Americans, less and less certain that the system will protect them, are being forced to rely on themselves. That self-reliance results in "maximum incentives to work," which produce maximum economic growth.
But others say this line of reasoning is a rationalization offered by people who no longer want to share what they have with the growing number of Americans whose incomes are falling behind. The many Americans who have prospered, said Frank Levy, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist, "have caught onto the fact that they can do better if there is no redistribution of income, and since power correlates with income, they are in a position to push the argument."
During the Depression, he recalled, many feared falling into poverty, even if they never did, so they were willing to accept legislation creating benefits that they might someday need for themselves. Now the many Americans who are prospering are less willing to share their prosperity with those who are not as well off, even as income inequality widens, Mr. Levy said.
That worries Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics who, as a young man, witnessed the communal approach take shape in the Depression years. "What I am sad about," he said, "is that just when the marketplace is creating more and more income inequality and we need an efficient, limited welfare state, we are dismantling it."
When Americans are asked about these issues, they tend to give conflicting answers, said Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of DYG Inc., a polling organization. "People feel no one should get something for nothing," he said, "but they also support entitlement programs" that give them back more in benefits than they pay out in taxes. "They are holding two opposing views, without being aware of it," he said. "They have not yet been forced to make a connection."
The opposing views, many experts say, are rooted in very different philosophies. One holds that people can control their own well-being, and through education, training and hard work, can prosper. If they do not, it is their own fault. "We grant adults more dignity when we grant them the right and the obligation to be responsible for their own actions," said David G. Boaz, executive vice president of the Cato Institute.
The other view holds that free markets take unpredictable turns, sometimes plunging even the educated and affluent into hardship beyond their control, not to mention the less skilled and the poor. "When times are relatively good and the world is at peace, there is a tendency to say, 'I can do it on my own,' " said Robert Reischauer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "But when the next Soviet Union arises, or a huge problem develops in how advanced medical technology can be afforded by the average person, then expect a communal response."
Meanwhile, self-responsibility takes hold. The signposts are numerous. The Social Security system, until now, has required each generation of workers to finance, through payroll taxes, the retirement years of their elders. The new proposals would shunt at least some of this tax money into individual accounts that workers would then use to help pay for their own retirements.
In this spirit, the proliferating 401(K) savings plans are gradually replacing corporate pension systems that obligated companies to guarantee workers a certain level of retirement income. Under the rubric of tightening up to survive intense competition, only about 35 percent of the nation's companies pay for all their employees' health insurance, down from 75 percent in 1980.
And companies, withdrawing job security, regularly tell their employees they must take responsibility to train and retrain themselves so they can jump to other jobs elsewhere, if the ones they hold disappear. The proliferation of new jobs in smaller companies, rather than in the Fortune 500 corporations that once were the source of most of the job security and rich benefit plans, accentuates this trend.
Even the proposals to revamp the Consumer Price Index are a step in the direction of self-reliance. A commission of economists appointed by a Senate committee concluded last month that the index overstated actual inflation. If that view is embraced by Congress, then Social Security benefits would no longer rise as much as they do now under a system that links annual increases in these benefits to increases in the C.P.I. Retirees would have to cover the new shortfall with their own money.
But the shift to self-reliance tends to separate the affluent from the less affluent, the educated and skilled from those who are less so, the healthy who are less expensive to insure from the sick. Congress, for example, recently approved an experiment in medical savings accounts that permit people to put aside money in tax-deductible accounts to pay some health care bills, and then pocket the money free of taxes, if it is not spent on care. That encourages people who are healthy and wealthy to pay less into the common pool for health insurance, said Paul Starr, a Princeton sociologist.
Similarly, the rise of charter schools, now legalized in 25 states, and of other alternative school arrangements supported with taxpayer dollars, tends to draw the most gifted, least difficult students away from the public school system. "What we are witnessing in the shift to taking care of yourself," Mr. Starr said, "is the secession of the people who are the best risks and the most advantaged from the rest of the population."

HEADLINE: K. P. Ellickson, 91, A Labor Economist

 BODY:
Katherine Pollak Ellickson, a retired labor economist with a lifelong commitment to the women's and union movements, died on Dec. 28 at the White Sands retirement community in La Jolla, Calif. She was 91 and had lived in Washington until 1978.
Ms. Ellickson was long associated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations and, later, with the merged A.F.L.-C.I.O. 
 She served as executive director of the White House Commission on the Status of Women during the Kennedy Administration.
A native of Yonkers, she grew up in Manhattan and studied economics at Vassar College, graduating in 1926.
She started her career in workers' education at Brookwood Labor College and also did field work in Southern textile mills and coal camps in West Virginia.
She did organizational work for the C.I.O. in the late 1930's and joined its national office as associate director of research in 1942.
Among her duties was liaison with the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
In 1961, she was enlisted to help prepar the President's Commission on the Status of Women and became is executive director under Eleanor Roosevelt and Esther Peterson.
She also assisted in the creation of the Federal Equal Employment Opportunities Commission in the early 1960's.
She retired in 1967 after a brief stint with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
She is survived by a daughter, Margaret Senturia of Brookline, Mass.; a son, Robert C., of Woodbridge, Conn., and three grandchildren. Her husband, John C. Ellickson, died in 1970.

Ford Said to Be in Deal To Sell Budget Rent A Car
Team Rental is expected to announce today that it is acquiring Budget Rent A Car for more than $350 million from Ford, as the big Detroit auto makers continue to flee the car rental industry, which they once dominated. 
 Team Rental, a small public company of used-car outlets and Budget franchisees, would become a big force in the industry. Ford and Team Rental were meeting with lawyers, putting the final touches on the deal, a person close to the talks said. [Page D2.]

A Shift to Personal Security
The one-for-all, all-for-one economic system developed during the Depression, and bolstered by government safety nets, is giving way to a do-it-yourself approach, evident in the recent proposals to revamp Social Security. News Analysis. [A15.]

Results are mixed in two recent news stories, one involving Michael Irvin and Erik Williams, the Dallas Cowboy football players, the other a Colorado couple whose 6-year-old daughter was found murdered in their home. Iver Peterson: Press. [D8.]

Grey's spurning of Domino's was notable because incumbent agencies almost always try to hang onto large accounts when they go up for grabs. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]

A book written by Toshihide Iguchi, the Daiwa Bank trader who lost $1.1 billion in the bond market over a dozen years, is gathering attention in Tokyo's normally low-key publishing world. [D8.]
 
Picket Fences for Net Users
Whether you are sending electronic mail to a sweetheart, buying books on line or browsing for something your mother would rather not know about, privacy and anonymity are rarely guaranteed on the Internet. But help may be available. Taking In the Sites. [D2.]
