HEADLINE: Turning to the Property Tax

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Since before he was elected in 1994, Gov. George E. Pataki has studied with more than a little interest the successes of his Republican colleague to the south, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, whose tax-cutting fervor catapulted her from obscurity to an upset victory in 1993 and national political prominence.
But in proposing on Saturday to use billions of state dollars to reduce local property taxes over the coming four years, Mr. Pataki also seems to have viewed Mrs. Whitman's experience as a cautionary tale. 
 From almost the moment in 1993 when Mrs. Whitman called for cutting New Jersey's income taxes by 30 percent, Democrats have charged that she was setting in motion a dangerous dynamic where the state would be forced to reduce assistance to local governments, putting pressure on them to increase property taxes to maintain essential services, mainly education.
The reality has been somewhat more complex. Late last year, Mrs. Whitman released figures showing that property tax collections had actually slowed somewhat in 1996 from previous years. But what Mrs. Whitman did not mention was that in many towns, tax collections had increased more than in previous years, and 43 had double-digit increases. So the debate has raged on, with Democrats continuing to accuse her of shifting costs onto the backs of property owners.
New York Democrats have leveled those same charges against Mr. Pataki ever since he proposed in 1994, and pushed through the Legislature in 1995, a plan to reduce state income taxes an average of 25 percent. Like Mrs. Whitman, Mr. Pataki released statistics suggesting that such dire predictions were unfounded, noting that property taxes increased in 1995 at the slowest rates in over a decade.
But Democrats say Mr. Pataki has forced the state to freeze or reduce its assistance to local governments and services. A result, they say, has been higher tuition at public colleges, higher transit fares and higher property taxes. While the first two problems might affect mainly urban residents who have traditionally voted Democratic, high property taxes strike at the core of the Governor's political base: suburban homeowners.
"There has been a tax shift," said Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat of Manhattan. "He's vulnerable on real property taxes because the suburbs are his base." She said the Assembly was developing its own figures to bolster its contention.
Mr. Pataki contends, and many economists agree, that cuts in state income tax rates have had little effect on local property taxes. But with the plan he released on Saturday, the Governor can now also argue that even if there have been any unhealthy effects from his income tax cut, he has the antidote.
Under his plan, which will be part of his 1997-98 budget, Mr. Pataki would give homeowners a $30,000 tax exemption -- $50,000 for people over 65 -- that would be used to reduce the taxable value of their homes. Local governments would calculate school taxes on the discounted value of the home and send that bill to the homeowner. Then it would calculate the taxes on the home before the exemption was applied. It would then send a bill to the state to make up the difference. That way, school districts would not lose any money from the program.
The plan would be phased in over four years, costing the state only $110 million in the coming fiscal year, but growing to $1.7 billion by 2001. When fully in place, the plan would reduce the average homeowner's property tax bill by 27 percent, or $450 a year, the Governor said. Mr. Pataki has not made clear how he would pay for this plan other than by relying on an improving economy.
The plan would provide less tax relief to New York City homeowners than to homeowners in other parts of the state, largely because the city's residential property tax rate is lower than in many suburbs or rural towns; the city relies more heavily on other taxes, like those on commercial and industrial properties, to pay for schools. The tax exemption would be available only for homes and condominiums and not for commercial or industrial property or cooperative apartments.
Mr. Pataki said there were no political calculations behind his latest tax-cut plan. But he clearly seems sensitive to the Democrats' charges of tax shifting, as was evidenced in a news conference on Saturday. Without having been asked a question, he testily told reporters, "A lot of you have been printing the nonsensical rhetoric of the Assembly about how the income taxes have shifted the burden to the property tax."
"There has not," he continued, "been a shift of the tax burden, as we have led the nation in cutting income taxes."
The property tax, most of which is used to finance education, is probably the most vilified tax in the state. Though Mr. Pataki and other Republicans often rail against high state taxes, New Yorkers pay close to the national average in state taxes, as calculated as a percentage of income. But when local property taxes are factored in, New York shoots to the top of the list. Indeed, during the last decade, local property taxes rose about 6 percent a year on average, nearly double the rate of inflation.
In many towns, taxpayers have begun to revolt, rejecting more and more local school budgets in recent years, said Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association. Such taxpayer anger has pressured school districts to keep the lid on expenses, which has resulted in significantly smaller property tax increases than in the 1980's, he said.
The anger has registered in Albany. Though not as visceral as the taxpayer revolt in California during the 1970's that resulted in Proposition 13, taxpayer protests in New York have led to a host of bills sponsored by lawmakers from both parties. Some of those bills even resemble Proposition 13, which placed tight restrictions on the taxation powers of local school boards.
One of Mr. Pataki's proposals would prohibit school districts from raising property taxes by more than the inflation rate, or 4 percent, whichever is lower. School districts could circumvent the cap only if two-thirds of the voters supported them in raising taxes.
With so many property tax plans now in play, and with the Governor having elevated the issue to the top of the legislative agenda, leaders in both houses of the Legislature now predict that some form of property tax relief seems inevitable this year -- even though no one has explained yet how the state will pay for it.
"It's just a question of how much and in what specific areas," said the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer. "It's where the public is."

HEADLINE: U.S. Machine Tool Orders Fell in November

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
United States manufacturers decreased orders for machine tools in November for the second month in a row, while demand from abroad rebounded, industry figures show.
United States orders for machine tools dropped 22.8 percent during the month to an estimated $647.0 million, the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association said today. In October, machine tool orders totaled an estimated $838 million. Demand fell in four of the five regions the industry groups use to chart United States machine tool orders, everywhere except the South. 
 For 1996 to date, estimated consumption totaled $7.7 billion. No comparison with 1995 year-to-date figures is possible because the industry groups switched their method of calculating orders in August 1996.
Machine tools are used to shape and assemble metal in products ranging from diesel engines to dishwashers, and orders tend to decline during November.
The industry estimates are extrapolated from actual orders placed by American manufacturers with United States and foreign companies. They are intended to give a more complete outlook than actual orders, which are lower because not all companies report their transactions.
Actual machine tool orders declined 6.9 percent to $420.79 million in November from a revised $451.95 million in October, the industry groups said. Total units ordered fell 7 percent to 3,108 during the month from 3,342 in October.
Demand for machine tools from abroad, counted separately from domestic orders, rose 4.8 percent to $41.7 million in November from $41.2 million during October.

HEADLINE: Look to Weather for Clues to Malaria Comeback

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Malaria Makes a Comeback, and Is More Deadly Than Ever" (front page, Jan. 8) captures the multiple factors -- population movements, chemical resistance, lapsed public health vigilance and environmental change -- influencing the resurgence of malaria. Mosquitoes, the transmitters of the disease, are indeed quintessential opportunists and adapt readily in disturbed environments. 
 As co-author of the World Health Organization report discussed in your article, I offer several recent findings. Consistent with model projections that global warming could hasten the geographic spread of malaria and dengue fever, these devastating diseases are now occurring at high altitudes in Latin America, central Africa and Asia. Cerebral malaria has occurred in Nairobi, Kenya, while dengue fever is found in the mountains around San Jose, Costa Rica.
Moreover, highland malaria and dengue fever are occurring in the context of upward migration of plants on many continents and summit glacial retreat in Latin America, Europe, central Africa and Asia. A recent study in the journal Nature confirmed that the freezing levels in the mountains have indeed shifted upward about 500 feet since 1970, representing a warming of close to 2 degrees Fahrenheit.
As we enter a year of debate concerning climate change (the convention will be held in Kyoto, Japan, in December), it is prudent to examine the potential consequences associated with continued warming and climate instability. Your article says that malaria "hinders economic development"; epidemics are growing ever more costly in terms of health, development, trade and tourism.
While the resurgence of infectious disease has multiple social, biological and environmental roots, meteorological factors may play an increasing role in the future. We may be vastly underestimating the social and economic damages associated with epidemics and extreme weather events as well as the potential benefits to society as a whole of changing our environmental and energy policies.
 
PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D.
Boston, Jan. 8, 1997
The writer is associate director of the Center for Health and the Global Environment at Harvard Medical School.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Lars Leetaru)

HEADLINE: In Trying to Get Into Cuba, CNN Hits Snags at Home

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 12

 BODY:
As president of CNN, Tom Johnson has been through his share of tough negotiations with governments before. But nothing, not even dealing with China's Stalinist bureaucracy when he sought to set up a news office in Beijing, prepared him for the difficulties of getting permission to open a bureau in Havana.
 
 This time, though, the problem is not a recalcitrant Communist dictatorship: Cuba granted the network permission to begin operations in Havana more than two months ago. Instead, it is the Clinton Administration that is hemming and hawing as it debates the wisdom of allowing American news organizations to establish a permanent foothold in Cuba, the object of an American economic embargo for 34 years.
 "This has been a very long and difficult process, and of course we are somewhat concerned, to put it mildly," Mr. Johnson said in an interview here Friday. "That the United States Government would resist in any way the opening of an independent news bureau by an independent news organization seems to us to run counter to all that this Government represents."
 Administration officials, however, say they are responding in part to what they describe as concerns expressed by "constituencies" interested in Cuban affairs. That, they said, includes rival news organizations worried that CNN will gain a competitive advantage and distressed that Fidel Castro will have the right to grant or withhold access to Cuba to American news organizations.
 That issue came to a crossroads Friday, when Mr. Johnson flew here from Atlanta to meet with David Lawrence Jr., publisher of The Miami Herald. The meeting came about after Mr. Johnson sent a letter to Mr. Lawrence on Tuesday, criticizing him for conducting what he called a "campaigning to convince the U.S. Government to block" CNN's request to open a Havana bureau.
 "I am astounded and dismayed that for purely competitive reasons you would call upon the U.S. Government to hinder CNN's legitimate news coverage efforts," Mr. Johnson wrote. "Your stance is contrary to your long record of support for a free press and the First Amendment."
 CNN says it is required to obtain a United States Government "license" to open operations in Cuba because the economic embargo, which was codified and extended last year by the Helms-Burton Act, strictly limits, and in many cases prohibits altogether, the sums American citizens and corporations can spend in Cuba. The network's bid to open a Havana bureau has been endorsed by press groups like the American Society of Newspaper Editors and the Committee to Protect Journalists.
 If successful, CNN would be the first American news organization to have a bureau in Havana since the Cuban Government expelled the last resident Associated Press correspondent in 1969. Under the present system, American news agencies, newspapers, magazines and television networks must apply for short-term visas to cover Cuban news events case by case.
 In a telephone interview after the meeting with Mr. Johnson, Mr. Lawrence said that The Miami Herald had never opposed CNN's effort to open an office in Cuba and that "I think he understands that now." CNN executives were under that impression, Mr. Lawrence said, because "they misheard or misunderstood some things in Washington" arising from The Herald's own efforts to open a Havana bureau. CNN is owned by Time Warner.
 "My concern for several years now is the Fidel Castro will ultimately 'choose' whom he will let cover Cuba, who will get a news bureau," Mr. Lawrence said, reading from a letter he wrote in November to James Dobbins, the National Security Council director for Latin America. "If we were shut out while other U.S. media outlets emerge in Cuba, that would run deeply counter to my sense of democracy and fairness."
 The Herald, which is owned by Knight-Ridder, has long sought increased access to Cuba, but has often been thwarted because Cuban officials object tot he substance and tone of the newspaper's coverage. More than half of all Cuban-Americans live in South Florida, and coverage of Cuban affairs is a major part of The Herald's news coverage and the backbone of El Nuevo Herald, its daily Spanish-language edition.
 "We think the news media ought to be able to report from Cuba, and we think the newspaper that for decades has covered Cuba more closely than anyone else and with more resources ought to be there as early as possible," Mr. Lawrence said. But, he added, "we never opposed CNN and we stand as tall as anyone for the freest access to covering anything anywhere in the world."
 Of CNN's competitors, ABC said it had no comment on the issue, and a spokesman for NBC was not available for comment. But Lane Venardos, CBS's vice president for news and special events, said he supported the CNN bid and hoped it would help open the door for other American news organizations. "We want to be in there, too, and our interest goes beyond CBS News to include our cable network in Spanish," CBS TeleNoticias, Mr. Venardos said.
 Most Cuban exile leaders here has insisted Cuba must grant access to radio and TV Marti - Spanish-language outlets owned and operated by the United States Government - as part of any arrangement in which private media organizations would open offices in Havana.
 Cuban exile groups have been especially critical of CNN's coverage of Cuba, in part because of the friendship between Ted Turner, the network's founder, and Mr. Castro. Mr. Johnson dismissed accusations that CNN is soft on Cuba as "offensive personally and professionally," saying "we are not pulling any punches in our coverage."
 Even if all this opposition is overcome, there still remains the task of winning over the White House. "The issue remains as it was," an Administration official said late Friday. "CNN made an application and it is under consideration. There's no requirement to make a decision."
 Mr. Johnson said he had already talked to Vice President Al Gore, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and his designated successor, Madeleine Albright, House Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott.

GRAPHIC: Photos: No American news organization has had a bureau in Havana since Cuba expelled the last Associated Press correspondent in 1969. So reporters like Bernard Shaw, the CNN anchor, have often had to save their interviews for Fidel Castro's rare trips out of Cuba. (George Bennett; Angel Franco/The New York Times) (pg. D8)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
What Bibi Got

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Benjamin Netanyahu spent most of the last few months trying to show the world that he was negotiating with the Palestinians in good faith. Now he faces the job for which he was elected: either show Israelis that he can give them a peace with security for themselves and their country, or in decent time tell them that it cannot be done, not now and probably not for many years to come.
Mr. Netanyahu said before he was elected he would work within the framework of the Oslo agreement signed by the defeated Labor Government, and which he mistrusted. That meant giving up major West Bank towns, including Hebron. He got somewhat more security for those 400 Hebron Jews who believe it is not a crime for Jews to live in one of Judaism's holy cities. 
 But to make future talks worth holding, he needed conditions on how to go on from Hebron -- specific and internationally publicized steps of reciprocity from the Palestinians. To get that he paid a price.
Assuming the agreement is approved by Yasir Arafat, who has been walking away from it for about two months, Mr. Netanyahu agrees to a final deployment from the West Bank by September 1998 -- almost a year before he wanted.
There is nothing approaching agreement on how much of the West Bank the Israelis will leave. Eventually that and Jerusalem will be the make-or-break issues.
Mr. Netanyahu and his supporters see territorial negotiation as a matter of survival -- time to spot and mobilize against attack. He is likely to insist on military control of at least 40 percent of the West Bank outside the towns -- much high ground and almost all the Jordan Valley. Labor would have settled for lots less -- how much it never said.
Still, if Likud signs any territorial agreement it is in effect consenting to creation of an independent Palestinian state. Mr. Netanyahu can call it an "entity" if he wishes. He can call it gefilte fish. It will be a state.
But he got what he needed to continue talking peace and keep good faith -- with his own people. That is the conditions of reciprocity that would make the talks believable to the 56 percent of Israeli Jews who voted for him.
They are set down in a "note for the record" by the U.S. team led by Dennis Ross. They commit the Palestinians to do things they promised at Oslo but have never carried out, nor been under any world pressure to do so.
Israeli sources say that as of late yesterday they were:
* The dismantling of the terrorist superstructure in Palestinian-controlled territory. That either means disarming Hamas, Islamic Jihad and similar groups or means nothing.
* Really, truly, at last scrapping the death-to-Israel covenant of the Palestinian movement.
* Reducing Palestinian armed forces to the one police organization of 18,000 allowed by Oslo -- not the half-dozen military groups that Mr. Arafat created with 45,000 men.
* Extraditing terrorists in Palestinian custody. Twelve of the 27 terrorists on Israel's wanted list are wearing Mr. Arafat's police uniforms now and most of the others walking free.
* Closing offices outside Palestinian-controlled territory. Most important: no longer using Orient House in Jerusalem as a foreign office.
* Stopping the constant verbal incitements against Israel by Palestinian officials, Mr. Arafat on down.
If Mr. Netanyahu gives up any of these conditions he may kill chances of majority support in his Cabinet.
For its part, Israel commits itself to a preliminary redeployment and the beginning of final-round talks, both within two months. It agrees to consider these steps: stopping closure of its borders against Palestinians as an economic punishment, release of current "security" prisoners, free passage between Gaza and other Palestinian-controlled territory, and a Gaza international airport.
Egypt and other Arab states will have fascinating fits if Mr. Arafat lives up to reciprocity conditions. They know that it would remove Palestinians from the constant state of political warfare against Israel that has been basic Arab strategy for a half-century.
So I doubt Mr. Arafat will live up to reciprocity conditions for long. But whatever he decides, ending the anti-Israeli political war will remain an underlying condition for ever turning peace talks into peace reality. That has been written in blood, so long.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Touches High vs. Mark After U.S. Support Is Affirmed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a 28-month high against the German mark and rose in most other currency trading yesterday after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin reaffirmed his support for a strong dollar.
It was the first time this year that a Clinton Administration official has reiterated the longstanding United States position on the dollar, and came against a backdrop of growing global demand for the currency. 
 The dollar was also helped by Hans Tietmeyer, president of the Bundesbank and chairman of the Group of 10 central bank governors group, who said current exchange rate levels between the dollar and European currencies were not any cause for concern. His comments in Basel, Switzerland, were interpreted as a signal to buy dollars.
Both Mr. Rubin's and Mr. Tietmeyer's remarks helped the dollar build on gains made on Friday, when the Labor Department reported a healthy growth in jobs last month and bolstered a view that the United States economy was vibrant while Japan, Germany and much of Europe look relatively vulnerable.
The dollar is now at the strongest level against the mark and Swiss franc in more than two years and hovering near a 45-month high against the yen.
"There's a growing realization that the economy here in the United States is being managed awfully well, combined with greater degrees of disappointment elsewhere in the industrialized world," said Kevin Raphael, manager of foreign exchange at the New York branch of Rabobank Nederland, a large Dutch bank. "Money keeps finding its way to the United States."
The dollar traded as high as 1.5925 marks in intraday dealings, the highest since August 1994, before it settled in late New York trading at 1.5886 marks, up from 1.5855 marks on Friday. The dollar rose to 116.44 Japanese yen from 116.06 yen and was unchanged at 1.3765 Swiss francs. The British pound slipped to $1.6739 from $1.6807.
Mr. Rubin's remarks at a conference in Washington became the main focus of the day. Asked by reporters to comment on the dollar's strength, he said: "Our comment is the same that it's always been. We believe a strong dollar is in our economic interest."

HEADLINE: Bonds Fall In Advance Of New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices slipped yesterday, as investors awaited reports on consumer prices and retail sales.
Signs that the economy continues to be robust have weighed on the market recently. On Friday, bond prices tumbled by more than one and a half points following a report that twice as many jobs as expected were added to the nation's payrolls last month. Bonds later recovered more than a third of their losses. 
 Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the market was more cautious. "People are playing the market from a more defensive posture than they were two weeks ago," he said.
Yesterday, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 2/32, to 95 20/32; the bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.85 percent, from 6.84 percent on Friday.
There was some short-covering and some portfolio shuffling, but the potential for gains was limited as investors used any rise in price to sell before the release today of data on consumer prices and retail sales.
"A lot of investors who are watching things would like to reduce their exposure, because signals of a strong economy are starting to stack up," said Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at the New York office of I.D.E.A., a British financial consulting firm.
Investors fear that such signals -- which could suggest a revival of inflation -- make it more likely that Federal Reserve policy makers will raise short-term interest rates when they meet early next month.
Bond prices fell yesterday even as the dollar continued to climb. The strength of the dollar had bolstered hopes in the bond market that foreign investors would continue to buy Treasury securities. But some are now growing skeptical.
"We are at a crossroads," Mr. Regan, the Josephthal strategist, said, "in that continued foreign investment in the Treasury market may not be as significant as we saw last year.
"With so much much certainty swirling, few people are willing to step up to the plate," Mr. Regan added.
Given the negative mood of the market, heavy issuance of new corporate debt is also expected to weigh upon Treasury prices. Some $5 billion of corporate debt is expected to be priced this week, led by a $2 billion to $3 billion offering from U S West; $1.3 billion offered by Tenet Healthcare and $1 billion by Tokyo Electric.
Elsewhere in the market, interest rates at yesterday's Treasury auction were mixed, with the results about average and with a slightly positive tone.
The average discount rate for a three-month bill was 5.04 percent, up a couple of basis points from the previous week's results, while the average rate for the six-month bill remained unchanged at 5.11 percent. Traders said demand was a bit softer than last week, but still healthy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Income Up at Morgan and Nationsbank

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Several of the largest American banks, including J. P. Morgan & Company and the Nationsbank Corporation, said yesterday that their earnings rose strongly in the fourth quarter.
Nationsbank, the fourth-largest bank in the country, said its profits surged 24 percent, while J. P. Morgan, the fifth-largest, said its earnings rose 14.5 percent. Earnings at the National City Corporation rose 48 percent, while those at Barnett Banks Inc. increased 8.3 percent. 
 "They were all at least as good as expected," said Moshe Orenbuch, a bank analyst at Sanford Bernstein Inc. "Revenue growth has slowed, but remained healthy, and expenses were pretty much under control."
Analysts said they expected American banks to continue their five years of record earnings, benefiting from a steadily rising economy, a bull market in stocks and cost controls.
Even losses on consumer loans, which have been a drain on earnings in recent quarters, may show signs of improving as banks tighten underwriting standards, they said.
The results at J. P. Morgan, which reported strong earnings in nonlending activities like securities underwriting and trading, suggest that other banks with big securities operations, like Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, are set to report healthy profits. J. P. Morgan, said net income rose to $419 million, or $2.04 a share, from $366 million, or $1.80, in the last three months of 1995. That beat analysts' estimates of $1.69 a share, according to a survey of 17 analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc.
In the last few years, Morgan, which is based in New York, has become one of the top 10 players in securities underwriting, advising companies on mergers and other businesses once reserved for securities firms like Merrill Lynch & Company.
Securities trading revenue surged 39 percent in the quarter, to $512 million. Revenue from proprietary trading -- in which the bank bets its own money -- jumped threefold, to $76 million. Equities trading revenue jumped 77 percent, to $69 million. Investment banking fees jumped 75 percent, to $277 million. Net interest revenue from loans and other investments, by contrast, fell to $484 million from $488 million.
J. P. Morgan shares rose $2.75, to $102.50 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Nationsbank, which is based in Charlotte, N.C, said its earnings gains were driven by increased lending and fee-based businesses and by cost cuts. Nationsbank said net income rose to $632 million, or $2.19 a share, from $510 million, or $1.87 a share, in the corresponding period last year.
Wall Street expected $2.13 a share, based on the average estimate of 27 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
The bank said net interest income, or income from lending, rose 12 percent, to $1.61 billion. Noninterest income -- including revenue from fees for mortgages, investment banking and other services -- increased 13 percent, to $958 million.
Nationsbank shares fell 37.5 cents, to $102.875 yesterday on the Big Board.
National City, which is based in Cleveland, said net income rose to $191 million, or 85 cents a share, from $129 million, or 58 cents, in the last three months of 1995. Analysts had predicted earnings of 84 cents a share, according to a Zacks survey. Barnett, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., said net income rose to $149.8 million, or 77 cents a share, from $138.3 million, or 69 cents, in the last three months of 1995. That exceeded the average analyst expectation of 74 cents a share, according to a Zacks survey.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
1996 changed the way Americans think about stock funds.

BYLINE: By Edward Wyatt 

 BODY:
IT might not have been the biggest year ever for the mutual fund industry, but 1996 certainly transformed how Americans think about mutual funds that invest in the stock market.
Including $13.5 billion of net inflows to equity funds in December, as estimated yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, mutual funds that invest in stocks received $223 billion in new cash from investors in 1996. 
 That surpassed by more than 70 percent both the previous record for annual equity cash flows, set in 1993 at $129.6 billion, and 1995's net inflows of $128.1 billion. For stock and bond funds combined, last year's inflow was $237 billion; the record was $243 billion in 1993.
Most surprising was the degree to which the level of fund flows held up in the second half of the year, even after several bouts of short-term stock market volatility caused net inflows to drop considerably from the first half pace.
In each of the year's first five months, monthly net inflows exceeded $20 billion, a level never reached before this year. By comparison, December's estimated $13.5 billion of cash inflows seemed relatively small. But while December's total was the second lowest of the year, it nevertheless ranked in the top 20 months of all time.
"In the first half of the year, there was an enormous amount of money chasing performance," said Jessica Bibliowicz, an executive vice president at Smith Barney and head of its mutual funds group. After the best-performing funds of 1995 -- those investing in small-cap stocks -- tumbled in the market downturn of June and July, some investors got spooked, Ms. Bibliowicz said. "But cash flows from other types of investors, like those in 401(k) plans, gained strength through the year."
Bond funds, too, seemed to gain a bit of strength throughout the year. Although monthly flows wavered between positive and negative for much of the second half of 1996, the total flows for each of the last two quarters were positive, with the December's flows alone more than four times those of the third quarter.
In December, bond funds took in an estimated $3.5 billion, the most since January of last year. Last month's flows included sizable conversions of bank trust assets to mutual funds, the institute said. But excluding the conversions, the estimated flow to bond funds in December was nevertheless in line with November's inflows of $1.3 billion.
For the entire year, net cash flow to bond funds totaled $13.9 billion. That was higher than in 1995, when bond funds suffered net outflows of $4.7 billion, but was far short of the record for annual inflows, set in 1993 at $113.8 billion.
"It strikes me that much of what we saw last year was reflective of relative returns," with the stock market greatly outperforming bonds, said John Rea, chief economist of the Investment Company Institute.
Ms. Bibliowicz agreed. "Cash flows in the second half reflect a broader diversity of funds," she said. "More people are interested in asset allocation funds" and other, more conservative products.
Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, a newsletter published in Santa Rosa, Calif., estimates that so far in January, that trend has continued, with more conservative growth and income funds getting the largest share of new cash. So far in January, cash has flowed into equity funds at a monthly rate of about $20 billion.
But Charles Biderman, president of Trim Tabs Financial Services, which publishes the newsletter, said he still wondered about the continued sustainability of cash flows. "I think by the end of the month, flows will fall off again," he said.
Some analysts think even December's estimates of cash flow are overstated. AMG Data Services had been estimating that equity funds took in no net new cash in December and might have suffered outflows of up to $2 billion. Robert Adler, president of AMG, said yesterday that he stood by that estimate and questioned whether the I.C.I.'s report accurately reflected the effect of fund company distributions.
Both AMG Data and the I.C.I. say their estimates exclude the effects of dividends and capital gains distributions that are paid to investors near the end of the year and often reinvested.
Mr. Adler -- while he is still awaiting reports from three large fund groups, Merrill Lynch, Franklin/ Templeton and American Funds -- said, "I am very confident of our numbers." The I.C.I will report its final report on December cash flows near the end of the month.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Stocks Are Favored" tracks net flow of investors' capital into or out of mutual funds in stock funds and in bond funds, from 1984 through 1996. (Source: Investment Company Institute)

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Academy's Role In Renewal of Downtown

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
For many years after its revival in the 1970's, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's hulking neo-Renaissance opera house floated like a cultural and financial island on the outskirts of Downtown Brooklyn.
Even as it forged an international reputation as an incubator of the avant-garde, featuring works by Robert Wilson and Peter Brook, critics and supporters both agreed that its success did little for the blighted area around it, scarred with shuttered stores and graffiti. 
 William Murray, a spokesman for the academy, remembered that as recently as a few years ago, "you couldn't even get a decent cup of coffee around here."
But in the last decade, millions of development dollars have begun to transform the area. With the changes has come a debate over what role BAM, or other urban cultural centers like the one being built in Newark, can play in improving their surroundings and attracting commercial growth.
At best, the relationship is indirect, experts say. "I think it has been a catalyst in the area," said Ron Schiffman, a former New York City Planning Commissioner and director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development. "But it's kind of a chicken-and-egg thing. At one time, both the neighborhood and the academy flourished. When the area decayed, it decayed. It's back now, and the neighborhood around it is starting to change."
Even critics agree that in the last decade, the academy's president and executive producer, Harvey Lichtenstein, has directed more of its programming and its business toward Brooklyn, drawing on the large number of professional jazz musicians in nearby Fort Greene and spending more in the borough.
The academy is now undergoing a $20 million city-financed reconstruction project to put in a cafe, a bookstore and movie theaters, which Mr. Lichtenstein hopes will make it more of a community gathering place or, in his words, "a hangout center."
Business owners in the area, like Michael Ayoub, who runs Cucina restaurant on Fifth Avenue, are waiting to see if those hanging out also stay to eat and spend money in Brooklyn.
"Already, when there's a big BAM performance, my restaurant is packed at 5:30 in the afternoon," Mr. Ayoub said. "It makes me feel like an ambassador for Brooklyn, in a gastronomical sense."

HEADLINE: Prime Lot Near Times Sq. Is to Be Site of a New Hotel

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a deal to develop the largest remaining parcel of land in the Times Square redevelopment area, private developers will build a 35-story budget-rate hotel on what is now a parking lot on Eighth Avenue opposite the Port Authority bus terminal, state officials said yesterday.
The agreement, between government development agencies and Milstein Properties, a family-owned development company that bought the site in 1983 for $5 million -- a fraction of its present value -- would end a long and litigious battle in which the Milsteins had held out for the kinds of property tax breaks that others on the same block had received. 
 It would also resolve longstanding questions over what should be built on the site. Previous proposals have been for a merchandise mart, which some officials hoped would be built by the Kennedy family, and an apartment building.
"This is really the final piece of the 42d Street puzzle," said Charles A. Gargano, the chief economic adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki.
Mr. Gargano said the agreement, which remains at a preliminary stage with some financial conditions still to be worked out, would help anchor the revitalization of the western part of 42d Street and encourage developers to move farther west.
The prospects of expanding investment in the blocks west of Times Square were underscored in a separate announcement yesterday by the New Second Stage Theater, a production company, which said it planned to renovate the second floor of a 70-year-old Art Deco building at the northwest corner of 43d Street and Eighth Avenue. The groups said the space would be used for musicals and other productions.
Still, the agreement with the Milstein family seemed likely to provoke criticism from officials who think the city and state have already reached too far into the public treasury to lure developers to Times Square, and maintain that no more tax breaks are needed now that the neighborhood has become a magnet for large private investment.
"This property is owned by the Milsteins, who could develop it in accordance with normal land-use procedures," said State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat who has long criticized public subsidies for Times Square development. "My question is why any incentives are necessary."
Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said yesterday that the scale and type of subsidies had not been agreed to in final form, but that they were likely to include real estate tax abatements. The subsidies would come from the city, he said.
Mr. Gargano said the tax breaks would be smaller than other Times Square developers have received because the Milsteins will be building long after 42d Street turned the corner from its days as a symbol of urban decline.
"It will add up to some little incentives," Mr. Gargano said. "Nothing more than we have to give."
He said the agreement would contain financial incentives to encourage the Milsteins to begin construction quickly, probably by the end of the year.
"What the Giuliani administration wants is to see this project happen sooner rather than later," he said.
The Milsteins' hotel project differs from other large-scale Times Square projects -- like the office building under construction for Conde Nast, and the Disney Company's renovation of the New Amsterdam theater -- because those projects involve land and buildings that have long been owned by New York State through its powers of condemnation.
For more than a decade, the Milsteins fought in court to stave off condemnation of their site. In the process, they held title to an otherwise derelict parking lot during a time when its value skyrocketed because of the improvements and real estate investments taking place around it. In recent interviews, real estate analysts have estimated that the state would have to pay over $35 million if it sought to condemn it.
Instead, according to the officials involved in the negotiations, the Milsteins have agreed to a form of friendly takeover of their 42d Street property by the state in exchange for tax breaks and other public subsidies that will increase the profitability of its hotel once it is built. Mr. Gargano said the state would pay "a token amount" to take title to the land, and in turn the Milsteins would retain control of the property and their new building through a long-term lease with the state.
The Milstein family, headed by Paul Milstein, 74, and Seymour Milstein, 76, declined to comment through a spokeswoman yesterday. But their agreement seemed likely to bring them a highly profitable victory in their long battle.
The developers, while fighting the state's efforts to condemn their property, have repeatedly been rebuffed in their attempts to play a major role in the Times Square renewal project.
In the early 1980's, they were rejected in their bid to develop four office towers at the intersection of 42d Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue. Then, in 1995, they were passed over by the state in their bid to combine the development of their site across the Port Authority with the construction of a hotel at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Now that they have apparently won a place in the Times Square project, Mr. Gargano said the Milsteins would be required to build a hotel that conforms to the style and business mix of the area.

HEADLINE: Serbian City Said to Rebuff Opposition On Election

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Jan. 13

 BODY:
 The local electoral commission in Serbia's second-largest city has balked at fulfilling a Government promise to honor election results and give an opposition coalition control of the city, opposition leaders said today.
The electoral commission's rebuff in Nis was symptomatic of the internal squabbling that has spread throughout Serbia's Government, Western diplomats said. 
 Several diplomats cautioned that the refusal did not necessarily mark a reversal of the Government's position. They suggested that it might signal instead a weakening of control from Belgrade and a continued rejection by hard-liners for a peaceful solution to the two-month-old political crisis in Serbia.
The decision by President Slobodan Milosevic to annul opposition victories in 14 of Serbia's largest 19 cities, including this capital, set off eight weeks of daily street protests. In the largest demonstration yet, more than 300,000 protesters filled the center of Belgrade tonight, gathering partly to celebrate the Serbian New Year.
The pressure on the Government, both internally and from Europe and the United States, has increased in recent days. Even Greece, which stood by Serbia during the Balkan war and is considered its closest ally, has called on Mr. Milosevic to honor the November vote. The economy also continues to crumble, with the Serbian currency, the dinar, steadily losing ground on the black market and most of the huge government factories working at 10 or 20 percent capacity.
"I think Serbia is on the border of financial disaster," Carl Bildt, the top international envoy in Bosnia, said today in Sarajevo.
The local electoral commission in Nis has called for a rerun of the local elections in nine Nis districts. The opposition coalition says it won 41 seats in the 70-seat city council. Serbia's Government says the coalition holds 38 seats, and the local electoral commission said today that the coalition had only 32 seats.
"There is no logic in this," said Zoran Zivkovic, leader of the opposition coalition in Nis.
The opposition today also called on the army and the police to support the protests, after reports in the independent media that hard-liners were campaigning in the Government for a crackdown.
"Top officials of the Socialist Party of Serbia and the Yugoslav United Left are demanding that the police use force to crush demonstrations in Serbia," the Zajedno coalition said in a statement, referring to the two-party alignment that runs the country.
The statement said the two parties were seeking to provoke conflicts and impose an official state of emergency in Serbia.
"The coalition therefore demands that the General Staff of the Army of Yugoslavia and the Serbian Interior Ministry protect the citizens and state interests of Serbia," which it said were being "openly attacked and jeopardized" by the two governing parties, the statement said.

HEADLINE: Downtown Newark Gambles on the Arts;
A New Center Is Almost Ready, But Will Patrons Fear to Use It?

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 13

 BODY:
It is barely past sunset on a clear winter evening, when about the only thing moving in the vicinity of Newark's Military Park is a go-go dancer in a turquoise string bikini and black spikes, grinding through her desultory routine inside the Dubonnet Cocktail Lounge.
The streets are barren. The stores and coffee shops clinging to life during the day rattled down their iron cages an hour or two earlier. Traffic is sparse. 
 Inside the bar, a dozen customers sit, intent on their drinks. No one tips the dancer, prompting her to sashay off for a break muttering, "I'm wasting my time." The Dubonnet will be shuttered by 10:30.
This is the bleak nighttime face of downtown Newark, but just 300 yards down the block rises a colossus conceived in the hope of transforming the city day and night. The New Jersey Performing Arts Center, nearly completed at a cost of $165 million, is being touted as both the engine of the city's rebirth and the monument that will finally endow the Garden State with some cultural cachet outside the shadow of New York City or Philadelphia.
State officials are so enamored of the project that they were inspired to build a status symbol for it: a new, $7 million highway exit ramp off Interstate 280 to the 12-acre site. Talk to anyone involved with the Performing Arts Center and the superlatives swirl endlessly through each sentence like confetti:
It will be the last great performing center built in this millennium. Luciano and Whitney and Bruce will perform regularly. Newark will resemble Paris.
"Our aspiration is to grow into an institution that can stand shoulder to shoulder with Lincoln Center and the Kennedy Center," said Lawrence P. Goldman, president of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, a private, nonprofit development company. "Our architecture and acoustics reflect that goal, the scale of what we are doing reflects that goal and our programming reflects that goal."
But detractors tend to favor a different sort of description: white elephant. They believe that the government and corporate love affair with the arts center has all but dried up financing for other worthy public art projects, and that Newark's problems are too entrenched to pin its cultural and commercial rejuvenation on one building.
"You still have a very unsafe city," said Raymond M. Codey, director of development for the New Community Corporation, a nonprofit organization that has helped rebuild pieces of Newark, including the first modern supermarket near the city center. "They need better schools, better health care and better police force, and then the changes will flow from there."
There is also concern that programs and ticket prices promised for impoverished Newark residents will get lost in the rush to attract wealthy suburban theater patrons.
"It is being built by nonresidents for nonresidents," Mr. Codey said. "They will come in and get dumped off at the front, see the show and then leave without having any impact on the community. I see it like those practice landings at the airport where they put their wheels on the ground and then take straight off again."
Built with heavy infusions of government cash, the center is to open in October. The full schedule of performances is to be announced in February, and the center hopes to attract more than 10,000 subscribers for the first year.
The center will be a permanent home to the itinerant New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, which should add luster to both its performances and the level of musicians it attracts, Mr. Goldman said.
Other groups who have announced they will appear include the American Ballet Theater, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Isaac Stern, Wynton Marsalis, the Israeli Philharmonic and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
Ask who will show up and the builders spew demographics. Within a 35-mile radius of Newark is a densely populated region of 4.9 million people on the Jersey side of the Hudson River alone, in some of the highest-educated, highest-earning communities in the country. The center practically straddles the state's four largest highway arteries, and is a 15-minute walk from Newark's Pennsylvania Station. There are 90,000 office workers and students in the city daily.
One question is whether the arts center will be enough of a draw in a downtown area that sets records for carjackings and inspires fear even among those accustomed to it.
"It is kind of spooky walking to the train from here," said Maita Negron, a bartender at the Dubonnet. "I am paranoid about being the only one walking through the streets."
The center is trying to overcome that by confecting itself as something of an all-in-one destination. The building, designed by the architect Barton Myers, has the look of a massive stage, with soaring glass windows and catwalks where the theatergoers can stare down at the mingling crowds.
When construction ends in August, the center will have its own restaurant and will front on a landscaped plaza. A renovated garage and other parking should provide roughly one space for every two audience members in both the main 2,750-seat concert hall and a more intimate 500-seat theater.
Despite unconfirmed rumors of celebrity restaurateurs setting up shop nearby, the builders have been disappointed by the lack of private development in tandem with the arts center construction, especially since the entire complex is supposed to be connected one day to an esplanade along the Passaic River.
Doubters tend to point to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, saying that despite years of selling out with modernistic performances like those by the German choreographer Pina Bausch, it has yet to inspire a parallel neighborhood development.
The New Jersey Performing Arts Center does not aspire to draw audiences out of Manhattan in any great numbers. But it would not mind diverting suburban theatergoers, and Mr. Goldman puts a certain gusto into his descriptions of Lincoln Tunnel traffic jams leaving New Jersey.
He is toying with the idea of hiring official greeters to welcome people at the doors, distinguishing his center from what he views as the somewhat surly atmosphere of performance palaces across the river.
For their part, New York theater impresarios say they welcome the added choice, while dismissing any impact on their audience size. "The number of people who are likely to find Newark geographically more convenient is relatively small, let alone what is offered there, and is not of concern to me," said Nathan Leventhal, president of the Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts.
He estimated that 15 percent of the five million visitors a year to Lincoln Center come from New Jersey. Troupes that have committed themselves to Newark are retaining their seasons in places like City Center.
"For people in Manhattan to cross the river, they think they are going to a different country," said Judith E. Daykin, president of City Center. "I was at BAM for 15 years and people acted like they needed a visa to come to Brooklyn."
Sometimes, the gamble of placing a castle of culture in the midst of an urban desert bubbles up into the conversation with the developers. Before yet another of his riffs about sidewalks and restaurants and cafes oozing life, Mr. Goldman sighed, "It is very hard for me to get people to imagine this."
Aside from the majesty of the building itself, he said he thinks the center will succeed by featuring the best New Jersey has to offer, by scheduling performances that appeal to a variety of ethnic groups (Portugal is featured the first year to woo residents from the Ironbound district) and by extensive workshops for children, which have already been running in schools.
Newark residents were taken aback by the $150 cost of one eight-week theater and dance workshop, although the center ultimately reduced the fee for some students.
Chase M. Jackson, the arts manager for New Community Corporation, applauded the idea of developing more local talent.
"The musicians and artists are in New Jersey, living in New Jersey, but we don't really promote our own," she said. "We are not a cultural wasteland, but people don't think of us, because we are so close to New York."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Stocks Calmer After A Statement

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Japan's Finance Minister seemed to reassure the stock market today and said that the ministry would watch the stock market with serious concern after stocks plunged in early morning trading and sent the main market index down sharply.
The fall of about 3 percent in the main index had initially erased more than half the overwhelming gains from Monday, when the benchmark Nikkei Average 225 recovered from staggering losses last week. But the market recovered on Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka's remarks, and the Nikkei index closed today at 18,093.13, down 25.66 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent from Monday's close. 
 On Monday, the Nikkei index soared 815.14 points to close at 18,118.79, up 4.7 percent from Friday. Those gains fizzled in early morning trading, however, partly after an Economic Planning Agency official acknowledged the economic risks of a market decline, saying it would have a "bad effect on banks."
He added: "However, at this current moment, I am optimistic and think the effects of a stock decline will be limited."
Though Monday's gains offered some hope that the market was settling, it was clear this morning that the same conditions that helped bring about last week's plunge, which pushed the Nikkei index down 10.6 percent, still exist.
Japan's economic outlook for 1997 remains dim, a rise in the national sales tax is expected to crimp consumption, and budget tightening by the Government will curb fiscal spending. The "Big Bang" plan to deregulate financial markets by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who returns from a state visit to Southeast Asia today, has also raised concern about the financial industry's ability to withstand new competition.
Moreover, highly risky Japanese investment funds seem to have influenced the wild market swings of recent days. Thus, analysts said, the market could see more such volatility in coming weeks.
"Tokyo has always been a volatile market," said Giles F. Ockenden, an equity strategist at Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo. "Sentiment is so powerful in the market, and it's not that connected to valuation."
Investors have always had difficulty evaluating the financial conditions of Japanese banks and brokerage firms, which have traditionally disclosed much less financial information than their American counterparts. Japan's thinly capitalized banks are still burdened by several hundred billion dollars in bad real estate loans, and it was those banks that bore the brunt of the market selloff last week.
Some investment analysts said that one significant factor moving the market in recent days seemed to have been the trading by large, leveraged Japanese investment trusts, called bull and bear funds.
Since their introduction two years ago, these funds have expanded to control more than 400 billion yen, or about $3.5 billion, and influence even more because of the big bets they take on the market. The largest of these aggressive bull funds, operated by Daiwa Securities Inc., has about $2 billion in funds.
"The bull funds exacerbated the selling" on Friday, said Kathy M. Matsui, equity strategist at Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd. "If the market is holding up, they do relatively well. If the market declines, there's a negative spiral."
Much more money is invested in the bull funds, and some of these offer individual investors double the return on the Nikkei index by trading in index futures. Fund managers adjust their positions daily, carrying out their huge trades toward the end of the day.
On both Friday and Monday, the Nikkei index saw large moves toward the end of trading. When the market starts dropping, bull funds must aggressively sell futures to reduce their exposure to the contracts. Bear funds do the opposite, so there is some offsetting in trading activity.
In a rising market, bull funds must aggressively buy back the futures.
Hiroshi Masuda, deputy general manager in the equity department at Yamaichi Securities, which also offers the funds, called it a significant factor in last week's drop. "The funds may have helped push up the market today," he said on Monday. "It is a factor that accelerates the upward or downward movement."

HEADLINE: Budget Equity in New York

 BODY:
By pledging to increase school aid for New York City and lower property taxes, largely for upstate and the suburbs, Gov. George Pataki has outlined some worthy goals. But the early numbers churned out by the Governor's budget office raise doubts about whether the city will end up worse off under the latest proposals. The Legislature also needs to resist locking in expensive new spending increases or tax reductions that later balloon in size. New York State's habit of launching programs with no thought about how to pay for them in the future has created chaos in its finances for years.
Only through a combination of good fortune and dubious fiscal gimmickry has the state been able to absorb the $5 billion in tax cuts enacted in the last two years. The luck came as a boom in the economy, particularly on Wall Street, yielded an estimated $1 billion in unexpected revenues for the state. It would be a mistake to assume that these resources will be there in the future to finance new programs. 
 Beyond that, the $1.7 billion in property tax relief proposed by Mr. Pataki is notable because it has been geared to voters upstate and in the suburbs surrounding New York City. Only 9 percent of the tax cut would accrue to homeowners in the city, where about 40 percent of the population lives. In political terms, the suburbs have become perhaps the biggest battleground for elections both locally and nationally. But that is no reason to favor one segment of the state over another.
The mechanics of the bias in the Governor's proposal are worth explaining. The areas outside New York City have higher property tax rates because, unlike the city, they do not impose high sales or income taxes to pay for government services. A home assessed at $100,000 in Queens pays a lower tax than a home assessed for the same amount in Nassau County. Mr. Pataki's proposal would give homeowners, on average, a $30,000 tax exemption on the assessed value of their homes, or $50,000 for people 65 years old or more, a benefit of much greater value if a homeowner is paying a higher tax rate.
To make his entire proposal more palatable to the city, Mr. Pataki proposes to increase state education aid by a separate $1.7 billion over the next five years, and to weight that increase in favor of the city as opposed to the suburbs. That is only fair because New York City, with 37 percent of the state's school population, receives only 34 percent of the state aid for schools.
But the numbers given out by the Governor's office only show what he would spend in the next year, and there is no sign that the state will even begin to address the equity issue then. By some measures it appears that the city will get even less of a portion of overall state aid than it has been receiving, since Mr. Pataki is proposing to cut funding for programs vital to the city school system, like special education and dropout prevention.
The overriding principles that the Legislature should apply are equity and practicability. New York City schools must get their fair share of state assistance, all New Yorkers should get their fair share of tax cuts and the state must do more than guess that the money will be there to pay for both.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WANTS CURB ON MEDICAID

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Over the objections of senior members of his own party, President Clinton is drafting a budget that would set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending as a way to help balance the Federal budget by 2002.
While the effort at fiscal discipline may please Republicans, many Democrats view the limits as undermining the open-ended nature of the Federal-state health program for the poor. Furthermore, they say they see no need for such limits because the program's growth fell last year to its lowest level in two decades. 
 Mr. Clinton's proposal says, in effect, that per-capita Medicaid spending may grow no faster than the nation's per-capita economic output, before adjusting for inflation. In practice, such a formula would allow Medicaid to grow 4 percent to 5 percent a year. At present, Medicaid benefits are available to anyone who meets eligibility criteria set by Federal and state law, and the costs have been unpredictable.
The President's budget request, which is to be submitted to Congress on Feb. 6, will be the opening move in months of arduous negotiations. The outcome is uncertain.
Federal Medicaid spending rose an average of 15 percent a year from 1985 to 1995, but the growth has slowed, averaging 7.9 percent a year from 1992 to 1996. And in the last year, Federal Medicaid outlays increased just 3.3 percent, to $92 billion, which is $3 billion less than Mr. Clinton predicted in the budget that he sent to Congress last February.
Reasons for the slowdown include greater use of managed care, a drop in medical price inflation, a decline in the growth of Medicaid enrollment and a Federal crackdown on ploys used by states to shift costs to the Federal Government.
In his new budget, Mr. Clinton assumes that, with no change in current law, Medicaid will grow roughly 7.5 percent a year for the next five years, so that Federal Medicaid spending in that period will be $55 billion less than he was projecting just 11 months ago.
But the Administration wants to make sure there is no return to the explosive growth of the late 1980's and early 1990's. (Medicaid outlays grew more than 27 percent a year in 1991 and 1992). So, Administration officials said, Mr. Clinton will ask Congress to squeeze at least $11 billion -- and perhaps twice that amount -- from Medicaid over the next five years, by imposing annual limits on spending and by cutting special payments to hospitals with large numbers of indigent patients.
A cap on Medicaid spending could directly affect the people who depend on the program for health insurance. For if a state reached its limit, it would have two choices. It could cut back the amount or scope of its Medicaid benefits, or it could curb payments to doctors, nursing homes and other health care providers, reducing the incentive for them to serve Medicaid patients.
The budget proposal has alienated some members of Mr. Clinton's party, a risk he runs throughout this year's budget negotiations.
Many Democrats, like Representatives John D. Dingell of Michigan and Henry A. Waxman of California and Senator Bob Graham of Florida, are urging the White House to drop the idea of a cap on Medicaid spending. It was understandable, they say, that Mr. Clinton offered such a proposal in 1995 as an alternative to a Republican plan to dismantle Medicaid and give each state a lump sum of Federal money to finance health care for the poor, with no Federal guarantee or entitlement.
But Republican governors and Republicans in Congress are no longer making a serious push for the block grant. So, the Democrats say, there is no reason for Mr. Clinton to persist in his efforts to set a "per-capita cap" on Medicaid spending.
Moreover, Democrats say, a cap would save much less money now that the growth of Medicaid has slowed. If, for example, Congress had set a cap limiting Medicaid growth to 4.5 percent a year, it would not have saved any money last year because spending rose only 3.3 percent.
Finally, the Democrats say, Mr. Clinton should wait to see the effects of welfare and immigration laws passed in the last six months. Health policy experts predict that those laws will further slow the growth of Medicaid by removing people from the rolls or making it more difficult for them to get on.
A newsletter that follows Federal spending for public health said today that Mr. Clinton would seek additional money for treating people with AIDS, for Head Start and for the Indian Health Service. But the newsletter, Community Health Funding Report, said many other requests from the Department of Health and Human Services had been "shot down" as the White House struggled to eliminate the deficit.
Budget documents provide these details of the Administration's preliminary decisions:
*The White House initially proposed a small cut in the budget for the National Institutes of Health, but then relented after an appeal from Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Mr. Clinton is now expected to request a total of $13 billion, or slightly less than would be needed to keep pace with inflation.
*Healthy Start, a Federal program to cut infant mortality by increasing the use of prenatal care, would be merged with other maternal and child health programs. Money for the combined programs would be reduced by 9 percent, to $719 million in 1998.
*The budget of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention would be cut slightly, to $2.2 billion. But spending on AIDS prevention would be increased $20 million, to $637 million, and the White House ordered Federal health officials to use the extra money to prevent H.I.V. infection among drug abusers.
*Mr. Clinton is seeking $5 million to enforce a new regulation that curbs the advertising and sale of tobacco products to children. He is requesting $26 million for other activities to combat tobacco use.
*Mr. Clinton will ask Congress to expand Head Start, so it serves 836,000 children next year, up from 750,000 in 1996, and he wants to have one million children enrolled in the program by 2002. The budget, $4 billion this year, would rise to $4.3 billion in 1998 and to more than $5 billion in 2002.
*For the immunization of children, Mr. Clinton requests $400 million. The amount is less than Congress provided this year, but would supposedly allow the Government to buy just as much vaccine. White House budget officials said immunization levels were approaching the President's goals, so no more money was needed.
The White House decided not to seek money for a giant nationwide computer system that was to pay all Medicare bills. In announcing the new system in 1994, Dr. Shalala said it would move Medicare "to the era of the super electronic highway." But the White House raised questions about the technical complexity of the project, the "management capacity" of Medicare officials and "the likelihood of cost overruns." Medicare finances health care for 38 million people who are elderly or disabled.

HEADLINE: Confusion Arrives Ahead of a Week of Tax-Free Clothing

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Beginning Saturday, New York State will eliminate sales tax for a week on clothing and related items that cost under $500, in a plan aimed at stopping the flow of shoppers out of the city and into surrounding states that do not tax clothing purchases.
The tax-free plan is intended to test its proponents' belief that revenues lost can be made up in increases in related sales, like the food shoppers eat and the transportation they take. 
 That would be good for the coffers of New York, but would it be good for bowlers?
That question arises because in its execution, the tax-free week is riddled with confusing details, as retailers try to figure out exactly which items are tax-exempt and which are not.
For example, under the plan, bowling shirts will be tax-exempt, but bowling shoes will not. Barrettes and hair bows will not be taxed, but head scarves will be.
Precipitation problems? A new pair of galoshes will solve them tax free, but if you opt for ski boots and waders, prepare to ante up to the government.
Ostensibly, the clothing exempt under the guidelines of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance is worn every day. But the state agency, which used other state tax policies as its yardstick for what is everyday wear, did make some odd calls. Bridal wear, for example, is tax free. Ditto for flip-flops (but not other athletic shoes).
"Flip-flops are worn every day in the summer," said an agency spokeswoman, Christine Golden. But the bridal costume? "That's a new one on me," she admitted.
Many retailers said yesterday that they had not yet really figured out what was exempt and what was not, and some smaller retailers said they were unaware of the program at all. Of six managers of sporting goods stores in three boroughs called yesterday, not one knew exactly what to tax. "It is going to be absolutely confusing," said Mark Guran, who owns Island Sports Inc. in Manhattan. "I have not received anything in detail. I don't know much about it."
Ms. Golden said she believed that all businesses that collect retail sales tax were sent a memo that listed exempt items, and that anyone with questions could call (800) CALL-TAX, or refer to the web site at http://www.tax.state.ny.us.
The plan for a week of tax abeyance was part of the budget package that the State Legislature approved and Gov. George E. Pataki signed last summer, with the blessing of the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a supporter of a permanent reduction in the retail sales tax. Local retailers have long lamented that shoppers use New Jersey and other surrounding states, which do not tax clothing, as a sort of giant duty-free shop.
New York City agreed to match the 4 percent state tax break with a 4 percent break of its own. The one-quarter of 1 percent Metropolitan Transportation Authority sales tax will also be eliminated between Saturday and Jan. 24.
This tax break, proponents argued, will stimulate retail sales during a usually lackluster sales week when shoppers are tapped out from holiday shopping and after-Christmas sales are winding down. Further, they say, it will prove that state and local government should adopt some permanent sales tax reduction.
In a news conference last week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani reiterated his position. "I believe very strongly that New York City needs lower sales tax on vital purchases like clothing, shoes and other things," he said.
The Mayor has already included in his proposed 1998 budget $70 million in cuts in the sales tax, which would require approval by Albany. He is seeking to cut, at minimum, 2 percent from the city's retail sales tax on clothing under $500.
"There is no tax that is more regressive than the sales tax," the Mayor added. "Poor people have to pay exactly the same sales tax as rich people have to pay. And when you consider how much business that we are losing to Nassau and Suffolk and Westchester, and Staten Island is losing to New Jersey, this is particularly important to us."
Indeed, retailers in Staten Island, an important political base for the Mayor, have complained the loudest about losing business to New Jersey.
"I would say about 10 to 15 percent of my business" is lost to New Jersey, said Bill Praschil, the general manager of the Sears, Roebuck store in Staten Island. "As far as Sears is concerned, a Sears is a Sears. But we wonder what this does to slow the growth rate out here."
The City Council has estimated that $7 million of city tax revenues will be lost for the week, and state officials have estimated the loss for the state at $10 million to $20 million for the week.
But things that may make up for the lost revenue, proponents have argued, could include improved corporate profits if sales indeed beef up during the tax-free week. Also, they say, losses from permanently eliminating the sales tax would be offset by long-term retail sales growth and additional spending on related businesses like restaurants and transportation.
"The city can do a billion dollars more in sales that they are losing to other states," Mr. Silver said in an interview. "That billion dollars represents corporate profits, jobs and employees in New York State who will pay income taxes here, who will make up for revenues lost in sales tax. It would be a win-win for New York."
State and local governments will do a cost-benefit analysis of the week to help them determine the usefulness of a permanent cut in the retail sales tax. While some economists applaud such a plan, others warn that a weeklong shop-a-thon in the dead of winter may not provide enough evidence to justify a cut.
"If I were to make a comparable analogy it would be the 10-day car sales for the nation, which are very erratic," said Rae D. Rosen, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "It is very hard to look at the demand of something for a week and try to generalize."
Ms. Rosen added: "All things being equal, we should recapture some of the sales that are being lost to New Jersey. I just haven't seen any rule of thumb that tells me that for sure."
So far, the advertising for the program has been scant but big retailers like Macy's are expected to push the idea later this week. Meanwhile, word has begun to trickle out to customers, and yesterday most of those interviewed had heard at least a little about the program.
A half-dozen people interviewed in front of Macy's Herald Square said that they were shopped out for now, but liked the idea of a reduced retail sales tax. "Now that I know about it, I'll definitely wait until then to do some shopping," Erin Kehoe, 30, an interior designer, said.
