HEADLINE: Albert Wohlstetter, 83, Expert On U.S. Nuclear Strategy, Dies

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Albert Wohlstetter, an influential innovator in strategic nuclear doctrine who advised Democratic and Republican Administrations on military strategy, died on Friday in his home in the Laurel Canyon area of Los Angeles. He was 83.
Mr. Wohlstetter's career as a strategic analyst was guided by certain key principles, including his conviction that the United States should be able to control its military forces in such a way as to permit varying the American response to foreign aggression according to the circumstances. The goal of such control, he felt, was to insure that the United States would not be obliged to mount an initial nuclear attack on the Soviet Union -- known to military analysts as a "first strike" -- but would have a variety of options instead. 
 Writing in Commentary in the early 1980's -- when nuclear doctrine was seen as being about how to deter nuclear attack and what to do should deterrence fail -- Mr. Wohlstetter contended that the President must be perceived as having choices in order to deter an attack, and that the President could not be left without choices should deterrence fail.
Mr. Wohlstetter and his wife, Roberta Wohlstetter, also an expert on national security, were awarded the Medal of Freedom in 1985 by President Ronald Reagan for their "great contributions to the security of the United States." Mr. Reagan said Mr. Wohlstetter had been "influential in helping to design and employ our strategic forces."
Mr. Wohlstetter was a senior policy analyst on the staff of the Rand Corporation, the California-based think tank, from 1951 to 1963 and a consultant to Rand for decades afterward. He also taught at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the University of California, Berkeley, in the early 1960's and at the University of Chicago from 1964 to 1980. And he was a longtime executive of Pan Heuristics Services, Inc., a California-based consulting firm dealing in security policy whose clients included the departments of State and Defense as well as private corporations.
A native New Yorker, Mr. Wohlstetter grew up in Manhattan and attended public schools. He earned a bachelor's degree and, in 1938, a master's degree, in mathematical logic from Columbia University. In the 1940's he worked for the War Production Board, and later went on to work in the aviation industry and as a Government housing executive.
He later became a member of Rand's research council and chairman of Rand's research program on conflict in allied, neutral and satellite countries. The studies that he carried out at Rand in the 1950's were all done for one client, the United States Defense Department, and were for the most part highly secret.
Soon after he joined Rand, a colleague there, Charles Hitch -- who later became an Assistant Secretary of Defense under Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara in the 1960's -- suggested that Mr. Wohlstetter carry out a research project about the selection and use of strategic air bases -- that is, air bases for nuclear bombers. There were no nuclear missiles until the mid-1950's.
James Digby, a friend of Mr. Wohlstetter who worked with him at Rand, recalled yesterday that Mr. Wohlstetter's paper "resulted in a change of Strategic Air Command's basing policy so that bombers were based far from the Soviet Union, and their bases, highly protected. This in turn led to the ability to strike back even after receiving a first attack by the Soviets."
In the 1970's, after Mr. Wohlstetter had left Rand, he and his wife performed studies on the Persian Gulf on behalf of Rand and with the Department of Defense as the client. These studies affirmed that the United States' European allies were highly susceptible to having important oil supplies blocked.
Also in the 1970's, Mr. and Mrs. Wohlstetter increased their analyses of the ramifications of the spread of nuclear weapons, and by some accounts that work led to changes in American law concerning the export of nuclear material, notably plutonium, and of nuclear technology.
In addition to his wife, the former Roberta Morgan, whom he married in 1939, Mr. Wohlstetter is survived by a daughter, Joan Wohlstetter Hall of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Russia Vows to Remove Georgia Nuclear Fuel

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Responding to repeated American appeals, Russia promised today to remove a cache of nuclear material from Georgia by March.
The supply of highly enriched uranium and spent nuclear fuel at a research reactor outside Tbilisi in the Caucasus has been a major worry for American officials, who fear that it could fall into the hands of aspiring nuclear powers or terrorists. 
 For much of the past year, senior Clinton Administration officials have tried without success to arrange the transport of the material to Russia for safekeeping.
Today, however, Viktor N. Mikhailov, the head of Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy, publicly pledged that the transfer would be carried out in the next two months. He spoke at a news conference in which he declared Russia's intention to increase its exports of nuclear power plants to nations like China, India and Iran.
On the issue of the nuclear material in Georgia, Mr. Mikhailov said: "During the past four months, we have been solving this question on what I would describe as the bureaucratic level. We are preparing for this operation. I think we will be able to withdraw this fuel in February or March."
Mr. Mikhailov privately gave American officials similar assurances last year, promising the material would be removed in August. Moscow then delayed the operation, and Mr. Mikhailov cautioned today that the final bureaucratic obstacles have not yet been surmounted.
"There must be an intergovernmental agreement," he said. "Dozens of ministries are involved. We must clear all these operations with them."
Additionally, Mr. Mikhailov did not say whether Moscow has abandoned its earlier plan to reprocess the spent fuel and return the nuclear waste to Georgia. Georgia says that it cannot accept the waste because it has no place to safely store nuclear debris. The Russian plan to return the waste has been a major sticking point.
According to Georgian officials, the research reactor houses 9.5 pounds of highly enriched uranium and 2 pounds of spent fuel.
Some American officials say that the nuclear material, while substantial, is not enough for a nuclear bomb. But some nongovernmental experts say it could be used to make a weapon with a small yield of about 1,000 tons of TNT.
American specialists have installed a security system at the Georgia reactor, but officials say the only long-term solution is to remove the nuclear material.
At the news conference, Mr. Mikhailov painted a grim picture of a Russian nuclear industry.
The Minister said that the delay in paying back wages to nuclear workers had been reduced to one-and-a-half months from three to four months. But that was accomplished, in part, by taking large loans from commercial banks at interest rates that reached as much as 70 percent a year. Those loans must be repaid next year, he said, adding to the nuclear industry's budget crunch.
The Minister said he hoped to deal with the financial crunch by expanding nuclear exports. He said that such exports exceed more than $2 billion a year and had increased by 10 percent last year.
He said that Russia hopes to build nuclear plants in China and India, as well as in Iran. The Iranian project has drawn strong protests from the United States, which says it will help Iran's effort to develop nuclear weapons.
Mr. Mikhailov is also seeking sales in Egypt, Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, Cuba, Brazil and Vietnam.
But many developing nations have budget problems, too, putting a cloud over the ministry's plans. While 150 Russians specialists are working on a project to build a nuclear reactor in Iran, the project is being hampered by financial concerns.
"Now some questions arose over cash flow -- how the payments will be made, through what banks and so on," Mr. Mikhailov said. "Iran is being a little choosy."
Mr. Mikhailov also blamed money problems for delaying the plan to remove the Georgia nuclear material, not mentioning that the United States has offered to advance $1 million in funds.
"We had no money to pay wages and we had to pay $500,000 for transportation to take out this amount of material," he said.
Another hitch, he acknowledged, has been Russian laws concerning the importing of nuclear waste.
"We have a law whereby waste fuel can only be taken out under an intergovernment agreement," he said. "And so, this bureaucratic red tape began. And it is still in progress."

HEADLINE: Cape Cod, Worried About Fresh Water Supplies, Seeks to Rein In Growth

BYLINE: By SETH KING 

DATELINE: BARNSTABLE VILLAGE, Mass., Jan. 10

 BODY:
With the number of permanent, year-round residents increasing steadily and putting new pressures on the limited supply of fresh water, Cape Cod is now wrestling with the question of how many more people can be permitted to move here.
For the past decade, the number of people living on the Cape year round has been increasing by about 5 percent annually. But the water supply will permit this growth rate to continue for no more than a decade, local planners say. 
 More than 200,000 permanent residents, or "year-rounders," as they call themselves, live on the Cape. About 300,000 more people come for the summer, so that on any given day in tourist season there may be 500,000 people on the 75 miles of glacial sand and rock that begins just north of the Cape Cod Canal and ends at Provincetown.
The fresh water that spouts from every faucet and shower head on Cape Cod must come from municipal and private wells supplied by an aquifer, which must be replenished by the approximately 45 inches of rain that falls on the Cape each year.
Virtually all of the Cape's waste water and sewage goes back into the aquifer after being treated in private underground septic systems that are on the property of houses and businesses. If the water is not properly treated, it can pollute the wells. The aquifer itself cannot be drawn down too low or sea water will flow in, ruining it.
The only way the Cape can assure an adequate water supply, planners say, is for town governments to buy open land and prohibit major construction on it. Keeping that land undeveloped insures that enough rainfall will soak into the aquifer; it also reduces the amount of waste water and sewage that must be treated to prevent pollution of the aquifer.
Last month, the Cape Cod Commission, which was created in 1990 to coordinate town development plans and help control growth, published the first regional plan for development. It shows that about one-third of the Cape is already protected from development, being owned by the 15 towns; another third is developed, and the remaining third, about 89,000 acres scattered over the Cape, is open land.
"The regional plan calls for the towns to buy up nearly half of this open land, about 35,000 acres," Armando J. Carbonell, the commission's executive director, said in a recent interview. "Most of this newly acquired land would be held as replenishment areas. The rest would remain in private hands and would be available for new houses on commercial buildings, with development controlled by town zoning rules."
In November, Cape Cod voters approved a resolution asking the Massachusetts Legislature for the authority to create a fund, known as a land bank, to buy the open areas. The fund, to be financed by a 1 percent tax on any property sale after the first $100,000, would raise at least $5 million annually that could be used by local governments to buy the 35,000 acres.
The proposed legislation would also give the towns the right to acquire the land under eminent domain.
If fully implemented, the plan would allow a maximum increase of 50,000 to 100,000 in the year-round population, Mr. Carbonell said.
"This is all the growth the permanent residents on the Cape want," he said. "They've made this clear, first in supporting the Cape Cod Commission's efforts to control development and second in their solid support of a land bank."
Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket already have similar land banks.
Commercial establishments opposed to the land-bank concept contend that it would curb commercial growth and increase property taxes.
Dick Neitz, a real estate agent who is chairman of the Cape Cod Economic Development Council, a local government agency that promotes development, said: "When you add a 1 percent land-bank tax, you add a new, unfair burden on property buyers and sellers, which makes Cape real estate much less competitive.
"This could curtail our commercial growth because we would be making Cape property too expensive and driving off people who would like to locate here."
While Mr. Neitz and other opponents of the land bank say they are not against the public purchase of undeveloped land to protect it, they contend that when land is removed from the tax rolls, towns are forced to increase property taxes to balance their budgets.
Legislation to create the land bank has been introduced by State Representative Eric Turkington, a Democrat who represents Falmouth, Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard.
Supporters of the measure express confidence in having support for passage in the legislature's current session.

HEADLINE: Social Security Funds Don't Belong in Stocks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Advisory Council on Social Security's report urging investment of Social Security revenues to insure the solvency of the program purports to solve a crisis that does not exist (front page, Jan. 7). Social Security benefits will be paid on time regardless of the trust fund's status. They are Government obligations and are paid out of current revenues, like the defense budget. A real trust fund does not exist -- and never has. 
 The panel ignores options that could restore the balance between intake and outflow. These include raising the early retirement age of 62, when most people begin receiving benefits, and correcting the overstated annual inflation adjustment.
The panel waves the magic wand of privatization without noting serious drawbacks. If Social Security is no longer a captive buyer of Government bonds, those bonds will be forced to offer higher interest rates to attract new buyers, which will raise borrowing costs. They will also depress stock market returns.
If Social Security buys stocks, which stocks? Risky upstart companies or "safe" enterprises like Philip Morris? If the latter, will the Government protect public health when it is a major stockholder in tobacco companies?
 
RICHARD L. KAPLAN
Champaign, Ill., Jan. 9, 1997
The writer is a professor of law at the University of Illinois.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Search Party Is Sought To Find a Commissioner

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 13

 BODY:
Four years and four months after Major League Baseball last had a commissioner without the word "acting" or "interim" before it, the owners will embark this week on yet another search for the right man for the job. How long it will take or where it will end nobody knows.
Bud Selig, who has served as acting commissioner since Fay Vincent resigned under pressure Sept. 7, 1992, and the executive council will appoint a search committee at the owners' meetings here this week. The committee will most likely be the executive council itself. 
 "We'll finalize that Tuesday night," Selig said today of the executive council meeting. "There are still some different variations on how to do it. But we'll get it done this week and move on."
The owners will also vote on placement of the two expansion teams. The Arizona Diamondbacks will join the National League in 1998 and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays will join the American League, creating two 15-team leagues, an uneven number for the first time, and requiring that interleague play become a permanent format after its two-year experiment in 1997-98.
Not everyone in baseball is convinced that the search for a commissioner will lead anywhere but to Selig himself. But Selig steadfastly says that he does not want the job, and another major league official said the committee would conduct a "serious search."
Jerry Colangelo, the Diamondbacks' managing partner, said, "I understand there's been speculation of late that maybe it's Bud Selig, but he continues to deny that he wants that to take place."
Not everyone believes that spoken stance. "I still believe Bud will wind up as commissioner," one official said.
Not everyone is convinced that the last search was serious. That one ended three years ago this week with the committee making no recommendation to the executive council.
It was evident at the time that those owners preferred leaving Selig in charge. With the exception of some critics in the National League, in fact, the owners generally have liked having Selig as commissioner -- for their purposes -- and many would like to see him take the job permanently. But in recent remarks, Peter O'Malley of the Los Angeles Dodgers, one of Selig's harshest critics, expressed another view that some owners hold.
"The best thing for baseball today," O'Malley said, "would be to identify someone from outside the game, totally fresh, who could bring to baseball a marketing background, high credibility, and lead baseball into the next century."
For a time a couple of years ago, George Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader, was considered the top candidate for the job. The man from Maine presumably remains available. He currently is special adviser to the president of Ireland.
No new names have jumped to the forefront. But one name certain to come up is Peter Goldmark Jr., who last month announced he was resigning sometime this year as president of the Rockefeller Foundation.
Goldmark, 56, who said he had not decided what he wanted to do next, often colors his comments with baseball analogies and served as a management-appointed member of baseball's economic study committee in the early 1990's. A person in Goldmark's office said he would be out of the country until next week and was not available for comment.
Whatever candidates surface during the committee's search, the owners may have difficulty agreeing on one person or even the type of person he should be. Election requires a three-fourths majority (23) of the 30 clubs with at least five votes coming from each league. Some owners believe the next commissioner should be a chief executive officer; others object to that idea. Some don't want an outsider because they feel that people who don't have experience within baseball don't understand the way it functions.
"Do you need someone who is politically correct or someone who rolls up his sleeves and knows how to get the job done as it relates to the sports industry?" Colangelo said.

HEADLINE: City Spending Less Per Pupil, Report Shows

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The Board of Education is spending less money per student now than at any time in the last decade, a new budget analysis shows, even as the reading scores of third and sixth graders in New York City have fallen to their lowest point in nine years.
The study, conducted by the New York City Independent Budget Office, shows that while overall spending on the schools has gone up, it has not kept pace with the much faster increase in student enrollment, which has risen by an average of 13,000 students a year since 1988. 
 Though there is no proven connection between spending and student performance, reading scores and spending have each fallen by about 13 percent from their peaks.
Over the last 10 years, average spending per student has risen and fallen based on spending decisions by mayors, chancellors and school board members. The total spent by the Board of Education on each student reached a peak in 1990, then fell somewhat in the middle part of the decade.
But after the significant cuts in the growth of spending by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in 1994 and 1995, the amounts fell to their lowest level since 1988, adjusting for inflation -- $6,952 spent per student this year, compared with $7,892 in 1990.
About 60 percent of the board's resources come from state and Federal budgets. While those amounts have also fluctuated over the last 10 years, per-student spending from those sources is roughly the same this year as it was in 1988, when adjusted for inflation. But the study shows that city aid per student -- spent at the discretion of the Mayor and the City Council -- has declined faster than total board spending. Though the Mayor recently spent $70 million for new textbooks, the total board spending for this year declined by about $70 per pupil.
The spending figures were calculated by the Independent Budget Office using simple arithmetic: dividing the amounts spent on education by the number of students enrolled each year. Then, to remove the effects of inflation, each year's dollar was made equal by applying the Consumer Price Index. Pension and debt-service costs were not included; like the rest of the city budget, they are calculated separately.
School spending has become a potent political issue this year because several candidates challenging the Mayor in his run for re-election have decided to make his spending cuts in education their primary issue. Last week, several of them blamed him for the decline in reading scores that began in 1994, saying the cuts were responsible for harming student performance.
The Mayor said on Friday that calculating the average amount spent on each student was meaningless in New York, because programs like special education siphon money away from regular classrooms.
"For the New York City school system, an average per student number is totally useless and means nothing, except for people who want to pander," he said on his weekly radio program after he was told of the study. He argued that the amount being spent is less important than how the money is spent, which he said has improved under Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew.
In fact, spending on special education has increased in recent years. And since special education is more costly than regular classroom instruction, to include the special education spending in the overall calculations -- as the budget office did -- actually has the effect of raising the per-pupil spending figure.
Dr. Crew said in a statement that he could not comment on past spending but that in 1996 the Mayor cut the school budget proportionately less than he cut budgets of other city agencies, and added the textbook money in this year's budget.
Per-pupil spending is a standard measure of education budgets, used by the Federal Government and national education groups to compare one school system's spending to another's. Douglas A. Criscitello, director of the newly formed Independent Budget Office, said it is the only measure that shows whether policy makers are keeping pace with changing enrollments.
"We think it's the most reliable indicator of spending in the classroom," said Mr. Criscitello, whose agency, mandated by the City Charter, began operations last year as a nonpartisan source of budgetary information. "It's not surprising that it's declined given the tremendous influx of additional students into the system." He added: "At some point, reduced spending per pupil will have an impact on the education being provided."
Education experts have long said there is no direct, clear-cut connection between spending and student performance. The two urban school districts with the highest rates of per-student spending around the country -- Washington and Newark -- have among the lowest rates of performance. And even with the cuts, New York City still has one of the highest urban rates of per-student spending in the country, though suburban areas tend to spend more.
The Mayor and other critics of the Board of Education have argued that a good deal of school spending has been wasted by a needlessly large bureaucracy, and administration officials say that his cuts have forced the board to trim its nonteaching staff. They also note that the percentage of the budget spent on education is larger under Mr. Giuliani than in the past, although the Mayor cut $1.2 billion from the board's spending requests in his first two years in office.
"It's a trap to think that one can evaluate the system simply because of dollars or dollars per student, and that's not the way one should evaluate it," said Randy M. Mastro, the deputy mayor for operations.
Mr. Mastro and school officials also raised questions about the methodology of the study, though no one disputed the basic calculations. Mr. Mastro expressed doubts about the manner in which the Independent Budget Office had adjusted the amounts for inflation, suggesting the organization was political because some former officials of the Dinkins administration work there. He did not explain what he believed was wrong with the calculations.
Mr. Criscitello, who was chosen by Democratic city officials not including the Mayor's office, is former chief financial officer for the Small Business Administration in Washington.
Report cards issued by the state earlier this month show that the number of third-grade students meeting the state minimum standards for reading has fallen by 9 percent in the three years that Mr. Giuliani has been Mayor. Sixth-grade reading levels have also fallen, although math scores are up for the same period.
In 1988 and 1989, when per-student spending was about 13 percent higher than it is today, reading levels in both the third and the sixth grades were also about 13 percent higher, according to scores compiled by the State Department of Education.
"When resources are used well, they can effectively change achievement scores," said Robert Berne, the vice president for academic development at New York University. "Clearly the Mayor and the Chancellor argue they have not been used well in the past," he said. "But my view is, over the long term, large amounts of resources taken out of the educational system can make a difference, and they have been removed."
Several of the mayoral candidates also tried to link the declines in spending to those in reading scores, and indicated they would do so in the coming mayoral campaign. Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said there was a clear correlation between the two, and Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, said parents could tell the difference in priorities.
 A picture in some editions, showing Ms. Messinger at St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx, carried an incorrect credit. It was by Chang W. Lee.

An article and a picture caption yesterday about Ruth W. Messinger's candidacy for mayor of New York referred incorrectly to the history of women in that race. Diane McGrath was the Republican-Conservative nominee in 1985, running against Mayor Edward I. Koch; Ms. Messinger, seeking the Democratic nomination, would not be the first woman nominated by a major party.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Expanding and consolidating, Golden Books takes six floors at Seventh Ave. and 57th St.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
THE Lone Ranger, Lassie and Felix the Cat are moving to 888 Seventh Avenue.
Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc., which owns the rights to the characters -- among many others -- has leased 112,500 square feet on six floors at the 45-floor, 866,000-square-foot office building at 57th Street. The 15-year lease is for the 38th through 43d floors. Financial details were not disclosed, but asking annual rents in the building are in the mid-$30's a square foot. 
 Golden Books is the largest publisher of children's books in the country and also creates and markets family entertainment. It will be moving from 35,000 square feet at 850 Third Avenue, at 51st Street, and 20,000 square feet of temporary space at 560 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street.
Tracey Riese, senior vice president for corporate marketing and communications at Golden Books, said the move came about because of recent consolidations and acquisitions. "We found we were out of space," Ms. Riese said.
Last May, an investor group that included Richard E. Snyder, the former chief executive of the Simon & Schuster unit of Viacom; Barry Diller, the head of Home Shopping Network Inc., and a fund managed by E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company acquired a controlling interest in Golden Books, which was previously the Western Publishing Group.
Ms. Riese said that when Mr. Snyder became chairman, much of the publishing business, including sales and marketing, was run from Racine, Wis., and that many of those operations had recently been consolidated in New York. In addition, she said, Golden Books had acquired the family video library of Broadway Video Entertainment, as well as "a significant proportion of its management."
The Georgetown Company advised Golden Books on the transaction; Arthur Lerner of Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. was the tenant's broker, and Paramount Group Inc. represented the building.
 
Urban League's New Home
The National Urban League has leased almost 49,000 square feet on two floors at 120 Wall Street, a 34-story, 600,000-square-foot building at South Street.
Two-thirds of the building -- 400,000 square feet -- is designated the Association Center, created in 1992 in cooperation with the city's Economic Development Corporation to help keep nonprofit organizations from leaving the city because of high rents. Nonprofit tenants in the center are exempt from real estate taxes.
The National Urban League's lease, for 20 years, was valued in excess of $22 million. With the league, which will be the largest nonprofit tenant, the center will have 31 nonprofit organizations, occupying 300,000 square feet. David Lebenstein of Time Equities Inc. and Arlene Wysong of Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. represented the tenant.
The league will be moving its headquarters from 500 East 62d Street, a 21-story, 123,000-square-foot building it owned and occupied with the United Negro College Fund for 23 years. The College Fund moved its headquarters to Fairfax, Va., in 1994, and the sale of the 62d Street building, to an undisclosed buyer, is expected to close next month.
 
First Boston Expands
Credit Suisse First Boston -- the corporate and investment banking firm combining Credit Suisse and CS First Boston that began life on Jan. 1 -- has leased an additional 286,000 square feet at 11 Madison Avenue, an office tower at 24th Street owned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Credit Suisse First Boston, part of the CS Group of Switzerland, has now leased more than 1.6 million square feet of the 2.2-million-square-foot building.
CS First Boston had leased 1.1 million square feet on 15 floors in the then-vacant building in a 20-year, $500 million deal in July 1995 and later took additional space, bringing its total to 16 floors and 1.2 million square feet. Last October, Credit Suisse signed a 20-year lease for 140,000 square feet on the 19th and 20th floors; the Swiss bank's new space comprises the 8th, 9th and 11th floors.
Luther Terry, a managing director in corporate services at Credit Suisse First Boston, said that Credit Suisse would be transferring its finance, administrative and operations divisions from 1 Liberty Plaza and 5 World Trade Center and also moving some employees from Princeton, N.J. Financial details of the new deal were not disclosed. Cushman & Wakefield represented Met Life; the Edward S. Gordon Company represented Credit Suisse First Boston.
 
Around Manhattan
Fresco, a Tuscan restaurant at 34 East 52d Street, has leased 14,410 square feet on two levels at the Lombardy Hotel, 111 East 56th Street, for its second Manhattan location. The site was once home to the French restaurant Laurent, which closed in 1991. Faith Hope Consolo of Garrick-Aug Associates, who with her colleagues Ferne Glanzrock and Joseph Aquino represented both the tenant and the hotel, said the 15-year lease was valued at $4 million. . . . Wm. H. McGee & Company, an insurance underwriting concern, has leased 65,000 square feet, the 47th and part of the 48th floor, at 2 World Trade Center. The company will be moving from about 50,000 square feet at 4 World Trade Center and the 29th floor of 2 World Trade Center. The 15-year lease was valued at about $25 million. John Cefaly and Augustus Field of Cushman & Wakefield represented the tenant.

HEADLINE: A New Optimism Grows at Howard University

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
When H. Patrick Swygert was named president of Howard University in April 1995, the historically black university faced immediate problems. Morale was low. Enrollment had fallen. Finances were tight. And the House Budget Committee had voted to end the $200 million annual subsidy to the university, about 40 percent of Howard's operating budget.
Mr. Swygert did not officially take office until that August. But even before he moved in, he persuaded Congress to reinstate the subsidy and give him a year to come up with a plan to revitalize the university. Howard, which is north of downtown Washington, is the only comprehensive research university among the nation's historically black colleges and, with Gallaudet University, is one of only two federally chartered universities. 
 Now, Mr. Swygert has not only drawn up a strategic plan and set new priorities, but he is also bringing energy, excitement and top students to the campus.
And in a victory that Mr. Swygert holds particularly dear, he announced on Jan. 8 that Howard had attracted 79 National Achievement Scholars, more than any other college in the country. Harvard University, which does not offer automatic scholarships to these students as Howard does, was second, with 69. (The National Merit Scholarship Corporation runs the achievement program for outstanding black students parallel to its regular merit program; it designated 850 Achievement Scholars among this year's college freshmen.)
"Attracting the largest number of Achievement Scholars is a real kudo for President Swygert," said William H. Gray 3d, president of the United Negro College Fund, which raises money for black colleges.
"There's a new optimism about Howard when you talk to alumni, trustees and others," Mr. Gray said. "The alumni feel good about the university. You pick up that sort of positive response, and a lot is due to Pat's leadership."
Howard, which has more than 10,000 students and 1,100 faculty members, once attracted many of the nation's best black students. But as the Ivy League and other prestigious colleges opened their doors wider, and other historically black colleges became more competitive, Howard saw many of its potential recruits heading elsewhere.
In recent years Howard drew unwanted attention, first from anti-Semitic speeches on campus by a former spokesman for the Nation of Islam, and then for the subsequent discouragement of a lecture by a Jewish professor from Yale. It also drew criticism for handing out large amounts of money and other compensation as severance pay to administrators even as it was laying off workers and suspending raises to faculty members to avoid deficits.
As Mr. Swygert has tried to revitalize Howard, bringing in top students, and especially the Achievement Scholars, was a high priority.
"To say I'm excited -- that sound you hear is my foot tapping," he said in a telephone interview. "These are the strongest African-American youngsters, and they are highly sought after. They are very bright kids and they lend a lot to any environment they are in."
He attributed the university"s success to a more efficient recruiting strategy and to "Howard's being back as a hot school." He said he talked with virtually every Achievement Scholar candidate who visited the campus.
Frank Turner, a freshman finance major from Mobile, Ala., who was a National Merit Scholarship finalist as well as a National Achievement Scholar, said about 10 colleges offered him full scholarships. But he chose Howard, Mr. Turner said, after he got "a couple of nice phone calls," as well as the promise of a laptop computer and full tuition, room and board. "It was one of the better deals," he said. "And I felt there would basically be more opportunities in Washington for economics and political science work."
But even as he brings students like Mr. Turner to campus, Mr. Swygert has more to do. He must contain expenses, especially those at Howard's hospital, which faces many of the problems of hospitals that give care to inner-city residents.
Mr. Swygert's strategic plan calls for a consolidation of Howard's 16 schools into a more focused and manageable 11 by next fall. The university has already cut the number of employees by about a third over the last seven years, to 5,067 from 6,800, and is likely to squeeze further, he said.
He has spent $7 million on improving buildings and services on campus, catching up on deferred maintenance and installing computer links in faculty offices and dormitories.
He also plans a new center for the study of African-American heritage and culture in an effort to regain Howard's luster as a center of black intellectual thought. Howard lost ground even as Harvard and other universities continued to strengthen their black studies programs.
"Howard has a very good faculty, but it doesn't have the names that are getting the attention," said Frank Matthews, a senior scholar at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., and publisher of the journal, Black Issues in Higher Education.
"Howard has not been able to keep the best and the brightest faculty," Mr. Matthews added. "Working at a black college has often been regarded as a hardship, because of the heavy teaching loads and the low salaries."
Mr. Swygert hopes to bring in additional private money to help attract faculty members and pay for programs. He is laying the groundwork for a major fund-raising drive to start later this year in an effort to bolster the university's $200 million endowment. Only 5 percent of Howard's 65,000 alumni donate money to the university. Mr. Swygert's goal is to raise that to 30 percent by 2001.
"When I came to Howard, I didn't find very much in the way of fund raising," he said, recalling that he had gone through a similar process when he was president of the State University of New York at Albany, which recently completed a $55 million fund-raising campaign that he initiated. "If I know one thing, I know how to raise money, and we'll be getting at it."
Mr. Matthews said that among black colleges, Howard had the best potential for alumni contributions, because with professional schools and other graduate programs, it had doctors, lawyers and other alumni who should be in a position to give. But he added that Howard alumni have been somewhat disgruntled in recent years, "bitter about their experiences at Howard, which has not enjoyed a reputation as a caring institution in the last two or three decades."
Some alumni, however, say that Mr. Swygert's progress is already making them feel more charitable.
Houston A. Baker, a professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania who graduated from Howard in 1965, said he and his wife, also a Howard graduate, now plan to raise their gifts to the university.
"I have given to Howard in the past," he said. "But until this point I never felt encouraged enough or felt that -- restricted or unrestricted -- the gifts would be managed well enough to make a difference. Now I do, and we will be giving significantly."
Howard's trustees express satisfaction, too.
"He has done exactly what we asked him to do," Harry J. Pearce, vice chairman of General Motors and a Howard trustee, said of Mr. Swygert.
Mr. Pearce, who headed the search committee that chose Mr. Swygert, said the committee wanted "a visionary, but one who also had an established track record" of running a university. "I couldn't be more pleased," he added.
Of course, not everything is fixed yet. But Mr. Swygert is upbeat.
"We've at least begun to address all these issues," he said. "I did it not because I'm a glutton for challenge, but because the board reached out to me with the hope that I really could get this place moving again. And I had been very, very fortunate. I've come home. I was raised at this university."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Inflation Data Add New Fuel As Dollar's Rally Continues

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar posted its fifth consecutive gain against the German mark yesterday and rose to a 45-month peak versus the Japanese yen after economic data in the United States soothed fears about inflation.
The dollar surged as high as 1.5973 marks, its highest level since July 1994, following the reports of subdued increases in consumer prices and retail sales in December. 
 "I think the dollar continues to benefit from strong economic growth and the perception of moderate to weak inflation in the United States," said John Nelson, a vice president at ABN-AMRO Bank in New York.
Comments from members of the German central bank council and from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin of the United States aided the dollar.
A Bundesbank council member, Helmut Hess, warned yesterday that the mark could weaken in the period leading up to European monetary union if investors switch their funds into other currencies.
Traders interpreted Mr. Hess's remark as an effort to mute speculation that the European central banks will intervene to support the mark.
His colleague Olaf Sievert also brightened the dollar's prospects. He said Germany's central bank would have no ground to raise interest rates in the near term and might even lower credit costs later.
In the United States, Mr. Rubin, for a second consecutive day, spoke in support of a strong dollar. But his remarks had little impact after giving the dollar a big lift on Monday.
The dollar rose to 1.5943 marks in late New York trading from 1.5886 late Monday. The dollar inched lower to 1.3761 Swiss francs from 1.3765 late Monday.
As the dollar staged its broad advance, the British pound fell to $1.6711 from $1.6739.
Against the yen, the dollar closed just shy of the psychologically important 117 level, ending at 116.93. The dollar ended Monday's session at 116.44 yen.
"A lot of people are very cautious about breaking above the 117 level, fearing Bank of Japan or Ministry of Finance intervention," said Jeffrey Yu, a senior trader at Sanwa Bank Ltd. in New York.
The Canadian dollar fell to 74.030 United States cents, from 74.156 cents at Monday's close.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
U.S. public pension investors are eager pilgrims in Shanghai.

BYLINE: By Seth Faison 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
FOR a bunch of money managers with $234 billion to invest, China can look awfully tempting.
Shanghai is alive with entrepreneurial dynamism, and almost any visitor will be struck by the sheer abundance of building -- there are more than 22,000 construction sites here -- a visible symbol of the nation's locomotive-like economic growth. 
 A troupe of American pension-fund managers, including the huge California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, popped into town yesterday to look for places to park some of their cash. By the end of the day, they were pretty taken with the place, but had no illusions about the challenges even the savviest investors face in China.
"Rarely have I been as excited as I was today," said Thomas E. Flanigan, chief investment officer of the California State Teachers Retirement System, which manages $65 billion. "This is where the growth is; this is where the future is. I've been in the investment arena 25 years, and I've never seen the kind of growth Shanghai has."
It is high time, Mr. Flanigan and other fund managers agreed, to allocate a greater share of assets to Asia generally and China specifically.
Calpers, America's largest pension fund, with $105 billion in assets, has $25 billion invested outside the United States, but mostly in Europe. Of the $7.7 billion it has invested in Asia, $5 billion is in Japan, and smaller amounts are in Hong Kong and Singapore.
"China is a place we feel we really have to be," said William D. Crist, president of Calpers. "We want to be here."
And yet it's difficult for responsible investors to be here. Even for fund managers willing to stretch the boundaries of their normal investing precautions, China offers precious few public places to park their cash. As many others eager to capitalize on China's economic boom have discovered, financial reporting is often unreliable at Chinese companies still mired in old-fashioned systems of management.
China's stock markets, though they have come alive in recent months, are still composed of companies that are opaque in how they divvy up profit. And the markets are small by American standards.
"The B shares are still so illiquid," said Patricia A. Small, treasurer of the Regents of the University of California, referring to the dollar-denominated shares available to non-Chinese investors. "When you have a large public fund, you need liquidity."
Matt Fong, the California State Treasurer, who is leading the group of two dozen public-sector money managers on a 12-day trip through Asia, said the solution in China might be private equity deals. Even then, relying on a partner to find direct investments in small- and medium-sized companies is a challenge.
Mr. Crist said Calpers made its first direct investment in China last year, agreeing to sink $100 million into a partnership with a Taiwan-based investment company called the China Development Corporation, to look for cash-hungry enterprises in southern China. Yet so far, he said, only $1 million had actually been placed in a local company, because it was harder than expected to find financially responsible takers.
That reality didn't seem to dampen the enthusiasm of other pension-fund managers.
"I am absolutely overwhelmed by the degree of activity going on in Shanghai," said Rich Rose, chief investment officer for the San Diego County Employees Retirement Association. "We don't want to wait for the listed markets to provide the kind of assurances we need; we want to get in now."

HEADLINE: What Crisis?

BYLINE: By Richard C. Leone; Richard C. Leone is president of the Twentieth Century Fund.

 BODY:
Critics of Social Security claim that the system is near collapse. Privatizing the system, they argue, will give everybody better protection in old age. But without a complete understanding of what Social Security already provides to Americans, how can we know whether to junk it in favor of something else?
First, despite what its critics claim, Social Security is not similar to a savings or investment program whose purpose is to yield the biggest return. Social Security is more like a disability and life insurance policy that provides vital protections to virtually every member of our society. Currently, seven million survivors of deceased workers and four million disabled Americans receive income support. 
 The Social Security Administration calculates the value of the disability insurance as the equivalent of a $203,000 policy in the private sector; for a 27-year-old average-wage worker with two children, Social Security provides the equivalent of a $295,000 life insurance policy. The total value of these two policies nationally is about $12.1 trillion, more than all the private life insurance currently in force.
Second, Social Security provides a lifetime retirement annuity whose benefits rise with inflation. Many corporate pensions run out after 20 years, and most are not adjusted for inflation. While there is a lot of loose talk about greedy geezers living luxuriously on the backs of their impoverished children, the facts tell a quite different story. Without Social Security, approximately half the elderly in America would fall below the poverty line.
The notion that these basic protections would be unnecessary if we all saved more money is simply false. The truth is that neither of these protections is available in the private market at a price that the vast majority of Americans can afford.
Social Security works because virtually all of us belong to it and pay into it. Social Security, after all, does not consist of a bunch of piggy banks with our names on them. Our pooled contributions insure that almost every senior citizen receives a minimum income.
Although some of us need the protection more than others, all of us get some benefits. It is the nature of such pooled plans that both the most fortunate among us (the wealthy) and the least fortunate (those who die young and without a family) get the least from the program.
It is a fallacy that everyone can do better than average if we take control away from the Government. Averages exist because some of us do worse and some of us better. In the brave new world of individual accounts, each winner would be matched by a loser. The only way we can insure that every citizen has a minimal retirement benefit is by requiring that we all participate in the Social Security system.
Though the search continues, there is no free lunch. Advocates of privatizing Social Security dangle the prospect of riches in front of impressionable young workers, but hide from them its high costs and risks.
The privatization plans proposed by two minority factions of the Advisory Council on Social Security come with an enormous transition cost. One plan would require increased taxes amounting to $6.5 trillion during the next 72 years; the other would raise payroll taxes by 1.6 percent, costing American families $13 billion each year.
Social Security has some minor problems, but faces no life and death crisis. In fact, without any changes at all, the system will be able to pay full benefits for the next 30 years and more than 70 percent of those benefits for 75 years.
Moreover, the entire Advisory Council agreed that modest changes -- such as including state and local government workers in the system -- could eliminate a fair share of the projected gap between revenues and benefits.
Thus, as this debate continues, let us agree that we cannot all be above average, and that when it comes to benefits we should compare apples to apples. We shouldn't give up a critical universal insurance program for no insurance at all. And we should not compare a guaranteed lifetime inflation-adjusted annuity to a 401(k) plan or brokerage account.

HEADLINE: Car Dealerships Are Facing Consolidation And Change

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Auto dealerships are rapidly beginning to issue stock or to be bought by publicly traded companies, a trend that could transform one of the last bastions of mom-and-pop businesses in American retailing.
Republic Industries said today that it would pay $200 million in stock for seven dealerships in Florida and New York, a day after it had agreed to pay $100 million for seven other dealerships in the Southwest. Three chains of dealerships -- Cross-Continent Auto Retailers Inc., United Auto Group Inc. and Lithia Motors Inc. -- have gone public in the last several months, and several more chains are said by investment bankers to be considering similar moves. And in the last month, the Ford Motor Company has largely abandoned its opposition to public ownership of its dealerships, the last big auto maker do so. 
 "I don't think there's any question you're going to see more dealerships traded on markets," John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of General Motors, said in an interview last week.
The chains that have issued stock are using part of the proceeds to buy more dealerships, in what could be the early stages of a consolidation of the nation's 21,000 dealerships.
Defenders of corporate ownership say that car buyers will soon find more professional managers, more consistent customer service standards and slightly lower price markups. Family-owned dealerships have long had trouble recruiting professional managers, who tend to see promotions inevitably going to family members. And corporations can borrow money at considerably lower interest rates than can most car dealers, a saving that might result in lower markups on cars, more investment in showrooms or both.
"We do have some economies of size," said Carl Spielvogel, the chairman and chief executive of United Auto, which runs 40 dealerships. "We will attempt to pass that on to customers in terms of better value."
But many traditional dealers are concerned by the arrival of big companies in their cozy industry. They warn that corporations could buy several dealerships in a city, for example, and use their greater market share to charge larger markups. And dealers question whether corporate managers will be able to provide personal service.
"I think a private dealer like myself has to provide better service; he can't compete with the deep pockets of the big organizations," said Christopher E. Smith, a Ford dealer in Platte City, Mo.
Several trends are driving the move to corporate ownership. The growth of Internet buying services has forced dealers to compete on price with dealerships in other cities, a competition that gives an advantage to well-financed corporations. Big companies can buy advertising in bulk at considerable discounts. And with the owners of thousands of dealerships close to retirement, many dealerships are for sale.
The ability of most corporations to borrow money at lower interest rates than independent dealers is important. Dealerships basically operate by borrowing millions of dollars to buy cars from the auto makers, and then repay their loans with the money they collect from selling cars. Corporations that borrow money in commercial paper markets end up paying interest rates that can be 3 percentage points lower than the rates charged to dealers by the financing arms of the auto makers, which now dominate this business.
But perhaps the most important development is that the auto makers themselves, after years of preferring to deal with many tiny dealerships scattered across the country, are beginning to accept big corporations as their franchisees.
The Chrysler Corporation began the trend a year ago when it granted a new-car dealership to Carmax, the used-car arm of Circuit City Stores Inc., and when it set rules last autumn allowing public ownership of its dealerships, provided that no company buys more than 10. G.M. quietly amended its franchise agreements last summer to accommodate corporate ownership. Foreign auto makers have been moving in the same direction.
And Ford, long the most reluctant auto maker to accept public ownership of dealerships, began overhauling its policies last month. Because many chains of dealerships include at least one Ford outlet, Ford's hostility to initial public offerings of dealerships and corporate ownership had previously made them difficult. Ford announced on Dec. 20 that it had reached a general agreement for Republic to begin buying its dealerships.
Ford executives said they were impressed by Republic's plans to try to improve customer satisfaction through better staff training and other steps. Beginning with a deal in Ohio right after Christmas, Republic has now announced five deals to buy a total of 22 new-car dealerships. John Ochs, a spokesman for Ford, said today that the auto maker had also given Republic its permission to buy two more dealerships in Florida.
Buying new-car dealerships is only part of Republic's strategy. The company is also developing a network of used-car lots. By adding new-car dealerships, which receive a lot of used cars as trade-ins, Republic can help fill its used-car operations with inventory, said Thomas A. Gruber, a senior vice president of Republic's auto retailing arm, Autonation. Republic has also bought Alamo Rent-A-Car Inc. and has an agreement to buy National Car Rental System Inc., which will give it an additional source of used cars. Based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Republic is publicly traded but is controlled by H. Wayne Huizenga, the billionaire who built Blockbuster Video.
Detroit's Big Three auto makers want to see a consolidation of their dealerships. The duplication of staffs and other expenses at dealerships -- there are 60 Ford and 24 Lincoln-Mercury dealerships in the Los Angeles area, for example -- has driven up the cost of distributing cars.
But the rise of corporate ownership could also hurt profits at the auto makers' financing subsidiaries, which do a good business lending money to dealerships. And if a single company wound up with 150 or so dealerships, it could offer a complete sales network to companies like Fiat that are not currently in the American auto market.
"That to me is the greatest potential downside" for the American auto makers, said Nicholas Colas, an analyst at CS First Boston.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Sink $5 on Fear Of Selling by Central Banks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Gold prices posted their biggest one-day loss in 10 months in New York yesterday, reaching the lowest point in more than three years, because of renewed fears that European central banks would sell gold and because of more evidence that inflation remained tame.
Gold for February delivery tumbled $5 an ounce, to $357.70, on the New York Mercantile Exchange's Comex division, the lowest price since Oct. 4, 1993, and the biggest daily drop since last March. The March silver contract fell 4.2 cents, to $4.675 an ounce. 
 The central bank of the Netherlands said yesterday that it had sold 300 tons of gold last year, a fifth of its reserves. Traders are concerned that European central banks will sell gold as part of a push to meet entry requirements for economic and monetary union in 1999.
The sales can be used to help reduce government debt to bring it into line with requirements.
"The Netherlands news is the important thing; that explains why the price is low," said Marty McNeill, a trader at Sinclair Group in New York. "The question is, who's the next one."
Gold also fell after further signs that inflation was under control. Some investors buy gold when inflation threatens to erode the value of other assets, like bonds.
The Labor Department said that American consumer prices, excluding the volatile food and energy categories, rose 2.6 percent last year. That tied the gain in 1994 as the smallest in the so-called core inflation rate since 1965.
Coffee prices jumped after exchange inventories posted a surprisingly large drop, renewing concern that supplies would stay tight.
Coffee stockpiles in warehouses monitored by the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange fell by 9,070 132-pound bags, to 23,388 bags, last week, the exchange said on Monday.
Coffee for March delivery surged 3.75 cents, to $1.222 a pound.
Orange juice rose for a second day on speculation that freezing weather could reach Florida's orange groves , damaging the fruit and cutting output.
March orange juice rose 2.8 cents, to 82.35 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange, the highest price since Dec. 26.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
After a War, a New Normalcy: Parking in Manhattan

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Taking a break from his job parking cars in a midtown Manhattan garage, Amir Behic drew slashes with a black pen across the weather map of his Croatian newspaper, circling cities and sketching new borders as he explained in halting English how the Yugoslav army surrounded his town four years ago.
It was in the early stages of conflict in the Balkans. Mr. Behic, 30, a Muslim from Bihac, an economic center in northwestern Bosnia minutes from the Croatian border, remembers the details. "The grenades started July 6, 1992," he said. "You couldn't go outside the city." 
 Now an assistant manager of the Edison parking garage under the Grace building on West 43d Street, Mr. Behic often finds himself talking about his war-torn native land. "When I say I'm from Bosnia, everybody wants to talk, to hear about the experience," he said.
In Bosnia, Mr. Behic worked as a producer at the local television station. He also produced records in a small studio at his parents' home, where he lived and kept a collection of professional-quality recording equipment.
"I was very satisfied before the war, really I can say I was happy," Mr. Behic said. "But war changed everything."
Before the conflict, the town of Bihac had an ethnically mixed population. With the fighting came ethnic mistrust. Many of the Serbs moved away from the town. Power lines were cut. There were shortages of food and other necessities.
A local army formed to fight the invaders. "That's not a professional army," Mr. Behic explained. "That was people who come from the street, like people who come every day here in the garage."
Mr. Behic continued to work at the television station. "When something happened on the front line, we would go and make pictures," he said. He also worked with local musicians, recording music and videos about their war experiences.
Death became commonplace. "Everything that is normal in normal life, it is not normal in war," Mr. Behic said. "I lost so many friends in the war." His best friend was killed by a land mine.
By the fall of 1995, Croatian forces had liberated the town of Bihac. But in December, Mr. Behic decided to join his aunt and uncle who had come to New York in 1994 and had just moved to Houston. He arrived as a refugee through an international rescue operation.
Mr. Behic, who could not speak English, got a job carrying groceries to customers' cars in the parking lot of a Houston supermarket. He said he was paid very little, and when his aunt and uncle moved back to New York, he joined them.
"Here it's better," he said. "You have more opportunities."
Shortly after the move, opportunity came his way. His uncle, a gynecologist, had helped a Bosnian woman in New York with her pregnancy and the woman introduced Mr. Behic to FEGS, an affiliate of UJA-Federation of New York, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The association paid for a three-month course to train him as a garage attendant. It taught basic English and how to recognize the makes and models of cars driven in the United States. He graduated last spring and now works 10 hours a day, 5 days a week.
He is responsible for adding up the day's receipts. "I do all the paperwork, balancing the reports," he said. "The balance must be zero -- if you have minus or plus, something is wrong."
He lives with his aunt and uncle in an apartment in Ridgewood, Queens, but he misses his homeland, especially his favorite food, cevapi, spicy minced meat stuffed in a special bread, which he cannot find in New York.
He is grateful for the job and thrilled to be working, but sometimes his green eyes grow red-rimmed with frustration. "I didn't come to spend my time for nothing," he said. "I didn't use welfare. I don't like to take money if I don't work. I am satisfied over here but I am not happy. This job is good. But I want to do something more."

HEADLINE: THE WHITMAN AGENDA: THE SPEECH;
Whitman Vows to Cut Car Insurance Rates by Curbing Suits

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that New Jersey drivers have for too long paid the nation's highest automobile insurance rates and proposed legislation that would allow insurers to offer limited coverage for lower premiums.
In her third annual address to the State Legislature, Governor Whitman praised her administration for a range of accomplishments from cutting income taxes to imposing statewide school curriculum standards, but she acknowledged that bringing down auto insurance rates remained one of her biggest challenges. 
 By vowing to lower auto insurance premiums, Mrs. Whitman sought to address a problem that her Democratic opponents promised to make a campaign issue in this year's gubernatorial race. In her 50-minute speech, the Governor also struck several other themes to appeal to voters, from the environment to education to crime.
The auto insurance proposal would require insurers to offer four options to drivers, all of which would continue to provide them with $250,000 of coverage for medical expenses and some lost wages. To varying degrees under the plans, drivers would be able to reduce their premiums by abandoning or restricting their ability to seek damages in court for pain and suffering.
Mrs. Whitman said she would also seek to eliminate surcharges that insurance companies impose on bad drivers and on new drivers. And she said she would eliminate automatic annual rate increases now given insurance companies by the state.
In the most recent survey of auto insurance rates, in 1994, the average premium in New Jersey was $964 -- $314 above the national average, according to the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. In New York, the average premium was $870, the fifth highest in the country, while Connecticut's $863 was the sixth highest.
According to Whitman aides, a motorist who now pays the average of $536 for the minimum mandatory policy would save up to $187 under the Governor's proposal by choosing the least expensive option.
Noting that various special interest groups have been successful in curbing efforts to bring down auto insurance rates in the past, Governor Whitman conceded that she faced an uphill fight in winning legislative approval for the plan.
But the Governor said she is ready. "Make no mistake," she said in her address, "enacting true auto insurance reform will not be easy. Powerful special interests are already mobilizing to preserve the status quo. But if they want a fight, we'll give it to them."
Assembly Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican from Salem County, said that the Legislature would take a close look at the proposal. While Mr. Collins said he did not anticipate objections from lawmakers over the Governor's plan to eliminate surcharges and curb fraud and abuse, he said that restricting coverage would not win easy approval.
"I don't know if that is the best way to solve it," he said. "I think that we have to be very careful. I am always concerned when you deny people the right to sue. But I understand that in some cases, it is for the betterment of society."
Democratic lawmakers attacked the plan, saying that auto insurance rates were high because the Whitman administration approved rate increases for 10 insurance companies, in addition to the automatic annual increases that range from three percent to five percent.
"We have higher rates because the Governor allowed the insurance rates to increase," said Joseph V. Doria, a Democrat from Hudson County and the Assembly Minority Leader.
Mr. Doria said that he was concerned that drivers would choose the least expensive option without fully understanding the impact of having less coverage and waiving their right to sue. "You will get the $1.98 policy that covers nothing," Mr. Doria said. "You will find yourself in a desperate situation. People will take the lowest policy and God forbid they would get hurt."
But Governor Whitman said that New Jersey had the highest auto insurance rates in the nation because "of years of control from Trenton."
And John K. Tiene, executive director of the New Jersey Insurance News Service, a lobbying organization sponsored by 21 auto insurance companies, called the Whitman proposal a "bold attempt" to address significant problems facing the auto insurance system. "We have advocated for many years that motorists should have more direct control over how they spend their insurance dollars," he said.
But the reasons for the high rates are more complex than the Democrats or Governor Whitman suggest. New Jersey is the most densely populated state in the country, and it also is the most litigious. Robert Hunter, insurance director of the Consumer Federation of America, said that the high density of traffic on the state's roadways also contribute to high rates.
Governor Whitman is the latest in a long line of governors who have tried to bring down New Jersey's auto insurance premiums. Former Gov. Jim Florio took perhaps one of the boldest steps when he eliminated the $222 surcharge imposed on all drivers to pay for a bad-driver insurance pool. He ordered the insurance companies to pick up the costs of the pool, known as the Joint Underwriting Association, whose debt burden had exceeded $1 billion. Several insurance companies balked at the plan, and challenged it in court.
Harrison J. Gordon, president of the New Jersey chapter of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, said that the Governor's plan would create two classes of motorists and force some residents to pay for access to the court system.
"The Governor's plan shuts the courthouse door for poor, working class and middle class New Jerseyans who, in an effort to reduce their insurance premiums, could choose policies that do not offer adequate protection in the event of an accident," Mr. Gordon said.
All four of Governor Whitman's proposed options would retain a central feature of the state's existing no-fault insurance system -- the $250,000 in so-called "personal injury protection" for medical costs, some lost wages and other services. That coverage is the nation's second highest, behind only Michigan's unlimited protection for a policy holder's medical bills and lost wages.
The main variant in Mrs. Whitman's plan deals with a motorist's right to sue beyond the $250,000 for medical bills and lost wages. These are the key provisions in each plan:
*Option 1 -- No right to sue the other driver for pain and suffering. The policy holder can sue for at least $15,000 in lost income and unreimbursed medical expenses. Projected premium saving: 20 to 25 percent.
*Option 2 -- No right to sue for pain and suffering. But policy holders could collect a pre-set pain-and-suffering benefit, depending on the injury. The policy holder could sue for economic losses. Projected premium saving: 5 to 10 percent.
*Option 3 -- Similar to existing policies of 88 percent of New Jersey drivers. But it narrows the types of injuries eligible for pain and suffering suits to those causing death, serious impairment of a bodily function or permanent and serious disfigurement. This restriction on pain and suffering suit is modeled after insurance laws in Michigan. Projected premium savings: 5 to 10 percent.
*Option 4 -- Unlimited right to sue for pain and suffering, regardless of the severity of the injury. Premiums will increase, except for motorists who currently have no restrictions on their right to sue. Premiums might decrease because of the new plan's crackdown on fraud, the end of surcharges and other cost-control proposals.

HEADLINE: THE GIULIANI AGENDA: THE SPEECH;
With a Nod to Oprah, Mayor Addresses Council

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
With a wireless microphone on his tie and an 83-minute speech firmly embedded in his memory, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday took the City Council on a lengthy tour of his first three years in office and promised a set of appealing spending plans that clearly signaled the beginning of an election year.
"I think we've effected more changes than any administration in the history of New York City in three years," he said. "But I can assure you there's a lot more to be done. There's a tremendous amount of enthusiasm for doing it. And if you think that we've made a lot of changes in the last three years, just hang on." 
 The annual address to the Council, known as the State of the City address, was one of the longest of his political life, and it touched on most of the Mayor's favorite topics: crime reduction, welfare reform, the value of immigration, the protection of children, the revival of the city's spirit. It also ventured into some new areas, from a freight tunnel under New York Harbor to tens of millions of dollars for new reading and computer programs in the schools.
Much of the text of the speech was familiar, but the wireless microphone gave an intentionally bravura feeling to the Mayor's performance, allowing him to roam freely through the front of the Council chamber in the style of Oprah Winfrey.
Though the lack of a teleprompter made the speech seem almost off the cuff, it was actually carefully choreographed and discussed at great length with the Mayor's political aides. It did not contain the one big new idea of the kind that marked last year's speech, in which he announced a dramatic reorganization of the city's child welfare system. Rather, it was a collection of smaller, easily digestible proposals that either the Mayor or other officials have discussed in the past, many of which seemed intended to shore up potential political weaknesses and to appeal to voting groups that he will need for his re-election bid this year.
After leaving the lectern to embrace the families of two slain police officers and a woman who found a job after leaving the city's workfare program, the Mayor focused most of his attention on education and economic development.
He said, for instance, that he would spend about $4 million to study the best location for a freight rail tunnel between New York and New Jersey, a familiar and complicated concept, as well as an associated deepwater port somewhere in New York Harbor. The city has estimated that a large new port and tunnel could create more than 40,000 new jobs.
He asked the Municipal Assistance Corporation to make available $125 million in city money to provide six hours of additional reading instruction a week to grade-school students, just a week after his political opponents attacked him over declining reading scores in the city schools. The city will also spend up to $150 million to buy 40,000 personal computers for the schools, and Mr. Giuliani committed himself to restoring arts education programs.
Finally, in effect acknowledging that many nonwhite neighborhoods remain suspicious of police officers, he vowed that the Police Department would seek an increased level of respect and courtesy across the city.
"The Police Commissioner is making respect, ending brutality, violence, disrespect, as important a part of the evaluation of a police officer as reducing crime," he said, "and I know that will make a significant difference."
The list of programs drew praise even from some of the Mayor's usual critics.
Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, said, "Who can possibly be against reducing police brutality, growing jobs and increasing reading scores for kids?"
Gail B. Nayowith, executive director of the Citizens Committee for Children, said that some of the education proposals were "terrific" but that she wanted to make certain that they would be backed up with a long-term financial commitment.
His challengers, of course, derided the speech as opportunism flavored with show biz.
"He needed to appear to be a softer, warmer more sensitive Rudy Giuliani, given the fact that most people think he's mean-spirited, and accurately so," said Councilman Sal F. Albanese, a Democratic contender for mayor. "This talk-show atmosphere -- this touchy-feely kind of demeanor -- plays into the image he's trying to convey."
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President and another mayoral candidate, criticized the Republican Mayor for stealing Democratic ideas on education and for not addressing such issues as AIDS, homelessness and public health in the speech.
By mayoral standards, however, the speech was unusually expansive, attacking only the Port Authority and criticizing Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to reduce property taxes. Mr. Giuliani liberally dispensed credit to unions and the Council for such programs as workfare and school construction. In the education centerpiece of the speech, he renewed his call for police control over school security but devoted some unusually soaring oratory to the restoration of programs in the arts, saying students "need to be opened up to beauty."
The more strongly he committed himself personally to improving the schools, in fact, the harder it seemed to become for him to say he has no control over the education system.
"Just like we've become a national leader and model for the country and some of the rest of the world in reducing crime and improving quality of life," he said, "we have to do the same thing for education."
Much of the speech was laced with elevating metaphors involving the rising sun of a new century shining on New York. But at one point he made it clear that such earthbound matters as his re-election are not that far from mind.
"On the morning of Jan. 1, 2000," he observed, "when I wake up in Gracie Mansion . . . " Then, he corrected himself: "I slipped," he said. "Let me go back to the text."
