HEADLINE: THE WHITMAN AGENDA: REACTION;
Democrats Hear an Address And See Only a Candidate

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
If there was any question about how closely Gov. Christine Todd Whitman analyzed last November's election results -- in which a strong turnout in urban areas helped cause her party's candidates for the White House and the United States Senate to lose by wide margins -- the answer came today.
Mrs. Whitman made no mention of her upcoming re-election bid, nor did she make any reference to the election last November. But with 10 months to go before voters decide whether to return the Republican Governor to the State House for a second term, Mrs. Whitman used her annual address to the Legislature today to lay the foundation for her campaign, citing her record on the economy, taxes, job growth and education, as she outlined what she called "three years of activity and accomplishment." 
 And one of the most striking aspects of Mrs. Whitman's unofficial campaign kick-off was the amount of time she devoted to urban initiatives, as well as the number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups whom she singled out in her speech.
In addition to outlining an expanded housing program and an effort to revitalize depressed cities, Mrs. Whitman called on a black former welfare recipient, a Hispanic educator and a black minister to stand up inside the Assembly chambers, as she recognized their individual achievements and the role that her programs had played in their lives.
Noting the Governor's apparent appeals to urban-based voters, Representative Robert E. Andrews, a likely candidate for the Democratic nomination, said, "She read the election results, didn't she?"
Mr. Andrews, of Camden, was also talking very much like a candidate today, although he said he would not make it official until next month. He asserted that voters in urban areas are much more concerned about jobs, health care and the quality of their local schools than the rosy picture painted by the Governor.
"She seems not to be living in the world that we're living in," Mr. Andrews said.
But even the Democratic politicians who attended the speech conceded that Mrs. Whitman was as smooth as ever in delivering her third annual address on the status of the state, and they acknowledged that she will be difficult to beat on Election Day.
"She's well-positioned going into the election," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli. Lower income taxes "are certainly a serious development," Mr. Torricelli said. "But the critical problems of rising property taxes and the aging infrastructure are still not being addressed."
As could have been expected, Democrats criticized the highlights of the Governor's address, as State Senator John H. Adler called her pledge to lower the state's high auto insurance rates "a bare-bones policy," and State Senator Richard J. Codey referred to it as "the equivalent of changing one spark plug when the engine needs an overhaul."
Throughout the day, as they conducted interviews just outside the Assembly chambers and issued statements around the State House, it was clear that the Democrats who are likely to run for governor are planning to attack Mrs. Whitman on issues related to job creation, education and property taxes.
"Today is her day," said Thomas Byrne, chairman of the state's Democratic party. However, he said, "As the campaign get's going, it will be a more level playing field."
Although the Governor has repeatedly pointed out that the average property tax increase in the state has been low under her watch, James E. McGreevey, a State Senator and the Mayor of Woodbridge, echoed other Democrats when he called the state's property tax rates a "crisis." Mr. McGreevey, who is also expected to announce his candidacy for governor sometime next month, called Mrs. Whitman "a gracious woman" who has exhibited "a fundamental refusal to tackle the tough issues of New Jersey."
Another potential Democratic candidate, George Zoffinger, a former State Commerce Commissioner, issued a statement criticizing the Governor for failing to create 450,000 new jobs in the state, as she earlier promised. In her address today, Mrs. Whitman noted that state has 150,000 new jobs since she took office.
Though the Democrats are facing an uphill battle in the governor's race and are also the minority party in the State Senate and the Assembly, they did not carry themselves like underdogs here today. Democratic officials packed into the Assembly gallery, sitting shoulder-to-shoulder with their Republican counterparts, and for the most part they appeared distinctly happy.
But most of the good humor did not come from talk about the Governor's address and the gubernatorial race, it came from plans for the big party that most of them will attend next week in Washington, when President Clinton is sworn in again.

HEADLINE: THE GIULIANI AGENDA: TIME LINE;
The Rise and Fall of the Brooklyn Waterfront

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:

EARLY 1800's -- Brooklyn is incorporated as a village in 1816 and construction begins on the Brooklyn Navy Yard in Wallabout Bay. After the Erie Canal opens in 1825, waterfront warehouses and factories begin to appear along the East River.
 
 MID-1800's -- Ports in Manhattan become overcrowded and more companies move to Brooklyn. 

1922 -- A Port Authority plan calls for a rail-freight bridge from Bay Ridge in Brooklyn to Bayonne, N.J.
 
 1950's -- After World War II, waterfront businesses begin to leave Brooklyn as traditional cargo shipping gives way to giant container ships. Because Brooklyn lacks inexpensive land for container storage, much of the region's shipping moves to New Jersey.
 
 1966 -- The Brooklyn Navy Yard, which at its height in World War II employed 70,000 people, closes and is sold to the city two years later.
 
 1981 -- In a move toward reviving the waterfront, the Red Hook Marine Terminal is dedicated, becoming the only port in the city where cargo containers are unloaded from ships. But after initial success, the volume of cargo traffic plummets and subsidies are used to generate new business.
 
 1988 -- Trying to revive the moribund Erie Basin south of Red Hook, the Port Authority opens the $25 million Fishport to attract fishing boats, buyers and fish-processing businesses. But little business materializes and the project is abandoned.
 
 1989 -- New York sets up a cocoa port on the 39th Street wharf in the Sunset Park waterfront area.
 
 1990's -- Representative Jerrold L. Nadler urges that silt clogging New York Harbor be deposited behind concrete dikes between piers on the Brooklyn waterfront to create a major new container port.
 
 1996 -- The city's Economic Development Corporation announces a stopgap deal to provide two shipping companies with incentives to prevent them from moving from Brooklyn to New Jersey.
 RANDY KENNEDY

HEADLINE: White House Offers New Ties to District

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The White House today unveiled a sweeping plan to rescue the nation's capital by transferring to the Federal Government many responsibilities that the city government proved unable to perform.
After two years of efforts by Federal lawmakers and local leaders to solve the problems, the Administration's proposals would fundamentally change the Federal Government's relationship with the city for the first time since the District won home rule almost 25 years ago. 
 The changes, which White House officials said would be included in the 1998 budget President Clinton sends to Congress next month, would include relieving the city of an assortment of responsibilities, including operating prisons, collecting taxes and improving roads. The Federal Government would also assume an unfunded pension liability of $4.3 billion for city workers and would increase the Government's share of Medicaid expenses.
The Administration plan is the latest in a series of efforts to save the capital from virtual insolvency and to reconstruct its shattered public services. Since 1995, the District has operated under a Federal control board created to oversee all aspects of the local government. So far, it has reined in spending of all city agencies, stripped the school board of most powers, pushed aside senior administrators and reduced the size of city government by thousands of workers. But like many of the city's elected officials, the control board members argued for a greater role for the Federal Government to relieve the city of responsibilities that are normally assumed by state government. The plan announced today, Administration officials said, was the first step.
Overall, the Administration plan would cost the Federal Government $3.9 billion over five years, or about $339 million more than it would pay the District under the existing arrangement of annual payments to the city, largely for land that cannot be taxed.
"This is without a doubt the bold est plan for the District that any President has ever proposed," Franklin Raines, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said at a news conference at the White House. "We want to revitalize the city as the nation's capital, and we want to improve prospects for home rule to succeed."
Local officials, including Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., agreed that the White House plan would strengthen home rule, by making city government more efficient, polishing the city's image to Wall Street investors and perhaps ending the need for Congressional subcommittees to approve the city budget each year.
Mr. Barry called the plan "a good first step." But he tempered his appreciation of Mr. Clinton's efforts by criticizing him for waiting so long to act. "In the last four years he has not done very much to help the District," Mr. Barry said of the President at his own news conference. "This is a beginning to make up for that lack of action."
Further, the White House initiative was immediately attacked by Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina, who was recently named chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee for the District. Calling the plan a "great rip-off," he said that any proposal that increases the Federal deficit "is a nonstarter with me."
A spokesman for Newt Gingrich said that the Speaker generally favored increasing Federal support for the District but that he had not been consulted by White House officials who formulated the plan presented today and thus had no knowledge of the details. Like many Federal lawmakers, Mr. Gingrich has criticized local leaders, saying their policies have contributed to the city's problems.
While the White House proposals would take over some of the responsibilities that are draining the city of almost $1 billion each year, they did not address other issues that have contributed to the decline of the city, like high crime rates and poorly managed schools.
Foremost among the neglected issues is a strategy to stem the exodus of residents and businesses to the suburbs of Maryland and Virginia, a steady migration that continues to shrink the city's tax base. Washington's current population of 543,000 residents is its lowest since 1933.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who appeared with Mr. Raines, said officials were working on "a set of proposals with respect to tax incentives" that would reflect the Administration's general policies of aid to urban areas, which include programs like community development banks and empowerment zones.
Mr. Raines said the Administration plan gives the District "a very major opportunity to be able to get its house in order and begin to stem the flow of people leaving."
Nor does the plan introduce any mechanism that would enable the city to broaden its limited taxing powers, a common complaint of city officials who cite the fact that two-thirds of the city's work force, about 300,000 people, work in Washington but live outside its borders, paying taxes to other jurisdictions.
Mr. Barry said he would "never stop fighting" for a commuter tax, and the District's lone delegate to Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton, said she would press ahead with legislation to cap the Federal income tax for District residents at 15 percent.
It was not clear how the new arrangement would affect efforts by some city officials to achive statehood for the District. Over the years, Mr. Barry and other elected leaders fought for the right to perform such functions as operating prisons and maintaining courts as a way to convince Federal lawmakers that the city should become the 51st state of New Columbia. And President Clinton recently expressed his support, albeit mildly, for District statehood.
But by stripping the city of the very functions it sought, the Administration plan would appear to push the idea far into the future.
Mr. Barry, who has served as mayor for all but four years since 1978, disagreed. He said the Administration plan "enhances" the possibility of statehood, insisting, "Part of the argument against it was, can you afford it? This makes it affordable."
As outlined, the five-year plan includes $917 million to increase the Federal Government's share of Medicaid payments to 70 percent, from 50 percent; $891 million to operate prisons, $885 million for prison renovations and construction, $681 million to operate the District court system, $125 million for roads and bridges and $117 million to take over income tax collecting.
But Administration officials cautioned that the plan would proceed only if District leaders, under the guidance of the two-year-old financial control board, continue to press for management reforms and spending cuts throughout the city government. Mr. Raines said that the plan includes "tough covenants" to keep pressure on the city to act wisely.
"We view this plan as a plan of tough love," Mr. Raines said. "We want to help the District, but we will insist that the District take specific steps to help itself."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Inflation Is Benign As Sales Rise Modestly
Consumer prices remained under control in December and for all of 1996. For the year, the core inflation rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy categories, was up only 2.6 percent. Along with an increase of the same size in 1994, that was the lowest core inflation since 1965. Over all, prices were up 3.3 percent in 1996.
And the Government's survey of retail sales confirmed what merchants had suggested for weeks: The holiday season produced gains, but they were smaller than retailers had hoped. Sales climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in December, to a level 4.4 percent above that of December 1995. [Page D2.]
 
Broad Rally in Stocks
The moderate inflation seen in the consumer price report encouraged buying in the stock and bond markets. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 53.11 points, to 6,762.29, its sixth record close in two weeks. Broader indexes also surged. [D8.]
 
Bond prices revived after a two-day slump. Yesterday's economic data eased fears that Federal Reserve policy makers would raise interest rates next month. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.77 percent from 6.85 percent on Monday. [D18.]
 
Struggle for Gold Deposit Increases
A fierce struggle for control of a rich gold deposit in Indonesia intensified, as Placer Dome proposed a $5 billion stock merger with Bre-X Minerals, which made the find in 1995. Bre-X has a competing offer from Barrick Gold of Toronto. [D2.]
 
Acquisition in Chip Industry
In a deal that would unite two strong niche makers of semiconductors, KLA Instruments said that it had agreed to acquire Tencor Instruments for $1.27 billion. [D4.]
 
Barnett to Buy Leasing Company
Barnett Banks agreed to acquire Oxford Resources, the largest automobile leasing company in the United States, for about $570 million in stock. [D4.]
 
Digital Wiretap Plan Reduced
Scaling back its earlier plans for electronic surveillance in the digital age, the F.B.I. released a new proposal that would make it easier for the bureau to place legal wiretaps on advanced telephone networks, but not with the scope previously contemplated. [A11.]
 
Fund Group Accused of Fraud
The S.E.C. accused the managers of the Permanent Portfolio family of mutual funds of violating fund investment policies and wrongly billing investors in the funds for thousands of dollars of expenses. [D20.]
 
Paper Destruction at UBS
Shortly after the Swiss Government ordered its banks to preserve any remaining records of their dealings with Nazi Germany, a suspicious security guard at the Union Bank of Switzerland halted the destruction of a range of World War II-era papers, including some that appeared to document "forced auctions" of property in Berlin in the 1930's. [A1.]
 
N.C.A.A. Attacks Gambling Ads
The National Collegiate Athletic Association has threatened USA Today and a number of other newspapers that it will deny them access to the college basketball championships unless they drop gambling ads that mention college sports. [A10.]
 
Shanghai Surprises
To American money managers who visit bustling Shanghai, China looks like a tempting place to invest. Yet when they dig beneath the surface, they find that it remains difficult for responsible investors to do so. Even for fund managers willing to stretch the boundaries of their normal investing precautions, China offers precious few public places to park their cash. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Chrysler Draws From Cars' Images
Chrysler's first corporate ad campaign in four years is continuing with new spots. The new TV ads, created by Bozell Worldwide, describe the genesis of the company's autos, using the tales to make a broader point about Chrysler. Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: THE PATAKI AGENDA: THE OVERVIEW;
Pataki Budget Tries New Tack

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a $66.1 billion budget today that relies heavily on strong economic growth and cuts to higher education and health care programs to finance additional spending on public schools and prison construction as well as a new round of tax cuts.
At the start of a year in which he will begin work on his 1998 re-election campaign, Mr. Pataki unveiled a plan that offers a clear blueprint of his political and fiscal priorities -- mainly reducing taxes, fighting crime and helping local school districts. 
 Under the plan, he would provide additional money for public schools, for 7,000 new prison cells and begin a multiyear plan to cut taxes on property, inheritances and certain businesses. He would pay for it all with new revenues from a buoyant economy, a $1.3 billion surplus from the current year and deep cuts to Medicaid, the state and Federal health care program for the poor and middle class, as well as to the State University and City University of New York systems.
But in a departure from his first two budget proposals, which called for deep reductions in a broad array of state programs, the Governor's newest fiscal plan would maintain spending on many services at or slightly above current levels.
Indeed, having successfully pushed the Legislature to reduce the portion of the budget financed by state taxes during his first two years in office, Mr. Pataki conceded today that his third budget would probably result in an increase in this spending.
He called for cutting spending from state taxes by $56 million to $32.8 billion, or a cut of just two-tenths of 1 percent. The Legislature almost invariably adds spending to governors' budgets, and Mr. Pataki said it was likely that that would happen again with this budget, meaning that the total spending would probably go up.
But even as Mr. Pataki called for his largest spending budget yet, his plan came under sharp attack. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called the plan to cut property taxes unfair to the city. Health care industry officials said the Medicaid cuts would drive urban hospitals to the brink of insolvency, and educators argued that the higher education cuts would prevent poor students from attending public colleges.
These attacks presage a fierce battle over the plan in the Legislature in the coming months. Last year, the Legislature enacted the latest state budget in the nation's history after making substantial changes to the Governor's original proposal. With several other contentious issues facing the legislators, including changes in welfare and rent-control regulations, most legislators are predicting that this year's fight could be every bit as protracted. The deadline for passing the budget is April 1, which the Legislature has missed for 12 years running.
As a sign of just how bitter the process may be, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who will be Mr. Pataki's major adversary in the budget talks, did not even attend his budget speech today, though a front-row seat was reserved for him. His aides said Mr. Silver had a previously scheduled meeting to attend.
In a 35-minute speech that echoed the major themes of his third address to the Legislature last week, Mr. Pataki said the tightfisted spending policies and tax cuts he ushered into policy beginning in the tightfisted spending policies and tax cuts he ushered into policy beginning in 1994 have brought the state back from the brink of fiscal disaster and made it possible to expand select programs.
"Over the last two years, New York State has changed course," he said. "This new course had placed us in the midst of a great comeback, and placed us on the path to returning our state to its proper role as leader among the states."
But groups that monitor the state's spending said the Governor's proposal relies too heavily on optimistic economic projections, particularly for Wall Street, and does not do enough to solve the state's longstanding habit of spending more than it collects. They charged that the plan's tax cut provisions, which would reduce state revenues by more than $2 billion over four years, could create huge fiscal problems if the economy stalled.
"It's fiscally irresponsible," said Cynthia B. Green, vice president for state studies with the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group that monitors government spending. "He spoke of a balanced budget. That's not the case at all."
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, said: "I'm concerned about the long-term implications. Historically, Wall Street has not had continued long-term growth at such a strong rate."
But Mr. Pataki said his plan was not based solely on a booming stock market, which he said provided a relatively small part of total state spending. Even without this year's record market performance, Mr. Pataki said, the state would have ended the year with a surplus.
Under the Governor's plan, spending from all state funds would increase by $1.4 billion to $66.1 billion, a 2.2 percent increase.
The Governor's deepest cuts would be to Medicaid, which he would reduce by $913 million through reductions in reimbursement rates for hospitals, nursing homes and home health care agencies, among other proposals. The Governor proposed many of the same initiatives last year, only to see them blocked in the Legislature.
New York has by far the highest Medicaid costs in the nation, and Mr. Pataki said his proposed cuts were necessary to restrain soaring health care costs. But health care industry officials predicted that the reductions would force the closing of many urban hospitals and nursing homes, which are already being squeezed by new competition in the industry and Medicaid cuts from last year.
Because Medicaid is financed jointly by the Federal, state, and local governments, the Governor's plan would actually drain a total of $2.1 billion from the health care system, according to the administration and health-care industry officials. "It looks like the health-care community is being asked to do more than any other community in terms of deficit reductions," said Kenneth E. Raske, the president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
Reviving a proposal he made last year, Mr. Pataki called for building 7,000 new maximum-security prison cells over the next three years at a cost of $635 million. He said the new cells are needed to relieve current prison overcrowding as well as to provide space for prisoners who serve longer sentences under existing and proposed laws pushed by Mr. Pataki. Today, the Governor also renewed his call for ending parole for all violent offenders.
The Governor called for cutting state spending on public colleges by $175 million in the coming academic year. However, to offset that reduction, he called on both systems to increase tuition by $400 a year, which would bring annual tuition at the State University to $3,800 and at the City University to $3,600. Both systems raised tuition by $750 during Mr. Pataki's first year in office to make up for state budget cuts.
Mr. Pataki's plan includes $120 million for the first phase of a four-year plan to reduce property taxes by $1.7 billion and a three-year plan to cut gift and estate taxes by $400 million. But the proposal also includes $75 million in increased fees, including for vehicle registration.

HEADLINE: THE GIULIANI AGENDA: THE PLAN;
Giuliani Proposes Rail Tunnel To Carry Freight Past Hudson

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed building a tunnel beneath New York Harbor to carry rail freight efficiently between the water-fringed city and the rest of the country, and said the city would study transforming the weed-strewn waterfronts of Brooklyn and Staten Island into a port for a new generation of deep-hulled ships.
In his State of the City speech yesterday, the Mayor did not mention how the $800 million to $900 million freight tunnel would be paid for, nor did he indicate how much a new port would cost. 
 The tunnel proposal has been around for more than 70 years, and a host of obstacles stand in its way: not only its cost, but the political difficulties of building anything so big in New York City, where projects like Westway and the Second Avenue subway were proposed but never built.
But Mayor Giuliani said that an analysis of the economics of both the tunnel and port showed that the benefits would outweigh costs by as much as $1.6 billion.
He said that the tunnel and revival of the city's waterfront would create 53,000 jobs in the region, sharply cut truck traffic and pollution, reduce prices of consumer goods and insure that New York Harbor remains the dominant seaport on the East Coast. New York Harbor stands to lose its primacy because new, larger ships cannot negotiate the shallow channels leading to the New Jersey piers that are now the heart of harbor commerce.
Mr. Giuliani made the tunnel proposal in a freewheeling 83-minute speech that reviewed many of his administration's efforts during the last three years and that offered several spending plans that signaled the onset of an election year. [Page B3.]
New York City is the only major American city where goods are shipped in almost exclusively by trucks, clogging roads and fouling the air, said Representative Jerrold L. Nadler, a Democrat from Brooklyn, who has fought for a tunnel since 1979. The tunnel would make the city more accessible to rail traffic, since freight trains now must go almost to Albany to cross the Hudson.
The first move toward the tunnel and a new port would be a pair of $2 million studies that could clear the way for partial Federal financing for the projects, Mr. Giuliani said.
The announcement was hailed on many fronts as the first significant commitment of a New York City mayor since 1923 to the building of a freight tunnel under the harbor, which urban planners have said is an essential component of any plan to return some of the area's shipping trade to the New York side of the harbor it shares with New Jersey.
More than a generation ago, 90 percent of maritime commerce shifted from Brooklyn to New Jersey, where ample rail links and acres of open space accommodated huge cranes and other gear needed to handle a new generation of shipping containers. But the newest ships are too big for the New Jersey ports, while Brooklyn's channels can be dug deeply enough to handle them.
Mr. Nadler said he was confident that up to 80 percent of the cost of the tunnel could come from Federal grants for projects to improve transportation and cut pollution. "I've been going at this for 18 years and nothing's happened," Mr. Nadler said. "But I feel jubilant today."
He said that previous studies by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey had rejected the idea without any real analysis.
Michael C. Finnegan, counsel to Gov. George E. Pataki, said Mr. Pataki had not yet seen the study upon which Mayor Giuliani was basing plans for the tunnel. But, Mr. Finnegan said, "The Governor has long been interested in any plans that would revitalize the waterfronts in Brooklyn and Staten Island."
Support from Mr. Pataki would be crucial because the Federal transportation money for such projects is given in blocks to states, with the states determining how it is spent.
A freight tunnel linking Brooklyn with New Jersey was first proposed in 1920, and it became the basis for the creation of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 1921. But the project became bogged down, and in 1923, New York City began building a tunnel to Staten Island instead.
That project died in political wrangling between the city and Gov. Alfred E. Smith, Mr. Nadler said. The concept was literally buried in the 1960's, Mr. Nadler added, when Robert Moses, who preferred roads to rails, used fill from the construction of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to seal one of the shafts leading to the stillborn tunnel project.
From the 1960's on, as Federal money flowed into the Interstate System of highways, rail transport became less and less competitive. But now, the city's air is fouled and its roads and bridges crumbling under the endless assault of 50,000 trucks a day, and truck traffic is only expected to increase because of the absence of new rail links, Mr. Nadler said.
Mr. Giuliani's enthusiasm for the tunnel grew out of a two-year study of ways to improve the shipment of goods to and from New York City, said Charles Millard, president of New York City's Economic Development Corporation. The study showed that the tunnel, without any improvement of the city's piers, would pay for itself in many ways, Mr. Millard said.
He said that only 3 percent of the 146 million tons of goods that move around New York City comes by rail, while the average for other American cities is around 30 percent and has been showing signs of increasing. Just in terms of wear and tear on roads and bridges, the shift of much of that commerce to rails would remove 870,000 truck trips a year from city roads by 2020, he said.
The new studies show that the tunnel, together with reviving Brooklyn's piers, makes sense for the port as a whole, Mr. Millard said. He said that it could cost $3.3 billion to deepen the channels leading to New Jersey and add several hundred acres of land there. But shifting deeper ships to Brooklyn and building the tunnel would cost $2.5 billion, he said.
Mr. Giuliani and his aides criticized the Port Authority yesterday for failing to give the tunnel serious consideration. Mr. Millard said, among other things, "A tunnel would take away from their tolls. Eighty percent of the truck traffic through the city goes over the George Washington Bridge."
Mr. Millard said the tunnel would run from a rail yard at 65th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, either to St. George, S.I., or Greenville, N.J., both of which have rail lines. The link through Staten Island would appear to make more sense, he said, because it would link up with any new port development there as well as in Brooklyn. It would also raise the possibility that the project could be done without the involvement of the Port Authority or New Jersey.
Putting together financing for the tunnel alone will entail substantial challenges at the Federal, state and local level, said urban planners.
"We couldn't be more supportive of the tunnel, but the biggest problem is who's going to pay for it," said Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, a private group that examines economic and environmental issues affecting New York City and the region.
"The problem is, the beneficiaries, businesses and air and roads, don't contribute directly to bonds that could pay for a tunnel," he said.

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

NEW YORK
 
Harbor Freight Tunnel Proposal
In his State of the City speech, Mayor Giuliani proposed building a tunnel beneath New York Harbor to carry rail freight between the water-fringed city and the rest of the country, and said the city would study transforming the weed-strewn waterfronts of Brooklyn and Staten Island into a hub port for a new generation of deep-hulled ships. [Page A1.] 

The Mayor took the City Council on a tour of his three years in office and promised appealing spending plans that clearly signaled the beginning of an election year. [B3.]
 
Pataki's $66 Billion Budget
Governor Pataki proposed a $66.1 billion budget that relies heavily on strong economic growth and cuts to higher education and health care programs. The additional money would finance increased spending on public schools and prison construction as well as a new round of tax cuts. The plan offers a clear blueprint of Mr. Pataki's political and fiscal priorities a year before his 1998 re-election campaign. [A1.]
 
The Governor's budget would raise state spending 2.2 percent, with most programs seeing modest increases but Medicaid undergoing a sizable cut. [B4.]
 
Mayor Giuliani assailed Governor Pataki's plan to cut property taxes in the state by $1.7 billion, saying it was unfair to New York City. [B4.]
 
Extreme Fighting Is Legalized
New York has become the first state in the nation to legalize extreme fighting, a competition that it once derided as a blood sport and that two other states have banned as too brutal. In extreme fighting, two combatants climb into an octagonal ring and do whatever they can -- aside from biting and eye gouging -- to send each other into unconsciousness or submission. [A1.]

The first potential juror was selected in the Megan Kanka murder trial despite objections from the defense because the man said he knew about "Megan's Law." CORRECTION-DATE: January 16, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A headline yesterday about a legal challenge to a New York State law that bans the on-line transmission of certain material to minors misstated the scope of the law. As the article stated, it prohibits transmission of indecent material, not just obscenity. (The courts have ruled that obscene material, which appeals to prurient interest and has no redeeming value, does not have First Amendment protection; the state's power to ban obscenity is not at issue. Indecent material does have some First Amendment protection, though the courts have ruled that it can be regulated to protect minors.)

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up 0.3%; Retail Sales Post Small Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Inflation remained under control in December, and consumer prices rose a total of 3.3 percent in 1996 spurred by food and energy prices, the Labor Department said today.
In another economic report today, the Commerce Department's monthly survey of retail sales confirmed what merchants had suggested for weeks: the 1996 holiday season produced meager gains. 
 Retail sales climbed six-tenths of 1 percent last month to a level 4.4 percent above that of December 1995, far less an improvement than merchants had generally expected given solid economic expansion and a roaring stock market.
"It's like a complete replay" of last year, said Susan M. Sterne, who specializes in consumer behavior as president of Economic Analysis Associates in Greenwich, Conn. "It's very difficult to entice consumers to purchase things."
This 4.4 percent increase looks particularly unimpressive when adjusted for inflation, which the Labor Department said rose 3.3 percent for the year as the cost of food and energy stopped acting as a moderating force on inflation and aggravated it instead. Prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December.
Securities markets greeted the two reports favorably, however, apparently viewing them as evidence that the economy would continue to expand without inflationary pressures that would prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
Despite the disappointing holiday sales, said Gary Schlossberg, senior economist at Wells Capital Management in San Francisco, consumer spending "is in the midst of a recovery from a weak third quarter" and, because retailers are increasingly discounting prices, may be a bit stronger than the figures imply.
Spending on personal consumption grew just five-tenths of 1 percent in the July-September quarter, but Robert T. McGee, economist at the Tokai Bank in New York, and others expect a 3 percent rate of expansion when the fourth quarter is reported Jan. 31.
Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, about evenly split between retailers and such recipients as doctors, utilities and insurance companies.
Today's inflation report was open to wide interpretation, with the markets seemingly most impressed by the fact that the Consumer Price Index edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent last month when the volatile food and energy components were excluded and rose only 2.6 percent on this basis for the full year. Along with an increase of the same size in 1994, this is the lowest core inflation since 1965.
On the other hand, analysts noted that food and energy accounted for nearly one-quarter of the price index and should not be entirely disregarded by inflation watchers just because their movements are often governed by temporary events like the weather and are outside the control of policy makers.
"There are some storm clouds brewing," Mr. Schlossberg said, pointing to continued tight labor markets and high oil prices, the latter becoming embedded to at least some extent in the economic fabric.
He and others are predicting that the Fed will decide to raise short-term interest rates, probably in late March but possibly as soon as the policy meeting in early February.
Although inflation is regarded as a lagging indicator -- and core inflation lags behind the economy even more than the full Consumer Price Index -- some found it unsettling that in 1996 overall consumer inflation rose to 3.3 percent from 2.5 percent in 1995.
Indeed, the 3.3 percent increase was the fastest since 1990, when inflation was 6.1 percent; since then inflation had eased every year except for 1994, when it was unchanged.
While the price of energy jumped 1.6 percent in December -- and 8.6 percent for the year -- the food and beverage index slowed to a one-tenth of 1 percent increase and grocery store food prices, reflecting lower dairy and fruit and vegetable costs, actually fell by that amount, the first decline in 13 months.
Airline fares jumped 3.9 percent last month to lift the 1996 increase to 14.7 percent while auto finance charges and used cars fell in price for the third consecutive month.
Medical costs, up two-tenths of 1 percent last month, rose 3 percent for all of 1996; this was down from 3.9 percent in 1995 and represented the slimmest annual increase since 1965.
In the New York metropolitan area, consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December and 2.9 percent for the full year, the Labor Department said.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 20, 1997, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Wednesday showing changes in consumer prices for major metropolitan areas in November misstated the percent changes from a year ago for New York and Los Angeles. They were a gain of 2.9 percent, not 3.3 percent, for New York, and a gain of 2.4 percent, not 2.9 percent, for Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: Ecuador's President Stands on His Record

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Jan. 11 news article "Ecuador Chief, the Populist, Is Anything but Popular" fails to point out the difficult economic situation in which President Abdala Bucaram, the youngest chief executive in South America, received the country, and the hard and unpopular decisions he has made in order to place Ecuador back on the path of growth and development. 
 In the five months since assuming office, Mr. Bucaram has renegotiated important oil contracts, substantially reduced the usurious bank loan rates, initiated the construction of 200,000 houses for low-income families and implemented social programs to provide free medical attention, school breakfasts and textbooks. All of this within the utmost respect to democratic freedom. There is not a single political detainee in Ecuador.
To help poor children, President Bucaram has recorded songs and raised millions of dollars in telethons. He has also refused to embark on a regional arms race and has committed to advance a peaceful integration process, especially with neighboring countries. Just today Mr. Bucaram arrived in Lima, Peru, to meet with President Alberto Fujimori to seek a joint and peaceful solution to the long standing territorial dispute between the two countries.
President Bucaram's administration should be judged only by the results of his policies. The road to social reform and steady development in Latin America is long and difficult.
 
HUGO CAICEDO
Ambassador of Ecuador
Washington, Jan. 13, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Eases Broadly on Signs Of Profit Taking After Run-Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against leading currencies yesterday for the first time in more than a week, hurt by profit taking after it reached a 29-month high against the German mark and a 45-month high against the Japanese yen.
"The market was just getting a little bit ahead of itself," said Jim Powers, vice president for foreign-exchange sales at Westdeutsche Landesbank in New York. "We really haven't had any down day on this recent move up, so it was a bit of a correction." 
 Fear that Japan's central bank might take steps to strengthen the yen today also contributed to the retreat in the dollar. Japanese financial markets were closed yesterday for a national holiday, Adult Day.
The dollar was further held back by a new rise in the British pound, on unexpectedly strong employment data in Britain. The news was seen as a further reason for Britain to raise interest rates.
The dollar rose as high as 117.20 yen in Asian trading, the highest since March 1993, before falling back to 116.88 yen late yesterday in New York, down from 116.93 yen on Tuesday.
In Europe the dollar reached 1.6000 marks, the highest since July 1994, before retreating to 1.5877 late in New York trading, down from 1.5943. The pound settled in New York at $1.6827, up from $1.6711.
The dollar had risen since Jan. 8, largely on a mixture of strong American economic news and signs of more weakness in Japan and Germany.
Traders said the momentum of the dollar's rise drove it higher in early dealings. News that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia would remain hospitalized at least until next week also undermined the mark, which often falls on signs of political instability in Russia. But large sell orders hit the dollar when it reached 1.6000 mark.
"We made such a rapid move up; I think clearly some consolidation was in order," said Tom Hoge, vice president for corporate foreign-exchange trading at the Bank of New York. Some dealers attributed the dollar's weakness in part to a surge in the Canadian dollar, which reached the highest level since November after an article in The Financial Times said that economists had become very positive about Canada's economy. Indeed, the Canadian dollar settled yesterday at 74.53 cents, up from 74.03 cents on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Heavy Supply Of Debt Hurts Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday as investors grew concerned about an abundance of new debt coming to market.
In addition to new corporate and municipal issues, the Treasury announced yesterday the sale of $30 billion in two-year and five-year notes next week. 
 By the close of the New York market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 9/32, to 96 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.79 percent, from 6.77 percent on Tuesday.
With no data of consequence and low average participation in the Treasury market, activity was dominated by corporate bond issues, said Ken Logan, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data. More than $5 billion in corporate debt is expected to be priced over the next couple of days.
U S West Capital Funding, a unit of U S West Inc., which plans to price $3.5 billion of debt today, leads the corporate and municipal issuers that are expected over the next few days.
"Investor appetite for spread products, like corporate paper, is very strong at this time," Mr. Logan said.
Still, dealers were uncertain about the eventual success in placing all the corporate paper, and they decided to hedge some of their exposure. "This hedging moved prices lower early on," Mr. Logan said. The market was able to recover and closed mixed as corporate supply went well and hedges were bought back.
The size of the U S West offering expected today is up from $2 billion, and will match in size the Lockheed Martin Corporation's offering last May, as the biggest sale ever of investment grade corporate bonds in the United States.
In the municipal market, New York City priced $805.3 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum 6.32 percent for an issue due in 2025 , while serial bonds with short maturities are priced to yield from 5.35 percent in 2003 to 6.27 percent in 2015.
The bonds are rated Baa1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by Standard & Poor's, with the exception of maturities that are due in 2007 to 2009 and whose principal and interest payments are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Corporation. Those securities are rated triple-A as a result.
The city also sold $300 million in floating-rate notes to foreign investors at a price to yield 25 basis points more than the three-month London interbank offered rate, set at 5.562 percent. The London interbank offered rate, or Libor, is the basic short-term lending rate in the Eurodollar market.
It is the first sale of a floating-rate issue by a United States municipality to foreign investors and the city's second foray into Europe.
Shorter maturities seemed to benefit yesterday from the uneasiness in the market over supply, reinvestment and coming economic data, as investors move from the longer maturities to the shorter end of the market to minimize exposure in the event of a downturn.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to issue $17.5 billion of two-year notes on Wednesday and $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Thursday. The size of the two-year note auction was reduced by $750 million.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.99 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.30 percent.

HEADLINE: Jesse Jackson Sets Up Office To Monitor Corporate Action

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
As if Wall Street has not been frenetic enough in recent weeks, it will soon have a new tenant who plans to shake it up even more: the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.
Mr. Jackson yesterday announced plans to open an office on Wall Street next month that will bring his brand of capitalism to the epicenter of the world's financial system. 
 Mr. Jackson said his new office would seek to cajole, persuade and pressure American companies to hire and promote more blacks and members of other minorities, name more of them to corporate boards and award more business to companies owned by members of minorities.
Speaking to an enthusiastic group of black executives at the World Trade Center in Manhattan, Mr. Jackson said, "Open up the walls on Wall Street."
To put pressure on corporate America, Mr. Jackson said he would publish details on how well 100 of the nation's largest corporations treat minorities. As further pressure, he pledged to form a group of a million consumers -- 20,000 in each of the nation's 50 largest cities -- and provide them with monthly updates on the records of specific companies' dealings with minorities.
Donald J. Trump received an ovation when he announced that he would donate office space to Mr. Jackson's civil rights group, the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, in 40 Wall Street, a 72-story building he is renovating.
"He's out there pushing for a lot of good things," said Mr. Trump, who noted that he and Mr. Jackson had become good friends over the years.
The office will be run by the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, which was formed by the merger of Mr. Jackson's civil rights and economic development groups, the Rainbow Coalition and Operation PUSH. He said the office would focus on the automobile, food and telecommunications industries.
"We insist that corporations stop the formula of targeting us for consumption and then boycotting us," Mr. Jackson said. "We don't want to be boycott partners. We want to be trading partners."
Not everyone in New York welcomed Mr. Jackson's arrival. Abigail Thernstrom, a senior fellow with the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research organization, said, "He'll make a lot of companies nervous."
"The instant Jackson suggest that companies might not be meeting his standards on affirmative action hiring or racial sensitivity, companies will immediately start chewing their nails," she said. "It's a very intimidating message."

HEADLINE: Christopher Sees Threat Of Isolation Via U.S. Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned today of "a new isolationism" emerging in Congress and said the State Department could not sustain more budget cuts without seriously undercutting American foreign policy around the world.
In a speech that was part valedictory and part call to action as he prepares to step down next week, Mr. Christopher said a steady decline in foreign-affairs spending had already forced the United States to close consulates and even embassies and to shortchange efforts in some parts of the world in order to address immediate crises in others. 
 Mr. Christopher warned that continued budget cuts could force the United States to reduce aid to countries considered essential to American interests, including Israel, Egypt and Jordan.
"The biggest crisis we're facing in our foreign policy today is whether we will spend what we must to have an effective American foreign policy," Mr. Christopher said in a speech at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
Mr. Christopher's speech echoed warnings he has made in recent months, as well as remarks made by his designated successor, Madeleine K. Albright, at her confirmation hearings last week. But it came as the State Department and the President's budget office continue to haggle over the size of the foreign-affairs budget that President Clinton will submit to Congress early next month.
After four years of steady decline, officials at the State Department now express confidence that Mr. Clinton will fight vigorously to prevent further reductions by Congress.
The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the President's budget for the fiscal year that begins in October would include $19.3 billion in spending on the array of agencies and programs grouped under the rubric of foreign affairs. That would represent a 5 percent increase over the $18.3 billion allocated by Congress for the current year, but it is also more than $1 billion less than the State Department had requested.
The officials said Mr. Clinton's budget would also include a plan to repay the United States' debt to the United Nations -- something Mr. Christopher, in today's speech, called overdue. The officials said the President proposed repaying the outstanding dues over two years, with $100 million in the coming year and $900 million in the year after, provided the new Secretary General, Kofi Annan, showed a commitment to reforming the United Nations.
Many of the President's budget proposals are likely to encounter resistance from Republicans in Congress as the budget is debated over the months to come. And some Republicans took exception to Mr. Christopher's criticisms, dismissing the accusation of isolationism.
"The biggest crisis, with all due respect to the Secretary of State, is the fact we have a budget deficit," said Jo R. Bonner, chief of staff to Representative Sonny Callahan of Alabama, who is the Republican chairman of the House appropriations subcommittee that oversees foreign affairs. "There's not a money tree to do all the things we would like to do here at home, much less in other parts of the world."
But other Republicans have made the case for an increase in spending. Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, who has advocated forcefully on the issue recently, agreed with Mr. Christopher's warnings. In an interview today, he said the President would have to make a strong case to win approval for his budget proposals, but that the chances this year appeared brighter.
"It seems to me the groundwork is a little firmer than has been the case in the last few years," he said.
In his speech today, Mr. Christopher said the United States needed to maintain spending on foreign affairs to advance American leadership around the world. But he noted that the foreign-affairs budget, when adjusted for inflation, had fallen by nearly half since 1985.
"Just as we need to preserve our military readiness by maintaining forces and bases around the world, we need to preserve our diplomatic readiness by supporting the people and the programs that help to keep our soldiers out of war," he said.
At one point, Mr. Christopher pointed to today's agreement between the Israelis and the Palestinians on control of Hebron as an example of the need to continue to devote adequate resources. He also noted that half of all foreign aid went to nations involved in the peace effort, and warned that such aid "will inevitably come under pressure, possibly irresistible pressure" if budget cuts continue.
Aid to Israel and Egypt, which total about $3 billion and $2 billion, respectively, has been a bedrock of American policy in the Middle East for years, and it is highly unlikely the Administration would propose or Congress would pass reductions in it.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Japan is in a mess, but there's optimism that the worst is past.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THERE'S nothing like a few hundred billion dollars in losses in the stock market -- in just a few hours last week, no less -- to stir interest in an economy's failings. The economy (knock on wood) is Japan, where near panic in the stock market has drawn attention to the surprisingly fragile machinery driving what was long seen as an unstoppable industrial juggernaut.
The new attention, though, is about three years late. For after years of going nowhere, the Japanese economy may finally be poised for a modest recovery. Indeed, Japanese housing starts, motor vehicle sales and payroll employment are all on the upswing. "There's light at the end of this tunnel -- really," argues Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan. 
 Like its American counterpart, the Japanese economy staggered into the 1990's trying to shake off the effects of a global recession. But unlike America, Japan never bounced back: since 1992 the American economy, adjusted for inflation, has grown 22 percent, while Japan's output is up an anemic 6 percent.
After the fact, Japan's tepid economic performance seems no great surprise. A strong yen made Japanese products far less competitive in world markets, while the Government bureaucracy's Pollyanna forecasts sapped business confidence. Perhaps most important, Japan has ducked a resolution of its banking crisis. "There's never been a comprehensive program, complete with bailout money, to put the problems of the financial system behind them," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
The timing of this stock market wobble is harder to explain. John Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, sees it as a reaction to the dawning perception that the Government really is determined to go through with plans to raise both income and sales taxes in April -- a move that would cut consumer purchasing power at a less-than-opportune moment. Mr. Saxonhouse links the stock market's jitters to a Government forecast of 1.9 percent growth in output in 1997, the lowest official prediction ever.
Whatever the reason, conventional wisdom says that the stock market's troubles will compound the problem of getting back to the 3 to 4 percent economic growth rate of the recent past. For one thing, falling securities prices feed expectations of general price deflation, which make even the current low, low nominal interest rates seem high.
For another, there's the issue of the banks' balance sheets. Lacking active bond or short-term commercial paper markets, Japan depends on banks for credit creation. But now that stock losses have further depressed their net worth, the banks -- reeling from real estate debts -- may be even pickier about where they lend money.
Why, then, the cautious optimism that the worst is in the past? The Economist magazine offers the novel argument that the party hacks now in power will be forced to take bold action to deregulate the economy because traditional means of recession-fighting -- fiscal and monetary stimulus -- have lost their punch. And while the long overdue deregulation of everything from retailing to land use hardly seems a substitute for Keynesian-style macroeconomic policies, it just might increase confidence and lead to an upswing in investment.
The more tangible basis for optimism, suggests Roger Kubarych, general manager at the firm of Henry Kaufman Associates, is exports. Japanese goods that were virtually frozen out of world markets when it took a dollar to buy 90 yen, look far more competitive at 116 yen to the dollar. And while companies in America -- notably in Detroit -- will no doubt howl about unfair competition, it will take time for Washington to work up righteous anger over sneaky Japanese attempts to sell high- quality goods to Americans at low prices.
The biggest puzzle is how the Japanese, so long admired for their adaptability as well as their industry and thrift, managed to snare themselves in the slow-growth syndrome one associates with, say, Britain in the 1960's and 1970's. One reason must be that very high savings rates and a superbly disciplined work force are no longer enough to cover a multitude of sins ranging from corruption to obsessive conformity. Few other democracies, one suspects, would allow an organization as blemished by scandal and incompetence as the Liberal Democratic Party to control its destiny.
Another reason, though, is more benign. In America, six years of economic stagnation would have generated great suffering. In Japan, unemployment remains below 4 percent and outrageous social problems like homelessness and childhood poverty are nonexistent, or at least disguised.
Consider, too, that the price deflation that has hobbled monetary policy and choked off investment creates winners as well as losers. "If you're working and not too worried about the future of your job," Mr. Kubarych notes, "you've enjoyed tremendous income growth in the last few years."

HEADLINE: Mexico Repays Bailout by U.S. Ahead of Time

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that Mexico had repaid all of the $12.5 billion it borrowed from Washington to stave off a financial collapse two years ago, ending one of Mr. Clinton's riskiest overseas ventures and releasing Mexico from tight economic controls imposed by Washington.
The repayment of the loan -- three years ahead of schedule -- was marked by a celebration at the White House today presided over by Mr. Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who had warned that a default by Mexico could bring down economies around the world. 
 "Two years ago helping our friend and neighbor in a time of need was quite controversial," Mr. Clinton said today, a reference to his decision to do an end run around Congress, which refused to act on an emergency package for Mexico, and to lend the cash from funds under the President's control.
"Some said that we should not get involved, that the money would never be repaid, that Mexico should fend for itself," Mr. Clinton said. "They were wrong." He stopped short of naming those opponents, who included Ross Perot, Patrick J. Buchanan and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican.
Mr. D'Amato made several attempts to stop the transfer of funds to Mexico, declaring in March 1995 that "the Mexican bailout is a failure" and that the Administration had made the economic climate in Mexico "far worse than it needed to become."
Today, Mr. D'Amato issued a terse statement saying that he was "pleased" and attributed the quick repayment to "vigilant Congressional oversight."
In the end, Mr. Clinton said, the United States ran a profit of more than half a billion dollars on the loans.
That money, which American officials said would go toward deficit reduction in the United States, is above the interest the cash would have earned had it remained in the Federal Reserve's emergency stabilization fund, which was originally designed to steady the dollar rather than the currencies of allies.
In Mexico City, the news prompted a rally in the stock and bond markets -- in part because paying off the loans meant that the country no longer needed to put up its oil production revenues as collateral. The Mexican stock market rose 2.66 percent today and is up more than 12 percent this year.
President Ernesto Zedillo declared that the Government had made a "bold step toward the economic recovery of Mexico."
In fact, what Mr. Zedillo did today was what most prudent homeowners do when interest rates dip: he refinanced. In the seven months that followed the collapse of the peso in December 1994, and the ensuing dance with national bankruptcy, private lenders refused to go near Mexico, only worsening its troubles.
For that reason, Mexico secured a credit line from the United States of $20 billion, but only needed to borrowed 60 percent of that. But now, with renewed confidence in the Government's reforms -- confidence that some economists warn is premature -- investors around the world are once again rushing to lend Mexico all that it needs.
So Mr. Zedillo's Government is exchanging high interest loans from Washington with new bonds issued by Mexico. While those bonds carry relatively high interest rates, Mexican officials said today that they would save Mexico about $100 million a year in payments.
"Some predicted that our country would collapse, that the foreign aid would be unpayable and infringe our sovereignty, and that in the short term we'd be in a worse crisis," Mr. Zedillo said in a morning speech in Mexico City. But the early retirement of the debt to the United States Treasury demonstrates, Mr. Zedillo said, "the coherence and responsibility the Mexican people and Government have shown in these tough times."
The Mexican debt crisis produced some of Mr. Rubin's tensest days at the Treasury, and in private he hinted that he worried throughout the spring of 1995 that it could fail. "This was Bob Rubin's Bosnia," one of his top aides said today. "And today he got the troops out."
The usually understated former investment banker was clearly reveling in the success of the bailout today.
In the Roosevelt Room at the White House, Mr. Clinton sidestepped a question about a recent decline in the value of the peso and deferred to Mr. Rubin, explaining "you've made so much more money than I have."
"There is a point to that!" said Mr. Rubin, who usually makes no references -- even in jest -- to his huge fortune.
Back at the Treasury later in the day Mr. Rubin raised an eyebrow when his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers -- who was the first to recognize the possible ripple effects of the crisis in emerging markets and who organized much of the loan effort -- joked that he would settle for just 1 percent of the Treasury's $580 million profit on the deal.
"Larry, anything you can negotiate, I'm happy to split with you," Mr. Rubin shot back.
While the Administration was eager to describe Mexico today as a patient in recovery, the cost was high for Mexican workers who lost their jobs during the austerity program imposed as a condition of the loans, for homeowners who were unable to pay their mortgages and for businesses that suddenly found themselves caught in a severe recession.
Crime has soared in Mexico City, the pay of Mexican workers is still badly depressed, and the peso has stabilized but failed to return to its earlier values. While Mr. Clinton made much of the fact that American exports to Mexico were higher today than they were in 1994, before the crisis struck, he failed to mention that the trade deficit with Mexico had surged by nearly $18 billion.
Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, said in an interview today that Mexico had assembled the funds for its final payment to the United States -- previously it had paid off about 70 percent of its debt -- by selling bonds denominated mostly in foreign currencies in European, Asian and American markets.
The most recent bonds, which had terms of five to 10 years, generally longer than Mexico had on the United States debt, had yields of 3.35 percent more than United States Treasury securities.
"That's a lot lower than we were paying a year ago," Mr. Ortiz said. The rates, which are also generally lower than those Mexico was paying to the United States, reflect the recovery of international confidence in Mexico's solvency made possible by Mexico's tough economic program and the American bailout, he said.
"Obviously the crisis took a toll in terms of economic welfare, and incomes are still down from their 1994 level," Mr. Ortiz added. "Consumption has not completely recovered yet. But had we not had the support of the international financial community and of the United States, the consequences would have been much worse."
Nonetheless, average Mexicans will still have difficulty understanding today's debt-retirement celebrations, said Rafael Fernandez, a professor at the Autonomous Technical Institute in Mexico. "The left will argue that in order to pay off these debts so quickly, Zedillo has had to impose tough austerity, and those that are suffering are the poor," he said.
One of the byproducts of the Mexican crisis was a move by the United States to press for far more extensive disclosure of critical financial information by countries around the world -- data that had they been published by the Mexican Government in 1994 would have made it clear that the country's foreign exchange reserves had dwindled to dangerously low levels. That meant Mexico was unable to pay $29 billion in short-term debt that was denominated in dollars.
Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers worried during the bailout that they were creating a "moral hazard" -- that other countries around the world might see the United States as a lender of last resort in financial crises.
"I'm not as concerned about that today," Mr. Rubin said this afternoon. "This experience has been enormously painful for the Mexican people. Countries are unlikely to decide that if worse comes to worse, we'll do what Mexico did."
Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers have also worked to set up international emergency funds, to which all nations would contribute, to handle further Mexican-style crises.
Today Representative James A. Leach of Iowa, the Republican chairman of the House Banking and Financial Services Committee, praised the success of the bailout but warned that "great caution is going to have to be exercised in assuming that this is the only or best way to proceed." American taxpayers, he said, cannot be "placed disproportionately in jeopardy."

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Artists Bring New Color To a Gray City

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.

 BODY:
"THE greatest thing about Peekskill," Ralph DiBart was saying with barely restrained pride, "is the mix. The mix is the whole key to our renaissance."
Exhilarated by the prospect of making his point, he scooted up Main Street from City Hall, his trench coat flapping against the wind. At the corner, he halted at a stone building with the words "Evening Star" etched above the door. Across the street stood the buildings of the projects. On the side was a playground. 
 "When Gannett took over the Star, they had no use for this building," Mr. DiBart said, relishing the surprise in store. He scurried to the side of the building and knocked on an unmarked door.
Voila! Inside was a big, airy artist's loft with a working artist, Andrew Lattimore, waiting to sing its praises.
"This has been the ultimate studio environment for me," said Mr. Lattimore. A painter, he moved here from White Plains two and a half years ago, when Peekskill was in the throes of marketing its poor downtrodden downtown as SoHo North. His 2,400-square-foot studio is one of three rental lofts in the old Evening Star building. "I've lived in New York, I've lived in Europe," he said. "I've never lived in a place as supportive as Peekskill."
MR. DiBART, a planning consultant hired by Peekskill to bring new life to the city's decrepit business district, was beaming. He had suggested a downtown artist district as Peekskill's best chance for survival. The reality has outpaced the dream. Nearly 100 artists now live or work here, and the city has received calls from as far away as Florida.
Ten years ago, this would have been impossible to believe. Peekskill, hometown of Gov. George E. Pataki, has always been Westchester County's sad little city to the north. Bordered by antiquesvilles like Cold Spring and fancy exurbs like Garrison, where the Governor now lives, Peekskill seemed to have more in common with the aging post-industrial cities farther upstate, like Schenectady or Utica.
But while Schenectady and Utica are in such dire straits that their leaders want to shut their governments down, Peekskill (pop.: 20,000) is realizing one big project after another. Last week, it announced plans for a boat launch and expansion of a walking trail, using a $100,000 state grant. Recently, it received approval for a $3.7 million state grant to construct 25 to 30 subsidized artists' condominiums on what is now a parking lot.
Dwight Douglas, the city's director of planning, also likes to talk up a project to develop Peekskill's industrial section, Charles Point. The city received a $98,000 state grant to help develop a waterfront park, which is being expanded with some of the $100,000 in state money.
"We have so many projects in the works," Mr. Douglas said. "It's not just the artists' district." Some of the ideas, he said, go back to the days when Governor Pataki was the part-time Mayor of Peekskill, from 1982 to 1984.
Mr. DiBart, a native of Peekskill whose father was mayor in the 1960's, seems most excited about the businesses that artists in Peekskill have attracted. Three years ago, Westchester Community College opened an annex that offers computer graphics and multimedia courses. Several computer graphics firms and multimedia businesses have since moved here.
WE knew that all we needed was a critical mass of artists to spur growth," Mr. DiBart said. "Now we have a critical mass."
It is not so obvious. On a walking tour of the district, Mr. DiBart kept pointing out artists' lofts. To the untrained eye, they looked like the vacant upper floors of old three-story brick buildings with stores at ground level, the kind you see in aging downtowns from here to Niagara Falls.
"It's true that you can't tell where they are," Mr. DiBart said. "We have to work on that. But the artists are forming a community by word of mouth. It has become the engine that drives development."
And it can't hurt that the Governor is a hometown boy. The Governor's family farm is still in Peekskill (though some of the 11-acre spread has been parceled for development). Mr. Pataki still commutes to Albany from Garrison, and he drops into Peekskill quite often.
Frances Gibbs, the Mayor, has lunch with Governor Pataki on a regular basis. "The Governor is interested in what's going on here," she said. But, she added, "We haven't received any special treatment. Peekskill has a long history of getting the funds it needs for development."

HEADLINE: Cutting Car Insurance Cost Poses Challenge for Whitman

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 15

 BODY:
Auto insurance reform has bedeviled New Jersey's last two Governors. Both of them, Thomas H. Kean and Jim Florio, proclaimed themselves champions of change and lower premiums. Ultimately, neither succeeded, and residents still pay the nation's highest premiums and grumble about it.
Now, as she prepares her run for re-election, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has weighed in with a new plan to reduce premiums anywhere from 5 to 25 percent by combating fraud and offering motorists a choice of policies that link savings to reduced coverage. 
 In the early sparring, the industry seems pleased with the plan. John Tiene, executive director of the New Jersey Insurance News Service, whose member companies write 70 percent of the state's car insurance policies, termed the Whitman plan "bold and dynamic." He said the industry was willing to accept Mrs. Whitman's abolition of its annual automatic cost-of-living premium increases and her proposed ban on the current practice of refusing to renew some policies without explanation.
Steven Goldstein, a vice president of the Insurance Information Institute, a trade association, praised her commitment to fewer "pain and suffering" lawsuits as an obvious way to reduce premiums.
But the president of the state's chapter of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, Harrison J. Gordon, dismissed the Whitman plan as "Draconian," asserting that it would benefit only the wealthiest policyholders.
Although the Whitman administration has approved some higher premiums, most of the issues that drive the state's insurance rates so high began long before Mrs. Whitman became Governor. Here are some of the factors:
*New Jersey has more traffic per highway mile than any other state, and plenty of nonfatal crashes; it trailed only Texas and Wisconsin in 1994, the last year with such figures available.
*Negligence lawsuits for "pain and suffering" are bountiful. Generous policies, with among the highest benefits in the country, produce high medical awards by juries and payments to policyholders.
*Controls against insurance fraud, both the state's and the industry's, are weak, critics contend.
*The insurance industry grumbles about state limits on profits, mandates that all motorists be offered insurance and limits on premium charges for the highest-risk drivers in urban areas. Costly policy surcharges persist to pay off billions in debt run up by insurance pools that existed for high-risk, bad drivers in the Kean and Florio years.
*Compounding everything have been years of sour relations between the industry in New Jersey and the state's trial lawyers. The lawyers have consistently fought any limit on drivers' right to file negligence suits for injuries caused by other motorists. Curtailing such suits for pain and suffering is now the centerpiece of Mrs. Whitman's insurance plan, to the delight of the industry and the consternation of the trial lawyers.
Many familiar with the state's insurance troubles say that the lawyers have the stronger lobbying voice in Trenton and that the fate of Mrs. Whitman's package in the Legislature will hinge in large measure on the two sides' willingness to compromise.
Today, the president of the State Bar Association, Cynthia M. Jacob, toughened her initial mild response to the Whitman plan. On Tuesday, Ms. Jacob offered the association's assistance in seeking reform. She said today that she had "great concerns" about Ms. Whitman's plan to curb lawsuits and said any restrictions on them would produce "nominal" reductions in premiums.
J. Robert Hunter, insurance director of the Consumer Federation of America, offered today a quick and simple solution to New Jersey's auto insurance woes and what appears now to be a lengthy struggle in the Legislature: simply adopt Michigan's "no fault" auto insurance law.
Only 11 states in the country have no-fault systems, including New Jersey and New York. Mr. Hunter said he considered Michigan's law the nation's best no-fault law because it provides motorists injured in crashes unlimited payments for their medical expenses and lost wages, and allows pain-and-suffering lawsuits only for death, serious impairment of a bodily function, and permanent and serious disfigurement.
Mr. Hunter said adoption of a single Michigan-type law in New Jersey for everyone would probably cut premiums 10 percent across the board and make an almost incomprehensible system far more understandable for the state's auto owners.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK -- Car Insurance: The Whitman Plan"
Here is how Gov. Christie Todd Whitman wants to cut the high cost of car insurance in New Jersey.
 
HOW SHE WOULD CHANGE THE SYSTEM
 
-- Eliminate automatic cost-of-living increases in premiums.
-- Eliminate "bad driver" surcharges for drivers who have just one accident or ticket.
-- Make it harder for accident victims to sue for pain and suffering.
-- Crack down of repair-shop and medical fraud.
 
HOW SHE WOULD CHANGE INSURANCE COVERAGE
 
A typical two-car family -- in this case, a 30-to-40-year-old couple with a 1995 Pontiac Grand Am and a 1990 Chevrolet Astro Van -- now pays $2,019 for the following coverage:
 
$100,000 -- Liability for injuries, including pain and suffering
$25,000 -- Property damage liability
$250,000 -- Medical costs and lost wages
$100,000 -- Compensation for an accident with an uninsured motorist. Damage, theft and collision with a $500 deductible. Right to sue for pain and suffering, but only if injuries are severe.

SAVING: $463
DIFFERENCES: Policyholder can sue or by sued for economic losses, like lost wages, but not for pain and suffering.
 
OPTION 2

SAVING: $133
DIFFERENCES: Similar to Option 1, but compensation for pain and suffering is determind by a schedule of what various injuries are worth.
 
OPTION 3
PREMIUM: $1,820
SAVING: $199
DIFFERENCES: Similar to the current coverage, with savings to come from system-wide changes.
 
OPTION 4
PREMIUM: $2,350
DIFFERENCES: Policyholder can sue for pain and suffering for any injury.
