HEADLINE: Beyond the Liberal Label;
Messinger Tries to Define Herself Before Giuliani Does It for Her

SERIES: OPENING STEPS: The Mayoral Race

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
"I know who you are! I know who you are!"
Carol Zappala, the manager of a lingerie shop in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx, looked up over her glasses and her telephone, greeting the vaguely familiar presence standing at the counter. Then she paused, locking eyes with her visitor, trying to raise the memory. "Refresh my recollection," Mrs. Zappala finally said. 
 Ruth W. Messinger -- a New York City Council member for 12 years, the Manhattan Borough President for 7 years, and now a Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York -- gamely refreshed her recollection, and Carol Zappala turned back to her telephone conversation:
"You know who I'm talking to? Ruth Messinger. Ruth Messinger!" At that, Mrs. Zappala looked past Ms. Messinger to the newspaper photographer behind her. "Let me take off my glasses," she said. 'They're taking my picture!' "
It was a cold Saturday afternoon in the Bronx, and Ms. Messinger -- a single aide at her side as she plodded up and down White Plains Road under the rumble of the IRT -- had just endured, in a humorous if slightly embarrassing moment, a reminder of the kind of political difficulties she faces in trying to become the next mayor of New York.
In Manhattan, Ms. Messinger is known as the earnest if slightly stern career legislator from the Upper West Side: the very portrait of government activism, always wrestling an outsize stack of papers under her arm as she leads battles for the city's downtrodden, fighting a huge project one day and City Hall the next.
But in much of the rest of the city, Ms. Messinger is, more often, a vaguely familiar face from the edges of politics and local television. What she is remembered for is not always helpful to someone running for citywide office, and it poses a central challenge to her candidacy.
She is the fiery woman who fenced so famously with the popular Mayor Edward I. Koch in the 1980's. And she is the Upper West Side legislator who came to be identified -- imprecisely, she now says -- as one of the faces of the kind of New York liberalism from which many politicians are distancing themselves with the rise of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Of all the candidates who are preparing to challenge Mr. Giuliani, none has worked longer, raised more money, is as well versed about municipal issues and seems as serious about her candidacy as Ms. Messinger. Even her critics, among them Mr. Koch, remark admiringly at her energy and persistence.
"Every time you see her and say hello, she sends you a letter saying it was nice to see you," Mr. Koch said the other day. "I believe that she has the dedication, the fire in the belly, to a greater extent then these other people."
It is that single-mindedness that leads Mr. Koch, and other political professionals, to suggest that Ms. Messinger has the strongest chance of winning her party's nomination.
Still, her candidacy remains somewhat unformed, facing even now a series of hurdles -- some of her making, and some not.
She, like the other Democrats, has the difficult task of making the case against Mr. Giuliani as he celebrates the city's declining crime rate and improving economy.
Perhaps just as problematic, she is in a quiet struggle to prevent Mr. Giuliani and her other opponents from encouraging potentially damaging preconceptions about her: that she is a captive of Manhattan; that she is a stiff campaigner who is more comfortable in front of a community board than before a television camera.
Most of all, though, it is that she is too liberal -- the "radical left," as Mr. Koch put it, or "extreme," as Mr. Giuliani said on the WCBS-TV program "Sunday Edition," signaling his intention to use against Ms. Messinger the strategy that has worked against such Democrats as Mario M. Cuomo, the former Governor.
"Once a word begins to be used pejoratively, you'd just as soon not have it attached to you," Ms. Messinger said over a steaming platter of pasta fagioli at Frankie n Johnnies, an Italian restaurant near Pelham Parkway, as dusk fell outside. She then offered this response to the characterization:
"If what people mean when they use the term pejoratively is that you don't take government's responsibility to spend its tax money seriously, then they've got the wrong person. If what people mean when they use the term pejoratively is that it's somebody who will not be attentive to the issues that define people's quality of life in New York, they've got the wrong person."
That criticism, she suggested, came from the reputation she built as a member of the Council, advocating a neighborhood that was particularly deluged by development.
"That was representing the West Side of Manhattan in the 80's," she said. "Now I'm representing the borough of Manhattan in the 90's. Not only have I evolved over 20 years in public life but times and issues in the city have changed."
In many ways, the story of Ms. Messinger's candidacy is about more than the candidate herself. Her attempt to adjust to changing times reflects how New York's political landscape has changed: It is, for example, no longer necessarily an advantage to be Jewish, or liberal, or from Manhattan.
If she won the nomination for mayor, she would be the first woman to be a major-party nominee for the post. While this is not exactly a groundbreaking event in American municipal politics, it is in New York, and it has already manifested itself in Ms. Messinger's campaign in a number of ways.
Ms. Messinger herself has acknowledged it in the way she presents herself to the public. As a candidate in the 1980's, she seemed more interested in what she was saying than in how she appeared.
Now, she is rarely seen without a string of pearls -- a standard accouterment for female candidates seeking to soften their public appearances -- and she tends to anchor her outfits with a bright dash of red, which looks good on television.
Along those lines, Ms. Messinger makes frequent note of her three grown children, who went through public schools, and how she rides the subway, does her own shopping and bakes what she asserts are the best chocolate desserts in New York. Ms. Messinger's makeover has been the subject of the kind of newspaper stories that normally do not appear about male candidates. Ms. Messinger seems a little uncomfortable, if resigned, to more such attention as the campaign progresses.
But there are indications, as well, that Ms. Messinger pays a substantive price for being a woman. She has been criticized, by newspaper columnists and some of her colleagues, as being overly aggressive in seeking public attention.
Her friends suggest that she is being held to a double standard because she is a woman, and in truth she is little different from many male politicians in this city, who are also renowned for their ability to elbow their way into a photograph.
More substantively, though, the prospect of Ms. Messinger as the first female major-party nominee for mayor seems certain to put to the test the question of whether this city is prepared to choose a woman for a post that is known, even outside New York, as the second-toughest job in the country. Women made up 57 percent of the electorate in the 1993 mayoral election, which presumably would bode well for Ms. Messinger.
But there are more than a few people who believe that Ms. Messinger's sex will hurt her, more than help her.
"In New York City, it would be a problem," said Rhoda Nadler, owner of a music store on Pelham Parkway. "You have a lot of male chauvinist -- I don't want to say its."
For her part, Ms. Messinger resists getting drawn into discussions on such questions. She even declines, following the unwritten book of rules that the Democrats have followed so far, to critique her primary opponents. "Not doing it," she said.
Mr. Giuliani is another story. She has spent much of the last few months exploring different ways of making a case against him, within the confines of her own long and detailed record of positions on the issues and Mr. Giuliani's political strengths, particularly on the issue of crime.
"Rape statistics are not going down," Ms. Messinger said the other night, speaking at the storefront headquarters of the New Democratic Committee in Harlem. "Too many people -- probably in this room -- know that statistics have gotten better, but don't feel safer in their own neighborhood."
"I'm glad the crime statistics are going down," she said. "But it worries me that when you call 911, it's going to take a minute longer than it did a few years ago for a police car to get there."
Similarly, Ms. Messinger, like the other major Democratic candidates -- Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn; Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, and the Rev. Al Sharpton -- point to the sliding reading scores in public schools as evidence that Mr. Giuliani has allowed his interest in fighting crime to overshadow any effort to improve public schools.
"This is an area in which this Mayor has let us all down," she said. "This is a Mayor who in three years has taken more than a billion dollars out of the education budget. You know what? You do not need to be a rocket scientist to understand that there will then be less money per child. There is a connection between dollars lost and why buildings are crumbling and why so many classrooms are overcrowded."
All that said, Ms. Messinger tends, as often as not, to speak in fairly general terms. She said that would change as she moves into the spring, but now, she is more apt to criticize Mr. Giuliani than to suggest what she would do instead. Thus, even as she assails the Mayor for cutting money for mass transit support and education, she declines to follow up her criticism with any promises.
"To say cuts should not have been made the way they were made," she said, "is not the same thing as saying put the money back."
 
Opening Steps
This is the second in a series of occasional articles examining the early campaign strategies of individual candidates in the New York City mayoral race.

"MINUSES"
 
1. A history of being associated with the Democrat liberal wing at a time when liberalism is increasingly on the defensive.
 
2. Identified with Manhattan, with little demonstrable support outside of it.
 
3. It's a question whether New York is ready to elect a woman for a tough executive position.
 
4. She has an uncomfortable television demeanor.

HEADLINE: Inventories Edged Higher In November

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Stocks of unsold goods barely rose in November as companies prepared warily for Christmas sales, the Commerce Department said today.
Total business inventories climbed one-tenth of 1 percent in November, to a seasonally adjusted $1.01 trillion, after an increase of one-half of 1 percent in October, the department said. 
 Analysts said the lean inventories and record low stock-to-sales ratios near the end of 1996 might clear the way for stronger production in the first quarter as businesses rebuild stocks.
The most significant change during November occurred at retailers, where inventories shrank four-tenths of 1 percent, to $314.05 billion, after an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent in October.
"Inventories did not expand robustly," said Kevin Harris, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. "There was some caution ahead of Christmas, obviously."
That caution was apparently warranted. On Tuesday, the department reported that retail sales in December increased six-tenths of 1 percent. For all of 1996, they were up just 5.3 percent from 1995.
Merchants previously said Christmas sales, though stronger than a year earlier, had not met predictions. Expectations had been high because of a strong stock market, plentiful jobs and incomes that grew throughout most of 1996.
Business sales in November were up six-tenths of 1 percent, to $729.83 billion, a third consecutive monthly increase.
That left the stock-to-sales ratio, which measures how long it would take to clear out inventories at the current sales pace, at 1.39 months in November, the same as in September and October. That is the lowest ratio since the Commerce Department began keeping records in 1982.
The small drop in November retail inventories was the first decline in eight months, since they fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in March. Most of the drop occurred at automobile dealers and furniture stores.
By contrast, manufacturers' inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November, to $439.89 billion, after a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in October. Wholesale inventories edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, to $285.02 billion, after a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in October.

HEADLINE: Pataki Wary on Financing Of a Hudson Freight Tunnel

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he was not ready to support Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to build a $900 million freight-rail tunnel under New York Harbor.
While indicating support for improving transportation around New York City and spurring the economy, the Governor said there might be preferable uses for the money. "I can't commit to financing" the project, he said in response to a question from a reporter during a forum sponsored by Crain's New York Business and the New York City Partnership. 
 Mr. Pataki said he looked forward to seeing a city study, now being prepared, that would spell out financing options and provide more detail on what would be the first new crossing of the Hudson River in 33 years.
Mr. Pataki's support is crucial because the Mayor is hoping that up to 80 percent of the cost of the tunnel would be paid with Federal transportation money. The Governor and the Legislature decide how New York's portion of that money is spent.
The main goals of the Mayor's plan are to speed the flow of goods in and around the city and to cut traffic, pollution and the wear on roadways caused by the vast fleets of trucks that crisscross the region. Because of a lack of direct access to rail lines, New York City is far more dependent on trucks than any other large American city. The tunnel, which would run from Brooklyn to either Staten Island or Jersey City, could also help draw shipping back to the city's piers by providing a link to the nation's rail system, Mr. Giuliani said.
In deciding to take on the tunnel project as he prepares for a re-election run, Mr. Giuliani is widely seen as taking a significant gamble in an arena, the realm of the mega-project, that is littered with past mayor's failures. But his administration and supporters at environmental and transportation groups say the gamble is critical if the city is to compete, clean its air and clear clogged roads.
"Without the Mayor's vision all we're going to have is a hodgepodge Band-Aid approach to a major regional problem," said Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation and an architect of the plan.
Most consumer goods bound for New York City, whether radios or potatoes, come by rail or truck to warehouses in New Jersey. The freight is then packed onto smaller trucks, which clog the George Washington Bridge and other roadways as they fan out to the five boroughs and surrounding communities.
If the tunnel was built, the same merchandise could travel nonstop by rail from New Jersey and points west under the Hudson River directly to Brooklyn. The merchandise would still get to stores or city warehouses in small trucks, so local truck traffic in the city would not change substantially. But the tunnel could dramatically cut truck traffic on bridges and overburdened routes like the Cross-Bronx Expressway.
Besides cutting costs for shipping goods to Brooklyn, the tunnel could help revive manufacturing in the city, and on Long Island. Problems with transportation helped drive many manufacturers out of the area in the last 20 years, said Representative Jerrold L. Nadler of Manhattan, who supports a tunnel.
Even if Mr. Giuliani succeeds in finding the money for the tunnel, it will likely take as long as a decade for environmental and engineering studies and then construction to be completed, according to projections by the city and the Tristate Transportation Campaign, a private group that studies transportation issues.
That means that other simple measures must be taken to avoid more choking pollution and continuing gridlock from trucks, said James T. B. Tripp, chairman of the transportation campaign and a lawyer at the Environmental Defense Fund.
"Congestion is going to continue to increase," he said. His group has urged the use of high tolls during rush hours and discounts at night to encourage truckers to move goods when the roads are clear. The city is planning to increase the use of rail barges to take train cars from New Jersey to the city, Mr. Millard said.

HEADLINE: When High Fliers Become Frequent Fliers;
Authorities Can Track Fugitive Financiers, but They Can't Bring Them In

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Giancarlo Parretti, the flamboyant former Hollywood mogul, could well be visiting his aging parents these days at the family olive farm just outside Orvieto, a medieval hilltop city some 70 miles north of Rome, his American lawyers say. They are not sure, though, since they communicate with him solely by fax.
Mr. Parretti, who mounted a $1.3 billion takeover of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. in 1990 only to lose control of the studio a year later amid allegations of financial mismanagement, is, after all, a man on the run. 
 The financier jumped bail and fled to his native Italy shortly before a Jan. 6 sentencing hearing in Delaware, his lawyers said early this month. At the hearing, he faced as much as 10 years in prison on perjury and evidence-tampering convictions growing out of the legal battle for control of the studio.
Exactly how and when the 55-year-old Mr. Parretti left the United States is a mystery. But by skipping the country, he has become the latest addition to the band of rogue financiers who have put off their date with American justice. And in joining the likes of Marc D. Rich and Robert Vesco, he has entered the shadowy -- and shifting -- world of the high-powered fugitive.
Because of technological advances in international police work -- chiefly the explosive growth in computer data bases and the lightning-fast transmission of photos -- those fugitives are finding that they can hide, but not run, at least not easily after the initial flight. Those who last the longest find a safe haven and hunker down, law enforcement officials say, avoiding high profiles and unnecessary movement.
The authorities say that no fugitive is ever really safe in an age when the next-door neighbor or the kid down the block can be the kind of vigilant citizen who regularly checks out the Justice Department's wanted list on the World Wide Web. Tracking down fugitives "is getting a little bit easier using these sophisticated programs," said James Carney, an inspector with the United States Marshals Service, the agency that brings them back.
But for all that, the wheels of justice can still turn awfully slowly. The United States has had little success in persuading even friendly nations to tighten laws that provide safe harbors for financial fugitives. And often there are serious questions about how hard anyone tries to find these international scofflaws.
In Mr. Parretti's case, for instance, an arrest warrant has been issued by Delaware authorities and a bail-forfeiture hearing has been set for Jan. 24, according to Paul R. Wallace, the state prosecutor handling the case. But no American officials have been dispatched to Orvieto or anywhere else abroad to find Mr. Parretti, Mr. Wallace said, explaining that such bilateral matters take time to work out.
Even if he is found, it may be some time before he returns to the United States, if ever. One measure of how hard it can be to win extradition is that in fleeing the United States, Mr. Parretti left behind another legal battle in Los Angeles, where he had been fighting an arrest warrant issued by the French Government for other MGM-related charges.
The United States has been trying to get its hands on some fugitives for years, even decades. For example, Mr. Rich, a suave international commodities trader, has lived openly in Zug, Switzerland, since 1982 after fleeing the United States to avoid prosecution in a tax case. Mr. Vesco left the country in 1972, when he fled Federal charges that he defrauded mutual fund investors of $224 million. He is now serving 13 years in a Cuban jail for other matters.
Ghaith R. Pharaon, the former front man for the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and its illegal purchases of financial institutions in the United States, was indicted on fraud and racketeering charges in 1991. He now flits between his native Saudi Arabia and Pakistan, former associates say.
The number of fugitive financiers is growing, said an official at the Office of International Affairs in the Department of Justice's criminal division, though the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, declined to provide specific figures. It is simply easier now than it was some years ago to get on a plane and disappear, at least at first, the official said, particularly since English has been increasingly adopted as the international language.
Meanwhile, the number of extraditions, relating to financial crimes and otherwise, has remained relatively flat. During the 12-month period ended Sept. 30, 160 people were extradited in all categories of crime, according to the Marshals Service. There were 191 extraditions for the period ending Sept. 30, 1995, and 177 for the year before that.
What hurts the "recovery" rate, Federal officials say, is that some countries, like Cuba, have no extradition treaty with the United States, while others, like Switzerland, make distinctions among forms of financial skulduggery that provide a safe haven to some.
"When you talk of financial crimes, you have to be careful," said Erwin Jenni, head of the extradition service at the Swiss Justice Department in Bern. In Switzerland, he explained, financial crimes involve fraud or embezzlement. Then there are so-called fiscal offenses, he said, which cover tax matters. "We don't extradite for fiscal and customs offenses," Mr. Jenni said, a policy that allows Mr. Rich, who has been indicted in the United States on charges of evading $48 million in income taxes, to live in Alpine comfort in Zug.
Another problem, said Mr. Carney of the Marshals Service, occurs when a fugitive successfully applies for citizenship in a foreign country. "Only some countries will extradite their own citizens," he explained.
To improve the Justice Department's record for capturing big-time fugitives, Attorney General Janet Reno last month started an interagency fugitive alert service, in conjunction with the United States Information Agency and the Voice of America. The effort includes a site on the World Wide Web (http:// www.usdoj.gov/criminal/oiafug/fugitives.htm) showing pictures of the most wanted fugitives.
In August, the Justice Department and the Voice of America began a radio broadcast, "International Crime Alert," that highlights a different fugitive each week. The program is heard in more than 50 countries.
While the new efforts have yet to bring in any well-known fugitive financiers, they did lead to the recent arrest in Guatemala of Leslie I. Rogge, a convicted bank robber who escaped from an Iowa prison, F.B.I. officials said. An American teen-ager living in Guatemala recognized Mr. Rogge from a picture on the F.B.I. web site, they said. Mr. Rogge had been working in the teen-ager's neighborhood as a handyman.
Most big-time fugitives have been a lot luckier than that. The anecdotal evidence suggests that those fugitives who have substantial reserves of money, like Mr. Rich, have a good chance of remaining at large. Mr. Rich even formed a new commodities trading firm in Zug. The firm, now run by others, has been a huge success -- and a galling symbol of frustration to American authorities.
A fistful of passports also seems to help. Most of the long-term financial fugitives on the Justice Department's list appear to hold at least two. Mr. Rich, for example, has American, Israeli and Spanish citizenship, sometimes visiting Spain and Israel on secret sojourns out of Switzerland. Mr. Pharaon, of the B.C.C.I. case, is believed to have both Saudi and Pakistani passports.
It is not that the American authorities give up trying to recapture those fleeing overseas. There have, for example, been occasional negotiations through intermediaries between Mr. Rich's lawyers and American law enforcement agencies to see if his return could be arranged. A variety of elaborate ruses to catch Mr. Rich outside Switzerland have also been considered and sometimes tried. In one such attempt, the American authorities staged a complicated commodities deal in an unsuccessful effort to lure Mr. Rich either to Kazakstan or Monte Carlo.
Some famous fugitives find it hard to stay out of trouble. Mr. Vesco is now languishing in jail following his conviction in Havana in August on charges of "fraud and illicit economic activity."
Others raise their public profile too high. David Friedland, a former New Jersey state senator who masterminded a plot to defraud $20 million from a local teamsters pension fund, found that out. After faking a fatal diving accident in 1985 in the Bahamas, Mr. Friedland moved to the Maldive Islands in the Indian Ocean. Using an alias, he bought and ran a number of scuba-diving schools there and even had his picture printed on a postcard. Such showmanship helped American authorities track him down in 1987. Mr. Friedland, who pleaded guilty to racketeering charges, was extradited and sentenced to 15 years in jail.
Eddie Antar, a fugitive from fraud charges for two years after the collapse of the Crazy Eddie electronics discount chain he co-founded, also has himself to blame for getting caught. The authorities got on his trail after he went to the police in Switzerland in 1992 and demanded help in gaining access to a $32 million bank account he kept under an alias.
Mr. Antar was arrested a short time later in Israel and extradited to the United States, where he faced charges that he defrauded shareholders of more than $74 million. After Federal convictions were overturned, Mr. Antar pleaded guilty last year to one racketeering count. Mr. Antar, who has already served four years in prison, is expected to receive three to five years more at a hearing next month.
The failure of Mr. Friedland and Mr. Antar to stay hidden highlights a key problem for a fleeing financier. Often, the flamboyance and egotism that helped bring riches in the first place cannot be repressed. The fugitive finds it hard to keep out of the public eye, let alone out of trouble.
Mr. Parretti, who began his career as a hotel waiter, has a history of high living and may find it tough to avoid the limelight now. When he took over MGM, he bought a Rolls-Royce, a jet and a $9 million mansion even as the studio bounced checks to stars like Dustin Hoffman and missed interest payments on bonds.
But for the moment, Mr. Parretti seems to be lying low. Manlio Morcella, his lawyer in Orvieto, did not reply to questions sent to his office, though he has given short interviews in Italy to say that Mr. Parretti had returned to face separate charges there relating to criminal bankruptcy and tax fraud.
Getting in trouble in a number of jurisdictions generally bodes ill for a fugitive, making it that much harder to remain at large.
In addition to his Delaware convictions and the charges in Italy, Mr. Parretti is accused of fraud in France relating to the hundreds of millions of dollars he borrowed from Credit Lyonnais, the large Government-owned bank, to finance the acquisition of MGM. Credit Lyonnais took over the studio after accusing Mr. Parretti of defaulting on the loans and of gross mismanagement. It recently sold the studio to a group that includes Kirk Kerkorian, the investor who originally sold MGM to Mr. Parretti.
With all the legal swords hanging over his head, Mr. Parretti may find a much-needed sense of sanctuary in Orvieto. The city is famed for its soft white wine. It is also known for a fresco-filled marble cathedral, where many come to pray.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A company founded by Marc Rich and now managed by close associates advertised in The Econnomist last month.
 
Map/Photos: "Easier To Find, Still Hard To Catch"
 Better communications networks are making it easier for law enforcement agencies in the United States to find people who have been charged with financial crimes and then flee to escape punishment. But even friendly nations sometimes resist American efforts to extradite financial criminals, and thsoe fugitives with the most resources seem able to stay a step ahead of the law.

HEADLINE: Pacific Telesis and 2 Other Bells In Dispute Over a TV Venture

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
In another digital-age relationship gone sour, the Pacific Telesis Group is clashing with its corporate partners over the future of Tele-TV, their ambitious but troubled phone company venture into television.
Executives familiar with Tele-TV said the other two partners, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation, want to shut down the company and fold its operations into Bell Atlantic. But Pacific Telesis, which plans to introduce wireless cable television service in Los Angeles this spring, is insisting that the partners continue to finance Tele-TV, at least through its introduction. 
 Pacific Telesis needs Tele-TV to supply the digital set-top converter boxes and billing systems for its cable service, according to people familiar with the company. Bell Atlantic and Nynex have shelved their own plans for wireless cable service on the East Coast. And people familiar with the companies said they do not want to pay for another company's wireless cable service on the West Coast.
"Pacific Telesis is spending hundreds of millions of dollars to build a television business in California," one executive at Tele-TV, who declined to be identified, said. "They don't want to see Tele-TV blow up just before they launch the service."
The fractures in the Tele-TV partnership illustrate what can happen when major companies unite behind a high-tech vision -- only to diverge later when the technology or the economics shifts. Tele-TV's partners pledged to spend $100 million to create a digital television company. But after spiraling costs and doubts about the technology, only Pacific Telesis is committed to entering television anytime soon.
Raymond W. Smith, the chairman and chief executive of Bell Atlantic, acknowledged that Pacific Telesis disagreed with his company and Nynex over how quickly to scale back the Tele-TV partnership.
Mr. Smith said the companies were negotiating about how to restructure the partnership in the wake of mammoth deals involving all three of the partners. Pacific Telesis is being acquired by SBC Communications Inc., while Bell Atlantic and Nynex are close to completing their $22 billion merger.
"We're working out how much we should pay for things and how much they should pay for things," Mr. Smith said in an interview yesterday. "There's no animosity whatsoever between the companies."
Mr. Smith said Bell Atlantic and Nynex expected to complete the Tele-TV talks within a month -- which is also when the two companies are expected to clear the last big regulatory hurdles to their merger.
Susan Petoletti, a spokeswoman for Pacific Telesis, declined to comment on the talks. A spokesman for SBC Communications, Larry Solomon, said any decisions involving Tele-TV would continue to be made by Pacific Telesis until SBC's acquisition closes, probably in March.
At the heart of the dispute is whether Bell Atlantic and Nynex should pay two-thirds of the cost of offering wireless cable service in Los Angeles. Under the terms of Tele-TV's partnership deal, the three Bell companies agreed to help finance the introduction of television service in each of their regions.
But Mr. Smith said the mergers involving the three partners invalidated the contract. For one, Pacific Telesis' new owner, SBC Communications, is a partner with three other phone companies and the Walt Disney Company in a rival programming venture, Americast. So even if Tele-TV continued on its present course, SBC would have to determine whether to back Tele-TV or shift Pacific Telesis into Americast.
People familiar with Pacific Telesis said the company was trying to hold Bell Atlantic and Nynex to the contract on two grounds: that the mergers have not closed, and that Pacific Telesis paid its share for television market tests in Bell Atlantic's region. Some people familiar with the companies predicted Bell Atlantic and Nynex might offer to pay a lump sum to Pacific Telesis in return for the ending of the venture.
Complicating matters further, Pacific Telesis has invested more heavily in wireless cable than its East Coast counterparts. It acquired licenses to offer wireless cable in much of the Los Angeles area through a $175 million acquisition of Cross Country Wireless in 1995.
One executive close to Pacific Telesis estimated that the company's total investment in wireless cable was $300 million. Moreover, on two other occasions, the company has retreated from television ventures, including plans for wireless cable in San Francisco.
Bell Atlantic and Nynex acquired licenses on the East Coast by agreeing to invest as much as $100 million in CAI Wireless Systems in 1995. But the companies became disenchanted with the technology when it became apparent that hills and buildings can block wireless cable signals. The companies and CAI recently agreed to suspend their deal.
While Mr. Smith said Bell Atlantic and Nynex might still draw on Tele-TV's programming and technical expertise for some market trials of video services in Philadelphia, he acknowledged that Bell Atlantic would not have a significant number of customers before next year.
Pacific Telesis, by contrast, hopes to have several hundred thousand subscribers within a couple of years, according to people familiar with the company. The company has relied on Tele-TV to design a visual style for the service and to line up more than 50 cable channels. It has also ordered 200,000 digital set-top converter boxes designed by Tele-TV.
Diverging strategies have undone other technology partnerships, including the $2 billion investment by the MCI Communications Corporation in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and U S West Inc.'s $2.5 billion stake in Time Warner Inc. These companies are also busy trying to unravel their alliances.
After Bell Atlantic and Nynex signaled their retreat in December, Pacific Telesis was nervous that Tele-TV's top programming and technical experts would flee before Pacific Telesis introduced its service in Los Angeles, people familiar with the company said.
Already, Sanford Grushow, the president of Tele-TV's programming arm in Los Angeles, has resigned to become the president of 20th Century Fox's television unit. Howard Stringer, the chairman of Tele-TV and the former president of the CBS Broadcast Group, is also negotiating to sever his contract, people familiar with the situation said. Neither Mr. Grushow nor Mr. Stringer would comment on the dispute.

HEADLINE: The Governor's Divisive Cuts

 BODY:
The $66 billion budget proposed by Gov. George Pataki on Tuesday is tailored for his familiar theme that New York State is "roaring" back toward fiscal health. But his proposed cuts in higher education and health programs for the disabled, elderly and poor are certain to yank the Legislature right back into the bitter wrangling that has paralyzed the budget process for two years in a row. Despite the Governor's claim, the budget also relies too heavily on the kinds of gimmicks that have given New York the worst credit rating of any state in the country.
Mr. Pataki has proposed some welcome new spending initiatives, particularly increases for children's services and welfare recipients. There were a few more details in the budget about how the state plans to mobilize job training, counseling and day care to help get families off welfare, and to provide vouchers for food and shelter for those thrown off the rolls because of the new Federal welfare law. The Legislature will have no higher priority than guaranteeing that the state use its resources to protect those hurt by the new law. 
Because the state economy is doing better and providing more tax revenue, Mr. Pataki's budget achieves balance without the harsh cuts he has urged in years past. Even so, nursing homes, hospitals, community health centers and home care for the elderly are being hit by significant cuts to help pay for the Governor's proposed property tax relief and other programs. Such huge reductions will inevitably impair health services for the neediest recipients. There are also ambitious schemes to introduce managed care and competition into the delivery of health services for the mentally ill, disabled and elderly that remain untested.
Also unwise are Mr. Pataki's proposed cuts for both the City University and State University systems. These would be offset by increasing tuition by $400 for students at both systems, making them less affordable for the poor and working class.
Mr. Pataki has brought some badly needed restraint to state spending. Like New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, he argues that his policies have led to declines in crime and the welfare rolls and higher tax revenues resulting from an improved economy. But the Governor undercuts his own record by repeatedly relying on dubious bookkeeping to balance the budget. His own numbers show that if the latest fiscal plan were subjected to generally accepted accounting standards -- which bar gimmicks like deferring the paying of bills or assuming revenues that are not really available -- it would be $768 million out of balance, and would increase the accumulated state deficit to nearly $2.8 billion.
In the coming year, moreover, Mr. Pataki wants to roll over a $1 billion revenue surplus from the current year and use it to pay for ongoing expenses -- a dangerous practice because the money may not recur even though the expenses will. In addition, his proposal for $3.4 billion in increased school aid and property tax relief is funded only in part for the next year. There are no details on how it is to be funded later, only projections of growing deficits in the years ahead.
With Mr. Pataki's re-election campaign less than two years away, the budget fighting is likely to be more fierce than ever this year. The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, who leads the Democratic opposition, only made tensions worse by leaving the room before the Governor began his budget speech. Whatever his motives, Mr. Silver's snub was a provocative and juvenile gesture incompatible with the Speaker's responsibility to work constructively on legislative issues.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Apple Reports a Loss Of $120 Million in Quarter
Apple Computer posted a loss of $120 million for its first quarter and said that it did not expect to return to profitability as quickly as it had predicted.
But Sun Microsystems, which a year ago entertained the prospect of acquiring Apple, reported record revenue and earnings for its second quarter. [Page D9.]
 
Mexico Pays Back Rest of U.S. Loan
Mexico has repaid -- three years ahead of schedule -- all of the $12.5 billion it borrowed from Washington to stave off a financial collapse two years ago, ending one of President Clinton's riskiest overseas ventures and releasing Mexico from tight economic controls imposed by Washington. [A1.]
 
Rudder Changes Set for 737's
The F.A.A. said it planned to require changes in the rudder controls of all 1,100 Boeing 737 aircraft in the United States, to preclude a sudden rudder movement that is suspected of having played a role in two crashes in the last six years. [A1.]
 
The airlines' robust financial recovery continued as AMR, parent of American Airlines, reported fourth-quarter net income of $284 million after a loss a year earlier. [D4.]
 
Uncertainty in Conrail Struggle
In most proxy fights, by the time of the shareholder meeting it is clear who will win. But tomorrow's meeting on the Conrail takeover struggle, at which shareholders will vote whether to accept less from the CSX Corporation or to hold on and hope that the Norfolk Southern will be able to pay more, is an exception. Neither side seems very confident. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D12.]
 
Stocks Lower in Heavy Trading
The stock market fell for only the third time this year as investors unloaded technology stocks in heavy trading. The Dow industrials lost 35.41 points to close at 6,726.88. [D12.]
 
Treasury prices fell as investors grew concerned about an abundance of new debt coming to market. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.79 percent from 6.77. [D19.]
 
Dissident Tandy Director Quits
Tandy's longest-sitting board member resigned, disappointing many shareholders who had looked to him as a voice of dissent on a board that has backed the company's embattled chief executive. [D4.]
 
Earnings Rise at Big Banks
BankAmerica and First Chicago NBD posted higher profits for the fourth quarter despite problems with credit card loans. And H. F. Ahmanson, the parent of the nation's largest savings and loan association, reported 50 percent higher profits. [D8.]
 
Inventories Up Only Marginally
Business inventories rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in November as companies prepared warily for Christmas sales. Analysts said the lean inventories and low stock-to-sales ratios near the end of 1996 might clear the way for stronger production in the first quarter. [D2.]
 
Jackson Ends Mitsubishi Boycott
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, the civil rights leader, called for an end to the boycott of Mitsubishi cars and trucks because the company agreed to improve job opportunities for women and minorities at its factory in Normal, Ill., and at its contractors and auto dealerships. [D4.]
 
Mr. Jackson plans to open a Wall Street office to pressure companies to hire and promote more members of minorities. [D4.]
 
Historian Sought Paper Destruction
A historian working for Union Bank of Switzerland ordered the destruction of hundreds of pounds of archives compiled by a subsidiary that had extensive dealings with Nazi Germany, investigators said. [A3.]
 
Movies for Time Warner Channels
Time Warner said that its movie companies would license the rights to 12 feature films to two of its cable services, continuing a trend in which media companies are increasing the value of their distribution businesses by putting their own programming on TV networks or cable services they own. [D10.]

HEADLINE: Foes of Affirmative Action Form a National Group

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 15

 BODY:
The opponents of affirmative action who persuaded California voters to pass Proposition 209 last November announced today that they had formed the American Civil Rights Institute to argue "aggressively" that the rest of the states, as well as Congress, should abolish all race and sex preferences in hiring, contracting and college admissions.
The founders of the institute, which is to be financed by individuals and foundations, said the new national organization would have a "strong presence" in Washington and in every state where opponents of preferences ask for help. 
 But they were careful not to predict quick victories, given recent reports of race and sex discrimination in some major American corporations and also given that supporters of affirmative action, particularly women's groups, have vowed to fight back on the hustings and in the courts.
Still, Ward Connerly, the black Sacramento businessman who led the Proposition 209 fight and now leads the new institute, reported today that groups in a dozen or so states, among them Colorado, Florida, Oregon and Washington, had indicated they might like help in putting anti-affirmative action propositions on the ballot or pressuring legislatures to pass anti-affirmative-action laws.
Proposition 209 has been put on hold by a Federal judge, pending a review of its constitutionality, but Mr. Connerly said that had not deterred opponents of affirmative action in other states.
As for the outlook for Congressional action, Mr. Connerly opined that it was better now than in 1996, an election year in which many Capitol Hill legislators chose not to grapple seriously with the touchy issue.
Polls indicate that a large number of Americans oppose affirmative action programs. But many others, among them President Clinton, take a mend-it-don't-end-it approach, arguing that although there are shortcomings and excesses, such as quotas, the concept is worth saving.
"There is no public policy which has greater potential to rip the fabric of American democracy than affirmative action, as it has evolved," Mr. Connerly said in a statement. "Every citizen should have an equal chance at the starting line of life's race. But there should not be a guaranteed outcome in the race. If you discriminate for someone, you discriminate against someone else."
Among the institute's leading founders and advisers are Thomas L. Rhodes, the president of the National Review, the conservative magazine; Clint Bolick, director of litigation for the Institute for Justice, and Grover Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform, both organizations that push conservative causes; and State Senator Quentin Kopp of San Francisco, an independent who is one of Sacramento's most outspoken legislative mavericks.
Mr. Connerly predicted that his announcement today would draw sharp criticism, saying that "some people in this country think they have a lock on what is right and that all the rest of us are morally wrong." And, in fact, the criticism was not long in coming.
First to attack was State Assemblyman Kevin Murray of Los Angeles, the chairman of the California Legislative Black Caucus, who called Mr. Connerly "despicable" and "indecent." Then, noting that the announcement of the institute's founding had been purposely scheduled, by Mr. Connerly's admission, for the Jan. 15 birthdate of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Murray asserted:
"To announce on Dr. King's birthday that he is setting out to destroy the civil rights advances Dr. King fought and died for is callous and utterly disrespectful of Dr. King's memory and accomplishments."
In Washington, Wade Henderson, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a major civil rights group, said that the new institute should not hold out much hope for success beyond California, especially on Capitol Hill.
"That group won't get very high priority here," he said, "particularly after the discrimination that has recently been turned up at places like Texaco and the like."
Elizabeth Toledo, the president of the California branch of the National Organization for Women and a former member of that group's national board, offered a similar judgment.
"It won't work," she said. "Women are determined to push back."
Mr. Connerly said he chose King's birthdate for the announcement because the practice of extending preferences on the basis of race and sex constituted reverse discrimination and was a direct affront to King's dream of a color-blind America.
Then he speculated on whether King would support preferences, were he alive today.
"He very well might," Mr. Connerly concluded. "But if he did and were sitting here in front of me, I'd go right up to him and ask him why and how he could justify that support given his earlier statements about a color-blind America. We'd have a dialogue. I don't shy away."
Mr. Connerly said the institute would seek money from individuals and foundations but expects few contributions from businesses and other organizations.
"They say they oppose preferences, but they turn to jelly when they come face-to-face with having to choose up sides on such a hot topic," he said. "But we expect to have enough money to go national in any case."
Mr. Connerly conceded in his announcement and in a news conference and interviews afterward that race and sex discrimination was still very much a problem in the United States. But he argued that preferences were not the right solution.
Rather, he said, the nation should enforce existing anti-discrimination laws and adopt programs and policies that reach out to people, all people, who are economically and socially disadvantaged.
"Yes, we at the institute are against solving the nation's discrimination problems with race and sex preferences," he said. "But at the same time we are nevertheless solution-oriented and favor steps that would reach out to every individual in need of help, not just a particular class or classes. Our Constitution protects every individual, not every group. It's a difficult position that we take, but it's the right position."

HEADLINE: Swiss Bank Cannot Identify Papers in Cache It Shredded

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: ZURICH, Jan. 15

 BODY:
A historian working for the Union Bank of Switzerland ordered the destruction of hundreds of pounds of archives compiled by a subsidiary that had extensive dealings with Nazi Germany, investigators said today.
The investigators said the material, which was shredded last week, filled three large packing crates, each roughly three feet square and two feet deep, and two plastic garbage bags four to five feet high. The papers destroyed may have accounted for as much as two-thirds of the cache, the investigators added. 
 The historian kept no inventory of what was destroyed, which will make it difficult to determine whether the bank broke a month-old Swiss law that prohibits companies from destroying material that may shed light on Switzerland's role as banker to Hitler's Germany.
"Our main problem is knowing exactly what was destroyed," said Peter Cosandey, Zurich's District Attorney, who is leading the investigation. "There were files in there that dated back to the 1870's, and they are obviously not relevant. But there are also documents from the 1930's and 1940's, and the time frame is such that they could at least theoretically have been useful."
The new details surrounding the destruction of documents came as the Swiss Government sought to mend its strained ties with Jewish groups worldwide.
Jean-Pascale Delamuraz, the Minister of Economics, apologized today for his comment last month that Jewish groups had engaged in "blackmail" when they demanded that the Swiss set up a fund for Holocaust survivors. Mr. Delamuraz, who was President last month under Switzerland's rotating cabinet system, said in a letter to the World Jewish Congress that he was "very sorry" and that he had been misinformed about what Jewish organizations were requesting.
The Union Bank of Switzerland flatly denied today that any "interesting" documents had been destroyed, saying the historian was "100 percent confident that none of the materials are related to the Holocaust." The company also said that the bank's management had known nothing about the shredding and that the action had nothing to do with the broader controversy over Nazi money.
But bank executives were at a loss to explain how the historian, who has not been publicly identified, could have taken the action, particularly given the new law. "The historian made his judgment that these documents had nothing to do with the present discussion about the Holocaust -- nothing, and that is the point," Gertrude Erismann-Peyer, the bank's senior spokeswoman, said in an interview today.
Jewish groups here and in the United States asked a series of questions today:
Why had the bank begun destroying potentially relevant documents precisely when Swiss banks are under intense pressure worldwide to provide information about their dealings during the Nazi era?
Why had the bank chosen this moment to uncover a cache of documents that had laid untouched in a vault ever since 1945?
How could the historian have possibly been unaware of the implications of destroying documents?
"The material now under investigation might be of historical interest or it might not, but that is not the point," said Werner Rom, head of the Israeli Cultural Center of Zurich. "The issue is that we have a law that became effective Dec. 13 that prohibits shredding of material that might be relevant. From a moral point of view it is absolutely not understandable that something like this has happened."
Switzerland's banking industry has been under siege for months now from Jewish groups and from the United States, where Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, has held hearings that publicized embarrassing information from American Government archives about Swiss dealings during World War II with Jews and with the Nazi Government.
Two commissions have been trying to answer questions surrounding money, gold and other items that belonged to Holocaust victims and may have been put in Swiss banks either by the victims themselves or by Germans during the Third Reich.
One commission, headed by Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is trying to find dormant bank accounts that belong to Holocaust victims. The other commission has been set up by the Swiss Government to analyze relations between Swiss banks, the Government and Hitler's Germany.
The law adopted on Dec. 13 is intended to protect documents that might be relevant to those inquiries.
The shredding at the Union Bank of Switzerland might never have come to light had not a night watchman named Cristoph Meili become curious about documents he saw being destroyed while he was making his rounds.
The guard took a number of documents from the bank last week and turned them over to the Israeli Cultural Center of Zurich, which is usually occupied with providing day care for Jewish children.
Today Mr. Meili, 20 years old and the father of two, is himself the target of a criminal investigation into whether he violated bank secrecy laws. He has been suspended from his job with the security company that served Union Bank.
Marcel Bosonnet, Mr. Meili's attorney, said the night watchman had been grilled for hours by Zurich authorities last weekend, and was repeatedly asked if he had demanded money or accepted money in exchange for documents he had taken.
Mr. Meili adamantly denied that money had been a motive. Rather, he said at a news conference on Monday with the Israeli Cultural Center, he became convinced that the documents might be of great historic importance and were being improperly destroyed.
"When God put these documents into my hands, I had to act on them," he said repeatedly on Monday.
Mr. Cosandey, the Zurich Dsitrict Attorney, said he had not yet decided whether Mr. Meili had violated bank secrecy laws because he did not work directly for the bank.
Mr. Bosonnet argued that his client had not violated secrecy laws, "but even if he were found to have violated bank secrecy laws, my answer would be that there was an overriding right that supersedes the law because there was such an important interest at stake." 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 18, 1997, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about a Swiss bank's shredding of Nazi-era records misstated the age of the guard who disclosed the development. He is 28, not 20.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens Versus Yen As Japanese Raise Red Flags

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday but fell against the yen after Japanese leaders expressed fears about the yen's weakness and rumors swept the market that Japan's central bank was selling dollars.
Market disappointment over Britain's decision not to raise interest rates also helped the dollar, as traders who had bought pounds sold them for dollars. 
 But many traders were more focused on the possibility of intervention by the Bank of Japan. Some said they had heard that the central bank was inquiring about exchange rates.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was at 116.44 yen, down from 116.88 yen on Wednesday, and 1.5943 German marks, up from 1.5877. The pound cost $1.6798, down from $1.6827.
Japanese monetary officials have been intermittently warning about the dangers of a weakening yen since the dollar began hitting a series of 45-month highs against the Japanese currency two weeks ago, climbing past 116 yen and 117 yen before retreating a bit on Wednesday.
"I can't imagine they're really happy with it above 115 yen," Jan Alvarez, head of foreign exchange trading at Corestates Bank in Philadelphia, said. "They're trying to soft-pedal it down to where they think it should belong."
The weaker yen has contributed to an outflow of capital from Japan and played a role in a sharp retreat in the Japanese stock market in recent weeks. Against other currencies, the dollar resumed its climb after a one-day pullback on Wednesday, largely on further evidence that the United States economy is having solid growth and low inflation.
The dollar also derived strength from weakness in the mark on talk that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, may reduce interest rates at its policy-making council meeting next Thursday.
The pound's retreat came after the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, said he had decided to leave interest rates unchanged after his regular meeting on Wednesday with Edward George, the governor of the Bank of England. Mr. Clarke said the pound's recent strength had a large role in his decision.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates on Wednesday, included: 1.3796 Swiss francs, up from 1.3715; 5.3790 French francs, up from 5.3585, and 1,550.00 Italian lire, up from 1,545.50.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Ford Plans Cutbacks at British Assembly Plant

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
In the first big step toward turning its unprofitable European operations around, the Ford Motor Company announced today that it would reduce employment by a third, or 1,300 workers, at its Halewood assembly plant near Liverpool, which makes its European Escort models.
Ford said it would produce fewer Escorts at the plant in northwest England through 1999, and then held out the possibility that it might begin building a new multipurpose vehicle there in 2000. But it warned that any future production would depend on its success in controlling costs. 
 The company's move is meant to stem losses in European operations caused by excess production capacity and weak sales. Some of the plant's output, now 800 Escorts daily, will be shifted to factories in Germany and Spain. Ford said it would offer early retirement and other compensation packages to workers and would try to make as many of the job cuts as possible through attrition.
The decision, which had been widely rumored since Ford reported a $472 million third-quarter loss in Europe, angered workers. The auto maker had presented the Halewood plant a global quality award last year and the plant had been cited as an example of modern British industrial efficiency. Analysts said the weakening sales of the Escort, a midsized model by European standards, rather than work practices at the plant were to blame for Ford's disappointing results in Europe.
The analysts said similar models, like the Volkswagen Golf and Opel Astra, were selling better. "People just didn't like the Escort," Charles Young, director of automotive research at the consulting firm J. D. Power-LMC Automotive Forecasting, said. "It was not as exciting as the competition, and Ford kept on having to revamp it."
"The actions we have announced today at Halewood assembly operations give the plant a realistic future, with an exciting new vehicle in the medium term, subject to approval and performance objectives being achieved," David Gorman, Ford's European vehicle operations manager, said.
Last week, Alex Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, said the European operations have "a cost problem which we are addressing very aggressively." In an interview, he added that Ford had "too much fixed cost in terms of capacity utilization. In short," he said, "we have more capacity than we need."
The United States company, which operates 12 plants in Britain, said the Halewood plant, which now employs 4,500, would operate on a single shift beginning in April "for the foreseeable future."
Speaking in Parliament this morning, Prime Minister John Major described the development as a "very surprising decision," coming at a time when British job rolls continue to grow and unemployment is the lowest among European Union countries.
Mr. Major, whose Conservative Government prides itself on facilitating foreign investments in Britain, said the move "flies in the face of most investment decisions which are moving to the U.K."
Labor union leaders at Ford asserted they "totally reject" the move, which they attributed to lax labor compensation laws in Britain that make it less costly to dismiss workers there than in other European countries. Britain has opted out of the so-called Social Chapter of the European Union, which offers strong protection to workers.
"A good plant with good people has been let down," Tony Woodley, the Transport and General Workers Union's national secretary for the motor industry in Britain, said, adding that the union was "very, very angry" and that a protest strike would be considered as a response.
The union officials said they would seek urgent talks with management to try to persuade it to reverse the decision.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Good Year for Manhattan Or Perhaps Not So Good

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Two of New York City's largest real estate companies, the Corcoran Group and the Halstead Property Company, have issued year-end reports, which -- surprisingly -- come to differing conclusions on the overall health of the residential market.
"High End of Manhattan Residential Real Estate Market Again Breaks All Price Records" trumpets the Halstead report. "One East Side, One West Side Neighborhood Top 20 Percent Gains for the Year; Only East End/Gracie See Prices Fall," another headline reads. 
 The report concluded that prices for the broad market in Manhattan below 96th Street for 1996 "rose a respectable 8.1 percent on average."
A competing annual survey, the Corcoran Report, however, reported that compared with 1995, average prices in Manhattan were down.
While the report maintained a cheery tone -- "One-bedroom sales take off for the first time in five years; Town house sales hit an all-time high; Expensive co-ops are in demand and hard to find" -- its first chart showed an average apartment price for 1996 of $398,000, compared with $416,000 for 1995, a 4.3 percent decrease. Corcoran's statistics are based on 20,051 deals -- its own and those gathered by a Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson, an appraisal firm.
The two companies are large brokerage concerns that handle a broad range of properties in Manhattan, from moderately priced small apartments in Greenwich Village to multimillion-dollar Park Avenue palazzos.
At Douglas Elliman, a company that reported Manhattan sales last year of over $1 billion and will issue its report next month, Alan Rogers, chief executive, said he was not surprised the two reports differed.
"Most of these reports that are produced, frankly, reflect poorly on the industry," he said. "They're just marketing pieces for the individual agencies. They're not a detailed review and analysis of the activity, which ours is." Mr. Rogers said his preliminary figures for 1996 showed prices rising "but not dramatically; more than inflation, but much of that is catch-up with the 20 to 30 percent drop of the beginning of the decade."
Yesterday, Clark P. Halstead, who heads Halstead, said his figures were "a legitimate statistical attempt," based on more than 2,000 of his company's sales, taken together with the projected sales prices of an additional 7,000 apartments currently for sale. He said he could not explain the difference between his and his competitors' market assessments.
Barbara Corcoran, head of the Corcoran Group, responding to Mr. Rogers's comments, said that her firm's report was not seen as a marketing tool, but as "an analytical tool for the real estate community."
At Brown, Harris, Stevens, which will issue its report in February, Lawrence Sicular, the chief statistician, said he had surveyed an area similar to the one the Halstead Report called "the Silk Stocking District," which both define roughly as Fifth and Park Avenues, Central Park West and Riverside Drive.
While Halstead's figures for average apartment sales showed a 13 percent rise over those of 1995 for apartments in the Silk Stocking area, Mr. Sicular's latest statistics, which cut off at the end of September 1996, found a negligible rise in the average apartment price: from $884,032 to $895,000. Since Brown Harris does not gather statistics from the broad-based market, the company did not offer an overall Manhattan average.
The Real Estate Board of New York, another organization that issues a quarterly report, is preparing its year-end analysis. Warren Wechsler, a vice president, said a quick look at the new figures indicated that 1996 prices were "pretty much the same as last year."
In his latest analysis of last year's data, Mr. Sicular found that while average prices over all had not changed much over the last year, the prices of smaller apartments -- and some larger apartments -- had risen significantly. (Nevertheless, Mr. Sicular found that prices of apartments with seven to eight rooms had decreased: from $1.4 million in 1995 to $1.1 million in 1996.)
For the Brown Harris report -- culled from sales by Brown Harris sales agents, sales of properties managed by Brown Harris and sales from other management companies -- Mr. Sicular found that the average one-bedroom sale for nine months of 1996 averaged $243,039, compared with $215,435 in 1995.
Mr. Sicular joined the rest of the real estate professionals in reporting that volume was up significantly. Joyce West, executive vice president of Charles H. Greenthal Residential, reported a 20 percent rise in volume from last year.
"Yet despite all the activity, the inflation-adjusted prices are still down," Mr. Sicular said. "They were down 1 percent in 1996 and 5 percent in 1995. The increases in the stock market are infinitely stronger than in the real estate market."
Mr. Halstead disagreed. "The residential market, both for sales and rentals, is astonishingly hot," he wrote. "I don't remember a year in which the price changes were so uniformly up. Averages can mask fluctuations, but this year the market has been very consistent. I believe it will stay in step with the stock market."

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXXI;
In Green Bay, No Turmoil at the Top

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH 

DATELINE: GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 15

 BODY:
Dan Reeves left the Giants after he and General Manager George Young split over who would have authority on personnel matters. Bobby Ross fled from San Diego to Detroit because he and Chargers General Manager Bobby Beathard couldn't see eye to eye.
Perhaps no other relationship in professional football creates more sparks than that of the head coach and the general manager. Big egos, strong opinions and obstinate personalties exist on both sides. Friction is the constant result, even with successful teams like the Super Bowl-bound New England Patriots. 
 Patriots Coach Bill Parcells had been given complete authority over the team's football operation, but the New England owner, Robert Kraft, took away some of that power this past off season, giving more control to Bobby Grier, the director of player personnel. As a result, Parcells may be doing his coaching somewhere else next season.
The team the Patriots will be facing in New Orleans has what is widely seen as an ideal relationship between general manager and coach. Unlike the Patriots, no one is writing stories about problems between Packers General Manager Ron Wolf and Coach Mike Holmgren.
"Both Ron and I work hard on our relationship," Holmgren said. "I think we both have big egos, but he made it very clear early on that he didn't want to coach the football team and I appreciated that. He also said he'd never give me a player I didn't want and I appreciated that.
"He does everything for me that I could possibly ask for and he's good at what he does. That's not to say we don't disagree on things, but we manage to communicate with one another and we respect each other. That's absolutely necessary to make the whole thing work in the National Football League."
Wolf, in turn, said that Holmgren "probably wins more than he should" when they disagree on personnel matters. But he said his first responsibility is to find players who will fit into Holmgren's system and make the team successful. And together they have taken a chance on players other teams have given up on, like Desmond Howard and Andre Rison, and made them valuable members of the team.
One player that they both agreed on was quarterback Brett Favre, the back-to-back N.F.L. most valuable player who has become the linchpin of the team's success.
Wolf, who is a protege of the Raiders' owner, Al Davis, was working as the Jets' director of player personnel in 1990 when he identified Favre as the best player in the draft that year.
The Jets did not have a first-round pick that year, having lost it by taking receiver Rob Moore in the supplemental draft the year before. By the time the Jets got to select in the second round, Favre had been chosen by Atlanta. But the second thing that Wolf did when he arrived in Green Bay in November 1991 -- the first thing he did was to hire Holmgren -- was to work out a trade with the Falcons for Favre.
Even though Holmgren and Favre got off to a rocky start, the coach did not blow up at Wolf for getting him a quarterback with a wild streak. Holmgren patiently worked with Favre to curtail his gunslinger tendencies on the field and now the Packers have one of the best quarterbacks in the N.F.L.
Under the 58-year-old Wolf, the Packers have selectively used free agency. They made a big splash by signing Reggie White to a $19 million contract in 1993, but they haven't done anything like that since then. Wolf is working to get Favre signed to a new contract. That's the Packers' next major deal.
"We decided to use free agency to shore us up and give us some identification," Wolf said. "But after that first year we saw the way it was going and we said, 'Oh no.' We knew that we had to keep our own players, our own good players. That's been our approach the last three years and that will be our approach this year."
That approach seems to be fine with Holmgren. And Wolf knows why he and Holmgren get along together.
"I think it's because Mike Holmgren is interested in one thing and one thing only, and that's winning football games," Wolf said. "I think he has an ego like most of the people in this game, but he realizes what he's very special at. He's very special at teaching players how to play and communicating with players."
Wolf added: "Coaches play a much more important role in the game than they ever have before. And it's from this standpoint -- they now have to take players and train them to play at a level they've never had to play before. They have to bring in new players and they have to play right away. Before, you never had that. You could season them for four or five years, play four preseason games and showcase some guys, and get some guys to play. You can't do that anymore, because those guys are gone. Somebody else is going to take them if they're any good. So, it's tremendous pressure on coaches, and they're the guys who have to function."
Wolf also admires Parcells and he considers the Patriots' coach a very good friend. In fact, he wanted to hire Parcells for the Packers' job.
"It never really got close, because he stopped it -- he had surgery," Wolf said, referring to one of two angioplasty procedures Parcells underwent to clear blocked arteries.
Wolf said he was not sure how he and Parcells got to be such good friends, but when he talks about him it's easy to tell he's quite fond of the coach standing between Green Bay and a Super Bowl title.
"We both respected and liked the game of pro football," said Wolf, who grew up in New Freedom, Pa., as a Baltimore Colts fan. "That's what we spent a large amount of our time talking about -- the game, the integrity of the game, players who play the game."
Wolf doesn't know if their relationship would have remained as close if he had hired Parcells and become his boss. Their philosophies on players are very different, Wolf said.
"He's a little more smashmouth than I am," he said. "Also a difference, and he'll probably object, but he's always looking for the sleeper. Always. I'm not. I'm looking for football players. Let somebody else be the genius. Through our friendship I've discovered how people in his position react to certain things. It's helped me. No question."
A couple of months ago there was speculation that Wolf would leave Green Bay and return to the Jets to be their general manager. He doesn't want to discuss it.
However, in talking about how ideal his working situation is in Green Bay, Wolf seemed to leave the window slightly open.
"This is the best situation a person can have in my capacity," Wolf said. "I don't know why a person would want to go anywhere else, other than economics."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ron Wolf, the general manager, has taken the Packers to the Super Bowl working in harmony with his coach. (Associated Press)
