HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD;
Looking Ahead: Two U.S. Documents

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Following are the texts of American documents related to the Israel-Palestinian agreement on the redeployment of Israeli troops in Hebron. The Note for the Record is an official addendum. The Letter to Netanyahu, Secretary of State Warren Christopher's letter to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, is not officially part of the deal. Mr. Christopher also wrote to Yasir Arafat, the president of the Palestinian Authority, but that letter has not been made public.
 
Note for the Record
The two leaders met on Jan. 15, 1997, in the presence of the U.S. Special Middle East Coordinator. They requested him to prepare this Note for the Record to summarize what they agreed upon in their meeting. 

Mutual Understandings
The two leaders agreed that the Oslo peace process must move forward and succeed. Both parties to the Interim Agreement have concerns and obligations. Accordingly, the two leaders reaffirmed their commitment to implement the Interim Agreement on the basis of reciprocity and, in this context, conveyed the following undertakings to each other:

Israeli Responsibilities
The Israeli side reaffirms its commitments to the following measures and principles in accordance with the Interim Agreement:

Issues for Implementation
1. FURTHER REDEPLOYMENT PHASES The first phase of redeployment will be carried out during the first week of March.
2. PRISONER RELEASE ISSUES Prisoner release issues will be dealt with in accordance with the Interim Agreement's provisions and procedures, including Annex VII.
3. OUTSTANDING INTERIM AGREEMENT ISSUES Negotiations on the following outstanding issues from the Interim Agreement will be immediately resumed. Negotiations on these issues will be conducted in parallel:
a. Safe Passage
b. Gaza Airport
c. Gaza Port
d. Passages
e. Economic, financial, civilian and security issues
f. People-to-people
4. PERMANENT STATUS NEGOTIATIONS Permanent status negotiations will be resumed within two months after implementation of the Hebron protocol.

Palestinian Responsibilities
The Palestinian side reaffirms its commitment to the following measures and principles in accordance with the Interim agreement:
1. Complete the process of revising the Palestinian National Charter.
2. Fighting terror and preventing violence.
a. Strengthening security cooperation.
b. Preventing incitement and hostile propaganda, as specified in Article XXII of the Interim Agreement.
c. Combat systematically and effectively terrorist organizations and infrastructure.
d. Apprehension, prosecution and punishment of terrorists.
e. Requests for transfer of suspects and defendants will be acted upon in accordance with Article II (7)(f) of Annex IV to the Interim Agreement.
f. Confiscating of illegal firearms.
3. Size of Palestinian Police will be pursuant to the Interim Agreement.
4. Exercise of Palestinian governmental activities, and location of Palestinian governmental offices, will be as specified in the Interim Agreement.
The aforementioned commitments will be dealt with immediately and in the parallel.

Other Issues
Either party is free to raise issues not specified above related to implementation of the Interim Agreement and obligations of both sides arising from the Interim Agreement.
Prepared by Ambassador Dennis Ross at the request of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Rais Yasir Arafat.

Letter to Netanyahu
Dear Mr. Prime Minister,
I wanted personally to congratulate you on the successful conclusion of the "Protocol Concerning the Redeployment in Hebron." It represents an important step forward in the Oslo peace process and reaffirms my conviction that a just and lasting peace will be established between Israelis and Palestinians in the very near future.
In this connection, I can assure you that it remains the policy of the United States to support and promote full implementation of the Interim Agreement in all of its parts. We intend to continue our efforts to help ensure that all outstanding commitments are carried out by both parties in a cooperative spirit and on the basis of reciprocity.
As part of this process, I have impressed upon Chairman Arafat the imperative need for the Palestinian Authority to make every effort to ensure public order and internal security within the West Bank and Gaza Strip. I have stressed to him that effectively carrying out this major responsibility will be a critical foundation for completing implementation of the Interim Agreement, as well as the peace process as a whole.
I wanted you to know that, in this context, I have advised Chairman Arafat of U.S. views on Israel's process of redeploying its forces, designating specified military locations and transferring additional powers and responsibilities to the Palestinian Authority. In this regard, I have conveyed our belief that the first phase of further redeployments should take place as soon as possible, and that all three phases of further redeployments should be completed within 12 months from the implementation of the first phase of the further redeployments but no later than mid-1998.
Mr. Prime Minister, you can be assured that the United States' commitment to Israel's security is ironclad and constitutes the fundamental cornerstone of our special relationship. The key element in our approach to peace, including the negotiations and implementation of agreements between Israel and its Arab partners, has always been a recognition of Israel's security requirements. Moreover, a hallmark of U.S. policy remains our commitment to work cooperatively to seek to meet the security needs that Israel identifies. Finally, I would like to reiterate our position that Israel is entitled to secure and defensible borders, which should be directly negotiated and agreed with its neighbors.
Sincerely,
WARREN CHRISTOPHER

HEADLINE: Medicaid Costs Are Seen Rising At Slower Rate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office radically reduced its estimate of future Medicaid costs today, relieving pressure on President Clinton and Congress to cut benefits for the poor. But the financial outlook for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly, improved only slightly.
The estimate of total Federal spending on Medicaid from 1997 to 2002 dropped by $86 billion -- more than all the Medicaid savings that Republicans proposed in their long, bitter struggle with Mr. Clinton over the budget in 1995 and 1996. 
 With no change in current law, the budget office said, Federal spending on Medicaid will rise an average of 7.8 percent a year, to $144 billion in 2002 from $92 billion in 1996. In contrast, the agency was predicting just six months ago that Medicaid would grow 9.7 percent a year.
The budget office's estimate assumes that greater use of managed care will help control Medicaid costs, as it has in the last few years. With permission from the Clinton Administration, many states are requiring the poor to join health maintenance organizations as a condition of Medicaid coverage.
But for the elderly, H.M.O.'s are purely optional: the Federal Government does not require any Medicare beneficiaries to join.
The Congressional Budget Office said today that it foresaw continued rapid growth in Medicare spending. And on the question of most interest to politicians, it said that Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund would run out of money in 2001 if Congress took no action to shore up the finances of the program. That prediction coincides with a forecast offered last June by the Administration.
The trust fund pays hospital bills for Medicare beneficiaries, who are elderly or disabled, and Republicans often cite it as a symbol of the need to slow Medicare growth.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said: "This new report from the Congressional Budget Office is disappointing and unfortunately dashes any hopes that Medicare's financial condition was significantly improving, or that Medicare would go bankrupt later than expected. It underscores the need for Congress and the President to forge a bipartisan agreement to save Medicare, without resorting to accounting gimmicks or tax increases."
The budget office said Medicare payments to doctors would increase more slowly than it predicted last year. But the savings in that part of the program do not help the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund.
Over all, the budget office said, Medicare spending will grow 8.6 percent a year -- to $314 billion in 2002 from $191 billion in 1996 -- a very modest decline from the 8.9 percent growth that the agency predicted in August.
The report today increases pressure on Mr. Clinton and Congress to take action to slow the growth of Medicare. But it may reduce the pressure to make major changes in Medicaid.
The White House said earlier this week that Mr. Clinton would propose firm limits on Medicaid spending as a way to help balance the Federal budget by 2002. Many Democrats in Congress contend that such limits are unnecessary and would undermine the program's ability to meet an increased need for assistance in times of economic recession.
The budget office's report predicted that increasing numbers of Medicare beneficiaries would voluntarily join H.M.O.'s, so that enrollment in them would rise from the current level of 5 million to 9.8 million in 2002 and then 14 million in 2006.
The budget office estimated that the proportion of Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in H.M.O.'s, now about 12 percent, would rise to 25 percent in 2003 and 32 percent in 2006, even if Congress took no action to encourage such enrollment.
The budget office sees annual Medicare payments to H.M.O.'s soaring from $26 billion this year to $73 billion in 2002 and $141 billion in 2006. The White House contends that H.M.O.'s are being overpaid, and Mr. Clinton plans to propose cutbacks in reimbursement as part of his budget proposal, scheduled for submission to Congress on Feb. 6.
The Congressional Budget Office sees only modest increases in the premiums that Medicare beneficiaries pay for physician and outpatient services. Under current law, it said, the monthly premium, now $43.80, will rise to $45.60 next year and to $47.10 in 1999.
But, it said, premiums will pay for a declining share of Medicare costs, and general revenue for a growing share.
Without waiting to hear from Mr. Clinton, Senate Democrats said today that one of their top legislative priorities was to provide health insurance for the 10 million American children who have none.
The Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said they would pursue this goal as tenaciously as they fought last year to make health insurance more readily available to workers who change jobs or lose their jobs.
These two Democrats are pursuing somewhat different approaches. Mr. Daschle said he would offer tax credits for the purchase of private insurance, while Mr. Kennedy would offer vouchers to families to subsidize premiums.
Mr. Daschle said he hoped Republicans would join him and Mr. Kennedy in supporting such proposals.
But Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican who has worked with much success in the last 15 years to extend Medicaid coverage to more children, said, "A new program is always very difficult in this atmosphere," when Congress is trying to balance the budget.
The uninsured children who would be helped by the Daschle and Kennedy bills are generally not poor enough to qualify for Medicaid.
Nine of 10 uninsured children live in families with working parents, and about two-thirds of such children live in two-parent families.

HEADLINE: Protests Erupt Across Haiti As Leaders Push Austerity

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Protesters burned tires and threw stones in towns and cities across Haiti today, calling for Prime Minister Rosny Smarth to resign and for President Rene Preval to suspend negotiations with international lending institutions and end austerity measures.
A young man was reported killed when security guards fired on a mob that stormed a food warehouse in the northern city of Cap-Haitien. 
 In Port-au-Prince, the capital, demonstrators set piles of tires ablaze, blocking intersections with the smoking barricades. Shops stayed shut, parents kept their children from school and no buses were running in the largest of a series of anti-Government strikes.
The strike was called by the Anti-International Monetary Fund Committee one day after a man lost his right hand to an exploding tear-gas canister fired by the police who halted a peaceful street demonstration.
More than 160 grass-roots groups joined the strike. The organizations, backed by many legislators, attribute inflation and unemployment to the Government's efforts to collect unpaid taxes, cut spending, privatize state-run enterprises and streamline the bloated bureaucracy -- prerequisites to receiving the foreign loans that have kept the Government afloat.
About 7,000 of 43,000 government workers are expected to lose their jobs over the next 18 months as a result of the austerity measures.
International donors finance more than 60 percent of Haiti's budget.
Officials from foreign lending institutions who arrived Monday to analyze the Government's economic performance said the strike would not affect their discussions.
"I don't think that our mission will be disturbed," Axel Porker, a representative of the World Bank, said on Radio Signal F.M.
The Government sent school buses to collect people trying to walk to work, but some were turned back by stone-throwing strikers in Cite Soleil, a seaside slum in Port-au-Prince.
Streets in the three main cities -- Port-au-Prince, Cap-Haitien and Gonaives -- were practically empty of traffic as many people appeared to stay home for fear of violence. Radio Haiti-Inter, another private station, said the strike was respected in most towns except Port-de-Paix, in the northwest.
"The strike was a total success," said Yves Sanon, a strike organizer. "The population has rejected the Government and its economic policy."
Rene Civil, another spokesman for the strikers, said at a news conference, "We warn anyone who does not respect the call that we'll force him to respect it."
Haiti's economy deteriorated under a corrupt dictatorship in the 1980's and was nearly ruined by international sanctions against a repressive military regime from 1991 to 1994. The United States sent troops to force out the military and restore the country's ousted President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
There are 1,600 United Nations peacekeepers in Haiti, including 300 civilian police officers who supervise and train the Haitian police. The peacekeepers are concentrated in Port-au-Prince, where they patrol but have no mandate to intervene in Haitian affairs.
There are no American combat troops left in Haiti, though a support unit of 300 to 500 troops builds bridges, repairs schools and digs wells.
The United States intervention force was replaced by United Nations peacekeepers in March 1995.
In February 1996, Mr. Preval succeeded President Aristide, who was opposed to taking stringent economic measures. Mr. Preval has refused to make concessions to grass-roots movements and Mr. Smarth has refused to resign.
"We have not made our economic policy choices lightly," Mr. Preval said in a State of the Nation address on Monday. "We have to take this road if we want a better future."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Fall In Selloff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities fell yesterday, as a heavy calendar of new corporate and municipal debt inhibited buyers. A Federal Reserve official's warnings on inflation contributed to the selloff.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 15/32 , to 9528/32 , to yield 6.83 percent, up from 6.79 percent on Wednesday. 
 Treasury prices have been held down this week by concerns over the market's ability to absorb a number of large debt offerings coming, in particular an offering by U S West Capital Funding Inc., which grew yesterday to $4.1 billion.
Prices fell further yesterday, when Laurence H. Meyer, a Federal Reserve governor, suggested in a speech in Charlotte, N.C. that if the unemployment rate fell much further, the Fed would move to raise short-term interest rates. His comments revived speculation that the central bank was about to embark on a series of rate increases.
Mr. Meyer's comments seemed more explicit than usual from a Federal Reserve official, analysts said.
"This bombshell came from Mr. Meyer when the market was already on the defensive from heavy corporate supply," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "And now some of the traders may be looking ahead to tomorrow's industrial production and trade deficit figures, bracing for possible negative news for bonds."
But Mr. Sohn also noted that Mr. Meyer had previously offered different views of the economy.
"In the past, he has always been balancing economic growth and inflation, implying that there is no need for the Fed to hike interest rates," Mr. Sohn said. "Today, however, he implied that the econony is already on the mountaintop, and that both inflation and economic growth could get worse and not better. And that while 1996 was an ideal year, inflation is likely to accelerate."
Adding that he agreed with Mr. Meyer, Mr. Sohn said, " While I don't expect a spike in inflation, the Fed nevertheless should purchase an insurance policy to make sure that inflation does not become a problem later on."
Mr. Sohn said Treasury prices were somewhat bolstered yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's regional survey for January. The survey's prices-paid index, which fell to 2.1 this month from 14.4 in December, pointing to controlled inflation.
In the corporate market, strong investor demand for U S West Capital Funding Inc.'s debt offering allowed the company to increase the size of its offering for the second time in two days.
The company initially planned to sell $2 billion of debt to repay debt related to its purchase of Continental Cablevision Inc. last year, but yesterday priced $4.1 billion of debt in six parts through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
Underwriters priced $600 million of noncallable notes due in 2002 at a spread of 55 basis points -- or hundreds of a percentage point -- above the when-issued yield of the five-year Treasury issue that will be auctioned next week, and $600 million of notes due in 2037 which were priced to yield 56 basis points more than the 5.875 percent Treasury note due Feb. 15, 2004. These notes can be sold back to the issuer in seven-years.
In the third part, the company priced $1.1 billlion of noncallable notes due 2007 to yield 80 basis points more than a comparable Treasury, and another $1.1 billion of noncallable debentures due 2027 that were priced to yield 107 basis points more than a comparable Treasury. For $500 milllion of noncallable debt due in 2097 the yield after pricing was 120 basis points more than a comparable Treasury, and for $200 million of callable debt due in 2032 the yield was 132 basis points above a Treasury. This security, however, is callable in 10 years.
The deal ranks as the largest investment-grade deal ever, although short of the RJR Nabisco Holding Corporation's $4.11 billion junk bond sale in 1989. Yesterday's sale was rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Duff & Phelps and Standard & Poor's.
Securities firms that arrange corporate sales often sell Treasury securities to hedge against losses. While the robust demand for U S West debt limited some of that hedging, the prospect of additional corporate debt combined with next week's Treasury auctions of new two-year and five-year notes continued to weigh down Treasury prices.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.03 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.33 percent.

HEADLINE: No Longer Flying in Formation;
Labor Rifts Return to Employee-Owned United Airlines

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Perhaps old habits do die hard, but optimism was widespread in July 1994 that United Airlines was going to mend its fractious ways.
When the pilots of United led an effort to create one of the nation's largest employee-owned companies, the buyout was cheered by the Clinton Administration as a way to preserve jobs. And from a distance, the experiment, two and a half years later, seemed to be working. The pilots got want they wanted -- a seat on the board, a big ownership stake and the power to hand-pick top managers. Adjusted for a 4-for-1 split, shares in the UAL Corporation, the parent of United, have jumped from $22 to nearly $60, rewarding outside investors as well as employees. 
 But rather than establish a new model for working together, labor and management at United have reverted to a familiar groove.
Yesterday, United's pilots voted down by a 4-to-1 margin a tentative agreement that called for a cumulative wage increase of 10 percent over four years. The two sides will now enter binding arbitration, with no possibility of a strike because the pilots' contract extends until the year 2000.
The pilots' vote has put the managers of employee-owned United in roughly the same position as their counterparts at the conventionally managed American Airlines. Last week, American's pilots, too, voted down a contract offer in hopes of winning a bigger share of the record profits earned by the AMR Corporation, American's parent company.
In the cases of both airlines, the unions appear to be ignoring management's warning that letting labor costs creep too high will undo hard-won gains and damage the carriers' standing on Wall Street.
In fact, United is falling into a familiar pattern. Employee ownership arrangements are often struck during a financial crisis at a corporation. The elation over such rescue deals can mask vague and conflicting assumptions by management and employees. And, once the crucible of crisis gives way to recovery, the parties sometimes regret concessions they made under pressure.
Indeed, other big corporations that once embraced employee ownership, like Weirton Steel and Northwestern Steel, have since retreated to more traditional labor-management schisms, with the workers giving up their majority control.
"The initial financial transaction did its job in most cases, but no new corporate model emerged," said Joseph R. Blasi, a professor of management-labor relations at Rutgers University who has written several books on employee ownership. "Management and labor never really changed their fundamental points of view."
United is exceptional in the speed of its recovery. The consensus estimate of its profits last year -- they have yet to be reported -- is $1 billion, up from the $662 million the company made in 1995. But for the moment, it looks like another experiment in employee ownership that is falling short of creating a new formula for running a business.
However the contract vote came out, leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association at United had warned that pilots would no longer try to foster a spirit of cooperation at the airline. In announcing the vote yesterday, union leaders, in a message on a telephone hot line, said that the results "sent a clear message of dissatisfaction. This dissatisfaction transcends a mere wage dispute. It is also a vote against a business-as-usual attitude that has no place in an employee-owned company."
In a statement by the company yesterday, Gerald Greenwald, the chairman and chief executive who was selected with the backing of the pilots, said he was "very sorry" to report the results of the vote. "If we, as an employee-owned company, have failed," he added, "I think it has been in the area of underestimating the time it is going to take to complete the journey from the United of the past to realizing the company we all want United to be.
"For that, I take responsibility. Employee ownership has not overnight erased past suspicions and mistrust. They persist today, on all sides and on virtually all levels."
The pilots' resentments are fueled by contrary perceptions about the reasons for United's rebound, with the pilots attributing the record profits mostly to the hard work of employees, and managers giving more weight to macroeconomic factors.
Members of the pilots' union and the International Association of Machinists took deep pay cuts in exchange for their 45.8 percent ownership stake in the company. Now, leaders of the employee groups say that with the airline doing so well, they should get big raises sooner. The run-up in the price of their shares, they add, is not enough because they cannot cash them in until they retire.
"The employees put their effort forth first, and no one ever anticipated the performance we've had," Michael H. Glawe, chairman of the pilots' union at United and a director of UAL, said before the vote.
"Like a great coach with a team, there is a big difference between mere ordering and leading to get the respect and motivation of people," Mr. Glawe said. "You can invest 20 cents in an employee and make one dollar, or you can try to save 20 cents and lose a dollar. We're missing the potential for the airline."
On the contrary, Mr. Greenwald said in an interview before the vote, the six-year contract that the pilots signed as part of the buyout put a cap of 10 percent on any midterm pay increase. Skirting the intent of the agreement, he said, would be ethically wrong and could frighten away outside investors and creditors, depressing the value of United's stock and raising borrowing costs.
"They're having trouble acknowledging, in a sense, that a deal is a deal," Mr. Greenwald said of the pilot leaders. "You signed a contract. It's legally binding. It's morally binding."
Certainly, the investment community sides with management. Philip Baggaley, an airline analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said that any increases beyond the 10 percent cap "would incur cynicism about whether employee ownership works as a concept for outside shareholders and creditors."
The harshness of the recent exchanges marks a reversal from the early days of the buyout agreement. Then, arcane work rules were discarded and employees were given more freedom to make decisions. Pilots were given leeway to set air speed to improve the airline's on-time performance, for example. Even many flight attendants, whose union elected to stay out of the buyout, warmed to the new management team after it eliminated weight restrictions and rules such as those prohibiting them from wearing shoes that revealed a glimpse of their toes.
Before that agreement, labor-management feuding at United was commonplace. After a strike in 1985, the pilots tried on several occasions to acquire United. The most recent effort started in 1992, when the former chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, approached the union and reiterated his concern about United's high labor costs and the need for wage and productivity concessions. Without them, he said, United would have to sell assets and pull out of unprofitable routes.
Ultimately, the pilots agreed, figuring that the big ownership stake and seat on the board that they won would give them a greater say over strategy. And it was the pilots and the machinists who picked Mr. Greenwald, a former vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, in part for his concern about labor relations dating back to a summer job he'd had as a teen-ager organizing for the garment workers' union.
The honeymoon lasted about 18 months. Then, last January, managers started hearing criticism from employees about bonuses -- based on the company's profit -- being given to UAL's top 600 managers and officers. The incentives were part of the 1994 contract that created the employee stock ownership plan.
Employee mistrust of management deepened last summer when, even before the new round of wage negotiations had begun, United's managers decided to hold a practice run-through arbitration. In a memorandum to employees, the company said it was only doing its job for shareholders, gaining a reference point for the approaching talks. But Mr. Glawe, the union leader, said his members viewed it as a sign of bad faith. "I don't feel the pilots have been accepted as equal partners, as opposed to merely being tolerated by management," he said.
With the industry ending a year of record profits, employees of other airlines are also pushing for higher pay. In voting down American's offer of a 5 percent cumulative raise through 2000, members of the Allied Pilots Association indicated that they want a greater share of American's record earnings of $854 million last year. American says it cannot afford to give a bigger raise to workers if the company hopes to grow and remain competitive.
At United, the frustration is even more palpable because the buyout was intended to give the pilots more control over the company.
But with their current contract in effect through 2000, the pilots' influence has dwindled. Before the vote, Mr. Greenwald acknowledged being surprised by the strength of the feelings held by the pilots -- and others. Last week, mechanics rejected an agreement similar to the one offered the pilots. Workers in another United division of the machinists' union, though, approved a deal.
The problem, Mr. Greenwald said in an interview in Washington, is straightforward: "No one thought we would do this well this quickly."
The appreciation of United's stock alone has made the average pilot $137,000 richer in less than three years, he noted. And, Mr. Greenwald said, he believed that stock was more important to pilots than they let on. He sometimes teases them with an offer to buy it from them, and they always refuse, he said.
While Mr. Greenwald said he would like to see Federal law changed to make the stock more liquid for employees, he believed when he took the job that the stock price would be the main measure of his success. In an interview published in Airline Business, a trade magazine, in March 1995, Mr. Greenwald said: "If the stock is high, people will like me. If it is low, they won't."
Mr. Greenwald recalled this week that when he was being interviewed for the job, he told the pilots over and over that he would represent the interest of all shareholders.
"These are the folks that hired me, they are my partners, but they did hire me to lead, not to follow," he said. "If they wanted to call the shots themselves, they should have bought 100 percent of the company, I guess."
To keep everyone focused on the long term, Mr. Greenwald said he would have to talk to employees even more than in the past.
"I thought we would be able to communicate a common goal more easily than we have," he said.

After United Airlines' employees bought 55 percent of the company in 1994, the new employee owners were featured on the cover of the company's annual report. 25,000 salaried employees and managers

22,000 members

23,000 members

PILOTS
8,000 members

HEADLINE: High Treasury Official to Join Salomon

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Jeffrey R. Shafer, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, will resign on Feb. 1 to join Salomon Brothers as a managing director and vice chairman of the Wall Street firm's international division.
"I have an excellent opportunity to pursue my interest in international finance in the private sector," Mr. Shafer said in a letter of resignation to Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin, himself former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, a Salomon rival. 
 Mr. Rubin accepted the resignation "with deep regret."
Mr. Shafer, 52, was sworn in on Dec. 27, 1995, replacing Lawrence H. Summers, who was promoted to Deputy Secretary of the Treasury.
The holder of a doctorate in economics from Yale, Mr. Shafer joined the Treasury as an assistant secretary in May 1993. From 1984 to 1993, he worked at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, and before that in the Federal Reserve System.

HEADLINE: After the Last Picture Show;
The Politics of Nostalgia Grows Bitter Over a Movie Palace in Flushing

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
As the elevated No. 7 IRT train slowed to its last stop in Queens some years ago, John P. Watts used to look outside fondly toward the northern end of Main Street. Against the nighttime sky, above the low rooftops of downtown Flushing where tall buildings with Chinese and Korean signs have since risen, he would pick out the red light of the RKO Keith's.
"The light told us there was something exciting down Main Street," said Mr. Watts, 41, the chief of staff for City Councilwoman Julia Harrison. "It was a fixture for so long. And then, when it wasn't there anymore, you missed it, and the excitement went away." 
 When the lights went out at the RKO Keith's on Labor Day in 1986, no one could have guessed that the closing of a movie palace, whose popularity had begun to ebb in the 1970's, would give rise to one of the longest and fiercest neighborhood battles in the borough. But a fight over a place where many Queens old-timers saw their first movies or stole their first kiss grew into a fight over memories, real or enhanced, of a Flushing that the newcomers had yet to change.
On one side was Thomas J. Huang, a Taiwanese-born developer, now 44, who bought and closed the theater in 1986 in the hope of reopening it as a combination shopping center, movie multiplex and hotel. In less than a decade in this country, Mr. Huang had brashly assumed the quintessentially New York City role of empire builder, a small-scale Donald Trump. The more than 100 residential and commercial buildings he erected in his corner of Queens allowed him to stand next to Reagan, Bush and D'Amato in photographs that now hang on his office walls.
On the other side stood some of Flushing's old-timers, most of them white, who contended that despite the $3.4 million Mr. Huang had paid, the RKO Keith's belonged, in some sense, to them, too. The fact that the theater's lobby and grand foyer had been awarded national landmark status in 1984 buttressed their belief.
So while shops and offices have mushroomed all over Flushing, one of its most prominent spots, the end of Main Street on Northern Boulevard, has remained lifeless. If the redevelopment of a landmark requires economic and political cooperation, the sight of the boarded-up building is perhaps a reminder of something unique about Flushing: the stark division between those with the money and those with the votes.
"They're really not helping Asian people," Mr Huang said of local politicians. "You can see this neighborhood, the Asian people put down money, work very hard. You have a lot of stores opened by Asian people, working 24 hours. And they bring money. What can they do? That's the most they can do." The Asian immigrants, few of whom are registered voters, have "zero" political pull, Mr. Huang added.
The RKO Keith's also suggests the political role nostalgia plays in Queens in a way it no longer can in Brooklyn or the Bronx. Those who remember the heyday of the Loew's Paradise or the Loew's Kings, two other movie palaces that have been closed for several years and whose future is uncertain, moved away from the Grand Concourse and Flatbush Avenue, respectively, long ago. But in Queens, a younger borough whose population grew partly by drawing people from the older boroughs, old-timers and newcomers are on the same blocks. And nostalgia can be used to conjure up an enchanted past or to label someone as hopelessly out of touch.
In Flushing, the politics of nostalgia, with the RKO Keith's as its touchstone, will be played out this year in the Democratic primary race for City Council. Mrs. Harrison, 76, the longtime incumbent who once had Asian-American backers, has lost most of that support because they say she has not stood up for their interests. Mrs. Harrison, who has described Asian immigrants as "colonizers" and last year likened their arrival to an "invasion," is being challenged by Ethel Chen, 58, a Taiwanese-American who is a Democratic district leader at large and who failed in her bid to unseat Mrs. Harrison in 1993.
In the meantime memories abound. Mr. Watts remembers that on hot summer days in the 1960's he would hang around the theater entrance, trying to cool himself in the wafts of air-conditioning. On the hottest days, clutching the few dimes his tolerant mother had slipped him, the boy was allowed into the lobby, past the grand foyer where plump goldfish swam below a marble cherub in a three-tiered fountain, and into the auditorium where he sat in one of the 3,000 seats and whiled away afternoons under a twilight blue ceiling.
"The Keith's was taken away from us," he said. Speaking of Mr. Huang, he said, "He ripped the heart out of Flushing."
Fred Borneman, 63, who works as a doorman in Greenwich Village and has lived in Flushing for 52 years, recalled as he walked toward the RKO Keith's the other day how he would run to it after school to get the 5 P.M. discount. But by the 1970's, movie palaces had fallen victim to high costs and declining attendance. The RKO Keith's, like the others, was carved into a triplex.
Back then, community organizers and elected officials did nothing, said Mrs. Chen.
"If they wanted to save this place, why didn't they do anything then?" Mrs. Chen said. "Now that an Asian has taken it over, they just criticize. They just bring negative views. They never have any proposals. They don't want change. But the reality is, we have changed."
Mrs. Chen and others said that Flushing's heart had already been ripped out by the time Mr. Huang came from Taiwan in 1973 and started studying at Queens College. As many of the baby boomers who grew up in Queens left the borough, downtown Flushing suffered from a high vacancy rate, and in the mid-1970's, there was talk of blight.
Mr. Huang became one of the first to invest in Flushing, which quickly began drawing more and more Taiwanese and Korean businessmen. Flushing was on the road to recovery and Mr. Huang was a prominent builder by the time he bought the RKO Keith's in 1986.
In 1987, the Landmarks Commission revoked his construction permit after $160,000 in damage to the landmarked foyer was found. Since then, Mr. Huang said, elected officials and overzealous members of a local group, the Committee to Save the RKO Keith's, have consistently impeded his attempts to revise his renovation plans according to city requirements. His critics, he said, had not helped with any proposals.
"In America, talk is cheap," Mr. Huang said. "People can point at you and say, 'You don't do that, you don't do this,' and keep talking. But doing is different."
In his office overlooking Northern Boulevard and the RKO Keith's, Mr. Huang held what he said was a list of tenants he had had to turn away because of the empty building. He said he never considered selling the site. "That location is gold!" he said.
Over the years, local elected officials and members of Save the RKO Keith's have accused Mr. Huang of trying to renege on his obligation by letting the building deteriorate. According to preservation laws, he must restore the landmarked portions before he can start building.
In recent months, relations have worsened. Inspectors were called and found asbestos and oil, and barred anyone from entering the premises.
According to Mr. Huang's lawyer, Jeffrey Chester, the city said early this week that it would consider Mr. Huang's application to repair the unsafe conditions if both sides agreed on an independent architect or engineer who would monitor the work and who would be paid by Mr. Huang. Mr. Huang agreed.
This week, though, the Keith's doors remained padlocked, with a notice from the Department of Buildings prohibiting entry. A handwritten message of scribbled anti-Asian epithets on the notice suggested that some people's anger toward Mr. Huang was only the tip.
Mrs. Harrison said that Mr. Huang's critics are angered by his conduct and not motivated by anti-Asian sentiments, but she added that such sentiments had probably increased because of him.
"Unfortunately he doesn't represent the best," she said. "And it's unfortunate, but he may have contributed to a feeling of hostility."
A current leader in Save the RKO Keith's, Jerry Rotondi, 55, whose phone number Mr. Watts punches in by heart on his office phone, said of the owner: "He's a greedy, unimaginative -- I don't want to call him a developer."
Asked what should be done with the building, Mr. Rotondi said he wanted a study done on possible uses. Other opponents say the site should become an entertainment center.
Although Mr. Huang was derelict, Mrs. Chen said, in not maintaining the building, she added that his critics were too envious to acknowledge his pivotal role in Flushing's rebirth.
Peter Casini, an architect who has long worked for Mr. Huang, said that politicians pleaded for Asian investments in the 1970's. But Asian-American success has caused resentment among old-timers, he said, and officials were using Mr. Huang as an easy target to shore up votes.
As for memories, Mrs. Chen's are different. A Queens resident for 33 years, she recalled that in 1977 she finally yielded to the pleading of her two young sons and took them to the RKO Keith's to see "Star Wars." It was her first time there, and she was appalled, she said, by the stench of urine in the ticket lobby and by the flagrant sales of drugs inside and outside the theater. She phoned her brother who sat with her children to watch the film while she waited in her car.
"People talk about the good old days," Mrs. Chen said. "But sometimes the good old days are not as good as nowadays."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Earnings Rise at Kodak, And It Plans Job Cuts
Eastman Kodak said operating profits in the fourth quarter rose by 21.5 percent. Wall Street was pleased, and Kodak stock rose 5 percent. 
 The company said that on an operating basis it earned $395 million, or $1.19 a share, up from $325 million, or 95 cents a share, a year earlier. Kodak also said it would eliminate 4,000 jobs, mostly in Europe, and the earnings report included a $256 million charge to cover the costs of the cuts. [Page D3.]

Digital Equipment Shows Profit
Digital Equipment regained profitability in its fiscal second quarter but is still suffering from slow sales of its Alpha computer systems. Digital reported net income of $31.9 million, or 15 cents a share, after posting a loss of $66 million, or 48 cents a share, for its first quarter. [D3.]
 
G.E.'s Quarterly Results Gain
General Electric said its earnings rose 10.8 percent in the fourth quarter, to $2.07 billion, from $1.87 billion a year earlier. [D3.]
 
Strong Profits Lift Stocks
Buoyed by the strong earnings reports, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.49 points, to close at 6,765.37, its seventh record in two weeks. Broader indexes also rose. [D7.]

The prices of Treasuries fell, with the long bond yield up to 6.83 percent from 6.79. [D13.]
 
Ford to Cut 1,300 Jobs in Britain
Ford Motor, which has been losing money in Europe because of excess capacity and weak sales, said it would cut 1,300 jobs at a plant near Liverpool, England. [D4.]
 
Mercedes-Benz Head Resigns
Daimler-Benz said that Helmut Werner, the head of its Mercedes-Benz unit, had resigned because he saw no appropriate role for himself after the planned merger of his unit into the parent company. [D4.]
 
Chief to Quit
At Federated Stores
Allen I. Questrom, who took Federated Department Stores out of bankruptcy and made it into the parent of many of America's best-known stores, said he would step down as chairman and chief executive in May. Mr. Questrom, who had hinted that he might depart, will be succeeded by James M. Zimmerman, left, the company's president and chief operating officer. The executives have worked closely together for years. [D3.]
 
Condos From the St. Moritz?
Faced with declining profit, the Australian company that owns the St. Moritz Hotel in Manhattan has decided to transfer the hotel's fate to Donald Trump. He plans to turn the St. Moritz into luxury condominiums, people in the real estate industry said. [A1.]
 
Paradoxical Prosperity for Koreans
Over the last few years, living standards have risen dramatically for South Korean workers. But a new law intended to let companies compete better with lower-wage nations is also increasing anxiety about job security. The immediate aim of the widespread strikes there is a repeal of that law, but more broadly the workers are taking a stand against the economic forces that brought prosperity but now threaten to take it elsewhere. [A1.]
 
Old Air-Traffic Computer Replaced
A 25-year-old computer at the Chicago air-traffic control center, probably the frailest major piece of equipment in the F.A.A.'s creaky system, was retired. The computer's replacement was declared operational, a step the agency says will make air travel faster and more reliable. [A16.]

HEADLINE: Thriving, South Koreans Strike to Keep It That Way

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: ULSAN, South Korea, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Until four years ago, Lee Soo Chun, an equipment repairman at Hyundai Heavy Industries, lived a threadbare existence with his wife and son in a single rented room.
Now he owns a two-bedroom apartment. Over the years he has also acquired a television, a VCR, a stereo, a car, a personal computer for his son and enough leisure time to indulge his passion for hiking. 
 The upward mobility of Mr. Lee and his fellow tenants of the Ten Thousand Apartments can be glimpsed mornings in the building's parking lot, where people push cars back and forth by hand in what looks like some kind of ritual.
So many residents have bought their first cars in recent years that there is now a severe shortage of parking spaces. People double-park, leaving the brakes off and the gears disengaged to allow others to shove their cars out of the way.
But Mr. Lee, 41, whose $20,000 salary is nearly triple what he was earning when he joined the company 15 years ago, feels far from secure. Last month the Government enacted a labor law that makes it easier for companies to dismiss workers, in an effort to compete with newly industrializing nations, where wages are still comparatively low. There are reports, Mr. Lee said, that Hyundai may lay off 3,000 workers.
And so he is on strike, joining a violent and bitter labor protest now entering its fourth week. His immediate aim is repeal of the new law. But in a deeper sense, he and his co-workers are taking a stand against the global economic forces that brought investment and prosperity to low-wage Korea and now threaten to take it elsewhere.
This is reflected in Mr. Lee's ambivalence toward the strike. Workers' animus, he says, is not really directed against Hyundai, the company that has brought his family and others solidly into the middle class. "We are not angry at the company," he said, "just at the Government. It's not about money, it's politics."
The strike differs from the labor unrest that has convulsed South Korea in past years. It is not so much about gains in wages and working conditions as about protecting them. It signals a shift in emphasis, similar to those felt in the United States and other developed countries, from higher pay to job security.
The complex dynamics can best be seen in this city of one million on the southeastern coast, which has long been the hotbed of labor unrest and is a focus of the current strike.
Here in Ulsan, South Korea's blue-collar capital, walking off the job over a perceived injustice is a matter of honor. Although he had misgivings about harming Hyundai, Mr. Lee felt compelled to strike.
"I'm afraid of what my son will think about me if I don't strike," he said. "My son will think I'm a chicken."
This city was practically built by the Hyundai Group, one of the largest of the giant family-controlled conglomerates, known as chaebol, that dominate the economy.
About 80,000 workers here are employed by the six Hyundai subsidiaries that stretch in a chain along the city's waterfront: the Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's largest car manufacturer; Hyundai Heavy Industries, the largest shipbuilding yard in the world; Hyundai Precision; Hyundai Pipe; Hyundai Wood Industries, and a Hyundai ship-repair facility.
Although the strike is large by Korean standards, it is concentrated among relatively few companies, and Hyundai, particularly its automobile subsidiary, is one. Some other chaebol, like the Samsung and LG groups, have experienced little or no unrest.
This has to do in part with Hyundai's history of poor labor relations. In a nation of endemic strikes, no company has had more problems than Hyundai. As a result, its unions are militant and primed for conflict.
"We are well organized and we have experience over the last 10 years," Lee Young Hee, the leader of the association of Hyundai unions, said proudly when asked why these unions were at the center of this strike. As he spoke, thousands of Hyundai workers rallied on the banks of the Taehwa River, singing protest songs with synchronized arm movements as if they were a well-rehearsed drill team.
Hyundai says its labor problems stem from the fact that so many blue-collar workers are concentrated in Ulsan, which makes them easy to organize. But labor officials say it has to do with the company's attempts to fight the unions.
In the interest of rapid economic growth, unions were suppressed by South Korea's authoritarian leaders until 1987, when democracy started to take root. At that point, workers began organizing and striking for a bigger share of the nation's growing wealth.
But Hyundai fought off unionization attempts. In the late 1980's, there were cases of hired thugs attacking labor leaders, and at least one case in which a union organizer was kidnapped and held for a few days, according to "Korean Dynasty," a 1994 history of Hyundai by Donald Kirk, a journalist. Workers, for their part, also resorted to violence at times.
In the last few years, the number of strikes for higher wages at Hyundai has diminished, but a bitter legacy remains.
In June 1995, for instance, a Hyundai Motor union activist, Yang Bong Soo, who had been dismissed for protesting company work practices, died from injuries he had suffered a month earlier setting himself on fire. In his honor workers walked out; after about a week the strike was broken up, its union leaders arrested.
A week ago, in a chilling replay, another Hyundai Motor worker, Chung Jae Sung, who had been a friend of Mr. Yang, set himself on fire. He remains hospitalized in serious condition.
Because of this history, the right to organize is very important to the Hyundai unions, and that is one of the issues in the current strike. The new labor law will make it easier for companies to replace striking workers.
And the law delays for three years the legal recognition of the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions, an umbrella group that is orchestrating the strikes and to which the Hyundai union belongs.
But the wealth now evident among workers in Ulsan has in some measure undercut the intensity of this strike, support for which is far from universal here.
[On Wednesday, some Hyundai employees wanting to return to work burst through the picket lines in Ulsan, clashing with strikers. Union officials say that nationwide, about 260,000 workers were striking Thursday. But the Government says the number was 80,000.]
Woo Byung Ho, 40, a welder at Hyundai Heavy Industries, said he could not afford to walk away from his job. "I was in strikes in 1988, 1989 and 1990," he said. "Now I dislike the labor union. During the strikes, I lost a lot of money."
Cheung Ho Pyung, a 55-year-old employee of Hyundai's ship repair yard, said the labor law issue was not a problem between the company and workers. "It has nothing to do with us," he insisted.
Workers' affluence is increasingly evident in Ulsan, which in the last decade has acquired trendy department stores, boutiques and an airport. In addition to salaries that have tripled in 10 years, Hyundai workers enjoy a variety of benefits typically available in company towns.
Employees are offered a 50 percent discount at the hospital, which is owned by Hyundai. The company also pays children's tuition at its own private school. And workers can rent or buy subsidized apartments like those at the Ten Thousand Apartments complex, which Hyundai built.
About 90 percent of married workers at Hyundai Heavy Industries and Hyundai Motor own their apartments or houses, a Hyundai spokesman said.
Wages have risen 15 percent a year for the past 10 years -- 8 percent after adjustment for inflation. The Goverment and South Korean corporations say that is too high and threatens the competitiveness of Korean industry. "Korea and the Hyundai Group are facing globalization," a Hyundai Group spokesman said, "but the labor leaders don't want to change."
Some workers say that pay is still not high enough and that their gains have been eaten away by inflation, which was as high as 9 percent annually a few years ago and is now about 5 percent.
"It's true that life is better," said Chung Jong Soo, 32, an assembly line worker at Hyundai Motor. "But I don't think we are well off."
When Mr. Chung began working, he was poor; in fact his poverty forced him into the work force right after graduation from middle school. Now he makes about $1,500 a month. But he said he still did not have enough money to buy a home, go to movies or travel.
Workers express concern that with the nation's economic growth slowing, their relative success might now be in jeopardy. Newspaper articles and television dramas are filled with stories of "honorary retirees," people induced to end their careers early in return for large severance packages. With the new labor law, many workers fear, companies will be able to dismiss them without severance.
"Hyundai Motor has 48,000 workers," said Kim Dong Soo, 36, an assembly line worker. "Twenty percent of them will be fired."
Such fears might not be misplaced. The Hyundai spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said no employee cutbacks had been made or announced at any Hyundai companies. But he noted that many companies in Korea are having to decrease their work forces.
Still, while some workers say they realize companies must remain competitive, this does little to assuage their fears. "I'm also worried about losing competitiveness," Mr. Kim said. "But it is necessary to protect workers' rights."
Workers are not oblivious to the argument that frequent strikes hurt companies' performance. "I think strikes do great harm to the firm," said Mr. Lee, the equipment repairman at Hyundai, as he prepared to depart for a hike. "Most workers are tired of going on strike. They don't want to strike anymore."

HEADLINE: Treasury Chief Will Begin Attack on Budget Amendment

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Opening a campaign to defeat a constitutional amendment that would require balancing the budget, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today that he planned to warn Congress on Friday that it was on the brink of making "a terrible mistake" that would pose "unacceptable economic risks to the nation."
In an interview in his office, Mr. Rubin acknowledged that sentiment in favor of the amendment, which was defeated by only one vote in the Senate last year, appeared to be building on Capitol Hill. 
 "This will be an uphill battle," said Mr. Rubin, who has been the Administration's most outspoken opponent of a constitutional limit. But he insisted that "those who count the votes say the outcome is still uncertain, and it is monumentally important that the balanced budget amendment not be put in place."
In his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Friday, Mr. Rubin said that he would affirm the Administration's commitment to balance the budget by 2002 -- but that he would also warn of "the many, many risks" of enshrining such a balance in the Constitution.
A constitutional amendment requires passage by two-thirds of both houses, and then by three-quarters of the state legislatures. Passage appears likely in the Senate, but the amendment's fate in the House is unclear. So is the timing of the vote.
But there is still debate among Republican proponents of the amendment over which chamber should take up the issue first. Those proponents also hope to use the prospect of a vote as leverage in their negotiations with the White House over the next budget.
President Clinton has no formal role in the approval or rejection of constitutional amendments, though Mr. Rubin said today that his testimony would be "the first public discussion of the very powerful reasons the balanced budget amendment would be a terrible mistake and something we should not do."
The first public discussion in recent months actually came from President Clinton, who gave a winding talk in mid-November in which he seemed at times to acknowledge that passage of the amendment would be hard to stop. Though Mr. Clinton expressed some misgivings then, he did not muster any strong language, leading Mr. Rubin to correct his boss gently the next day.
In his testimony on Friday, Mr. Rubin said he would stress that if the amendment was in force, an economic downturn could quickly "turn into a recession, and a recession into something worse."
"The problem is that if the nation does in fact get into a recession," he said, "we now have automatic stabilizers that go into effect that can increase demand in the government sector to offset declines in the private sector. What the balanced budget amendment would require is that during a recession we would have to raise taxes or cut spending to put ourselves back in balance. And that could exacerbate the recession."
The Administration has in the past marshaled economists to make the point that since the Government began using Government spending to compensate for economic downturns, a practice that did not begin until World War II, recessions have been shorter and less severe.
But it is unclear how big an effort the Administration will make, especially if it fears spending Mr. Clinton's limited political capital in Congress. Instead, it could focus its efforts in the state legislatures, arguing that if Federal spending was sharply cut back because of the amendment, the burden might fall on the legislatures.
Mr. Rubin also plans to unleash several other arguments. Among them is that an amendment would increase the chances of default on the national debt because it would restrict increases in the debt limit, the amount the Government is allowed to borrow. Similarly, he argues, it could pose additional risks for the Social Security system.
In his speech in November, Mr. Clinton speculated about the possibility of including an automatic "escape hatch" in the constitutional amendment that would permit deficit spending in times of economic downturn. Under the current wording of the proposed amendment, such spending would require approval by 60 percent of both houses of Congress, a high hurdle. Proponents of the amendment say such an extraordinary obstacle is needed to insure that the Government balances the budget except in times of national emergency, like war.
Mr. Rubin says it would be virtually impossible to write wording that would protect the economy. "I haven't seen a trap door I thought was commensurate with the complexities of the economy," he said today.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Good U.S. Trade Data Help Dollar Against Mark and Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar reached its highest level in two and a half years against the mark and Swiss franc yesterday in a rally powered by better-than-expected United States trade data and by hints of lower German interest rates from two top Bundesbank officials.
The dollar also rose to a 45-month high against the yen, helped by more signs of economic anemia in Japan. 
 Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin further aided the dollar by declaring for the third time this week that a strong currency was desirable.
Traders who had bet on a lower dollar scrambled to buy dollars as it surpassed important technical levels against the mark, accelerating the dollar's advance in what is known as a short-covering rally.
"The dollar has really had a substantial up move," said Victor Polce, vice president and corporate foreign exchange manager at the New York branch of Commerzbank.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.6174 marks from 1.5943 on Thursday, and to 1.3989 Swiss francs from 1.3796 francs. Both were the highest levels for the dollar since mid-June 1994. The dollar rose to 117.38 yen, from 116.44 yen on Thursday, the highest since March 1993. The British pound fell to $1.6674 from $1.6798.
Traders said the main force driving the dollar higher yesterday was the report from the Commerce Department that the United States trade deficit edged up only slightly to $8.4 billion in November, well below the $10 billion widely expected. The report was seen as a sign that the dollar's nearly 14 percent rise against the yen and 13 percent rise against the mark over the last year had not started to expand the deficit.
The dollar strengthened further on mark weakness after Johann Wilhelm Gaddum and Franc-Christoph Zeitler, two senior members of the Bundesbank, suggested that German interest rates might be eased.
In separate remarks made in Germany, Mr. Gaddum said "interest rate increases certainly aren't on the Bundesbank's present agenda," and Mr. Zeitler said benign German inflation would give the central bank flexibility to lower rates.
Their remarks came less than a week before the Bundesbank council meets, and there has been growing speculation it will nudge rates lower.

HEADLINE: Epilogue for Another Bookstore

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
Books & Company, the venerable Upper East Side bookstore that has provided a home for a generation of writers, giving them space for readings and allowing them to browse uninterruptedly amid its dark paneled stacks, will close on May 31, the owner, Jeannette Watson, announced this week. "We just cannot afford to pay the rent," Ms. Watson said.
It is the latest in a series of independent bookstore closings in Manhattan. On the Upper West Side alone, at least three independent bookstores have closed since a Barnes & Noble superstore moved in in 1993. Nationally, the American Booksellers Association has estimated, some 50 to 60 independent bookstores shut down in 1996. And as the news of Books & Company's closing spread through the literary community, the reaction was dismay. 
 "I'm heartbroken," said the writer Cynthia Ozick over the phone last week. "What does it tell us? That New York City can't support an independent bookstore?"
The reason for the closing, said Ms. Watson, is simply that business has been bad lately. The building, on Madison Avenue at 74th Street, is owned by the adjacent Whitney Museum of American Art, and Ms. Watson's lease is up. "They were not willing to lease it on terms that were economically reasonable for Books & Company," she said.
The new lease provided for a rent increase that Willard Holmes, the deputy director of the Whitney, called "a small percentage."
Mr. Holmes added, "It's unfortunate that they're not going to renew." Neither he nor Ms. Watson would say exactly what the rent was, but rents for relatively small spaces on Madison Avenue can be as high as $400,000 a year.
Books & Company was started in 1977 by Ms. Watson, the granddaughter of Thomas J. Watson, the founder of I.B.M., and her partner, Burt Britton. Since then it has been a gathering place for writers, its antique air, its smell of old books and creaking floors making it seem like a bit of London.
When she opened her store, Ms. Watson, a divorced mother of a son, was doing charity work. She had attended Sarah Lawrence College and had always loved books, so much, in fact, that her father called her "Madame-Nose-in-Books," she said.
Still, her friends and family were surprised that the wealthy young woman would want to tend store. Her father, Thomas Watson Jr. a former Ambassador to Russia, asked, "Why do you want to start a bookstore?' " Ms. Watson remembers. "I told him I want to start something no one can take away from me."
For 10 years the shop flourished. It was a place where literary fiction got the best display, not the latest best sellers. Ms. Watson called those years the Golden Age. "It was not unusual to make a $2,000 sale to one person," she said. "People had a tremendous amount of money. They would buy expensive art books."
Through its reading series, the bookstore introduced young writers, among them Amy Hempel, Susan Cheever, Steven Millhauser and Edwidge Danticat. Harold Brodkey met his wife, the novelist Ellen Schwamm, there and called Books & Company "symphonically important to me."
The poet James Merrill even wrote a poem about the store for its 10th anniversary:
Ten years of browsing, and the shelves
Mysteriously grow more packed
Full of reflection, silver-backed . . .
Looking for books, we find ourselves.
During those years, Ms. Watson met and married her second husband, Alex Sanger, grandson of Margaret Sanger and president of Planned Parenthood of New York City. They had two sons.
But the last decade has not been kind to Books & Company. Real estate values have driven many aspiring writers out of the neighborhood. The superstores have come along, offering big discounts. And now there's competition on the Internet. "You give your credit card number," Ms. Watson said in describing Amazon.com, an Internet bookstore, "and the book comes in two days."
Ms. Watson resisted change. "We stayed old-fashioned," she said. She never put in a computer. When customers called to request a book, she would dash around the store looking for it while the customer waited on the line. To increase business, she did start a personal delivery service, to anywhere in the city.
For the last five years, said Ms. Watson, she has been putting some of her inheritance into the place. "But a bookstore should not be a charity," she said. "It should be a business. I give money to charity." Sales picked up at Christmas, she said, but it wasn't enough.
Last year she started a publishing venture with Jonathan Rabinowitz of Turtle Point Press in Purchase, N.Y. The first book was a reprint of Hannah Green's "Dead of the House," a coming-of-age novel that the author, who died last year, had painstakingly worked on for years. "Just a beautiful book," said Ms. Watson. "We have to keep reprinting it. We're sort of close to breaking even."
She has discovered she loves publishing: editing, "working on the book jacket," all the minutiae. And she will continue doing it after the store has closed. " In May will come "A Journey With Elsa Cloud," a travelogue about India by Leila Hadley, a descendant of James Boswell.
"This has always been my private club," Ms. Watson said of her store. "It's an amazing way of getting to know people. I like to go through my house charge customer lists: 'Oh, interesting! They're reading this! They're sending the book to the White House!' I felt this thrill of pride. My books are going all over the world. It's taught me not to judge people simply by what they do. The doormen on Madison Avenue, for instance, have an intense interest in books."
There has been talk of a final reading. "But that would be too hard," she said. "We'll have a final party, instead. We'll just invite everybody."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeannette Watson, owner of Books & Company, which is going out of business. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bonds, Ignoring Strong Reports, Are Unchanged

BYLINE: >By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in choppy trading yesterday in an abbreviated session ahead of a long holiday weekend. The market will be closed Monday for Martin Luther King Jr. Day.
The 30-year bond was unchanged at a price of 9528/32 for a yield of 6.83 percent. 
 Traders attributed whatever price gains the market managed in the short session to a strong dollar and an article in The Washington Post that asserted that senior officials of the Federal Reserve appeared unlikely to raise short-term interest rates anytime soon as a precaution against a resurgence of inflation.
The market's friendly tone was only temporarily interrupted by the Government's reports on trade and industrial production yesterday. November international trade figures showed little change, as the deficit widened 4.9 percent, to $8.4 billion, from the $8 billion in October. That was well under expectations of the deficit's widening in November to $9.8 billion after shrinking 30 percent the month before.
Industrial production and capacity utilization in December continued to expand, as production rose eight-tenths of a percent, compared with estimates of seven-tenths of a percent, and November's number was revised lower by one-tenth of a percentage point, to an increase of eight-tenths of a percent. Capacity reached its highest level of the year in December, to 83.8 percent, up from 83.3 percent in November and higher than the 83.5 percent economists had expected. However, it is still below levels that raise fears of bottlenecks and potential inflation pressures.
Traders said the negative impact of the economic news was short-lived, as consumer confidence fell. The University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment this month fell to 96 from 96.9 in December.
Max Bublitz, president of Conseco Capital Management, Carmel, Ind., said that until the last Federal Open Market Committee meeting in December, he had expected the Fed to tighten. But, he said, it appeared to him that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had since made it clear he would not raise interest rates unless there was a sharp rise in inflationary pressures.
"The markets are ill prepared for a tightening," Mr. Bublitz said, "but they're better than they were a month ago, before Greenspan made his 'irrational exuberance' comment."

HEADLINE: A Tunnel to the Future

 BODY:
In an age when New York City seems to have given up on big building projects, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has made a smart, farsighted decision to press for construction of a $900 million rail freight tunnel between the city and New Jersey. But to succeed, the Mayor will have to build some political bridges.
New York City is economically crippled by its inability to connect to the national rail freight system, which lies just over the Hudson in New Jersey. The city's passenger train tracks do not have enough clearance for taller cargo freight cars, and the closest usable bridge for freight is almost as far north as Albany. As a result, virtually all the cargo moving into and out of the metropolitan region is carried by truck. 
 Truck transport over long distances is more expensive, both for manufacturers and consumers. There are also the indirect costs of traffic jams, air pollution and deteriorating highways and bridges. The lack of a rail freight connection also helped destroy New York's port, sending shippers across the river to Newark.
New York's deep, natural harbor is one of its greatest resources. It took a combination of civic shortsightedness, union intransigence and bad planning to allow the bulk of port business to go to New Jersey, where land was cheaper but the harbor is much shallower and difficult to navigate. Now the Newark port is not deep enough to accommodate newer, larger ships without blasting through the bedrock beneath the water at enormous expense. A recent study by the city showed that building the rail freight tunnel and rebuilding the Brooklyn harbor would be cheaper than deepening Newark's port. It also concludes that an expanded regional port involving both facilities could protect Newark's shipping business while adding more than 50,000 jobs to New York City. The city now plans to go ahead with two more studies that could make the projects eligible for partial Federal financing.
In the meantime, Mr. Giuliani has a lot of work to do. New Jersey must be convinced that the project is also in its interest. New Jersey politicians regard expansion of New York's port as a greater threat than the increasingly competitive ports elsewhere. The Mayor also needs to bring Gov. George Pataki in as a full partner. The state controls the distribution of Federal transportation aid, and there is a distinct lack of enthusiasm about the idea in Albany. The tunnel could be Mr. Pataki's crowning achievement as an environmentalist, and give credibility to his contention that he is as concerned about the future of New York City as he is about his own suburban and rural base.
The Mayor has demonstrated that he is capable of working in a bipartisan, cooperative manner. He embraced the rail freight idea even though it is the brainchild of Representative Jerrold Nadler, who has been fighting for the project for nearly 20 years. The liberal Mr. Nadler demonstrated how productive such alliances can be when he formed an unlikely partnership with the Conservative Party's head, Michael Long, who likes the idea of those thousands of potential Brooklyn jobs.
Now Mr. Giuliani must reach out further. If this project succeeds, he and Mr. Pataki will be remembered among the city's great politician-builders.

HEADLINE: Vindication of the Mexican Bailout

 BODY:
Mexico's early repayment of loans made by the United States in 1994 puts the finishing touch on a public-policy success. President Clinton's decision to bail out Mexico, over Congress's opposition, was politically unpopular. But with support from the Republican leaders Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole, Mr. Clinton tapped an obscure Treasury fund to lend Mexico more than $13 billion.
Loans from the United States and the International Monetary Fund helped Mexico repay foreign lenders and halt collapse of the peso. Mexicans suffered from their Government's austerity program, and wages are still falling, but the economy grew by about 4 percent last year. After the peso collapsed in the early 1980's, Mexico stagnated for the rest of the decade. 
 Mexico pledged its oil exports as collateral and adopted strict monetary and fiscal policies -- the only way foreigners could be coaxed to reinvest. The austere conditions and stiff interest charges sent other countries the message that Western bailouts would not serve as an attractive alternative to adopting responsible policies.
The United States intervened in Mexico because Mexico's economic collapse would have slashed demand for American exports and driven illegal workers across the border. Such dangers will not be easily replicated elsewhere. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence Summers, understood that United States intervention could help Mexico, thereby encouraging other developing countries undergoing market reforms. Powerful politicians criticized the bailout. To everyone's benefit, Mr. Clinton did not retreat.

HEADLINE: Moynihan Says He Plans To Run Again For the Senate

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Moving to end speculation that this will be his last term in Washington, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he had arranged a birthday fund-raising event to kick off his re-election campaign. The unusually early event -- the election is not until 2000 -- is also intended to discourage fellow Democrats from jockeying for his seat, aides said.
Senator Moynihan said his decision to run was all but final. "It means that would be my present intention," he said. 
 The Senator from New York said that in arranging a fund-raising event almost four years before the election -- a $1,000-a-head reception on March 10 at the Rainbow Room in Rockefeller Center -- he was bowing to aides who are concerned about the escalating cost of senatorial campaigns, and about Mr. Moynihan's tendency to put off raising money. The Senator spent about $6 million during his 1994 campaign, and aides said he was likely to spend close to $10 million in 2000.
The decision to schedule and draw attention to the fund-raising reception, first reported yesterday in The Forward, the English-language Jewish weekly, was clearly intended to put an end to discussion that has begun about Democrats who might run for Mr. Moynihan's seat in 2000.
There has been widespread Washington speculation, which Mr. Moynihan's aides described yesterday as unfounded, that the Senator, 69, would not run again because of his age, his health or out of frustration with finding himself a member of the Senate minority.
"I picked this up, too," Mr. Moynihan said of the speculation. "I know why: I wasn't raising money." As to his health, Mr. Moynihan described himself as fit. He said he was satisfied with his effectiveness in Washington, even with the Republicans in control of Congress.
And while Mr. Moynihan will mark his 70th birthday at the fund-raising event, he suggested that he is serving in an institution that values, rather than frowns on, older members. "Senate, senior and sentient are all related terms," he said.
There are currently 14 senators older than Mr. Moynihan. If he ran and won, he would be 79 by the end of his next term.
The speculation about Mr. Moynihan's intentions was set off when Andrew M. Cuomo was nominated by President Clinton to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. In accepting the nomination, Mr. Cuomo specifically ruled out any intention of challenging Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in 1998, and there was speculation that Mr. Cuomo would join the list of Democrats who would seek Senator Moynihan's seat.
Mr. Moynihan, though, could not resist holding out a sliver of enticement to any other Democrats hungering for his position.
"Well, yes, it means it would be my present intention," he said of running for re-election. "But I've been around long enough that surprises come along. I just heard today of a friend who has been nominated to be U.S. permanent representative in Geneva.
"Now if you offered me that job? A most beautiful house, a view on the lake, once every August the economic-social council meets, and what else you do, I don't know -- check out the restaurants?"
"No one's offered it to me yet," he said. "But try me."
