HEADLINE: Trade Gap Modestly Wider; Industrial Production Surges

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Record exports and a surge in industrial production combined late last year to propel the economy at an accelerating pace, Government figures showed today.
Led by sales of farm products, exports climbed to a new peak of $72 billion in November as the nation's trade deficit widened, but considerably less than expected, to $8.4 billion, the Commerce Department reported. 
 And American industry raised output in December by a hefty eight-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month, surpassing most forecasts, as plants operated more intensely than they had in more than a year.
Despite such momentum, which has prompted many analysts to raise their estimates of overall economic growth to a rate of 4 percent or more for the final 1996 quarter, the Federal Reserve is still not expected to see enough risk of accelerating inflation to raise short-term interest rates at its coming policy meeting in early February.
"We still anticipate the entire economy to ease in coming quarters," said Tim O'Neill, economist at the Harris Bank/Bank of Montreal, reflecting a widespread view that Fed officials have strongly indicated they share. "Factors cooling the economy should include consumer demand, residential contraction and a stronger U.S. dollar."
A higher-valued dollar, now up 10 percent on a trade-weighted basis from its lows of early 1995, tends to curb foreign sales of this country's goods and services.
The bond market took today's data in stride while stocks barreled to yet another record, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 67.73 points, to 6,833.10.
After a sharp narrowing of the American trade deficit in October -- more than one-third of it reflecting overseas deliveries of big commercial aircraft, which tend to occur in bursts -- most analysts had expected a substantial rebound in the other direction for November. But today's report showed only a modest $400 million widening of the gap between exports and imports as sales of soybeans, corn and other farm products soared.
Still, the trade deficit for last year is now certain to eclipse the $105.1 billion recorded in 1995; the 11-month total stands at $102.9 billion. This would be the fifth straight annual increase.
Although many American exporters have been able to overcome the disadvantage of a rising dollar, they suffer from the inability of weakened trading partners to buy their goods. On the other side of the equation, American consumers can afford to indulge themselves by buying foreign goods and services -- $80.4 billion in November, second only to the record $80.8 billion of May 1996.
Today's report also showed that United States deficits with both China and Japan narrowed substantially in the latest month, but analysts cautioned against drawing conclusions about trends. One reason is that the figures for individual trading partners -- unlike the aggregate numbers -- are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation, and goods for the holiday shopping season were mostly brought here before November.
The gap with China, which last year briefly surpassed that with Japan, narrowed to $3 billion from $4.9 billion, about two-thirds of this from lower imports and one-third from higher exports to China.
John Park, economist at Sanwa Securities in New York, called the big decline with China "a one-time blip."
With Japan, the gap shrank to $4.3 billion from $5 billion as imports fell about twice as much as exports.
The monthly figures for China and Japan do not yet include services, on which the United States runs a substantial surplus.
The American deficit with Western Europe narrowed $400 million in November while expanding that amount with Mexico, the report also showed. The deficit with Canada shrank by $500 million but this result was again muddied by the strike there at General Motors, which ships huge amounts of parts and vehicles across the border.
The Federal Reserve's report on industrial production for December showed sharp advances in output of business equipment and consumer goods and materials, excluding energy, with the production index of 129.1 standing 5.1 percent higher than in December 1995.
And had it not been for exceptionally mild weather last month, which caused a 3.3 percent slump in utility output, industrial production would have risen 1.1 percent instead of the reported eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Manufacturing rose 1.1 percent last month after an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in November while the nation's mines had a 1.2 percent gain, twice that of November.
The Fed's report also showed that use of industrial capacity increased four-tenths of a point in December, to 83.8 percent, the highest level since August 1995.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Expansion May Cause Teams to Trade Leagues

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 17

 BODY:
Like kids trading baseball cards, the National and American Leagues may soon trade teams -- Houston for Kansas City, for example, or maybe Montreal for Tampa Bay.
Those swaps were two of the early possibilities raised today on the outcome of the study by baseball's realignment and expansion committee that owners and officials believe will lead to a geographical shuffling of teams between leagues. Expansion by two more teams to 32 was also viewed as a likely development. 
"I'm not a big proponent of expansion, but I think at some point there will be expansion," Tom Schieffer, president of the Texas Rangers, said today.
The Rangers were one of the clubs whose opposition to the placement of the Arizona Diamondbacks in the National League helped prompt the realignment study. Schieffer hopes the study leads to a change that would put the Rangers and the Astros in the same league.
"We would prefer Houston move to the American League, but that's something we all should be open-minded on," Schieffer said by telephone from Arlington, Tex. "I hope this discussion will lead to teams considering changing leagues if it enhances a regional rivalry."
The Rangers, Schieffer noted, do not have a regional rival in the American League. And, worse, playing in the A.L. West with three teams in the Pacific time zone creates difficulties for the team.
"If you had Houston and Texas playing in the same league, you'd have an intrastate rivalry that would be good for baseball," the Rangers' executive said. "The people in the Dallas-Fort Worth area think the people in Houston are competitors. We would have been much better served years ago if we had been in the same league."
Based on the Rangers' experience, Schieffer said he believed the Florida Marlins and the new Tampa Bay Devil Rays would fare better economically if they played in the same league.
"That was my advice to the people in Florida," he said.
Vincent Naimoli, the Devil Rays' managing partner, said Thursday that he liked being in the American League because his team will be the only A.L. team in the Southeast. But a natural geographical alignment would have the Devil Rays, Florida and Atlanta in the same division. Then if Charlotte, N.C., gets an expansion team, it could form one of four divisions in a 16-team league.
If the Devil Rays were to switch leagues after their first two years, Montreal could replace them in the A.L. and form a natural rivalry with the Toronto Blue Jays, Canada's other team.
Drayton McLane Jr., the Astros' owner, did not return a telephone call seeking his views on changing leagues, but Schieffer said he believed McLane had "pretty much the same feeling" about the Rangers and the Astros being in the same league.
"I think Kansas City might look favorably on something like that, where they could play St. Louis all the time," Schieffer said. "There's such a logic to geographic realignment. These time zones have much greater effect than people think. If you can get it lined up right, it could have a tremendously beneficial effect on the game."
David Glass, chairman of the Royals, did not return a call seeking his views, but a person who attended Thursday's meeting said that Glass had discussed the possibility of moving to the National League.
Glass had been opposed to moving to the A.L. West in 1998, a move that was considered a possibility in conjunction with Tampa Bay's joining the A.L. East. But in an effort to avoid further conflict, Tampa Bay is headed to the West for two years.
George Steinbrenner of the Yankees took advantage of the change in Tampa Bay's placement by swapping two series of interleague games with the Devil Rays in 1998. The changes must still be approved, but the Yankees would play Los Angeles and San Francisco and give the Devil Rays their games with the Marlins and the Braves.
When interleague play begins this year, teams in the corresponding divisions will play each other.
After meeting Thursday, the owners discussed keeping the same interleague matchups for 1997 and 1998 instead of switching to other division pairings. That plan would enable the Mets and the Yankees, for example, to play at Shea Stadium in 1998 after playing at Yankee Stadium in 1997.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Trade Deficit Up Slightly As Exports Reach Record
Record exports and a surge in industrial production combined late last year to propel the economy at an accelerating pace. Led by sales of farm products, exports climbed to a peak of $72 billion in November as the nation's trade deficit widened, but considerably less than expected, to $8.4 billion, the Commerce Department reported.
The report also showed that United States deficits with both China and Japan narrowed substantially in the latest month. The gap with China, which last year briefly surpassed that with Japan, narrowed to $3 billion from $4.9 billion. [Page 37.]

Court to Hear Insider Trading Case
Urged by the Federal Government to close a "large loophole" in the prosecution of securities fraud, the Supreme Court agreed to review a lower court's decision that cut back sharply on the Securities and Exchange Commission's approach to illegal insider trading. The case may produce one of the most important Supreme Court decisions in years on a question of securities law. [37].
 
New Price for AT&T-Loral Deal
The $712.5 million deal by Loral Space and Communications to purchase AT&T's Skynet Satellite Services will be repriced, after the disclosure by AT&T that one of its telecommunications satellites had been declared permanently out of service. [36.]

Gas Producer May Sell Field
The TransTexas Gas Corporation, a major natural gas producer, is close to an agreement to sell one of its largest and most productive natural gas fields to Conoco for about $1.2 billion, people close to the transaction said. A purchase by Conoco would be unusual because major oil companies have been selling some of their large domestic oil and gas fields in recent years as they shift their investment and exploration efforts overseas. [36.]

Market Continues Its Record Ways
Propelled by strong earnings reports, the stock market continued its January rally. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 67.73 points, or 1 percent, to close at 6,833.10, its eighth record this year, and a 6 percent gain since Dec. 31. Pacing the advance were: Du Pont, up 2 7/8 points, to 111 5/8; McDonald's, up 1 7/8, to 46 3/8, and Merck, up 1 7/8, to 86 3/8. Broader measures were also up, although not as strongly as the Dow. The S.& P. 500 rose 6.42 points, to 776.17, and the Nasdaq composite 8.59 points, to 1,349.05. [37.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities changed little in choppy trading ahead of a long holiday weekend. The yield on the 30-year bond held steady at 6.83 percent. [48.]
 
Dayton Hudson Paring Mervyn's
Dayton Hudson said that its Mervyn's division was pulling out of Florida and Georgia and that it would close 10 other stores as part of its effort to turn that division around. As a result of the moves and of previously announced plans to close five Marshall Field's stores in Texas and Illinois, it will take a pretax charge of $134 million against earnings. [36.]
 
Amre Plans Bankruptcy Filing
Faced with mounting losses, Amre Inc., a home improvement and remodeling company that licenses the Century 21 name from HFS Inc., said that it would file for bankruptcy protection and sell assets to repay creditors. In September, Amre successfully completed a public offering of 1.6 million shares at a price of $16 a share; the stock was last quoted on Thursday at 43.75 cents a share. [36.]
 
Equity REIT to Buy Wellsford
Equity Residential Properties Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Chicago and controlled by Sam Zell, said that it would buy Wellsford Residential Property Trust for $620 million in stock. The deal solidifies its position as the nation's largest apartment owner, with 317 complexes comprising 90,873 units -- about double its nearest competitor, Security Capital Pacific Trust. [36.]
 
Dollar Rises Against Mark and Yen
The dollar reached its highest level in two and a half years against the mark and Swiss franc in a rally powered by better-than-expected United States trade data and by hints of lower German interest rates from two top Bundesbank officials. The dollar also rose to a 45-month high against the yen, helped by more signs of economic anemia in Japan. [38.]

HEADLINE: Stores Gear Up for Week of Tax Relief

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Today is Day 1 of a weeklong experiment in which most clothing costing less than $500 will be free of sales tax in much of New York State, and retailers have reprogrammed cash registers and beefed up sales forces, hoping to serve throngs of bargain hunters.
Most of the confusion among many retailers earlier in the week over exactly what articles were tax-exempt seemed to have cleared up by yesterday. The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance held seminars all week with local Chambers of Commerce and distributed an encyclopedic list of the tax-free categories. Among the finer distinctions: nylons, chef uniforms, ski masks and clerical vestments are tax exempt, but riding boots, bobby pins and watch bands are not. 
 "We're continuing to get the word out to vendors and consumers about what is and isn't taxable," said Kevin C. Quinn, a department spokesman.
All but 8 of New York's 62 counties have agreed to participate in the tax-free week, ending Jan. 24, by waiving their local sales taxes on clothing in addition to the state's tax break. In New York City, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has tirelessly promoted this week as a possible prelude to permanent sales tax relief, consumers will save 8.25 percent -- 4 percent from the state, 4 percent from the city, and one-quarter of 1 percent levied by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
"We're pretty optimistic about the week," said Jack Delargy, vice president and general manager of the Brooks Brothers store on Madison Avenue at 44th Street. "We have bolstered up our staffing of sales associates and managers."
Beverly Butler, a spokeswoman for Gap Inc., the retail giant that owns Banana Republic, the Gap and Old Navy stores, said, "We think there may be a pent-up demand because it's been publicized that the sales tax will be repealed, so we're going to increase our sales staff by 10 to 20 percent."
Many stores in New Jersey -- where clothing is not taxed -- are in the midst of their post-holiday clearance sales anyway. But at least one mall, Newport Center in Jersey City, said it had rescheduled a sale to compete with New York's sales-tax holiday. "Usually we hold our winter sidewalk sale the first weekend of January," said Sarah Liddle, the mall's marketing director. "But when I got wind of what was going on with the New York tax abatement, I decided to plan it for this weekend."
Newport Center, which is just opposite a PATH train stop, draws 25 percent of its customers from New York City. Like other retailers in New Jersey that are frequented by cost-conscious New Yorkers, the mall is keeping a wary eye on New York's consideration of repealing sales taxes on clothing. "If the repeal is extended," Ms. Liddle said, "it would have a big impact in the beginning, but people are still going to want to come over here and shop in a climate-controlled environment."
The plan for a week of tax abeyance was approved by the State Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki last summer as part of a budget package. Local retailers have complained for years that they were losing business to New Jersey and surrounding states, where clothing is not taxed.
State and local governments plan to study the results of the tax-free week to gauge the wisdom of making a permanent cut in the retail sales tax. But some economists and retailers have questioned the usefulness of a one-shot shopping spree, arguing that bitter temperatures and advance news media coverage could skew the outcome.
"It's an unfair test," said Marcia Wilson, a vice president of Daffy's, a discount apparel chain with stores in New York and New Jersey. "If I wanted to spend a lot of money advertising a sale in my stores, I guarantee I could drive up sales."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stores like this one on Broadway in lower Manhattan hope to reap profits in a week without sales tax, which begins today. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hot Garden Rivalry: Battle for Tickets

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Forget about the Knicks versus the Bulls. Forget about the Rangers versus the Islanders. The hottest Madison Square Garden clash of the winter season took place yesterday in State Supreme Court. And when the smoke cleared, the outcome was still in question.
At stake is not a trophy or a playoff berth but the rights to some $86,000 worth of season tickets, covering a block of eight seats at mid-ice or midcourt for each Rangers and Knicks home game. 
 Swirling in the pool of bad blood between the combatants are allegations of revenge and blackmail, the defeat of an infant's birthright, the denial of charity, the specter of insult to the Archbishop of Newark and the presence of celebrities like Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins.
In one corner in this battle are Dennis Riese and the Riese Organization, better known as operators of food outlets like Nathan's, Pizza Hut, Kentucky Fried Chicken, TGI Friday's and Houlihan's, as well as restaurants like Charlie O's, Beefsteak Charlie's, Martini's and the Java Shop.
In the other corner are Madison Square Garden (home to the Rangers and Knicks) and the Garden's president, David W. Checketts, known to the better-spoken sports aficionados as Dave.
In the black robes, refereeing yesterday's contest was Elliot Wilk, State Supreme Court Justice.
According to court papers, the Garden and Mr. Checketts revoked the Riese season ticket subscriptions that date back some 30 years "in a mean-spirited pique" after deciding that the Riese Organization failed to move quickly enough to conclude a real estate deal proposed by the Garden and involving the lease on Riese's Beefsteak Charlie's restaurant in the Seventh Avenue arcade leading into the arena.
"I was completely stunned," Mr. Riese, president and chief executive of the Riese Organization, said as he recalled the Jan. 2 letter that informed him of the cancellations. "It was like a punch in the gut."
Applying to the court for injunctive relief and damages, Larry Hutcher of Davidoff & Malito, the lawyer for the Riese interests, used language like "economic revenge" and "blackmail" to describe the motives underlying revocation of the subscriptions, which were described as "irreplaceable."
In reply, Ken Munoz, executive vice president and general counsel for Madison Square Garden, said: "Well, that's just not accurate. The law is very clear. We have the right at any time or for any reason to revoke a season subscription. There are many cases in New York that have so held."
Mr. Munoz also disputed a Riese contention that the Garden had refused to allow the corporation to continue to advertise in the Garden and on the MSG cable network after it had spent more than $1 million from 1994 to 1996. Mr. Munoz said Mr. Riese "unilaterally terminated that on us."
He said, "We have had an acrimonious business relationship with the Riese Organization." And he said that in the past, the Garden had revoked season subscriptions "when we decided not to have any further business relationship with that company."
The court papers said that the Riese tickets were used for purposes of business and goodwill -- given to employees and customers, donated to charities for use in raffles, made available to people like the Archbishop of Newark and used for family purposes.
Mr. Riese, who is 43, said he had looked forward to sharing a Ranger game with his son, Samuel, now 6 months old. But, he said, "MSG, for perverted reasons, now seeks to deprive me of this pleasure both as a fan and a father."
On the evening of Jan. 8, Mr. Riese contended in his court papers, four people who intended to use their tickets were removed from their seats by security guards and escorted from the building, and the Garden used the tickets "to curry favor with their celebrity clientele by giving them to Susan Sarandon, the Oscar-winning actress and her husband actor/director Tim Robbins."
On Jan. 10, in the first courtroom skirmish, Justice Lorraine S. Miller awarded Mr. Riese and the Riese Organization a temporary restraining order, which prevents the Garden from interfering with the Rieses' right to use their tickets. When the parties faced off at 2 P.M. yesterday before Justice Wilk, he vacated that restraining order, pending a hearing on Tuesday, when the argument will resume over the Riese request for a permanent injunction against the Garden and unspecified damages.

HEADLINE: Consuming Passions

BYLINE: By Andrew Delbanco; Andrew Delbanco is the author of "The Death of Satan: How Americans Have Lost the Sense of Evil" and a forthcoming book on classic American writers.

 BODY:

WOMEN AND THE COMMON LIFE
 Love, Marriage, and Feminism.
 By Christopher Lasch.
 Edited by Elisabeth Lasch-Quinn.
 196 pp. New York:
 W.W. Norton & Company. $23. 
 When Christopher Lasch died three years ago at the age of 61, he left behind a body of work as likely to endure as that of any postwar American intellectual. According to many who knew him, he was a courteous and gentle man; but for those, including me, who knew him only through his books, his writing conveys a feeling of controlled outrage, as if he were working hard to convert indignation into argument.
Lasch, who was a professor of history at the University of Rochester at the time of his death, was angry about the condition of American society. In his provocative book "The True and Only Heaven: Progress and Its Critics" (1991), a study of how the Enlightenment ideal of progress has been perverted into a frantic consumer culture based on the ceaseless "transformation of luxuries into necessities," he describes contemporary America with a phrase that nicely declines to distinguish between greed and lust: we are, he writes, a culture obsessed with "the pornography of 'making it.' "
In a personal introduction to the same book, Laschallowed himself the ironic remark that the "one unambiguous success" he and his wife could claim in raising their children in this unappeasable consumer culture was their "failure to educate them for success." One of these children, Elisabeth Lasch-Quinn, succeeded in becoming a professor of history at Syracuse University, and she has now assembled her father's last essays into a book entitled "Women and the Common Life: Love, Marriage, and Feminism." Along with a touching memoir by Ms. Lasch-Quinn of her father's last weeks, the new book comprises nine essays whose topics range from medieval romance to Robert Bly and the "men's movement."
"Women and the Common Life" is vintage Lasch. It continues his assault on the culture of consumption, and extends it to feminist and academic critics who claim to stand outside and above it. It carries forward his lifelong theme that each generation must provide for its children not chiefly in the material sense but in the sense of bequeathing to them a structure of thought and feeling through which a meaningful life may be achieved. As long ago as "The New Radicalism in America, 1889-1963" (1965), Lasch concluded that "at the end of the 19th century, middle-class parents found themselves unable any longer to explain to their children why their way of life was important or desirable." Thirty years later, in an essay in "Women and the Common Life" on the spiritual deprivations of suburban life, he returns to the same theme: "how to revive a sense of vocation in a society destitute of any sense of common purpose."
"Revive" is a key word for Lasch, who writes, perhaps more than he realized, in the religious tradition of calling a backsliding people to return to its abandoned ideals. One of the refreshments of reading him is that he states his beliefs outright, rather than wrapping them in putatively objective historical arguments -- as when he remarks (in an essay in "Women and the Common Life" on romantic love) that it is "heartbreaking" that "lifelong marriage no longer serves as the standard to which erotic practice ought to aspire," or when, in "The Revolt of the Elites" (1994), he declares that "luxury is morally repugnant."
Lasch knew that such pronouncements would be greeted by howls of post-modern derision: Whose standards? Whose morals? Why prefer self-denial to self-indulgence? What entitles anyone to imagine that one's disgust is more than a local or contingent response to an alien value? Isn't the very vocabulary with which we discuss these matters -- using words such as "dissipation" and "discipline" -- proof that the etymology of our moral terms leads back through an endless chain of conventions to . . . nowhere? These are the sorts of hectoring questions one hears in the background of Lasch's work, and to which he writes in fervent response.
In "Women and the Common Life," the ideal world whose virtue has been lost to the fashion of relativism is best expressed through the symbol and actual practice of marriage. The kind of marriage Lasch has in mind is not the old "dynastic" institution that preserved wealth within the confines of the propertied gentry and was therefore threatened when sexual attraction erupted between members of distinct classes. He has in mind a different, essentially middle-class ideal of marriage, more erotic than contractual, which he traces from its appearance in the Middle Ages, through the 18th century with its political debates about what constitutes legitimate marital union, and into our own time.
In defending this "union of desire and esteem," Lasch reveals himself as a true puritan -- not in the pejorative sense of being prudish, but in the sense of believing that good societies (on the small scale of families and the large scale of political communities) can be sustained only if desire is sanctified by respect. This is why the New England Puritans (to whom Lasch grew increasingly sympathetic as he grew older) thought of marriage as a "miniature commonwealth," a model for human relations in which appetite and obligations are held in delicate balance. Lasch agrees, which is why he may be fairly described as an economic liberal and a cultural conservative -- a liberal whothinks that humane societies must curb excesses of wealth and poverty, a conservative who thinks that individual members of such societies should be held accountable to a standard of personal responsibility.
In Lasch's view, the structures that have fostered this kind of moral equipoise in the past -- political institutions, civic and charitable organizations, and especially families -- are today in chronic crisis, and nothing much has arisen in their place. Unlike neoconservatives, who seem to imagine that the so-called traditional family has somehow always existed, he locates its invention in the 19th-century "cult of domesticity." But he differs just as sharply from historians on the left who regard its invention as a scheme for suppressing the aspirations of women. For Lasch, the new family -- with its companionate marriage ideal, its premium on maternal nurture and its complement in the public sphere of women's leadership in reform and charity -- was a "liberal solution to the problems of industrial society."
Whatever one thinks of this historical account, it seems beyond dispute that in our postindustrial era the traditional family is under assault -- by poverty and illegitimacy in what is often termed the underclass, by the imperative of two wage-earning parents and the disappearance of domestic servants in the middle class, and by divorce and the rise in respectability of extramarital sex and homosexuality across the classes. Since Lasch believes that the threatened family has been the chief means of imparting such values as love, realism, obligation and trust, he suspects that we are losing our best means of resistance to the contrary values of the marketplace. (It would have been interesting to have his response to the movement for gay marriage that has accelerated since his death.) We are ruled, he thinks, by an "increasingly narrow identification of the American dream with the American standard of living," and since for much of the middle class that standard is no longer rising, a spiritual crisis has seized us.
One comes away from Lasch's last work with disturbing questions. What resources can Americans call upon to deal with their reluctant discovery that "progress" -- understood solely as material acquisition -- is slowing down and will perhaps even be reversed? What ideals do we have left besides the rule of the marketplace, the thrill of power and the "sharp, small, immediate and more or less interchangeable pleasures" of sex? These are among the questions with which "Women and the Common Life" interrogates feminism, which Lasch fears has been infected by the spirit of the marketplace. "The feminist movement," as he puts it, "far from civilizing corporate capitalism, has been corrupted by it. It has adopted mercantile habits of thought as its own." He doubts that the prospect of upward mobility alone is enough to confer meaning on the lives of women any more than on the lives of men.

HEADLINE: Take My Job, Please

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his review of my book "Kellogg's Six-Hour Day" (Dec. 22), Michael Kazin objects that my explanations for the death of shorter hours in Battle Creek, Mich., fall short because "many . . . workers tolerate long hours when their jobs are challenging, dramatic or essential to helping people they know and like." Sounding for all the world like a business management textbook writer from the 1950's, Mr. Kazin concludes with a utopian fantasy that has long befuddled historians and sociologists: "Automation can, over time, eliminate the most tedious occupations." 
 I most certainly did not ignore this development. To the contrary, I spent two of the book's nine chapters detailing the rise of the very rhetoric Mr. Kazin employs. I argued that in order to counter shortening work hours, a process that had been going on steadily for over a century, managers, industrial leaders, senior male workers and sympathetic academics fashioned a rhetorical foundation for industrial work discipline. This new, word-based work discipline included the promise of "good jobs" (Mr. Kazin's wonderful, "challenging" jobs) and emerged over the last 50 years to combat successfully the threat of increasing leisure, stanching the hemorrhage of time flowing out of the economy.
Once I shared Mr. Kazin's fantasy that a "good" job is a realistic expectation for most people. But on my first visit to Battle Creek, one of the women workers glared at me over half-spectacles and said: "Sure, everybody wants a Prince Charming job. But the jobs I know about, and that the people I know are likely to get, are mostly a pain in the butt. Everybody but a complete idiot or a college professor who has never hit a lick of work in their lives looks forward to quitting time, and the sooner it comes the better. Why do I even have to tell you that time off is way better than having to work?"
 
Benjamin Hunnicutt
Iowa City

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAN 

 BODY:

 Holy Land
 A Suburban Memoir.
 By D. J. Waldie.
 Norton, $24. 
 Placelessness has been a favorite conceit of writers on the postwar suburbs almost since their beginning. D. J. Waldie grew up in Lakewood, Calif., a West Coast Levittown rolled out near Los Angeles in the early 1950's "on fields cut to stubble only hours before construction began." What is unusual about Mr. Waldie, and what gives his book, "Holy Land," its uncanny force, is that he still lives there, in the house where his father died; he also happens to work there, as a Lakewood city official. Mr. Waldie is much too close to Lakewood to sentimentalize it and far too deeply rooted there to buy into any glib notions of its placelessness. He has written a quirky, multidimensional portrait of Lakewood in the form of a mosaic: "Holy Land" is constructed of 316 sharp and often weirdly elliptical chapters, some as short as a sentence, none longer than a page. What Mr. Waldie is up to is overlaying a sequence of different perceptual maps on his hometown: he lets us see it by turns through the grids of history, memoir, journalism, geology, politics, economics and anecdote. And by the end of this short, fascinating book, he has presented Lakewood with a history as rich and various -- as storied -- as the most ancient of cities. Michael Pollan

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Fort Lauderdale

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO; MIREYA NAVARRO is chief of the Miami bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
With its reputation as a spring-break capital long behind it, Fort Lauderdale -- along with its neighboring beach towns -- is working hard to become known as a destination for grown-ups who cherish good food, shopping bargains and a taste of Americana. While Miami, just 25 miles to the south, offers Cuban food and salsa music, the 28 municipalities known as Greater Fort Lauderdale boast cowboys, a flea market with drive-in movies, and a circus.
But Fort Lauderdale is also competing for the tourist dollar on sophistication and comfort. There is top-notch dining among its more than 2,500 restaurants. The airport is receiving nearly $1 billion worth of new terminals, gates and refurbishing, and is already attracting South Floridians fleeing the congestion of its counterpart in Miami. 
 The beach and warm weather, of course, are the primary draw in the winter. But to lure more international visitors, another $1 billion in public and private money has been earmarked for new attractions over the next five years, including an entertainment and retail complex and an aquarium, both in downtown Fort Lauderdale and scheduled for completion in 1998.
 
 
 
Events
 At Las Olas Art Fair, on Las Olas Boulevard in Fort Lauderdale,on Feb. 1 and 2 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., more than 250 artists will show their paintings, sculptures and pottery, and restaurants will serve food from booths during a popular event that also includes live music. For information, call (954) 472-3755. Free.
Native American dancing, food and crafts will be on display at the Seminole Tribal Festival, Stirling Road and Highway 441 in Hollywood, from Feb. 6 to 9. Wildlife attractions include deep-water alligator wrestling, a snake show and an exhibit on the Florida panther. Admission is $10, $5 for children; hours are 9 A.M. to 8 P.M. on Feb. 6 and 7, 9 AM. to 11 P.M. Feb. 8, and noon to 6 P.M. Feb. 9. Call (954) 967-3434.
The largest rodeo east of the Mississippi takes place at the Florida Westfair in the Davie Arena, 6501 Orange Drive in Davie, Feb. 21 to March 2. Visitors can play ball with members of professional sports teams like the Florida Marlins baseball club, and amusement rides, arts and crafts, country Western music and a classic car show are also featured. Open 5 P.M. to 11 P.M. Monday through Friday, and 10 A.M. to 11 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Admission is $4, $2 for children under 12, but rodeos, concerts and truck shows cost extra. Call (954) 537-1010.
Afro-Caribbean culture is spotlighted at the Sistrunk Historical Festival on Feb. 1, at Sistrunk Boulevard from Northwest 7th Street to Northwest 15th Avenue in Fort Lauderdale; (954) 357-7348, with bands, dancers and food from Jamaica, the Bahamas and Trinidad. From 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free admission.
Part of the Salvador Dali collection in St. Petersburg has traveled across Florida for an exhibition at the Museum of Art, 1 East Las Olas Boulevard in Fort Lauderdale, (954) 525-5500, from Friday through April 6. The show includes 30 paintings, plus prints, gouaches, drawings, and bronze and glass sculptures dating from Dali's teen-age years through the 1970's. Open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Friday till 8, and Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. Admission is $6, $1 for children 5 to 18.
 
 
 
Sightseeing
 Riverwalk, which winds for a mile and a half along the New River, links restaurants, shops and other attractions in downtown Fort Lauderdale. A pleasant stroll leads you past tropical flora, yachts and gazebos, and attractions such as the the Museum of Art. There is free outdoor jazz on Feb. 2 and March 2 near the Broward Center for the Performing Arts.
Near the Riverwalk is a prime stop for children, the Museum of Discovery and Science at 401 Southwest Second Street, (954) 467-6637, with interactive exhibits and the Blockbuster Imax 3-D Theater. Through April 4 the theater is showing "Across the Sea of Time," the story of a boy who goes back to Ellis Island in 1904, when his Russian ancestors immigrated to the United States. Open Monday through Saturday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday noon to 6 P.M. Combination admission to the museum and theater is $12.50, $10.50 for children.
Not all the attractions bowl you over with cutting-edge technology. About five miles north of Fort Lauderdale is Butterfly World, 3600 West Sample Road in Coconut Creek, (954) 977-4400, where the aviary and gardens are aflutter with beautifully colored butterflies. (Butterfly World is part of Tradewinds Park, which offers horseback riding, canoe rentals and miniature golf.) Open Monday through Saturday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. (last admission at 4 P.M.). Admission is $10.95, $6 for children 4 to 12.
South Florida's marshlands are worth a trip inland. Airboat rides through the sawgrass, past alligators and other wildlife, are a half-hour's drive away, at Everglades Holiday Park, 21940 Griffin Road; (954) 434-8111, (800) 226-2244 for reservations. Rides are offered from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily at $12.50 a person, $6.25 for children.
Further inland is Kissimmee Billie Swamp Safari at the Seminole tribe's Big Cypress Reservation (800) 949-6101, which offers canoe rides for $10 an hour per two-person canoe, and safari packages, including a two-hour tour of the wetlands, an airboat ride and lunch, for $46, $30 for children 6 to 12, free for those younger.
For fans of the Flintstones, Garfield and Batman, the International Museum of Cartoon Art at 201 Plaza Real in Boca Raton, (561) 391-2200, houses collections of caricatures, editorial cartoons, comic books and videos. Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 6 P.M. Sunday. Admission: $4, $2 for students and children 6 to 12.
 
 
 
Where to Stay
 The Bahia Cabana Beach Resort, 3001 Harbor Drive, (954) 524-1555, fax (954) 764-5951, is a cabana-style hideaway with 99 rooms distributed among five mostly two-story buildings. The central building has a bar and grill overlooking the marina that is popular for cheap, laid-back dining or a cold drink during a beach break. There are three pools and a huge Jacuzzi. Rooms are equipped with refrigerators. Standard double: $120.
The Best Western Oceanside Inn, at 1180 Seabreeze Boulevard, (954) 525-8115, fax (954) 527-0967, is a 101-room bed and breakfast on Fort Lauderdale Beach. Refrigerators, cribs and laundry machines are available. A double room, including a full buffet breakfast, costs $109.
Budget: On a long strip of small lodgings is Banyan Marina Apartments, 111 Isle of Venice, (954) 524-4430, fax (954) 764-4870. This two-story lodging has 10 eclectically furnished rooms and a pool on a waterway, with the beach about half a mile away, across a drawbridge. Double rooms with kitchenettes start at $130. Children under 6 stay free.
A block away from Fort Lauderdale Beach is La Casa del Mar Bed and Breakfast, 3003 Granada Street; (800) 739-0009, fax (954) 467-7439. This 10-unit Spanish-style lodging has double rooms ranging from $100 to $135, including breakfast and wine and cheese beside the pool in the afternoon.
Luxury: In the middle of Fort Lauderdale's trendy commercial strip is the Riverside Hotel, at 620 East Las Olas Boulevard, (954) 467-0671, fax (954) 462-2148, a charming, Old World 109-room hotel built in the 1930's. Afternoon tea is served in the lobby and the renovated rooms are furnished with the original oak furniture. Doubles from $159 to $229.
The beach beckons just a catwalk away at the Radisson Bahia Mar Beach Resort, 801 Seabreeze Boulevard, (954) 764-2233, fax (954) 524-6912. This 300-room hotel with a tropical feel has amenities ranging from tennis courts and a fitness center to shops on the property. The Jungle Queen dinner cruise ship anchors outside. Double rooms, decorated in Art Deco and neo-Classical style, range from $189 to $209.
 
 
 
Where to Eat
 Zan Z Bar, 602 East Las Olas Boulevard, Fort Lauderdale, (954) 767-3377, specializes in South African food and wines. The Taste of South Africa ($18.95 for two) is a good introduction to the sausages, cured beef strips and ostrich tips that appear as entrees on the menu. Try Boerewors and Pap -- grilled beef sausages served with thick cornmeal "pap" topped with a tomato-onion gravy ($14.95). Worth trying for dessert is the milk tart, a traditional South African cinnamon-dusted custard in a light pie crust ($4.95) that gives the flan some serious competition. Dinner for two with wine comes to about $95.
Mark's Las Olas, 1032 East Las Olas Boulevard, (954) 463-1000, serves creative fare combining Floridian, Caribbean and Italian touches in a stunning contemporary setting. The basket of assorted breads alone qualifies as an appetizer; among the official ones are a sublime Napoleon of sweet plantains with Cuban braised pork and chimichurri sauce ($10). The white duck with mango-honey glaze, charcoaled vegetables and sweet potato-vanilla bean puree ($21) and the yellowtail snapper with toasted garlic, lime juice, pumpkin-scented rice and conch fritters ($25) are fine entree choices. Dinner for two with wine comes to about $120.
Casablanca Cafe, 3049 Alhambra Street, (954) 764-3500, offers international cuisine in an elegant former private home with a terrace overlooking the beach. Starters include quesadillas (seafood $8.95, chicken $7.95). Among the entrees, the Steak Havana with black beans, rice and crispy plantains is grilled to taste ($12.95) There is a Brazilian seafood stew in a spicy coconut-milk saffron tomato broth served over rice for $16.95. Salads, sandwiches, pizzas and pasta are under $10. Dinner for two with wine costs about $55.
Cafe Europa at 726 East Las Olas Boulevard, (954) 763-6600, is a popular eatery ideal for a late snack and people-watching from its outdoor tables. It serves pizza, calzone, sandwiches and heavier specials like spinach lasagna for under $10.
 
 
 
Shopping
 One of South Florida's biggest tourist draws is Sawgrass Mills, 12801 West Sunrise Boulevard at Flamingo Road, Sunrise, (954) 846-2350. Its more than 270 discount stores, billed as the world's largest outlet mall, range from Saks Fifth Avenue, Mikasa and Barneys to $1 stores. Open Monday to Saturday from 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M., Sunday 11 to 8.
After visiting the Dali exhibition at the art museum, you may be ready for a surrealistic shopping experience at the Swap Shop, 3291 West Sunrise Boulevard in Fort Lauderdale, (954) 791-7927. a huge (88-acre) and messy flea market with indoor and outdoor kiosks selling just about everything imaginable. It also offers a circus show with elephants; carousel, Ferris wheel, and train rides; a farmer's market; and a video arcade. Open Monday through Wednesday 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M., Thursday and Friday 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., Saturday and Sunday to 6:30.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
O Glorious France! (Born In the U.S.A.)

BYLINE: By Bernard Holland 

 BODY:
AMERICANS. HANG YOUR HEADS. France is not pleased with you. It is not enough that your State Department fails to treat her as a mighty diplomatic power; now you persist in fiddling with her culture. Careful, lest you and your British colleagues find yourselves relegated to the wrong side of the French border, wistful outsiders looking in at the musical glory that is modern France.
Yes, Bruce Springsteen and the Who do seem vile next to that Gallic giant of rock-and-roll, Johnny Halliday. Duke Ellington fades in comparison with Michel Legrand. Begone Tina Turner and McDonald's. French sensibility has no need of you. (I say this last with some puzzlement after watching a hundred of France's young elite struggle desperately to purchase Big Macs on the Rue de Rennes last October.) 
 The world watches in awe as the French Ministry of Culture legislates quotas for imported television programs and plays neological catch-up in its attempt to replace omnipresent English terms with French equivalents. One wishes these rear-guard actions against impurity well, but will "gros porteur" ever really replace "jumbo jet"?
But France. Take care whom you reject. With all of us English-speakers gone, who is going to put on your operas and play your music? Think on Germany's postwar Economic Miracle: What would have happened if, in the middle of it, that vast imported Turkish work force had suddenly been sent home. In music, that crisis is multiplied, for not only have the Americans and English dug the ditches; they have drawn up the plans as well.
France. You have not done a very good job with your music, but don't worry; we are there to help you. The new Paris Opera at the Bastille is by all reports a bureaucratic, political and artistic morass, but perhaps its new music director, the American James Conlon, will knock the appropriate heads together.
Rejoice, France, in the revival of Baroque opera: the re-emergence of Rameau and the careful reconsiderations of 17th- and 18th-century style that have gone with it. Whom shall we applaud for this considerable accomplishment? Who better than that great symbol of French cultural superiority, William Christie, of South Wales, N.Y., founder and director of the ensemble Les Arts Florissants?
Paris. Thanks for all the money given to the Theatre du Chatelet last October to support an extended survey of Stravinsky and France's influence on his work. Difficult to explain, however, is why it took an orchestra from California (the Los Angeles Philharmonic) to bring it off.
With the American Robert Hale as Wotan, Jeffrey Tate, an Englishman, led the first Paris "Ring" cycle in 36 years three years ago; Antonio Pappano, an American, led the recent, successful "Don Carlos." Consistently high-level orchestra concerts have come not from the Orchestre de Paris but through the regular visits of the London Philharmonia.
The evident star of the Bastille's "Cosi Fan Tutte" not long ago (again with Mr. Tate) was a Welsh mezzo-soprano named Eirian James. Paris in the 1990's has known a Richard Strauss craze, but with blessed few French singers in the major roles. (Try Maria Ewing or Karen Huffstodt as Salome instead.) Strauss aside, the distinctive French singing style, with its clear, fastidious head tones, has more or less vanished into an international one-size-fits-all school of opera singing. Mr. Christie's young Baroque performers come the closest I have heard to keeping French singing alive.
Don't look to the Paris Conservatory for help here. In Cherubini's time it may have been a great institution. In my era there, in the 1960's, it was not, offering instead a viciously competitive educational system that rewarded toughness and uniformity and crushed the weak and the different. Everyone played more or less the same, and today's paucity of important French conductors, players and singers seems to indicate that not much has changed in 30 years.
The buildings are better. France has poured millions into arts construction, and to be fair, it has done valuable and expensive work in developing its regional operatic and music centers. Yet as one Parisian commentator said not long ago in these pages, "Money can't buy the ability to create." Pierre Boulez's master classes for conductors last May at the shiny new Cite de la Musique complex in Paris attracted full houses for two days. The orchestra was from Cleveland, and by the way, the classes were in English.
The most interesting music in Paris is coming not from the so-called major institutions but from the relatively marginal Chatelet. The city has provided it money, a lot of which is going to bring in creative artists from Britain, America and elsewhere. France did better in the past. Indeed, when contemporary musical politics finally fade away, it may well dawn on the world that Debussy has been the century's greatest composer. Today, Henri Dutilleux's music gives off an elusive, tantalizing beauty that will also be more widely recognized. Along with his striking approach to composition, Mr. Boulez is approaching greatness as a conductor of the general repertory. Beyond these people and perhaps a few others, the pickings are slim.
France's correct response to American culture is not insults and condescension. Nor is it quotas. Replacing simple English terms with complicated and confused French ones seems just one more foolish battle. France will expel our popular culture from its consciousness only by replacing it with a strong culture of its own. Be patient, France. We are doing our best to help you build it.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Chasing Value In Fliers' Miles

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON; DAVID CAY JOHNSTON is a business reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
SOME people will go to absurd lengths to collect frequent flier miles, traveling from New York to Seattle by way of Charlotte, Atlanta or even Miami, or staying in a pricey hotel on the company tab to take advantage of a double miles offer. But how much value you get for your miles can be even more important than how you earn them.
As demand for air travel has grown with the economy, the airlines have in the last couple of years trimmed back on miles they give out, raised the number of miles for some awards, added blackout dates, tightened up on the availability of seats that can be purchased with frequent flier miles and added new fees. But there are ways to get more bang for your miles. 
 The rule of thumb is that a frequent flier mile is worth 2 cents, based on the notion that a domestic ticket typically costs $500 and such a ticket requires 25,000 miles on most airlines. With some smart moves frequent flier miles can be worth a nickel or even close to a dime each. But the airlines are perfectly happy to let you redeem 25,000 miles for a ticket you could have bought for $100, valuing your miles at less than a half cent each.
Flexibility Is a Major Plus
What you can get for your miles depends on your travel plans, your tastes and on knowing how to spot a chance to get a good deal from the airlines. It also helps to be flexible, and to know the signals that an airline has seats going begging. And you might consider using miles for benefits you might otherwise regard as extravagances, such as first class or even a ride on the Concorde.
The first rule of cashing in miles is flexibility. "Go off peak," advises Karen Goodwin, editor of Frequent Flyer Magazine. "Don't expect to find the seat you want at the busiest season. The airlines can easily sell seats to London in July and August so they don't make as many free ones available."
Joe Chapline, Delta Air Lines's frequent flier director, says it also pays "to be flexible about which days you travel. Going one or two days earlier or later will truly make a difference," he continued, "and remember that flying Thursdays and Saturdays you are more likely to get frequent flier award seats."
Being flexible about which airport, or changing planes, can help, too. If you want to fly from New York to Los Angeles and are told no seats are available, ask about a seat to nearby Orange County, said John McDonald, a spokesman for T.W.A. Flights to Orlando may not be available, but the amusement parks are only an hour or so drive from Tampa, Daytona Beach and other Central Florida cities whose flights may have plenty of seats.
Likewise, if you want to spend high season in Paris, London or Rome but cannot find a seat, you might have better luck asking about a seat to Brussels, Nice, Milan or Manchester, assuming you want to visit one of those cities and like European trains.
Changing planes instead of going nonstop can also help at busy times, said Richard Metzner, a vice president for marketing at Continental. "If the agent tells you nothing is available nonstop ask, 'Is there anything available via Cleveland or Houston?' "
If you want to stop over in a connecting city, say in Pittsburgh on your way from Boston to New Orleans, most airlines will charge you a much higher fare, but many reward tickets allow stopovers, according to Mark Seltzer, a Toronto dealer in rare travel books. Likewise, tickets bought on deep discounts often prohibit an "open jaw," in which you fly to one city, but fly home from another, while many reward tickets allow this option.
The second rule is to watch for signs that an airline has unsold seats. Last summer, when most airlines offered fewer frequent flier seats across the North Atlantic because they had a surge of paying customers, Continental increased the number of frequent flier seats to Europe by 68 percent over summer 1995. The reason? The airline had added more flights, increasing its capacity by 30 percent. If the airlines are offering incredibly inexpensive seats or bonus miles, they may well have seats available for reward travel.
Airlines often offer deals to new destinations or when they are trying to get fliers to associate their name with a destination. When United bought Pan American's Asian route system a decade ago, for example, it offered travel to Japan or Tokyo for half the usual number of miles, a program that packed its planes and soaked up a lot of frequent flier miles, which are a liability on the company's books. Cathay Pacific recently offered round-trip coach travel to Hong Kong for 40,000 American Airlines miles from any city in the United States. In the recent past, it has offered trips to Australia, Thailand, India and South Africa for similar amounts.
"If you see a destination on sale it's a good bet that there are plenty of frequent flier seats on those flights," said David Castleveter, a spokesman for USAir.
Airlines will sometimes offer brief frequent flier sales. Continental sometimes has trips to Europe for 25,000 miles, half the usual requirement. And United and some other airlines also sometimes offer a combination cash and miles deal, such as Europe from the East Coast for 20,000 miles and $100.
High-Value Upgrades
 Some of the best deals come from using frequent flier miles for business class or first class. USAir frequent fliers can go round trip to Europe on five carriers -- Air France, Alitalia, Sabena, Swissair and USAir (and British Air until March 29) in coach for 60,000 miles during the warm months, when an advance purchase ticket is often around $1,000. But business class requires only slightly more at 80,000 miles. First class is 100,000 miles, while a first-class ticket costs about $8,000, making miles worth about 8 cents each. And the even costlier Concorde is 125,000 miles, although that deal ends when USAir's alliance with British Air ends.
Greg Lyon, 25, a computer consultant in St. Louis, used 85,000 miles last May to fly T.W.A. business class to New York and first class on to London and return the same way. "For 50,000 miles I could have flown coach from St. Louis to London, a ticket worth maybe $500." Mr. Lyon said. "But for 70 percent more miles I got a ticket that would have cost five to eight times that much. To me that's an excellent value."
Tony Todd, 44, a software developer in Tampa, figures he got $24,000 worth of tickets for 240,000 miles and $1,000. He used 160,000 miles for two round-trip first-class tickets to London and another 80,000 miles to upgrade two round-trip coach tickets, which had cost $500 each, to business class. "I figure I got close to a dime per mile," he said.
His trip also illustrates two additional ways to get more value for your miles: plan and travel in pairs. American Airlines requires 200,000 miles for an "anytime" first-class ticket to Europe good on any flight. But by planning your trip well in advance and avoiding the blackout dates, you only need 100,000 miles. If you travel with a companion, however, two first-class plan ahead tickets bought well ahead of time require only 160,000 miles, a 20 percent discount.
But sometimes, you can get more value for your money with a last-minute trip, if seats are available. Airlines often charge a fee of $50 to $75 for arranging tickets within three weeks or less of flying. But some will let you redeem miles at the airport -- Delta Air Lines, for example, charges $60 for last-second mile redemption -- and take the next flight with an open seat.
Frequent Flyer Magazine, in an annual reader poll, found that the availability of first-class upgrades was the most desired perk for people who participate in frequent flier programs, but that 66 percent of those responding said it was getting harder to get into first class.
Airlines typically offer three ways to fly up front without buying a first-class ticket: an upgrade certificate given as a bonus to its most frequent fliers; a fee, typically $30 for short flights and $90 cross-country or an upgrade bought with miles. If you choose the last option, be careful which miles are deducted because miles in old programs can often be more valuable. On Delta Air Lines, for example, to upgrade from coach to business or first class from most fares, including a deeply discounted ticket, you need only 2,500 miles from its old program. But if you use miles from its current Sky Miles program, the upgrade costs 10,000 miles.
The worst way to get value for your miles is to let them expire. Continental, T.W.A. and USAir miles never expire. But American Airlines miles expire after three years, and on Jan. 1 the first to go were those earned in 1993 and earlier. United and Northwest miles begin expiring at the end of this year if they are three years old. Delta Air Lines miles also expire after three years if you have not flown on the airline in that time.

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
A World of Enchantment, Page After Illuminated Page

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
FOR MORE THAN a thousand years, beginning around A.D. 500, Roman Catholic monks copied stories and illustrated them with heroic saints and fantastic beasts, capturing the glorious imagery also seen in medieval stained-glass windows. These illuminated manuscripts have been popular ever since, first with monarchs and bishops, and more recently with bankers and industrialists.
This year, illuminated manuscripts will be more visible in New York than they have been in decades. A bizarre world of monsters, demons, groveling humans and wide-eyed angels is vividly depicted in the new book "The Illuminated Manuscripts of Medieval Spain," by Mireille Mentre. The book, which was published last month by Thames and Hudson of London, focuses on works from around the year 1000. 
 The Metropolitan Museum of Art will include 50 books of exotic illuminations in "The Glory of Byzantium," an exhibition that will run from March 8 through July 6. The most ambitious show of such art, "Medieval Best Seller: The Book of Hours," will be held at the Pierpont Morgan Library, from September into January 1998. It will present 100 books from the 13th to the 16th century.
A prelude to this rich feast is currently on view in "Princely Magnificence," an exhibition of 50 illuminated manuscripts at Ursus Rare Books, in the Carlyle Hotel, through Feb. 8. The show of 13th- to 16th-century works is the first of its kind at Ursus, which was founded 25 years ago by T. Peter Kraus. He got started in the business 30 years ago, working in Manhattan for his uncle, Hans P. Kraus, the Vienna-born dealer in rare books who dominated the market in illuminated manuscripts until his death at 81 in 1988.
The Ursus exhibition was organized with Jorn Gunther of Hamburg, Germany, a dealer in medieval manuscripts and early printed books. He also apprenticed at H. P. Kraus a decade ago.
The works at Ursus range in price from $27,500 for a gilded 16th-century image of Pentecost, depicting the Holy Ghost as a dove descending on the apostles and Mary, to $5.5 million for a 13th-century psalterfrom Wurzburg, Germany, containing many surrealistic images. Among them is a haloed Christ, seated in a temple among elders who wear hats shaped like flying saucers.
The boldly rendered illuminations enchant medievalists because they are so readily understood. "But what appeals even more to collectors is that most of these books come from great collections," Mr. Kraus said. "To know that an illuminated manuscript once belonged to a French king, or J. P. Morgan, helps them to identify with these men of power."
Past owners of books in the show include many famous people. In the 1930's, Henri de Rothschild, for example, owned a 15th-century Parisian Book of Hours, a medieval book of prayers. And at the turn of the century, William Waldorf Astor bought another French version of the book, made in about 1520. That book is now called the Astor Book of Hours. J. P. Morgan, the banker, was also buying a century ago when he acquired "Ars Moriendi Treatise," a colorfully decorated 15th-century work about death.
In centuries past, wars and social upheavals caused many books to come on the market. "In France, illuminated manuscripts were still in religious houses in the 18th century," Mr. Kraus said. "They got dispersed during the French Revolution." But these days, sales of illuminated manuscripts are sparked by either plummeting financial markets or soaring prices.
During an economic downturn in 1983, Peter Ludwig, the German chocolate manufacturer and collector of everything from medieval books to Pop Art, sold his 144 illuminated medieval manuscripts to the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., for $50 million.
Six months later, Sotheby's auctioned the most important book of illuminations ever to go under the gavel, the Henry the Lion Gospels, a book given by a 12th-century Bavarian duke to the Brunswick Cathedral. The $11.7 million sale price was then the record for any work of art sold at auction. It was paid by a team of dealers headed by H. P. Kraus, acting as agents for the German consortium that bought it.
Since then, the market for medieval illuminations has been largely quiet, even though Christopher de Hamel organizes auctions of such manuscripts twice a year at Sotheby's in London. Of the five or six collectors buying important medieval books today, the most prominent is J. Paul Getty Jr. With rare exceptions, Mr. de Hamel said, the buyers become known only when they sell their libraries.
Mr. de Hamel said it was not until the 1983 sale that "I realized Peter Ludwig was a collector of illuminations." Ludwig, who died last July, kept his passion secret by buying almost exclusively at H. P. Kraus.
For collectors like Ludwig, these books have a singular distinction. "Illuminated manuscripts remain the one true confluence in art of words and images," Peter Kraus said. "It's where paintings and books come together as art."

HEADLINE: The View From: Danielson Airport;
Exercise In Small Town Aviation

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
MOST airfields are bustling centers of activity, but at Danielson Airport they do in a month what some would do in a busy afternoon. There are generally just 100 to 200 takeoffs and landings a month, including students at the flight school. "Sometimes in the winter when the weather's real bad, we might not have any for a day or two," said J. Gary Boroughf, president of Northeast Air Management Inc., which manages the airport.
The track team from the adjacent Harvard H. Ellis Technical School maintains a 3.5-mile trail on the airport property, and the State Police have a shooting range in a gravel pit just south of the runway. Dagwood, a yellow dog with a great disposition, wanders among the 63 parked aircraft, cadging the occasional biscuit. State Traffic Commission signs warn visitors, "Area closed from sunset to sunrise." 
 "It's a great, grass roots, general aviation airport," said Mr. Boroughf. And, he said, people want it to stay that way. In November, when the Federal Department of Transportation announced a $900,000 grant for improvements, including resurfacing the runway, new lights and new signs, town and airport officials were quick to emphasize that no expansion was planned.
Keith L. Knowlton, vice president of Fiberoptic Technology Inc. in Pomfret, who flies a Beechcraft Baron -- "The best thing ever made for turning money into noise" -- said no one wants to relive the battles in the 1980's when the local business community advocated extending the runway 300 feet. That would have made it safer to land the twin- and single-engine propeller planes at Danielson, and reduce everyone's insurance premiums, he said.
But, Mr. Knowlton added, "People in the area think extending the runway is a nefarious scheme to bring 747's into Danielson."
As Mr. Boroughf explained, "We try to maintain a balance between the neighbors and the flying public. There are always going to be noise issues and esthetic issues, but those can be managed if you're careful about traffic patterns and pilot practices."
There are occasional conflicts. R. Thomas Homan, town manager of Killingly, which encompasses the borough of Danielson, said a few years ago townspeople were upset about a plan to fence in the airport property. Eventually the State Department of Transportation modified the design, leaving unfenced some heavily used walking trails.
A new dispute centers around a Federal Aviation Administration plan to clearcut more than 40 acres of trees to provide a clearer flight path -- a plan the town only heard of by accident, Mr. Homan said.
"You've got a lot of residents around there, and those trees are an important resource," both to the environment and because they provide a buffer between the airport and nearby homes, Mr. Homan said. "They should have at least talked to us about it first." Forty acres might not seem like much to a major Federal agency, he acknowledged, but in Killingly it certainly counts.
The F.A.A. is "always willing to sit down and work out a compromise once they realize people are upset," he said, "but sometimes they don't consider how much of a controversy a project might cause."
Robert F. Juliano, chief of the Bureau of Ports and Aviation at the State Department of Transportation, said the $900,000 Federal grant and $100,000 in state funds meant Danielson represents less than 3 per cent of the $35 million annual operating budget of Bradley International Airport, the state's largest.
But Mr. Juliano said small airports are important. With more companies buying their own aircraft so they are no longer at the mercy of commercial schedules, he said, general aviation fields are economic development tools. They also provide other services -- a local stop for organ transplant teams, for instance.
To get to Danielson Airport, off Maple Street in Killingly, one takes a narrow, winding asphalt road through dense woods, to a one-story hangar surrounded by planes with names like Yankee Boy and Top Gun. There's a T-6 military aircraft from South Africa and an Army L-19 Bird Dog, once used for reconnaissance over Vietnam. There are old fabric-body planes, and more than a few tail-draggers, the tiny propeller planes with the back landing gear mounted as far back as possible, used by many weekend flyers.
It has a 2,700-foot air strip that runs east-west. A dense stand of pine borders the runway to the south, and hardwoods lie to the north. To the west is the Quinebaug River, and, to the east, a housing complex for elderly people.
"We don't get any complaints about the airport as it is now," said Town Council Chairman John E. Burke. "The airport predates most of the housing in that area. People built their homes knowing it was there." The airfield was built in 1963 for the aviation department at Ellis Technical School, said to be the oldest public aviation school in the country. The head of the department, Edward A. Baranski Jr., said interest in the three-year post-high school course has waned in recent years because of publicity about downsizing by the airlines; only half of his 80 student slots are filled. But there is no shortage of jobs for aircraft mechanics.
"The schools can't supply enough," Mr. Baranski said. "Most of my students have several job offers when they graduate. They're in the enviable position of being able to pick and choose."
Mr. Baranski, who flies a Piper Tomahawk out of Danielson, said his department gets about 24 planes a year for repairs, from all over New England and New York, and sometimes farther. "I turn enough work away to keep someone in business full-time," he said.
Does Danielson need some help? Yes, Mr. Boroughf said, pointing to some aerial pictures of the airport. "This is work that we've needed to do for a while," he said, noting the photographic evidence of worsening conditions in the last decade or so, since the fissures first appeared in the asphalt. Today, a walk on the runway reveals a spider web-like collection of cracks.
This will be the first renovation of the runway since the airport was built, and the repairs are likely to last for another 30 years because of light traffic and because it is built on top of an old gravel bank, which means good drainage and less weather-related cracking and heaving, Mr. Borough said.
And Danielson is becoming increasingly important as other small airports -- like one in Fall River, Mass. -- shut down. A few planes came in from Lakeside Airport in Voluntown when the operations there were scaled back this year. And the Woodstock Parachute Center is expected to move to Danielson soon, joining a glider club and a chapter of the Experimental Aircraft Association that are already there. "Now you'll have three groups competing for the same time slots on the weekends," said Donald N. LaPointe of Brooklyn, a pilot who flies a 1961 two-seater Piper Colt out of Danielson, and belongs to the association. "It'll be interesting to see if we can all get along."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 41; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk
