HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Worthy of a World Capital

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
GOOD NEWS. THE WILDLY imperfect process of creating civic architecture in New York has produced a first-rate piece of design. It's time to rub our eyes. Wake up and see the architecture. Step up to one big question.
Will New Yorkers recognize the chance to make a marriage between a major civic site and a design worthy of its stature? Or will we derail a process that richly deserves our contempt and in doing so kill off an excellent project and set architecture in New York back another 25 years? 
 The project is Murphy/Jahn's design for Tishman Speyer Properties' proposed redevelopment of the Coliseum site on Columbus Circle, one of the most important locations in the world's greatest city, and Helmut Jahn has come up with a plan that is more than worthy of this site. It is on a par with the best architecture in the world today.
Many of us will be strongly tempted to disbelieve this. New Yorkers are more than entitled to be cynical about the schemes our public agencies come up with. And Helmut Jahn is probably not the first name you would think of in connection with a solid work of design. For many New Yorkers, Jahn brings to mind unpleasant images of glitzy skyscrapers from the go-go 80's.
But times and architects change. Don't trust my word for it. Judge for yourself. Nine competing designs for the Coliseum project will be on view through the end of the month in the Coliseum's lobby. A more ambitious show, sponsored by the Municipal Art Society, will open on Tuesday at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue. Debate on the merits of all nine projects will take place on Feb. 19 and 20 at 2 Columbus Circle. These events, also presented by the Municipal Art Society, could prove invaluable to restoring the well-being of architecture in New York. Or they could just reinforce the denial that contemporary architecture in New York is far less creative than this vibrant city deserves.
The issue transcends the respective merits of the designs. It even overarches the dismal political process that produced them. How do you make discriminations in a relativistic universe? How do you distinguish architecture from the kind of architectural impersonations proposed by a majority of the developers for the Coliseum site? How do you persuade public officials that the values of art, while subjective, are no less real than the hard facts of the bottom line?
Probably many New Yorkers don't even want to hear about the Coliseum project. Talk about deja vu all over again. Twelve years ago, an earlier round of proposals subjected the city to an urban psychodrama that dragged on for four years. Esthetically, the choices lay between Moshe Safdie's strident piece of glass origami and David Childs's nostalgic Art Deco reprise.
No building resulted from that contest. First lawsuits, then the collapse of the real estate market, prevented the realization of either project. But the exercise was not fruitless. At least New Yorkers got to see the intellectual bankruptcy of the public agencies responsible for building in the public realm. The redevelopment of this major civic site was conducted as if it were a fire sale. Art counted for nothing. The bottom line ruled.
Public officials even seemed to take it as a point of pride that they were not "imposing" their esthetic judgments -- as if anyone in their right mind were expecting them to do that, as if the only two choices available to civic building were the esthetic dictatorship of politicians or the tyranny of the bottom line. What was expected then, and what is expected now, is that public agencies adopt the mechanism of the design competition, an arrangement accepted as a matter of course by every other major city in the civilized world.
Sadly, New York seems no closer to recognizing the value of this device today than it was 12 years ago. Once again, economic factors alone are likely to determine the outcome of this process. At a news conference on the nine proposals, officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Empire State Development Corporation declined to say what role, if any, designers would play in the selection of the developer, which is expected to take place in the spring.
The M.T.A.'s indifference to architecture was not a surprise. It could have been gleaned from the request for proposals that the agency sent out last July. Apart from a vague reference to the desire for a "world class" plan and a requirement that the new building define a circular street wall, the document offered little guidance to the meaning or cultural value of this site.
Let's write our own.
Columbus Circle is a child of the City Beautiful movement, born just over a century ago. The Columbian Exposition, held in Chicago in 1893, with its famous White City, set out the movement's guiding ideas: classical, academic, monumental, homogeneous, dedicated to sweeping urban vistas of Beaux-Arts buildings adorned with fountains and heroic statues. The movement produced some noble cityscapes and buildings, like the New York Public Library and Bryant Park, as well as comically unrealized visions like Columbus Circle.
No point trying to exhume the movement's precepts today. They represent an outmoded style of art and an objectionable political philosophy. As Lewis Mumford observed decades ago, the City Beautiful movement was the perfect style for America's imperial phase, of trusts and monopolies, of the exploitation of regions by industrial urban centers. But there's no reason architects couldn't ask themselves to visualize the beauty of the contemporary city.
Indeed, New York's most important buildings of this century have done precisely that. The United Nations headquarters, the Seagram Building, the T.W.A. Terminal at Kennedy Airport: each of these, in different ways, channeled urban energy into built form. More recent projects, outside New York, have also crystallized the beauty of particular cities. Arquitectonica's Atlantis condominium tower in Miami; Jean Nouvel's Cartier Foundation in Paris; Arata Isozaki's Convention Hall for Nara, Japan; Frank Gehry's plan for the Walt Disney Concert Hall in downtown Los Angeles: these projects, too, show that the beauty of cities changes.
Like most of the other plans, Jahn's reuses the existing Coliseum and adjacent office building at 10 Columbus Circle. The tan brick facades are stripped away; the office tower is enlarged with structural additions that transform the floor plan from a rectangle to a trapezoid. This then becomes the base for two triangular towers, each 40 stories high, rising at the east and west ends of the site. The whole composition is then wrapped in a taut glass skin.
This is no plain glass box. Like Nouvel in his design for the Cartier Foundation in Paris, Jahn pushes glass beyond its standard curtain-wall application. On both towers and base, Jahn cantilevers the glass skin beyond the building envelope, so that one sees the glass as pure transparency, as well as the semi-opaque curtain wall.
The design's tripartite division is forthrightly classical. Public areas -- stores, restaurants, exhibition space, a museum -- are housed in the curving base that defines the site's circular street wall. The glass trapezoid contains offices. Twin towers, two precisely placed prisms, will house condominium apartments. Classical, too, and classically modern are the exposure of structure and the deference of its forms to light and void. Who wouldn't make a detour to watch the towers reach up, grab a square of sky and rotate the space gently between them?
The James Stewart Polshek & Partners plan for Millenium Partners is the only other proposal that one could reasonably call architecture. Like Jahn, Polshek defines the street wall with a cinematically grand curving glass screen, though Polshek contains his screen within a metal frame and projects it toward the sidewalk. Two glass towers, soberly expressionist, rise from the curving base. But Polshek's is cautious compared with Jahn's design.
EVALUATING A PROJECT LIKE the Coliseum involves two kinds of truth. One kind is objective; it can be quantified. The M.T.A. has not provided any financial data, such as how much each developer proposes to pay for the site, but the difference between, say, a $250 million bid from one developer and a $300 million bid from another developer is a coolly factual $50 million. The other kind is subjective -- no one can prove that Jahn's and Polshek's designs are superior to the other seven -- but it is a truth nonetheless. Indeed, it's one of the highest truths that art and architecture can lay claim to.
The purpose of a design competition is to honor that claim. The decision of a jury is, of course, the result of opinions. But the jury process is grounded in the belief that informed opinions of art are more likely than uninformed opinions to distinguish good from bad. It may not always work out that way -- look at last year's overbearing winning design to expand the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. But even in a case like that, the design competition still stands for an important principle: subjectivity is a serious matter. It is not the same as chance, whim or public relations. Any architect can hire a publicist to write words like "bold," "visionary," "dramatic," "inventive." The architect may believe them; a public official, unveiling a design at a news conference, may repeat them with something like stirring conviction. Occasionally, they may even be true.
In 1987, New Yorkers justly fought the Coliseum proposal because of the shadows it threatened to cast over Central Park. Will they rally to support this building because it would actually improve the play of light and shadow on the West Side skyline?
A sentence from F. Scott Fitzgerald's "Crack-Up" comes to mind: "New York had all the iridescence of the beginning of the world." Fitzgerald was talking about 1920's, and the great giddy skyscrapers that were redefining the Jazz Age skyline. Like no other New York building in the last 25 years, Jahn's design recaptures the romantic promise of Fitzgerald's great lost city. A scaffold, cloaked in light, the project conveys with minimal means the enduring idea of New York as the great world capital of permanent becoming. You could imagine Christopher Columbus making port in this radiant image of the New World.

LENGTH: 1265 words

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Dee DelBello;
Former First Lady Reigns as a Publisher

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
FOR almost a decade, she was the First Lady of Westchester County and she had a brief reign as the Second Lady of New York State -- all the while pursuing her own career. Today Dee DelBello is the publisher of the weekly Westchester and Fairfield Business Journals. Her husband, Alfred, the former Westchester County Executive and New York State Lieutenant Governor, is in private law practice, having lost a bid to the State Senate two years ago.
Mrs. DelBello was recently honored with the annual Samuel J. Duboff Memorial Award, given by the Fund for Modern Courts, for her work from 1976 to 1994 as one of two people who are not lawyers on the 11-member New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct. 
 The commission, based in Manhattan, considers complaints brought against judges.
Gerry Stern, a resident of White Plains, has been its executive director since its formation in 1976. The position on the commission was one of several jobs Mrs. DelBello has held over the last 25 years, during which she had a daily interview show on radio station WFAS-AM (1230) and worked as a regional public relations director at Bloomingdale's.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mrs. DelBello, who lives in Lewisboro:
Q. You are someone who at times has felt the press has wronged your husband or yourself. You crossed to the other side when you bought The Business Journals. What processes took you through that?
A. It was a very easy process in that I understood the other side. And having come from public relations, I understood somewhat the press side, but not nearly enough. I suppose if I knew all that I know now about publishing I might not have at that time bought the newspapers because it's a very tough business. Particularly in 1990 when I bought the papers it was the beginning of the recession and the worst advertising slump.
Q. Do you have more empathy now for what reporters go through?
A. I do have empathy for what reporters go through. I'm very concerned about maintaining the integrity of the newspaper. I understand the other side. I understand what the subject of an article might be going through, but I also understand the need to maintain that integrity, not to be persuaded or dissuaded by any empathy one might feel. So what we try to do, as all good reporters do, is tell both sides of the story until we get to the truth of the story. We tell every aspect as scrupulously as we possibly can, without any influences, whether it be influences from the subject of the article or influences from sales; you know, the dynamics between sales and editorial.
Q. As publisher, do you read everything that goes into the paper, or do you rely on your editors for that?
A. I rely on the editors. I don't get involved, except from a philosophic point of view in what's going into the newspaper. I am concerned about how the papers look, what the stories are about and whether we are maintaining our mission, which is to cover local business news.
Q. Do you miss politics?
A. Yes, I do. I miss it to the extent that there is an involvement in what's happening in the community that only can occur when you're involved politically. You can make things happen. I look around and I see the programs that Al initiated when he was County Executive, and they're still in existence. I also miss the opportunities to meet so many people.
Q. Will Al try to run for public office again?
A. I don't know.
Q. What about you?
A. Oh, goodness, no. I enjoy working behind the scenes.
Q. Did you ever, when Al was running for State Senate two years ago, have any conflicts as the owner of a newspaper?
A. No, we really don't cover political campaigns. We really stick to our niche. We don't endorse.
Q. What made the work on the Commission on Judicial Conduct interesting for you?
A. It gave me a view of the judiciary that I never had before. You are inside the judiciary, understanding what makes it work, what's going on.
Q. Is it true that people who are not lawyers bring an entirely different perspective to such a commission?
A. There is no question about it. I think they bring more objective viewpoints. They have no ties to other lawyers. The lay people look out for all the citizens they encounter when they're involved in the court system.
Q. By the time something got to the commission, past the staff people, had there already been a screening so you heard only serious complaints?
A. The complaints are, of course, looked at by the staff, and they are screened to a certain extent as to which are more serious than others. But the commission essentially looks at every complaint. Even when a staff person may recommend dismissal, if one of the commission members thinks there is some substance to the complaint then the complaint is considered further. There is not one complaint that is acted on in a willy-nilly fashion. Gerry Stern, the executive director, is the most effective public administrator I have ever come across. Any agency that doesn't have some one like Gerry Stern should have some one like him, and he has put together the most loyal and committed staff.
Q. Are most complaints ones in which litigants did not get what they wanted so they blame the judge in some manner?
A. When you're a litigant, sure, if the case does not go in your favor you're going to feel put upon. But you really need to have more of a basis than that to complain against the judge. Remember, the Commission on Judicial Conduct oversees the conduct of a judge on the bench. If a judge drank a lot that wouldn't be an issue unless that affected his conduct on the bench. So, yes, there are some dissatisfied litigants who bring some complaints. But whether the majority of them were that way, no, I wouldn't say that.
Q. What were the types of complaints that had some validity? Drunken judges? Judges who showed partisanship? Corrupt judges?
A. All of those things. Remember judges are human, but they hold almost a sacred role in their jobs. They have to be held to higher standards.
Q. Did you feel the commission was tough enough on judges it found had done something wrong?
A. Yes, generally. We would argue for hours, days sometimes, hold things over, just to make sure that justice was done for both the judges and the court system as a whole and the citizenry of New York as a whole.
Q. In the last 20 years that you served, the selection process for judges has changed. There is screening by panels that did not exist a few decades ago. Did you get a sense that better judges are sitting on the bench?
A. Yes and no. I think we have an imperfect system, and we probably will always have an imperfect system because whether judges are selected by election or by appointment, it is always a selection of one kind or another.
Q. There was a time in some of New York's rural areas when a local judge did not have to be a lawyer. Is that still the case?
A. It's still so for town justices; I don't remember all the numbers right now, but I think about two-thirds of these town judges are not lawyers. But that's really not so important because they are trained. It's important that they know their locale and get the proper training.
Q. Often you hear people say: anyone on the bench can be bought. What's your response?
A. Not true. There are, in every profession, people who are not perfect. There are some terrible doctors, some terrible lawyers, terrible politicians. But by and large, the judges are a good group and with the help of the Commission and the Fund for Modern Courts, they have become better.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 13; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 779 words

HEADLINE: Sunday, January 19, 1997: BOOKS;
Experts Agree: We're Finished

 BODY:
With the year 2000 approaching, it seems that everyone Christians and
secularists alike is theorizing about scary futures, often in prose whose inscrutability rivals the Book of Revelation's. ("As middle-aged 13ers survey the Crisis-era detritus of the Unraveling," argues one such book, "The Fourth Turning," "they will see the opposite of what the midlife Silent saw in the Awakening-era wreckage of the High.") Lest you think we exaggerate, here's a sample side by side, for comparison, with prophecy from an apocalyptic Christian. Read 'em and tremble.
 
1998-2000
*"The Clash of Civilizations and the Remaking of World Order," Samuel P. Huntington: A Harvard political scientist explains how "the fault lines between civilizations are becoming the central lines of conflict in global politics." The culture to watch as 2000 rolls around: Islam. One in five people on the planet now prays to Allah. Ever restive, the Islamic world starts to think seriously about grabbing a bigger piece of the global pie.
*"The Next War," Caspar Weinberger and Peter Schweizer: "Fictive accounts" of wars that could occur thanks to our supposed military unreadiness. Trouble comes large and loud when China invades Taiwan while North Korea surges across the DMZ. Seoul is sacked, United States troops are hit with biological weapons, and the U.S. exchanges tactical nukes with Korea and China. We accept an unfavorable peace, realizing that we cannot risk an all-out war with another superpower.
*"The Fourth Turning," William Strauss and Neil Howe: Pop futurists examine what the cycles of history tell us about America's next rendezvous with destiny. The authors believe that the "next Crisis era will most likely extend roughly from the middle Oh-Ohs to the middle 2020's." Key to this period are the Millennials, good, selfless hard-working young people (now entering high school) whose destiny is to save the world (if they can) from a baby-boomer-generated economic, spiritual, political and environmental collapse, circa 2005.
*"Beginning of the End: The Assassination of Yitzhak Rabin and the Coming Antichrist," John Hagee: A look at the Bible's apocalyptic timetable by a fundamentalist Christian. (Hagee resists giving dates, saying only that these events are coming "very soon.") Islam unites with a reborn Soviet Union to invade Israel. Israel nukes her enemies and triggers global war. The Antichrist rises and sets himself up as God. For this he is assassinated, but then he is reborn -- live on CNN.
 
2000-2010
*Huntington: World War III begins when China invades Vietnam to tap its oil. The U.S. engages but is hobbled when Japan declares itself neutral. Chaos results. India attacks Pakistan but is repelled by Iran. An Arab coalition attacks Israel. China squeezes Japan until it joins the war against the U.S. Every major civilization is mobilized.
*Weinberger and Schweizer: A radical mob sacks the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City. A drug gang blows up a Houston shopping center. The U.S. invades Mexico to topple its evil "Presidente Ruiz."
*Strauss and Howe: Boomers start collecting Social Security, but the system is bankrupt, and when too many boomers try to unload their greedily hoarded assets, Wall Street lays an egg. "The Fourth Turning" begins as economic collapse and other boomer-related problems cause society to seize up like a rusty engine. Two possible scenarios:
1) A state-led tax revolt ignites secessionist frenzies, Federal occupation, militia violence and a demand for a Constitutional convention. 2) A new, highly contagious killer virus prompts "unsafe neighborhood" quarantines and a three-way war between the National Guard, urban gangs and suburban militias.
*Hagee: Islam is defeated. Israel, governed by the Antichrist, must fight 200 million Chinese at Armageddon. Jesus arrives to defeat the forces of evil.
 
2020-3000
*Huntington: Hispanic men and women grow to become a full quarter of the U.S. population and we become a "cleft country." Civil war and national dissolution are probable.
*Strauss and Howe: The Crisis of 2005 ends circa 2025, very likely with a deadly civil war or larger global conflagration. If we're not all dead, we'll have the Millennials to thank, for it will be their can-do spirit that rebuilds America to a state of post-World War II greatness.
*Hagee: Christ's earthly reign ends after a thousand years. God destroys the present earth and eternity begins, in Heaven. If you want to be a part of it, Hagee writes, repent now. "Like no other generation," he writes, in a conclusion that could apply to all these books, "we are the ones who cannot take for granted tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Patricia McCann-Vissepo;
Educating New Haven, and Its Critics

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
THE chairwoman of the New Haven Board of Education, Patricia McCann-Vissepo, is determined to dispel stereotypes about urban schools. In fact, said Ms. McCann, "I would send my own child to any New Haven high school before I would send him" to the suburban West Haven High, East Haven High or Hamden High. And she does. Her eighth-grader attends a New Haven magnet school, West Hills Middle School.
That's because, she said, "I think we have more programs, more specialization, more resources and a much more creative curriculum. I think we have a much higher rate of sensitivity to children, especially children of color than any of those schools." New Haven, with 2,000 employees and 45 buildings, has a student population of 20,000, about 60 percent black, 25 percent Hispanic and 15 percent white. 
 Raised in Puerto Rico -- her full name reflects the Hispanic tradition of linking her father's and mother's last names -- Ms. McCann spoke Spanish as her first language. Aside from her volunteer work on the Board of Education, and as a member of the New Haven Advisory Group on Educational Improvement that advocated region-wide public school choice in the wake of the Sheff v. O'Neill case, she is executive director of Casa Otonal, a human services and housing organization.
Recently Ms. McCann met to discuss some of her concerns about urban education. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. The New Haven Board of Education is the only board in Connecticut to be appointed by the mayor rather than elected. Should that system be changed?
A. Only about 2 percent of the boards in the country are appointed. When I began I really thought it was a mistake, that we should have an elected group. Then several things happened that changed my mind.
One, I went to the National School Board Convention in Los Angeles and all the conversations I heard were "How do you raise money for your campaign?"
Then we removed some employees from the system, which would have been much harder to do if we were an elected body.
Then we voted to put condoms in New Haven middle schools, a very controversial decision.
Being appointed gives us freedom to do what's right. You may see more appointed boards in the future.
Q. The Hartford Board of Education hired Educational Alternatives, a private management firm, to run some of its schools. Will New Haven try this also?
A. I saw through Educational Alternatives Inc. in a hot minute. They took me out to dinner. I could tell those people were selling snake oil. It was so obvious. I asked these people literally seven times -- I counted -- "How do you make money?" The first time the answer was a story about their founder who had a special ed child. Then they told me another lovely story about another child. They just wouldn't answer.
Q. What do you think of moving some children from the city to suburban schools?
A. I am not convinced that suburban schools are better than our schools. They do have higher Connecticut Mastery Test scores but that is tied to socio-economic factors. The greatest indicator in S.A.T. scores is family income. The higher the family income the higher the S.A.T. scores.
We might ask ourselves, why can't we change the district lines: Just put Fair Haven in East Haven, put West Haven out in Woodbridge, the Hill in West Haven. Seems perfectly reasonable to me. Is it politically realistic? Probably not.
Q. Do you think more magnet schools will end racial isolation? How about vouchers?
A. I have advocated for all schools to be magnet schools. Every child is unique. We have a lot of children who for whatever reason we have not been able to engage. The bigger the menu of things we have to offer, the more likely we are to find something that will engage each child. We'll have schools that focus on science, health, the arts. The more you have to offer, the more likely something will click.
Vouchers are a fraud. They are very misleading. For parochial schools to receive vouchers, I think poses a Constitutional problem. Why do parochial schools do better? They pick their children.
Q. Do New Haven teachers and administrators receive excessively high salaries?
A. It's true our teachers are the highest paid teachers in the United States. On the other hand it's a very hard job for which you have to prepare academically for a long time and have to continue to take courses. It's not like you finish your B.A. and that's it.
Given those realities I think they earn a fair wage. A starting teacher gets about $29,000. It goes up to about $60,000, but that's for someone who has a Ph.D., who has worked for 20 years.
Could some of our teachers give more? Absolutely, that's something we have to work on. We also have a responsibility as management to develop teachers.
Elementary school principals make around $68,000, $69,000. It's a decent salary but it's a big job. They are responsible for several hundred children, teachers, custodians, food, para-professionals. If you look at the private sector they pay significantly more than that.
The superintendent of schools supervises 2,000 employees and makes about $120,000. The man who heads United Illumination supervises 1,000 employees and makes $500,000.
Q. Why are resources scarce in the New Haven public schools?
A. It's a bureaucratic problem. People haven't figured out how to get supplies to schools in a timely fashion. We are hiring our own purchasing agent. Given the large volume of our purchases it makes sense.
We have made progress with updating textbooks and maps. We had maps that still showed the Belgian Congo! Have we had as much progress as we should have? No. Our main focus has been to buy literature books and computers. With computers we have a very good ratio of seven to one. Every single kindergarten and first grade has computers.
Q. Are the New Haven schools emphasizing early childhood learning?
 A. We made a strategic decision partially based on the Connecticut Mastery Test results. How can we best amortize our resources for all grades? We obviously have not given up on the older children, the sixth to eighth graders, but what we decided was to take the youngest kids, those entering kindergarten, and give them everything we had -- the computers, a teacher's aide. If by the time these kids take the fourth grade Mastery Test they don't do well then we know we really have a problem.
Q. Would you like the school age requirement moved down from 7 to 5 or 6?
A. Finally people have realized if you don't start early you start late. We have a large number of children who come to kindergarten who don't know their colors, right from left, their numbers. It is so archaic, so 19th century, it boggles the mind.
Q. Is special education a thorny problem for the board?
A. It's a lot of money. There probably are a lot of kids who are labeled without needing to be labeled. On the other hand there are a lot of parents who feel that this is a way for their child to get extra resources. I don't blame them.
We have children who spent their first year in an incubator. We have crack babies coming into to school who can't sit still for 10 seconds.
We don't do as much out-placement as we used to. We try to handle more and more at the home school. Out-placement tuition is outrageous. We had some kids whose placement cost $100,000.
Q. What about the rate of violence, drug abuse and pregnancy among New Haven teen-agers?
A. I saw an ad once that said, "If 40 percent of drug users live in the city where do the other 60 percent live?" Where indeed?
We have had no violent incidents in the last two years. Gangs are not that much of a problem. I am not saying there are no weapons in school. That would be naive. But they are not using them in schools. If weapons are found, the kids are expelled.
Teen pregnancy is down 4 percent. We have a school for teen moms and their children, Polly McCabe School. Two Yale sociologists did a study that showed McCabe students are 80 percent less likely to have a second child. It shows that intervention works.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patricia McCann-Vissepo, chairwoman of the Board of Education in New Haven. (Helen Neafsey for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 6; Page 18; Column 4; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1040 words

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Something Doesn't Love a Wall

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
THE OVERNIGHT transformation of George Stephanopoulos from partisan pitchman to television journalist highlights a disturbing phenomenon: the progressive collapse of the walls that traditionally separated news from propaganda.
Self-respecting news organizations used to pride themselves on the sturdy barriers they maintained to guard against all kinds of partisan contamination. Inside the office, they built a high wall between those who reported and analyzed events and those who offered opinions about them -- between the newsroom and the editorial page. A second wall separated both the news and editorial departments from the commercial ambitions of the business office. And an especially thick wall was erected around the entire enterprise to keep out the pollution generated by politicians and advertisers. 
 Particularly in television, America's primary source of news, the walls are buckling. Stephanopoulos is hardly the first politician to breach them. But his case shows how no one even bothers any longer to decontaminate a convert (like, say, Bill Moyers) by stretching out his passage from politics to reporting over a cleansing period of time. Nor does anyone feel the need to put distance between an active politician (like Pat Buchanan) and the news team. On the contrary, the commerce of television welcomes celebrity and contentiousness.
When ABC News first announced the hiring of Stephanopoulos, it said he would be both a "political analyst" and a "correspondent," with appearances weekdays on "Good Morning America" and Sundays on "This Week." That gilding of an amateur must have caused a ripple of resentment among reporters who take pride in the title "correspondent." So a second announcement quickly emphasized that the new recruit would not be reporting news or questioning guests, like other correspondents. And that, it was said, would avoid any "appearance of conflict."
Oh, sure. Who could possibly find conflict in an "analysis" of the words, deeds and motives of Bill Clinton and his Administration by one of the architects of his Presidency who just happens to owe his celebrity and new job entirely to that President? How could anyone discern even the appearance of a conflict between Stephanopoulos's four-year career of media manipulation for the White House and whatever he will now say or neglect to say as an ABC commentator?
If our senses are so dulled to journalistic conflicts of interest, it cannot be because of any redeeming features of the Stephanopoulos appointment. It must be because news organizations, and particularly television talk shows, so routinely confuse dispassionate news analysis with the expression of partisan opinion. At most, they compensate for one prejudiced commentator by employing another, which further conditions us to getting heat where there should be light.
As ABC argued in self-justification, why should it not put Stephanopoulos on a Sunday program that has frequently featured William Kristol, a former aide to Vice President Dan Quayle? (Quayle, at least, is a former Vice President and not quite a candidate for President in 2000.) But then why be squeamish about Kristol and Stephanopoulos questioning guests, like real reporters? A professional opinion-monger like George Will routinely does that on the same program and thereby baits reporters, like Sam Donaldson and Cokie Roberts, into expressing their contrary opinions.
The trouble with news programs that lapse into bouts of opinion is that the panelists end up scoring points instead of illuminating events. The ultimate perversion occurs on "The McLaughlin Group," whose members are encouraged to rudely shout out ill-argued conclusions, often three or four at the same time. And some television "news" shows abandon all pretense of nonpartisanship by staging cockfights among unemployed politicians -- pitting John Sununu against Geraldine Ferraro or Mary Matalin against Dee Dee Myers.
The paradox in all this is that the principal network anchors, who used to be scorned for coloring the news with the curl of a lip or the arch of an eyebrow, now stand out as the most impartial and polite voices in television news. Although the experiences and independence of Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings, Dan Rather and Ted Koppel would give their opinions a lot more weight than those of any politician, they still observe the disciplines of their craft. Their on-air analyses plumb the views and prejudices of others without parading their own.
To be sure, none of us in the news business are perfectly disinterested; we are not entirely above commercial motive or always successful in suppressing a personal view. And yes, The Times once felt a need to balance the opinions on its Op-Ed page by hiring Bill Safire direct from President Nixon's staff of speech writers. And so long as Nixon remained in the White House with Watergate bursting all around, our colleague Bill showed himself understandably conflicted in some of the columns he wrote. But they were plainly carried as columns of opinion, strictly segregated from the news reports. In my experience, The Times was insufficiently fastidious only once, two decades ago, when it hired Leslie Gelb, an arms control expert, to write about diplomacy soon after he had practiced it inside the State Department. It even let him shuttle to and from government, making an exception that reinforced our rule against such slackness.
Why is television increasingly lax about the old standards? Obviously, a Stephanopoulos has star qualities. He comes as a ready-made celebrity expert, telegenic, charming, articulate. He brings promise of an immediate lift in the ratings and in profits. The same qualities and promise must explain why, contrary to custom, the highest officials of Columbia University escorted him before the cameras to announce Stephanopoulos's other new job -- as teacher and scholar.
If he is serious about academia and journalism, Stephanopoulos will in time outgrow his youthful ardors and escapades, recover his chastity and qualify as a professional student and observer of public affairs. But if television news is serious about its reputation for disinterested analysis, it had better cement those walls.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1858 words

HEADLINE: Deregulation: A Seismic Shift, Intensity Unknown

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
NO one knows with any degree of certainty what the impact will be if the New York State Legislature takes steps in the next few months to further deregulate the state's 1.2 million rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments. Empirical studies of the economic and social consequences of removing rent regulations have simply not been done, scholars of housing say.
But opponents and proponents of deregulation do agree on one thing: Some people will be jolted and dislocated in a seismic shift. 
 Who would experience that shock, how deeply and for how long are questions subject to a revolving hologram of points of view, most of them focused through prisms of ideology. And yet, one of the most thoughtful supporters of opening all rents to free-market pricing, James W. Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Urban Policy at Rutgers University, likens the possibility -- in intensity, if not magnitude -- to the collapse of the Soviet Union.
"It's not a clean, pretty process," Dr. Hughes said. "Clearly, any change that radical is going to produce pain and dislocation. There would certainly be short-term turmoil, with a great number of individuals subject to economic shock treatment."
But, eventually, Dr. Hughes believes, "some new equilibrium is going to be reached."
"Housing is going to be better off because it's going to generate new construction," he said. "Rent-paying capacity will be one of the forces that define rent structures. You're going to have a functioning market. The problem is, eventually can be a very long time."
And as one deregulation opponent, W. Dennis Keating, a professor of urban affairs at Cleveland State University, said, paraphrasing the noted economist John Maynard Keynes, "It's like, 'In the long run it will work, but we'll all be dead.' "
The deregulation gauntlet was thrown down last month by the State Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno, when he virtually dared Democrats to either cooperate in eliminating most controls by mid-1999 or, he said, he will simply not permit the Senate to vote on renewal of current rent laws before they expire June 15. "When a law sunsets, it sunsets all by itself," said Mr. Bruno, a Republican from Rensselaer County.
A week later, Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican facing re-election next year, called for a more gradual approach, saying, "We have to have an intelligent transition that has an orderly process that protects seniors, the disabled, people on fixed incomes."
Mr. Bruno then softened his stance, saying he would support maintaining rent protection for poor tenants, but that he would still allow the current laws to expire if Democrats do not agree to decontrol any apartments that become vacant and to lower the income threshold for what is called luxury decontrol -- though he would not say to what level. The current level is $250,000 for two consecutive years for tenants in apartments renting for $2,000 or more.
What the Legislature and the Governor ultimately do remains, of course, to be seen. But, perhaps as never before, the debate has raised searching questions about whether or how to dismantle a system that protects about about 2 million people from sharp rent increases, most of them in New York City.
Perhaps surprisingly, scholars of housing have no economic model for how and with what consequences deregulation might evolve. "I don't know anybody who has done empirical studies of removing rent control," said Susan Wachter, a professor of real estate economics at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business.
In Dr. Hughes's estimation, "There's too much ideology by so many of the players in the discussion, and so there is no quantitative model that's going to settle the argument."
Proponents of letting landlords charge what the market will bear argue that rent regulation is counterproductive, does not help those it is meant to help and disrupts normal market movement by creating incentives for people to stay in place. By limiting rent rolls, they say, regulation reduces tax revenues, constrains municipal services, discourages building maintenance and eventually leads to abandonment of properties.
And, the proponents say, rent regulation is a self-fulfilling prophecy. "It makes the market tight by discouraging investment," said Arthur Zabarkes, dean of New York University's Real Estate Institute. "People stay in much bigger apartments than they need, you have low turnover, low maintenance, no new production and the market becomes very tight. Then, whenever you look at the market, you say we can't deregulate because it's too tight."
What is needed, some supporters of deregulation say, is as painless a transition as possible, one that prompts tenants to move from apartments too large for their needs, that induces landlords to upgrade existing buildings and developers to construct new ones. And, in time, they say, affordable housing will filter down to all segments of the population.
Opponents of deregulation are, to say the least, skeptical of the trickle-down theory.
There will be tremors throughout the city, they say. In today's very tight market, long-time tenants of large apartments in regulated buildings will see their rents rise by multiples or be uprooted. Middle-income people will face "sticker shock," or, if they can, will move to the suburbs or buy a co-op or condominium. Or they will relocate to less expensive neighborhoods, raising rents in those communities and squeezing out poorer residents.
OF the deregulators' contention that a free market will eventually produce affordable housing, Dr. Keating said: "That's quite a stretch. If deregulated markets work the way the supply-siders argue, then why do we have such terrible slums in cities like Houston and Miami? That's where filtering should have worked, by now. They've never had regulation."
The private sector, said Chester Hartman, president of the Poverty and Race Research Action Council in Washington and a former professor of housing policy at Harvard University, has never been very interested in producing apartments for the poor.
"The market seeks to maximize its profit, so there are tens of thousands of families who can't afford what the market will produce," Dr. Hartman said. "And particularly at a time when the Federal government is cutting back on its housing programs, this can only exacerbate the market's inability to provide for the lower end of the income scale.
"I can't imagine that ending rent regulations will do anything but force people out of their homes, or force them to spend larger proportions of their income for housing and neglect other necessities, like food and clothing."
Dr. Hartman wonders what impact deregulation might have on communities. "I think one wants to look not just at individual cases, but what it does to neighborhoods, to stability."
And, though the Wharton School's Dr. Wachter favors deregulation, she voices similar concerns: "Low-wage workers could be priced out. This could have consequences for the availability of blue-collar and service workers for the general economy."
The impact of deregulation on middle-income tenants is not clear, said Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at N.Y.U.'s School of Law.
"The abolition of rent regulation will lead to increases for families currently in regulated housing," said Professor Schill. Eventually, however -- as underutilized apartments become available, construction starts and buildings are rehabilitated -- rents for middle-income tenants would moderate, he said.
Professor Schill concurs with those who say the newly available housing "would probably not be affordable to low- and moderate-income New Yorkers." But not all poor tenants in rent-regulated buildings would be harmed by the end of regulation. "In some predominantly lower-income sections of the city, rent regulations are irrelevant because market rents are actually below what is permitted by the regulations," he said.
"There is little doubt, however," Professor Schill said, "that a substantial number of low- and moderate-income tenants or tenants on fixed incomes would be hurt by a sudden ending of rent regulation."
Dr. Keating sees three ways that the Legislature, if it chooses to deregulate, might go.
"The first and, I think, the worst" is immediate decontrol upon vacancy, he said, because it is "scattershot, hard to keep track of; in the same building, apartment by apartment, one person's rent is tremendously different by the sheer accident of who moved out." And vacancy decontrol spurs some landlords to harass tenants to move, Dr. Keating said.
The second method is to deregulate certain classes of apartments, such as higher-priced units, by certain dates, "so people have notice," he said, and the city "can keep track."
And the third is a step-down process: giving landlords larger increases than they would receive under rent regulations, but delaying total decontrol. "That way everybody knows there's rules and, presumably, there's much less chance of landlords trying to get rid of tenants," Dr. Keating said.
Dr. Wachter and Dean Zabarkes believe, however, that vacancy decontrol is the least disruptive method because it does not affect tenants remaining in place -- as long, Dr. Wachter said, as there are protections against harassment, and as long, Dean Zabarkes said, as it is not implemented during a tight rental market.
"If you agree that we want deregulation, then you have to do it by softening the market at the same time," Dean Zabarkes said, perhaps with a "short window of incentives" for new construction.
Professor Schill wonders whether increased tax revenues from rising property values could help soften the deregulatory blow. "If these gains in revenue are redistributed to lower-income households through rent vouchers or increased production of affordable housing, it could lessen the hardship," he said.
THE chairman of the Assembly Housing Committee, Vito J. Lopez, a Democrat from Brooklyn, believes the deregulation fight will, in the end, focus on proposals to lower the income threshold for luxury decontrol. "I believe the battle will be: do we move it to $200,000 or lower?" Assemblyman Lopez said. If that happens, he said, middle-class tenants will be forced out of Manhattan "and we will economically ghettoize certain communities."
State Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Republican from Manhattan who opposes any form of deregulation, believes the debate will focus on outright vacancy decontrol. "It was a disaster under Rockefeller because of widespread harassment of tenants by landlords," Senator Goodman said. The Senator was referring to a period between 1971 and 1974 when vacancy decontrol was implemented, only to be limited, in Dr. Keating's words, "by, of all people, Nixon, when he instituted national wage and price controls."
Presumably, all those routes to deregulation will be fiercely debated in the coming months. But in the end, as Dr. Hughes said, if any significant change in rent regulation is enacted, "This will be the great housing experiment."

GRAPHIC: Photos: If unregulated markets work, asks Prof. W. Dennis Keating, left, "why do we have such terrible slums in cities like Houston?" (Barney Taxel for The New York Times); James W. HEADLINE: A Victim of DES Puts Experience Into a Documentary

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER 

 BODY:
JUDITH HELFAND was 14 when she heard about DES, a drug given to five million women from 1938 to 1971 to prevent miscarriages. Ms. Helfand was home from Kennedy High School in Bellmore because of a broken leg when she saw a talk show about DES, the synthetic estrogen diethylstilbestrol, a and its legacy. Of the 2.4 million daughters of the women who took DES, half have malformed reproductive organs or child-bearing problems, and 1 in 1,000 has developed or is expected to develop DES-related cancer.
"I was struck by the idea of these mothers taking a drug to have a baby," Ms. Helfand recalled. "And now these babies can't have babies." 
 It stuck in her mind, and when her mother, Florence, returned home to Merrick from working as a librarian at Roslyn Middle School, the girl told her mother about this "terrible thing."
Ms. Helfand remembers seeing her mother "turn white."
"She couldn't even talk," Ms. Helfand said. "But finally she said, 'Judy, I took that drug and I've known about it since you were 8. I always knew you'd read about it and ask me, and I've been waiting until you were old enough to tell.'
"At that point I knew that my future, my potential, had been challenged. There was a time bomb ticking inside me."
For 18 years DES has played a pre-eminent role in her life. Like so many "DES daughters," she cannot have children. She had a hysterectomy in 1990, when she was given a diagnosis of cervical cancer.
Now Ms. Helfand, a film maker, has created a documentary about her experience, "A Healthy Baby Girl."
The film is one of 15 feature documentaries in competition this week at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, and when the awards are presented on Saturday, her parents will be at her side.
Public television has scheduled the film for the spring.
The 56-minute film chronicles in cinema verite style five years of family life, from the diagnosis of clear-cell adinocarcinoma to the fifth anniversary of the surgery.
There are intimate scenes of Ms. Helfand and her mother and father, Ted, who sells commercial interiors, trying to deal with their grief. At one point Mrs. Helfand tells her daughter that she is depressed because she has no nice clothes or money or a decent place to live, adding, "You don't have what you would like to have."
"On top of that," Ms. Helfand said, "I don't have my reproductive organs."
"Later," she said in an interview, "I realized it was my mother's grasping at things she was able to fix."
For seven years Ms. Helfand went every six months to the DES Screening Center at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park for checkups, with negative results.
"My mom would come with me," Ms. Helfand said, "but never say anything, because I knew she felt so guilty and just couldn't talk about it. So my dad would come, too, making it kind of a family affair."
At 21, when "DES daughters" were thought to be past danger, the Helfands began to relax. "Besides," Ms. Helfand said, "only 1 in 1,000 daughters get cancer, and you never think you'll be the one."
By 1990, Ms. Helfand had credits on her reseume from working on two documentaries on public television, "Through the Wire," a study of women in prison, and "Broken Minds," a look at schizophrenics.
"I had some free time after 'Broken Minds,' and when friends told me about a film on DES that two women were making, I volunteered to do research for them," Ms. Helfand said.
Her colleagues, Darci Picoult and Dina Boogaard, insisted that she have a checkup, which she had avoided because she thought that "at 25 I was over the hump."
"Besides," Ms. Helfand said, "I didn't have health insurance and couldn't afford to see a doctor privately."
Coincidentally her application for group insurance through a professional organization was approved, and she went for an examination. "They found a DES tumor," Ms. Helfand said, "and after more tests and second opinions, surgery was ordered."
The film makers decided to make their movie about Ms. Helfand. "I even considered having them at the house in Merrick when I told my parents," she said. "Luckily my therapist talked me out of it, asking me if I was out of my mind."
She asked her brother Alex, of New Rochelle, a software engineer, to accompany her. Another brother, David, is a special-education teacher in Eugene, Ore.
"When I told them," Ms. Helfand recounted, "my mother ran into the bathroom to cry. My father went into the kitchen, because at a time like that we needed food. I was terrified for my mother, afraid that this would kill her, since she was suffering from Graves' disease," a goiter.
The next hurdle was deciding where Ms. Helfand would recuperate after the surgery. "I wanted to stay in Manhattan with my friends," she said. "I was afraid to go home to heal in the room I had grown up in. Neutered and fixed, coming back to my mother as a baby again.
"But my mother put her foot down, saying, 'I need to take care of you,' and she was right. The six weeks I spent at home marked the beginning of us truly dealing with a DES-exposed life. Why did my parents agree to the documentary? I guess they were so overwhelmed that they had no room to say no. For me the film was a means of escape."
But frustrated because the film makers refused to spend the time that Ms. Helfand thought was necessary , she withdrew. That film, "The Children of DES," was shown on "The Health Quarterly," without her participation.
Ms. Helfand decided to go it alone. Using a cousin's camera, she began keeping a video diary that over five years evolved into "A Healthy Baby Girl."
"Granted I was a little obsessive," Ms. Helfand said. "But the only thing left was this experience, not my reproductive organs. Besides, as a documentary maker I knew that by showing in detail the impact that this experience had on a family, I could tell a story that was personal, but very universal, very public."
Ms. Helfand also wanted to give viewers a message about corporate greed and responsibility and accountability.
"It's not just about DES exposure," she said. "It's a concrete example of all toxic exposure. My cancer and other problems caused by toxic chemicals or improperly tested drugs are a much bigger issue affecting everyone. And grounded in one house, my house, it's told through relationships everybody can relate to."
Major financing was from the Independent Television Service, an arm of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Other grants were from groups like the State Council for the Arts and the Fund for Jewish Documentary Filmmaking-National Foundation for Jewish Culture.
The support from the fund, which Steven Spielberg finances, was especially appropriate, Ms. Helfand said, because the film is a "very Jewish story." Not only because it had a Yiddish scholar as a co-writer, Irena Klepfisz, and has a score by the Klezmatics, but also, she said, because "of the 150,000 women served by the Long Island Jewish Medical Center's DES Screening Center, half are Jewish."
"And while statistics aren't available elsewhere," Ms. Helfand added, "I'd guess that the same holds true in other affluent urban and suburban areas.
"Continuity, or the lack of it, has always played a major role in Jewish life. Just look at the Matriarchs, all of whom were barren, but by hook or by crook managed to bear children. We're always concerned about how we can make it into the future and into the next generation."
To emphasize that connection, Ms. Helfand has been screening the film at synagogues. It will be shown at e the North Country Reform Temple in Glen Cove on Feb. 9.
The screenings are accompanied by discussions led by Rabbi Dianne Cohler-Esses, director of the New York Kollel Feminist Education Project.
When "A Healthy Baby Girl" is shown on television, Ms. Helfand said she hoped similar sessions would cross sectarian, social and economic boundaries.
"I want all people to make that connection between their health, the environment and corporate greed," she said, "so that the DES story won't be replicated over and over again."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Judith Helfand, film maker, and her mother, Florence, who took the drug DES during pregnancy in 1963. (Photo courtesy Ted Helfand, left; Nancy M. Stuart)

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Delano Stewart;
Offering News From a Black Perspective

BYLINE: By THOMAS CLAVIN 

 BODY:
DELANO STEWART is the founder and publisher of Point of View, a bimonthly newspaper that is subtitled, "News and Opinions from the African-American."
Point of View, which is published in Wyandanch, contains articles, columns, reviews and essays that deal specifically with black issues and that address major regional and national issues from that perspective. Mr. Stewart, who has also served as the Long Island campaign coordinator for the Rev. Jesse Jackson, lives in Wyandanch. 
 Q. Why did you start Point of View?
A. Over the years I had been talking to people about the way black communities on Long Island were being portrayed by the media, and we didn't feel that portrayal was accurate nor was there adequate information being shared about black communities. There appeared to be a pattern of misrepresentation. It didn't seem like the mainstream was going to change its views and practices. It was necessary to have another point of view. Thus the publication and its name.
Q. What did you bring to being a newspaper publisher, and why did you take on the responsibility of presenting that other view?
A. I did not have any direct publishing experience. My background includes working in the school system in the late 1970's, being actively involved in several community efforts. By occupation I was an insurance broker.
I had no intention of starting a newspaper. My role, as I saw it, was to prod black people in the media to do it. Though it was discussed, nothing happened. Then I figured if I started a publication, I would embarrass others to jump in and get involved. Well, I was wrong because I began Point of View and no one jumped in. So I kept doing it myself.
Once I was doing it, I learned a lot and became more comfortable. It's been a lot of work. I do or oversee everything and the kitchen sink too, though now there are more people giving of their time and effort. I sold my insurance business to make a full-time commitment. I feel this publication is not only necessary but important because as H. L. Mencken said, "Every civilized people had their own newspaper."
Q. Do you feel that African-Americans on Long Island are treated unfairly by the media or that they are omitted from coverage?
A. It's some of both. The unfair treatment is a result of social conditions. Many people don't see things as being unfair but more like "that's the way things are." For example, there is an unfair rate of taxation in black communities but many good, upstanding, church-going folks will not want to see this or think there is nothing wrong with it, that's just the system and they'll enjoy the advantages of it.
There are unfair portrayals. Recently I picked up a copy of a major Sunday newspaper and counted stories and photos of 27 black people in it. One was a reporter, another was a sports figure and a third was a child. The other 24 were criminals of various kinds. White people in the paper were portrayed as strivers or victims. Day after day of this inevitably leads readers to form conscious and unconscious judgments about African-Americans.
Q. Why are there so few African-American decision-makers in the media?
A. I often read and am confronted with at media-related conferences that the journalism industry takes heart from what they consider incredible improvement in minority hiring. Sure, if you add one black to the black who's already there, you've improved by 100 percent.
In my experience over the last few years, the racial composition of newsrooms bears no relation to the population they serve. That composition has a considerable impact on the tone, quality and balance of reporting.
But on our end, among black people and leaders, we have been slack too. We need to better prepare people, provide them with educational, occupational and other outlets for growth prior to having them enter the newsroom. We need more black community newspapers that can serve as training grounds along with spreading accurate information about black communities. By itself, I don't think the white-dominated major media will instigate significant changes.
Q. On Long Island there appear to be few mixed-race communities. Why are many communities separated by color?
A. Long Island as a whole is one of the most racially segregated communities I know of anywhere. A big reason is very deep-rooted steering practices in real estate. Blacks are simply turned away from open-market housing options. When blacks do make the attempt to integrate communities or blocks, often they are made very uncomfortable, ranging from painful social interaction to criminal activity against them.
I don't like it, but I understand why this happens. A large percentage of Long Islanders have moved out here from the city, especially the Bronx and Brooklyn, to escape the encroachment of minorities, particularly during the so-called "white flight" of the 1960's and 70's. This escape from the developing mix of different colors and cultures was an attempt to set up communities on Long Island that they hoped would be impervious to encroachment. But by being closed, negative and fearful, they are repeating the same mistakes as in the city. You can't run away from a problem; there just isn't that much room left.
Q. Are there ways that blacks are discriminated against illegally that go unnoticed or unreported?
A. The major acts of discrimination are noticed and reported, though they go uncorrected. But what is potentially damaging long-term are the ways of discrimination that are not officially illegal but essentially serve the same purpose. One example is the withholding of services a town is supposed to provide. Point of View did a comparison of the man-hours spent providing taxpayer-supported services in Wyandanch to those provided in surrounding communities, and Wyandanch came up way short. So we're victimized twice, by receiving fewer services and paying more for them, or three times if you consider that black taxpayers help underwrite the services given to white communities. This is institutional discrimination that we know exists but we're unable to correct it, and it is so embedded in the system that it's not news.
One effort to correct the inequality is through Federal block grants. Much of that money ends up going to communities that have already benefitted unfairly. The reason is political leaders try to curry favor with the majority of their constituents. So acts don't have to be illegal to be harmful, and often they are so subtle that they go unnoticed and unreported.
Q. Isn't the court system an opportunity to resolve inequities, and isn't it an option when other measures fail?
A. Yes and no. Yes, in that many laws promoting fairness are on the books. No, in that they aren't applied fairly enough.
In my role as a journalist, I've spent a lot of time in courtrooms. I've seen that when you have two youths, one black and one white, and both have been charged with first offenses, they are treated completely different by the D.A. In one case I saw the white defendant was released on his own recognizance while the black defendant was given $25,000 bail. This difference can have lifelong consequences. However, unless such defendants are in the same court at the same time, the disparate treatment is not so obvious. It goes on all the time, and the far-reaching effects are subtle.
Look at the composition of the court system. The only black judge in Suffolk County was Marquette Floyd, and he was recently appointed to the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court. Now there are none. That has to have an impact on the judicial environment.
Q. Does the political system offer more opportunity?
A. There are no black officeholders that I'm aware of, except for Town Clerk Joan Johnson in Islip, in Suffolk County. A major problem is the structure of county and town elections, where people run at large. No matter how much blacks target their votes, it is very difficult to overcome the majority.
Nassau County is, promisingly, a different story. The switch from a Board of Supervisors to legislative districts -- and I suppose we can thank the court system for this -- has worked to the advantage of black people, with predominantly black districts electing black legislators. Suffolk County, though, has been racially reticent about joining the 20th century.
Q. What would you like to see happen that would enhance racial cooperation that would ultimately benefit Long Island?
A. There has to be a coalition of political and economic power that can be shared or wielded to achieve equality among the races. This won't happen by itself, no matter how much you dream. Black communities have to look to incorporation to have political clout, and from that we will have increased participation in the decision-making processes and the practices at all levels of government on Long Island.
There also has to be an increase in the amount of business development within black communities. We must make ourselves stronger in ways that will be influential and attractive to the overall business community and by extension socially and politically. Many studies and examples have shown that an increase in economic and political power have resulted in a decrease in racial discrimination.
The Village of Hempstead offers such an example. Some years back, as a reaction to the increasing black population and political participation, many white-owned businesses left and for a time the central business area resembled a ghost town. But recently, with black leaders in place, there has been a rebuilding of the economic base and the people involved are doing a terrific job. As a result, some white business owners are coming back and others are starting up in Hempstead. In this climate, there appears to be increasing cooperation between the races for mutual benefit.
The bottom line is developing and promoting an atmosphere devoid of fear, mistrust and disrespect. We all want to make Long Island a better place to live.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Delano Stewart, the publisher of Point of View. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Homeowner Faults Utility Over Cutting Down Trees

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: LEWISBORO

 BODY:
WHEN Jacqueline F. Oliva built her house here 27 years ago, she chose a heavily wooded plot for its privacy and tranquillity. The house, designed to nestle into the landscape, was set back nearly 200 feet from the road, and Ms. Oliva ruled out a lawn in order to let the forest grow free.
Nearly three decades of privacy were wiped out in one day, however, when New York State Electric and Gas recently cut a wide swath through mature trees and saplings on Ms. Oliva's property. Now passing motorists can see her at work in her kitchen, and her own view of webbed branches has been replaced by two exposed utility poles. 
 The power company, which had an easement on the property, says it was only doing what was necessary to keep the lights on in Ms. Oliva's neighborhood. Ms. Oliva, on the other hand, says the company butchered her land. She is especially outraged because she says the electric company went back on several agreements it had made with her about its wire-clearing plans.
Ms. Oliva says her experience is a cautionary tale for homeowners, because she took pains to avoid excessive cutting. At the least, the dispute highlights the potential clash that can occur wherever there are overhead wires, between the public's demand for safe, reliable power and its love of high-arching, sheltering trees.
Ms. Oliva, a criminal lawyer, said her anguish began when she arrived home from her office one recent night.
"The car's headlights picked up what looked to me like another driveway," she said. "My stomach sank; my heart pounded, and I screamed. They had cut 86 feet in from the road. It took me three days before I could walk that land. I couldn't look out my kitchen window."
Ms. Oliva, knowing that the electric company had an easement covering 10 feet to either side of the wires leading to the two utility poles on her property, said she had carefully arranged with the company to be home when tree trimming took place. She met with a representative of Tree Preservation Company, the contractor hired to do the job, and agreed in advance to the removal of "four or five trees." Later, she met with an electric company forester to discuss a mature ash whose health was in dispute.
Soon afterward, the electric company left a message on Ms. Oliva's office answering machine saying that the trimming would take place before the scheduled date. What she did not know, Ms. Oliva said, was that the trimming was taking place that very day.
"Had she said, 'We're cutting today,' I would have borrowed a car and run home," Ms. Oliva said, as trees outside her living room window swayed in the stark winter light. "I would never have stood by and let them do what they did."
In all, she said, 61 trees, including the ash and many saplings, were removed from an area 86 feet long and 20 feet wide. "I think they went beyond the easement because the easement says they have the right to cut 'to the extent necessary.' Rather than topping the trees, they cut them to the ground, and that was beyond the extent necessary. Besides that, I measured, and I think two trees might be outside the easement."
She continued: "I would have preferred to have just trunks standing. I would have been dismayed, but there wouldn't have been the devastation there is now."
William P. Morrison, operations manager for the electric company, upheld the company's right to cut trees on Ms. Oliva's property, but said he would not comment on her complaints because of a possible lawsuit. (Ms. Oliva said she is negotiating with the company to restore plantings and has no immediate plans to sue.) Mr. Morrison said the company had cleared branches and trees along 154 miles during the fall, and that out of 2,400 property owners, only Ms. Oliva had been dissatisfied.
"In many cases, our representatives have been greeted with open arms because of all the outages," he said, referring to the aftermath of recent storms. Mr. Morrison added that the company removes trees "that are going to grow up into the lines," especially along the "least reliable circuits." Since trimming is only done every four or five years, he said, significant cuts must be made in order to allow tree branches to bend under the weight of snowfall.
"You have to weigh economics in there somewhere," he said. "You can't clip six inches or a foot and come back every six months."
Trimming is also done to comply with laws relating to the safety of workers, he said. Workers in trees close to power lines must be protected from electric shock.
In order to work cooperatively with the public, Mr. Morrison said, New York State Electric and Gas, which operates largely in northern Westchester County and farther north, hires real estate agents to go door to door notifying residents of the planned cutting. Foresters become involved if there are disagreements, but usually the electric company prevails, he said. "If a person says the company has no right of way, one of our real estate people goes to our files and digs out a copy of the actual easement," he said. "That usually resolves the final problem."
He said he himself reviews any further disputes, implying that he has little patience with a heels-dug-in attitude. "If you've cut across 999 property owners and made that circuit safe, what do you do about that last customer?" he asked. "Exercise your rights of way or just ignore it?"
Consolidated Edison follows a similar notification procedure in southern Westchester, William Lent, a spokesman, said. But he added that the company, which operates with only a 6- to 8-foot easement on either side of its wires, was "not as aggressive as other utilities are" in tree clearing. "We're trying to be less visual in what we do," he said. "We don't want to cut those big holes in the middle of the trees so our wires can get through."
In the quest for a balance between natural beauty on the one hand and safety and efficiency on the other, many regard buried power lines as an obvious solution. But Mr. Morrison said underground wires -- besides being expensive -- can be even more trouble than overhead ones. "In order to put underground cables into a three-inch-deep ditch off the road, you'd have to cut trees to get the cable installed," he said. "You'd have to keep it free of trees to keep roots from growing into the cable."
As a result, he said, "You'd have to keep clearing trees even more than with overhead wires."

Oliva surveys her property in Lewisboro, where New York State Electric and Gas cut down trees. (Roberta Hershenson for The New York Times) (pg. 13)
