HEADLINE: The Power Women Share as Lobbyists

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE president of a prominent taxpayers' group has discounted them as "self-annointed do-gooders" who squander public money. And the chairman of the county chapter of the Christian Coalition recently claimed their "so-called people's agenda" was a front for Planned Parenthood. But judging by the handprint that the Westchester Women's Agenda left on the county's latest budget, the impact of their political influence is difficult to deny -- their critics' sentiments notwithstanding.
During a budget process that was as contentious as any in recent memory -- in-fights over privatization and taxes and the proper role of government -- elected officials said it was clear that the newly formed feminist group had become a lobbying force to be reckoned with. 
 And while their roots are in a gentle tradition of volunteerism and ministering to the needy, their strength now lies in the fact that 53 percent of registered voters in the county -- as in the rest of the country -- are women.
"The numbers tell the story: it's happening everywhere," said Camille Murphy, director of the Westchester Office for Women and an ex officio member of the Women's Agenda.
"Finally," she said, "feminists are using their vote and their voice to influence government."
Ms. Murphy, who is also the president of the National Association of Commissions for Women, which represents 270 offices for women in the United States, said that as governments at all levels seek to downsize and as women and children's issues are increasingly at risk, feminist lobbying groups are intensifying efforts to protect their interests.
Leaving earlier endeavors behind, some feminists with political agendas -- in Westchester, as in other parts of the United States -- have parted ways with organizations like the League of Women Voters, where many cut their teeth on public policy issues.
Claiming that the League and similar groups lack real clout because they do not endorse candidates, the Westchester Women's Agenda formed a political action committee and endorsed its first slate of state legislative candidates sympathetic to their issues last fall.
In its two-year history, the Women's Agenda has taken on the business of child care, women's health, domestic violence and affirmative action. Untroubled by criticisms that they are little more than domestic do-gooders -- "It's better than being called do-badders," said Amy Paulin, a founding member -- they tick off a list of legislative accomplishments so far:
During the 1995 county budget negotiations, they lobbied successfully to establish a supervised visitation program in Westchester for children and custodial parents who are at risk of physical, sexual or other kinds of abuse from the non-custodial parent. That allotment -- $160,000 -- has been continued in subsequent budgets.
In 1996 they won $200,000 in state and county money to provide services for victims of domestic violence. And they advocated for the creation of a countywide domestic violence council, which was formed. For 1997, they persuaded the Board of Legislators and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to allocate about $150,000 to establish a supervision program for abusive spouses or companions through the county's criminal courts program.
Also, they are in part responsible for obtaining $1.7 million for three county neighborhood health centers. And they lobbied for $4.2 million in county day-care subsidies for children of working poor families.
County Legislator George S. Latimer, a Democrat from city of Rye and the minority leader on the 17-member Board of Legislators, described the impact of the Women's Agenda on the budget process in recent years as profound.
But critics see them otherwise and question whether public money should be spent on their agenda. "Not only do they not represent all women, they don't represent all taxpayers," said Kelly Jones, president of the Taxpayers' Alliance of New York, a 500-member anti-tax advocacy group. "If they are so concerned about families, where do they stand in terms of easing the tax burden?"
Mr. Jones, who in another role is Deputy Commissioner for the state's Department of Economic Development, also challenged the feminist group's concern for the needy, saying that "moral sentiment is not a substitute for political passion."
Another critic, Wendy L. Holibaugh, chairwoman of the Westchester Christian Coalition, wrote in a letter to the editor of Gannett Suburban Newspapers, that "promulgation of such issues as abortion and family planning is nothing but a front for Planned Parenthood, an organization that receives big tax dollars to undermine parental authority and push sales of abortion and birth control services onto young people without parental knowledge or consent."
Last week, Mrs. Holibaugh said: "Certainly the group doesn't represent conservative women in the county. They're trying to push through a liberal Democratic agenda as though it is everyone's agenda, and that just isn't so."
Mrs. Holibaugh, a single mother of three children, opposes money in the budget for day care and advocates instead tax breaks for families "so that mothers can stay home."
The Christian Coalition, a national organization with state and local chapters, represents an alliance of "evangelicals, Catholics and other people of faith that seek to enact public policy friendly to the family," according to its literature.
Mrs. Holibaugh said the aim of the coalition is "to get churchgoers out of the pews and into the party process."
Countering the opposition, Polly Rothstein, a steering committee member and president of the Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion, a 25-year-old advocacy group, denied that the Women's Agenda was a front for Planned Parenthood but said the group was clearly concerned with women's reproductive health issues.
"Our bottom line is abortion rights, and no candidate will get endorsed who is not pro-choice," she said. "However, if someone is only pro-choice and terrible on everything else, they won't get an endorsement either."
Citing the positive side of the opposition, she observed that Mr. Jones and Mrs. Holibaugh's criticisms were "a clear indication that our message is getting through."
Also in response to the opposition, Charlotte A. Watson, a member of the Women's Agenda steering committee and executive director of My Sisters' Place, a domestic violence service and shelter, said that the group did indeed represent the views of most women -- and men as well.
She suggested that the intensity of the group's efforts was in part responsible for some of the opposition.
"Some of us have been willing to risk everything for this, and, yes, we're coming on very strong," she said. "But we're not going to back down." County officials, however, said they were not put off by the group's political power brokering -- or its decision to endorse candidates.
"We take them very seriously," County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said. "They're where the issues are."
With the county's $956.6 million budget representing less than a 1 percent increase over last year, Mr. O'Rourke observed that taxpayers' groups should have little to complain about.
County Legislator Paul J. Noto, a Republican from Mamaroneck and majority leader of the Board of Legislators, said he was not troubled by the group's apparently liberal agenda.
"And I don't see their point of view as either Republican or Democratic," he said. "Their issues are legitimate and cut across party and socioeconomic lines."
Mr. Noto added: "For that matter, I don't see the issues as necessarily liberal or conservative. If they're working to strengthen collection of child-support payments, then that's actually a conservative issue, because it saves taxpayers money and gets people off the welfare rolls. Actually, it's a good Republican issue, too."
A question facing the Women's Agenda is whether the organization will be able to maintain its momemtum. As Stephen P. Tenore, previous chairman of the Board of Legislators and a former political mentor to some members of the organization, said: "The real test of any group, and this one is no exception, is their staying power. I saw many well-meaning groups come and go in the last few years of my political career, and right now, it's too soon to tell about this one."

HEADLINE: Trying to Keep Alive Nobel Laureate's Ideas

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH FOLBERTH 

DATELINE: BRONXVILLE

 BODY:
THE last time C. Lowell Harriss, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University, saw William Vickrey, his friend and colleague of 61 years, he said Professor Vickrey was "just the epitome of happiness."
"He was obviously on top of the world," he added. 
 The occasion was a champagne reception at Columbia on the day Professor Vickrey learned that he had won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. Finally, the gentle visionary, who had been proposing practical economic solutions to everyday problems like traffic jams and crowded subways since the 1950's, seemed to have found his bully pulpit and. Professor Vickrey said, after learning of the prize, the "chance to spread some economic sense into the nonsense world."
On Oct. 10, three days after the public began to pay attention to the work of a lifetime, Professor Vickrey, 82, suffered a heart attack and was found dead at the wheel of his car on the Hutchinson River Parkway, not many miles from his home in Hastings-on-Hudson. Two months later, Professor Harriss accepted the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in Stockholm on behalf of his friend. He returned determined to be a missionary, to make sure that Professor Vickrey's ideas and ideals continue to get a valid hearing.
The two men met when both began graduate study in economics at Columbia in 1935. They worked together at the United States Treasury during World War II and were colleagues on the faculty at Columbia University for almost 50 years. Their wives were good friends.
Yet even Professor Harriss did not appreciate the full measure of his friend's brilliance until Professor Vickrey was given the Nobel award. In Stockholm, Professor Harriss said he was stunned by the extensive international admiration for Professor Vickrey's work.
"What is the saying?" Professor Harriss said with a chuckle, in a recent interview at his home here. " 'A prophet is not without honor, save in his own country, and in his own house,' something like that. People in Westchester, around here, didn't know the qualities of this neighbor they had.
"I have known almost all of the persons who have gotten the Nobel Prize in economics since it was instituted in 1969," added Professor Harriss, who was inspired to reread Professor Vickrey's book, "Public Economics," "and there's none, absolutely none, who has the range of content or subject matter that my friend had. Just one subject after another in which he did innovative work.
"He was a Quaker," he said. "I don't know what he believed theologically but in terms of human conduct, he was the epitome of what could be fine in human character and behavior. He believed that economic knowledge could help human beings get more out of life."
Professor Harriss, 84, sat on a loveseat, surrounded by gilt-engraved invitations, elaborate menus, books, posters and other memorabilia from his weeklong stay in Stockholm.
Shaking his head in awe, he recounted the pomp and circumstance of the constant round of gala events, including a luncheon at the American Embassy and being feted by the King and Queen of Sweden at the palace, spectacular occasions "like you read in storybooks or see in the movies."
Professor Harriss's was a special case. Only once before in the 100-year history of the awards had a recipient died before he could receive a prize, said Kristina Fallenius of the Nobel Foundation. That was in 1931 when the Swedish author Erik Axel Karlfeldt died before he could receive his Nobel Prize in Literature. Mr. Karlfeldt'swidow attended the ceremony in the Concert Hall but was seated in the audience. Professor Harriss was seated on the dais and accorded the same dignity and attention as the other Nobel laureates.
There was only one subtle difference dictated by the Nobel Foundation for Professor Harriss's appearance. After accepting Professor Vickrey's award, Professor Harriss bowed only to KingCarl XVI Gustav while the other laureates bowed to the King, then to the chairman of the Swedish Academy of Sciences, then to the audience.
Cecile Vickrey, Professor Vickrey's wife of 45 years and his sole survivor, was unable to travel to Stockholm, hampered by both ill health and grief. But the Harriss family was represented by three generations: Professor Harriss's grandson, Christopher, 20, a sophomore at Columbia University, and Professor Harriss's son, Brian, 47, of Greenwich. Professor Harriss said of the experience, "These people are at the pinnacle of their careers, leaders in the world, and having the opportunity to associate with them is a privilege that only very few people in the whole civilization will ever have."
Professor Harriss said that many of the laureates he met were shy, unassuming scholars who like Professor Vickrey had waited years for recognition of their work. One reason for his friend's relative obscurity was that the ideas he was proposing, in the 1940's through 60's -- like congestion pricing for subway and bus fares or averaging income for tax purposes over a lifetime -- were so innovative that the technology did not yet exist to make them feasible. Technology is just now catching up with his vision.
Professor Harriss is not alone in trying to keep Professor Vickrey's ideas alive. Professor Vickrey's last paper, "Fifteen Fatal Fallacies of Financial Fundamentalism," is posted on Columbia's economics department's Web site, http://www.columbia.edu/cu/economics. On April 28, a conference at Columbia University , involving the tristate Regional Planning Association, will focus on Professor Vickrey's transportation proposals.
"Vickrey was deprived of the bully pulpit," said Dan O'Flaherty, associate professor of economics and public affairs at Columbia University and an organizer of the conference, "so we're trying to let the world hear some of the things that would have been said from the bully pulpit."
Before his trip to Stockholm Professor Harriss tried out his missionary role by speaking to the international relations group of the League of Women Voters of Bronxville.
"His talk kept the audience spellbound," said Elsie Hall, chairwoman of the committee. "His presentation of Vickrey's economics opened up a new world for us. Not much abstract theory, but a definite conviction that with Vickrey's ideas everybody could be better off. Lowell put his listeners in everyday situations of frustration: behind the wheel of their cars, sitting in a traffic jam.
"Vickrey's solution was to put stickers on cars and cameras in much trafficked areas that would note time of day and subsequently bill car owners. Many drivers would thus choose to avoid rush-hour traffic," she continued. "That solution was ridiculed as cumbersome and indisputably unworkable when Vickrey proposed it. Note today's E-Z Pass at toll booths. All through Lowell's talk we were astonished by how adventuresome and exciting economics could be."
Ms. Hall said the League of Women Voters of Bronxville has asked Professor Harriss to speak again on Feb. 6 at 7:30 P.M. at the Reformed Church in Bronxville. The meeting is free and open to the public.

HEADLINE: MUGGED BY REALITY

 BODY:
"Why so much anger" about the welfare system? Not, as Jason DeParle's article "Mugged by Reality" (Dec. 8) suggests, because David T. Ellwood's ideas have been hijacked and brutalized by the conservatives but because the ideas remain locked within the flawed logic of welfare. Cash entitlements -- the basis of the welfare system -- are simply inconsistent with the principle of work.
The only way to "end welfare as we know it" is to end the welfare system. Not abruptly, all at once, but gradually, over a period of a generation. 
 As individuals reach the age of, say, 18, they should have the right to register not for welfare but for work -- a system with three basic elements: job counseling and training; job placement and government as the employer of last resort. The guarantee of a stipend would be replaced by the guarantee of work.
Because it would change a whole generation's view of work and of government's responsibility for the individual citizen, it would rehabilitate an entire lost segment of society, with inevitable benefit to the economy.
 
JOHN SHARNIK
Rowayton, Conn.

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
Wall Street Meets Main Street, Not Far From Chicago

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
THE 87,000 residents of Elgin, Ill., are about to get a 10-month, $2 million course in personal finance, compliments of Money magazine, with some help from Fidelity Investments, the Nasdaq stock market and Microsoft.
The project -- whose goal is to raise the "financial I.Q." of Elgin residents -- is part of the magazine's run-up to its 25th anniversary issue in October. The events will begin on Jan. 29 with an introductory session for the entire town that will feature former President George Bush. Highlights in coming months will include: 
 * Free seminars with Money editors and reporters.
* Workshops to teach adults and children about specific money matters like investing, saving, retirement planning and reducing taxes.
* Consultations between Elgin residents and certified financial planners.
* A free one-year subscription to Money for each household in the town.
The magazine will conduct a poll at the beginning and the end of the project to document its progress. And each month, beginning with the current February issue, articles will track the progress of individual families toward their financial goals.
Money says it chose Elgin, 38 miles northwest of Chicago, because it is a "virtual mirror of America," with a diverse population and incomes and property values that are near national averages.
Frank Lalli, Money's managing editor, has written that the project was selected over a traditional fancy party for advertisers as a way to celebrate the magazine's 25 years.
Sounds like a win-win proposition for all concerned. The folks in Elgin may well gain from the financial advice, and some of those free subscriptions are bound to turn into paying ones for Money. The other companies, which are picking up some of the expenses, will also pick up a lot of good will. Fidelity might attract some customers, and the Nasdaq some investors. And tracking investments would be a lot easier on new computer software. Right, Bill Gates?
 
BACK TO THE LAND In their February issues, four personal finance magazines take a look at real estate investments. Kiplinger's and Individual Investor like real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, while Money advocates buying rental property directly.
Worth takes a different approach. In a cover report, the magazine examines the pros and cons of owning land -- acres and acres of it, that is. It suggests ways to make the investment work, including farming, timber operations and hunting leases.
Worth also compares returns on land with those of stocks and gold. During the last nine years, timberland has produced an annualized return of 21.87 percent; farmland, 6.26 percent, and other property, 3.74 percent. During the same period, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has returned 14.8 percent annually. And gold? Since 1985, it has produced a miserly 1.7 percent a year.
 
A MATTER OF INTEREST Money's Michael Sivy, in a forecast for the year, argues that rising credit-card debt could lead to a stock market drop of 15 percent or more. Consumer debt stands at $1.2 trillion, up 52 percent over the last three years, and a typical adult has nine credit cards and a total balance of almost $4,000. Mr. Sivy contends that these factors will undercut the economy and hold down corporate growth, leading to a setback for stocks this year. But he also expects that they will soon come "roaring back."
In another article, Money throws one of its occasional punches at credit-card issuers ("plastic peddlers," the magazine calls them) for what it says are excessively high interest rates and other charges. The magazine conducted a survey in which readers overwhelmingly endorsed proposed legislation aimed at curbing some practices, like assessing huge penalties on card holders who miss a single payment, or charging fees to people who pay their balances in full each month.
Smart Money and Kiplinger's also weigh in on the subject. In Smart Money, Nelson D. Schwartz and Scott Medintz provide a useful guide to the best and worst credit-card deals, and offer some strategies for getting the most out of a card. Kiplinger's points out some favorable deals for credit-worthy customers.
 
PICKING MUTUAL FUNDS Money and Smart Money have splashy cover articles on their favorite mutual funds for 1997 -- and the two lists share not a single fund. Money's 11 "winners you can count on," in various categories, are: Brandywine, T. Rowe Price Equity-Income, Managers Special Equity, EuroPacific Growth, Ivy International A, Merrill Lynch Developing Capital Markets B, Vanguard Bond Index Fund -- Total Bond Market, Merrill Lynch Corporate High Income B, Loomis Sayles Bond, Vanguard Municipal Intermediate Term and Dodge & Cox Balanced.
Smart Money's seven "best mutual funds for 1997" are Legg Mason Value Trust, Third Avenue Value, Janus Worldwide, Longleaf Partners Small-Cap, T. Rowe Price Growth Stock, Mairs & Power Growth and Scudder Growth and Income.
 
FLYING HIGH Individual Investor looks beyond the proposed merger of Boeing and McDonnell Douglas and sees a potential boom for three suppliers to the new, combined aircraft maker: BE Aerospace, Fairchild and Ducommun. BE, based in Wellington, Fla., makes aircraft interior fittings. Fairchild, whose headquarters are at Dulles International Airport near Washington, supplies an average of $900,000 worth of bolts and fasteners for every plane Boeing builds. Ducommun, which supplies various parts to the aerospace industry, is described as well-suited for work on the new Boeing 777. Individual Investor provides good research on these companies and is careful not to overlook risks.
 
BITS AND PIECES Kiplinger's sees good growth in four oilfield-service companies and examines on-line computer services. . . . Smart Money has a guide to good restaurants at or near some big United States airports. . . . Individual Investor's cover article examines the fickle fashion business.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Conducting An Energy Audit

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
UNLIKE space shuttles and Mason jars, houses are not meant to be airtight. Some houses, however, are better than others at letting outside air in. And what may be good in moderation turns to bad when what is leaking into your house is a lot of cold winter air.
Rather than just bundling up and bearing it, however, homeowners can use winter's onslaught to their advantage: There is no better time than now to conduct a home energy audit. 
 "In all likelihood, any house built more than 15 years ago and never upgraded could benefit from an energy audit," said Alex Wilson, editor and publisher of Environmental Building News, a trade journal in Brattleboro, Vt.
An energy audit, Mr. Wilson said, is used to determine the efficiency of a home's heating system and to pinpoint where energy is being lost.
Professional energy auditors, Mr. Wilson said, will typically use special tools -- like infrared cameras, smoke pencils and blower doors -- to prepare a highly detailed assessment of problems and recommended solutions.
John Lyon, the owner of Energy Services Group, a diagnostic and consulting company in Frazer, Pa., said that when he conducts a home energy audit he gives the house an infrared scan.
An infrared scanner, Mr. Lyon said, like an infrared camera, will display differences in temperature when pointed at a surface. Accordingly, he said, an infrared scan conducted from inside the house will reveal not only the areas of cold air infiltration, but areas of walls and floors that are warmer or colder than adjoining areas.
"We can see heat ducts, water pipes, even the studs in the wall," Mr. Lyon said, adding that the infrared scan will also reveal areas of inadequate or nonexistent insulation.
After the scan, he said, he will then conduct a pressurization test using a blower door -- a fan with expandable sides and top that allow it to fit snugly in a doorway -- to draw air out of the house.
"When we suck air out of a house, the outside air comes in through all the points of leakage," Mr. Lyon said, explaining that while the outside air is coming in, another infrared scan is taken to determine where the house is leaking -- thereby allowing the homeowner to take action later to plug the leaks with caulking or insulation.
In houses with hot-air heating systems, Mr. Lyon said, an energy auditor should also perform a duct-flow analysis test to assess the integrity of the ductwork in the home.
In such a test, he said, the air blowing out of the system through delivery vents is measured and compared with the amount of air going back into the system through return vents. Since it is more efficient to have previously heated air reheated, Mr. Lyon said, the closer the two numbers are, the better.
"You want the system to be as tight as possible," he said. "So if you're delivering 1,000 cubic feet of air per minute into the house, and only 300 feet per minute is going back into the system, then the system's getting air from somewhere else." That "somewhere else," Mr. Lyon said, is typically from unheated areas of the house -- like the basement or attic.
To pinpoint where air is leaking into the system, he said, an auditor will use a smoke pencil -- a pencil-shaped device that emits white smoke to search for points in the system where the smoke is either sucked in or puffed away -- an indication of a leak that can then be sealed.
Most homeowners, of course, don't have access to infrared scanners, blower doors or smoke pencils. They can, however, conduct their own mini-pressurization test by closing all doors and windows and turning on ventilation fans in kitchens and bathrooms. They can then use an incense stick to smoke out areas of air infiltration around windows, doors, baseboards, electrical outlets and at seams in ductwork.
Homeowners can also conduct their own energy audit by calculating the total efficiency of their house and its heating system.
"It's easiest when you heat with fuel oil because in most cases, oil is only used for heat," said Mr. Wilson of Environmental Building News. In some houses, he said, the oil-fired furnace is also used to heat household hot water, making an assessment of heating costs alone difficult. Houses that use gas or electricity for heat, he said, pose even greater problems because those energy sources are typically used for other purposes -- such as cooking and running household appliances.
John Morrill, a spokesman for the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, a public interest organization in Washington, said that homeowners can assess the efficiency of their heating system by first calculating the B.T.U.'s used during the last year, from July 1 to June 30. Since one gallon of oil produces 138,000 B.T.U.'s of heat, the total number of B.T.U.'s used can be calculated by multiplying the gallons of oil used during the season -- a figure that can be obtained from the oil supplier -- by 138,000.
They should then calculate the total square footage of the heated area of their home, and, finally, determine the total number of "degree days" for their area during the 1995-1996 heating season.
(Degree days are calculated by taking the average of the day's highest and lowest temperatures and then subtracting the result from 65. So, for example, a day with a low of 30 and high of 50 would equal 25 degree days. The total number of degree days for last year's heating season -- which varies from one area to another -- can usually be obtained from local fuel oil dealers, who use the figure to estimate when customers need fuel deliveries.)
Once the necessary numbers have been calculated, Mr. Morrill said, homeowners should divide the total number of B.T.U.'s used by the total square footage of the heated space in the house, and then divide the result by the total degree days for the heating season.
"You end up with B.T.U.'s per square foot per degree day," Mr. Morrill said. "An average home should be somewhere between 8 and 12." The higher the number, the more potential there is for efficiency improvements. If the result is higher than 12, he said, the homeowner should try to identify the cause of the problem -- which could be an inefficient furnace, insufficient insulation, or a combination of the two.
"I've personally poked my head into attics from Massachusetts to California," Mr. Morrill said. "And although the country has been more energy aware over the last 25 years, there are still millions of homes with pathetic levels of insulation."
Generally, Mr. Morrill said, homes in the Northeast should have at least six inches of insulation in their attics.
In many cases, the efficiency of a heating plant can be assessed by the fuel supplier. Most fuel oil suppliers will provide customers with a furnace inspection for a nominal fee, and an annual tuneup for about $100. Gas customers can call their local utility for similar services.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Warehouses;
For Developers, It's Raise High the Roof Beams

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE 1950's-era factory building on Andrews Road in Hicksville, L.I., is a curious sight: Its walls stop at a one-story height, but the roof, like a raised eyebrow, stands 11 feet higher with nothing but a network of steel columns attaching it to the structure below.
The building, owned by Reckson Associates Realty Company of nearby Melville, is an indication of a trend in industrial property: Warehouses are getting taller as operators push to handle more goods in the same place. 
 Warehouses occupy an important if seldom noticed place in the chain of commerce. They are the place where products are stored after being shipped from manufacturers and before being sorted for shipment to retailers for sale to customers.
"There has been a steady progression in warehouse height from under 20 feet in the 1960's to the mid- to high 30's currently," said William L. Mascharka, president of Frazier Industrial Company in Long Valley, N.J., which manufactures the racks used to hold material stored in the buildings. The racks make it possible to organize the inventory in a warehouse and to quickly load and remove containers -- doing so would be a slower, more difficult process if pallets were stacked on top of each other.
Mr. Mascharka said improved lifting equipment, some of it developed in Europe, had made the more vertical operations practical in recent years.
Brokers said the scarcity of unoccupied land close to New York City and the consequent rising price had also induced warehouse operators to look upward. "As land costs get higher, you end up paying less for cubic feet than square feet," said Ronald Shalom, chairman of SBWE Inc., an industrial and retail brokerage in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. "Existing buildings with 12 to 16 feet of clear space under the roof are obsolete."
Mr. Shalom said the lack of large tracts of space close to New York had also been driving distribution companies to locations farther from the city. "The Meadowlands are pretty well built up," he said. "So the new development is taking place in central New Jersey."
Another trend leading to the construction of bigger, higher warehouses is the desire of companies to reduce the number of separate locations they are operating. "There is a trend to fewer but larger warehouses," said Eugene A. Preston, director of marketing for the International Trade Center in Mount Olive, N.J., a project of Rockefeller Center Development Corporation.
He said newer warehouses were being constructed with 300,000 square feet of floor space or more, compared to the 100,000- to 200,000-square-foot facilities that were standard in the past. Mr. Preston said the center already contained 2 million square feet of warehouse space and was prepared to build more on a recently acquired 250-acre site adjacent to the existing property.
"We can put up one as big as 1 million square feet, or several at 300,000 square feet," he said.
He said new technology was helping to make the new buildings more economical. "There have been tremendous developments in sprinkler technology," Mr. Preston said. "The new, high-efficiency sprinkler heads can dump an enormous amounts of water."
This means a warehouse only needs one set of sprinkler pipes installed near the roof to suppress fires. The alternative is putting sprinklers at each level of a rack system, which could involve four or five times as much piping.
Taller buildings also demand more precision in construction. If, for example, floors are not all but perfectly flat, at 45 feet high, the forks of a lift truck could be several inches out of alignment with the pallet it is attempting to remove.
Industrial real estate specialists caution that very high warehouses need costly automated equipment. "If you have a 40 or 50 foot building, you are going to need a robotic system that follows guidewires in the floor and ceiling while somebody works a computer," said Ben Katz, a managing director of Insignia/ESG, the new name for the former Edward S. Gordon Company.
HE said most existing warehouses in the heavily industrialized areas between Exits 8A and 10 along the New Jersey Turnpike are of a medium height, although he acknowledges pressure to build new buildings taller. "For now, the Turnpike crowd will accept 24 feet," he said.
But that leaves a lot of buildings erected as manufacturing plants in the early post-World War II era, with single-story horizontal layout, languishing on the market.
The building on Andrews Road was built to house a factory producing aluminum storm doors and windows. In the fashion of the time, the 175,000-square-foot structure was built with a clear height of just 14 feet and a band of windows around the top to admit some natural light for factory workers.
It was acquired in foreclosure by a bank and sat empty for about six years until it was bought by Reckson last year. "Buildings like this were typical of the early industrial market in the Hicksville area," said Gregg Rechler, an executive vice president of Reckson.
Mr. Rechler said the company decided to buy the building and reposition it by raising the roof so it could function as a modern warehouse. "We were able to buy it at a pretty good discount to replacement value," he said. "We are raising the roof and going to put on a new skin, new mechanicals and modern lighting."
He said the location close to the Long Island Expressway, the Cross Island Parkway and other roads should make the structure attractive to distributors. "There is not a lot of this type of product in this location," he said.
The roof lift is being managed by another Melville-based company, Space Technology, which markets a technology developed by Industrial Service Enterprises of Dover, N.J.
To do the lift, the existing columns are cut at the floor level and then encased in a sturdy steel sleeve. Hydraulic jacks at the top of the sleeves then lift the old columns at the rate of a foot an hour. The roof goes up intact, with its structure, lighting, piping and rooftop equipment undisturbed.
The roof on Andrews Road was lifted 11 feet, from 14 feet of clear space to 25 feet, because of the need to keep about three feet of old column within the sleeve, so the two can be securely bolted together. The new upper area will be sheathed with insulated steel panels, to keep out the weather and to give the building an attractive appearance. The band of windows, which would be of no value to a warehouse operation, will be eliminated.
Roof raising is becoming increasing popular as a way of recycling old buildings, said Gregory Benson, a vice president of Industrial Service Enterprises. "It was pretty spotty in the past, but for the last three or four years we have had a steady flow of work."
Brokers specializing in industrial properties said that roof-raising costs from $6 to $10 a square foot, far less than it would cost to demolish an old structure and build a new one. Nevertheless, they say, the economics work best on larger properties because the return on a 20,000- or 30,000-square-foot building usually does not justify a renovation project.
GOING up rather than out, as had been the practice in the past, avoids a host of problems, said Jeffrey R. Allen, a partner in Space Technologies. No new land needs to be purchased, and the often-contentious process of getting government approvals is truncated.
"If you do not build out, you do not have to worry about zoning changes," Mr. Allen said. "That means it is a building permit issue, not a planning board issue."
Raising an existing roof means a building can be quickly back into operation, said Stuart I. Goldring, another official of Space Technologies. "With electricity, you can splice a loop into existing cable that unfolds as the lift proceeds. With the sprinklers, you turn them off during the lift, put in a new section of vertical pipe afterward, and you are back in business."
Mr. Rechler said Reckson decided to rehabilitate the building on a speculative basis because "it is pretty hard to get across to the user what it will be without doing the work." He said he started hearing from brokers after the first of four sections of the roof was hoisted.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gregory Benson of Industrial Service Enterprises at warehouse roof-lifting project in Hicksville, L.I. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
In Just a Year, Reckson Gains a Major Role in County

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
FROM a perch atop a pyramidal office building that looks like something out of "Star Trek," Salvatore Campofranco surveys the 1.2 million-square-foot Tarrytown Corporate Center below him with satisfaction and some surprise.
Since Reckson Associates Realty Corporation entered the Westchester market last year by purchasing 768,000 square feet of the office space in the complex on Route 119 just east of Tarrytown, the property has consistently outperformed the market and has now reached nearly full occupancy, said Mr. Campofranco, managing director of Reckson's Westchester Division. 
 When Reckson bought the Tarrytown Corporate Center from Halpern Enterprises "occupancy was at about 90 percent," Mr. Campofranco said. "Now it's 96 percent, and we expect it to reach 98 percent soon."
Reckson, now a real estate investment trust based in Melville, L.I., started out as a family business on Long Island in 1962. It now owns or has under contract 9.3 million square feet of office and industrial space in the New York metropolitan area.
Last year, it completed the $86 million purchase of most of developer Jon L. Halpern's office portfolio, which included eight buildings with a total of 935,000 square feet. Five are in the corporate park. Reckson has since added two additional buildings with total of 181,000 square feet.
Since taking over the Westchester Division in June, Mr. Campofranco said he had been so busy trying to meet the needs of his tenants and signing new leases that he had not had time to unpack boxes or even carve out space for his own office.
He is currently working out of a windowless cubbyhole in a nondescript inner sanctum of 660 White Plains Road, which is the flagship building in the park.
In the tight space, Mr. Campofranco has piles of boxes and papers teetering precariously in every direction. The floor is covered with carpet remnants that don't meet in places, exposing large sections of the cement floor.
"It came down to whether I was going to spend time working on my office or helping the tenants with their needs," he explained. "In real estate, there's always been a philosophy that you'd move into the basement if necessary in order to keep the best space for your tenants."
"When I look at the office vacancy reports, they don't reflect my experience or the excitement I see," he continued. "We have companies that are expanding and need more space and new companies coming in. It's been very dynamic."
The Tarrytown Corporate Center is situated in a section of the county known as the western corridor. Most of that area's buildings are concentrated along Route 119 inside and just outside Tarrytown.
LAST year, the corridor posted a 9.4 percent vacancy rate, down from 13.8 percent the year before, according to the Edward S. Gordon Company, a commercial brokerage.
"If you looked at our properties alone," Mr. Campofranco said, "the rate has got to be at historic lows. It doesn't get much better."
Reckson now owns about one-seventh of the office space in the county's western market. "Historically there's been less available space in that segment of the market," said Michael H. Siegel, executive director of the Edward S. Gordon offices in White Plains and Stamford, Conn. "A lot of companies like to be located there because of its proximity to Rockland County, where a lot of the labor pool comes from."
It is also a part of the county loaded with attractions for commercial tenants, according to Frank Tomasulo, first vice president with the CB Commercial brokerage in White Plains. "There are a lot of hotels there and conference centers and restaurants," Mr. Tomasulo said. "It's always been considered very desirable."
The Tarrytown Corporate Center has a Marriott Hotel on its property. "It really helps us attract tenants," Mr. Campofranco said. "It has a swimming pool tenants can use, a spa and restaurants. In a suburban park, it's great to have something like that people can walk to."
Built between 1974 and 1985, the Tarrytown Corporate Center has fared well even in the worst of times. "At the lowest point of the recession, we were 80 percent leased," explained Mr. Halpern, whose family company created the park and sold all but two owner-occupied buildings to Reckson.
Part of the reason for its success, Mr. Halpern said, is that the park was built for the long term. "We were investment builders," he explained. "If we put up a building for I.B.M., we did it with an eye toward having to market it to another company some day. It had to be flexible."
Mr. Halpern now works with Reckson as executive vice president in charge of acquisitions and financing. He is also president of the Westchester Division.
Before joining Reckson, Mr. Campofranco was chief financial officer for Towermarc Corporation, a privately held real estate development company in Boston. "The suburban market there is very similar to Westchester's," he said. "We had the same kind of downsizing with several high-technology firms. But things have started to stabilize just like here."
One of the buildings that Reckson added to its portfolio in the western corridor -- 555 White Plains Road, across from the Tarrytown Corporate Center -- was a former Halpern property that had fallen into foreclosure. As a result, occupancy plummeted to 37 percent. It is now at 100 percent occupancy, Mr. Campofranco said.
RECKSON purchased the 121,000-square-foot building for $4.8 million in April. "It really helped us address some of the needs of our tenants in the park who needed to expand," Mr. Campofranco said.
The building is now undergoing a $3.5 million renovation, Mr. Campofranco explained, which will include a new entrance, a new cafeteria, a computer-ready conference room and remodeled elevators.
As Reckson succeeds in filling up its buildings, it is on the lookout for new opportunities in Westchester, Mr. Campofranco said. Last year, the company formed a joint venture partnership with Capelli Associates, of Valhalla, to purchase 360 Hamilton Avenue in White Plains. The 380,000-square-foot building has been largely vacant since I.B.M. abandoned it in 1989.
"We see White Plains as a very desirable market," Mr. Campofranco said. "We think the building can be successfully repositioned and have a new life. It's being marketed now. We need a kick-off tenant to take at least 50,000 square feet before we can begin working on it."
John H. Rostenberg, a principal of Rostenberg-Doern, a commercial brokerage with offices in Purchase and Stamford, Conn., said that with the new ownership, 360 Hamilton Avenue was in a great position to turn around its fortunes. "It's a well-constructed and esthetically pleasing building," he said. "It's near affordable housing so people could walk to work, which is a very unique feature. I think they'll do well with it."
While White Plains had strong leasing activity last year, it nevertheless continues to be plagued with corporate downsizing. The vacancy rate in the central business district reached 27.5 percent in 1996, up from 24.4 percent the year before, according to Edward S. Gordon. The county's overall vacancy rate also climbed -- to 17 percent from 16.4 percent in 1995.
If Reckson is successful in repositioning 360 Hamilton Avenue, it would mean one of the most persistent drags on the White Plains market would be eliminated. "We have no false expectations," Mr. Campofranco said. "We know it will take time, but we think it's a viable candidate for a big user of space. "There's less of the big blocks of space available," he said. "We believe it will be a big success."

HEADLINE: Renewal of Union Square Reaches a Key Block

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
THE long-awaited construction of a mixed-use building on the full block south of Union Square between Broadway and Fourth Avenue is under way, foreshadowing a large expansion of retailing and entertainment activities in an area that has been one of the most active for redevelopment in Manhattan.
Layered within an immense glass box rising 85 feet from street level on four sides will be a new Virgin music and entertainment store, almost as large as the megastore that Virgin opened on Times Square last April; a 14-screen theater component for United Artists Theater Circuit, which will have 3,500 seats, and a Circuit City electronics store, the first in New York City by a national chain that wants to be the somebody who beats The Wiz. 
 The presence of a Nobody Beats the Wiz store on the west side of Union Square Park -- and a Barnes & Noble on the north side, a Toys "R" Us on the east, a Bradlees on the south, and a P.C. Richard half a block away -- underscore the growth of retailing already under way.
The new project also has a major residential component. From the roof of the retail base, set back from 14th Street, will rise a tower with 240 apartments, with 50 reserved for people of lower income. The total development cost is estimated at $130 million, with $50 million in financing for the mixed-income residential portion coming from tax-exempt state bonds.
The developer, The Related Companies LP, has sponsored a competition under the auspices of the Municipal Art Society and the Public Art Fund for the selection of a monumental artwork rising from the facade facing Union Square. It is the key element in the design by the firm of Davis Brody Bond, and is intended to set a tone for the southern terminus of a midtown spine stretching all the way from Union Square along Park Avenue South to Grand Central Terminal. The artwork will stand 100 feet high and 60 feet wide and form a visual link with the residential structure. The winner of the competition is to be announced by the developer at a ceremonial ground-breaking on Feb. 25.
Apart from its purely local impact, the Related project throws light on several aspects of the Manhattan development scene in the mid-90's. It shows anew how closely tied new development has been to the availability of tax-exempt bond financing from New York State. Without this financing, and city tax abatements that are also available, the development would not have gone forward, said Stephen M. Ross, chairman of The Related Companies.
It also demonstrates how in strong or promising retailing locations in Manhattan, retailing is often the dog that wags the residential tail. The Lincoln Square development on Broadway in the West 60's, with condominium apartments above a base of superstores and theaters, was the model.
Not only have the developers taken advantage of the zoning to provide the superstores that big specialized retailers want in the 90's; they have also used the retailing commitment as a critical building block in the financing of the entire project.
In another sense, the Union Square development shows how the happenstance of the business cycle as much as the well-laid plans of mere mortals influences who builds what in New York, and when.
But for the sharp decline of the real-estate market in the late 80's, the developer of the 50,000-square-foot site might have been Philip Pilevsky, the principal in Philips International Holding Corporation. He had a contract to buy the northern, or 14th Street, portion of the site from its two owners, and had already bought the 13th Street side, which had been in single ownership, when the real estate recession struck. "The timing was horrible," Mr. Pilevsky said.
The 14th Street portion fell back into the hands of the landowners, First Sterling Corporation and a partnership of Marvin Fastenberg and Dan Birnant. A lender, FGH Realty, took control of the 13th Street half.
In 1993, Mr. Ross of Related ran into a nephew of Marvin Fastenberg, the late Steven Fastenberg, on a flight to a meeting of shopping center executives in Las Vegas. "He was sitting in front of me and recognized me, and turned around to ask if I'd be interested in that site his uncle has," Mr. Ross said. "I said yes."
Mr. Ross made a commitment to lease the land from the two 14th Street owners, but the deal was contingent on his ability to get control of the 13th Street side. Ultimately, he was able to make that deal, getting a leasehold to the retail portion and fee-simple-ownership of the residential portion.
Then Related sold the leasehold position for the 250,000-square-foot retail base to a state pension fund -- the State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio, which effectively becomes the owner of the commercial base. Related will manage the investment for the pension fund. The payments made in these various deals were not disclosed.
LAST year Related demolished the remaining building on the site, the eight-story 1902 structure at 842 Broadway, on 13th Street. In its day it had housed Rogers, Peet, the men's clothing store; The Village Voice and Berkey Photos.
With the firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron as its architect of record, Related is producing a structure of about 500,000 square feet of space. Half the site is in the special Union Square zoning district and half is out of it. Both portions allow commercial and residential use up to a floor-area ratio of 10 above street level (10 square feet of building area for each square foot of land). But the allowable proportion of commercial use to residential use is higher within the special zoning district than on the 13th Street side.
Utilizing somewhat less than the total zoning potential of the site, Related will build 458,000 square feet of space above street level, more than half of it for the stores and theaters. The commercial base will have 248,000 square feet of space above street level (plus 48,000 square feet, not counted for zoning purposes, below street level). The residential space will start on the fifth floor and rise to the 21st floor. Residents will enter a 2,000-square-foot lobby on Fourth Avenue and take an elevator to the residential floors.
"The minimum street-wall height allowed on Union Square was 85 feet," said Peter Claman, the architect. "The maximum retail height allowed on 13th Street is 85 feet. This made the whole project feasible."
The Virgin music and entertainment store will be entered from 14th Street and Broadway and occupy space on the ground floor and basement for a total of 75,000 square feet. The main entrance to the United Artists theater space on the third and fourth floors will be at 13th Street and Broadway, with escalators running to the third-floor lobby.
The Circuit City store on the first and second floors will be entered at 14th Street and Fourth Avenue, with an internal escalator taking shoppers to the second floor. It will occupy 48,000 square feet of space, mainly on the second floor.
At various stages in the development process, Related was close to a deal with Caldor, Kmart and Sears Roebuck & Company, said Robert Futterman, senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates, the retail-space brokerage firm, who was Related's leasing agent for the project. But Sears decided not to go forward with its first Manhattan location, he said, and the prospect of a bankruptcy proceeding for Caldor led Related to back away from that deal.
Had any of those deals been completed, the retail base of the building would probably have been built to its maximum zoning potential, with five retail levels and the full 500,000 square feet, plus 50,000 square feet below street level, Related executives said.
The "art wall" along 14th Street will be one of the city's most prominent pieces of public art, costing the developer about $1 million. Last June six finalists were chosen from the 100 artists across the country who responded to an invitation to join the competition. They were commissioned to develop their preliminary ideas further. The finalists were Ivan Chermayeff; Kristin Jones & Andrew Ginzel; Clyde Lynds; Matt Mullican; Tom Otterness, and Frank Stella.
In August, after consulting with an advisory committee drawn from the community, the arts organizations and Davis Brody Bond, the developer decided to continue with the development of two of the proposals, the Public Art Fund said. The two were not identified.
Visually, the sculpture will relate to the masonry residential component more than the glassy commercial component, said Steven M. Davis of the architectural firm. "The tower grows out of the art," he said. The glass facades above the clear glass at the base of the building will be of a different tone on either side of the sculpture, Mr. Davis said: an opaque curtain wall of a pewter tone on the Broadway side, and translucent in a range of tones on the eastern side.
As for the housing component, it will have 57 studio apartments, 152 one-bedrooms and 31 two-bedroom apartments. To finance it, the New York State Housing Finance Agency has issued $50 million in tax-exempt bonds, including $1 million for a debt service reserve fund. Rents for the 80 percent of apartments that will be leased at market rates are expected to average about $33 a square foot a year, or roughly $2,100 a month for a one-bedroom apartment.
THE lenders providing credit enhancement -- which insures repayment on the bond to the bondholders -- were Fleet Bank and Hypo Bank of Munich, as it is known in this country. (The German name is Bayerische Hypotheken-und Wechsel-Bank.) Securing credit enhancement is a necessary part of the financing process, and not always an easy one. The state won't issue bonds until the security for the bondholders is assured.
Stephen J. Hunt, president of the Housing Finance Agency, said that the statewide commitment of tax-exempt bonds under the 80-20 program (with 20 percent of the units reserved for lower-income occupants) has expanded significantly since 1995. The pipeline now stands at about $850 million statewide, of which about $650 million is in New York City, where the program works particularly well. The $650 million is expected to finance about 3,100 additional Manhattan apartments, of which 20 percent are to be for lower-income tenants.
The program works well in Manhattan because Manhattan is one of the few places where developers can obtain high enough market rents to provide an internal cross-subsidy benefiting lower-income tenants. This subsidy at present is estimated at about $18,000 per lower-income one-bedroom apartment a year, Related says. That is to say, the lower-income tenants pay rents that are about $18,000 a year below the market-rate rents. "The combination of tax-exempt financing, the tax abatement programs and the market-rate rents we can get in Manhattan make the entire project feasible," Mr. Ross said.
Handling the new construction on Union Square is HRH Construction, one of the constituents of the Starrett Corporation, a public real estate services organization. Last week Starrett disclosed that Related Capital Company, one of the financial services affiliates of The Related Companies, had agreed to buy a majority stake in Starrett, most of it the holdings of Paul and Seymour Milstein. Besides HRH, major operating entities of Starrett are Grenadier Realty, a national housing management company, and Levitt Homes, a leading home builder in Florida and Puerto Rico.
Refraining from specifics, Mr. Ross said that he hoped to build the company as a real-estate services organization. He also commented that it was important to keep HRH intact under the leadership of Frank Ross, its chief executive (and no relation to Stephen Ross).
The major improvements to Union Square Park that the New York City Parks Department began in the 80's have played an important role in encouraging new investment and development around the perimeter. A $3.4 million program included the creation of east-to-west and north-to-south sight lines that helped make the park a safer place at night. In 1993 two new playgrounds were added at a cost of $300,000.
Future expansion of the park is planned in a westward and to some extent in a southeasterly direction, said Henry J. Stern, the Parks Commissioner. "It will be a bigger, greener place a few years from now," Mr. Stern said. The park currently embraces 3.593 acres, and expansion could add at least an acre, he said. On the northwest side of the park, the Union Square Greenmarket, celebrated in Manhattan for the produce it sells four days a week, will be unaffected by the expansion.
On certain sites, redevelopment activity needs little further inducement. New York University is already in construction with new dormitory building on 14th Street between Broadway and Third Avenue, on the former site of Luchow's Restaurant. It will have 20 floors on the 14th Street side and 14 floors on the 13th Street side, with 172 apartments, 637 beds, and dining facilities for 300 people. Davis Broad Bond is the architect.
AND farther east on the block, J.D. Carlisle Development Corporation is in contract to buy the property where the Palladium Club operates under a lease that will soon expire, plus a contiguous property that is operated as a parking lot. This site might support a major building on a substantial 41,000-square-foot footprint.
The Related project is scheduled to open late next year. For those who have worked for the advancement of redevelopment in the Union Square area over the last several years, the opening will mark a long step forward.
"It will bring activity to the street, and fill in a broken tooth in the comb that breaks the flow of retail traffic," said Jonathan F. Fanton, president of the New School for Social Research, on West 12th Street, and co-chair of the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation. "And in the evening the theaters will generate street traffic."
James I. Gabbe, a board member of the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District, who lives in the 670-unit Zeckendorf Towers condominium on the east side of the park, said that by bringing in shoppers and new permanent residents the development will expand the contribution to areawide improvement that William Zeckendorf Jr. made when he developed Zeckendorf Towers in the 80's.
And William L. Haines, principal in an ownership group on lower Fifth Avenue that leases stores to Barnes & Noble, The Gap and other office and commercial tenants, said that 14th Street had long been retailing's Achilles heel in the area. "Now it's starting to take off," he said.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
For an Art Museum's Sake

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
Some see only the generations of paint flaking from the concrete block walls, the rust of steel showing through a pillar here and there, the plaster on the floor and the faded block letters saying "Blow Horn" -- mementos of the 1920's when this shell of a building was a post office garage.
But Nina S. Jacobs sees a museum. 
 "Over there will be classrooms," she says, excitement flashing in her dark eyes in the illumination of the construction lights strung overhead. "And when the skylight area is built, it will create a corridor here, and we'll line it with display cases, for the most part Jersey City history."
Ms. Jacobs, despite the sign, can't stop blowing the horn, not her own but that of the Jersey City Museum. It is an institution for which she has labored for almost a decade, four of them as its director. After almost 100 years in the same location -- cramped quarters on the fourth floor of the public library whose roof leaks -- the museum is being relocated to a two-story, yellow brick building that will provide three times more gallery space, an auditorium, classrooms and a resource room for the city's growing population of artists.
Overseeing the $5.2 million renovation is Ms. Jacobs, a lapsed painter turned administrator. At a time when funding for the arts is drying up, she was able to get a $2 million grant last July from the New Jersey State Council of the Arts, one of the last sizable grants from a 1987 bond issue for cultural institutions. And now she is about to begin a campaign to raise matching funds for a museum that she hopes will reflect and unite the diverse peoples who make up this battered industrial city.
"You know, we're building a museum, but this is a much larger issue than a museum," she says. "This is really about community revitalization and urban revitalization. We're going to have a significant impact on the life and optimism of what's happening in Jersey City, the development of Jersey City."
She adds, "This is a historic time for us."
If that sounds like ego talking, it isn't. Ms. Jacobs, 43, cringes at talking about herself, her skills as an administrator and the frustrations that keep her from painting again.
"The museum is interesting; I'm not," she says.
Attached to the wall, just inside her small office, is an old industrial-style sink. It is not a quaint piece of art but a real sink, clogged, suggesting that her office could once have been a janitor's closet. The office, overheated in winter, stifling in the summer, overlooks the roofs of tenements. It's filled with books and papers and several scale models of the new building, a 25,700-square-foot-structure that, Ms. Jacobs notes gleefully, will have a working heating and air-conditioning system.
"This is not a self-aggrandizing moment for Nina," said Charles Gifford of Myer & Gifford Architects of Manhattan who has been planning the building with her. "She's really an unselfish person who is not driven by a desire for glory or even the desire for a new office that has a working air-conditioner and doesn't have a sink in it."
Since she discovered and fell in love with the abandoned postal garage, which literally had trees growing from its roof two years ago, she has been unafraid to get her hands dirty. During a driving rain last year, she headed up to the snow-covered roof of the building, a pickax in her hands, to look for clogged storm drains, -- embarrassing a work crew into coming up to help.
"She's a real, genuine person, despite all this artsy stuff," said Bob Cotter, director of the Jersey City planning department. "A stuffed shirt wouldn't be appropriate for a museum like Jersey City's."
She joined the museum at another historic time, 1987, when it was almost forced to close for lack of funds, as it had once before, from 1953 to 1975. In 1987, the city gave the museum its own budget line, separating it from the library's finances.
At first she worked in development, writing requests for grants and funds, then in public relations, publicizing exhibitions and programs. She moved up to assistant director, acting director, and in 1992, director.
As director, she is responsible for cultivating community, political and financial support for the museum. She also oversees day-to-day operations, insuring that they are consistent with the museum's mission, and provides guidance to a 10-member staff that includes an assistant director, curator of education, and teachers, collection manager, public relations associate, development director and a curator who plans the exhibitions.
Catherine Dunning, an educator with the museum, praised Ms. Jacobs for supporting the summer Public A.R.T. (Art Related Training) Program in which youths are paid to create murals and billboards under the guidance of professional artists. When the starkness of some of the anti-drug and anti-violence messages drew criticism, Ms. Dunning said, "She showed a certain courage and was willing to field any comments." She added, "She has not backed down."
Some directors, many being artists themselves, assume the role of curator as well, but she has chosen not to, and wisely so, said the architect, Mr. Gifford.
"She leaves people alone to do their jobs," Mr. Gifford said, while focusing on "the more important issues like the museum's future, mission and constituency."
Barbara Russo, executive director of the State Council of the Arts, said that in awarding the $2 million grant, her agency had been impressed with the museum's impact on cultural life beyond Jersey City and by the scope of its programs for the community.
"She's taken an important cultural institution and shown how it can work with a community of artists and a community of residents and be meaningful," said Ms. Russo.
Carlos Hernandez, the president of Jersey City State College who serves as chairman of the museum's board of directors, says it is Ms. Jacobs' background as a painter that enlightens her work as director.
"She understands the bridge between what the arts are and what they can do to stimulate excitement and creative energies in people," Dr. Hernandez says. "It takes a creative person to spark that creative flair in others."
Ms. Jacobs was born in Red Bank but grew up in Keyport. Her father at various times was a salesman, auto body shop owner and restaurateur. Her mother worked in a doctor's office.
She credits her great grandfather, John Wester, a Danish emigre architect who designed schools and churches in New Jersey at the turn of the century, for her lifelong interest in art.
"I have early memories of sitting with him and learning how to draw," she recalled.
After graduation from Keyport High School, she attended the University of Miami in Florida for two years, but missed New Jersey and returned to major in studio art at Douglass College.
During college, she worked odd jobs, including sales, to pay for her tuition, and after graduation in 1980, moved to Erwinna, Pa., to live the life of an artist. For a half-dozen years, she explored her talent, painting full-time, and to support herself designed clothes, gave private art lessons and eventually took work as an assistant editor for a company that published art books for major museums.
She moved back to New Jersey eventually and briefly lived with her sister in Highlands. It was at this point she heard about a job opening at the Jersey City Museum and applied. The job, she says, demanded most of her time and she eventually quit painting.
"It's painful," she says of painting, a solitary act, she adds, that puts one's intimate creations up for criticism and then becomes a process in which one is forced to promote the work. "It requires a kind of focus I can't give it right now."
Maybe at some point she will resume. "I know I've been thinking about it," she says. "I've been seeing things that have been pulling at me."
But something else is pulling at her now: a new museum.
"This has given me everything that I ever looked for in terms of an art career," Nina Jacobs says, cheerily. "I'd like to think that this is a creative project. And trying to envision a space for the future and the activities that are going to occur in the space, to be able to create a flexible space that a hundred years from now will still be of service -- that's a pretty challenging proposition."

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE;
Getting Help Getting Children in for Vaccinations

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
In the back of a rundown Newark house, up a short flight of unlighted stairs, in a bedroom where MTV blares, is Rebecca Gordon, hugely pregnant and between labor pains.
Ms. Gordon is 22. She is having twins. She has four other children, 6, 5, 3 and 1. Understandably, Ms. Gordon, who is single, on welfare, overwhelmed by her duties as a mother and likely to become more so, lets some things slip. 
 One such thing is her children's vaccinations. Her youngest child, until tomorrow, anyway, is months behind on his vaccinations. That is why Frank and Heidi Abernethy have dropped by. They are volunteers in a Fair Lawn organization to aid parents in vaccinating their children.
New Jersey has 7,000 other volunteers in Hope for Kids, as the organization is called. It was started by church members in 1993 in Orlando, Fla. It moved to Harlem, then Fair Lawn, and has branches in 29 states and Africa, the Caribbean, Central America, India and Cambodia.
In Newark and Paterson, as in all of New Jersey's economically depressed cities, large numbers of children are unimmunized. Many do not get their shots protecting them against serious childhood illnesses until they are 5 or 6, when they must be immunized to enter school. In Newark, nearly half the children are unimmunized; in some neighborhoods, the immunization rate is as low as 1 in 5.
When a high percentage of children in a neighborhood are unvaccinated, the risk of serious illness is high. Children should be vaccinated against measles, mumps, rubella, diphtheria, polio, whooping cough and tetanus, among other diseases.
They should receive five shots between 2 months and 2 years. Some people assume that childhood diseases are an irritating but harmless part of growing up, but these illnesses can cause deafness, blindness, brain damage, paralysis and death. When measles swept the country in 1991, it was children from inner cities like Newark and Paterson who suffered and died.
Ms. Gordon agreed that vaccination is a good idea. But she has no way of getting to a clinic. Transportation and money are obstacles for many low-income parents. Another is suspicion of government programs and fear of officials. A drug-addicted mother may worry her child will be put in foster care. Some religious groups oppose vaccination. Some parents believe that vaccination is harmful, causing the disease it is supposed to prevent.
The same morning that Rebecca Gordon was awaiting the birth of her twins, Susan Hirsch, a South Orange piano teacher, brought two children, 2 1/2 and 4 1/2, for their first shots, which they should have received at 2 months.
"This is what I have to do to get them in school," she said. She believes a diet of organic foods and immunity created by light cases of disease is far superior. "I don't believe in this stuff," she said. "It's the religion of my life."
This conviction is held by some parents adhering to alternative medical theories, from homeopathy to voodoo. It is opposed by doctors and public health officials.
But most parents whose children have missed immunizations have simply forgotten or procrastinated.
In the mid-80's, the percentage of children vaccinated dropped steeply around the country at all income levels. Memories of the toll of childhood diseases like polio and measles, once fresh in parents' minds, had dulled, said Elin Gursky, an assistant commissioner in the State Department of Health and Senior Services. By the late 80's, New Jersey, like the rest of the country, saw large increases in measles and mumps and smaller increases in diphtheria.
New Jersey's legislators, like other state and Federal officials, assumed childhood diseases were no longer much of a threat. Legislators cut budgets, creating "failing public health systems," Ms. Gursky said.
When 1,138 New Jersey children contracted measles in 1991 and 4 died, the Legislature, shaken, improved its tracking of immunizations. A system to follow the vaccinations of each child born in the state is slated to be ready by the end of 1997.
To do any good, leaders of volunteer organizations need more than good will. They also need political savvy. Lawton Chiles 3d, known as Bud, has this in abundance.
He learned it as a child from his father, Lawton Chiles, a former Senator from Florida and now its Governor. A few years ago, in Harlem and Bedford-Stuyvesant, the younger Mr. Chiles hooked up with Mayor David N. Dinkins, who had warehouses of donated vaccines and medical supplies earmarked for low-income children, but lacked the staff to connect the children with the medical workers. Mr. Chiles supplied workers, transportation and door-to-door canvassing, and let the credit go to the Mayor.
In New Jersey, he and his organization work with county health departments, getting names of children who have missed vaccination appointments and visiting their homes. New Jersey volunteers have followed 300 children through their five-shot cycle over a two-year period. In Trenton, Jersey City, Paterson and Newark, 200 volunteers are following 600 other children. They also offer information on other childhood health concerns: lead poisoning, nutrition, AIDS testing and asthma.
The problem is not a lack of vaccines or medical workers, Mr. Chiles said. It is connecting, getting parents and children to clinics. "We keep coming back," he said, "visiting the kids, whatever it takes."

HEADLINE: What Whitman Says, What Whitman Does

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When Governor Whitman said it was necessary to concentrate on a law to equalize school financing to meet a Supreme Court deadline, the teachers, Democrats and the public believed her. Big mistake. 
 Without confiding in the public at all, for the first time in our history, Governor Whitman slips in a provision for state financing of student transfers to outlying school districts. Since the receiving district can pick and choose, will this siphon off the better students and devastate inner-city schools? Never discussed.
Clearly, the Governor believes public education is some kind of a "business." Public schools should "compete," and if inner-city schools go "out of business," too bad.
This is no surprise. The Governor's public persona is one of caring, but her track record tells a different, cynical story: her eliminating the Public Advocate so utility rates can escape public scrutiny; her shifting of the tax burden to municipalities and homeowners, and her financing of her famous "income tax reduction" by looting the pension funds and unemployment funds of billions.
When it's time to shine, she's on television. When it's time to explain hidden deals, the spokesmen speak. When times get tough and these chickens come home to roost, she will have "moved on to better things." She should be moved out now because she does not level with the people.
 
JOHN TOMASIN
West New York

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Renaissance Ballroom: Lost for $1,000

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON 

 BODY:
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, and a group of Harlem investors had big plans for the Renaissance Ballroom, a faded relic of Harlem's heyday. Restoration plans for the two-story building on 138th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard included reviving the banquet hall, where Harlemites had held dances and celebrated weddings and other life passages. But the investors did not have title to the property.
Led by the Abyssinian Development Corporation, the group of investors had for years been trying to buy both the Rennie, as they called it fondly, and the nearby nightclub Small's Paradise. In 1992, they came close when they bought the mortgages to the historical landmarks from the Resolution Trust Corporation. But a real-estate investor, Baruch Singer, retained the title. 
 But early last month, their hopes of owning the Renaissance Ballroom were dashed when a real-estate investor, Michael Berman, who is also a partner of Mr. Singer, outbid Abyssinian Development in a foreclosure auction that Abyssinian sought in an attempt to gain ownership. The Harlem investors had come within a hairbreadth; the winning bid ($3,671,000) was $1,000 higher than theirs.
"We were stunned," said Darren Walker, director of development for Abyssinian, who said the group's representative had not been authorized to engage in a bidding war.
In the aftermath, community activists denounced Mr. Singer as an unscrupulous speculator.
"This project is dear to us," said Dr. Preston R. Washington, president of Harlem Congregations for Community Improvement. "Where is the community's equity? I don't think it's appropriate for the community to accept this. We are sick and tired of being a colony that is run by outside interests."
Mr. Singer, who defaulted on his loans, says he does not see himself as a speculator. "I am committed to develop the property, and I am willing to work with the community," he said, blaming the economic downturn for his failure to develop. The owners said a number of retailers and entertainment companies were interested in the site. The area is anticipating a boon, partly as a result of millions of dollars to be allocated by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.
The issue of ownership of the Renaissance is also charged because of the property's history. Unlike other popular nightspots that catered to a largely white clientele, the Renaissance Ballroom, with its arched Palladian windows, was always a haven for middle-class blacks and featured films with all-black casts and was home to the Renaissance Big Five, a semiprofessional basketball team regarded as one of the best of its time.
But the ballroom's popularity declined in the 1960's as people began patronizing clubs downtown. In 1989, Mr. Singer and investors bought the building for $2.7 million. Soon afterward, Mr. Butts began negotiations to buy it. In 1991 the church won a grant to study the building's commercial potential.
During the savings and loan crises of the early 1990's, the bank that held the mortgage failed and was taken over by the Resolution Trust Corporation. Representative Charles B. Rangel persuaded the corporation to sell the mortgage to Abyssinian for $300,000. And the group led by Abyssinian bought the mortgage for Small's Paradise, also owned by Mr. Singer's group, for $100,000.
With the Renaissance lost to them, the Harlem investors are trying to avoid losing Small's Paradise. The foreclosure auction on that is set for Feb. 11. JANET ALLON
