HEADLINE: MEDICARE PANEL ADVISES A FREEZE ON HOSPITAL PAY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
A Federal advisory panel has decided to recommend that Congress freeze Medicare payments to hospitals next year. It would be the first time in the history of the program that hospitals have not received an increase.
In approving the recommendation, the panel said that hospitals had effectively controlled their costs, so that existing Medicare payment rates were generally adequate. 
 The chairman of the panel, Prof. Joseph P. Newhouse of Harvard, said in an interview that payment rates could be kept level next year without harming the quality of health care or access to care for beneficiaries.
Medicare finances care for 38 million people who are elderly or disabled. Payments to hospitals totaled $84 billion last year, or 44 percent of all Medicare spending.
The Federal advisory panel, the Prospective Payment Assessment Commission, voted this week to recommend a "zero update" -- no change -- in Medicare payment rates for hospitals. Congress pays close attention to the panel's advice, often providing less money but rarely more than it suggests.
The unexpected recommendation offers President Clinton and Congress a relatively easy way to reduce the Federal budget deficit and shore up the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills.
Carmela S. Coyle, a vice president of the American Hospital Association, said: "We are surprised that the commission recommended no increase at all in Medicare payment amounts. It's unprecedented. Hospitals have become more efficient. We've kept down costs for two or three years in a row. There have been real cuts in the cost of treating Medicare patients. But how long can these cost reductions be sustained?"
Mrs. Coyle said hospitals were, in effect, being punished for having improved their productivity. Federal officials contend that Medicare should share the benefits of such improvements, and that hospitals can continue increasing productivity.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said the Medicare proposal was "the third stroke of a triple whammy" adversely affecting hospital revenues. New York State recently lifted price controls on hospitals, forcing them to compete for patients by offering discounts to insurers. In addition, Mr. Raske said, New York has cut Medicaid payments to hospitals, and Gov. George E. Pataki is proposing deeper cuts.
The recommendation from the Federal advisory panel coincides with new evidence showing how inflation has been squeezed from the health care industry.
The cost of medical care, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, rose last year by just 3 percent, the smallest amount in three decades. The price index for all items increased 3.3 percent. It was the first time since 1980 that medical prices rose less than the overall index, which measures changes in the prices paid by consumers for a fixed market basket of goods and services.
While the Government data show that medical prices are leveling off, some economists say they are actually declining.
"For example," said Dahlia K. Remler, a health economist at Tulane University in New Orleans, "the price you have to pay for extending your life after a heart attack is not rising as fast as the price of other goods in the economy like food, clothing and housing. In the last 15 years, the price of what we care about -- the price of having our health improved when we are sick -- has gone down in real terms."
Since 1984, hospitals have received a fixed amount of money for each Medicare patient they treat, regardless of how long the person stays in the hospital. Each Medicare patient is assigned to 1 of 495 categories, depending on the illness. Payments are set in advance for each category and can be updated annually.
The Congressional Budget Office had assumed that payment rates would be increased 3 percent next year. Based on that figure, the panel's recommendation would save more than $2 billion in 1998. It would permanently lower the base for future increases, saving more than $11 billion over five years.
The sum, while substantial, is a relatively small part of the savings that will be needed to guarantee the long-term solvency of Medicare.
In the last decade, the commission has recommended increases averaging 3 percent a year, and Congress has approved increases averaging 2.6 percent a year.
Stuart Guterman, deputy executive director of the commission, said: "Hospital costs have been declining while Medicare payments have increased at a moderate rate. As a result, hospitals have found their Medicare business more profitable."
The hospital association boasted last year that "increases in hospitals' costs of delivering care hit their lowest point in 40 years." One reason, the commission said, is that wages and benefits of hospital employees are growing more slowly than compensation in many other industries.
Data collected by the Government show that hospital profit margins have, on the average, been rising for several years. But Mrs. Coyle said the data also showed that some hospitals were experiencing financial difficulties. Nineteen percent of hospitals lost money over all, she said, while 39 percent lost money on their Medicare business.
Kay Ford, an economist at the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that the growing use of managed care had helped hold down health costs. Nearly three-fourths of workers with health insurance are in some type of managed care.
Both H.M.O.'s and traditional insurance plans are negotiating with hospitals to get lower rates for their patients. Hardly anyone pays the full list price any more.
Economists told Congress last month that the Consumer Price Index tends to overstate increases in the cost of living because it does not fully account for the development of new products, improvements in the quality of old products and other changes in the standard market basket of goods and services.
Such changes are occurring throughout the health care industry. New drugs and devices and medical procedures are introduced every month. Employers, labor unions, H.M.O.'s and insurance companies are continually devising new ways to pay for services. Different people often pay different prices for the same service provided by the same doctor or hospital.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics has data showing the prices of hospital rooms over the last 60 years. But the price index does not take account of the fact that the average length of hospital stays has declined in the last 15 years, especially for elderly patients.
In addition, "a hospital day today is very different from one 10 years ago in terms of the procedures a patient receives," said Dr. Mark McClellan, an economist and physician at Stanford University.
David M. Cutler, an economist at Harvard, said that the services provided by doctors and hospitals today were worth more than those provided 10 or 20 years ago.
Mr. Cutler, Dr. McClellan, Ms. Remler, and Mr. Newhouse recently studied the care of people who had suffered heart attacks. In a study published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, they found that while the "use of more intensive procedures like bypass surgery and angioplasty has skyrocketed," prices have come down and patients are living longer.
For these patients, they said, the cost of living in a literal sense -- the cost of prolonging life after a heart attack -- has declined.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Is Crossing Starting Line for Year 2000

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
When President Clinton takes the oath of office for the second time on Monday, it will mark a watershed in the career of Vice President Al Gore.
From that point on, Mr. Gore will begin, very slowly at first, then perhaps more rapidly, to emerge from Mr. Clinton's shadow. He will still be subject to the rule that Vice Presidents are more seen than heard. He will still be a very junior partner in the White House firm, there more than anything else to assume the Presidency if anything should happen to the President. 
 But he will also be the heir apparent, the favorite for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000, when Mr. Clinton must step down.
"Tuesday is the turning point," said Thomas J. Downey, a Washington lobbyist who served for 18 years as a Congressman from Long Island and who is counted as a member of the Gore inner circle. "The salad days are over."
Although Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore are from the same generation and the same region, and although they have shown an unshakeable loyalty to each other during the last four years, it is conceivable that their interests will diverge in the months to come. One Gore intimate suggested, for example, that in a budget deal, Mr. Gore would want to get the fiscal "pain" out of the way before 2000 and Mr. Clinton would want to push it into the future.
"One would be a back-loader, one a front-loader," the friend said, although he predicted that any tensions would be handled in private.
Peter S. Knight, who served as the manager of the Clinton/Gore 1996 campaign and might manage Mr. Gore's effort in 2000, said he thought any such divergences would be rare. "The most important thing Al Gore can do for his future is help to make this the most successful President in history," he said. "What's good for Clinton is good for Gore. They are joined at the hip, politically."
That close identification can cut both ways, of course. If Mr. Clinton is popular three years from now, if the economy remains sound, if there is no major crisis abroad, Mr. Gore will benefit. But many second terms go awry for one reason or another, and that could cost Mr. Gore the nomination or force him to fight so hard for it -- like Hubert H. Humphrey had to in 1968, when Vietnam split the party -- that he is fatally weakened for the general election.
Mr. Gore is also a kind of hostage to Mr. Clinton's frailties, including his legal problems. Should the Paula Jones case or the Whitewater affair or some other scandal blow up in the President's face in the months ahead, Mr. Gore will have to decide, as one of his friends said, "whether he can afford to be a bit less vigorous in his support or whether that would look disloyal."
He also has his own problems. During last year's campaign, he got caught up in the controversy surrounding fund-raising for the Democratic ticket, holding what proved to be an illegal, if unintentionally comical, fund-raiser in a Buddhist temple among nuns who had taken vows of poverty. Like Mr. Clinton, he sometimes seems excessively technocratic, lacking political passion. And he has not entirely shaken his reputation as a rather wooden, humorless campaigner.
In an interview at the White House this week, Mr. Gore said he would keep his plans for 2000 under wraps until well after the 1998 Congressional elections -- until "about two and a half years from now," as he put it.
"The country doesn't want these campaigns to start as early as they do," he said. "I'm not going to change my outlook or way of thinking. Any campaign associated with me is going to be a lot like my macarena -- no visible movement but some people may think they know what I'm doing anyway."
Mr. Gore said he intended to pursue the same interests in his second term that have occupied him in his first term, like the environment, the reorganization of the Federal Government and foreign policy, especially United States relations with Russia, China, Egypt and South Africa.
At the Cabinet retreat a week ago, Mr. Gore added, the President asked him to speak and he spent his entire time on "reinventing Government."
Presumably, those sorts of issues would play an important part in a Gore campaign for the Presidency. But the campaign to shrink and restructure the Government has met with only limited success, with the Internal Revenue Service, for example, still considered a big problem, even by Mr. Gore.
"We're ahead of schedule, but we still have a long way to go," the Vice President said. "I'm very pleased with the progress that has been made. But we have not yet crossed the threshold beyond which the American people generally say, 'Yeah, I see a big change' or 'I feel a big change.' "
Much of his work has lacked political glamor and, hence, saleability.
"Among Gore's responsibilities are a lot of things like trying to clean up the fissionable materials in Kazakstan," said Martin Peretz, the editor-in-chief of The New Republic, who taught Mr. Gore as a freshman at Harvard University and has maintained a close friendship with him. "They could be crucial to our children and grandchildren, but they don't matter a lot to most of the voters of today."
What he can do in planning and policy terms in the Vice Presidency is largely dependent on Mr. Clinton. In that sense, too, Mr. Gore is not entirely captain of his own fate.
Few of those around him expect him to win the nomination in a walkover, no matter how well he performs his duties, how popular Mr. Clinton is three years from now or how strong Mr. Gore looks going into 2000.
"It's inevitable that he'll have challengers," said Roy M. Neel, the president of the United Telephone Association, which lobbies on telecommunications issues. "You have to go back a lot of years to find a vice president who wasn't challenged when he went after the Presidency."
In fact, only four of the nation's 45 Vice Presidents were elected to the Presidency at the end of their Vice-Presidential terms: John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, Martin Van Buren and George Bush. Like several others, Richard M. Nixon tried and failed when he left the Vice Presidency in 1960, but he was elected President eight years later, a unique accomplishment.
Mr. Neel, who served as Mr. Gore's assistant in Congress and later as his vice-presidential chief of staff, suggested that rivals might begin to emerge as early as this year. The first sign, he said, would be when a Democratic governor or senator took a public position on a prominent issue that differed from the President's.
Among the Democrats who may challenge Mr. Gore are Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader in the House, and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, both of whom ran unsuccessfully for President in 1988.
But it is former Senator Bill Bradely of New Jersey who gives Mr. Gore's advisers nightmares. Mr. Bradley plans to teach and to make a series of public-service television commercials, which should keep him in the public eye. One of the Vice President's friends said he most feared a Bradley campaign built around a crusade against the present system of financing American politics.
People like Mr. Downey, Mr. Knight, Mr. Neel and Jack Quinn, the departing White House counsel who is also a Gore sidekick, have of course long since begun mulling over strategies for 2000 and making preliminary plans.
"You have to think it through very carefully, far in advance, and have a plan in mind," Mr. Quinn said. "But don't show your hand too much. For political as well as legal reasons, you don't display your ambitions."
No Gore fund-raising operations are likely until 1999, but that does not prevent the Vice President from buttering up past contributors. He is doing that this weekend in a series of events at his official residence, including a cocktail reception for 500 this evening and a brunch on Tuesday.
He has also developed a core of loyalists within the Administration. Among them are Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency; Leon Fuerth, his longtime foreign-policy adviser, and the incoming Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Andrew Cuomo, son of the former New York governor, who is widely regarded as a rising Democratic star.
This week, Mr. Gore added another. Steve Grossman, a fund-raiser from Massachusetts, was named to oversee the day-to-day operations of the Democratic National Committee. Though his choice was ratified by Mr. Clinton, he is more Mr. Gore's man, according to leading Democrats here and in Boston.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL;
Modern N.F.L. Makes Coach a Marked Man

BYLINE: By Timothy W. Smith 

 BODY:
George Seifert's resignation as head coach of the San Francisco 49ers last week left a few people scratching their heads. The head scratching continued when the 49ers chose his successor: Steve Mariucci, who guided the University of California to a 6-6 record last year in his only head coaching job.
What in the name of George Halas is going on these days in the National Football League? How does a team go from the coach who won more games than anyone in its history to a man who has never coached in the league? 
 By the time the 1997 season starts, a third of the 30 teams in the league will have new coaches. Some of the coaches who were fired were in their jobs for only a short time. Mike White lasted two seasons in Oakland. Rich Brooks made it through two seasons with the Rams. Rich Kotite fired himself after two seasons with the Jets. That was better than his predecessor, Pete Carroll, who lasted one season. The Jets' next coach will be their third in four seasons.
Of the 10 coaches who were dismissed or resigned this past season, only three had tenures of more than five seasons: Jim Mora (11 years with New Orleans), Wayne Fontes (9 years with Detroit) and Seifert (8).
Bills Coach Marv Levy, who will be entering his 12th season at Buffalo when the 1997 season kicks off, has the longest tenure of any active N.F.L. coach. Levy, who will be 73 on Aug. 3, has a chance to break Halas's record of being the oldest coach in the N.F.L. The way things are going in the N.F.L. these days, the fact that Levy would be in his 14th season with the same team and would be 74 would be equally amazing feats.
Halas was 73 when he retired as the Bears coach on May 27, 1968. He stepped down from 1929 to 1933 in a dispute over play-calling with his co-coach, Ed (Dutch) Sternaman. Halas also left from 1942 to 1946 for a stint in the Navy and again from 1955 to 1958 to let his friend, John (Paddy) Driscoll, coach the team.
In all, Halas coached the Bears for 27 years. Granted, he owned the team and answered to himself for most of those years, but it is almost impossible for any modern N.F.L. coach to last half that time.
The modern N.F.L. coach must be not only a combination of Halas and Vince Lombardi, but also equal parts Dale Carnegie and P. T. Barnum. That's why many of the N.F.L. jobs will go to college coaches, who have spent time recruiting players, know how to sell a program to fans and are adroit at quickly assembling teams with disparate players because of frequent turnover.
Several factors have converged to make an N.F.L. coach a marked man. The main factors are player free agency, stadium free agency (the quest for enhanced luxury-box revenue) and the need to win quickly. They are all tied together in a bundle that is placed squarely on a coach's shoulders. If he buckles under the load, he will be gone. There is no time for him to try to shift the weight and carry on.
N.F.L. owners believe they can build a winning team quickly with free-agent talent. They need ready cash for the huge signing bonuses commanded by the top free agents. Luxury boxes provide the owners with a steady stream of available cash besides their television revenue. New stadiums have more luxury boxes with better amenities that command higher prices. Winning teams attract more corporations and groups to the luxury boxes.
It is a sinister spiral that sucks up coaches like a rampaging tornado and spits them out in the land of unemployment.
The Rams were looking to relocate from Anaheim, Calif., to St. Louis a couple of years ago. They had to convince a largely apathetic football fan base in St. Louis that they were bringing a winner to town. What is the best way to do that? Fire the old coach and hire a new one.
Out goes Chuck Knox with his tired 15-33 record and in comes Brooks, a fresh-faced winner from college (Oregon). The Rams christened their Trans World Dome this season with a losing season. Now, Brooks is out.
Same thing in Cleveland. Bill Belichick bit the dust before the moving vans could load up for the trip to Baltimore. Down the road in Cincinnati, David Shula, the son of the N.F.L. coaching great Don Shula, had to go to make a new stadium proposal appetizing to the Hamilton County electorate. Falcons Coach June Jones kept looking up at a lot of empty seats and a few darkened luxury boxes inside the Georgia Dome this season. Now, he is looking for a new job.
Sometimes it is not all about winning.
Seifert carried the load for a long time in San Francisco, where the 49ers would like a new stadium, and he did it well. Under Seifert, the 49ers were 108-35, won four straight National Football Conference West titles (five in all), played in four N.F.C. championship games and won two Super Bowls. Carolina surprised them and won the N.F.C. West this season, and the Niners were knocked out of the playoffs by the Packers.
Seifert knew he had to leave. Nothing short of another Super Bowl victory is good enough in San Francisco. In comes Mariucci, a fresh face whom the 49ers have tabbed the next great coach in the line of Bill Walsh and Seifert. Good luck, Mr. Mariucci.
If Halas had luxury boxes to fill and free agents to cajole, would he have lasted 27 years? Would he have been able to spend five years developing a championship team as he did from 1958 through 1963? Or with dwindling fan support, empty luxury boxes and poor merchandise sales would Halas have pulled a Kotite and fired himself?

HEADLINE: Tax Respite May Not Prove Much

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The one-week repeal of the sales tax on clothing that costs less than $500 may have stirred a tumult of promotion yesterday in stores across New York City and most of the state, but in the end this experiment will probably be of little use in gauging what would happen if the tax were reduced permanently.
If the cold does not ward off shoppers and clothing sales rise this week, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other officials will no doubt point to the jump as evidence that the state should forever cut the tax, which in the city totals 8.25 percent. That, they say, would stanch the flow of New Yorkers who travel to New Jersey and other states with lower sales taxes to buy their clothes. 
 Yet economists and retail analysts say there is no way to draw that or any other conclusion from a trial run that will last only seven days. So, given its origin in a round of horse trading last summer in Albany, the one-week repeal seems to be more of a political contrivance than a fruitful experiment.
"As a piece of hype, it rates an A," said Isaac Lagnado, publisher of the Tactical Retail Monitor, a newsletter that covers the retail industry. "As a sincere, empirical measurement of a new way of doing business, it's irrelevant."
Even the Mayor himself, who has been talking up the tax-exempt bargains like a sidewalk barker, acknowledged yesterday that the experiment was flawed, particularly because it was occurring in the month after Christmas, one of the slowest retail periods of the year.
But he emphasized that the Legislature, which sets sales taxes for both the city and state, had refused his request to reduce the tax permanently, so he had to settle for this abbreviated test. He said, in fact, that he didn't think there was any need for an experiment because he was already certain that a permanent cut in the sales tax would generate so much economic activity that it would ultimately leave the municipal government with more money from other taxes.
"The State Legislature picked the week of the year that had the least amount of retail activity," the Mayor told reporters during a shopping trip to Herald Square to focus attention on the tax holiday. "And they gave us only a week. I would have liked this to have been longer."
Even if shoppers do flock to the stores for the whole week, officials will have great difficulty in directly determining the size of any jump in revenues. The state is asking retailers to tally their sales of tax-exempt items, but there is no corresponding information for previous years because the state normally tracks sales taxes and retail sales quarterly, and does not keep separate statistics on sales of clothing items that cost less than $500.
To be sure, all of this naysaying is directed at the brevity of the experiment, not at the impact of permanent reductions in sales taxes. Economists say many studies have shown that sales tax cuts can influence where people shop, though there is some disagreement over how much.
In criticizing the experiment, retail analysts point out that they generally recommend that stores run promotions -- and the one-week tax repeal is essentially a state-sponsored giveaway -- for at least three months before assessing their impact. By doing so, the stores can lessen the effect of a host of factors that can cloud an analysis, from the weather to inventory size to the state of the economy.
For example, the biting cold that hit the region last week and may continue could skew the results of the repeal by depressing sales.
In the case of a tax holiday, officials also have to determine whether a rise in clothing sales means there has been a geographic shift in spending -- which is their goal -- or merely a chronological one.
In other words, are New Yorkers who normally shop in New Jersey keeping their business at home, or are people who do their shopping in New York simply concentrating their purchases on this week? Are residents who never set foot in New Jersey doling out their whole winter or spring budgets for clothing in this one week to take advantage of the discount, causing a short-lived spurt in sales?
The Mayor called on residents to follow this strategy, saying they should squirrel away their money until this week. If clothing sales rise, he says, that will pressure Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature to reduce the sales tax permanently.
"By lifting the tax for one week and really increasing sales, we can send a powerful message to Albany," Mr. Giuliani exhorts in one of the radio advertisements that the city is broadcasting to broaden awareness of the tax holiday.
To economists, though, the shifting around of money that residents would be spending in the city anyway does not prove anything. They say it merely gives people a temporary tax cut, one that for the week will cost the city $7 million and the state $20 million.
"Economists are always suspicious of any kind of tax holiday system," Prof. John L. Mikesell, an expert on tax policy at Indiana University, said. "You are just moving activity from one period to another. The week before and the week after are going to be stolen from. In terms of base economic activity, there is no change."
The assertion that the tax holiday is more political expedience than policy-making tool stems in part from its beginnings in Albany. Mr. Giuliani and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, had pushed for a permanent cut in the sales tax, but Mr. Pataki and Republicans in the State Senate, who are more interested in reducing business and property taxes, balked.
As a compromise, the two sides agreed last July to the experiment.
Of course, the state could have repealed the sales tax for a longer period, one that might have yielded more insight. But that would have cost much more in tax revenue.
State leaders actually picked such a slow sales week so the government would not lose much tax revenue. Economists and retail analysts say the timing of the week is one more reason the state will not get an accurate picture.
"Trying to gather any information from this strikes me as an impossibility," said Prof. William F. Fox, a tax expert who is head of the economics department at the University of Tennessee. "I don't think it's a meaningful experiment at all."

HEADLINE: Virginia Seen as Undercutting U.S. Environmental Rules

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Virginia's shores are just across the Potomac River from the Environmental Protection Agency's waterside headquarters here, but a political gap much broader than that is threatening the usual partnership between the state and the Federal pollution authorities.
Senior officials at the E.P.A. call Virginia a leading example of widespread resistance by some states against vigorous enforcement of Federal environmental laws. The problem the state exemplifies, they say, is especially alarming at a time when states are gaining more responsibility in this area. 
 Virginia officials respond that the E.P.A. has been heavyhanded and rigid, and that its leaders are distorting Virginia's more flexible approach to environmental regulation for political reasons.
"I think that it is unfortunate that you have a lack of leadership in the state," said Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the E.P.A. "There is a disregard for the requirements of Federal laws, and I think there is a belief on the part of some in Virginia that ignoring the environment and public health standards is what the business community wants."
Becky Norton Dunlop, Virginia's Secretary of Natural Resources, said she strongly resented such remarks. "It is not something that Carol Browner has ever had the moral character to say to any of us directly," Ms. Dunlop said.
"I have made very clear with the E.P.A. people whom I have worked with that none of this is personal," Ms. Dunlop said. "This is strictly a matter of policy, not personality or politics."
The differences between the two sides came into sharp relief last month when the Federal Government sued Smithfield Foods and two of its subsidiaries about pollution of the Pagan River at the company's meat plants in Smithfield, Va. The E.P.A. acted because Virginia, in a suit of its own, had sought far lighter penalties than the agency wanted.
But modest penalties are just part of what concerns Federal officials -- and also some in Virginia's General Assembly, which recently received a highly critical review of the state's Department of Environmental Quality by the Joint Legislative Audit and Review Commission, the lawmakers' nonpartisan investigative arm.
In the 1996 fiscal year, Virginia assessed just $4,000 in civil penalties for water violations, one-tenth of the penalties the year before and sharply less than the average of the previous four years, the report said.
Additionally, according to the report, the number of cases referred to state law-enforcement authorities for prosecution has declined steadily in the past eight years. The number of inspections for air and water pollution violations is declining even as the number and complexity of pollution sources increase. (The state has said it is hiring more inspectors and expects water penalties this year to surpass the past five years combined.)
Virginia is appealing to the Supreme Court the requirements of 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act setting up a new system of air-pollution permits that states are supposed to enforce; the court is about to decide whether to hear the case.
The state has also blocked the E.P.A. from adding several new sites to the Federal list of the most serious Superfund violations. And over the agency's objections, it has enacted a law protecting companies from disclosure and punishment when they detect pollution violations in self-inspections and remedy them.
Some of these arguments go back many years, but they heated up when Gov. George Allen, a Republican, took office in 1994, pledging to make the regulatory climate more favorable to business.
Senior officials in the state continue to defend that approach and said that the E.P.A. was putting too much emphasis on prosecuting violations and collecting penalties and not enough on less punitive approaches, like negotiated consent orders.
"We think they should be working in partnership with the states, rather than engaging in 'gotcha,' if their interest is in the environment rather than building a bigger Federal bureaucracy," Ms. Dunlop said.
In pilot projects, the Federal agency has recently promoted alternatives to environmental regulation, Ms. Dunlop noted. "Even the Clinton Administration recognizes that compliance first is a legitimate policy of government," she said. "Then when you have bad actors, you fine them, and pursue them."
The state's critics, though, reply that to take this policy too far risks removing any economic incentive for companies to clean up their pollution problems, and that Virginia has been doing everything possible to minimize the Federal role in state environmental policy.
"The Allen administration has sought to turn this into an ideological battle over states' rights," said Katherine Slaughter, a staff lawyer at the Southern Environmental Law Center in Charlottesville, Va., an advocacy group. "If you look beyond the environmental question, they have done it with the motor-voter legislation for voting registration, with the rejection of the Goals 2000 program for the schools. So it is consistent with their ideology.
"The consistent message has been throughout that the states should be left to do their own thing, and on the environment, even more so."
 
Jurisdictions
Officials Clash Over Smithfield Case
Virginia officials say that the Federal Government's intervention in the highly publicized case involving Smithfield Foods, a maker of traditionally cured hams and other meat products, exemplifies Washington's interference in the state's handling of environmental enforcement.
In December, the E.P.A. filed a complaint against the company seeking as much as $125 million in civil penalties for longstanding serious water pollution violations, including discharges of fecal bacteria, phosphorous, ammonia, cyanide, oil and grease into a waterway. The state, trying to head off the Federal action, had earlier filed its own suit, but sought far lighter penalties.
The animosity between the state and Federal agencies erupted in late August, when Virginia officials learned that the E.P.A. was about to sue Smithfield.
The state was upset because what the Federal Government considered continuing violations concerned wastewater discharges that were within the limits of a consent order the state had negotiated with the company. The order gave the company time to hook up its meat operations to sewage treatment plants.
Virginia officials defend their use of consent orders rather than penalties, saying that they have led companies and municipalities to make billions of dollars of investments in pollution control.
The Federal authorities, for their part, were upset by the long history of violations by Smithfield, the continuing damage to the river and the state's lack of punitive action, an approach that critics say allows companies to enjoy economic gains from violations of the law.
Thomas L. Hopkins, director of the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality, argued angrily in a letter in August to the E.P.A.'s regional administrator that the E.P.A.'s planned complaint "strikes a grievous blow to E.P.A.'s credibility and to Federal-state cooperation in environmental enforcement."
A few days later, the state filed its own complaint against Smithfield, knowing that this usually pre-empted any Federal action. But this time, Michael McCabe, the E.P.A.'s regional administrator, signaled that the Federal Government would not defer to the state.
"Virginia has a history of initiating enforcement once E.P.A. informs the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality of its intentions to pursue Federal action," Mr. McCabe wrote to Mr. Hopkins on Sept. 19, citing three specific cases involving municipalities in the state. "In each case, the actions taken by the Commonwealth and the penalties collected were much less than E.P.A. believes were appropriate."
Reciting statistics showing how enforcement cases and penalties were steadily declining, he wrote that the decline "does not correlate to any increase in compliance" and complained that top Virginia officials "have made clear the desire to conduct less enforcement."
The Smithfield Foods case, Mr. McCabe said in the letter, was not an isolated example. Another was the state's decision to file for a modest penalty against Allied Signal Inc.
For many years, that company, which is based in Morristown, N.J., but has operations in Virginia, had spilled chemicals resulting in several fish kills. It paid penalties for spills from 1989 to 1991, but not for another series of spills from 1992 to January 1996. Two more spills of sulfuric acid last March and April killed thousands more fish. Three days after the E.P.A. moved to penalize the company, the state sought a penalty, but a lighter one.
"If there remained any question of your intentions to try to insulate violating industries from Federal enforcement, your recent order with Allied Signal Inc. should erase all uncertainty," Mr. McCabe contended. "The sanctions by the Commonwealth in attempting to shield two violators from legitimate Federal enforcement has provided no basis and little hope for effective cooperation on enforcement matters."
In his letter on Dec. 5 to the state legislative panel investigating the situation, Mr. Hopkins called Mr. McCabe's words "ill-advised" and said that E.P.A. aides had said informally that Mr. McCabe had acted for political reasons over the objections of his aides.
Ms. Dunlop, in an interview, echoed that complaint.
"I feel that E.P.A. truly became political," she said, contending, for instance, that the agency was making a point of going after states controlled by Republicans. "I find this frankly very disturbing. When you make environmental policy a political issue, you frankly damage the credibility of the agency with the people. And they have certainly damaged their credibility with me."

Weaknesses
A Poor Guardian Of Clean Water
 Virginia's critics have raised another serious concern about the Smithfield case, saying that it disclosed weaknesses at the heart of the water pollution control program, a system established by the Federal Clean Water Act but managed by the states, in which companies record and report data about their own discharges within the limits of permits.
Like other states, Virginia is supposed to oversee compliance with water pollution permits by using monthly reports known as discharge monitoring reports, or D.M.R.'s. These are based on samples collected by the companies and analyzed by the companies' laboratories or by labs that the companies hire.
"It appears that Virginia has never had adequate oversight of the D.M.R. process, and any oversight which may have existed in the past has diminished recently," the Virginia legislative report found.
The Smithfield case is especially noteworthy because the company was filing falsified reports, an offense that eventually led to a guilty plea by the person responsible.
In two consecutive months in 1993, the legislative investigators found, Smithfield submitted identical pollution reports for two different spots: the exact same amount of coliform bacteria, cyanide and nitrogen, for example, were said to be entering the water at two different locations two months in a row.
Other factors convinced state investigators that, as the report said, Virginia's "current water monitoring programs are inadequate":
*Virginia canceled a program in 1994 that used a mobile laboratory to check the accuracy of companies' lab analyses.
*Annual quality-control tests required by the E.P.A. show that in 1995 fewer than half of all water permit holders in the state achieved acceptable scores, the lowest performance in seven years.
*Unlike other states, Virginia has no minimum requirements for operating a lab to sample permit holders' effluents; some labs in Virginia actually seek North Carolina certification as a way of proving their competence to customers in Virginia.
The Federal Government, meanwhile, has a separate problem with Virginia's use of the discharge data. Beginning in October 1994, the state stopped entering the figures into the national data base known as the Permit Compliance System.
Last summer, after months of staff negotiations, the E.P.A. told Virginia that it would withhold water quality grants until the situation was corrected. Virginia promised that it was bringing a new computer system on line and would enter all the missing data by the end of 1996. According to E.P.A. officials, that has yet to be completed.
 
Beneficiaries
Small Companies Get Deference, Too
 Large companies like Smithfield and Allied Signal are not the only ones to have benefited from the state's policies.
For almost a mile downstream from the Casta Line Trout Farm, at the spot in the Shenandoahs where Cockran Spring feeds the Middle River, the water quality is "severely impaired," Virginia records say.
More than a year ago, state environmental enforcement officials drafted notices of violation for Casta Line and two other fish farms. In March, an inspection found several more violations of Casta Line's permits. But the officials were ordered by superiors not to press the case, and no fines or other penalties were assessed, according to a state report.
While the pollution by trout waste of one mile of creek water might seem trivial in a state that monitors 32,000 miles of waterways for pollution, critics of Virginia's environmental performance say the case typifies the state's deference to the needs of businesses.
In July 1995, the same month that the state's enforcement staff was drafting notices of violation for the fish farm, Ms. Dunlop wrote Brian Plemmons, the owner of Casta Line, about "your frustration that Virginia is applying E.P.A. regulations more stringently than other states."
Though her letter did not address the specifics of the violations at the trout farm, she promised Mr. Plemmons that the state would take action, including "minimizing monitoring requirements, to reduce the burdens on fish farms."
To Mr. Plemmons, accusations that he is polluting the water are ridiculous. He described his violations -- which inspectors said included inappropriate flushing of solid fish waste into the stream, failing to take samples during normal operations and failure to file a required report -- as mainly just technicalities.
"I have gotten a notice of violation for using ditto marks in a monthly discharge report," he said. "I have gotten a notice of violation for photocopying my signature. I have gotten a notice of violation for a broken membrane on my dissolved oxygen meter, and I think the inspector broke it."
But the scathing report issued in December by the State Legislature's panel cited the trout farm's case, along with many others, as evidence that Virginia's top environmental officials "have chosen to disregard" the state's laws and Constitution and were skirting Federal environmental requirements to favor industry.
"The state continues to experience difficulty in addressing long-term noncompliance and does not have a consistent, credible enforcement program," the report said. "D.E.Q.'s lack of leadership in these areas puts the state's future water quality at risk."
In response, Mr. Hopkins said the state agency believed that punishment was less important than bringing pollution under control, using what he called "an ascending ladder of compliance and enforcement tools."
"The change in policy is a deliberate attempt to change the focus of enforcement by shifting from punitive enforcement as the initial and primary compliance tool, as it had been a demonstrated failure nationwide," he said.

HEADLINE: Setting Campaign Goals, Whitman Describes a Record Broader Than Income Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Her proposal to cut the state's income tax helped get her elected. And keeping her promise accounts for much of her popularity. But now that Christine Todd Whitman is seeking re-election as Governor of New Jersey, she says she is concerned that she seems to be known for just one thing: cutting taxes.
"I keep hearing that 'She cut taxes by 30 percent, and that is all she has done,' " Mrs. Whitman said. "That infuriates me because we have done so much, a lot of it not sexy stuff but very important things. We have done a lot of things that have built the base for real quantum changes over the next few years, that really will make a long-term difference." 
 Mrs. Whitman offered these remarks today in an interview in which she laid out an election strategy intended to broaden her appeal among Democratic and independent voters. She insisted that in her first term, she had taken major steps to overhaul the juvenile justice system, the state's welfare programs and the way that New Jersey sets curriculum standards and finances its public schools. She said she was seeking a second term to see those changes through.
In addition, she said her priorities would be more jobs and affordable housing in the state's cities and to help strengthen the state's economy.
She dismissed critics who contend that all she has done is cut state taxes and pay for those cuts with risky fiscal maneuvers.
"They are wrong," she said. "There are schools. There is welfare. There is the environment. There are jobs. There is the Transportation Trust Fund, and there have been smaller, but important changes, like tort reform, and binding arbitration, which should help localities lower property taxes."
Although she made no mention of her upcoming re-election bid in her annual address to the Legislature last Tuesday, Mrs. Whitman clearly was staking out her administration's accomplishments in areas where Democrats believe she is vulnerable. She offered a plan to bring down the state's high automobile insurance rates. She said property tax increases have been, on average, the lowest in decades. She also promised millions of dollars in new spending to help build affordable housing in the cities.
"She sounded like a Democrat running in a Democratic primary," said Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Congressman from Camden County and one of seven potential Democratic challengers who insists that she can be toppled in November because of voter anger over property taxes and the quality of public education.
Mrs. Whitman said that perhaps she has been at fault for not getting out the message about her administration's accomplishments. She said that she was determined to tell voters about her whole record.
She also said that she was not daunted by the large Democratic turnout at the polls in the state's urban areas last November because she thinks that many of those voters will vote for her.
"You never forget your base," said Mrs. Whitman, who vowed to run as "an underdog" even in Republican strongholds. "Politics is the heart of the election process and we have done a lot of things. I refuse to concede anything. I am not going to concede any part of this state.
"I am Governor of the whole state, and I have always been someone who has been very interested in what we can do with some of the bigger challenges. I hear a lot about that Democrats are the ones who care, and they are in the cities. Look at the cities. Our cities are in really bad shape. Republicans have not been running them. I believe that our state can not thrive if our cities are not doing better."
Mrs. Whitman's job performance ratings in polls have been consistently above 50 percent. And as Clifford Zukin, a pollster and professor at Rutgers University, says, she may be tough to beat because the state's economy shows no signs of weakening, and incumbents usually fare well in good economic times.
"Right now, people are satisfied with the way the state is run," Mr. Zukin said. "They like her. There is not a reason in the world to vote against her. She is well liked, but people don't know much about her. She is not viewed as having a second issue yet."
Mrs. Whitman said she knows that Democrats will try to make an issue out of the state's high property taxes. She said she does not have a plan similar to that proposed by New York Governor George E. Pataki that would provide localities with direct property tax relief. But she said that she would look at the proposal and consider similar measures, if re-elected.
At the same time, she said she thinks voters understand that local governments, not state government, set the local property tax rate, and she believes that local governments are reining in their spending, which has led to the slowest property tax growth in decades. She also said she signed legislation last year returning the property tax deduction on state income tax returns.
"I can't take away the property tax," she said. "But there is no question about it, we have done a great deal to address the issue, like taking over the court system from the counties, which gives the counties and the municipalities the flexibility that they need to address the issue on their own."
During her 1993 campaign, she said some of her political advisers urged her to propose property tax relief instead of an income tax cut. But she said her economic advisers, among them Steve Forbes, convinced her that only a reduction in the state's income tax rates would improve the state's business climate and create jobs.
"I grew up in this state," she said. "I understand the property tax issue, but it wasn't going to be what we needed to turn this state around, and my goal was to turn this state around."
Although she said there was much more to do to help create jobs, she said she was confident that the state was on the right track. Yet there are new challenges ahead in attracting and keeping business in the state, she said, with new technology making it easier for companies to locate outside the northeast and away from their customers.
Although gubernatorial races in New Jersey are publicly financed, the playing field this year is far from even since all of the potential Democratic challengers are relatively unknown outside their districts, with the exception of former Gov. Jim Florio, who has not yet said whether he wants the job back.
Mrs. Whitman, who assembled her own campaign team this week, said she thinks that a rematch with Mr. Florio would be "fascinating because there would be a real apples to apples comparison," and she is confident that voters would approve her approach toward government.
Of the other potential Democratic candidates, she said Representative Andrews or State Senator James E. McGreevey, who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge Township, would pose the biggest challenges because they each can claim a political base in important areas of the state.
Under New Jersey's campaign finance rules, Governor Whitman begins fund raising this week, like all the other candidates, without any money in the bank. But she has already established her ability at fund raising, collecting $4 million for the state and national Republican Committee last year. A $500-a-plate fund-raiser has been scheduled in February. Her brother, former Assemblyman Webster Dan Todd Jr., who served as her campaign manager for much of her 1993 race, will return to her side for this campaign as her finance chairman.
Contributions are limited to $2,100, and there is a $6.9 million campaign spending limit, including $4.6 million in taxpayer funds.
But Mrs. Whitman said that she expected outside money would be spent in New Jersey, perhaps from organized labor or even the Democratic National Committee. She said that it was too early to know whether the Republican National Committee would allocate resources to her campaign.
Mrs. Whitman, who was much talked about last year as a possible vice presidential nominee, brushed aside questions about whether she would promise voters that she would serve her an entire term and whether she had political aspirations beyond New Jersey.
"Honest to God, I am not thinking about any agenda beyond New Jersey," she said. "Obviously, I would like to be re-elected comfortably because that would be an affirmation of what we have been doing, and I think that we have done an awful lot."

HEADLINE: Tax Break Warms Shoppers' Hearts, Despite Cold Snap

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
On a day so cold that newscasters were advising people to venture out only for essentials like bread and milk, Beth Murphy bundled up and went to the Gap. There, amid the blue sweaters and smart black shoes, she found her own comforting warmth in the form of New York State's temporary sales-tax repeal.
Inside the store at Herald Square, with the hood of her pink coat still pulled over her head and her hands clenching and unclenching to regain feeling, Ms. Murphy patiently tried yesterday to explain why she had risked frostbite to shop. There is something liberating, she said, in seeing a price tag and knowing that no further math is involved to determine the final cost. 
 "What you see is what you get," she said. "It's a real incentive."
Throughout the city and in most of the state, the first day of a weeklong tax exemption on most clothing and accessories lured shoppers from the warmth of their homes and into temperatures that, with the wind-chill factor, dipped below zero. The idea is to test the economic effect of ending the tax permanently, but tax experts say the brief experiment will probably be of little real use. [News analysis, page 30.]
At Bloomingdale's on Lexington Avenue and East 59th Street, as many as 200 people were waiting outside for the store to open at 10 A.M. By late afternoon, a spokesman estimated, the store had doubled the sales it enjoyed at the same time last year. But it was hard to determine yesterday whether the scene at Bloomingdale's was an aberration or the norm.
A Victoria's Secret on East 57th Street was more crowded than usual, while a Banana Republic on Fifth Avenue was less crowded, perhaps because of the cold weather. Also, January is the month when customers receive credit card statements stating, in the starkest of terms, what they owe from that giddy holiday spending spree in December. Widespread frugality traditionally ensues, leaving sales clerks with nothing to do but fold and refold the sweaters on display.
"I don't think it's really a true test," said the general manager at Banana Republic, at Fifth Avenue and 53d Street. "Everyone is spent out."
At the very least, the tax holiday prompted several of the state's politicians to come down with shopping fever. Gov. George E. Pataki went to Macy's at Herald Square. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani visited the Manhattan Mall nearby, then joined the Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, at the Staten Island Mall. And the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, went looking for shirts, ties and a tuxedo along Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens.
Before heading off to browse at Modell's, Mayor Giuliani banged a gong to ring in the day. "I know that dropping the sales tax will bring more commercial activity to New York City," he said. "I know that it will bring more jobs to New York City. And if you see the fear that people around us have of this happening, you realize that I am right."
The bang of a gong signaled the declaration of war, or at least a brief battle, against that shopping haven to the west, New Jersey, where the sales tax is considerably lower. Governor Pataki and the State Legislature instituted the 4 percent state tax reduction -- on clothes and certain other items costing less than $500 each, regardless of the total bill -- in part to test the sense that New York was losing business to New Jersey and surrounding states.
All but 8 of New York's 62 counties chose to match the state's tax exemption. Meanwhile, New York City suspended its 4 percent tax at the same time that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority tax, of one-quarter of 1 percent, was waived. That translated into an 8.25 percent tax break in the city.
So if Ms. Murphy had spent $100 on clothes at the Gap yesterday, she would have saved $8.25 -- enough to buy two pairs of Gap socks that could have been worn to ward off frostbite on her way home.
Ms. Murphy, a secretary who lives in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan, chose not to buy anything at the Gap. Even so, the sales tax exemption had been enough to lure her from her apartment. "I wouldn't normally come out when it's this cold," she said.
Ms. Murphy was not alone in her arctic expedition. David L. Fisher, a senior vice president at Bloomingdale's, said the store's strong results were part serendipitous, part self-fulfilling. Sales were slightly sluggish last week, which he said indicated that people were waiting for the tax waiver. In addition, Bloomingdale's had called many of its preferred customers to recommend that they wait until the tax holiday to shop. "We advised them that this would be a good time to shop for apparel, shoes and some accessory items like scarves and gloves," he said. "We solicited it."
In fact, shoppers everywhere were finding ways to capitalize on the tax holiday. Customers repeatedly called Jildor's, an upscale shoe store in Cedarhurst, L.I., last week to request that shoes be put aside for them; those customers began returning yesterday to complete their tax free purchases of shoes that generally cost more than $100 a pair.
Sheila Stehlik, a store manager, motioned toward a back room. Inside were shelves stacked with more than 200 reserved boxes of shoes, all labeled with the names of customers.
Over all, the day with little taxation annoyed some and pleased others. Vincent Valentino, the director of the South Bronx Business Improvement District, said the organization had spent $20,000 promoting the tax free week. And so far, he said, he was not pleased with the turnout.
"This should have been done right before Christmas or after Thanksgiving," Mr. Valentino said.
Meanwhile, Beverly Conner and Kisha Lettine resisted the urge to cross the Goethals Bridge to New Jersey and were rewarded with savings at the stores on Staten Island, where they live.
"Of course, we're down here for the tax savings," Ms. Conner said, her arms wrapped around packages. "I usually go to New Jersey," Ms. Lettine said, "but because of the tax free day, I was able to save myself the $4 toll."
This was the reaction hoped for by Governor Pataki, who also did what he could yesterday to promote his Shop New York cause. The Governor, his wife, Libby, and his daughter Allison arrived at Macy's with his pronouncement, "We're here to shop." The family then bought several items, including a sweater and a jacket, at a tax savings of about $12.
As the Governor was leaving the department store, a woman stopped him at the door with a question: "Can you buy me a bottle of perfume."
"Buy you a bottle of perfume?" he said, somewhat stunned. "No."
If the Governor had bought the constituent a bottle of perfume, the gesture would have been magnanimous without being politically useful. In New York, perfume remains a taxable item.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The shoes fit and looked good, so Olibia Blanc snapped them up at Yaffa Fashion on 149th Street in the Bronx, saving about $2 in sales tax. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times) (pg. 30)

For details, shoppers can call (800) CALL-TAX weekdays, or check the World Wide Web site at http://www.tax.state.ny.us.

NONEXEMPT: Helmets.
 
HANDS

NONEXEMPT: Baseball, tennis, biking, golfing and surgical gloves.
 
FEET

NONEXEMPT: Shoes for water sports. Wading, climbing and ski boots.
 
ACCESSORIES

NONEXEMPT: Handbags, handkerchiefs and most hair wear (barrettes, clips, bows, bands, etc.)
 
SPORTS
EXEMPT: Sports uniforms, including caps; martial-arts attire, bowling shirts and bathing suits.
NONEXEMPT: Cleats, gloves, ice skates, shoulder pads, bowling shoes, goggles and life vests.
 
MISCELLANEOUS

NONEXEMPT: Crib blankets and wigs. (Source: New York State Department of Taxation and Finance) (pg. 30)

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: THE ISSUES;
Crowded, Ambitious Foreign Policy Agenda Awaits President in New Term

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
There would be enough on the foreign policy plate even if this President were preoccupied with foreign policy. If President Clinton's first term was about minimalist goals -- intervening when absolutely necessary to stop the killing in Haiti and Bosnia, finding a workable China policy, helping to keep Russia from falling apart -- his second term is inevitably more ambitious.
Mr. Clinton would like to preside over an expanded NATO, a Syrian-Israeli settlement in the Middle East, peace in Northern Ireland, and a relationship with both Russia and China that anchors them in the obligations of the community of nations. 
 Some senior European diplomats even worry that a re-elected President, with a bolder, more vocal Secretary of State in Madeleine K. Albright, will overreach. But she describes herself as a "principled pragmatist," looking to make Americans understand how important foreign policy and foreign trade are to their daily jobs and lives.
No one has a very compelling "vision" of this new post-Soviet world, but Ms. Albright, with her experience at the United Nations, is as prepared as anyone to try to persuade Americans, as The Economist magazine suggested last week, of "how alliances and multilateral institutions can enhance and legitimize" American power, "rather than hamper it."
But discussions with State Department, White House and Congressional foreign policy experts suggests that this year's agenda will be dominated by NATO expansion, Russia's opposition to it, China and, of course, the Middle East.
 
NATO and Russia
There is a lot to get done before July. It is then that NATO leaders meet in Madrid, in a trans-Atlantic version of the Oscars, to name the successful candidates for membership in 1999. The oddsmakers are pretty sure about Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, but they are uncertain about Slovenia and doubtful about the chances for Slovakia, Romania and everybody else.
But by then, Washington wants to have an understanding with Russia -- sometimes called a charter -- laying out Moscow's security relationship with a "new" NATO and allowing Moscow to have some institutionalized, advisory say on pan-European issues like Bosnia.
The idea is to try to make Russia -- whose transition to a democracy and a market economy without imperial ambitions is supported by Washington -- more comfortable with the enlargement of an alliance set up to defend Europe from Russia. Turning a sense of ostracism into one of inclusion is a difficult trick the charter is supposed to perform.
While Washington does not want to make NATO expansion dependent on the completion of such a charter, important NATO allies like France and even Germany are stressing the need for parallelism. President Jacques Chirac of France said this month that it was "unimaginable" to expand NATO without a complete charter, and senior American officials themselves say that by July, "we need to have a package of understandings that makes concrete the rhetoric of cooperation with Russia."
Tomorrow, NATO Secretary General Javier Solana is expected to be in Moscow to begin such discussions. But with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia still recuperating from his heart operation and pneumonia, the Russian position is hard to read.
Meanwhile, citing the "threat" of NATO enlargement, the Russians are holding off on ratifying the second strategic arms reduction treaty, Start 2, and are making intermittent and possibly idle threats about merging with Belarus and refusing to conclude a border dispute with Estonia.
While backing Mr. Yeltsin, American officials admit their frustration with the stagnant Washington-Moscow relations of the last six months.
Mr. Yeltsin's Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, is being allowed more authority to discuss security issues, and he and Vice President Al Gore will have one of their semiannual meetings in the first week of February. Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton are scheduled to have one of their regular summit meetings in March. Still, many American officials believe that talks on a charter will go down to the wire.
Ms. Albright must also try to insure that NATO expansion does not diminish the security of countries that will not join NATO now, like the Baltic states and Ukraine.
 
China
July is also the month the British flag comes down over Hong Kong as it reverts to Chinese rule. Washington regards the manner of China's reabsorption of Hong Kong as a benchmark. Some American officials fear that friction between Hong Kong's democracy advocates and its new Chinese rulers could spark overreaction by Beijing, producing popular revulsion among Americans over closer Sino-American ties.
Last year, the Clinton Administration tried to rebuild a relationship with Beijing on the basis of mutual interests in security, nuclear nonproliferation and trade. The idea is to pull China more firmly into the community of nations, while persauding Beijing that membership also means responsibility on intellectual property rights, arms sales, global trade, regional security and human rights.
While Beijing is cooperative on important questions like the future of collapsing North Korea's nuclear program, it has been less than forthcoming about its nuclear and military cooperation agreements with Pakistan and Iran, has put blunt military pressure on Taiwan, has not adequately opened its huge market to foreign goods and its human-rights record has worsened.
The Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, is due in Washington sometime before March, and Vice President Gore -- taking on more foreign policy responsibility as he burnishes his resume for the 2000 campaign -- is scheduled to visit Beijing.
Chinese President Jiang Zemin is likely to make a state visit here in the autumn, presuming that the Hong Kong hand over goes relatively smoothly, with President Clinton due to visit Beijing in 1998.
 
The Middle East
The special envoy Dennis B. Ross just spent the best part of a month trying to get Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to conclude the details of an agreement already negotiated: the redeployment of Israeli troops in Hebron. The core problem is trust, or the lack of it, complicated by almost total disagreement on the harder issues to come, like the final status of Jerusalem and whether there will be a Palestinian state.
Mr. Clinton is inviting both men, plus the Egyptian and Jordanian leaders, Hosni Mubarak and King Hussein, to Washington meetings to discuss the future.
Mr. Clinton would like Israel to resume peace talks with Syria, but Damascus wants back the Golan Heights, which Mr. Netanyahu intends to keep.
The first task, as aides to Mr. Ross admit, is to see whether Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat are able to meet without an American mediator in the room.
 
Money and Neighbors
Mr. Clinton is eager to make his first Presidential trip to Latin America -- which could take place before the end of March, officials say -- to acknowledge the spread of democracy and promote freer trade. He will also make a trip to Mexico, to congratulate the leaders there for paying off all their emergency loans from Washington last week. But some officials worry that Mexico is not out of danger from unrest and economic mismanagement.
Ms. Albright promises a renewed effort to stop the slide in spending, in real terms, on foreign policy. Leadership, she says -- and as Warren Christopher said before her -- cannot be had "on the cheap." But to make the case, she will need a concerted effort from Mr. Clinton, which he has not yet been willing to make. And the United Nations is expecting its largest debtor to pay its bills.
 
Nailbiters
New tensions over Cyprus have officials extremely worried. The Greek Cypriots have told American diplomats that their purchase of an air-defense system from Russia is only to prepare them for negotiations with the Turkish side. Istanbul does not see it that way, and has threatened war, if necessary, to block deployment.
The Administration will need to rethink its decaying policy of "dual containment" of Iran and Iraq. The Saudis, trying to mask dissent by religious fundamentalists, are pointing at Iran for the bomb that killed 19 American soldiers last year in Dhahran. Iraq's Saddam Hussein remains in place and unbowed. Avoiding military action of some sort in the gulf over the next four years, some officials think, will be difficult.
Conflicts in Rwanda, Burundi and Zaire simmer, with the potential for new genocide in Africa. Northern Ireland is fraying again, with no quick prospect for a renewed ceasefire, let alone peace. The South Koreans need constant hand-holding as North Korea totters. India and Pakistan, both with nuclear weapons, love each other no more than before.
In the former Yugoslavia, where the United States has troops in Bosnia, the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, is teetering and the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, is dying, while an arbitrator's decision on the disputed town of Brcko is due in a month. Most officials consider this a recipe for instability.
And no matter what any American President's goals may be, there is always the Middle East.

HEADLINE: Governor of Puerto Rico Presses Battle for Statehood

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 13

 BODY:
At his inauguration as Puerto Rico's re-elected Governor earlier this month, Pedro J. Rossello apologized to those who find him "stubborn, obsessive, even intransigent." He then promised more of the same for his next four-year term, including forging ahead with a new plebiscite to get the island and the United States to redefine their nearly century-old relationship once and for all.
"It is the responsibility of this generation, facing the new millennium, to define clearly, decisively and finally the route of our political destiny," Mr. Rossello said from the grounds of El Morro, the four-century-old fort that provided a backdrop of Spanish colonialism for the Governor's reference to what he and other supporters of statehood for Puerto Rico regard as its modern-day American version. 
 The new millennium and next year's 100th anniversary of the Spanish-American War loom heavily on this island as its leadership seeks a permanent political status that leaves behind any vestiges of colonialism. Mr. Rossello provided the momentum last November when he carried his pro-statehood New Progressive Party to its greatest electoral triumph ever by capturing 51 percent of all votes cast, the first absolute majority victory for the party in an election for governor.
Most agree that Mr. Rossello, a 52-year-old pediatric surgeon with no previous experience in an elective office before first winning the governorship in 1992, won more on personality and performance than ideology. His tough anti-crime measures and government-sponsored health insurance program have drawn wide support, and his confrontational style of politics is tempered by a populist image best captured last year when he campaigned in blue jeans and to the beat of the "Macarena," dancing to wild cheering.
But Mr. Rossello also campaigned on a pledge to seek a binding, Congressionally sponsored plebiscite in 1998 that would allow Puerto Rico's 3.7 million residents to choose among statehood, independence, the existing commonwealth or some other form of association with the United States. And the election results are seen by many here and in Washington as a strong demand, if not for statehood, then for the chance to vote on that choice.
"There's no doubt we have a mandate to deal with the decolonization process," said Charlie Rodriguez, the pro-statehood president of the Puerto Rican Senate.
It is unknown whether the current Congress will be any more ready to set out the terms under which the island would be admitted to the union than previous ones, which have failed, despite bipartisan support, to reach a consensus on statehood and the enhanced political and economic benefits that go with it. But statehooders here, fresh from also sweeping both houses of the Legislature, most municipalities and the island's nonvoting seat in Congress in the November election, are confident that they would be able to win a majority in a status referendum, enough to be taken seriously by Congress and prod it into action.
A spokeswoman for Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, said he planned to re-introduce a bill that drew encouraging support last year in the House and that called for a plebiscite next year, ratification by voters and Congress, and a phase-in period to carry out the chosen option by 2010. In a letter to Mr. Rossello last month, President Clinton for the first time promised to work "to establish a process that would enable the fundamental issue of Puerto Rico's political status to finally be resolved."
Spain ceded Puerto Rico to the United States in 1898 after the Spanish-American War and Puerto Ricans became American citizens in 1917. Puerto Rico has its own laws, taxes and government but is subject to Federal policy, including military service. Puerto Ricans who live on the island do not pay Federal taxes, cannot vote for President or receive full representation in Congress, and their Federal aid is limited.
Although supporters of the commonwealth status established in 1952 see the relationship with the United States as a bilateral agreement, proponents of statehood and independence shun it as second-class citizenship or colonialism.
The historic ambivalence in Congress over a status change in Puerto Rico is sharply mirrored on the island, primarily because of concerns over the fate of the Spanish language, American citizenship and the island's nationhood under new political formulas. In a nonbinding plebiscite held in 1993, the commonwealth option won 48 percent of the vote, compared with 46 percent for statehood and 4 percent for independence.
But support for the commonwealth eroded from a previous plebiscite held in 1967, when that option got 60 percent of the vote, compared with 39 percent for statehood. In a recent interview here, Governor Rossello credited the gains in the pro-statehood movement in part to demographics -- young voters, who cast their ballots for him in large numbers, "are more open to change and more confident of their own capabilities," he said.
Mr. Rossello acknowledged that the idea of a 51st state will encounter resistance in the mainland, particularly from those threatened by the growth of the nation's Hispanic population. But he said Puerto Rico has the world's largest unenfranchised population and belies American championship of democracy.
The New Progressive Party sweep came at the expense of the two other political forces on the island, the pro-commonwealth Popular Democratic Party and the Puerto Rican Independence Party. The Popular Democrats, who say commonwealth status offers Puerto Ricans the best of two worlds, attribute their loss to campaign mistakes and the need of their party to modernize and focus on urban problems.
