HEADLINE: Paul Tsongas, Ex-Senator Who Sought Presidency in '92, Dies at 55

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts who was the only candidate in the 1992 Democratic Presidential campaign to offer painful solutions to the nation's economic problems, died last night at a hospital in Boston. He was 55.
Mr. Tsongas, who was hospitalized on Jan. 3 with a liver problem related to his treatments for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a slow-growing cancer of the lymph system, and later developed pneumonia, died at Brigham and Women's Hospital, officials told The Associated Press. 
 Mr. Tsongas made his survival from cancer an issue in his Presidential campaign when he and two of his doctors, Dr. Tak Takvorian and Dr. George Canellos, said he had been cancer-free since a bone-marrow transplant in 1986.
In May 1996, he underwent another transplant, getting bone marrow from his twin sister, Thaleia Schlesinger, to correct myelodysplasia, a bone-marrow disorder common in people who have recovered from lymph cancer.
In seeking the nomination, Mr. Tsongas offered a somber analysis of the nation's economic plight in a book published by his campaign, "Economic Call to Arms." He opposed a tax cut for the middle class but advocated one on capital gains to stimulate investment.
Instead of fire-in-the-belly oratory, Mr. Tsongas offered a wry, self-deprecatory and occasionally moralistic message about responsibility. He began the primariy campaign with a victory in New Hampshire and went on to win in three other states and the caucuses of four states.
He suspended his campaign after losing primaries in Illinois and Michigan. By not formally withdrawing, Mr. Tsongas retained his delegates, which totaled 551 by convention time, but Bill Clinton had more than the 2,145 needed for nomination.
Mr. Tsongas once said three things defined him: working as a young man in his father's dry-cleaning business in the economically depressed city of Lowell, Mass., serving in the Peace Corps and contracting the cancer that interrupted his political career in 1983.
He said the first made him aware of economic hardships; the second brought a joy in public service that led to a political career, and the third, his cancer, tempered what he called an overriding ambition.
"Pre-cancer, I was one of the pettiest people you've ever run into," Mr. Tsongas said in an interview in 1992. "I would get angry at my wife for leaving the top off the toothpaste. I'd get angry at my kids for the dumbest things. Looking back on it I feel mortified. I was a fool."
In his Presidential run, he tried to blend his three defining experiences into a political philosophy, characterizing his emphasis on building the economy as well as maintaining traditional Democratic social programs as "compassionate realism."
At the start of the campaign, Mr. Tsongas used what he said was his victory over the disease in his advertisements, and demonstrated his health by swimming the strenuous butterfly stroke. His doctors said he had been free of the disease after a bone marrow transplant in 1986.
But in April 1992, a few days after the New York primary, Mr. Tsongas conceded that he had been treated in 1987 for a recurrence of the lymphoma. Months after the campaign, Mr. Tsongas said he had erred in not disclosing the recurrence.
He pledged that if he ever ran again, he would submit his medical records to independent experts.
Most of Mr. Tsongas's political career was a triumph against the odds. After serving on the Lowell City Council from 1969 to 1972 and later as a Middlesex County Commissioner, he decided to seek the Congressional seat for his home district in 1974.
He won the Democratic primary with 70 percent of the vote. Then, in the aftermath of Watergate, he defeated the one-term Republican incumbent, Paul W. Cronin, to become the first Democrat to represent the district in about 90 years.
In 1978 he was one of five Democrats who sought to challenge Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts. Mr. Tsongas won the primary with 36 percent of the vote and then defeated Senator Brooke by about 200,000 votes.
On Sept. 29, 1983, when Mr. Tsongas discovered a lump in his groin, he thought it was a hernia, an inconvenience that would interfere with his plans to run in the Boston Marathon. But it was the cancer that would change his life.
What followed was a painful bone marrow transplant that left him with a new sense of his mortality. With that came a desire to spend more time with his family and subsequently a decision to retire from the Senate. He then joined the Boston law firm of Foley, Hoag & Eliot, saying that there he could earn the kind of income that would provide security for his family should he die.
But Mr. Tsongas said he did not want to be remembered only as the Senator who quit his political career because he had cancer.
In part, he said, it was his five-year freedom from cancer that had prompted him to run for the Democratic nomination when President George Bush's popularity was at its high point. But Mr. Tsongas had long coveted the office.
Like President Clinton, Mr. Tsongas was inspired to go into politics by President John F. Kennedy. In 1962, answering Kennedy's call to public service, Mr. Tsongas was among the first young people to join the newly created Peace Corps. He spent two years as a teacher in Ethiopia.
After returning to the United States, he attended Yale Law School and spent two summers working in the Washington office of Representative F. Bradford Morse, a Republican who represented Mr. Tsongas's home district.
Fascinated by the Vietnam War, Mr. Tsongas read about Vietnam and studied its language. He considered becoming a medic with the Green Berets. Instead, after he finished law school, he returned to the Peace Corps as director in the West Indies. Unable to recapture the satisfaction he had felt as a volunteer, he decided to go into politics, this time as a Democrat. Mr. Tsongas attributed the switch to his experience in the Peace Corps and growing up in a declining city.
Paul Efthemios Tsongas was born Feb. 14, 1941, in Lowell, the son of Efthemios and Katina Tsongas, who had immigrated from Greece. Growing up in Lowell after the closing of the textile mills, he keenly felt the plight of its residents. It was a city whose empty factories and stores and jobless workers, he said, reflected the economic troubles of the nation as a whole.
His father, who had missed graduating from Harvard by a semester because of the Depression, owned a modest dry-cleaning business where Paul and his twin sister, Thaleia, worked after school. He straightened hangers, he said, and brooded about not being able to take part in school sports because of the work.
Mr. Tsongas said he had had a respectful and sometimes strained relationship with his father, particularly when the son's growing liberalism conflicted with his father's conservatism. The elder Mr. Tsongas died in 1980, and Paul Tsongas's mother died tuberculosis when he 6.
Survivors include his wife, the former Nicola Sauvage; three daughters, Ashlay, Katina, and Molly, and his twin sister, Thaleia Schlesinger.
On Dec. 1, 1992, when he disclosed at a news conference that he had developed a new type of lymphoma, Mr. Tsongas exhibited his characteristically dry humor. Asked what he would say if he had been elected President, he replied: "I would love to be standing here today as President-elect. The fact is a lot of people who should have run for President didn't. There was a medical problem with gonads, not lymph nodes."

Mexico Repays Its Debt

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
No sooner had President Clinton bailed out Mexico in 1995, forestalling an economic collapse that might have also sunk other big, emerging markets, than critics warned he could kiss that $12.5 billion goodbye. Getting a better rate from the international lenders who have returned to Mexico, the Zedillo Government repaid Washington -- and the Administration boasted that it made $560 million in interest. HEADLINE: The Clinton Principle;
The Vital Center Will Not Hold

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is a professor of American history at Columbia University and the author most recently of "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War."

 BODY:
President Clinton approaches his second inauguration with his campaign still running at full throttle. Having spent 1996 embracing the political center so fervently that his Republican opponents were hard-pressed to find an issue on which they disagreed with him, he has been talking ever since of governing from a new "vital center." "The public wants us to work together," he said recently. "I stand ready to forge a coalition of the center. . . ."
 The image of a consensual, bipartisan politics is an old and attractive one. It is also unattainable. Standing above partisanship was a brilliant campaign tactic, but campaigning and governing are two different things. If President Clinton really expects to govern without conflict by identifying an noncontroversial center, his second term wll be even more frustrating than his first. For there is nothing -- either in our history or in the present, fractious political moment -- to suggest that there is a nonpolitical route to progress. 
 There were similar efforts in the first years of the Republic, when most Americans considered the idea of party and faction antithetical to the nation's founding ideals (but which produced some of the bitterest partisan battles in our history); the "era of Good Feeling" after the War of 1812, when the two-party system briefly collapsed and James Monroe was elected President virtually without opposition (an era that also produced extraordinary acrimony and, eventually, another vigorous party system), and Lincoln's effort to produce a national unity government through the Union Party in 1864 (followed by the agonizing politics of Reconstruction). None of them succeeded in the end. In our large, diverse and contentious society, there is rarely any real consensus on anything beyond a few broad principles. And a leader who ceases to take sides simply abdicates his role and hands authority over to his strongest competitors. That is precisely what President Clinton now risks doing.
 We have seen a glimpse of what this strategy would likely produce were the President to pursue it. The election was hardly behind us when he backed away from his longstanding, principled opposition to the balanced-budget amendment -- apparently reluctant to shatter the "era of good feeling" that he is so implausibly trying to create. But nothing would be more damaging to Clinton's hopes than an inflexible requirement that the budget be constantly in balance. The President may not be able to stop Congress from passing the amendment, but to acquiesce now will destroy any influence he might have over the ratification process, where it might still be derailed.
 President Clinton won re-election by targeting his campaign at a small group of middle-class, white swing voters whose impatience with partisan politics borders on disdain. For them, the "vital center" will seem appealing. But those voters will not be working Capitol Hill this year. Highly organized and lavishly funded interest groups will. And interest groups have no incentive to embrace the center; each of them is answerable to the constituency that employs them. A President who shies away from conflict will greatly increase their power.
 Nor does the 105th Congress seem any more likely than the 104th to sign up for membership in the President's "vital center." If anything, the present Republican leadership may be more partisan (even if less vocal about it) than it was in the last session. Newt Gingrich continues to insist that the meltdown of his own political reputation is a result of unscrupulous attacks by his opponents. And Trent Lott -- the personification of the iron fist in the velvet glove -- has proclaimed that he will not cooperate in any effort to reform Medicare unless President Clinton first renounces his own "demagogic" campaign attacks on the Republicans. If the verdict of the electorate was for centrist policies, it was a verdict that seems lost on the Republican leaders in Congress.
 President Clinton's most significant achievements in his first term were the result of arduous partisan struggles. He passed his first budget, substantially lowering the deficit, without a single Republican vote. He both stalled the "Gingrich Revolution" and revived his own campaign by refusing to accept the Republicans' budget in 1995, despite two shutdowns of the Federal Government. By contrast, his ambitious health care reform was tailored to meet conservative objections, and he urged Congressional consensus on the issue. The result was an epic political disaster.
When Arthur Schlesinger published "The Vital Center" in 1948, he surely did not anticipate that its title would be appropriated to describe President Clinton's careful, limited second-term agenda. The problem of democracy, Schlesinger wrote then, was that it failed to inspire much passion and was, therefore, vulnerable to competition from the millennial promises of the totalitarian right and left, and even more to widespread disaffection and apathy. For the "vital center" of democracy to thrive, he wrote, it had to be more than a cautious, pragmatic creed. It had to be a "fighting faith," an arena of struggle "breeding contradiction, breeding strife," capable of answering questions vital to the human condition. If President Clinton wants to create a true "vital center," he will fight for what he believes and exhort others to follow -- not seek a refuge in the myth of a world without politics.

HEADLINE: A Rising Tide Sinks All Boats

BYLINE: By Matthew Miller; Matthew Miller is a syndicated columnist and a senior editor of The New Republic.

 BODY:

ONE WORLD,
 READY OR NOT
 The Manic Logic of Global Capitalism.
 By William Greider.
 528 pp. New York.
 Simon & Schuster. $27.50. 
 Most thinking Americans, and even some investment bankers, get wind of events in today's global economy and aren't sure what it all means. If you've been baffled by the whirlwind but haven't known where to begin, I wish I could say that William Greider's new jeremiad, "One World, Ready or Not," is the one book you'll need. But it's only half of it.
The truth is there won't be another book this year that grapples more ambitiously with the big picture in political economy -- or which fluctuates so maddeningly between brilliance and fallacy in its analysis. Mr. Greider, the populist critic (and onetime David Stockman confessor) who writes for Rolling Stone, predicts an almost apocalyptic reckoning if upheavals in commerce, finance and societies worldwide go unchecked. The problem is that for all his impressive reporting, imaginative syntheses and moral conviction, Mr. Greider's economics are often sloppy or worse. The result is a paradox. Usually books like this feature compelling diagnoses followed by lame cures. Here, though Mr. Greider mischaracterizes many of our troubles, he's full of important ideas about what we should do about them.
It's hard to do summary justice to Mr. Greider's many-layered argument, but here goes. We live at the dawn of a new age, in which technology has brought transport, communications and computing costs low enough to make production and capital flows truly global. Governments, heeding the Wall Street types who control the terms of public borrowing (and who benefit most from globalization), have pushed the process along through deregulation. While global integration brings undeniable marvels and progress (Islamic women get bank accounts thanks to Motorola's training; British homeowners get cheaper mortgages thanks to George Soros's war on the pound), it also brings social havoc and power that is accountable to no one (Islamic men ask what happened; Brits ask who elected Mr. Soros anyway).
If this sounds a little like the creative destruction of capitalism and its discontents, it is. But Mr. Greider goes farther. New features of global capitalism, he argues, will bring unparalleled inequality and exploitation. The coming power of new computer chips makes job losses from automation look piddling. Worldwide competition drags wages in advanced nations down toward those of the poorest countries. Capital, answerable only to itself, seeks maximum returns, regardless of the dislocations its sudden flight brings or the chaos its burst speculative bubbles can shower. As poor nations race to get into the industrial game and rich ones innovate to stay ahead, the globe is flooded with chronic overproduction, sure to bring mass plant closings and unemployment. With labor unorganized or suppressed, inhuman treatment becomes routine.
Worse, Mr. Greider says, there's no obvious fixer. At the dawn of this century, a time of similar abuse, governments could step in with minimum wage, child labor and workplace safety laws that saved rampant capitalism from itself (and the states from bidding against one another to get jobs). No international authority exists that can similarly temper the global market's excesses. Instead, governments everywhere are in retreat, unable to appease angry constituents yet scaling back services, tax bases and safety nets to lure multinationals and keep bond traders happy. All in all, Mr. Greider concludes, it's a recipe for social meltdown and financial disaster, unless we reverse our unthinking deference to the dictates of global business and capital, and fast.
While spinning out this cataclysmic vision, Mr. Greider's rich reporting brings the global economic beast to life in all its splendor and horror. The biggest assembly plant in the world -- a hundred acres of Boeing engineering miracles under one giant roof -- inspires awe at human ingenuity; girls locked and killed inside a tinderbox Thai sweatshop prompt revulsion at human indifference. Mr. Greider shows the perpetual ambiguity of events from the global citizen's point of view: when Boeing transfers production to China in exchange for access to its market, Mr. Greider is torn between lamenting the loss of good American jobs and cheering the Chinese, for whom plane building offers a path out of poverty. He also denounces the hypocrisy of global elites, like financiers who preach the virtues of free markets 364 days a year, until Mexico collapses and they need a little "big government" to bail out their bad bets.
But while the social concerns raised by Mr. Greider's reporting are surely valid, his almost Marxist prophecies of doom flow from some basic economic confusions. His contention, for example, that wages here will inexorably fall to third-world levels ignores the fact that American workers are still far more productive than their counterparts (and thus can earn far more without pricing American goods out of world markets). For all the talk of globalization, moreover, tradable goods account for only one-fifth of our economy. If you're a textile worker in South Carolina, yes, you're in trouble; but most workers' wage woes have more to do with getting United States productivity moving even higher and the premium new technologies place on having greater skills.
In addition, while certain industries, like steel, see new factories mysteriously financed even in the face of existing surplus, there's little evidence of the global supply glut Mr. Greider repeatedly stresses. If he were right, we'd expect Depression-era rates of unemployment, plummeting prices and stock markets, and very low interest rates, thanks to the savings surplus that would accompany underconsumption. We have none of these. Similar fallacies mar Mr. Greider's views on many other issues, from trade deficits and the economy's growth potential to the structure of demand and the causes and cures of our Great Depression. Readers otherwise sympathetic to Mr. Greider's ambitious project will learn to bleep over them.
But economists (whose role as the arbiters of much public debate Mr. Greider regrets) will seize on these errors to dimiss the book outright. That's a mistake. You don't need to agree we're facing apocalypse soon to know we're facing spiraling unfairness already, or to admit that Mr. Greider's right when he says all whose Christmas list included Asian-made toys are probably complicit in exploiting the weak. Indeed, his moral passion is a rebuke to the petty obsessions of many modern economists, and a tonic for today's fainthearted debates.
Mr. Greider rightly calls on governments to moderate (not derail) the pace of this latest industrial revolution and push the global system toward more equitable outcomes. This means refusing to yield a society's destiny to multinationals or financiers unfettered by social obligation. He'd restore some controls on capital flows; tax wealth more heavily while slashing payroll levies that punish work; ask trading nations to honor labor rights or face tariffs; and subsidize low-wage employment to assure a decent life for those not equipped to thrive in the high-tech age. A new commitment to "lifting the bottom" is Mr. Greider's sensible answer to the downward pressures the global economy brings.
Like James Fallows and Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr. before him, Mr. Greider urges American elites to wake up and pursue a Japanese model of national interest, rather than cling to pretty trade theories that sanction the loss of major industries. He'd renew Louis O. Kelso and Senator Russell B. Long's worthy efforts to increase employee ownership, steps that might let market incentives triumph while making everyman a capitalist. And his plea for our best minds to fashion a new ideology for a world now truly indivisible ("global humanism," he tentatively calls it) is inspiring.
Many of Mr. Greider's proposals -- such as transaction taxes to damp currency speculation, and labor agreements in trade deals -- would take multilateral action to work, no small feat. And some of his tics, like his endless Fed-bashing, are off base. But challenges like Mr. Greider's to establishment nostrums and powerful interests are rare. In a season when politicians seem determined to make no large plans, Mr. Greider's ideas deserve wide debate. They made me question many of my assumptions. Given the choice between economists with little passion for justice and progressive journalists like Mr. Greider with little patience for economics, it's the latter who stand the best chance of pointing us to a brighter world.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Paradoxical Reign of the King of Steel

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
With streams of flame and showers of fire, white-hot ingots and yellow-hot rails, muscle pitted against metal and the smoke-blackened faces of sweating men, tonight's "American Experience" brings back the beginnings of America's age of steel.
"The Richest Man in the World: Andrew Carnegie" is the story of the king of steel: the boy from an impoverished family in Scotland and the Slabtown section of Pittsburgh who became his adopted country's master of industry and its most prodigious philanthropist. But the program is considerably more than an upward-and-onward tale as it tries to get at the character of a man who squeezed customers, subverted competitors, betrayed partners and beat down workers in the bare-knuckle capitalism of the late 19th century, yet also enhanced the lives of his employees and of many other Americans. 
 The evening's historians, much abetted by the evocative photographs for which "The American Experience" is justly known, trace Carnegie's feelings for workers to his father's ruin by the steam-powered looms that put Britain's hand-loom weavers out of work in the mid-1800's and drove the Carnegie family to America. From his father he may have inherited radical anti-privilege notions, but it was his mother, with whom he lived until her death, when he was 51 years old, who is credited or blamed for fueling his drive for success, whatever the price in egalitarian ideals.
His career, vividly sketched in these two hours, is in the Horatio Alger mode, except that Carnegie worked harder and with fewer scruples than any Alger hero. Operating in a man's world of railroads, coal, iron and finally steel, he makes today's power players of Wall Street, Silicon Valley and Hollywood seem like sissies.
But even at his toughest, he presented himself as the worker's friend. Whether his proclaimed philosophy that what profits business profits everyone was hypocrisy or self-deception or an early faith in supply-side economics, you can decide.
The bloody 1892 conflict at his Homestead, Pa., factory town receives the attention it demands. The way Carnegie distanced himself from his company's clash with a strong union evidenced his determination to win without being forced to face up to the meaning of such a victory for his principle that workers have a right to organize. He left the battle, involving Pinkerton detectives, strikebreakers and the state militia, to his manager, Henry Clay Frick, who was not known to be burdened by a social conscience. Carnegie cheered him on privately from Scotland.
Carnegie won that fight, as he won most of his fights; there would not be another steel workers' union for 45 years. But, as the narrator notes, "His image as a radical reformer, so carefully cultivated, was in shambles." When Carnegie set foot in Homestead a few years later, it was to dedicate one of his libraries.
 
THE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE
The Richest Man in the World: Andrew Carnegie

(Channel 13 in New York)

HEADLINE: Essay;
'We Meet Again . . .'

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Only 13 times in American history has a President delivered a second inaugural address.
Consider the changes the second time around: 
 George Washington's second, notable for its brevity, seemed to invite criticism. The indispensable man swore an additional oath that if he knowingly violated the Government's injunctions, "I may (besides incurring constitutional punishment) be subject to the upbraidings of all. . . ." (Second-term upbraidings came, and President Washington was annoyed.)
Madison's second was mired in the conduct of the War of 1812, and Monroe switched emphasis in his second to foreign affairs. The seconds of Jackson, Grant and McKinley were unexceptional, but Lincoln's second revealed the searing change that four war years made in him.
"With malice toward none" begins the peroration by which it is remembered. Less remarked is the way he asserted national unity by calling for peace not between North and South, but "among ourselves" -- as individual Americans in all sections.
His first inaugural had been a legal argument against secession and a warning that he would fight for the Union, but his second was a mysterious sermon to justify the war's unforeseen suffering. Taking as text Matthew 18:7, he dared suggest that the long agony of both sides was in expiation for the nation's sin of slavery.
Lincoln wrote later to a friend that although the speech would "wear well," he did not expect it to be immediately popular: "Men are not flattered by being shown that there is a difference of purpose between the Almighty and them." No second-term President in our century made such a reach into religion.
Woodrow Wilson's first peroration was the most thrilling of all: "Men's hearts wait upon us; men's lives hang in the balance. . . . Who shall live up to the great trust? Who dares fail to try?" But impending war forced him to start his second with "the shadows that now lie dark upon our path . . ."
F.D.R.'s second used the perfect ecclesiastical verb for the occasion -- "reconsecrate" -- but pressed the politics of a new New Deal by seeing "one-third of a nation ill-housed, ill-clad, ill-nourished."
Eisenhower, in his first, sternly saw freedom pitted against slavery; in his second, after smiling "we meet again," he took as his theme "the price of peace," offering hope though not help to "those nations which, now captive, long for freedom."
Nixon's first was inspirational, his second uninspired. Reagan's second was consistent with his first, proud of the economic rebound, memorable for his evocation of the political friendship made late in their lives of John Adams and anti-Federalist Thomas Jefferson, who both died on the Fourth of July, 1826.
Of all the second inaugural addresses, the most vindictive was Jefferson's. His first had been conciliatory, but in his second, after taking credit for cutting taxes, he launched a diatribe against the media. "The artillery of the press has been levelled against us," he seethed, "charged with whatever its licentiousness could devise or dare." He was thinking less of the critics of his extraconstitutional Louisiana Purchase than the "falsehood and defamation" of the journalist James Thomson Callender, who had accused him of siring the children of a slave mistress as well as trying to seduce the wife of an absent neighbor.
Jefferson gloated at the public's "cool and collected" reaction to "these outrages" that resulted in his overwhelming re-election, which he found "consolatory to the friend of man who believes he may be trusted with the control of his own affairs."
Though cautioning that "no other definite line can be drawn between the inestimable liberty of the press and its demoralizing licentiousness," the furious friend of man noted ominously, "he who has time renders a service to public morals and public tranquillity in reforming these abuses by the salutary coercions of the law."
Our 13 second inaugurals have ranged from mean-spirited to high-minded, from boring to stirring, but most revealed a striking change in the man taking the oath and his message to the people.
Clinton must know his first fell short; Americans will listen intently to his second, wishing him and one another well in this once-in-a-generation moment of reconsecration.

HEADLINE: Promoting Technology In America's Rural Areas

BYLINE: By DAN CARNEY 

 BODY:
Senator Conrad Burns, a Montana Republican, does not have the polish or erudition of most senators. He has no college degree, no expensive suits and few pretensions. On most days when the Senate is in session, he can be found telling stories about his ranching and farming constituents, people he once described as "awful good folks."
His legislative interests include Western land policies, farm price supports -- and Federal policy on encryption software. Like many of his colleagues who represent rural areas, Mr. Burns maintains a keen interest in technology and telecommunications issues. 
 The interest of legislators like Senator Burns -- not to mention two House members from the Appalachian part of Virginia, Robert W. Goodlatte, a Republican, Rick Boucher, a Democrat; Senators Patrick J. Leahy, Republican of Vermont; Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota; Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, and John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia -- is based largely on the theory that the information revolution is the best hope for economic development of their remote districts.
Their theory is that people and whole companies will migrate to places with lower labor costs and a higher quality of life once they are freed of the need to live and work in close proximity to customers and fellow employees.
"Rural America will gain enormously from advances in telecommunications," Mr. Boucher argues. "We have a low-cost business environment, an excellent work force, a superb quality of life. What we're lacking is telecommunications services."
With a determination that evokes earlier decades of the 20th century, when rural legislators pushed to get electricity and telephone service to their districts, the lawmakers are active on two technological fronts. The first is local telecommunications issues, particularly making sure high-speed transmission lines come to small towns. These lawmakers helped write "universal service" language into the 1996 telecommunications bill; some have gone even further.
Mr. Boucher, for instance, helped four towns in his district with populations of less than 10,000 bypass the local phone company and install their own fiber optic networks, which can handle far greater amounts of information than traditional copper telephone wires.
On the other front, they are devising the broad operating principles for the Internet. These include such things as a new copyright law that will allow publishers, film makers, songwriters and others to sell their products on the Internet without fear they will be illegally copied and circulated. These issues also include encryption policies that let companies and individuals protect confidential communications from hackers or competitors.
Rural legislators would like to see the Internet become a medium where employer, employee, producer and consumer can interact efficiently and securely. When that happens, they believe, physical proximity will be less important to commerce and employment and more people will move to small towns.
To this end, Mr. Goodlatte and Mr. Boucher are trying to write a new copyright law that will function in a medium in which copying is extremely easy. On a parallel track, the 65-nation World Intellectual Property Organization approved two copyright treaties in December that will be up for ratification in the Senate this year. The issue of copyright law and digital technologies is complex, and understood by only a few members of Congress -- many of them representing rural areas.
Encryption is critical to rural lawmakers because it is used to encode and decode electronic communications. Software producers believe encryption programs will be as fundamental to security in the information age as the lock and key are now.
The issue pits business groups and self-described cyberlibertarians against Federal law enforcement and security agencies, which fear their ability to conduct surveillance will be greatly curtailed. The rural lawmakers come down on the side of business and the libertarians. Mr. Burns, Mr. Leahy and Mr. Goodlatte all have bills to ease restrictions on the use of encryption programs.
Neither of these issues has come to a vote. They are complicated and have not been give priority by the Republican leadership in either house. But they both could see some action this year. For now, their biggest champions are rural lawmakers.
All of this interest in the Internet and technology raises the question: are these lawmakers onto something or is this just the latest economic development fad that will go the way of business incubators and lavish tax concessions for foreign auto plants?
While the answer is still unclear, there is some evidence this may be more than a fad. After decades of almost unbroken decline, rural America has reached parity with metropolitan America in population growth. The average growth rate in rural counties started approaching that of metropolitan counties in the early 1990's and caught up in 1995, according to an Agriculture Department demographer, Calvin Beale.
And while communications technology is not solely responsible for this reversal of fortune, it certainly has played a role. William Beyers, a professor of geography at the University of Washington has studied a number of economically growing rural counties and found them full of independent consultants, contractors, brokers and other types of professionals that use modern telecommunications (along with some leg work) to serve customers around the country and around the world.
"It's not just the Internet, though that gets all the hype," Professor Beyers said. "It's good old-fashioned file transfer and even telephones." File transfer refers to a direct link from one computer to another without the Internet.
In one of his studies, he found that 40 percent of the new companies in rural areas were primarily serving customers outside of their regions.
Many of them are small professional companies, sometimes just a single person, that are commonly called lone eagles. They might be a graphic arts studio in New Mexico that does most of its business in Texas, or a stockbroker who has fled Los Angeles for the more pristine environment of Washington State. Though not primarily telecommunications companies, they rely on Internet technology to gather information and talk with customers.
In addition to these tiny companies, some major corporations have made telecommunications-related shifts that have benefited a few communities. Availing themselves of the lower labor costs, banks, credit card companies, airlines, telephone companies and a host of other businesses have put big switchboard operations and information centers in small towns. A call to directory assistance in the Washington, D.C., area, for instance, is routed to a bank of operators in Mr. Boucher's district in the southwest corner of Virginia.
But there is still no guarantee that rural America will benefit any more from the approaching technological era than from previous ones.
"It's not a silver bullet, but it's not a fad either," said Bob Rowe, Public Service Commissioner of Montana. Mr. Rowe said that rural areas could benefit from the new technologies, but only if people formed local networks and learned how to use them to their own benefit.
In this sense, information is no different from other technologies. Those who learn how to exploit it most effectively will prosper.
Some critics point out that rural America already has an up-to-date system capable of carrying vast amounts of information around the world. It's called a telephone, and it did not stop the exodus out of small towns this century.
Others argue that while changes in telecommunications may hurt big American cities, there is no guarantee that the beneficiaries of this will be small American towns.
"There's no reason it stops in Fargo, N. D., or wherever," said Andrew Blau of the telecommunications-oriented Benton Foundation. "Maybe it goes on to Malaysia or Mexico. It goes right past our borders, goes over our fence into the Southern Hemisphere."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;
Making the Internet come to you, through 'push' technology.

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
I HAVE seen the future. It may work but it is very pushy.
Using catchers, whackers, finders, savers and casters -- software that has a slightly different attitude from passively casual browsers -- a nascent industry is trying to create a new model for the use of the Internet, one that will have almost nothing to do with hyperlinks, cyberspace or the electronic frontier. The goal is to make the Internet come to you, not the other way around. 
 This is being called "push" technology and is one of the hottest areas of Internet development. Microsoft and Netscape are planning to incorporate it into future software releases. Apple plans to use it to update software automatically. And right now, custom-designed news reports are being pushed into PC's, most famously via Pointcast with 1.7 million users of its free software (http:// www.pointcast.com) automatically getting reports from CNN, Wired and other publications including this newspaper. There are even commercial programs like Web Ex and Web Whacker that offer virtually a utopian promise: the software bears the burden of waiting on line; sites are downloaded for quick viewing, free of crashes and pauses. Off-line dipping replaces on-line surfing.
The startling thing about the interest in this technology is the built-in contradictions. It promises freedom from the very aspects of the Internet that have been so highly praised -- the spur-of-the-moment discoveries, the libertarian freedom from predetermined form and content. Each advantage of the Net has become a disadvantage when seen through the prism of push.
During the usual "pull" usage of the Net, we grope about, grasping sites with laborious dedication. The idea behind push technology is that the viewer becomes more passive; the material is thrust out of cyberspace, following a custom-built series of requests. It is more like home delivery than browsing, more like TV than PC.
Push technology is more appealing for making money on the Internet. Sites are guaranteed more visitors, which means that they can offer advertisers more attractive audiences. Advertisers' banners and images are inserted on the home PC, and may have greater impact because they are part of requested material. Gradually, there may come to be a kind of junk mail that will fill Web browsers along with E-mail boxes. If the Web is to have any economic future, it may be founded on the basis of pushing rather than pulling.
The promise of push, the value it adds, is its delivery of organized, edited information -- information that has been requested, things often hard to come by on the Net. And a wide variety of experiments testing how much such a service should be employed are in progress. The New Century Network (http://www.newcentury.net) calls itself the best of America's newspapers" and includes, in rather haphazard form, an anthology of news and information. (New Century is partly owned by The New York Times Company.)
New Century's contents are designed by its editors and delivered wholesale. A custom-designed result can be created on the Newspage site (http://www.newspage.com), where an individual profile will create a "daily custom newspaper," compiling sources ranging from industry trade magazines to wire services.
Pointcast is almost completely a matter of push. Theoretically it is like having a personalized ticker tape and news service: all news, all the time, all over the PC. Imitators have emerged, like Intermind Communicator (http://www.intermind.com). One new push-meister, Marimba (http://www.marimba.com), promises to do for software updates what Pointcast has done for news (Apple will be using their technology for self-updating software).
Push technology may ultimately be pushing the Net into a form of computer radio, and indeed, one of the most conveniently pushy objects I have recently tried has been the $149 Newscatcher from Global Village Communication, which regularly delivers news headlines and information to the PC via a radio network; its main problem is the brevity of the information.
Newscatcher was so appealing, though, partly because it managed to avoid many of the problems of push technology in its infancy: awkwardness, messiness, slowness. Automatic downloads can cause system crashes, eat up memory, clutter the PC with as much junk as accumulated magazines waiting to be read.
It was great to be able to read the lead news articles in The Boston Globe and The Los Angeles Times courtesy of Pointcast, but downloads were more time consuming than just leaping to those newspaper's Web sites via the traditional, now crusty browsers.
Not even commercial packages were completely satisfying. This kind of software requires a user with very specific desires, with a clear notion of which sites and which information needs to be regularly accumulated. But sometimes that can only be discovered through browsing.
Ultimately, the best form of push technology may be a sort that makes the Net almost irrelevant except as a vast sea to be explored at will by smart agents that fish at our request. The ultimate push will be the creation of custom-built channels, an individualized on-line service that is built when a user is off line. The numbers of channels is potentially infinite, with each one bearing the stamp of the user's desires.
By the time that happens, the Internet will have evolved into a utility more than a technological novelty, a convenience rather than a mode of consciousness. And as we channel-surf through these programs, delivered for our entertainment and enlightenment, push will have really come to pull.

HEADLINE: Latin Democracies Do Not Need F-16's

 BODY:
If President Clinton cherishes the democratic and economic revival that has transformed much of Latin America in the 1990's, he will overrule the recommendations of his departing Secretaries of Defense and State and maintain the ban on exporting advanced weapons to the region.
The Pentagon, pleading the case of American arms exporters and eager potential customers like the Chilean military, has long favored elimination of the restrictions. The ban was first imposed by President Carter in response to the belligerent rhetoric and human rights abuses of Latin American military regimes. The State Department, reflecting the Administration's goal of curbing regional arms races and encouraging poor countries to shift scarce resources from military to civilian needs, argued for maintaining the ban. 
 But just before leaving office, Secretary of State Warren Christopher has reconsidered his views and joined with outgoing Defense Secretary William Perry in recommending an end to the ban. Madeleine Albright, nominated as Mr. Christopher's successor, has generally championed restraints on arms sales, but has not yet specifically addressed the Latin American question.
Those who favor arms sales note that with the exception of Cuba, all Latin American governments are now headed by elected civilians. But selling expensive, high-tech weapons like F-16 fighter planes is no way to nurture these developing democracies. Significantly, the loudest Latin voice for unrestricted arms sales comes from Chile, where the military is not yet under full civilian control. If F-16's are sold to Chile, neighbors like Argentina and Brazil will feel compelled to catch up.
Although the United States is the largest arms seller to Latin America, other countries also sell weapons to the region and some are ready to sell high-tech equipment. But when Belarus recently sold two types of advanced aircraft to Peru, Washington rightly tried to discourage the deals, warning that they threatened regional stability. It is hard to see why that logic should not apply to American sales as well.

HEADLINE: My Kingdom for a Sound Stage

BYLINE: By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
From the void come giant raptors and Michael J. Fox, music videos and lava flows, commercials and chat shows. But first comes the void, the sound stage.
Nature abhors a vacuum. The movie and television industries adore it, or at least an unused space of 10,000 square feet -- equal to two basketball courts -- that is 35 feet high and has no columns or windows. 
 Television networks have proliferated in recent years, and the number of films released by studios last year rose 11 percent over 1995. This has meant the physical scope of those movies has grown, as well as the demand for sound stages -- not just in Los Angeles County but in New York, London and parts of Europe.
"The motion picture industry is running up against capacity constraints," said Jack Kyser, chief economist at the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation. And, he added, "think of television: the actual number of productions, features, TV series, movies of the week, cable channels."
"Both cable and computer hit at the same time," added Mitchell E. Stokes, vice president of the John Alle Company, a real estate brokerage firm. "Music video is a whole separate cottage industry. And they all need stages. There's never been as much demand in the western Los Angeles County area, as well as Burbank, for studio space." The current 306 sound stages are overbooked.
So, after 40 years in which sound stages were torn down and back lots turned into condominium developments and office towers, the Los Angeles area is at the beginning of a stage-building boom. Last May, CBS opened three new sound stages in Studio City. This May, Disney will open two more in Burbank. In July, Shamrock Holdings Inc. and CFN/Flesch & Neuhauser will break ground in Manhattan Beach for 14 new sound stages.
If Dreamworks answers local community objections, there could be 15 new sound stages in Playa Del Rey. Currently, there is 3.8 million square feet of sound stage space available in and around Los Angeles; the Manhattan Beach and Dreamworks complexes, when completed, will add another 750,000 square feet.
All these projects will fall within a radius of 30 miles from the Hollywood intersection of Beverly Boulevard and La Cienega. "That's the center of the studio zone," said Fred Baron, senior vice president of feature production for 20th Century Fox. "And you want to be as close to that as possible." Beyond that 30-mile zone, union contracts require additional travel stipends.
Any large space inside that zone -- be it a warehouse, hanger or decommissioned factory -- is fair game for conversion. Bring in the lights, the cameras, the rigging.
It's not just that there are more companies creating programs, films and videos for more outlets. The insatiable appetite for capturing the fantastic on film -- the same appetite that drives special effects companies to top themselves -- drives producers to seek bigger spaces. Everything from 55-foot-high Bat Caves to shots of the destruction wreaked by volcanoes or floods, requires what film makers call "scale" (and other people call "space").
"You really have fights over the sound stages," said Gary Martin, president of production and administration for Sony's Columbia Tri-Star. "If anyone goes over schedule, the other guy has to get in. We tell them which end of the set to strike first, because we have to get started building."
The demand for studio space has driven up rental costs to the point at which they are "back where they were when it was the highest, like 1985," said Vince Vellardita, who runs Studio West production operations in Los Angeles County. The growth has been a bonanza for real estate agents after the decline of the aerospace industry and the crash in home prices this decade.
"In '92, you could get stages cheaper," Mr. Vellardita said. "But right now there's no space available, so prices are really high." He said he rented 10,000 square feet for $10,000 to $15,000 a week. Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens offers its largest stage -- 26,000 square feet -- for around $15,000 a week.
In New York, buildings on piers in the Hudson River, empty armories in Harlem and in Park Slope in Brooklyn and old buildings on 10th Avenue near 14th Street have joined the Silvercup & Kaufman studios as production centers for television ("Spin City," "Cosby" and "Law and Order") and films like "Ransom" and "First Wives Club." A 15,000-square-foot sound stage in the Silver Screen Studios at Chelsea Piers in New York would rent for $15,000 a week, according to Darryl Jefferson, who manages the studio -- but "Spin City" has already booked it for the year.
Some producers sound downright grumpy about the situation. Ron Schwary, a producer of "Scent of a Woman" (shot at Kaufman Astoria Studios) and "The Mirror Has Two Faces" (at the 142d Street Armory) could not get a sound stage in New York for "Meet Joe Black," which will star Brad Pitt. It will be shot, instead, at an armory in Park Slope.
"The only stage that's decent is Kaufman Astoria," Mr. Schwary said, "and it's tied up with 'Cosby.' "
"It's tight in New York, and in London," said Robert Relyea, head of physical production for MGM/UA. "And London has spread to Europe. It's spreading east." To shoot "Goldeneye," the last James Bond film, Mr. Relyea had wanted to use the football-field-sized, 45,000-square- foot "007" stage at Pinewood Studios, 20 miles west of London. "Didn't work out," he said. The stage was being used for "Mary Reilly." "So we found this Rolls-Royce helicopter engine factory."
In addition to the increasing demand for filmed entertainment, concessions by craft unions have made it easier to produce shows, and local governments from London to New York are selling their cities as ideal for film work.
But while other venues are competing for business, Los Angeles has a natural advantage. "You find more and more people who like the idea of going home to their family and sleeping in their own beds," said Bruce Hendricks, the executive vice president of motion picture production for Walt Disney Studios. Then, too, studios have become somewhat reluctant to let big-budget pictures go off for extended periods to Hawaii, where they -- and their cost overruns -- are more difficult for studio executives to track.
Most of the studio sound stages are dominated by television production. "Television used to be a very seasonal business," said Richard Nelson, senior vice president for back lot operations at Paramount. "It would shut down late March, April and pick up in July. Now with pilots and replacements we're busy right through the year."
Then there is the issue of scale, especially pressing this year with mammoth movies like "Titanic," "The Lost World" (the sequel to "Jurassic Park") and "Batman and Robin."
"When you have a 'Titanic,' there's no such thing as a miniature," said Bill Mechanic, the chairman of 20th Century Fox. "Last summer, with 'Independence Day,' 'The Rock,' 'Mission Impossible' and 'Twister,' you had four big movies, all about scale."
"What producers are looking for now," said the economist Jack Kyser, "are big, big spaces with lots of access on the sides."
That means spaces like the Spruce Goose Hangar in Playa Del Rey, where part of "Independence Day" was shot, or the Spruce Goose Dome in Long Beach, Calif. Warner Brothers has leased the Dome for five years, and it is there that "Batman and Robin" has built its biggest sets.
"There is almost nothing that can't be done on film now," said Joel Schumacher, the director of "Batman and Robin." "But you've got to build something fantastic. You need a lot of space." After "Batman and Robin" finishes shooting this month at the Dome (where Howard Hughes stored an enormous airplane, called the Spruce Goose because it was made of wood), the Bat Cave and Wayne Manor will remain, awaiting the next Batman movie. The rental cost: $1 million a year. ( About 75,000 square feet will remain open for other productions.)
"What I assume is that it's cheaper to hold it there than to raze everything and start over," Mr. Schumacher said.
The movie business, however, is cyclical; the current boom may not last. "You will reach a point of saturation sooner or later," Mr. Kyser said, "and then people will go to the best stages, like Shamrock in Manhattan Beach. It's a great location."
AS Mr. Martin of Columbia Tri-Star said, "You go three or four years and you can't get a stage, and then two years later, you can't give them away."

Walt Disney Studios: Burbank, 5 sound stages; 700 acres of back lot in Acton, 20 miles north of Los Angeles. Two new sound stages to open in Burbank this spring.

HEADLINE: Vision and Reform

 BODY:
The arctic temperature gripping Washington this weekend is not the only blast of inclement weather surrounding the inauguration. President Clinton's oath-taking today takes place in an atmosphere chilled by scandal, contentiousness and widespread public disappointment in the ethics of Mr. Clinton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich. This is a moment when both parties need to pause and think soberly about past mistakes and put forward an agenda to drive tainted money, reckless fund-raising and special interests out of national campaigns. The problem is that like their leaders, both national parties are in denial about the public's deep-rooted fervor for clean politics and the equally deep-rooted longing for trustworthy leaders.
Inaugural speeches must offer an expansive vision, but they also need a strong, specific anchor. The issue of clean politics, therefore, offers a huge opportunity for Mr. Clinton to step forward in a largely unoccupied area of leadership. We hope to hear at the heart of Mr. Clinton's speech a pledge to clean up his party's fund-raising practices and push Congress toward the campaign reform promised in his first inaugural address. With that commitment as a foundation, Mr. Clinton can use his speech to convey a sense of broad national purpose that is energizing, responsive and realistic on many fronts. 
 Since Mr. Clinton will be making the last inaugural address of the 20th century, he needs to guide Americans toward his vision of the century to come. Based on advance word from the White House, it sounds as if he will try to do just that. The President, his aides say, intends to focus on an appeal for racial healing, as well as programs to help Americans adjust to an economy driven by revolutions in information and technology. We hope that in the process he will build on one of the finest moments of his first term, when he defended affirmative action as a necessary tool to redress the heavy legacy of racial injustice in America.
Four years ago, Mr. Clinton's inauguration speech seemed to usher in a new era of government activism. Now, marking a different approach, he must say how government can still prepare Americans for rapid economic changes while honoring his new-found commitment to a balanced budget. Recent economic improvements may make it easier to reduce the deficit, but eliminating the deficit altogether will be extremely difficult if Mr. Clinton is also to preserve education, environment and health programs and reform welfare without warring against the undefended poor. Mr. Clinton's greatest gifts lie in summoning Americans to a sense of community, and starting today, on these issues, those abilities will be tested to their utmost.
In preparing for the subject, he would do well to look at the valedictory comments by departing Labor Secretary Robert Reich, who noted in a recent speech that growing economic inequality in the United States is jeopardizing the social compact that has long kept the country together. A similar breaking apart of the compact can be seen in the attempts by some to turn Social Security into a voluntary investment program in which the well-to-do would inevitably benefit the most and to let public education atrophy for lack of funds.
In foreign policy, the most urgent philosophical issue Mr. Clinton needs to join is how to square the United States' economic interests with its human rights and security concerns, particularly with China. The President has done more than his recent predecessors to educate Americans on the importance of competing for markets and investments abroad. But he has not told Americans how the country can keep pace economically and still push for its values and for curbing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and other arms.
More than most re-elected Presidents, Mr. Clinton still comes across to Americans as unfinished and unpredictable. It is particularly interesting that his inauguration has been preceded by a revealing glimpse of his Presidency in the form of Dick Morris's book, "Behind the Oval Office." It portrays Mr. Clinton as endlessly torn by conflicting impulses, defending and attacking government at the same time and being wary of just about all his advisers -- a solitary man for all his gregariousness.
After all the gyrations and reinventions of the last four years, the public hungers for a President who presents a clearer image because both his goals and personality are fixed. History will remember Mr. Clinton for winning re-election, but it will measure him by what he learned from the victory. Bill Clinton's second inaugural address will be our first report on that question.

HEADLINE: Paul Tsongas, Who Made Presidential Bid, Dies at 55

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts who was the only candidate in the 1992 Democratic Presidential campaign to offer painful solutions to the nation's economic problems, died on Saturday at a hospital in Boston. He was 55.
Mr. Tsongas, who was hospitalized on Jan. 3 with a liver problem related to his treatments for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a slow-growing cancer of the lymph system, and later developed pneumonia, died at Brigham and Women's Hospital. 
 Mr. Tsongas made his survival from cancer an issue in his Presidential campaign when he and two of his doctors, Dr. Tak Takvorian and Dr. George P. Canellos, said he had been cancer-free since a bone-marrow transplant in 1986.
In May 1996, he underwent another transplant, getting bone marrow from his twin sister, Thaleia Schlesinger, to correct myelodysplasia, a bone-marrow disorder that can occur in people who have recovered from lymph cancer.
In seeking the nomination in 1992, Mr. Tsongas offered a somber analysis of the nation's economic plight in a book published by his campaign, "Economic Call to Arms." He opposed a tax cut for the middle class but advocated one on capital gains to stimulate investment.
Instead of fire-in-the-belly oratory, Mr. Tsongas offered a wry, self-deprecatory and occasionally moralistic message about responsibility. He began the primary campaign with a victory in New Hampshire and went on to win three other state primaries and the caucuses of four states.
He suspended his campaign after losing primaries in Illinois and Michigan. Bill Clinton went on to win the nomination and the Presidency.
After leaving the Presidential race, Mr. Tsongas practiced law and, with former Senator Warren Rudman of New Hampshire, a Republican, helped start the Concord Coalition, a nonprofit group that focused attention on the budget deficit and other economic problems.
He also remained active in public affairs in his home state.
Mr. Tsongas once said three things defined him: working as a young man in his father's dry-cleaning business in the economically depressed city of Lowell, Mass., serving in the Peace Corps and contracting the cancer that interrupted his political career in 1983.
He said the first made him aware of economic hardships; the second brought a joy in public service that led to a political career, and the third tempered what he called an overriding ambition.
"Pre-cancer, I was one of the pettiest people you've ever run into," Mr. Tsongas said in an interview in 1992. "I would get angry at my wife for leaving the top off the toothpaste. I'd get angry at my kids for the dumbest things. Looking back on it I feel mortified. I was a fool."
In his Presidential run, he tried to blend his three defining experiences into a political philosophy, characterizing his emphasis on building the economy as well as maintaining traditional Democratic social programs as "compassionate realism."
At the start of the campaign, Mr. Tsongas used what he said was his victory over the disease in his advertisements, and demonstrated his health by swimming the strenuous butterfly stroke.
But in April 1992, a few days after the New York primary, Mr. Tsongas said that he had been treated in 1987 for a recurrence of the lymphoma. Months after the campaign, Mr. Tsongas said he had erred in not disclosing the recurrence.
He pledged that if he ever ran again, he would submit his medical records to independent experts.
Mr. Tsongas began his political career on the Lowell City Council, on which he served from 1969 to 1972. He later became a Middlesex County Commissioner. In 1974, he defeated Representative Paul W. Cronin, a Republican, to become the district's first Democratic member of Congress in about 90 years.
In 1978, he defeated Senator Edward W. Brooke, a two-term Republican, with 55 percent of the vote.
On Sept. 29, 1983, when Mr. Tsongas discovered a lump in his groin, he thought it was a hernia, an inconvenience that would interfere with his plans to run in the Boston Marathon. But it was the cancer that would change his life.
What followed was a painful bone marrow transplant that left him with a new sense of his mortality. With that came a desire to spend more time with his family and subsequently a decision to retire from the Senate. He then joined the Boston law firm of Foley, Hoag & Eliot, saying that there he could earn the kind of income that would provide security for his family should he die.
But Mr. Tsongas said he did not want to be remembered only as the Senator who quit his political career because he had cancer.
In part, he said, it was his five-year freedom from cancer that had prompted him to run for the Democratic nomination when President George Bush's popularity was at its high point in 1991. But Mr. Tsongas had long coveted the office.
Like President Clinton, Mr. Tsongas was inspired to go into politics by President John F. Kennedy. In 1962, answering President Kennedy's call to public service, Mr. Tsongas was among the first young people to join the new Peace Corps. He spent two years as a teacher in Ethiopia.
He then attended Yale Law School and spent two summers working in the Washington office of Representative F. Bradford Morse, a Republican who represented Mr. Tsongas's home district.
Fascinated by the Vietnam War, Mr. Tsongas read about Vietnam and studied its language. He considered becoming a medic with the Green Berets. Instead, after he finished law school, he became a Peace Corps director in the West Indies. Unable to recapture the satisfaction he had felt as a volunteer, he decided to go into politics, this time as a Democrat. Mr. Tsongas attributed the switch to his experience in the Peace Corps and growing up in a declining city.
Paul Efthemios Tsongas was born Feb. 14, 1941, in Lowell, the son of Efthemios and Katina Tsongas, immigrants from Greece. Growing up in Lowell after the closing of the textile mills, he keenly felt the plight of its residents. It was a city whose empty factories and stores and jobless workers, he said, reflected the troubles of the nation as a whole.
His father, who had missed graduating from Harvard by a semester because of the Depression, owned a modest dry-cleaning business where Paul and Thaleia worked after school. He straightened hangers, he said, and brooded about not being able to take part in school sports because of the work.
Mr. Tsongas said he had a respectful and sometimes strained relationship with his father, particularly when the son's growing liberalism conflicted with his father's conservatism. The elder Mr. Tsongas died in 1980, and Paul Tsongas's mother died of tuberculosis when he was 6.
Survivors include his wife, the former Nicola Sauvage; three daughters, Ashley, Katina and Molly, and his twin sister, Thaleia Schlesinger.
On Dec. 1, 1992, when he disclosed at a news conference that he had developed another type of lymphoma, Mr. Tsongas exhibited his dry humor. Asked what he would say if he had been elected President, he replied: "I would love to be standing here today as President-elect. The fact is a lot of people who should have run for President didn't. There was a medical problem with gonads, not lymph nodes."

HEADLINE: Silicon Valley Of the East? Try Malaysia

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., Jan. 19

 BODY:
Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, made a pilgrimage to Silicon Valley last week, calling on the area's companies to join in an ambitious effort to build a replica of the region in his nation.
Speaking here before a group of Silicon Valley executives, Mr. Mahathir sketched out a vision of a 25-year plan to build a "multimedia supercorridor" that would stretch south from Kuala Lumpur, the capital, to the city's new international airport, which is under construction. 
The 9-mile-by-30-mile area, which would include two new cities and a computer network designed to exceed those in the world's most advanced technology centers, would be created in part with generous tax and financial incentives by which the Malaysians are hoping to attract hundreds of corporations to build research and development as well as manufacturing operations.
"Fantastic changes are taking place which make what was impossible in the old economy of the Industrial Age suddenly possible in the new world of the Information Age," Mr. Mahathir said.
Mr. Mahathir met on Wednesday with William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, and on Thursday with a group of Silicon Valley leaders including Jim Barksdale, president of the Netscape Communications Corporation; Larry Ellison, chairman of the Oracle Corporation; Scott McNealy, chairman of Sun Microsystems Inc., and Lew Platt, chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Company.
A number of industry leaders have agreed to serve on an advisory group for the Malaysian project, and at least one of the companies, Sun Microsystems, has already agreed to locate a software development group in the region.
While American companies for years have been making high-technology products in Asia for the United States market, Silicon Valley executives are growing more interested in opportunities to sell in the region, where economies are growing more rapidly than in other parts of the world. To develop products for these markets, many executives believe that the companies need to base development staffs closer to them.
Malaysia's plan is an effort to move beyond manufacturing to high-technology development, and the Prime Minister pledged that in addition to the financial incentives the project holds out, his Government was in the process of passing laws that would be attractive to high-technology companies. He said these would include new legal structures to accommodate electronic commerce, intellectual property protection and a promise not to censor the Internet.
Several Silicon Valley leaders said they believed that in the economic wars of the future, regions like the planned Malaysian corridor would provide America with some of its fiercest competition.
"This will be the new challenge," said John Morgridge, chairman of Cisco Systems, a computer networking firm based in San Jose, Calif. "It won't be missiles that they are sending over here."
This competition could even extend to sensitive issues like computer encryption technology. In response to a reporter's question, Mr. Mahathir said that because the United States, for security reasons, had placed strict export controls on data-scrambling technology it would be necessary for his country to develop similar hardware and software independently.
The Government plans to begin construction on the two cities before the end of the century, according to the Prime Minister. One is to be the new seat of the Government, and it is expected to have a population of 250,000. The second city, to be named Cyberjava, is to be an education and research and development center, and it is projected to have 100,000 residents.

HEADLINE: In Japan, Phones on Go And Talk Is Cheaper

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
When Keiko Takei moved into a new apartment in May, she did not bother ordering telephone service. She simply began using her mobile phone as her home phone as well.
Miss Takei, a 27-year-old employee of a trading company, is using the Personal Handyphone System, known as P.H.S., a kind of poor man's cellular service that has attracted 4.3 million users in just the 18 months it has been offered. Many of these new customers are young people who previously could not afford a mobile phone. 
 The quick growth of P.H.S. subscriptions, as well as the deregulation and falling prices of conventional cellular phones, has turned Japan almost overnight into one of the world's fastest-growing markets for mobile telephones, with more than one million subscribers signing up each month, or one every two seconds.
Just three years ago, the low use of mobile phones in Japan was seen as a prime example of how over-regulation and high prices were retarding Japan's advance into the information age. Only 1.5 percent of the population had a mobile phone, one-third the rate in the United States.
But by the end of October, 16.4 percent of the Japanese population had a mobile phone, a slightly higher rate than in the United States and, indeed, the highest in the world outside of Scandinavia.
For Japan, the rapid growth of cellular phones and P.H.S. stands as a prime example of the changes that can be wrought by telecommunications deregulation, something that is being contemplated for other parts of the nation's economy.
Mobile telecommunications has become a driving force of Japan's economy. Capital investment by the mobile telephone industry is expected to exceed $15 billion this fiscal year, more than the investments by either the chemical, automobile or steel industries. And earnings from the telecommunications sector are helping cushion electronics companies from the adverse effects of the collapse of memory chip prices.
Japan's Government and industry are also pushing, with some success, for other countries to adopt the P.H.S. technology. P.H.S. mobile service is expected to begin this year in Thailand, and then perhaps in Australia, Hong Kong and Indonesia. Recently, China, a potentially huge market, agreed to set aside some radio frequencies for P.H.S. service. Other countries, including Argentina, Guatemala and Uruguay, will use P.H.S. technology for basic phone service because it is faster to build a wireless network than to install a wired one.
P.H.S. is not likely to be accepted in the United States because such phones do not work in fast-moving cars. But P.H.S. is similar in concept to some of the personal communications services, or P.C.S., that are being introduced in the United States.
The experience in Japan, where P.H.S. service has been operating since July 1995, could serve as a preview of what might be expected in the United States as American cities served until now by only two cellular phone companies are opened to as many as three P.C.S. providers.
In Japan, P.H.S. phones are being sold for as little as 1 yen (or about 1 cent) to lure subscribers. P.H.S. subscriptions are being sold in convenience stores and even vending machines. Cellular phone prices have plummeted as well.
But if growth is buoyant, profits are virtually nonexistent for the mobile telephone service providers, which are accumulating huge debts building their networks and subsidizing the sales of the phones at low prices. Some industry executives expect a brutal shakeout.
"My concern is if competition further accelerates, the weaker carriers may be forced to fold and we will see at that stage whether customers are happy or not," said Takeo Tsukada, president of the Nippon Idou Tsushin Corporation, a provider of conventional cellular service.
The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation deployed the world's first cellular phone system in 1979. But prices were so high that barely anyone used such phones.
As recently as three years ago, it cost about $450 to sign up for cellular service and $130 a month as a subscription fee, plus calling charges. The Japanese Government required customers to rent their phones from the service provider, paying about $600 a year.
The turnabout in the market started in April 1994, when the Japanese Government moved to deregulate the mobile phone industry, allowing customers to buy their own phones and permitting two digital cellular service providers to compete with the two existing companies that provided conventional service.
Competition further intensified in mid-1995 with the start-up of P.H.S. service, which is offered by three companies. The leader, with about half the market, is the DDI Corporation, a competitor to NTT in the long-distance and cellular markets. The two others are NTT and the Astel Group, a new company backed by 155 corporations including the Mitsubishi Corporation, Mitsui & Company and Toyota.
P.H.S. phones are similar in concept to cellular telephones, which work by breaking a city up into blocks, or cells, each served by a separate antenna. As a car moves from one cell to another, the cellular call is automatically handed off from one antenna to the other.
But P.H.S. does not provide the high-speed handoff from one cell to the next, so it cannot be used in fast-moving cars and trains. Still, the lack of handoff capability allows P.H.S. to be cheaper than cellular service.
Because it takes so many antennas to cover an area, P.H.S. will probably not be economical outside of densely populated regions. There are already about 300,000 P.H.S. antennas in the Tokyo area alone,
The introduction of P.H.S. did not eat into sales of regular cellular telephones; indeed, P.H.S. apparently gave them a huge boost. Many people attracted by the publicity surrounding P.H.S. chose regular cellular phones when they saw the shortcomings of P.H.S.
Cellular providers, in response to the threat of P.H.S. and their own deregulation, cut prices sharply. The sign-up fee for a cellular phone, which was $450 three years ago, fell to about $60 last year and was eliminated entirely by some companies in December. There are 16.5 million cellular subscribers in Japan, about four times as many as for P.H.S.
So far, cellular phones have been used mainly by business executives, while P.H.S. is becoming more of a consumer item. About 10 percent of the P.H.S. users are teen-agers.
P.H.S. service has a sign-up fee of 7,200 yen, or about $62, and a monthly fee of 2,700 yen, or about $23. A local call costs 40 yen for three minutes, much less than the 150 yen for a cellular phone call and only slightly more than the 30 yen for a pay phone.
In Japan, ordering a home phone costs about $700, so some people find it more economical to just get a P.H.S. phone.
Japan is now starting to deal with some of the social problems raised by mobile phones, especially their potential to disturb people nearby. Service providers are running advertisements urging people to be polite in the use of the phones. And some phones now come with a "whisper mode," which enables callers in a crowd to whisper.
