HEADLINE: World Trade Body Opposes Canadian Magazine Tariffs

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The United States appears to have won an important skirmish with Canada over trade restrictions on intellectual products like magazines, a development that could strengthen Washington's case against cultural protection trade policies used by many other countries.
The World Trade Organization, which decides issues among more than 120 nations that trade with each other, ruled on Thursday night that Canada could not try to ban the Canadian editions of magazines from the United States by imposing heavy excise taxes or other measures that throttle trade, including favorable postal rates for domestic magazines. 
 The ruling was preliminary, but it was considered unlikely that the trade organization would change its mind before reaching a final decision next month.
Canada has long contended that it needs to keep out the Canadian editions of magazines like Sports Illustrated to protect the country's own modest magazine industry.
The regular editions of magazines from the United States can easily be found at most newsstands, where only about 20 percent of the magazines displayed come from Canada. But unlike the Canadian editions, the regular editions contain no advertising specifically for or by Canadians.
The complaint filed by the United States Office of the Trade Representative argued that the excise tax and other measures constituted an attempt to ban the Canadian editions of United States magazines and thus violated international trading conventions that Canada had already agreed to follow.
Canada uses a range of trade restrictions and legal limitations to protect books, films, television and radio broadcasts and other aspects of what it considers its cultural heritage from American domination. Such products are excluded from the provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement, but are covered by trade agreements overseen by the World Trade Organization.
Officials in Ottawa argue that culture cannot be treated the same way as auto parts or other goods that cross international borders.
"Essentially, the Americans are trying to get culture back on the table," the president of the Canadian Magazine Publishers Association, Catherine Keachie, said in a statement. "They're trying to bully what they couldn't bargain in open negotiations with Canada."
Trade analysts have said that a victory before the World Trade Organization, one of the most influential trade bodies in the world, would bolster the United States' position and pave the way for future challenges in other countries.
At issue in the complaint against Canada is what are called "split runs" or local editions of magazines from the United States. For example, in 1993 Sports Illustrated, a division of Time Warner Inc., started to publish a Canadian edition in which most of the editorial content came from the United States. A few Canadian stories were usually added.
But since the original advertising sold in the United States more than covered publication costs, the magazine could sell advertising in the local edition to Canadian companies at rock-bottom rates.
Trade officials in Ottawa argued this was a kind of dumping, intended to put competitors out of business. To fight back, in December 1995, the Canadian Government imposed an 80 percent excise tax on advertising sold in Canada for each weekly edition of Sports Illustrated.
Sports Illustrated stopped publishing a Canadian edition then because the tax would have forced up the price of the magazine to a level that consumers would have rejected.
Now, Nicholas P. Wattson, sales manager for Sports Illustrated in Toronto, says that there are no plans to start publishing another Canadian edition soon.
"We're not chomping at the bit to come back into this market," he said.
Ottawa is still trying to assess the full impact of the decision. Nicole Bourget, a spokeswoman for the International Trade Minister, Arthur Eggleton, who was on a trade mission to East Asia, said that Canada still had a chance to submit additional arguments, or appeal a final ruling.

HEADLINE: With State Budget, First Impressions May Deceive

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
At first blush, New York State's balance sheet looks pretty good. The state, more flush with cash than in many years, expects to end its fiscal year March 31 with a $1.3 billion surplus, thanks to a strong economy and a boom on Wall Street.
But independent analysts say that Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed $66.1 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1 squanders a rare chance to use the surplus to correct longterm problems, instead making them worse. They liken the budget to someone using a windfall to live beyond his means for a while, rather than following the wiser course of paying off credit card balances, fixing the roof and putting something away for an emergency. 
 One problem, critics say, is that the state would have a $768 million shortfall in the portion of the budget financed by state taxes, using money left over from this year's surplus to make up the difference. Spending would remain about the same, even as tax cuts reduce revenue, creating a problem when the surplus runs out.
"This budget's not balanced, and it drives large deficits in the years to come," said Cynthia B. Green, vice president for state studies at the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group that analyzes the state's and New York City's spending. "It's bad public policy. When you have a surplus, you use it for one-time expenditures. You use it to pay down debt. You should not roll a surplus over."
But John Signor, a spokesman for the Governor's budget office, offered a vigorous defense of what he called "a responsible, well-balanced plan," and added a sharp rejoinder to Mr. Pataki's critics. "These are the same people who for the first two years said we were out of balance," he said. "They said the sky was falling. They were wrong."
The underlying assumptions in Mr. Pataki's plan are a bit optimistic but reasonable, analysts say, though they caution that, six years into an economic expansion, a downturn is always possible. The budget envisions that the economy will grow at the same rate as in 1996, that the stock market will rise 15 percent and that personal income growth in New York will slow somewhat.
Mr. Signor noted that the Governor's chief Democratic adversary, Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, has maintained that, if anything, Mr. Pataki had underestimated revenues for the coming year. In his first two years in office, Mr. Pataki, helped by a strong economy, cut the budget gap the state faced the following year. "We've made substantial progress, so if you look at the big picture, we're moving in the right direction," Mr. Signor said. "Why don't they come up with a list of where we can save a billion dollars?"
Still, an official at a major bond-rating company, speaking on condition of anonymity, had this assessment: "The budget works for '97-98, but beyond that, there's trouble."
New York has by far the largest debt of any state, and analysts contend that it should use the surplus to make early payments on some of that borrowing, reducing the principal and lowering future interest payments. But under Mr. Pataki's budget, the debt would continue to grow.
The Governor's proposed budget anticipates that the state would have to spend $3 billion, or 9.5 percent of all state tax revenue, to make payments on that debt. The median among the states is 3.5 percent, said Robert A. Kurtter, vice president for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service. New Jersey spends less than 3 percent, while Connecticut spends more than 13 percent.
Mr. Pataki boasted last week that with his budget, the state's rainy-day fund, a cushion that can be used to soften the blow of a recession, would swell to $332 million, "the greatest level since it was created a half-century ago." But New York is hobbled by a provision of the State Constitution that prohibits putting more than two-tenths of 1 percent of the general fund, or about $63 million next year, into the reserve fund in any year. Many far smaller states keep a bigger emergency reserve than New York does. "It's clearly an area where New York State lags tremendously," Mr. Kurtter said "I mean, little Indiana has $2 billion."
On average, he said, states have reserves of about 5 percent of annual state tax revenue. With the increase Mr. Pataki proposes, New York's reserve would grow to 1 percent of state taxes. New Jersey's is $440 million and Connecticut's $241 million, each about 3 percent.
"When we have surplus, a good portion of it should be committed to reserve," said State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat who is seen as a possible 1998 challenger to Mr. Pataki.
Medicaid presents an area of major uncertainty for New York, as for other states, because no one can be sure how fast medical costs will rise. The Governor's budget anticipates that unrestrained, Medicaid expenses will rise 5.7 percent,
Last week, the Congressional Budget Office projected Medicaid inflation nationwide at 7.8 percent, down from its projection of 9.7 percent six months ago. The Citizens Budget Commission predicts that in New York, it will fall between 5.9 percent and 8.5 percent. The Greater New York Hospital Association says it will be less than 5 percent, and bond raters, too, think the state's estimates are high.
"The numbers depend heavily on the number of people enrolled in Medicaid, and that could fluctuate widely with changes in the economy, and in Federal policy," said James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, a health care research organization in Manhattan. "It's a very hard area to predict."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Fancy Talk Aside, Cuts Mean Hunger

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
THE Rev. William A. Greenlaw stood in the middle of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles' soup kitchen, at Ninth Avenue and 28th Street, while a line of dejected-looking men filed past. Each carried a tray with a helping of scalloped ham, carrots and bread, and, on the side, a handful of incongruously festive Christmas candies. Few of the men looked up from their trays as they walked by.
"There's a meanspiritedness in this that's an indictment against our whole society," Father Greenlaw said, struggling to be heard over the rattling trays and scraping chairs. Then he quickly added, "But I don't believe that the people of New York want to be that meanspirited." 
 Father Greenlaw was talking about changes to the welfare system, specifically about a new provision of Federal law that could end food stamp eligibility for thousands of New Yorkers starting next month. Under the provision, able-bodied, childless adults under age 50 who are not working at least 20 hours a week can receive no more than three months of food stamps every three years.
There is, however, a way to sidestep the provision that 11 states, including Illinois, Pennsylvania and Ohio, have already pursued. To soften the provision's impact, Congress allowed states to apply for waivers for regions where there are "insufficient jobs." In New York, several regions, including New York City, would qualify for such a waiver if the state applied.
But Gov. George E. Pataki has chosen not to. Instead of seeking the broadest possible waiver, he has sought a narrow one that would apply only to regions with unemployment rates above 10 percent. In New York, no such regions actually exist.
Advocates for the poor and religious leaders, like Father Greenlaw, have widely deplored the Governor's decision and assert that as many as 100,000 people could go hungry as a result. They are particularly disturbed, they say, because food stamps, unlike other welfare programs, are paid for solely by the Federal Government. Liz Krueger, associate director of the Community Food Resource Center, estimates that without the waiver, the state's residents will lose up to $80 million a year in Federal aid.
"Isn't the job of a governor to make sure he maximizes Federal revenues?" she said.
SO far, at least, Mr. Pataki has refused to be drawn personally into the debate, leaving it to aides to respond. Much of their effort has gone into challenging the dire predictions about the measure's impact.
Administration officials maintain that most of the people affected by the new Federal law are already required by state rules to work or to enroll in workfare programs and, as a consequence, will remain eligible for food stamps. They calculate that at the very most, 17,000 people might lose their benefits and that, ultimately, local governments will find workfare slots for these people as well.
The Governor's aides have also challenged the whole notion that New York ought be seeking Federal money for the poor just because it is available.
"It is unfortunate that some people out there are talking about money instead of human beings," said John Signor, a spokesman for the State Budget Division. "We don't look at it as additional money. We look at it as trying to move people out of the web of dependency."
He continued, "The welfare lobby wants to keep people dependent on the government."
Critics of the administration counter that Mr. Pataki's decision not to apply for a broad waiver is less a matter of social welfare philosophy than political calculation. The Governor frequently boasts that thousands of new jobs have been created in the state since he took office. Were he to apply for a broad waiver, the gesture could be interpreted -- at least by his political opponents -- as an admission of the state's continuing economic weakness.
"It is so offensive to the Governor to declare that we don't have enough jobs," Ms. Krueger said, "that he is prepared to lose $250 million over the next three years."
IN the meantime, letters have already started to go out to thousands of food stamp recipients warning them about the impending changes.
A homeless woman who gave her name only as Gila and was waiting to see a counselor outside the Holy Apostles soup kitchen said that she had received her letter and was worried about what to do when her three months were up.
"How are you supposed to survive the other months?" she asked.
A homeless man who identified himself as Tyrone Robinson "and a failure," also said that he had received a letter. He then searched for it, unsuccessfully, among the various admonitory letters from the city's welfare agency that he carried folded in his pockets.
He was evasive when asked whether he would try to find a workfare position to maintain his eligibility for food stamps. And he seemed less angry about the change than resigned to it, explaining, "I knew it was coming."

HEADLINE: Russia and U.S. Are at War (But Only if You're Driving)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 19

 BODY:
With the American flag fluttering from his limousine, the top United States diplomat here rode out of his embassy on Thursday.
But no sooner had the car belonging to the diplomat, John Tefft, passed through the embassy gates than it was stopped by the Russian traffic police on Moscow's Garden Ring road. 
 After a check of official documents, the diplomat's car was allowed to drive on. But there seemed little mistaking the message to American officials:
Russia would retaliate for an embarrassing series of traffic violations its diplomats had been accused of in New York. And not even even Mr. Tefft, the charge d'affaires and senior American diplomat here pending the appointment of a new ambassador, would be exempt.
"They were hitting really hard," an American official said today, referring to the recent, and highly unusual, road checks of American diplomats.
For four decades, Moscow and Washington were bitter political adversaries. But now, with the cold war behind them, Russia and the United States appear to be embroiled in a tit-for-tat traffic war.
Ever since a Russian envoy and his Belarussian colleague were accused late last month of abusing their diplomatic status and becoming involved in an altercation with New York police officers, Russia's Foreign Ministry has responded with howls of indignant protest.
And articles have appeared in the Russian press accusing Western diplomats of drunkenness and irresponsible behavior on Russia's anything-goes highways.
But the latest twist is something Moscow's traffic police call "Operation Foreigner." On Thursday, the first day of the campaign, according to a police spokesman, traffic officers stopped 1,000 foreign-owned cars. More than 200 violations of traffic rules were discovered, he said, most committed by Americans.
Russian traffic officials publicly insist that they are merely trying to maintain order in the disorderly scrum that typifies Moscow's road travel. But Western officials, as well as many Russians, trace the crackdown to politics.
Certainly, Russia's feud with New York's police department contrasts markedly with the approach taken by Georgia. When a Georgian diplomat was accused earlier this month of causing a fatal accident in Washington, the Georgian Government apologized and stripped the envoy of his diplomatic immunity so that he could be prosecuted.
But then, Georgia is seeking to strengthen its economic and diplomatic ties with the West while the Russians see their run-in with the New York police as the latest in a series of painful humilations.
Russia's dust-up with the New York police began last month when Russian and Belarussian diplomats scuffled with the police after being accused of parking near a fire hydrant and seeking to drive while intoxicated.
It intensified last Monday, when New York police officers ticketed the limousine of the Russian Ambassador to the United Nations three times for illegal parking.
Three days later the Moscow police launched "Operation Foreigner," with Americans, British and French diplomats apparently receiving the brunt of the attention. Over the weekend, however, the number of road checks appeared to decrease.
Singling out Americans is a simple task since their cars display telltale license plates, with the numerals "004" identifying their nationality. The letter "D" identifies diplomats. The letter "K" is used to identify foreign correspondents.
In addition to Mr. Tefft, the embassy's chief of protocol was stopped three times on the way between the ambassador's residence and the embassy.
The American Embassy is still in the process of compiling a statistical record of the road checks. But one official said today that when Mr. Tefft asked at a meeting of senior American officials about their recent experiences driving in Moscow, "everyone had a story to tell."

HEADLINE: G.I.'s Might Get Even More for Less

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In the daily life of American soldiers, few perks are as prized as shopping at the base department store, which sells almost everything from lingerie to lawn fertilizer at cut-rate prices.
But regulations adopted in 1949 to protect mom-and-pop stores outside the base from unfair Government competition also spell out in quirky detail what the military stores, or post exchanges, cannot sell. 
 The exchanges, called P.X.'s by generations of G.I.'s, may sell television sets, for example, but none with screens larger than 27 inches. They may sell rugs, but none larger than 9 by 12 feet. And they may sell cheaper, ready-to-assemble furniture, but not fancy mahogany dining tables.
The Pentagon has proposed lifting the remaining restrictions next month, arguing that family businesses have largely succumbed to big discounters like Kmart and Wal-Mart, and that troops are clamoring for big-screen TV's, high-end computers, foreign-made microwave ovens and other products the exchanges are barred from selling.
"The dynamics in the retail sector render these restrictions obsolete and present an unfair burden to our servicemen and women," Frederick Pang, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, wrote to the House and Senate military committees recently.
But under intense lobbying from trade associations representing big retailers like Circuit City, Montgomery Ward and Sears, Roebuck & Company, as well as many Main Street merchants, the House National Security Committee has ordered the Pentagon to wait until Congress holds hearings on the matter.
"Many businesses and chambers of commerce see this as a tremendously unfair advantage for the P.X.'s," said Representative Walter B. Jones Jr., a North Carolina Republican who has three military bases in his district and who sits on a special House panel that is responsible for the "morale, welfare and recreation" of the armed forces.
The dispute has caught lawmakers on the House panel between their duties to improve the benefits of the all-volunteer military -- a vital incentive in recruiting and retaining a top-quality force -- and the economic interests of constituents who are small-business owners.
"It's a very sensitive issue in that we have to balance the interests of the soldiers and the local community folks," said Representative Saxby Chambliss, a Georgia Republican on the House panel.
The Senate, which in the past has supported lifting the restrictions, is now taking a wait-and-see approach, pending any House hearings.
Though Congress may be cool to the Pentagon plan, it is a big hit with the troops and their advocates.
"We fully support lifting the restrictions," said Sydney T. Hickey, associate director for government relations for the National Military Family Association, an advocacy group in Alexandria, Va. "These regulations were done to protect mom-and-pop stores outside the gate. They ain't there no more, and it's difficult to see how Wal-Mart is a mom-and-pop."
At Bolling Air Force Base's exchange here, where as many as 6,000 customers a day are served on weekends, military personnel voiced strong support for the proposal.
"It's a great idea," said Lieut. Bill Shea, a 26-year-old Air Force logistics planner, who was browsing for compact disks. "Right now, the big-ticket items is where they are really limited."
Lieut. Steve Smith, a 28-year-old Navy officer, said he spends as much as $200 a month at the exchange, and added, "More selection would be better."
Since the first exchange opened in 1895, the stores have sold merchandise to troops, veterans and their families at prices averaging 25 percent below what other commercial stores charge. That's a big difference for any service member, but particularly for a young sailor or private earning $20,000 a year. Exchanges have lower retail markups, charge no sales tax and offer cheaper financing than their commercial rivals.
Unlike the military commissaries -- groceries that receive a $1 billion annual Federal subsidy -- the exchanges are largely self-supporting. Last year, the military's 360 exchanges earned $307.5 million on $9.2 billion in sales.
About two-thirds of the profits go toward building and maintaining recreational activities on bases, like golf courses and bowling alleys.
But exchange sales and the corresponding dividends to recreation funds, another important quality-of-life account, have been declining as the military has shrunk to just under 1.5 million troops from 2.1 million a decade ago.
Pentagon officials say expanding the exchanges' wares could increase annual sales by about $106 million and bring in an additional $18.4 million a year for more bowling alleys, day-care centers and swimming pools on military bases.
This would mean waiving the limits not only on TV's and rugs sold, but also on diamond rings (only one carat and below are sold now), electrical appliances that cost more than $81.75 (ruling out high-end bread makers and juicers) and some foreign-made goods, like small microwave ovens built in Korea.
"In today's retail world, the current system just doesn't make sense," said Robert F. Swarts, a retired Air Force major general who heads the American Logistics Association, a group of companies that supply the exchanges and support the Pentagon plan.
But the powerful retail lobby on Capitol Hill is fighting hard to knock down the proposal, warning that unfair Government competition will drive even more small retailers out of business and hurt the communities surrounding military bases.
"What we're saying is, 'Philosophically, this is too much,' " said John J. Motley, senior vice president of government affairs for the National Retail Federation in Washington. "It'll undermine the local tax bases."
A compromise may be in the offing: to let each base commander decide which of the 13 remaining restricted retail categories to lift, depending on the local economy. "That," Representative Jones said, "would be a step in the right direction."

HEADLINE: Slower Growth in Number of Prisoners

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
The rapid growth in the number of people in the nation's jails and prisons slowed last year for the first time in a decade, according to a study released yesterday by the Justice Department, reflecting at least in part a decline in the crime rate over the past five years.
At the end of June 1996, there were 1,630,940 people in Federal and state prisons and local jails, an increase of 4.4 percent over the previous year, compared with an average annual growth rate of 7.8 percent in the last decade, the study found. 
 The growth rate slowed most noticeably in city and county jails, rising only 2.3 percent last year after increasing by an average of 6.9 percent over the previous decade. Inmates sentenced to jail usually serve a term of a year or less.
The slowing in the overall growth rate "is good news; it could be an early reflection in the incarceration rate of the drop in crime over the last five years," said Alfred Blumstein, a professor of criminology at Carnegie-Mellon University.
But Professor Blumstein and some other experts tempered their enthusiasm, noting that a slower growth rate in one year could be a random fluctuation. It will take a few years to confirm whether this is a real trend, he said, noting that the slowdown was not dramatic and that the incarceration rate grew last year despite the five-year drop in the crime rate.
In fact, Franklin Zimring, the director of the Earl Warren Legal Institute of the University of California at Berkeley, suggested that because the incarceration rate has continued to increase even as crime has fallen, the number of people in prison "tells us more about our feelings about crime and criminals" and about changes in sentencing laws than about the the actual crime rate.
The total number of people in jails and prisons doubled over the last decade and tripled over the last 20 years as politicians pushed for tougher sentencing laws and for building more prisons in response to mounting public fears about violent crime. The national incarceration rate was 615 inmates per 100,000 Americans last year, up from 313 per 100,000 in 1985.
One reason it is difficult to calculate precisely why the incarceration rate goes up or down is that there is enormous variation in prison populations among states and regions. The new study found, for example, that the District of Columbia had the highest number of prisoners per capita, 1,444 per 100,000 residents, followed by Texas with 659, Louisiana with 611 and Oklahoma with 580. But states in the northern Midwest and northern New England tend to have much lower rates. North Dakota had 90 per 100,000, followed by Minnesota with 108 and Maine with 112.
The South had the highest imprisonment rate with an average of 487 prisoners per 100,000 people, and the Northeast had the lowest, with 306.
An important factor in explaining why the prison population has continued to grow, while the crime rate began to decline in 1992, experts say, is that the crime which has led to the largest increase in incarceration, the sale and possession of drugs, is not counted in the F.B.I.'s crime index. Over the last 10 years, Professor Blumstein estimated, drug offenders accounted for about half the growth in the prison population.
The crime index tracks four violent crimes (murder, aggravated assault, robbery and rape) and four property crimes (burglary, auto theft, arson and larceny, or minor thefts like like shoplifting). Murder has dropped the fastest of the crimes included in the index, though the murders make up only a very small part of the total number of crimes.
Another reason the number of prison inmates has continued to increase, despite the decline in serious and violent crimes, is that it often takes a year or longer for offenders to be tried and sentenced to prison.
It is unclear whether the slower growth in the prison population could be interpreted as a sign that tougher sentencing laws are successful. While experts agree that building more prisons may reduce crime by removing some career criminals from the streets, they have long argued about whether the threat of harsher sentences deters criminals.
Professor Zimring said he was skeptical about a deterrent effect because the prison population has tripled in 20 years while the crime rate has oscillated in a slim range.
But Steven Levitt, an economist at Harvard University who studies the effectiveness of prisons and police, said, "The underlying amount of crime would have grown faster had we not locked so many people up."
To measure the effectiveness of imprisonment in reducing crimes, Professor Levitt has studied the results of successful prisoner lawsuits to reduce overcrowding.
In 12 states where such suits resulted in a judge's decision to reduce overcrowding, he said, the growth rate of those states' prison population was 12 percent slower than that of the nation over the next three years, while the violent crime rate in those states exceeded the national average by about 10 percent. Similarly, the property crime rate in those 12 states surpassed the national average by about 6 percent in the three years after the lawsuits.
Although Professor Levitt acknowledged that using prisons to fight crime was costly in both human and dollar terms, he said the new figures showing slower growth in the incarceration rate "are a very clear indication" of the nationwide drop in crime since 1992. "I would not be surprised over the next five years to see more falling crime rates accompanied by continuing small increases in the prison population," he said.
"It is conceivable that we have gotten over the hump, or cleared the peak of the fight against crime," Professor Levitt said.
The new report released yesterday was written by Darrell Gilliard and Allen J. Beck of the Bureau of Justice Statistics, the statistical arm of the Justice Department.

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: THE OVERVIEW;
Americans Foresee Harmony in Capital

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
On the eve of President Clinton's second inauguration on Monday, the American people and their political leaders said they had high hopes for uncommon bipartisan cooperation even as the capital was riven by battles over the ethics controversies enveloping both parties.
But while the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that the public is optimistic that there will be harmony, it also makes clear that Americans have lower expectations about what they view as particularly intractable problems facing the nation. Far fewer than half of those polled expect progress toward balancing the budget, restraining entitlement costs and reforming the way campaigns are financed. 
 In another manifestation of the public's upbeat feeling but caution about the future, Americans give a higher rating to the way things are going in the country today than they did four years ago. But they are more uncertain about the future than they were when Mr. Clinton took the oath four years ago.
Even as the ethics accusations against Speaker Newt Gingrich and the campaign finance problems that confront the Democrats draw attention away from the inaugural festivities and exacerbate partisan hostilities, 66 percent of the Americans polled said that they thought Mr. Clinton and the Republicans who control Congress would be able to work together on the most important issues.
The poll of 1,307 adults nationwide, conducted by telephone Tuesday through Friday, found that Mr. Clinton's job performance rating of 60 percent is at the highest level of his four years in office. Statistically, it ties with the 62 percent rating President Ronald Reagan drew at the start of his second term.
Over all, 66 percent of the Americans polled said they were "generally optimistic" about the next four years with Mr. Clinton. The poll's margin of sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points.
While Mr. Gingrich's favorability rating is rock bottom at 15 percent, that in itself does not appear to have dampened the public's expectations about how much the Congress can accomplish. The job approval rating of Congress stands at 45 percent, the highest since 1991. And slightly more than half of the Americans polled said that they expected Congress to accomplish more than it usually does in a two-year period; 26 percent expected fewer accomplishments.
In fact, even though Mr. Gingrich is preoccupied by his own ethics problems, people are nearly evenly divided over whether the House or Senate will have more influence over the nation's direction.
Despite the positive outlook expressed by party leaders and the public, there were signs of deep partisan fissures on the eve of Inauguration Day. Erskine B. Bowles, who takes over as White House chief of staff on Monday, vowed to work hard to defeat a Constitutional amendment to balance the budget. "We don't think it's right to muck around with the Constitution," Mr. Bowles said on the NBC News program, "Meet the Press."
Earlier, on the same program, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, had sharp words for Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who on Friday warned of the ill consequences to the economy of a balanced budget amendment. "He really was hysterical," Mr. Lott said. "I was very disappointed in him."
Mr. Clinton, who was polishing his inaugural speech today, is expected to stay clear of such partisanship in his address on Monday. His advisers said that the President planned to emphasize national unity and the importance of reaching out to the Republicans.
And, despite his tough words today, Mr. Lott insisted in a recent interview that he intended to move beyond the aggressive partisanship that marked Mr. Gingrich's early tenure as Speaker. "There will be areas where the debate will be passionate, and it will be contentious at times," he said. "But I think we're starting off on a positive note, and I think we have a lot of potential to work together."
Despite the President's move to the center in his re-election campaign, he will be leading a country whose partisan leanings have not changed appreciably in the last four years. The public is still closely split among those who describe themselves as Democrats, Republicans and independents, and more Americans continue to call themselves more conservative than liberal.
In contrast to two years ago, the public views Mr. Clinton and the Congressional Republicans as much more evenly matched. Forty percent of the Americans polled said that Mr. Clinton would have more influence over the direction of the country; 50 percent said Republicans in Congress would have more influence. But in January 1995, when the first Republican majority in 40 years took over both chambers of Congress, 78 percent said Congress would have more influence. Only 14 percent cited Mr. Clinton then.
Mr. Clinton's advisers have said that he was extremely concerned about his place in history. At the start of Mr. Clinton's second term, the public has rendered a mixed verdict: 40 percent said he had been a "good" or "very good" President; 47 percent described him as "average" and 13 percent said he had been "poor."
Nedra Robinson, 42, who owns a child care center in Minneapolis and was one of the people surveyed, explained her hope for bipartisan progress. "I'm hoping that they'll be able to see beyond all this personal stuff and get on with dealing with the issues facing this country," Ms. Robinson, who voted for Mr. Clinton, said in a follow-up interview.
Another respondent, Joseph Waldspurger, a data processor in Cary, Ill., who voted for Bob Dole, said he thought that the parties would cooperate, but only so much. "They'll be able to work together but they won't be able to set any specific goals that are worthwhile because of partisan bickering," said Mr. Waldspurger, who is 52. "There's a lot of emphasis being put on balancing the budget and they'll probably make some headway on that, but I'm not convinced it's a high priority."
Beneath their general sense that the parties would try to work in harmony, people expressed doubts when they were asked about specific serious problems. Only 45 percent said that Mr. Clinton and Congressional Republicans would make progress toward balancing the budget in the next four years; 52 percent said that the leaders would not. Only 39 percent said they would be able to resolve most of the problems with Medicare funding; 56 percent said they would not. And only 36 percent expect the parties to resolve most of the problems with Social Security funding; 58 percent said that the parties would not.
People who expect little progress in those areas said they were dubious largely because the problems were inherently too complicated, rather than because of partisan rancor.
On another matter that the parties have squabbled over for years, reforming the campaign finance system, 39 percent said the President and Republicans would make significant progress. Fifty percent said they would not. But those who foresaw little progress were highly skeptical that the President and Congress were truly serious about wanting reform.
The public has limited expectations in other policy areas as well. Only 33 percent expected the nation's education system to be better by the end of Mr. Clinton's second term; only 18 percent expected fewer people to be living in poverty. In both those areas, most Americans expected the same number as now. And only 24 percent expected a decrease in violent crime by the end of Mr. Clinton's term.
The survey found that the economy had faded as one of the most pressing concerns of Americans. Seventy-one percent said the condition of the economy was good. Only 35 percent had responded with that assessment four years ago when Mr. Clinton entered office after capitalizing on the discontent over President George Bush's handling of the economy.
As the major political parties install new leaders this month, the controversy affecting Mr. Gingrich and the inquiries into the Democratic Party's fund raising practices do not seem to have altered the relative popularity of either party. Fifty-five percent of the Americans polled said that they had a favorable view of the Democratic Party; 50 percent had a favorable view of the Republican Party.
Even so, 50 percent said Congress should hold hearings to investigate events surrounding illegal campaign contributions that the Democratic Party received from foreign business executives; 30 percent said hearings were unnecessary. On another distraction for the President, the public, by 56 percent to 39 percent, said Paula Corbin Jones's civil lawsuit against Mr. Clinton should be postponed until he leaves office.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Tuesday through Friday with 1,307 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges in the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For the question that asked respondents to rate on a scale of 1 to 10 the way things are going in the United States at the present time, the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 0.10; that is, in 19 cases out of 20, a mean rating by the poll's respondents of 5.64 on that scale would be no lower than 5.54 and no higher than 5.74 if all adults had been sought out.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Power Is Underpriced, Energy Secretary Says

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The price of energy is artificially depressed in this country, Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary said in an interview on the eve of her departure from office, and Americans will not be serious about conservation or energy independence until the price goes up or there is another shock.
Mrs. O'Leary also said members of Congress do not care nearly so much about making the right technology choices in handling nuclear waste and weapons as they do about providing jobs in their districts. 
 No future secretary of energy will undertake trade missions to foreign governments, she said, because of the criticism she received for her travel expenses. As a result, she predicted, America's competitors will march into countries that want new technology or services and are accustomed to dealing government to government and "go laughing all the way into the next meeting with the minister."
Mrs. O'Leary said she was exhausted by the last four years and that anyone who stayed longer in the job was "probably certifiable." She said she would continue working with black organizations, especially those concerned with education in science and other fields.
President Clinton has nominated Federico F. Pena, who has been Secretary of Transportation for the last four years, to replace her.
In the last few days she has renewed a campaign of "openness," announcing that thousands of films of early nuclear weapons tests would be declassified, and giving information on plutonium left by the United States in South Vietnam 20 years ago. Whatever follows, she said, the culture of secrecy has been broken.
Mrs. O'Leary was interviewed in her seventh-floor office at the Energy Department, with its northern wall of windows giving both a stunning view of the castle-like Smithsonian headquarters and a perpetual chill. She, like her predecessors, makes a conservation compromise: using an electric space heater to supplement the inadequate central heating system.
Mrs. O'Leary, who served in the Energy Department in the Carter Administration and was an executive at the Northern States Power electric company when President Clinton named her Secretary of Energy, said she did not want another Government job.
She said that she had tried within the constraints of the budget to nurture alternative fuel and energy technologies. The prevailing view, she said, was that "somehow, miraculously, the market will present itself" for technologies like fuel cells, which make electricity from liquid hydrocarbons, and photovoltaic cells, which can make electricity from sunlight. But Government will have to subsidize these technologies to help lift volumes and keep costs down, or let energy prices rise.
"The price of energy is artificially less in the United States," she said. There is no political will to raise prices, she said.
Mrs. O'Leary said that in Germany and Japan, governments subsidize purchases of solar cells. Referring to American dominance of manufacturing, she said, "We own 47 percent of that market share, and if we're not careful, we're going to lose it," she said.
Referring to dependence on imported oil, she said, "We need a wake-up call, and I know for a fact that doesn't come from the Secretary of Energy wandering the land and saying what needs to be done, because it's not nearly as dramatic as a price shock or some other dislocation.
"Almost any short-term dislocation, from a place like Venezuela, which is in fact our largest source, or from Russia would get our attention in the short term," she said.
But the reaction to price shocks, she said, is to try to sell oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. That, she said, is "a sin, a shame, and it ought to be stopped." Some oil from the reserve has been sold in the last few years to pay for improvements in storage equipment, and some members of Congress have proposed selling more to balance the budget.
The Department's main work is not energy, though, but nuclear weapons. Production of weapons materials had mostly ended when Mrs. O'Leary took office, but she moved to retire many cold war-era factories, most sitting on environmental nightmares. She said that in the last four years, her department had cleaned up 700 factories, storage areas, ponds and other sites -- but the total inventory is between 5,000 and 10,000. In contrast, Mrs. O'Leary said fewer than 80 had been cleaned up in the previous four years. Environmental spending runs about $6 billion a year, much of it for maintenance.
Mrs. O'Leary said Congressional debates over what new equipment was needed for the weapons complex were mostly devoid of discussions about technologies or economics, and instead were based on politics.
"We've built ourselves into a system where we have to overcome those expectations and try to do what's best and good for all, as opposed to, take care of 'my district, my state, my constituency,' " she said.

HEADLINE: Casino Plan Stumbles in Albany, But Maneuvering for Bill Persists

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
To the casual observer, a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling now before the State Legislature must have looked like a wounded animal in its death throes last week. Support for it had eroded among the State Senate's Republican majority. Democrats were complaining that it did nothing for New York City. The opposition was in full-tilt mobilization.
"The chances of a casino bill passing in my house presently would be pretty remote," declared the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Rensselaer County Republican, on Wednesday. 
 It seemed a stunning turnaround for a measure that just weeks ago appeared on a fast track to passage. But the amendment is far from dead. And while it clearly is in trouble, it has become the object of an awkward pas de deux involving the Senate's 35 Republicans and 26 Democrats that may yet result in its passage.
The amendment's problems in the Senate can best be understood with a little geopolitical arithmetic. The amendment calls for one casino in each of three areas: Buffalo, Niagara Falls and either Warren or Saratoga County. It would allow an unlimited number in the Catskills. And it would authorize harness race tracks to install video poker and slot machines.
With the exception of Buffalo, those are mainly Republican districts. And with the exception of Saratoga County, those regions have been clamoring for casinos. That means that more Republicans than Democrats want the gambling amendment to be passed.
Passage in the Legislature would send the amendment to voters in a referendum in November.
Many Republicans oppose the measure because they believe allowing gambling would cause a host of social ills. And many others, including several from New York City, are lukewarm at best to it because their districts stand to gain little or nothing from casinos.
The result, according to Mr. Bruno: the amendment cannot pass with Republican votes alone. It needs Senate Democrats -- about 15 of them, the unofficial Republican head count indicates.
But most of the Democrats come from New York City and are under little pressure from their constituents to vote for or against the amendment since it will not directly affect their neighborhoods. Their votes are, in a sense, free to be traded.
Many Democrats say they believe that enough Republicans want the amendment to pass that Mr. Bruno will, in fact, be forced to trade for their votes.
In return, the Democrats want Republican support on any number of issues, from staving off budget cuts, to increasing state aid to city schools to maintaining rent regulations that are scheduled to expire on June 15.
"These casinos are not in Democratic strongholds, they're in Republican districts, and those people want them," said Senator Larry Seabrook, a Bronx Democrat. "Bruno will have to negotiate. It's crucial to him."
Jubilant that they might be in the coveted position of having something that the majority actually wants, the Senate Democrats have tried to walk a fine line between flirting and playing hard to get. When asked last Monday by Mr. Bruno how many Democrats would vote for the amendment, the Senate minority leader, Martin Connor of Brooklyn, demurred. Democratic officials say Mr. Connor has ordered his members to "stay loose."
In a survey by The New York Times last week, only one Democrat said he would vote for the measure while four committed to opposing it. More than half -- 14 -- said they were undecided. (Six did not respond.)
"At this juncture, I'm taking a wait-and-see attitude," said Senator Carl Kruger, a Brooklyn Democrat, echoing a typical Democratic sentiment.
In the Assembly, the measure is expected to pass because it is strongly supported by the Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
Mr. Bruno has studiously maintained a poker face when confronted with the issue. He expresses ambivalence about the amendment, saying he opposes gambling but wants the measure to pass in the Legislature so that voters can have the final say. He will not pressure Republicans to vote for it, nor negotiate with Democrats for their votes, he said.
And in what would appear to some to be the ultimate expression of indifference, Mr. Bruno announced last week that even if he thought the amendment would fail, he would still bring it up for a floor vote. "If it doesn't pass in two or three weeks," he said, "it will be dead this year."
Democrats say they think Mr. Bruno is bluffing. Eventually, they contend, he will quietly open negotiations with them. "It's more important to him than he's letting on," Senator Seabrook said. "He's trying to get our votes on a benevolent approach. But we're more sophisticated than that."
But if Mr. Bruno publicly supports casinos, he may find trouble in his backyard. The strongest pocket of opposition to casino gambling in the state comes from Saratoga, in Mr. Bruno's district. Local business leaders, ministers and even Skidmore College have mounted a furious lobbying effort against the amendment, asserting that a casino nearby would hurt the Saratoga race track, weaken the local economy and cheapen their quaint tourist area.
The opponents have vowed to work against anyone who supports the amendment, including Mr. Bruno. "People would to some extent hold him responsible," said the Rev. Jay Ekman, a Presbyterian minister from Saratoga who is coordinating an anti-casino campaign for the New York State Council of Churches. "If we lost and this community were changed radically, he would be perceived as the man who had the power to stop it and chose not to."
Though Mr. Bruno is one of the three most powerful people in Albany, capable of directing huge amounts of state spending into his district, he won re-election over a political unknown last November by a surprisingly narrow margin: 58 percent to 42 percent. For that reason, Mr. Bruno may feel compelled to say he will do nothing to advance the amendment.
Still, some casino opponents think that Mr. Bruno may be under pressure to get the amendment passed from his Republican ally, Gov. George E. Pataki, who contends that casinos will help the state's economy. But the Governor has insisted repeatedly that he will not cajole any lawmaker to vote for it.
If that remains the case, and both Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bruno stay on the sidelines, the measure is considered likely to fail in the Senate. That would probably mortally wound it for this year, but only this year, Mr. Bruno and other lawmakers say.
"It has been killed by the Legislature four times since I've been here," said Senator Hugh T. Farley, a Saratoga County Republican who opposes the amendment. "It keeps getting resurrected. It's like a phoenix."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: THE INAUGURATION: THE FIRST LADY;
Hillary Clinton, an Evolutionary Tale

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
There is something startling and even poignant in the speed with which White House spokesmen quash suggestions that Hillary Rodham Clinton helps create her husband's policies.
Just last week, Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, did not hesitate when asked whether Mrs. Clinton was a "prime motivating force" in drawing the Clinton Administration's attention to the plight of the District of Columbia. 
 "I'd say it's more accurate the other way around," he replied. Mr. McCurry said that it was President Clinton's interest that "led a number of people throughout the Administration to think about what they can do to lend support," thereby lumping the President's wife of 21 years with assorted unnamed bureaucrats, or "others throughout the Administration."
But in an interview on Friday, Erskine B. Bowles, Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, gave Mrs. Clinton more credit. "She is the one that actually originally came to the President with thoughts about doing something in D.C.," he said.
Scorched by the fallout after Mrs. Clinton's leadership in seeking universal health care coverage, the White House has labored to play down her influence, describing a conversion from policy-maker to speech-maker, helpmate and goodwill ambassador, a seemingly docile role for an accomplished lawyer with more than two decades of experience in public life and no shortage of opinions.
But while the White House may lump her various causes under the anodyne rubric of "children's issues," Mrs. Clinton is still pursuing a far broader agenda of causes -- including foreign development, immunization in the inner cities and expanding financial credit for women -- than almost any predecessor in the undefined role of First Lady.
Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledge that she remains among the President's most powerful advisers, and Administration officials credit her with fighting internally to preserve or increase their budgets.
"I think she's easily the most influential First Lady in history," said Michael Beschloss, a historian of the Presidency.
The evolution of Mrs. Clinton's role parallels the arc of the Clinton Administration itself. She may no longer be trying to rework the nation's health care system, but neither is the Administration undertaking such a monumental cause. She may have taken to the bully pulpit and embraced politically milder goals, but then, so has her husband.
At all levels of the White House, officials walk on eggshells when questioned about Mrs. Clinton's plans. Asked whether he would like to see her take more of a public leadership role, Vice President Al Gore said quickly: "That is completely for her to decide."
Mrs. Clinton has been vague about her intentions during the second term, and she has declined most interview requests, including one for this article. In an interview broadcast today on C-Span, she described the political difficulty of spelling out her role as First Lady, a position she called "a struggle."
"On the one hand, people want a wife of a President to be concerned and caring about the issues confronting the country and to work on something of public interest," she said. "On the other hand, they don't want her to do it in a public way on a policy level."
But she indicated that she would not confine herself to noncontroversial issues, offering this daunting tongue-twister: "I'm not about to start caring about things that I've never cared about because it's not appropriate in somebody else's mind for me to continue to care about what I've always cared about."
Some of her allies believe that Mrs. Clinton's public image suffered from her early honesty about her influence. Previous First Ladies, they argue, cannily downplayed their impact. "It's almost as if she's been penalized a little bit because she didn't hide parts of herself," said one associate, speaking, like many, on condition of anonymity.
A New York Times/CBS Newspoll shows that most Americans agree with that analysis. Seventy percent said Mrs. Clinton had the same influence as previous First Ladies, but that it was "just more visible."
Given that view, and the vivid role Mrs. Clinton played in the first two years of the Administration, it may be too late for the White House to camouflage her, as it tried to do during the campaign. Further, since the election, Mrs. Clinton has demonstrated that she will not bury her sharper views with an avalanche of First-Lady-like bromides.
In a speech in Australia in late November, Mrs. Clinton criticized the free market, "which by definition knows the price of everything but the value of nothing," and reported that in the United States, women were still striving "to claim their share of personal, political, economic and civic power."
"Will we stop pigeon-holing women and invoking stereotypes that limit their potential?" she asked, posing a question she might well put to some on her husband's staff.
Many in the White House believe it is the press that wants to pigeonhole Mrs. Clinton, a point Mr. McCurry made last week as he minimized her role in the District of Columbia. "Every time she says anything about any subject," he said, "everyone rushes off to write some new thing about some new role."
Although Mrs. Clinton's popularity has climbed in polls, some of her allies acknowledge that the drumbeat of scandals touching her, particularly Whitewater, darkened her image. In a typical late-night jab last week, David Letterman told his television audience that one goal of the designer of Mrs. Clinton's inaugural dress was to make the sleeves long enough to hide her handcuffs.
Mrs. Clinton's devoted friends talk about her thoughtfulness, about birthdays remembered and losses understood. They describe a complex woman with a wicked, teasing sense of humor and a rollicking laugh. And, sadly, they add that that person rarely comes across in public, because she has to be guarded.
"You can see her sometimes almost censoring the first and second and third thing that comes into her head," said Diane Blair, an old friend who is a political science professor at the University of Arkansas.
But others say that Mrs. Clinton was trained to be publicly stern. Michael Conway, another old friend, noted that only 10 percent of the students in Mrs. Clinton's Yale Law School class were women. And when the two of them worked together on the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry, he said, 2 of the 40 lawyers were women.
"That's her formative training," he said. "She was trained to be a woman lawyer, and particularly to be a trial lawyer, and had to be more determined, more intense, more humorless, to be accepted." Criticizing her for seeming that way in public, he said, was "sort of like criticizing a graduate of West Point for being too rigid and too militaristic."
Still, officials throughout the Administration are beating down Mrs. Clinton's door to line her up as a speaker. They just don't necessarily talk up her role in molding the policies she speaks about.
"The policies are made," said Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, referring to the new welfare law. "Now we need to go out to talk to the people."
Others in the Administration said that they have learned to count on Mrs. Clinton as more than a spokeswoman.
"I don't think that the Endowment would be alive today if it weren't for strong White House support, and I'm sure she plays a very important role," said Jane Alexander, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.
At the Agency for International Development, Brian Atwood, the administrator, said of Mrs. Clinton's grasp of complex development issues: "She understands these issues better than 90 percent of the people who operate within the foreign policy community."
Mrs. Clinton has been working with A.I.D. to import to inner cities lessons learned abroad, on child immunization, for example, and inexpensive techniques to combat diarrhea. She has taken a particularly strong interest in "microenterprise lending," or efforts in developing nations and troubled cities to lend small amounts of money for new businesses, often run by women.
It is no coincidence, Mr. Atwood said, that the Administration is seeking to slightly increase the budget for A.I.D. next year. "She deserves more credit for that," he said, "than anyone."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Banc One Seen in Deal To Acquire First USA
 Banc One is expected to announce today that it has reached an agreement to buy First USA, one of the fastest growing credit card issuers in the country, for about $7 billion, people familiar with the transaction said.
Banc One is offering about $52 a share for First USA, a premium of about 41 percent over its closing stock price on Friday. The deal would vault Banc One to rank third in the credit card market, after Citicorp and MBNA, with $33 billion in credit card loans. [Page D2.]
 
U.S. Wins Round in Dispute
The United States appears to have won an important skirmish with Canada over trade restrictions on cultural products like magazines. [D8.]
 
Energy Secretary's Valedictory
The price of energy is artificially depressed in the United States, Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary said on the eve of her departure from office, and Americans will not be serious about conservation until the price goes up. [B6.]
 
Mobile-Phone Use Surges in Japan
Japan has almost overnight become one of the world's fastest-growing markets for mobile telephones, with more than one million new subscribers signing up each month, or one every two seconds. [D5.]
 
End to Limits on P.X.'s Is Sought
The Pentagon may lift the last restrictions on what post exchanges can sell, arguing that small businesses near military bases, which those rules had been intended to protect, have mostly succumbed to large chains. [A10.]
 
High Technology's Rural Benefits
Some of the strongest Congressional advocates of communications technology come from places where the valleys are made not of silicon but of old-fashioned soil. They think that the information revolution may be the best hope for economic development in their rural districts. [D5.]
 
A Silicon Valley for Asia
Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, has visited Silicon Valley companies, asking them to join an ambitious, and similar, effort in his country. [D4.]
 
A TV Channel's Two Faces
By day, WBIS in New York dresses up with business-oriented programs from the domain of one owner, Dow Jones. By night, it loosens its tie to cover sports, the preserve of the other owner, ITT. [D7.]

Lights, Camera, Backhoe
After 40 years in which movie and television sound stages were torn down for real estate development, the Los Angeles area is at the beginning of a stage-building boom. [D7.]
 
Just Browsing? Sorry.
With programs called catchers, whackers, finders, savers and casters, a nascent industry is trying to create a new model for use of the Internet, replacing the browsers. Edward Rothstein: Technology. [D5.]
 
$1 Million Worth of Support?
If the three supporting stars of the NBC hit comedy "Seinfeld" get the $1 million per episode they are said to have asked for, the economics of the television industry could become more and more problematic. What, for instance, would Tim Allen, left, of "Home Improvement," be worth? Bill Carter: Broadcasting. [D7.]
 
Bond Market Is Closed
The Treasury bond market and most American banks will be closed today in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But the stock market and most commodity markets will be open.
